a. IMPERATIVE MARKER imperative (particle appearing at the end of a command; replaces final e of verb). ààkú ðaa go get it for me [a-à-ku aðee-a] (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). hápa púzeða! dry that corn! (FH). wiëîke líi tà, húu hce éa when Sonny gets back here, have him come over here. kusúðe a remember it [archaic; expected form is kusúða] (RBn10-5:JW). óëì hpíiëi ðìké, ókØà ðáalìhkí[ð]a don't get angry, have good ways (01/04/95/FH/pc). hkâàcezi ðiilóca peel the orange [from ðiilóce 'peel'] (RBn10-20).

a-. PRNM 1st person sg. agent pronominal ('I', subject of regular verbs).  

á-. LOC on, upon; for (locative prefix; sometimes has benefactive sense). [Retains accent.] níhkaçi nâhka çki álìì íisipe, ínahiëipe he didn't like to carry people on his back, he didn't agree with it (RBn10-2:MOJ/79).

••• Cf. álìì. 

áa. N arm. áa àðíxòpe they broke my arm (BE2.4; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 5: a arm; that part of the shoulder to and including the hand.

áace. V [reg., áa_ce] (trans.) climb, climb onto (by using the arms) (01/09/95/FH/pc). îpehi áace climb back on the pallet (BE2.20; RBn10-6:JW). îpehi áaca get on the pillow (crawl onto it) (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). hpôãe áace zì yellow climbing squash. ëìkáëì apa ëâà áaci apai the children are climbing a tree (RBn10-6:JW). • (trans.) embrace, wrap one's arms around.

•• LFD 7: <a´-dse> to embrace; to clasp in the arms with affection; to climb a tree. áace <a´-a-dse> I clasped in my arms. áðace <a´-tha-dse> you clasped in your arms.

••• Cf. walézeáace. 

áacexcì. V [reg., á_cexcì] (intr.) feel sorry for (lit., 'embrace indeed'). áacexcì I feel sorry for you (spoken to someone in pitiful shape) (FH/pc).  

áachi. V, ADJ [uninfl. or stat., áa_chi] (intr.) (be) sick with fever; feverish, running a little fever (RBn2-38; MREI/pc). áachi he's sick (MREI/pc). áachi nìkçé? do you have fever? are you sick? (MREI/pc).

•• LFD 268: áchì <a´-tsiæ> to be feverish. LFD 45: âchì <oæ´-tsiæ> I am feverish. áðichì <a´-thi-tsiæ> you are feverish. wachì pe <wa-tsiæ i> we are feverish.

••• QU hátØe to be sick, ill (RR), ëóhkahte fever, to have a fever (RR).

áadle (variant of ále).

áahkò. N armband (FH; HRE); muscle (LS) (not 'muscle' 04/19/95/FH/pc; HRE/12/29/01/pc).

•• LFD 12: áhkò <a´-Ðoæ> muscle of the arm (04/20/95/LS/pc:ok). áhkà ànie ha <a´-Ðoæ oæ-ni-e ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] my muscle is sore.

áahkòle (04/13/95/LS) (variant: áahkòla (BE2.11). N bracelet.  

•• RB: <áh-koæ-lah> (lit., arm put inside).  

•• LFD 13: áhkòhta <a´-Ðoæ-¾a> wrist band, wrist guard.

áahu. N wing. áahu saakí wing, the kind used in peyote meetings (lit., 'hard or firm wing'; in a peyote meeting, a wing is sent around after midnight so that everyone can fan off [RB]) (LS).

áahu saakí ðée hpaaãé I'm going to let the wing go; I'm sending the wing (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok). áahu ðée hpáaãe hta mìkçé I'm going to send the wing (BE2.159; 05/01/95/LS/pc:okc). • N shoulder blade (MREI).

•• LFD 10: áhu <a´-hiu> wings.

áahu htà. N big wing (LS); one who possesses wings. •• LFD 11: áhu htòi <a´-hiu-¾oæi> who possesses wings. A ritual term. [LF unconfirmed, 05/01/95/LS/pc: áahu htô or áahu htâ does not state possession.]

áahu mâðì. N turkey cock (LF only). •• LFD 10: áhu màðì <a´-hiu moæ-thiæ> wings walking; the turkey cock.

áahualìì. N angel (lit., 'wings upon') (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-moj/p3).

áahukØoe. N Holes in the Wings (personal name). áahukØoe kikØô kçíe hta apái Henry [holes-inthe-wings] is going to paint him (for burial) (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-moj/p21).  

áakxa. VP [ée 'say' + akxa CONT] they say, he/she says; they were saying, he/she was saying; they/he/she said (postverbal singular or plural marker of reported information deriving from person[s] who is/are present and not moving). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] óohò akxa tooská ðìké áakxa the cook says there are no potatoes (RRBn1-43). •• JOD (Devouring Mountain, p2, ln10): wahôiëìka bráanì na nâàce âpastòka ku káaãape áakxa ska <Wahªuæi§ciñ´§ka p¢a´hniæ-na´ nªan´§t§ce aæ§pastªuñ´§ka §kü §kaxa§pi, á akqa ska> the orphan that I devoured made my heart turn soft, he said.

áakxà (variant: áatkxà). V [uninfl.?] [possibly a contraction of áðiikxà] (intr.) lie down, as to sleep or rest. áatkxà mìkçé I'm lying down (FH). • (trans.) lie against; lean up against (FH).

áatkxa áëà lie up against it, lie on (e.g., a divan) (FH/pc). ••• Cf. áðiikxà.

áalake. V [reg., aa_lake] (trans.) be bothered or annoyed by, be irritated by; find bothersome (dn/fh980930; FH/11/19/01/pc). [Not stative; **ðílake is unacceptable.] áalake it bothers me, it irritates me, it's bothersome (03/01/95/FH/pc:pc). íixa çtà áalake her laughing all the time bothers me. íixa çtà áaðalake? does her laughing all the time bother you? (lit., 'you are bothered by her laughing incessantly?') (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). íixa çtà che wáali âàlakape her laughing all the time really bothers us (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). ••• Cf. waaláke, wáalake.

áale (variant of ále).

áalìì. N chair, seat (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). áalìì táahpa stool (lit., 'round chair'). áalìì wahéhe tòpéwai the chair looks weak (BE2.152; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 10: álì tahpa <a´-gthiæ da-¼a> round chair; a stool. álì sòsòða <a´-gthiæ šoæ-šoætha> a rocking. LFD 170: aliche aðalì <a-gthi-tse a-tha-gthiæ> you occupied the chair.

áalòðì (variant: áalòði). V [reg.+sync., aa_lò_ðì (first or second slot in verb may optionally remain unconjugated)] (trans.) forget; leave behind (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod; orig; FH/07/09/01/pc). áawilòbre ðààché ìké I'll never forget you (01/12/95/FH/pc). áalòbrì I forgot. áalòbri I forget. áðalòçcì you forget. áaðalòðì ðìké you didn't forget it (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.50). tooská áaðalòçcì ðalíe you forgot to bring back potatoes. áaðilòðì he forgot you (FH:5/02/96/prod). John akxa áalòðì akxai John forgets. âàðilòðì ðààché ìké we'll never forget you (FH:5/02/96/prod). àkáalòðì akátxa we forget (RBnot-nd1/10; 01/30/95/FH/pc:ok). áalòðì ìká ðì don't forget it [said to one person] (RBn10-7:JW). áaðalòðì ðìké! don't forget it! (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.50).

•• LFD 10: álòðì <a´-gthoæ-thiæ> to forget; failure to remember; unable to recall something that is past. áalòbrì <a´-a-gthoæ-bthiæ> I failed to remember. àkálò ðì pe <oæga´-gthoæ thiæ i> we forgot.

áalôðì (variant of álòðì).

áapa. REPORTATIVE [ée 'say' + apa CONT] they say or are saying or were saying; he/she says or is saying or was saying (indicates that information in the sentence is or was reported by another or others). níhkaçi apa wálì ókØà hpíiëi brî aapái people say I'm hard to get along with (RBn17-p02). níhkaçie tówa apa pâ apa áapa those people coming there are just hollering, they're saying (01/04/95/FH/pc:okc; FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). Carolyn apa wéðuãe aðeé hta apa áapai Carolyn is going to a wedding [they say] (02/27/95/JS/pc). wiëîke akxa waëáëeíe ípahò áapai Sonny knows Osage, that's what they're saying. màxpúmèì apa oðíchìpe aapai lightning and thunder are getting you [pl.], they are saying (line from a children's song) (FH).  

áape (variants: áapie [archaic], áap, éepe). REPORTATIVE [ée 'say' + api + ðe] he/she/they said, it is said, known by hearsay (indicates that information in the sentence was reported by another or others; often used in ceremonial speech and in storytelling). ëìkáëì çki cØéðe apa áape it is said that they are also killing children (RBn3-03). wahkôtaki nî áapie they said you were a doctor [expected Mod. Os. form of áapie is áape] (BE2.33). àkóðihkíepi áha, ðakØéwaðakíðe hta nìkçé áap when we talk to you, they said you would pity us. áwanòbre ðiiçtâpe, çtôpe çkôçta, ónòbre çki áëupi áape, waskúe çki áëupe they got the tables finished, do you want to look at them?; and they've even put the food on, they said, they've got fruit on the table, too (FH:prod). hcí hcéka ðiiçtâpi áape wahûe [i.e., wahôi] hta akxai they said that the new house is finished so she's going to move in (FH/06/20/95). hkiistó panáapi áape he adjourned the meeting, they said. tówa apa waachípi áape they said those men danced. taaké ðaaçé áape they said you were fighting (RBn22-19). wiçîke íe akxa áape they said he talked; they said he was talking. táatà ðáalì waðakçíe hta ðíe nìkçi áape they said you're the one that's going to make everything good for us (RBn22-02). íe ohkípçe nìkçí áape they said you keep your word. • as it is or was told or said (e.g., in a story or in the Bible). ìhtáci wahkôta, mâëà ðáalì ìkçi ðaníhkaçi nìkçí eepe our father, who art in heaven. hcí káaãi che éëi ípahòëi apa áape no one would ever know where she made her nest (RBn19-03).  ••• Cf. áapa.

áapiolà. N armband (HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok; RBn).

áatkxà (variant of áakxà).

ábro N shoulder (BE2.120; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). •• LFD 6: ábro <a´-btho> shoulder or shoulder blade; upper arm. [The gloss 'upper arm' is unconfirmed (MREI).] ••• Cf. áahu. 

áceðe. V [reg., á_ceðe] (trans.) build a fire on. •• LFD 7: áceðe <a´-dse-the> to build a fire on some place or object. áaceðe <a´-a-dsethe> I built a fire on (a stone). áðaceðe <a´-tha-dse-the> you built a fire on (a stone).

òkáceða pe <oæ-ga´-dse-thape> we built a fire on (a stone). ••• Cf. océðe. 

achí V [reg., _achí] [initial a is sometimes omitted in 3rd person forms and normally omitted in imperatives] (intr.) arrive here, come here (motion accomplished), reach as a location or place. achíe I've arrived. màðí ðachíe? did you come afoot? hâàhkaëi, oðíhta olîì achíe no, I came in a car (BE2.22). mîìoðaake çáhpe tà achíe I got here at six o'clock (RBn1022/JW&FW). ðáalì waëô, waðákitòpe ðachí che it's good, what you have done, to come and see us (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). ðáalì waëô, waðákitò ðachí che it's good, what you have done, to come and see us (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). ðachíe you [sg.] have arrived. hcéka ðachíe? did you just get here? (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). háatxàta waðákiçtòpaapi ðachí hta nàkxáaçe? when are you all going to come see us? [to more than one, seated]. ðachípe you have come; you've arrived [to more than one] (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). ðachíe ska you have been here before; you must have come here before (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). níhkaçíe achípe some people came. chí hta ðé? is he coming? will he arrive here? (RBn12-06). níhkaçíe tóe achípe some people came (01/06/95/FH/pc). achípe they've arrived; they have come. waëáëeíe àkáchipe we've come here to speak Osage (RBn23-01). àkáchipe we [three or more] arrived; we've arrived; we've come (RBn3-47; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.4). àkáchie we [two] arrived; we [two] have come. miðóhtà tà wanôbre chí pai at noon, come here to dine [pl. addressee]. miðóhtà tà wanôbre chí ði at noon, come here to dine [sg. addressee]. chípi tà íinòòhpapai íðaapi tà when they come be careful when you [pl.] speak (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

•• LFD 16: achíì to <a-tsi´iæ do> I have come. achínàëì <a-tsi´-noæ-zhiæ> came and stood. LFD 162: hci <¾si> [expected Mod. Os. form: chi] to come. achi <a-tsi> I have come. ðachi <tha-tsi> you have come. àkachi <oæ-ga-tsi> we have come. ðihtâke chi a(?) <thi-¾oæ´-ge tsi a(?)> has your sister come?

áðaace. V [sync., á_ðaace] (trans.) repeat or say again, call upon again, name again. [Unattested in modern Osage.] •• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p24, ln9): wíëìðé, waaðô che áðaata ðì hau <Wí§ciæ¢é, wa¢ªuæ´ tsªe á¢a§tá-¢iæ haú> Elder Brother, that song, repeat it.

áðahtaha. N (location) on the other side (FH:4/18/96/tape). áðahtaha ípçape àëi owáhkie apaëíe they went right past us [on the other side] but didn't speak to us (RB-MSB 4/7/83; FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). áðahtaha íðapçe you passed right by (FH:4/18/96/tape:prod).

áðasta (variant of ásta).

aðée (variants: aðíi, ðée, ðíi). V [sync., (a)_ðée] [initial a is often omitted, regularly so with 1st singular and 2nd person subject; this verb is rarely used in imperatives (màðî is preferred)] (intr.) go there (motion underway), set out for there, be on the way to there (RBn23-17). hpôhka htâwà ìkçi brée I'm going to Ponca City (01/31/95/FH/pc:prod). htáabre brée I'm going [big game] hunting (FH:ok). waachí abrée [initial a is unexpected] I'm going to dance (PM). ëâà akubrée na I'm going to get wood. ówehci ce brée hkôbra I want to go to the grocery store (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). howáìki çcée? where are you going? howáìki çtáape? where are you [pl.] going? waachí watôa çcée hta ðàìçé? are you going to the dance? çcée hta paaçé? are you [pl.] going? ilôìhpa howáìki ðée? where did Sonny go? (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). ilòìhpa akxa htâwà ki aðáape Sonny went to town (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.56-57). hkáwa alîì aðée iche he's gone horseback riding (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). çôke akxa htâwà kçi aðée apai the dog is on his way to town. hkáwa alîì aðáapi che they went horseback riding (01/31/95/FH/pc:plural). çîtoëi apa aðée ìké hta apai the boys aren't going to go (RBn10-2). oðíhtà olîì aðáape they got in the car and went (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). kahíke, mâhi htàà, éðòòpa nímàse aðáapi áape the chief and superintendent went abroad [it is said] (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). hcí hta aðáape they went into the house (05/01/95/FH:pd). mâàãe ðáalì tà, hóolà àkái hta àkái if the weather is good, we are going to go fishing (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). hkiistóhci ci àkái hce let's [two persons] go to the courthouse. sîka àkóce àkái hce let's [two persons] go squirrel hunting. húhekahci ci àkáðe ðálì we ought to go to the hospital. hòpái wanôbre àkáðape we're going to the dinner today (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). hòpái wanôbre àkái htai let's [three or more persons] go to the dinner today. opáwìãe àkái htai let's [three or more persons] go for a ride. ðíi ìká, wáaspa ði! [for ðée ðììká . . .] don't go anywhere, stay there! (FH). ààkú ðaa go get it for me (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). pée ðaaëî hta apai nobody is going (MSB02583). • leave, be leaving. çòðeðe brée hta mìkçé I'm going to leave for good (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). çäée ðáalì! leave! go on! (lit., 'you should leave') (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.78). çòðéðe aaðáape he left for good (e.g., when a husband leaves a wife, not to come back) (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). • go forward, set out, start off. kaðò tôpe aðáape he started off to see what he could see (lit., 'and he immediately went looking') (RBn15-03).

•• LFD 143: bréì to <bthe´-iæ do> [expected Mod. Os. form: brée] I am going. àka ða ì to <oæ-ga tha iæ do> [expected Mod. Os. form: àkáðape] we are going. ðée <the´-e> he went. ðekôðaëi <the-goæ´-tha-zhi> no desire to go. bréhkòbra màëi <bthe´-Ðoæ-btha moæ-zhi> I do not want to go.

áðibra (variant of áðubra).

áðihta. V [sync., á_ðihta] (trans.) go or be contrary to. wahkílaace áðihtà he violates the law (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 192: wáhkilace aðihta <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse a-thi-¾a> to violate [the law]. wahkilace aðihta <wa-Ði-gtha-dse; a-thi-¾a> goes-contrary-to-rule; to violate.

aðíi (variant of aðée).

áðiihtà (variants: áðihta, álihtà). V [sync., á_ðihtà] [á- LOC + ðiihtâ] (trans.) close by grasping. [Contrasts with áðiità 'close by pulling'.] okáhòpa áðiihta close the window (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). okáhàpa áðiihta, níiëu akxai close the window, it's raining.

••• QU ádihtà aim at something (RR).

••• Cf. waðíhtà.

áðiikxà (variant: áðììkxa). V [uninfl.] (intr.) lie down against; lean up against, recline, rest (FH:4/25/96/tape). kaatxá aðîìkxa aëîìhe hce let me just lie down and sleep a while. áðììkxa aëîìhe hta mìkçé I'm going to go lie down and sleep. aðîìkxa! aðîìkxa màðî! lie down and rest! go lie down! (e.g., to a child) (FH:6/25/01). áðììkxa ëîìhe màðî you'd better go lie down and sleep.

•• LFD 315: áðihkò <a´-thi-Ðoæ> to recline as when attacking.

••• QU ádikhà ithéde pull over [a sg. standing object]; make an upright object lean by pulling it (RR).

••• Cf. áakxà. 

áðiikxà ëàà. VP [reg., áðiikxà _ëàà] recline.

•• LFD 15: áðihkà ëà <a´-thi-Ðoæ zhoæ> to recline. áðihkâ aëà <a´-thi-Ðoæ a-zhoæ> I recline. áðihkâ ðaëà <a´-thi-Ðoæ tha-zhoæ> you recline. áðihkâ àëà pe <a´-thi-Ðoæ oæ-zhoæ i> we recline.

áðiità. V [sync., á_ðiità] [á- LOC + ðiitâ] (trans.) close by pulling; pull to; shut (RBn1-25). [Contrasts with áðiihtà 'close by grasping'.] hciëé áðiita níwahce akxa close the door, it's cold (01/09/95/FH/pc: ok; BE2.20).

•• LFD 15: áðitò <a´-thi-doæ> to pull over one, as a blanket; to shut, as a door. ábritò <a´-bthi-doæ> I pulled it over me. âkaðitò pe <oæ´-ga-thi-doæ i> we pulled it over.

••• KS áyaidà (MR) pull on (RR).

áðikØo. V [sync., á_ðikØo] (trans.) cover with earth; pull dirt over.

•• LFD 15: áðikØo <a´thi-Ð'u> to pull earth over some object. ábrikØo <a´-bthi-Ð'u> I pull earth over it. ôkaðikØo pe <oæ´-ga-thi-Ð'u i> we pull earth over it.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 15).

aðímà. V [sync., a_ðimà] (trans.) fasten. saakí açäíma you fastened it [tightly] (FH).

áðixope. V [sync.?, á_ðixope?] (trans.) honor. hôòpa ðé wéenà akxai ðe níhkaçi tóa áðixopape, hpáðì wéhkili íweeehkili ì kçíãape she's grateful today because they honored her, they dressed her [lit., 'made her clothe herself'] in Kiowa clothes (RBn23-17; cqc).

••• Cf. ðixópe. 

áðiëà. V [reg., á_ðiëà] (trans.) put s.o. to bed; make s.o. lie upon a bed; have s.o. in bed. John akxa Mary áðiiëà hîðokiëì John has Mary in bed naked (RB).

aðî. V [sync., a_ðî] (trans.) have, own, possess (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.64). mâzeska tóa açcî nìkçé? do you [sitting] have any money? mâzeska tóa açcî ðaìçé? do you [moving] have any money? (01/04/95/FH/pc). mâzeska háanà açcì ðatxâçe? how much money do you [standing] have? (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). mâzeska aðî ðe? does he have money? mâzeska aðî akxai he has money. mâzeska húuwaalì apai he has a lot of money. hîìce húu aðî akxai they have a lot of dishes. wahóohta açcî paaçé? do you [pl.] have guns? howé, àkáðì àkáe yes, we have them [guns]. níhkaçi apa hkáwa záani aðî apai all of them own a horse.

•• LFD 15: aðî <a-thiæ´> to have. abrî <a-bthiæ´> I have. àkáðî pe <oæ-ga´-thiæ´ i> we have.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 15).

aðîachi. V [sync.+reg., a_ðì(a)_chi] [aðî + achí] [initial a of achí is sometimes omitted in 3rd person forms] (trans.) bring here; arrive here with (motion accomplished). ëààníeëì awíbrìachíe I brought you some candy. ónòbre tóe açcîðachi hta ðaaçé? are you going to bring some food? (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). haxî wì açcîðachie? did you bring a blanket?

(01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). hâàhkaëi, haaskámi abrîachie no, I brought a shawl

(01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ónòbre háachi àðìchí apai they keep on bringing food. óðaake waléze aðìchípe? did they bring the newspaper? (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). táatà àçcîðachíe? what did you bring me? àkáðìàkáchie we [two] brought it. àkáðìàkáchipe we [three or more] brought it.

aðîaðee. V [sync.+sync., a_ðî(a)_ðee] [aðî + aðée] [initial a of aðée is often omitted, regularly so with 1st singular and 2nd person subject and in imperative] (trans.) carry. ábrìbree hta mìkçé I will take it (JS, 03/15/95/PM/pc:ok). haxî wî abrîbree mìkçé I'm taking a blanket [there]. mâzeska aðîðee? is he taking any money [with him as he leaves]? (RB). ópoce áçihta aðîðaa take the trash outside (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc). • take there (motion underway); take away (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok). wakØóëì wì màhkâ aðìðíi aape iiðáahpapi wait for little white woman carrying medicine (translation of the Cree name of woman who married into the Kaw tribe) (FH).

•• LFD 16: aðîðe <a-thiæ´-the> to take away an object. abrîbre <a-bthiæ´-bthe> I took it away. òkáðì òkaða pe <oæ-ga´-thiæ oæ-ga-tha i> we took it away (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok).  

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 16).

aðîahi. V [sync.+sync. h-stem, a_ðî(a)_hi] [aðî + ahí] [initial a of ahí is often omitted, regularly so with 1st singular and 2nd person subject] (trans.) take there; bring there (motion accomplished), deliver. ówe che hcí àkóhtapi aðîhi bring those groceries [there] to our house (FH). táatà aðìhi take something there, deliver things to someone (04/04/95/FH/pc:ok). wiëîke akxa haxî wì aðîahípe my son took a blanket over there.

•• LFD 16: aðîhi <a-thiæ´hi> to reach a place with some object. LFD 34: tátà aðì hi <da´-doæ a-thiæ hi> delivery of gifts.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 16).

aðîahu. V [sync.+reg., a_ðî(a)_hu] [aðî + ahú] [initial a of ahú is often omitted, regularly so with 1st singular and 2nd person subject] (trans.) bring here (motion underway). wiëîke akxa haxî wî aðîahu akxai my son is bringing a blanket here. abrîpçu mìkçé I'm bringing it there. ëâàxe wì aðìhú hta apai they're going to bring a board [for the baby] (FH:prod).

aðîakçi. V [sync.+reg., a_ðî(a)_kçi] [aðî + akçí] [initial a of akçí is sometimes omitted with 3rd person subject] (trans.) take back there; take home; bring back there; bring home (motion accomplished). wiëîke akxa haxî wî aðîakçipe my son took a blanket home, got home with it.

aðîaku. V [sync.+reg., a_ðî(a)_ku] [aðî + akú] [initial a of akú is sometimes omitted with 3rd person subject and in imperative forms] (trans.) bring back here. hcí hta ówe aðîku bring the groceries in the house. ðéekaa áðìku bring it here (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ówe che hcí hta áðìku bring those groceries sitting there inside (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). áðìku bring it back (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.12).

aðîalee. V [sync.+reg., a_ðî(a)_lee] [aðî + alée] [initial a of alée often omitted with 3rd person and in imperative forms] (trans.) take back, take home (motion underway); set out to take s.t. home, back (only in sentences showing completed action). aðîalaape they set out to take it home. abrîalee I took it back/home (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc). aðîðalee you take something back/home [aðî is unexpectedly unconjugated in this example] (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc). àkáðìàkálaape we took something back/home (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok). wáaðìlaa take this [back home] to them (2/3/84/080).

•• LFD 16: aðîle <a-thiæ´-gthe> to take something home. abrìale <a-bthiæ-a-gthe> I took something home. àkáðì àkala pe <oæ-ga´-thiæ oæ-ga-gtha i> we took something home.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 16).

aðîali. V [sync.+reg., a_ðî(a)_li] [aðî + alí] [initial a of alí is often omitted in 3rd person forms and in imperative] (trans.) bring back here, bring back home (motion accomplished). ëâà toa abrîalie I'm back with wood. ówe toe aðîìli bring some groceries back (01/06/95/FH/pc: prod).  

•• LFD 16: aðìli <a-thiæ-gthi> to bring something home. abrì ali <a-bthiæ a-gthi> I brought something home. àkáðì àkali pe <oæ-ga´-thiæ oæ-ga-gthi i> we brought something home.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 16).

aðîaëà. V [sync.+reg., a_ðîa_ëà] [aðî + áëà] (trans.) copulate with, screw, lay, have intercourse with. óëàke paskúha abrîaëà hta akxai I could screw her beside the road (RB).

••• KS áaëà lie on, to "lay," have sex (RR).

áðìchi (see áðîachi).

aðîðee (see aðîaðée).

aðìhé, áðìhé  (variants of àðìhé).

aðîhi (see aðîahi).

aðìhú (see aðîahu).

áðììkxa (variant of áðiikxà).

aðîkçi (see aðîakçi).

áðìku (see aðîaku).

aðìlee (see aðîalee).

áðìli (see aðîali).

aðîmàðì. V [sync.- reg., a_ðîmà_ðì] (trans.) take away. káache aðîmàðì take away this thing here.

aðóoha ADV again (RB, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 16 (unconfirmed): aðóha <a-thu´-ha> again.

áðubra (variant: áðibra). V [sync., á_ðubra] (trans.) spread upon; spread over (04/26/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 15: áðibra <a´-thi-btha> to spread oilcloth. [This verb does not actually imply

'oilcloth'.] ábribra <a´-bthi-btha> I spread oilcloth. âkaðibra <oæ´-ga-thi-btha> we spread oilcloth.

••• KS blá spread out, as dishes on the table (RR).

áðuãe. V [sync., á_ðuãe] (trans.) marry, get married to, take as a husband (gender-specific term). howaðéeçki áðuãe hkôbra ìké I don't want to marry anybody (RBn17-p02). wáçcuãe? did you marry? (FH:4/25/96/tape). Davea áçcuãe? did you marry Dave? (FH:4/25/96/tape:prod). Johna wáçäuãe hta ðaìçí aape they said you were going to get married to John. Dave áðuãe akxai she married Dave (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). wáðuãe they're married (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): waðúãe <wa-¢ü´-xªe> to take a husband, to marry.

•• LFD 204: wáðuãe <wa´-thu-xe> to marry; to take a husband.

••• QU ádiãe marry a man, take a man for a husband (RR); KS áayüãe marry a man, take a husband (RR).

••• Cf. wáðuãaëi, wáðuãe, wéðuãe. 

áðuuhta. PPN across. níi htâà áðuuhta brée hta mìkçé I'm going to go across the ocean (FH/04/08/01/pc). áðuuhta ðée go across.

••• QU dihté cross a stream (RR).

áðuuhta ðée. VP [sync., áðuuhta _ðee] (trans.) cross.

áðuwì. V [sync., á_ðuwì] [á- LOC (benefactive sense) + ðuwî] (trans.) buy for another. [Not used when the person benefiting from the purchase is present at the time of speaking; in that case kíðuwì (dative) is used.] ábruwì I bought it for him. áçcuwì you bought it for him. áðuwì she bought it for him. áàðuwì we bought it for him. áðuwì they bought it for him.

••• Cf. áwaðuwì. 

áðuzu. V [sync.?, á_ðuzi?] (trans.) pull over to cover; tug s.t. over in order to cover s.t. or s.o. (RBn3-23; cqc). omíëi áðuzu cover him with a blanket (as a person sleeping) (RBn3-23).

•• JOD (slip file): áðuzúpe <a´-¢ü-¦sü´-§pe> to pull the edge of a blanket, etc., over one, to cover him.

••• KS áayüzübe pull the edge over one, as a blanket (JOD, RR).

áãaake. V [reg., á_ãaake] [á- LOC (benefactive sense)+ ãaaké] (trans.) cry for. áðiãaakí apai they're crying for you (MSB). áãaake apai they're crying for her.

áha (variants: aha, ahá). ADV, CONJ whenever. mâzeíe ohkíe áha ohkíhkie akxái they talked [by phone] whenever he called (FH:prod; MSB). íiwiði áha owíhkie màëí hta mìkçé whenever I see you I'm not going to talk to you (FH/02/17/96/pc:prod). òkóðihkiepi áha ðakØéwaðakie hta nìkçé áape they said you would pity us whenever we talk to you (RBn22-01). ànâðapi áha awáhkie ðílàpe whenever they saw me they wanted to talk (MSB). • as soon as, immediately when; whereupon. çímiëì apa anâðapi aha óhkà apái just as soon as the girls saw me, they helped her. ànâðapi áha taaké apai when they saw me, they started fighting (lit., 'they saw me, whereupon they were fighting') (3/2/753/MSB). ànâðapi áha àwâhkie kôðape when he saw me, he [immediately] wanted to talk with me.

•• JOD (slip file): áha immediately after; thereupon.  

ahcí (variant: hci). V [reg., _hci] (intr.) camp, make camp. ààhcí htai let's camp [more than two people] (01/09/95/FH/pc:ma). ahcí apáiðe /hcí apáiðe they are camping (01/09/95/FH/pc:ma). ðéekaa ðahcí ðaìçé? are you [one person] camping here? (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn3-28). ðéekaa ðahcí paaçé? are you [more than one person] camping here? (BE2.16).

áhcihtà. N arbor; dance arbor; brush arbor (HH/pc). áhcihtà kçi àkái hce let's go to the arbor (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.4). dance

ahí. V [sync. h-stem, (a)_hi] [initial a is often omitted, regularly so with 1st singular and 2nd person subject] (intr.) go there (motion accomplished), come there, arrive there (03/20/95/FH/pc:prod). wahkôtaki ci pçíe I went to see the doctor (and he was standing up) (RB). wahkôtaki ìkçé pçíe I went to see the doctor (and he was sitting down) (RB). pçíe ðe I went over there (01/31/95/FH/pc:prod). haaská óce pçíe I went to look for a shirt (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). htâwà kçi haakôtà çíe? what did you go to town for? hcí wíhta ci çí hkôbra I want you to come to my house (T#14b- p2; (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.23). hòòpái hówaìki çíe? where did you all go today? (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). wanôbre ahípe he came over and ate (FH:4/22/96/tape). tookétà hípe it's summer (lit., 'summer arrived') (BE2.129). çímìëì okåla kôða apa, éehtana htâwà ìkçi pçíe the girls want some clothes, that's why I went to town (01/31/95/FH/pc:with éehtana, okc). wiëôa éðòòpa àkáhi sister and I went over there (01/31/95/FH/pc:prod) orig). miðóhta tà wanôbre híi ði come over and eat at noon [one person] (01/11/95/FH/pc:ok). wanôbre hí ði you [sg.] must come eat over there (RBn3-39). hcí ahí come to the house [implied: 'my house'] wanôbre hí paði you [pl.] must come eat over there RBn3-39). • be there; be in attendance; stop in, go by, come by. àkáhi hta àkái we'll be there (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.137). àkáhi we've been over there (RBn1-25). ðáalì, pçí hta mìkçé yes, I'll be there (said in accepting an invitation) (RB). àkáhi hta che we'll be there (said when accepting an invitation) (RB). pée na ahí hta ðé? who is going to be there? (MSB:02583). ahí hta apai they'll be there. táatà çäíità tà, hcí ci híðì when you get through with what you're doing, come by the house. • get (e.g., 'get old'), become (suddenly?). [Perhaps to be understood as 'arrive at (a state or condition)'.] wáali oðúucØake çíe you have really gotten lazy (lit., 'indeed you arrived at laziness') (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.77). nôò àkáhipe we've gotten old. hpáze ahíi tà when it gets evening (FH:4/17/96/tape). íçpaðo ahíipe all of a sudden, he became a Mexican (FH:08/05/99/DNpc; FH:okc). wáli oðúucØake çie you really got tired (e.g., responding to an invitation) (RB). • begin to, start to; suddenly start to. ãaaké ahíipe he started to cry. awâhkie çô akxa kaðò ãaaké ahíipe he was talking to me, then suddenly he started to cry (FH/8/30/94,prod).  

•• LFD 10: ahí <a-hi´> he has been to. ahílì <a-hi´-gthiæ> having arrived there I sit (a ritual expression).

••• Cf. híðe. 

ahíce (variant of híce). 

áhkiasàci. V [conjug. unknown] [hkik- RECIP + ásàci] (intr.) put each other to a test. ahkíasàcí aðìkçé we're putting each other to a test (RB, unconfirmed; (04/26/95/FH/pc:uk; PM: uk).

áhkie. V [reg., á_hkie] (trans.) talk for or against; talk up or talk down, as when expressing one's emotions with respect to some topic; take up for, argue on behalf of; take s.o.'s side (as an attorney at law argues on behalf of a client) (9/17/94/PM/pc; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.4).

áwihkie I'm taking up for you (FH:prod).

•• LFD 12: áhkiða <a´-Ði-tha> to contend as in a fight. áahkibra <a´-a-Ði-btha> I contend. ôkahkiða pe <oæ´-ga-Ði-tha i> we contend. áhkiða hce <a´-Ði-tha ¾se> defiance; to defy.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 12). 

••• Cf. íe áhkie, wáhkie. 

áhkiha. ADV beyond another thing (05/01/95/LS/pc/prod); afterward; following, next. áhkihà çi çkôçta if you want to, come afterward (FH:prod).

••• Cf. ihcóçpa áhkiha, ëìká owáhkihà. áhkihkaaspe. V [reg., á_hkihkaaspe] [hkik- REFL + ákaaspe] cover oneself up. áahkihkaaspe I'm covering myself (04/26/95/LS/pc; BE2.26).

áhkihkie. V [reg., á_hkihkie] [hkik- RECIP + áhkie 'talk for or against' (also used as transitive)] (intr.) contend with or compete with one another (01/11/95/FH/pc:ok). áhkihkie apái they're competing with each other. • (trans.) compete with. áhkihkie hkôbra ìké I won't compete with you (lit., 'I don't want to compete with you') (01/11/95/FH/pc:prodorig; BE2.23).

•• LFD 12: áhkiða <a´-Ði-tha> to contend as in a fight.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 12).

áhkihpa. V [reg., á_hkihpa] (trans.) encounter, meet (JOD; LF).

•• JOD (Wolf and Fawn p1 ln1): hcaléëe ozó ki áhkihpape ska <Tca-§k¢e§ce u§sú §ki ákipá§pe ska> he met Fawn on the lowland.

•• LFD 12: áhkihpa <a´-Ði-¼a> to meet another.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 12).

áhkihtòpe. V [reg.+sync. fortisizing stop stem, á_hkih_tòpe] [hkik- REFL/RECIP + átòpe (sometimes used as transitive with suus semantics)] (intr.) watch over oneself; watch oneself; look at oneself; look after oneself (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). áhkihtòpai watch out for yourself (MSB t2s2). áhkihtòpa look out for yourself. áhkihtòpape he looked at himself (MSB t2s2; 02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). íe áhkihtòpá ðíe watch your talk (BE2.151; 03/16/95/JS/pc:okc). áhkihtòpa ðíe watch yourself (admonition to a person who did something wrong).

waðilàekòìkí apai, dekôòci áhkihtôpa ðì there are crazies out there, watch out for yourself (FH:98/pc). taapóska çäée hta ðàìçé tà áhkihtôpa ði when you're going off to school, take care of yourself. • watch over each other. áhkihtòpapai you all watch each other, take care of each other (FH/07/09/01/pc). • (trans.) watch over things for oneself; watch over one's own things. wacúe skú ahkíhtoì hcé let me go look at my cake (e.g., while it's baking) (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc).

áhkiisto (variant: ahkíisto). N trial, hearing; legal proceeding (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.144).

••• Cf. hkiistó.

ahkílaðì (variant: hkílaðì). V [reg.+(sync.), _ahkila(_)ðì (optionally doubly inflecting in 1st sg., single inflection in 2nd person)] [hkik- REFL + aláðì] (intr.) carry oneself, conduct oneself, hold oneself or carry on in a certain way. ahkílaðì ~ ahkílabrì I will carry myself. ðahkílaðì you will carry yourself. waxpáðì ahkílabrì môëò ðéka I'll carry myself pitiful here on earth. wáli ahkíluhpíiëi àëi óðàëi ahkílabrì hta mìkçé I made a bad mistake, but I'll carry myself on anyway (RBn 5/3/79). wahkôta akxa eená hta akxa na, hpahâle mâì, ahkílaðì pai soon it will be only God, put him first, carry yourself that way (04/04/99/FH/pc). waxpáðì nà ahkílaipi carry yourself humbly [to two or more persons] (RB). wáðohtà ahkílae I behave myself (lit., 'carry my body good') (MF 11-19-83). wáðohtà mèè ikØúca try to make me behave myself (MF 11-19-83).  

ahkílì. V [reg., a_hkilì] [hkik- REFL + aðî (sometimes used with suus semantics)] (trans.) have for oneself; have as one's own. ahkílìaláape he took it home to have it for himself.

ahkílìalée. V [reg.+reg., a_hkilì(a)_lee] [hkik- REFL +aðî + alée (has suus semantics)] (trans.) take home for oneself, take home as one's own. wiëîke akxa haxî wî ahkí[ì]laaláape my son took a blanket home as his own.

ahkíliiçki (variant of hkilíiçki). 

áhkiòðe. V [reg.?, á_hkiòðe] [apparently contains hkik- REFL/RECIP] (trans.) meet; encounter; happen upon. áwihkiòðe I happened upon you in my life (9/4/94/FH/p.c.).

áhkita. N [shortened form of áhkihtòpe 'look after each other' (FH)] law enforcement; police; army, armed forces; soldier, armed person; officer, grenadier (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). áhkita wahtôka a soldier with authority (BE2.97; FH). áhkita apa ahú apai here come the police (BE2.105). áhkitamàì armed man (RB; PM/7/7/94; 03/10/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 11: áhkita <a´-Ði-da> officer or soldier; grenadier; policeman. áhkita hci <a´-Ðida-¾si> officer's house. áhkita ëîka <a´-Ði-da zhiæ-ga> a private (soldier). áhkita wahtòka <a´-Ði-da wa-¾oæ-ga> officers. áhkita wahtòka <a´-Ði-da wa-¾oæ-ga> an officer of high rank, a general.

áhkita nâàëì (variant: áhkita náaëi). N soldier (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

áhkita okØà. V [reg.?, áhkita o_kØà?] (intr.) conduct a drill; hold military maneuvers.

•• LFD 11: áhkita okØà <a´-Ði-da u-Ð'oæ> to drill; to engage in military exercises.

áhkita omâðì (variant: áhkita omáì). N armed forces; army, navy, marines (BE2.125; 01/06/95/FH; 03/13/95; 08/22/96).

••• Cf. áhkita nâàëì.

áhkita onâàëì waachí (variant of áhkitanâàëì waachí).

áhkita totâhàka. N officer.

•• LFD 11: áhkita totàhàka <a´-Ði-da do-doæ-hoæ-ga> an army officer of rank.

áhkitanâàëì waachí (variant: áhkita onâàëì waachí). N soldier dance. áhkitanáaëi waaðô soldier dance song (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125). ahkíhta onâàëì waachí soldier dance. áhkita onâàëì waaðô soldier dance song (lit., 'soldier song').

ahkíëàmie V [1st sg. of hkíëì 'be angry'] I am angry.

áhkiëi. V [reg.?, á_hkiëi?] [reflexive (hkik-) possibly from aëî] (intr.) think or feel oneself to be a certain way (?). líe ðáha óëo áhkiëi ðí aape when she came back she was proud of herself (RBn19-03).

••• Cf. óëo áhkiëì. 

áhkoopçe. V [reg., á_hkoopçe] [á- LOC + hkóopçe] (trans.) meet; encounter, run into. áwihkoopçe I met you (LS/prod: áwehkoopçe). áðahkoopçe? did you meet him? (05/01/95/LS/pc).

ahú. V [sync. h-stem, a_hu] [initial a is often omitted, regularly so with 1st singular and 2nd person subject] (intr.) come here (motion underway). pçú mîkçe I'm coming [sitting]. pçú àhé I'm coming [moving, shortened form]. pçú aðîhe I'm coming [moving, full form]. hcíhta pçú hkôbra I want to come inside (FH/prod). ðekáha ðahå? [unconfirmed irregular form; çú is expected instead of ðahå] are you coming over here? (7/8/94/PM/#98b). hôòpa hú akxai morning's coming. ahú apai they're coming (RBn14-06). çíi toe ahú apa some people of those are coming here (7/8/94/PM/#98b).  

aîpaxo. N copperhead (RBn HW13, unconfirmed); Arapaho (lit., 'over the mountain') (RBn HW13, unconfirmed).

ákaaãace. V [reg. kaa-ret., á_kaaãace] (trans.) cover over by spreading some material upon.

•• LFD 8: ákaãace <a´-ga-xa-dse> to cover up something. áakaãace <a´-a-ga-xa-dse> I cover it up. áðakaãace <a´-tha-ga-xa-dse> you cover it up. âkakaãaca pe <oæ´-ga-ga-xa-dsa i> we cover it up.

••• Cf. paaãáce. 

ákaahtami (variant of íikaahtamà).

ákaasìce. V [reg. kaa-ret., á_kaasìce; secondary accent on sî in inflected forms] [á- LOC + kaasîce] (trans.) close on; slam on. hciëé áðakaasîce you closed/slammed the door on it (FH; MSB).

akáaspe. N shade, blind, covering. okáhàpa akáaspe ðuumâçi raise the window shade.

ákaaspe. V [reg. kaa-ret., á_kaaspe] (trans.) put over, put upon. ëìkáëì haxî ákaaspa put a blanket on the child (RBn10-12:JW). • cover (as with cloth or blanket), cover with dirt (as a grave), cover over, cover up (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; 01/13/95/FH/pc:ok). áakaaspe I covered it up (01/13/95/FH/pc). áahkihkaaspe I'm covering myself (04/26/95/LS/pc; BE2.26). áðakaaspe hta ðáìçe? are you going to cover it up? (01/13/95/FH/pc). âàðakaaspe hta ðáìse? are you going to cover me up [with a blanket]? (01/13/95/FH/pc). haxî ákaaspa cover him or her with a blanket (e.g., when someone is sleeping) (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). níi ákaaspa cover the water (RBn HW). ónòbre ákaaspa cover the food (RBn HW).  

•• LFD 8: ákaspe <a´-ga-špe> to cover up an object. áakaspe <a´-a-ga-špe> I cover up an object. áðakaspe <a´tha-ga-špe> you cover up an object. ôkakaspa pe <oæ´-ga-ga-špa i> we cover up an object. ákaspe <a´-ga-špe> the falling of something heavy on a person or thing. ëò aðikaspe a <zhoæ a-thi-ga-špe a> did a tree fall on you? ëò àkaspe <zhoæ oæga-špe> a tree fell on me. ëò wakaspa pe <zhoæ wa-ga-špa i> a tree fell on us.

••• KS ágaspe cover completely (RR).  

ákaaëi. V [reg. kaa-ret.?, á_kaaëi] [á- LOC + kaaëí] (trans.) force over or through s.t.; order, command, or force s.o. to do a task, make s.o. do s.t. Mary iihô akxa ákaaëipe Mary's mother made her do that.

ákabra. V [reg. kaa-ret., á_kabra] (trans.) open, as one's eyes or arms. ììçtá ákabra open your eyes (RBn17-p04). hóçechíepi tà, ììçtá ápisài koe áa ákabra nâàke htaacéëì oðîìke ahú apai he was excited, with his eyes closed and his arms open he came running to catch Whirlwind (RBn17-p; cqc).

•• LFD 7: ákabra <a´-ga-btha> to open the eyes on something. ìçtá aakabra <iæ-shta´ aa-ga-btha> I opened my eyes on it. ìçtá aðakabra <iæ-shta´ a-tha-ga-btha> you opened your eyes on it. ìçtá òkakabra pe <iæ-shta´ oæ-ga-ga-btha i> we opened our eyes on it. LFD 77: ìçtákabra <iæ-shta´ ga-btha> to open the eyes. ìçtá abra <iæshta´ a-btha> I open my eyes. ìçtá ðabra <iæ-shta´ tha-btha> you open your eyes.

ákaha. PPN on top. ákaha álà put it on top [of it]. ákaha oolâàka put it on top [of it] (PM; BE2.143; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/22/95/PM/pc:ok). • N top, summit. paaxó ákaha the top of the hill or mountain.

•• LFD 5: ákaha <a´-ga-ha> on top of, on the outside. ápahta akaha aaëu ì ta <a´-ba-¾a- a-ga-ha a-a-zhu iæ da> I put them on the fence. ápahta akaha aðaëu ì ta <a´-ba-¾a a-ga-ha atha-zhu iæ da> you put them on the fence. ápahta akaha òkaëu ì ta <a´-ba-¾a- a-ga-ha oæ-gazhu iæ da> [ì ta is not used in Mod. Os.] we put them on the fence (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk). LFD 8: ákaha <a´-ga-ha> upon the brow of.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 8). 

ákahahpa. N vest (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 8: ákahahpa <a´-ga-ha-¼a> vest. ákahapa aki òbra achi mìkçe o <a´-ga-ha-pa agi oæ-btha a-tsi miæ-kshe o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I left my vest home.

ákahahta. ADV outside of a certain area; on the outskirts of, in the surroundings of; on the other side (of a perimeter) (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok). hcí che ákahahta anâàëì akxàhé I'm standing outside of this/that house (03/23/95/FH/pc). hcí che ákahahta ðanâàëì you are [standing] outside of the house (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc). • ADV afterward, after the present event; off the record, outside of the main events or activity and in secret; isolated from, socially distant from. ákahahta ahkílaðì ðíape he's keeping himself on the outside (03/23/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 8: ákahahta <a´-ga-ha-¾a> on the outskirts. ákahahta màðì <a´-ga-ha-¾a moæthiæ> a recluse. ákaha <a´-ga-ha> on top of, on the outside. hci che akaha hta anò ëi <¾si tse a-ga-ha ¾a a-noæ zhi> I am outside of the house. hci che akaha hta ðònò ëi <¾si tse a-gaha ¾a thoæ-noæ zhi> you are outside of the house.

ákahamì (Hominy form; variant: ákahami). N [ákaha + mî 'blanket, robe'] coat (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.21); cape.

•• LFD 8: ákahami <a´-ga-ha-mi> a coat; a long cape; a mantle.

ákaçke. V [reg. kaa-ret., á_kaçke] (trans.) tie to s.t.; tie up (as a horse) (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok). hkáwa ákaçka! tie up the horse! (04/26/95/FH/pc). hôòpa ókaaãeìke híe ðáha, oðíhtà ákaçkape when Saturday came, they tied him to the wagon (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). • (intr.) tie a knot (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok). àkákaçkape we tied a knot (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 8: ákaçke <a´-ga-shke> to tie a knot; to tie a scalp lock on a pole. áakaçke <a´a-ga-shke> I tie a knot. áðakaçke <a´-tha-ga-shke> you tie a knot. ôkakaçka pe <oæ´-gaga-shka i> we tied a knot.

ákazo. V [reg. kaa-ret.?, á_kazo] (trans.) inquire into, examine, inspect, probe, test by questions.

•• LFD 263: ákazo <a´-ga-šu> to examine. LFD 8: ákazo wahtòka <a´-ga-šu wa-¾oæga> to judge, the judge; one who inquires into.

••• Cf. wákazo. 

ákiãe. V [uninfl.?] (trans.) move around, be all around, encircle a place or a person (especially in an annoying way) (RRBn1-31; 12/30/94/FH/pc/ok). níhka ákiãe ðí áape that man is all around [bothering] her [they said] (FH/09/22/01/pc). • (intr.) be around, especially in a bothersome way. ákiãe ðàìçé you're bothering around (FH/09/22/01/pc). • (trans., intr.), pass by; circle around (as in a teepee meeting: 'go clear around', avoiding the center); (intr.) go table-hopping; table-hop; hang around, be around close; be arrayed around, as when making a path around; skirting the edge (such as cows around a pond). ákiãe apái they're around close; he's around the edges (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok; BE2.41; FH:4/22/96/tape:prod). hcí ákiãe akxái he is passing by [or circling around] the house [but now he is motionless and present as this sentence is spoken] (RBn10-7:JW, unconfirmed). hcí ákiãe apai they are hanging around the house, circling around the house (RBn10-7:JW; FH). • PPN around (e.g., the edge of a pond); skirting the edge of s.t. (HRE/12/29/01/pc:ã). hlaaskáëì ákiãe kîìkììeëì huuhtâà íiðape he saw many butterflies around the flowers (RBn15-03).

••• Cf. opáwìãe. 

ákihtòpe. V [reg.(+sync.), á_kih(_)tòpe] [kik- SUU + átòpe] (trans.) watch over, look after, look at (one's own things or people). ëìkáëì ákihtòpe watch that child [hearer's own child, or a relative's child], watch your child. • (intr.) watch over, look after, look at one's own. ákihtòpa ði you look at your own (MSB t2-s2; 02/22/95/FH/pc:okc).

ákitòpe. V [reg., á_kitòpe] [ki- DAT + átòpe] (trans.) watch over, tend (s.o. who is not a family member or not close).

•• LFD 354: ákitòpe <a´-gi-doæ-be> watch over someone. ákòze. V [reg.?, á_kòze] [á- LOC + kôze] (trans.) examine. hcéka ðiníe che ákòze hta akxa ska I guess he will examine you now (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.42).

akçí. V [reg., _(a)kçi] [initial a is often omitted with 3rd person subject] (intr.) arrive back there; arrive home, return there. ksí hta ðe? is he coming back? çeeðo akçí hta apai they're going to come back there [where you are] (PM/7/8/94; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 11: akçíe ðaha <a-ki´-e tha-ha> when I get home. LFD 141: ðakçíe ðaha <thaki´e tha-ha> when you get home.

akú. V [reg., _(a)kú] [initial a is often omitted with 3rd person subject and in imperative ] (intr.) come back here (motion underway). nåëu apa akå apai the rain is coming (RBn1021/JW&FW/77). htaacé hpíiëi apa akå apai a tornado is coming. àkáku àkáðe we're coming back (MSB 04-83-2). ðeekáaha kå come this way. kü ðíe, àkái hce come on [you], let's [us two] go. kåpi, àkái htai come on, let's [three or more persons] go (01/11/95/FH/pc:ok; all). óðaake waléze akå màðî go get the newspaper (01/10/95/FH/pc:okc, with kiu). ðékaa kå come here (01/10/95/FH/pc: kyu, kiu diphthong). hcíhta kå come in the house. • (trans.) get, fetch, bring, come here with. níi tóe akå mâðì go get some water [and bring it here]. óðaake waléze akå màðî get the newspaper [and come here] (akü here contrasts with ðuuzé 'get [from a specific place; take it]') (01/10/95/FH/pc). nâãe toa ðuuzá get [take] some ice (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). nâãe toa akå màðí get some ice (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). ààkå ðaa go get it for me (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). ààkå màðî go get it for me (this expression is preferred over ààkå ðaa: FH) (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.54).

•• LFD 51: kiu <gi-o> to come.

••• Cf. akçí.

akxa. CONT [often appears as akxai (from akxa + ðe DECL; ðe earlier characterized female speech)] continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 3rd person sg. or pl. nonmoving subject that is present with speaker (contrast apa). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] íxope akxai he's telling a lie, they're telling a lie. kôða akxa he's wanting it. wapúçka tóe nôpØì akxai they've got beads around their neck (RBn12-08). iiséwai, ëeká akxa ânàkØòëi akxái the hateful thing is that my legs won't listen to me (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; HRE:ok). íiðaëi akxá they couldn't see (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok/prod). ðe hpáata akxa hôòëì akxai those eggs are bad (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod, HP). níhce akxa he was cold. ìhtáci wahkôta akxa óxiða káaãi akxái God created this death (said at a peyote meeting). hòpái mâàãe ðáalì akxai today the weather is good (FH, PM). hkáwa akxa cØé akxai that horse is dead. kasîxci hóolà bree hkôbra àzi nuuëúëu akxai I wanted to go fishing this morning but it was sprinkling (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod. orig.). màãíwaapi akxai they're lying to us now. màãíàðe/màãíàðape we lied to him (MSB 3-83). waachí akxai he's dancing in place (MREI 1-14-82). tàhî akxai they are well [lying down or sitting or standing still and present]. ahí hta akxai he'll be there. • he/she/it is characterized by, they are characterized by [the immediately preceding word or phrase, which may be a noun phrase]. hîì hpíiëi akxa he has bad teeth. waðílà hpíiëi akxa they have a bad temper. iitáipi ókikxà akxai he's got a birthday.  

akxa. SUBJECT MARKER (follows a subject [sg. or pl.] that is not moving, including dead nonhuman animates [apa is used for dead humans] and is present with speaker or is an abstract entity; contrast apa). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] sitôì mâàãe akxa wálì hpíiëi aape the weather was very bad yesterday (RBn3-18). ðée akxa íihò hâàpa ókØà hta apai they're going to have something on Mother's Day. Christine akxa hóxpe òô îkçé? does Christine have a cold? (RBn3-55). kaxé akxa okúhpu akxai the creek is full (flooded) (RB; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; FH/09/21/01/pc:ok). • generic noun subject marker. hpéeceníi akxa ëúoka ðíðuuhpíiëi hta akxai whiskey is bad for your health (lit., 'whiskey will make your body bad') (JS). níi akxa opØâðe nàpé water steams (2-2-670). iihô akxa the mother [subject of sentence, if sitting or not moving].

•• LFD 7: çòke akxa hci che atôpe pe ha <shoæ´-ge a-ka ¾si tse a-doæ-be pe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] the dog guards the house. LFD 143: ðe akxa <the a-ka> this [person] sitting.

akxái (see akxa CONT).

ákØahúe. N south wind (BE2.125, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 11: ákØa <a´-Ð'a> the south wind. LFD 136: htáce akØa che <¾a´-dse a-k'a tse> south wind; south.

aláðì. V [reg.+sync., a_lá_ðì] (trans.) carry one's items; carry along one's items; carry or take one's own, have or take as one's own, inherit (02/27/95/JS/pc:okc). çímiëì apa haaskámi aláðì hta apai the girls are going to take their shawls (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok). alabrì hta mìkçé I will take it.

•• RB: <áh-lah-thiæ> have as one's own, inherit.

•• LFD 9: aláðì <a-gtha-thiæ> to have or to keep one's own; to inherit. môze ska alabrì <moæ´-še ška a-gtha-bthiæ> I inherited money. môze ska che àkálaðì pe <moæ´-še ška te oæ-ga´-gtha-thiæ i> we inherited money. LFD 34: tátà alaðì <da´-doæ a-gtha-thiæ> inheritance.

•• KS aláyì to have or keep one's own (RR); OM same as Osage (LFD 9).

aláðìðee. V [reg.+reg., ala_ðì_ðee] [apparently contains kik- SUU (perhaps irregular suus of aðîaðee; by phonological rule would be alîaðee or alîðee)] (trans.) take one's own. wióohòëì alábrìbree hta àhé I'm going to take my little cooking utensils (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok). ëìkáëì apa kasîxciëì páahà nàpé, taahpóska wábrìbree nai the children get up early, I take them to school (02/27/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.131).

aláðìku (variant: aláìku). V [sync.+reg.?, ala_ðì_ku?] [apparently contains kik- SUU] bring back s.t. that belongs to oneself, or come back with s.t. that belongs to oneself. mâà aláìku bring the arrow back [where he belongs (sic)] (RBn23-17c).

álaha. V [reg., á_laha] wear one's own; put on (as clothes, shoes, coats) (04/06/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 9: álaha <a´-gtha-ha> to wear one's own clothing. áalaha <a´-a-gtha-ha> I wear my own. áðalaha <a´-tha-gtha-ha> you wear your own. ôkalaha pe <oæ´-ga-gtha-ha i> we wear our own.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 9). 

álà. V [reg., á_là] (trans.) place vertically against (e.g., stick s.t. up against a fence); place on, put on (2-2-849).

ále (variant: áale). V [reg., á_le] (trans.) place an item upright on another item, set on (e.g., set a kettle on a fire). [In this verb, l is sometimes pronounced dl (áadle).] hpéece ále set it on the fire (BE2.119; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc).

•• RB: <áh-d-?-leh>.

•• LFD 9: ále <a´-gthe> to place on top of another in an upright position. áale <a´-agthe> I placed on top. áðale <a´-tha-gthe> you placed on top. àkála pe <oæ-ga´-gtha i> we placed on top.

alée. V [reg., a_lee] [initial a is often omitted in 3rd person and in imperative] (intr.) go back there, return there, go home (motion underway). hcí ce alée I am going back to the house (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). a[a]lée I return there. ðalée you return there. alée he returns there. àkále[e] we return there. çîtoëì akxa achípe àëi aláape, çí achíëi hta akxai the boy who came here left [just now] and he won't be coming back again. hcí ci àkále we are going back to the house. oðíhtà ci àkále hce let's go back to the car. aláape they went back. hcí ci àkále htai let's go home (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.58). haakôta Johna lée? why did John go home? alée hta apai they're going home [going to go home] (5-83-2). alée apai they're on their way home (5-83-2).

•• LFD 53: le <gthe> to go home. ále <a´-gthe> I go home. ðále <tha´-gthe> you go home. àkála pe <oæ-ga´-gtha pe> we go home.

 alí. V [reg., _(a)li] [initial a is often omitted in 3rd person and in imperative] (intr.) arrive back here; arrive home here; return here, come back, get back (motion accomplished) (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). wàkò alí hta mìkçé I'll come back quickly (FH). sitôì alí I got home yesterday. ëâà toa abrîalie I'm back with the wood (RBn23-16). mîìoðaake sáhta ci alíe I got back at five o'clock (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). ðalí tà hiiðáa take a bath when you come back (01/06/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.23). tooská áaðalòçcì ðalíe you forgot to bring back potatoes. háatxàce ðalíe? when did you get back? (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). háatkxàta ðalíe? when are you coming back? (a line in the turtle song [FH]). háatxà ðalí hta ðààçé? when will you come back? (T#14b-p7; 04/07/95/LS/pc:ok). záani çi lí apai you all came back (again) (RBn10-13). ðáalì huukôì ðalípe it's good a lot of you came back (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). ðáalìe huukôì lí apa che it's good a lot of you have come back (as I see) (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). nà háakxàci líie? when did she get back? (02/01/95/FH/pc:prod). nà háakxàtà líie? but when is she coming back? (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). wiëîke líi tà hú hce éa she asks you to send Sonny to her when he gets here. ðée lípi che çki wéewinai I'm thankful, too, for these who have come here (FH/10/13/96). alí apai they're back. alípe they came back. kasîta àkáli hta àkátxa we'll come back tomorrow (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; kaasî). àkálipe we came home. hpázewanôbre lí ði come back for supper. wiëîke nahkôì mîìake çáhpe tà lí hcea tell those two boys to come back at six o'clock. Homer mîìake çáhpe tà lí hcea tell Homer to come back at six.

•• LFD 9: alí <a-gthi´> returning. "This expression is found frequently when referring to the return of one who has been searching for some particular thing. It is a ritual expression."

••• Cf. akú.

áliha, álìha (variants of álììha).

álihtà (variant of áðiihtà).

álìì (variants: álì, áli, álii). V [reg., á_lìì] (trans.) sit upon. [In this verb, l is sometimes pronounced dl (ádlìi).] ðéeka áðalìì çkôòçta? do you want to sit in one of these? • ride on. níhkaçi nâhka çki álìì íisipe, iinâhiëipe he didn't like to carry people on his back, he didn't agree with it (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; RBn16-01). hkáwa álìì/hkáwaalìì ride a horse. • place upon (e.g., put a suitcase on a table). áwanòbre ádlìì put it [the suitcase] on the table (FH:5/02/96/prod). hpahâle níi che ádlìì hta apai they're going to set the water on the table (in a bucket or pitcher) (FH:5/02/96/prod). PPN upon (used in numbers). lébrà álìì hce wîìke nineteen (lit., 'nine upon ten'). N chair. [Takes  'standing' positional article che.]

•• LFD 170: aliche aalì <a-gthi-tse a-a-gthiæ> expected Mod. Os. form: álììche oálìì] I occupied the chair. aliche aðalì <a-gthi-tse a-tha-gthiæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: álììche oðálìì] you occupied the chair.

••• Cf. olîì.

álìì (variant of lébrà álìì in numbers between 'eleven' and 'nineteen').

álììha (variants: álìha, áliha, álììhai). V [reg., á_lììha] (intr.) excel; be above others, outstanding, excellent, as in making good grades in school. áalììha I excel (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

àkálììhape we excel (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok). • PPN after, past (RBn19-01). hpéðòòpa álììha akxa it's past seven o'clock; it's after seven (RBn1-17). mîìoðaake lébrà álììha tà brée hkôbra I want to go after ten o'clock (RRBn1-49). mîìoðaake lébrà álììha akxái/mîìake lébrà áliha akxai it's past ten o'clock (03/06/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.101). • ADV afterward. áliiha ékimà etxa eçkítà aha, ðíe ðáalì waðakçíe hkôbra afterward when I am done, also, I want you to make it good for them (RBn/FHok).

•• LFD 10: álì ha <a´-gthiæ ha> to exceed; to excel. áalì ha <a´-a-gthiæ ha> I excel (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok). áðalì ha <a´-tha-gthiæ ha> you excel (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok). wòkálì ha pe <woæ-ga´-gthiæ ha i> [expected Mod. Os. form: àkálììhape] we excel. álì ha <a´-gthiæ ha> excellent; excess.  

álììhceðe. N wheelchair. álììhceðe oðáha oðíhta owíbraha hang the wheelchair on and I'll follow your car (RBn; MREI/01/11/93).

álììscee. N [álìì + scéce] divan, sofa, couch, chaise longue (lit., 'long chair') (01/20/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.32).

•• LFD 10: alî scece <a-gthiæ´ stse-dse> long chair--a settee.

álòðì (variant: áalôðì). V [reg.+sync., _álò_ðì] [á- LOC + lôðì] (intr.) get drunk. kaakô çô ðaaçé, ðáalòçäi nana keep on until you get drunk (RBn2-moj/p28). áalòbrì hta mìkçé I am going to get drunk (RBn1-MOJ/p40; RBn2-MOJ/p27). áðalòçcî you got drunk.

áma (variant of âmà).

ámaxa. V [ reg.?, á_maxa?] (trans.) skin, as an animal; remove the hide from anything (RBn1016). • N Omaha tribe or person (RB, unconfirmed).

amâ (variant of âmà).

ámàðì. V [(reg.+)sync., á(_)mà_ðì] (trans.) walk on. níi çki ámaçäì áape they said you [even] walked on water (RBn23-17). • N water-strider bug.

•• LFD 105: niámàðì <ni-a´-moæ-thiæ> walks on water (04/06/95/PM/pc:ok).

ámàhta (variant: émàhta). ADV other way (lit., toward the other) (RB, FH). ámahta na hkilíihkoìãa turn yourself the other way. • N the other side (RB; BE2.146).

ámàhta hkilíikoìãe. VP turn around the other way; turn oneself the other way or to the other side; (metaphorically) begin to do right, mend your ways (RB). ámahta na hkilíikoìãa turn yourself around (BE2.146; FH:ok).  

ámàhtaha (variant: ámahtaha). ADV in the other direction, the other way, the other side.

ámàçi (variant: ámaçi). V [conjug. unknown] [á- LOC + mâçi] (trans.) be on top of or above s.t. else. ámaçi akxái he or she is upstairs (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.147). • place s.t. up or above. ámaçi hta mìkçé I'm going to put it up above (HRE/01/17/02/pc). • ADV up or up above, upstairs, in the upper part. paaxó ámaçi ki màðî go up into the mountains. ámaçi aðáape she went upstairs (RB; 02/27/95/JS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 13: ámàçi <a´-moæ-shi> upstairs. ámàçi bre ha <a´-moæ-shi bthe ha> [sentencefinal ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I went upstairs. ámàçi àkaða pe ha <a´-moæshi oæ-ga tha pe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] we went upstairs. ámàçiahta <a´-moæ-shi-a¾a> above; up there.

••• QU màçí upper, upward; heaven (RR), màçíde go up, ascend (RR), mâçi hí high, high up; incommunicative (RR).

ámàhta (variant of émàhta).

ámìce. V [reg., á_mìce] (trans.) crawl on, crawl upon. hpáaëì akxa ánaahkoe ámìci akxai the baby is crawling on the floor.

•• LFD 92: mìcé <miæ-dse´> to creep; to crawl on the hands and knees. ëà hkilé kçe ci amìce bre ha <zhoæ Ði-gthe´ ke dsi a-miæ-dse bthe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I crawled under the log.

ámò (variant: ámòì). V [1st sg. of ôò 'wear'] (trans.) I wear.

ánaaçile (variants: ánaçìle, ánaëìle). N stairs (BE2.126; 04/06/95/LS/pc:okc; 03/14/95/FH/pc:uk). ánaaëi (variant of ánààëì).

ánààhkoe (variants: ánahkoe, ánàhkò). N floor (T#38a-p2/38HH10). hpáaëì akxa ánaahkoe ámìce akxái the baby is crawling on the floor (RBn13-01). • porch ânààhkoe kçi àlîì htai let's sit on the porch (T#38a-p2/38HH12; 05/02/95/LS/pc:okc). ánààhkoe ci àkái hce let's [the two of us] go on back to the porch (RBn10-18; CQc).

•• LFD 13: ánòhkoke <a´-noæ-Ðo-ge> floor; porch. ánôhkoke ðalì wì abrì <a´-noæ-Ðu-ge tha-gthiæ wiæ a-bthiæ> I have a nice porch.

ánààëì (variants: ánaaëi, ánààëi). V [reg., á_nààëi] [á- LOC + nààëî] (trans.) stand on top of, be superior to in some quality (used in comparative and superlative constructions) (MSB). scécape, záani ánààëì he's taller than everyone else (lit., 'he is tall, he stands atop others [in tallness]'). • step on, step in. áðanààëì you stepped in it. mastósto áðanaaëî you stepped in mud (FH:4/24/96/prod). táatà hpíiëi wì áðanààëî ska táabrà ðàìçé you must have stepped on something bad, because you're smelling bad (FH:prod). îì wì áanààëì I stepped on a rock (BE2.127; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

ánàhkò (variant of ánààhkoe).

ánàkØò. V [reg., á_nàkØò ] [á- LOC + nàkØô] (trans.) listen to, heed (RBn10-6:JW). ánàkØò ðî [expected form: âànàkØò (from á-à-nàkØò)] listen to me [sg. addressee] (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn2-moj/p23). ánàkØò pi [expected form: âànàkØò pi] listen to me [pl. addressee] (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). iiðánahìmaëí mìkçé àëì âðanakØòëíe I objected to it, but you didn't listen to me. waaðáta tà áðinàkØô hta akxái pray and he will hear [listen to] you. • (intr.) listen. áðanàkØò, owíhkie aðìhé are you listening, I'm talking to you (RBn19-05). ánàkØòpi, íe tóa ékipçe hkôbra listen [pl. addressee], I want to say a few words (RBn23-17). ánàkØòò! listen! (05/01/95/LS/pc).  

apa. CONT [often appears as apai (from apa + ðe DECL; ðe earlier characterized female speech)] continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 3rd person sg. or pl. moving or absent subject (contrast akxa). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] ée ékiò apai he's doing it himself (RBn1021/JW&FW/77). kôða apa he's wanting it. óxpa apái he has just lost it (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; 04/14/95/FH/pc; RBnOT 2/10/83/p3). Meg apa çímiëì ðáalì apai Meg is a pretty girl (MSB 2/24/83). màðî alí a apai she's walking home (MSB 2-24-83). kahúuëà mâëà ðéka omâìpe he lived on this earth a long time (RBn10-13:JW): completed event, compare with: kaahúuëà mâëà ðéka omâì apai he lived [was living and moving] on this earth a long time ago (RBn1013:FH). màðî alí apai she's walking home. ðiskíke káaãe apai? are they making you tired? iihô apa óohò apai mother is cooking. óxpa apái ðe he lost something (04/11/95/LS/pc).

hóçechíepi tà, iiçtá ápisài koe áa ákabra nâàke htaacéëì oðîìke ahú apai he was excited, with his eyes closed and his arms open he came running to catch Whirlwind (RBn17-p). ðikØú apa he gave it to you as he was moving along (MSB 9-3-82). waachí apai he's dancing [moving through space, traveling horizontally]. háakòta wacúe skúe çpáase ðikôða apai? why did they want you to cut the cake? háanà óoëu apái? how many people have put in? (e.g., cans of food, as a contribution) (03/09/95/FH/pc). tàhî apa they [absent and moving] are well. • (following future/potential hta). áahukØoe akxa kikØô kçíe hta apái Henry [holes-in-thewings] is going to paint him for burial (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.101, RBn2-moj/p21). ahí hta apai they'll be there. • he/she/it is characterized by, they are characterized by [the immediately preceding word or phrase, which may be a noun phrase]. hîì hpíiëi apa he has bad teeth. waðílà hpíiëi apa they have a bad temper.

apa. SUBJECT MARKER (follows a subject [sg. or pl.] that is moving or is not present with speaker; contrast akxa). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] îì apa skíke apai that rock is heavy; those rocks are heavy (the rocks are being carried in this instance, therefore are moving) (FH/07/31/01/pc). hâàkòta çôke apa çkâkàða? why is this dog moving around so much? huuhtâka ohkíhkie apai, hcíle apa hípe a whole bunch of them were talking when the family came over (3/2/89/MSB). hkáwa apa okaxpápe he got thrown off the horse (lit., 'the horse threw him') (RBn19-01). iihô apa the mother [subject of sentence, if "up and around"] (2-1-50-2). wiëîke apa mâzeska ðìkí apai Sonny doesn't have any money [Sonny is absent]. • used for respect with deceased persons even if present (akxa is used with animals). çíi apa cØápe that man died (RBn22-17).

•• LFD 39: hkâace xoce apa cuuta pe o <Ðoæ´-dse xo-dse a-ba dsiu-da bi o> [sentencefinal o is not used in Mod. Os.] the plum is ripe.

ápahta N fence (BE2.46; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 5: ápahta <a´-ba-¾a> a fence; a stockade.

••• Cf. mâze ápahta.

apai (see apa CONT).

ápazo. V [sync., fortisizing stop stem, á_pazo] (trans.) point at, point to. ápazo! point at it! (RBn10-9:JW). çáake àwâpazo ðìká don't point the finger at me (said to the children by FH's mother) (01/24/95/FH/pc:prod). • select by pointing to.

•• LFD 5: ápazo <a´-ba-šu> to indicate, to point at; to select. áhpazo <a´-¼a-šu> I select. áçpazo <a´-shpa-šu> you select. âkapazope <oæ´-ga-ba-šu i> [expected Mod. Os. form: àkápazope] we select. ëâche áhpazo <zhoæ´-tse a´-¼a-šu> I point at the tree.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 5).

••• Cf. wéapazo. 

apaëi. [apa CONT + aëí NEG; contrast paëí].

ápe. N leaf (?).

•• LFD 288: ápe <a´-be> leaf or leaves. LFD 57: házi ape çtaha <ha´-ši a-be shta-ha> large wild grapes, with smooth leaves (02/03/95/FH/pc:uk, unconfirmed).

••• Cf. ëààpé. 

ápetxa (variants: ápetxà, ápetkxà). PPN around (e.g., house, tree, teepee, drum). • N wrapping; wrapper, covering wrapped around s.t. (LS/pc). V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) wrap or tie up.

ápetxa! tie that up! (RBn1-25).

••• Cf. ópetxà. 

api (variant: pi). SUFFIX [api + ðe DECL contracts to (a)pe; api + aëí NEG contracts to (a)paëí] pluralizer of 1st or 2nd persons ('we', 'us', 'you'). ëâàxe ànâchìpe we hit him with a stick. ónòbre wakØúpi apai we were fed, food was given to us (lit., 'they fed us'). ëîìhe ðáalì çkáaãapi? did you sleep well? (03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok). waðímòpi akxai he stole from you [pl.]. hôòpa háaëòpe? what did you [pl.] do today? (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). záani wanôbre hi pi you all come over and eat (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). wéeðinààpi akxai he's grateful to you all, he's thanking you all. záani wawíhòìpi I address you all as friends and relatives. waachí hí ëiiçô ðée ðe hpahâle hânahpaze oolâàpi wáhkôbra before the dances start, first I want you all [lit., 'them'] to put him in jail (FH/09/22/01/pc). John apa íiðiðe kôðapí apa nà, çoðée hpaaãé hta mìkçé John wants to see you [pl.], so I'm going to send him to see you (FH:5/01/96/tape119a). waðímòpi akxai he stole from you [pl.]. oohô ðiiçtâpe, àwânôbre htai the cooking is finished [lit., 'they finished cooking'], let us [three or more] eat. waachí ki çtáapáëi na you [pl.] never go to dances [çtáapáëi  from çcée + api + aëí NEG]. íiðiðapaëi akxai he doesn't see you [pl.]. áðahtaha ípçape àëi owáhkiapaëíe they went right past us but didn't speak to us (RB-MSB 4/7/83; FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). mâàhì wahúhka âkaëupaëí, mâzehcuka na àkáëupe we didn't put a knife or fork on, we just put spoons on (RBn3-49). táatà záani çcíiçtàpe? have you got everything all prepared? (lit., 'all things did you [pl.] finish?') (04/13/95/LS/pc:pl). çpáasape? did you all cut it off? (FH/11/17/01/pc). àwámaðòpe we [pl.] stole things (contrast àwámaðò 'we two stole things'). çi záani ðalípi hkôbra I want you all to come back again (RBn10-21). • pluralizer of imperative. çkáace màðîpi! you all go on and play! • pluralizer of 3rd person. wéenàpi they're thankful (02/03/95/FH/pc:prod) orig). pée kípàpaëíe  he didn't invite anybody (FH:ok, reconf; 5/12/83/rbnot D). • noncontinuative marker for 3rd person (sg. or pl.). ëâàãe ànâchìpe he hit me with a stick. tówa apa aðáapaëíe he/they [moving] didn't go [paëí < api + aëí] (2-1083-p2). nàniôpaëi wì kôðape he had wanted that "awhile back" (3-2-42[2]). • marker of predicative noun-plus-adjective phrases. hkáwa ðáalìpi nà he continues to be a good horse (RBn12-03p5). hkáwa ðáalìpe he's a good horse. níhkaçi wawîkçapaëíe she's an untruthful person (RB:MSB). kóe htáa htóhoëì wì pe once there was a little blue deer (RBn15-01). waachí hpíòpe he is a good dancer (lit., 'he knows how to dance'). níi akxa opØâðe nàpé water steams (2-2-670). oçpéëì nàlôòha apái ðée apa ahú apai óceçtàpe they're hiding their things because the people coming are snoops (or are always snooping).  

•• LFD 17: âkaxopapaëi pe <oæ´-ga-xo-ba-ba-zhi i> we desecrated it.

apíaapé [api + áape REPORTATIVE]. plural or 3rd person plus reportative: e.g., 'it was said of him/her/it/them/us/you (pl.)'.  

ápisà. V [uninfl.? (sync. 1st sg. **áhpisà and reg. or sync. 2nd sg. **áðapisà, **áçpisà are all unacceptable)] (trans.) hold down (e.g., a lid or a person); mash, push down on; shut, close (e.g., one's eyes) (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). ápisà nìkçé you're holding it down (02/24/95/FH/pc). hóçechíepi tà, iiçtá ápisài koe áa ákabra nâàke htaacéëì oðîìke ahú apai he was excited, with his eyes closed and his arms open he came running to catch Whirlwind (RBn17-p). ápise hta mìkçé tà aðáaapia I was going to hold him down, but he's gone (RBn10-5:JW, FH:okc).

••• QU ábisàhte [sync. fortisizing] catch by pressing on; hold down (e.g., on his back); lie on s.t. (RR).

ápçe. ADV around (e.g., pass around, give around, walk around). níi ápçe wákØue pass the water around (lit., 'give the water to them around') (03/16/95/JS/pc:prod; BE2.151). • V [reg.?, á_pçe?] (intr.) go around, circulate. húheka hpíiëi wì ápçe apai there's a bad sickness going around (RBn22-09).

•• LFD 14: ápçe <a´-pshe> to walk on, or to go from house to house [a more exact translation is probably 'go around']. ápçe bre ha <a´-pshe bthe ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: ápçe brée; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I go [probably better 'I go around']. ápçe òka ða pe <a´-pshe oæ-ga tha i> [expected Mod. Os. form: ápçe àkáðape] we go [probably better 'we go around'].

••• Cf. ípçe. 

ápuãe. V [uninfl.?] (intr.) boil, as food boils when cooking, foam up (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.10). níi ápuãe beer (lit., 'boiling or foaming liquid'; meaning 'beer' not confirmed) (RBn10-15).

•• JOD (slip file): ápuãe to boil, as water; to foam.

•• LFD 6: ápiãe <a´-bi-xe> the boiling of water.

ápuçtai. V [reg., á_puçtai] [á- LOC + pu- INSTR + çta (= çtáha)] (trans.) spread on (as shoe polish) (RBn23-05). wéli hòòpé ápuçtai polish your shoes (lit., 'spread grease on (your) shoes') (RBn23-05).

ásàci. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) put to the test, test s.o. (RB). ásàci apai they're putting each other to a test (MSB, RB; 04/26/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• KS áanàsàýe to stamp on something (JOD).

••• Cf. áhkiasàci, kasôci, opásàce. 

asíhpa. N baby sister (anyone's; can be used as vocative); baby daughter (anyone's; used vocatively by father and mother) (FH). [Does not use the inalienable possessive prefixes.]  

asíëì. N fourth daughter (and subsequent daughters).

•• LFD 6: ášì ëìka <a´-šiæ zhiæ-ga> special kinship term for the fourth daughter.  

asîka (variant: açîka). N third daughter (04/07/95/LS/pc:okc; 02/27/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 6: asîka <a-šiæ´-ga> same as <ši´-ge>. asîka akxa ìce luëa pe <a-šiæ´-ga a-ka iæ-dse gthu-zha bi a> little sister washed her face.  

ásta (variant: áðasta). V [sync.?, á_sta?] (trans.) stick to, adhere to. ónòbre akxa áwanòbre kçi ásta akxai the food is sticking to the table. áwanòbre áðasta akxai the food is stuck to the table (MSB 2-25-83). áwanòbre ásta akxai it's stuck to the table.

••• Cf. stáðe.

áçihta (variants: áçi, açíhta). ADV outside, outdoors. áçi tôpa look outside (RBn10-

21/JW&FW/77; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-moj/p31). áçihta alîì mìkçé I was sitting outside (RBn22-09). áçi brée hkôbra I want to go outside (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok). áçi àkáðe we are going outside (03/03/95/FH/pc:okc). áçi ðée! go outside! áçihta màðîpi you all go outside (as to children) (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.99; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 14: áçihta <a´-shi-¾a> outside.

áçihta wanôbre VP [reg.-awa, áçihta wa_nòbre] (intr.) picnic, dine outdoors. ónòbre àkáðì tà áçihta àwánòbre çkí ôò htai we have food, so we will have a picnic (too) (BE2.102; 03/07/95/FH/pc:okc). açîka (variant of asîka).

áçka. ADV nearby, close, a short distance away (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). áçkaëì lîìka sit right here by me (BE2.20). áçka ku come close. áçka mâìpai àëi oðáxpae hta ðaaçé [mâìpai < màðî + pai] stay close or you'll get lost.

áçka ci. PPN close to or near s.t. or s.o. tóosku káxa kçe áçka ci alîì I live near Spring River [sweet potato creek].

•• LFD 14: áçka <a´-shka> near; close by; short distance. áçka xci mòbrì <a´-shka xtsi moæ-bthiæ> I walked a short distance.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 14).

átaa. V [reg., á_taa] (trans.) freeze to; freeze sticking to s.t.

•• LFD 117: nâãe ata <noæ´-xe a-da> iciness; icy.

••• Cf. ótaa. 

átahkà (variant: átahkaì). N lamp, light. átahkaì ðuutáaëi turn off the light (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

átahkáì káaãa turn on the light (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.75).

•• LFD 7: átahkò <a´-da-Ðoæ> a light; artificial light. átahkòðe <a´-da-Ðoæ-the> a lantern [meaning unconfirmed].

••• OM <a-na-Ðoæ> (LF).

átahkà wéli níini. N oil well (lit., 'lamp' + 'oil' + 'spring, well').

•• LFD 7: átahkò weli nihni <a´-da-Ðoæ we-gthi ni-hni> oil well. átòhkò welì nihni wì mòëò ðòti abrì ha <a´-doæ-Ðoæ we-gthiæ ni-hni wiæ moæ-zhoæ thoæ-di a-bthiæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: átahkà wéli níini wì mâëà ci abrî; ðòti is not recognized in Mod. Os.; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] an oil well is on my land.

átòpe. V [sync., fortisizing stop stem, á_tòpe] (trans.) watch over; watch, tend, take care of (e.g., some entity, such as a baby or a purse, or some process, such as cooking)

(03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). wacúe çku áhtôpe brée hce I'm gonna go see about the cake; let me just go see about the cake (0109/95/FH/pc:prod). wacúe çku áhtôpe hce I'm gonna watch the cake (01/09/95/FH/pc: prod). átòpa! you watch! (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). átòpai watch it; look out for it (e.g., baby, purse) (MSB t2s2; FH; same as átòpe). níhkaçi ðe átòpa watch that man; take care of that man. níhkaçi pa wáatòpa take care of those men [standing or sitting]; look after those people. waátòpa! watch over them! [sg. or pl. addressee] (FH/08/01/01/pc [not 'us']).

waátòpapi watch over us (FH/08/01/01/pc). oohô átòpe tend cooking (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 38: áhtòpe <a´-¾oæ-be> I watched over him. áçtòpe <a´-shtoæ-be> you watched over him. âkatòpa pe <oæ´-ga-doæ-ba i> we watched over him.

átxà (variant: átkxà). V [reg.?, á_txà?] climb (by wrapping around?). hòbrîke átkxà ecí áape they said that there were beans climbing (FH/09/09/01/pc).

••• Cf. ápetxa.

áwaachi. V [reg., á_waachi] [á- LOC (in benefactive sense) + waachí] (trans.) dance for. áwawaachi I danced for them. âàwaachi ðíe dance for me. áwaachi! dance for him! áwiwaachi àtxâhé I'll dance for you.

áwaðilà. V [sync., áwa_ðilà] [á- LOC + waðílà] (trans.) meditate on, deliberate over, consider. áwabrilà I'll meditate on it (when one is asked for a favor, this is a more tentative answer than íbrilà).

•• LFD 17: áwaðilà <a´-wa-thi-gthoæ> deliberate, consider. áwabrilà <a´-wa-bthigthoæ> I considered it (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok). áwaçtilà <a´-wa-shti-gthoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: áwaçcilà; áwaçtilà is archaic] you considered it. âkawaðilà <oæ´-ga-wa-thi-gthoæ> we considered it.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 17).

••• Cf. íðilà.

áwaðuwì V [sync., áwa_ðuwì] [wa- VAL + áðuwì] buy stuff for s.o. áwahkie (variant of wáhkie).

áwanòbre. N table (RB). lîìka áwanòbre kçí be seated at the table (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok). áwanòbre hîìce áëu put the dishes on the table (02/27/95/JS/pc; RBn1-43; BE2.131; 02/27/95/JS/pc:ok).

áwanòbre aðibra (variant: áwanòbre haa). N tablecloth, any covering to spread on the table (e.g., oilcloth) (05/02/95/LS/pc:ok; FH).

•• LFD 17: áwanòbre aðibra <a´-wa-noæ-bthe a-thi-btha> oilcloth for table use, as a tablecloth [strictly speaking, 'oilcloth' is not part of the meaning].

áwaçi. V [reg., á_wasi] [á- LOC + waçí] (trans.) work for, accomplish a task or tasks for s.o.

(especially drumming for s.o. else's singing in a peyote meeting) (RBn1-12). áwawaçi hkôbra 

I want to ask someone to work. meeting

áwawaçi. V [reg., á_wawasi or áwawa_si?] [á- LOC + wawáçi] (trans.) ask folks to work for one; hire people to work for oneself.

áwaëìka nâàke (variant of éwaëì nâàke).

áwisi. V [reg.? á_wisi?] [á- LOC + wísi] (trans.) jump over (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.72).

áxa. V (trans.) beat s.o., as in a race.

••• Cf. káaxa. 

áxopaëi. V [áxope + aëí NEG] (trans.) desecrate, show dishonor to.

•• LFD 17: áxopaëi <a´-xo-ba-zhi> to desecrate. âkaxopapaëipe <oæ´-ga-xo-ba-ba-zhi i> we desecrated it.

áxope. V [reg., á_xope] (trans.) honor. àkáxope àkatxâi we honor that (RBn HW13; FH:okc).

•• LFD 17: áxope <a´-xo-be> deference; respect. áaxope <a´-a-xo-be> I respected it. áðaxope <a´-tha-xo-be> you respected it. àkáxopape <oæ-ga´-xo-ba i> we respected it.

••• Cf. ðixópe. 

áëamì (variants: ëaamí, ëamí, ëamî, ëámì). V [1st sg. of aëî 'think'] I think.

aëáëì (variants: ðaëáëì, ëáØaëi). V [2nd sg. of aëî 'think'] you think.

áëà. V [reg., á_ëà] [á- LOC + ëâà] (intr.) lie down. áaëà I'm lying down

(02/15/95/FH/pc:okc;conf áaëa I lie down ok). áëà áaëà pçíe I went to [lie down on the] bed (BE2.7; 04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ma 108-b/FH/200). áðaëà nìkçé? are you lying down? (FH/pc). • N bed. áëà kíkáaãa make up your bed (01/07/95/FH/pc:). áëà brée ðe I went to bed (01/07/95/FH/pc). áëàmàze an iron bed (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok).

áëà ëìka. N divan (LF).

•• LFD 17: áëà ëìka <a´-zhoæ zhiæ-ga> a divan.

áëàì ðuucØáke (variants: áëàkì ðuucØáke [RB]; áëaì ðuucØáke). VP [presumably from aëî 'think', originally áëàØì; Ø has been replaced by k in RB variant] (be) confused. ðée táatà áëàki brúucØake mìkçé I'm confused, I'm mixed up, I can't make head nor tails out of it (lit., 'I am unable to think something about that') (RBn10-21/JW).

áëàëì. N small cot (PM).

aëí (variant: ëi). NEG [initial a replaces final e of preceding verb; pl. negator paëí; 1st sg. negator maëí] not (negative, negator). bráamàëíe I didn't go [from brée]. pée ðaaëí hta apai nobody is going (MSB). tówa akxa aðáapaëie he didn't go, they didn't go (2-10-83-p2). tówa apa aðáapaëíe he or they [moving] didn't go (2-10-83-p2). kasî wanôbre aðîëipe he didn't have breakfast. waaðôaëi/waaðôòëi they don't sing; not singing, don't sing! mâàhì wahúhka âkaëu apaëí, mâzehcuka na àkáëupe we didn't put a knife or fork on, we just put spoons on (RBn3-49). waachí ki çtáapáëi na you [pl.] never go to dances [çtáapáëi  from çcée + api + aëí NEG]. íiðiðapaëi akxai he doesn't see you [pl.]. áðahtaha ípçape àëi owáhkiapaëíe they went right past us but didn't speak to us (RB-MSB 4/7/83; FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). níhkaçi wawîkçapaëíe  she's an untruthful person [wawîkçapaëíe from wawîkçe + api + aëí NEG + ðe DECL] (RB:MSB).  

•• LFD 17: âkaxopapaëi pe <oæ´-ga-xo-ba-ba-zhi i> we desecrated it.

••• Cf. ðìké. 

aëi hta. [aëí NEG + hta POTENTIAL MARKER] never will be, never will, will not. [No Osage word means simply 'never'.] ékòòëi hta akxái [ékò + aëí + hta + akxa + ðe] it will never be like that; it's never going to happen (02/27/95/FH/pc; BE2.92).

aëi nà. [aëí NEG + nà ITER] never. [No Osage expression means exactly the same thing as English 'never'. For the Osage equivalent of 'never' in future-time contexts, cf. aëi hta.] ëìkáëì wíhta waëáëeíe awákçuìze maëí nà I never taught my kids the Osage language (RBn10-16).

aëî (variant: aëákì [RB only]). V [reg.+sync. nasal vowel stem, (_)(a)ëa_ì (object pronominals in first slot, subject pronominals in second slot; underlying stem aëáì becomes aëî when no subject prefix precedes the ì)] (trans.) think or believe regarding s.o., hold an opinion of s.t..

áëamì/aëamî/ëamî I think. aëáëì/ðaëáëì you think. aëì he thinks. àkáëì we think. oëo áëì admire or think something or someone is pretty (RBn HW; cqc). oëo áëamì I think she's pretty (RBn HW;cqc). hpíiëi aëî hate someone (lit., 'think badly of'). cØéka wiëamî I think you're crazy (RBn23-20). ékò ëamí ìké I don't believe it (RBn22-05). ðáalì áëamíe, ðáëaëie? I myself think that's good, do you think so? (FH/06/27/01/pc). ðáalì ékò ëámì I think that's right (03/20/95/FH/pc). àkítàhé xci hta mìkçé áëamí I'm sure enough going to get better, I think (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc). âðihice akxai ëaamí/áëamí he's teasing me, I think

(03/20/95/FH/pc, both ok; BE2.138). háakò ëáØaëi [Ø is unexpected] what do you think of it? (03/20/95/FH/pc). ékò ëáØaëi do you think that's right? (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc). wáali ohtáza aëîpe he thought they were very beautiful (RBn15-01). ðáalì àaëì ðìkí apái he doesn't think well of me. níi táahpa ìkçí ëìka nôòðe ðáalì, ecíe ska ààëî àkátxa the pond is a good place to raise children, we think it's there (RBn19-04). hóo ðáalì açcî aëî àëi ohláaëi açäîe they think you have a good voice, but it isn't right.

•• LFD 129: hpíiëi aëì <¼i´-zhi a-zhiæ> to have a bad opinion of a person.

••• Cf. áëàì ðuucØáke. 

áëò (variant: áëòe). V [2nd sg. of ôò 'wear'] (trans.) you wear.

áëu (variant: áaëu). V [reg., á_ëu] (trans.) put out, set out (multiple items); place, array, display (multiple items) on top of s.t. else (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok, 03/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.31). áðaëu? did you put [s.t.] on top of [s.t.]? (MSB). wiëîke mâzeska tóa céãenii áëu áwakçie hta mìkçé I'm going to have my son put some money on the drum (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). hììcéëì áëu hta apai they're going to set out their crafts (as for sale).
