(FH:5/02/96/prod). hîìce áëu àðîìçtàpe we finished setting the table (RB, 03/09/95/FH/pc:okc). mâàhì, wahúhka àkáëupáëi we didn't put a knife or fork on (for each place setting) (03/09/95/FH/pc:okc). mâze hcúka éena àkáëupe we just put spoons on (03/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.109). hlaaská óxe áëu put flowers on the grave • pour s.t. on or over another surface; put a pourable substance on s.t. else (FH:). paaçcéka ëaaní (toa) áëu put some sugar on the strawberries (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok). pààçcéka ëààníe tóa áëu bríiçtà I already put some sugar on top of the strawberries (RBnB152). áëu he's pouring it on there (e.g., on a grave) (PM).

•• LFD 17: áëu <a´-zhu> to put a number of articles on a rack [actually, on top of anything, not just a rack].  

••• Cf. hcíwaëu. 

à-. PRNM 1st person sg. patient pronominal, used as object of active verbs ('me', 'for me', 'to me', 'from me', etc.). waléze wì àkçíãa write a letter for me; write me a letter; write a letter to me (HHtape; 18a). àkísue ði remember me. íixa àçkáaãe you make me laugh. ðâàce oâlìì he lives within my heart (04/04/99/FH/pc). óðohta àçkáaãe çäuucØáke you can't make me behave (MJ 1-19-83). nàniôpaëì àkôða apai a whole bunch of them wanted/want cigarettes from me (3-2-140). • 1st person sg. patient pronominal prefix, used as subject of stative verbs ('I'). âskike I'm tired. ëààníe âhòò I like candy  

à- (see àk-). PRNM 1st person dual or pl. agent pronominal ('we', subject). [This is the form taken by this prefix before consonants. It contracts with verb-initial i to form ànà.]

âà (variant of àhâì?). INTERJ yes (female speaking). âà, ékiò ðée hta ché okay, we'll do it [verb lacks 1st pl. inflection] (RBn17-p03).

ààðìhé (variant of àðìhé).

ààhé (variant of àhé). 

àðé. CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker for moving 1st dual subject 'we two' (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] wanáçe é[ð]òòpa àkále hta àðé Wanáçe and I are going home [the two of us]. • (indicating action or state continuing from past to present, corresponding to English perfect 'have been' or 'had been'). âðihkihtòpe àðé we've been looking after you. táatà wì àmâðòe àðé we two stole [have stolen] something. • we two are characterized by [the immediately preceding word or phrase, which may be a noun phrase]. wawéeðe hôòëi àðé we see poorly (lit., 'we are of bad sight') (RB). howáìki àðé wherever we [two] are (04/28/95/LS/pc).

àðìhé (variants: aðìhé, áðìhé, ààðìhé). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for moving 1st sg. subject (more emphatic than àhé). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] pçú aðîhe I'm coming. owíhkie ààðìhé I'm telling you [as I'm going along]. iinâ, áðìhe mother, here I am (RBn18-01). óðohta àhé I'm behaving, I've been behaving (FH). tóoska akØé hta aðìhé I'm going to dig potatoes (BE2.31; FH:ok). owíhkie áðìhé I'm going as I'm talking to you (MJ).

••• Cf. àhé. 

àðìkçé (variants: àðîkçe, àìkçé). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for sitting or lying down 1st dual subject ('we two'). ónòò àðìkçé we [two, sitting/lying down] are old (FH). âðihkihtòpe hta àðìkçé we [two, sitting/lying down] are going to look after you àëîìhe àðìkçé we [two] are sleeping [while lying down] (02/15/95/FH/pc). ëìkáëi wáaçäìka àðìkçé we kissed our children (02/14/95/FH/pc; BE2.73).

àhâì (variants: àhái(?), àhâ, âà). INTERJ yes (female speaking) (03/24/95/PM/pc:okc: ì). oðíhta hcéka wì çcúwì? did you buy a new car? àhái, wì brúwì yes, I bought one [woman speaking]. (BE2.162).

àhé (variant: ààhé). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for moving 1st sg. subject (less emphatic than àðìhé; action or state may continue from past to present, corresponding to English perfect ['have/had been']). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] kóoci açkàà ààhé I've been going on for a long time (MOJ). awápuçtaha àhé I've been ironing. pçú àhé I'm coming [unemphatic]. • I am characterized by [the immediately preceding word or phrase, which may be a noun phrase]. hîì hpíiëi àhé I have bad teeth (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc). waðílà hpíiëi àhe I've got a bad temper (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; (MREI/#95).

àìkçé (variant of àðìkçé).

àk- (before a, à, o, ò [and perhaps u?]), à- (elsewhere). PRNM 1st person dual or pl. agent pronominal ('we', subject of regular or syncopating verbs).  

àkáðe (variants: àkáe, àkái). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for moving, sitting, or lying 1st pl. subject. ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] ékò àkái we're like that (RBn17-p03). àkáku àkáðe we're coming back. • (action or state may continue from past to present, corresponding to English perfect ['have/had been']). àwâpuçtaha àkái we've been ironing. ëìkáëì háachi àkâàzà àkái we bawl the children out every time. • we are characterized by [the immediately preceding word or phrase, which may be a noun phrase]. hîì hpíiëi àkáðe we have bad teeth. waðílà hpíiëi àhe we've got a bad temper.

àkatxâ (variants: àkakxâ, àkatkxâ, àkatxá, àkakxá, àkatkxá). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for standing (sometimes lying down) 1st pl. subject. (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). waachí wáazo àkakxai we're enjoying watching the dances. àníe àkatxa we're all living (MREI/6/7/94/#94; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). àëîìhe àkakxái we [three or more] are sleeping [lying] (02/15/95/FH/pc). • imminent future action or state, regardless of whether subject is standing. kasîta àkáli hta àkátxa we'll come back tomorrow (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). mìðóhta wanôbre táatà àðáache hta àkátxà? what are we going to eat for lunch? (RBn12-07). záani àðáahtà hta àkatxâ we're all going to drink it (RBn10-21). àkóðuuxpaðe àkatxái we're going to take it out (FH/09/23/01/pc). omáìhka hcéka ðóha anâðe àkatxá we're about to see a new year (RB; cqc).

••• Cf. àtxâ, àtxâhé.

àkó (variant of àkóta).

àkóe (variant of àkóta).

àkóhta. PRON ours; our (belonging to two or more of us). mâëà akóhta our land (RBn22-08). hci àkóhta our house. • we ourselves (emphatic).

•• RB: <óæ-ko-tah> (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.99).

àkóhtapi. PRON ours; our (belonging to three or more of us) (FHt#128a). hcí àkóhtapi our house, the house belonging to us [three or more].

àkónà (variant: àkóna). V, PRON [àkó(ta) + na 'only']  [1st person pl. of eenâ 'be the only one'] (intr.) (be) only we. àkónà it is only we.  

 ••• Cf. ðínà, eenâ, wínà. 

àkóçki. PRON we also.  

àkóta (variants: àkóe, àkó) PRON we (emphatic), us (emphatic). àkóe ékiðaapaëíe [as for us] we don't think so (RBn15-01). àkóe àhpáahà àkái we're getting up; we're waking up (LS). àkóta çki we also. àkó çki we also.

•• LFD 132: àkoçki pe <oæ-gu-shki i> we also.

àkxàhé, àkxâhe (variants of àtxàhé).

âmà (variants: áma, amâ). PRON one of several; one to be chosen among many (FH). çkôçta tà âmà ðúuza if you want it, choose one (04/18/95/FH/pc). • other (one of two). áma htáha the other way, the other side (MREI, LS).

•• LFD 122: âmà <oæ´-moæ> one of two things.

ànìkçé (variant of àðìkçé).

àtxâ. CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for standing 1st dual subject ('we two'); may also be used for imminent future action or state, regardless of whether subject is standing (RBn10-3:MOJ/79; 1-1-65).

••• Cf. àkatxâ, àtxàhé. 

àtxàhé (variants: àkxàhé, àtkxàhé, àtxâhe, àkxâhe, àtkxâhe). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for standing 1st sg.

subject (MSB:t9). mâàãe akxa hpíiëi akxái, waaspé hta atxàhé the weather is bad, I'm going

to stay (RBn12-06). brúhcepe hta atxâhe I can handle it (RBn; MREI/01/11/83; FH:okc). súhka tóopa oowáhà àtxâhe I'm [going to be] cooking four chickens. çô àtxâhe I'm still standing. scéce akxâhe I'm standing here tall. íe àðánàkØò çkôçta ìké paaçé àëi iðáe àtxàhé you all don't want to hear me talk, but I'm talking (RBn10-16). • imminent future action or state, regardless of whether subject is standing. oðíhtà wì àðúwì àtxâhe we're about to buy a car [said while sitting] (MREI). mîìðohta wanôbre táatà àðáache hta akátxa? what are we having for noon meal?

•• LFD 133: çôahtàhe aðo <shoæ´-a-¾oæ-he a-tho> [expected Mod. Os.: tx rather than ht] I am still standing. çôðahtàçe <shoæ´-tha-¾oæ-she> [expected Mod. Os.: tx rather than ht] you are still standing.

••• Cf. àkatxâ, átxà. áwahkie. N lawyer, attorney (lit., 'taking up for a person').  

••• Cf. wáhkie. 

áwaëìka nâàke (variant of éwaëì nâàke). 

àëi. CONJ but. íe àðánàkØò çkôçta ìké paaçé àëi iðáe àtxàhé you all don't want to hear me talk, but I'm talking (RBn10-16). ékò brîe àëi ékò hkôbra màëí that's the way I am, but I don't want to be that way (FH). íhkihkawi hpáaãe àëi mâzeska brúuze mìkçé I exchanged it, but I took money (1/20/83/631; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). môëò ðáalì ðékçe môëò ðékçe ðìké hta aëi íe wíhta çòòçôðe aðée hta akxai heaven and earth shall pass away, but my word shall endure (FH:02/07/96/pc). • or. waaspé hta nìkçé àëi çäée hta nìkçé? are you going to stay or are you going to go? (BE2.127). áçka mâìpai àëi oðáxpae hta ðaaçé [oðáxpae is unexpected (rather than oðíxpae, from oxpáðe)] stay close or you'll get lost.

âëò ðìké. INTERJ goodness; my goodness!; I don't have the mind or nerve! (FH/pc).

 

 

brá (variant of brâ).

bráaða (variant: bráaðe [FH]). ADJ broad; wide and smooth, as a prairie; smoothed out (e.g., icing on a cake, a fabric or tablecloth lying flat on a surface, but not a blanket on a bed or pallet) (04/19/95/FH/prod).

•• LFD 28: bráða <btha´-tha> broad; wide.

bráaãe. N edge, edging (e.g., a fabric or ribbon sewn around the edges of a blanket or garment). haaská háabrehka bráaãe kaaãá put ribbon around the edges of the shirt [on the neck opening and/or on the lower edges and sleeves] (lit., 'make a ribbon edge on the shirt') (FH:4/22/96/tape: prod).

bráaska. ADJ flat (01/26/95/FH/pc:ok). wéeli bráaska a person with a flat head; a flat fish (perch) (lit., 'head' + 'flat') (01/26/95/FH/pc:okc; (BE2.49).

••• Cf. wacúe ðubráaska. 

brákØa. ADJ flat (FH).

•• LFD 28: brákØa <btha´-Ð'a> flat board.

brápxààke. N mosquito. [Pawhuska usage (RB).]

•• RB: <bráh-pxáh-iæ-keh, bráh-pxahæ-keh> (BE2.89, unconfirmed).

••• KS yáphòìge mosquito (JOD, RR).

••• Cf. lápxààke. 

bráze. ADJ torn (FH).

••• KS bláablaze torn in several places, torn up, chapped (RR), blaze torn (RR).

••• Cf. hcéze bráze, ìcé bráze, kaabráze. 

brâ (variant: bra). V [uninfl.?] (intr.) smell, emanate an odor, give off a fragrance. bra hpíiëi [it] smells bad (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). bra éëi it smells odd (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.124). wabrâlì brâ akxai he/she smells like perfume (RBn10-20). brà ðáalì it smells good. brà hpíiëi it smells bad. • N smell, odor, scent (03/02/95/FH/pc). bràðáalì a pleasing smell, a fragrance. bràhpíiëi a bad odor.

•• LFD 28: brà <bthoæ> odor; scent. brâ hpiëi <bthoæ´ pi-zhi> an offensive smell. bràðálì <bthoæ-tha´-gthiæ> fragrance; pleasing odor.

bréhka. ADJ lean, thin. wacúe bréhka pancakes, thin bread (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 28: bréhka <bthe´-Ða> thin. LF 187: wacúe brekxa <wa-dsiu´-e bthe-ka> [expected Mod. Os. form: wacúe bréhka] thin bread. wacúe brehka hkòbre <wa-dsiu´-e btheka Ðoæ-bthe> [expected Mod. Os. form: wacúe bréhka hkôbra] I want pancakes.

••• Cf. háabrehka. 

brì (variant: brîe). V [1st sg. of ðî] (intr.) I am, I was. ékò brîe àëì ékò hkôbra ìké that's the way I am, but I don't want to be that way (FH:08/22/96). waëáëe brî I'm Osage (RBn12-03). níhce brîe I'm cold. hâàpa záani wapúçtaha brîe I ironed all day (FH:prod). íkaski àhé I'm out of breath. íkaski bríe I'm out of breath [synonymous with preceding example] (FH). • I am characterized by (e.g., I have a certain condition). wawéeðe hôòëi brî I see poorly (lit., 'I am of bad sight') (RB). • I am present, I was present. howâìki ðòòpá ðáabrì náçki ecíe akxa tà, wíe ée brî hta mìkçé nà ée eçíe wherever two or three only are, I will always be [even] there, you said (Matt.18:20; FH:prayer). brîe I'm present (FH).  

bróka. ADV in bulk (e.g., a purchase of fruit, coffee, or kerosene); wholesale, in large quantities, overall, undivided; by the yard (fabrics); in large pieces, not merely pieces of some item but the entire item (cooking); in its entirety, fully, whole, entire, complete (FH/pc). bróka brúwì hta mìkçé I'm going to buy it [fabric] by the yard (rather than made up into articles such as shawls and blankets). watkxâ bróka oowáha hta mikçe I'm going to cook some squash (by cutting whole squash up in big squares, laying skin side of each piece on bottom of pot for first layer, then skin upward for remaining layers, and cooking it outside on a fire with maple syrup and margarine). hkâàce bróka brúwì hta mìkçé I'm going to buy the fruit in large quantities [not piece by piece]. bróka óðaake ìká! don't tell it all! (FH/09/23/01/prod). súhka bróka oohô! cook a chicken whole! (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.157). • N dollar. bróka sáhta five dollars (FH:ok; BE2.33).

•• LFD 28: bróka <btho´-ga> entire; a whole thing, a whole; a dollar; firm; solid; strong; hard.

brúbruãe (variant of ðibrúbruãe).

brúuska. ADJ flat, wadded up (crushed?). niikáapxokeooëu çtáaçtà tà, ðibrúuska when you are through with the pop can, wad it up (02/24/95/FH/pc).

••• Cf. bráaska. 

 

ce (variant: ci). ADJ last; the most recent (used of units of time). wíe, hâàci ówatòe pçíe myself, I went to a show last night (RBn3-25). htòòtâce htáabre çíe? did you go hunting last fall? (RBn11-02/JW&FW; HH/14-a/274ff). ómaìhka háaçi ecí the same place last year (RB).

••• KS dogéýi last summer (RR).

céãe (variant: hcéãe). N bucket, pail; kettle; pot (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.13).

•• JOD (slip file): céãe <¦t¦se´-xe> a pot or kettle.

•• LFD 161: hcéãe <¾se´-xe> kettle, a pot for cooking; a tin pail.

•• KS ýéeãe kettle (RR).

céãenii (variant: hcéãenii). N drum. [Takes 'sitting' positional article ìkçé.] céãenii ochî ðáalì çkáaãe you hit the drum good (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). céãenii ochî ðáalì káaãape he hit good drum for him (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). céãenii ochî ðáalì ìkçí áape he hit good drum for him (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). céãenii ochî ooláaëi káaãape he didn't hit drum quite right [not up to par] (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). céãenii okØóce ahí akxa the drum has a hole in it

(04/25/95/PM/pc:okc). ilôòçka céãenii war dance drum (04/25/95/PM/pc). céãenii kaaðéçpa hta apai they're going to give the drum away; they're pressing or pushing the drum over there [to another person] (BE2.36; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). hôòpa ðe céãenii kaçúpe hta apai they're paying for the drum today (FH:prod) 8/96). hôòpa ðe céãenii ðée káaãe hta apa? are they going to pass the drum today? (FH:prod) 8/96). céãenii ochî waaçkâpi aha ðáalì ché aha, ahú ókaçeìke céãenii ðée ìkçe whenever they're doing their best hitting the drum, when it's good, it's an untroubled, peaceful drum (RB; gloss by cq; céãenii non-preaspirated; BF/12/30/01).

•• JOD (slip file): céãenì <§t§se-xe-niæ> a drum.

•• LFD 161, 259: hcéãeni <¾se´-xe-ni> tomtom; drum.

••• KS ýéeãeyì drum (RR).  

céãenii aðî (variants: céãenii waðî, waðî). N drumkeeper (lit., 'he has the drum') (BE2.36).

•• RB: <tséh-xeh-ni ahæ-thíæ> (01/20/95/PM/pc:okc).  

céãenii ðée káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, _kaaãe] pass the drum (lit., 'make the drum go'). hôòpa ðe céãenii ðée káaãe hta apa? are they going to pass the drum today? (FH:prod; 8/96).  

céãenii káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, _kaaãe] tie the drum (lit., 'make the drum'; involves wrapping the drum up and tying it). céãenii káaãa tie the drum (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). céãenii saakí káaãa tie the drum tight (RB).

céãenii ochî. N drum boss; drumstick (lit., 'he strikes the drum') (01/20/95/PM/pc:prod; BE2.36).

•• RB: <tséh-xeh-nóæ-tsi> (sits to the right of the roadman in a peyote meeting).  céãenii ochî scée. N drumstick (lit., 'drum beating long') (RBn12-07; BE2.36; 01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). [Less preferred in this meaning than céãenii ochî (PM).]

••• Cf. ëâàxe céãenii.

céãenii waðî (variant of céãenii aðî).

céãeska (variant of hcéheska).

céãeëì. N small kettle.

céëe. V [reg., _céëe] (intr.) urinate. acéëe hkôbra I want to pee (RBn10-7:JW;

02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; FH:5/01/96/tape). (trans.) urinate upon. âðaceëe you peed on me.

•• JOD (slip file): céëe <t§se-ce> v. to urinate. 1st sg. <§¢at§sece>, 2nd sg. <a§t§se§ce>, 1st pl. <aæt§secapi au>.

•• LFD 350: hcéëe <¾se´-zhe> urinate.

••• KS ýéeëe urinate (RR).

••• Cf. äéëe, océëe. céëenii. N urine (RB; 02/27/95/JS/pc).

••• Cf. hkáwaceëenii. 

céëeniiooëú. N bladder.

•• JOD (slip file): céëenioëú <§tse´-§ce-ni-u-§cú> a bladder.

•• LF162: ccéëenioëi <¾se´-zhe-ni-u-zhi> urine pouch; the bladder.

••• Cf. ëé.

che. POSIT positional article for standing inanimate sg. nonsubject (also used for intangible entities: e.g., heart attack, song, pain). níe che húukaaãa pass the water. màhkásai ché this coffee sitting [standing] here. hcéka ðiníe che ákòze hta akxa ska I guess he will examine you now (lit., 'just now they'll examine your hurt, I suppose') (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). môçò che káaãa let the feather touch it (lit., 'make the feather stand upright [and thereby touch it]'). wacúe che ípasàì turn that bread over (FH). óohò che átòpa look after the cooking (RBn326). mîìihuðe che? is the sun coming up? (04/13/95/FH/pc:prod; FH:4/25/96/tape káache táatà waaðô? what kind of song is that? • positional article for pl. sitting nonsubjects (those that would take ìkçé when sg.). hòbrîke che hpahíke I sorted the beans (FH:ok). ówe che hcíhta áðìku bring those groceries sitting there inside (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). kachéðe there's something sitting there; there it [pile or stack of sitting/round items] sits (lit., 'that standing there') (FH). haxî hcéka che haaská wasúhu opétkxà wrap up those new blankets in a clean cloth (03/22/95/FH/pc). tooská che hkôbra I want the potatoes (RBn3-43). haxî che paaxcé tie those blankets up (FH). haxî kóoche opétkxà tie those old blankets up (FH). hcéheëì hówaìki che? where are the dishes [sitting]? 

•• JOD (slip file) ëà ðuhtâle che <§caæ ¢u-tañ´-§k¢e (tsªe)> an upright tree, a tree that still stands [not a log].

•• LFD 48: káche <ga´tse> this; this pile of things before us (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc). LFD 170: aliche aðalì <a-gthi-tse a-tha-gthiæ> you occupied the chair. LFD 175: aliche aalì <agthi-tse a-a-gthiæ> I occupied the chair. oscé che <u-stse´ tse> the rest that has been gathered and stands in a pile; the remainder; part of a number left over.

che. COMPLEMENTIZER that, whatever, until (links a preceding subordinate clause to the following main clause). táatà záani çkáaãe che ëaaëì? do you think you can do all of it? (lit., 'do you think that you'll do everything?'). ðáalì tâhe níkçé che, tâhe níkçé che ðáalì it's good [that] you are keeping well (05/01/95/LS/pc:okc). ðetkxâha haakô éepçe che ékò hkôbra from now on, I want it to be like [that which] I've said (03/22/95/FH/pc). wiëîke hâàpaska híi che? káanà ahí akxa Sonny, has daylight come? just a little bit (lit., 'like this [showing with hand]') (FH/09/24/01/prod). ðáalì ðachí che it is good that you [sg.] came. ðée lípi che çki wéewinai I'm thankful, too, for these who have come here (lit., 'I am also grateful that these ones have come back here') (FH/10/13/96). lâ aðée che iiðáahpe hta mìkçé I will wait until he goes away mad. taaké óhesaëi hi chí aapé the war is getting worse (lit., 'fighting fiercely has arrived there, they said') (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

che. EVIDENTIAL evidential marker indicating that speaker or addressee has circumstantial or sensory evidence (rather than witnessing) that the situation reported in the sentence occurred (can often be approximately translated as 'have/has/had already'). aalée che híe ðáha I had already left by the time he got there. wakØó akxa táakapi che that woman has fought; that woman did fight (FH:05/06/94). káaãapi che bráache mìkçé they had prepared it, and I'm eating it. alée che híe ðáha I had left when he got there. oðíhtà çkâà ché? is the car started? (FH:prod). okáhàpa kaaléke ché someone broke a window, that's the way it is (FH:01/07/95; LS:ok). ooðáhà che bráache mìksé you had cooked it and I'm eating it. owáhkà bríiçtà che achípe I had already finished helping her when they got there (FH:prod). aðée che híe ðáha you [sg.] had already left when he got there (FH/07/27/95/pc:ok). táatà záani ecí che? is everything there? (RBn12-11). óhkà ecí che? is there room over there? wiëîke hâàpaska híi che? Sonny, has daylight come? (FH/09/24/01/prod). táatà záani ée ecí che? is everything there [ready]? (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc; BE2.42). Jacka háakò eekíe che iiðáçtà I agree with what Jack said (contrast with Jacka háakò ékie tà iiðáçtà 'I agree with what Jack says') (FH/09/25/01/pc). íiðaapi ché they have seen it (RBn22-0). háakòpi ché? how did they do?; what happened to them? (RBn22-01). haçíhta apa ékiapi ché the ones before me said that (RBn22-01). hkáwa alîì aðáapi che they went horseback riding (01/31/95/FH/pc:plural). ëìkáëì apa omíëe wasúhuëi káaãapi ché the children have dirtied the rug (BE2.31). ëìkáëì apa hcéheëì ðuulékepi che the children broke a dish, they've done it, and they've left it, and it's there (FH/07/27/95prod). nàniópaëi kôðapi che she found out that he had wanted a cigarette. súhka htâà oohô ðáalì káaãapi ché the turkey was well prepared (RBn2-moj?/p2). káaãapi che bráache mìkçé they had prepared it, I'm eating it. hkáwalìì aðéei che/hkáwalìì aðáapi ché they have gone on horseback.

chí (see achí).

chúe (variant: chú). V [reg., _chu] (trans.) copulate with, have intercourse with, screw. ðalôçäì tà, çîtoëì apa ðichú hta apai when you get drunk, the boys will screw you (RB). nâàke wachú screwing while running (Buffalo clan personal name).

••• Cf. wachú. 

ci (variant: ce). PPN in. Johna táatà íiðe ðe watôehci ce? what did John see in the store? ecí akxa he's in there (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). ëâà cí olîìpe he lived in the forest (RB/16-02). Johna táatà íiðe ðe watôehci ce? what did John see in the store? súhka mâzeoohò ce oowáhà I baked a chicken (lit., 'I cooked a chicken in the oven') (FH/09/21/01/pc). • to (s.t. upright or vertical, sg.). oðíhtà ci àkále hce let's go back to the car (RBnB1-41). hkiistóhci ci àkái hce let's go to the courthouse (RBnB1-41). waachí ci àkái hta àkái we're going to the dance (RBn3-18). • at. mîoðaake sáhta ci alíe I got back at five o'clock (RBnB1-46; cqc: ì). mìðóhta ci súhka taazíhi àðáachape at noon we ate fried chicken (RBn3-02; cqc: ì). mîðohta ci súhka taazíhi àðáachape we ate fried chicken at noon.

••• Cf. ecí, ki 'in', kçi 'in'.

ci txà. PPN from.

cúða (variant of cúuða).

cúuce. ADJ done (e.g., in cooking); cooked (FH/07/09/01/pc). htáa cúuce káaãa cook the meat well done (lit., 'make the meat be well done') (01/11/95/FH/pc; BE2.24). • ripe, mellow, mature (e.g., fruit and grain) (01/11/95/FH/pc:okc). hkâàce xóce apa cúutape the plum is ripe, the plums are ripe (01/11/95/FH/pc:ok). • V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) cook well done (01/11/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 39: cúce <dsiu´-dse> cook done (well done). hkâce xoce apa cuuta pe o <Ðoæ´dse xo-dse a-ba dsiu-da bi o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] the plum is ripe. cúce <dsu'-dse> mellow; softened with ripeness.

••• KS ýåüýe cooked, burned, blistered (RR), waýåüýe mush (RR); QU títe(?) [transcription of original source is ambiguous] ripe, cooked (RR), watíhte mush, "boiled until done" (RR).

••• Cf. cúutaëi. 

cúuða (variant: cúða). ADJ ragged, torn, ripped (PM/03/10/95/pc); worn out, worn, insufficient

(said of clothing) (RBn22-17). áhkahamì wíhta akxa cúuða akxai my coat is ragged (RBn2217). ìléha wáli htàà akxai, híðaxa ðíhta akxa cúðaëipe his bottom is really large, your diaper is insufficient (BE2.14; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• KS ýåüya worn, of clothing, torn, ripped (RR).

cúutaëi. ADJ [cúuce + aëí NEG; c>t before aëí] unripe, green (e.g., unripe fruit); raw, uncooked, undercooked.

•• LFD 39: cutaëi <dsu-da-zhi> unripe or uncooked; applied to fruit.

cúxe (variant of kaacúxe).

cØá htâà. N devil, Satan. [Possibly a contraction of wécØa 'snake' + htâà, htâka 'big'; perhaps borrowed from English Satan.]

•• RB: <ts'áh-tah> (lit., 'big snake' [RB]) (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn10-5:JW).

•• LFD 157: cØáhtàka <¾s'a´-¾oæ-ga> Satan. "The Osage did not know the name of Satan till the missionaries came."

cØáaðe. ADJ sour (taste). paazéníi cØáaðe sour milk.

•• JOD (slip file): cØuxe <¦t'u-qªe> acrid, synonym of cØáðe <ts'á¢e> (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125).

•• LFD 157: cØáðe <¾s'a´-the> sour; like the taste of green gooseberries. LFD 19: paséni cØaðe <ba-še´-ni ts'a-the> sour milk.

cØáaëi. N [cØé + aëí NEG] cross; crucifix (RBn2-moj/p30; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok); clubs (suit in a deck of cards) (lit., 'dies not') (RBn10-21/JW).

•• LFD 157: cØáëi <¾s'a´-zhi> the cross, crucifix; clubs in playing cards.

cØáiëì. N husband (typically used by an older woman speaking to or referring to her elderly husband). cØáiëì wíhta my husband. cØáiëì ðíhta your husband. cØáiëì íhta her husband.

• elderly man (used by anyone referring to an elderly man).  

•• LFD 157: cØáke ëìka <¾s'a´-ge zhiæ-ga> an old man.

cØáke. N my father-in-law (used by a man addressing or referring to his wife's father; used by anyone referring to a man's father-in-law). cØáke ðíhta your father-in-law.  

cØé. V [reg., _cØe] (intr.) die (04/11/95/FH/pc:ok). hòpai haçíhta hóni acØé some days back I almost died (2/3/83/1/330; 01/20/95/FH/pc:okc). hóni àcØée we died (01/20/95/FH/pc:prod). hóni ðacØé you almost died (FH). hkáwa akxa cØé akxai that horse is dead (RBn22-17). çíi apa cØápe that man died [subject is present but deceased, hence subject marker apa is used] (RBn22-17). • N death; the dead, dead person. cØé çki çô ìkçe çcúhpaahà nìkçé aapai they said you raised the dead [pl. dead; lying down pl. positional article ìkçé] (RBn23-17).

•• LFD 157: cØe <¾s'e> to faint, to swoon; to die; decease; demise; defunct. ahcé <a¾se´> I faint. ðahcé <tha-¾se´> you faint. âhca pe <oæ´-¾sa pe> we faint.  

cØéðe. V [reg., cØé_ðe] [cØé + ðe CAU] (trans.) kill, slay, assassinate, murder; make die

(02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). cØéða kill it (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). hcéska wì àcØéðe htai let's kill a beef

(02/14/95/FH/pc:okc). ëìkáëì çki cØéðe apá aape they're also killing children [they said]

(02/14/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.73). hcéska wì cØéðe htai let's kill a beef (RBn2-moj/p6b; 02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). nàníòpaëi apa cØéði[ð]e hta apai cigarettes will kill you (RBn HW).

••• Cf. wacØéðe (sometimes with non-valence-reduced meaning).

cØéhkiðe (variant: cØéhkie). V [reg., cØe_hkie] [hkik- REFL + cØéðe] (intr.) kill oneself, commit suicide (BE2.73; 02/14/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 159: cØéhkiðe <¾s'e´-Ði-the> suicide; the killing of one's self.

cØéka. V, ADJ [stat., _cØéka] (intr.) (be) crazy; insane; demented; mentally retarded; mentally unstable (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok). cØéka ókØà ée ìká don't try any funny stuff; don't act the fool (BE2.27, unconfirmed; 03/16/95/JS/pc:uk). cØéka okØâ ékiò ðìkápi don't do crazy things; don't take crazy actions (RBn10-7:JW). cØéka wiëamí I think you're crazy (RBn23-20). záani ðicØéka paaçé you're all crazy (RBn23-20). cØéka nôò grown but no sense. cØéka ókØà ìká don't act the fool; don't try any funny stuff; don't act crazy (12/30/94/FH/pc/ok).

•• LFD 158: cØéka <¾s'e´-ga> to be crazy, insane, mentally unsound, demented; a dolt, a dunce, a crank.

cØéka ókØà. NP funny stuff, foolish acts. cØéka ókØà ée ìká don't try any funny stuff, don't act the fool.

cØélòðì (variant: cØelôðe) [cØé + lôðì] ADJ giddy; running here and there, not satisfied anywhere (RBn10-2:MOJ/79); dead drunk, excited, out of one's mind (FH/3/19/00).

••• Cf. páalòðì. 

cØéokØa (variant of hcéokØa). 

cØîða (variants: cØíða, cØí [LS]). N wrinkle (04/17/95/LS/pc).

••• KS cØîya frown, wrinkle the forehead (RR).

••• Cf. paacØî. 

cØìça (variant: cØîëe[?]). ADJ crooked, curved; bent over (as a person, a tree, or a hooked staff) (RBn10-5:JW; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.27).

•• LFD 209: wahléle cØíça <wa-xthe´-xthe-ts'-iæ sha> the standard made with a crook by the Osage and Omaha.

••• Cf. paacØî. 

cØîxa (variant: cØîxe). ADJ crooked, bent over (referring to a human body) (FH/12/16/94/pc; (04/13/95/LS/pc:uk).

••• KS cØîxa bent (may be long) (RR).

••• Cf. paacØî. cØóka ADJ droopy (FH/05/13/94).

••• Cf. ììçtáhaa cØóka. 

cØóxe. N hunchback (04/06/95/FH). cØóxe ëì little hunchback (personal name) [Gentnor Drummond's Indian name] (FH).

äáahpa. ADJ [diminutive of táahpa] short; rounded and somewhat squat; short and small. äáahpa brîe I'm short. äáahpa nìe you're short. ðiäáahpa you're short (FH; RBn105:MOJ/79). waaché wíhta äáahpa my skirt is short (03/10/95/PM/pc; FH:4/24/96/pc). iðáce akxa . . . äáahpape his father . . . is short (2-2-259). äáahpaëì. ADJ [äáahpa + -ëì 'little'] short and small. äéëe. V [diminutive of céëe] pee-pee.

äóopa ADJ, N [diminutive of tóopa] little, few; a small amount or number, a little bit. (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). mòhkása äóopa àwáëu pour me a little coffee (RBnB1-36). äóopa nàðe káaãe do/make a little at a time (FH/05/08/01:ok).

•• LFD 39: äópa <dsu´-ba> few; scant; not sufficient. äópanàðe káãe <dso´-ba-noæ-the ga-xe> to do or make a little at a time.

äóopa ekô káaãe (variant: äóopa káaãe). VP [sync. k>p, _kaaãe] lessen, reduce, decrease (lit., 'make small-like') (FH:prod).

•• LFD 39: äópa ekò kaãe <dsu´-ba e-goæ-ga-xe> to reduce the amount; to lessen. äóopaëì. ADJ, N [diminutive of äóopa] a very small amount; very little; a few (BE2.3). háazu äóopaëì che there are very few grapes. nii äóopaëì àkØú give me a little bit of water (02/16/95/FH/pc:prod orig; 02/16/95/FH/pc:okc).

 

ða-. PRNM 2nd sg. agent pronominal ('you', subject of regular verbs).

ðaa-. INSTR by mouth.

ðáabrì. ADJ, N three (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.140). ðáabrì paaçé? are there three of you? hîìce ðáabrì akxa there are three dishes.

•• LFD 140: ðábrì <tha´-bthiæ> three. ðábrì à <tha´-bthiæ oæ> three times; thrice. ðábrì à eci pçi e ðo <tha´-bthiæ oæ e-dsi pshi e tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: ðáabrì ecí pçíe] I have been there [better 'I went there'] three times.

ðaacé. V [sync., _ðaacé] (trans.) call on s.o.'s name; say the name of s.t. or s.o. wíbraacé I call on your name. • call, define as; assign a name to s.t. or s.o., use a name for s.t. or s.o.; say; pronounce (03/22/95/FH/pc:okt). "dog" táatà ðaatápe? what do they call a dog? çôke ðaatápe they call it "çôke" (RBn19-02). 'telephone' akxa táatà ðaatápe? how do you say 'telephone'? (lit., 'telephone, what did they name it?') (RBn10-9:JW; cq ok). ékò ðaacé! say it right! pée ðaacé hta ðé? who is going to name them? (2/25/83; PM/07/14 /94). pée ëáëe wáðaace hta ðé? who is going to give them names? (MSB02/25/83; PM/07/14 /94). táatà ðaatáape? what does one call it? (lit., 'what did they name it?') • read. waléze ðaacápe they read the book (FH/09/11/01/pc; not ch). bráace I read it (FH/09/11/01/pc).

•• LFD 140: ðacé <tha-dse´> to call as by name; to pronounce. bráce <btha´-dse> I call by name. çtáce <shda´-dse> you call by name. àðáca pe <oæ-tha´-dsa i> we call by name.  

••• Cf. láace. 

ðaaché. V [sync., _ðaache] (trans.) eat (03/22/95/FH/pc:okt). bráache I ate it (BE2.39). ðáacha! eat it! toa çtáache? did you eat some? tóa çtáache ðalì you ought to eat some. çtáace hkôbra I want you to eat it. mîìðohta ci súhka taazíhi àðáachape we ate fried chicken at noon. sinôbre çtáache nàpe? do you eat kidney? káache ðaachá eat this.

•• LFD 142: ðaché ðalì <tha-tse´ tha-gthiæ> delicious; good to eat. ðaché <tha-tse´>to eat. bráche <btha´-tse> I eat. stáche <sta´-tse> you eat. àðácha pe <oæ-tha´-tsa i> we eat.

ðaacØáke. ADJ, N leftover; uneaten; items one was unable to eat, leftovers (RBn22-18).

••• Cf. ðuucØáke.

ðáahlì (variant of ðáalì).

ðaahtâ. V [sync., _ðaahtà] (trans.) drink (03/06/95/FH/pc:okc; 03/22/95/FH/pc:tape; MREI). níi huuhtâ bráahtà I'm drinking a lot of water (03/22/95/FH/pc). màhkása bráahtà I drank coffee. màhkása ðé bráahtà hce I'll just drink coffee. táatà çtáahtape? what did you all drink? waðáahtà àkái hta àkái we are going drinking [boozing]. hkáwaceëeníi tóa àðáahta àkái hce let's [two people] go drink some beer. hkáwaceëeníi tóa àðáahta àkái htai let's [more than two people] go drink some beer (BE2.35). àðáahtà àðìkçé we [two] drank [it]. • puff, puff on, smoke. ðaahtâ puff on it (RBn10-21). nàníòpaëì tóopa ðaahtâà smoke [lit., 'drink'] four cigarettes (RBn10-3:MOJ/79, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 142: ðahtâ <tha-¾oæ´> to drink. bráhtà <btha´-¾oæ> I drink. hpéëe màhkà sae brahtà <¼e´-zhe moæ-Ðoæ ša-e btha-¾oæ> I drink tea.

••• Cf. waðáahtà. 

ðaakØî (variant: ðaakØí). V [sync., _ðaakØì] (intr.) spit. àðáakØìpe we spit. • (trans.) spit on, spit out (MSB 5/83/p1). àðáakØì ìká ði don't spit on me.

•• LFD 334: ðakØi <tha-Ð'i> to spit.

ðáalì (variant: ðáahlì, ðâàlì). ADJ, V [stat., _ðaalì] (be) good. ðáalì húukôì ðalípe it's good a lot of you came back (said at War Dances to welcome public and dancers). • feel good about s.t., be glad; thank you. àðáalì I feel good; I'm glad; I like it; thank you (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.59). • ADJ fine, splendid, pretty, beautiful, handsome; good (e.g., the weather). ëîkáëì ðáalì beautiful children. çímiëì ðáalì a pretty girl. hci ðáalì a fine house. hâàpa ðé akxa ðáalìëi akxai it's not a pretty day today (lit., 'this day is not good'; i.e., the weather is not good today) (FH/10/13/96). • ADV well, finely, skillfully. súhkahtàà oohô ðáalì káaãapi ché the turkey was well-prepared (lit., 'they did well the cooking of the turkey, apparently').  

•• JOD (slip file): ðálì <¢a´-k¢iæ> good, to be good.

••• Cf. ðálì. 

ðáalì (variant of ðálì).

ðáalì káaãe (variant: ðâàlì káaãe). VP [sync. k>p, ðáalì _kaaãe] (intr.) be successful; do good works, do good (lit., 'do well'). háakò ówòe che ðâalì çkáaãe you were successful with what you set out to do (lit., 'whatever you undertook, that you did well') (FH/pc). wahkôta iiëîke íe oðáha çí aha, ðáalì çkaaãé whenever you follow Jesus' teachings, you will do good works.  

ðáalì kçíðe (variant: ðâàlì kçíðe). VP [reg., ðáalì _kçíðe] achieve success for s.o., make s.o. successful. háakò ówòe çí che, ðáalì ðikçí[ð]aáape they did for you what you set out to accomplish; you were successful due to their efforts (lit., 'whatever you went there to undertake, they did it well for you') (FH/pc).

ðáalìhkiðe. V [reg., ðáalìhki_ðe] make oneself good (e.g., with respect to one's behavior). óëì hpíiëi ðìké, ókØà ðáalìhkí[ð]a don't get angry, have good ways (01/04/95/FH/pc).

ðaanîì (variant: ðaaníi, nîì). V [sync., _ðaanìì] (trans.) consume; eat up or drink up, devour. súhka záani ðaanîìpe he ate [consumed] all the chicken (FH07/31/01:ok). ðaanîì ði drink it up (RBn22-09). màhkása àðáanìpé we drank all the coffee (RBn23-17). màhkása çtáanie you drank all the coffee up (RBn23-17). súhka záani abráanìì I ate all the chicken (FH). màhkása bráanie I drank all the coffee up (RBn23-17). hpáze wanôbre nîìpe? did you all eat supper?

ðaaçcúe. V [sync., _ðaaçcúe] (trans.) swallow (food or drink). bráaçcue hta mìkçé I'm going to swallow it (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.130).

ðaaçé (variant of ðaìçé).

ðaaçkíke. V [sync., _ðaaçkíke] (trans.) chew. mîìihtôili bráaçkike I'm chewing this gum (RB; 01/24/95/FH/pc:prod).

ðaaçóe. V [sync., _ðaaçóe] [ðaa- INSTR + çóce] (trans.) smoke (e.g., tobacco); suck. nàníòpa ðaaçóe tà if he smokes tobacco.

ðaaçtápe. V [sync., _ðaaçtape] (trans.) lick. çôke akxa hîìce ðaaçtápe akxái the dog is licking the plate (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn2-moj/p22).

•• LFD 140: ðastápe <tha-šta´-be> to taste; to lick, as sugar off a cookie. brástape <btha´-šta-be> I tasted it. àðástapa pe <oæ-tha´-šta-ba i> we tasted it.

ðaaçtâ. V [sync., _ðaaçtâ] (trans., intr.) finish eating or drinking (from). [Appropriate for men or women, but more likely to be used by women than by men; according to some sources men are more likely to use ðiiçtâ (RB, HRE, FH).] bráaçtà I'm finished (eating). niikáapxokeooëu çtáaçtà tà, ðibrúuska when you are through with the pop can, wad it up (02/24/95/FH/pc, HRE/12/29/01/pc). • (trans.) end or stop an activity involving the mouth (LS). ãaaké ðaaçtâà! stop crying! (HH; LS).

•• LFD 141: ðaçtâ <tha-shtoæ´> to stop whatever one is doing; used as a command. braçtâ <btha-shtoæ´> I stopped crying. àðáçtà pe <oæ-tha´-shtoæ i> we stop crying.

ðaawá. V [sync., _ðaawá] (intr.) count (LS, FH). ðaawá! count, say the numbers! (FH). • (trans.) count out; measure. ðaawá count it out (or measure it) (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ðaawáða hkôbra I want you to count it/them out (e.g., coins, beads). (01/13/95/FH/pc). wáðaawa count them (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.26). waëîkake wáðaawa count the birds.

••• Cf. waðáawa, ëâà wéðaawa.

ðaaxô. V [sync., _ðaaxô] (trans.) break by mouth; break by biting or with the mouth. ðaaxôpe he bit it and broke it.

••• Cf. ðaaxôke.

ðaaxôke. V [sync., _ðaaxôke] (trans.) break into pieces by mouth; chew; chew into pieces, bite into small pieces. nâãe ðaaxôke çò akxái, hi ðixôkape while he was chewing ice, he broke his tooth.

ðaaxtáke V [sync., _ðaaxtáke] (trans.) bite (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn10-2). wécØa akxa ðíðaaxtake hta akxai a snake is going to bite you (in a generic sense: e.g., 'snakes bite' or 'what snakes do is bite') (FH/09/25/01/prod).

•• LFD 142: ðaxtáke <tha-xta´-ge> to bite. bráxtake <btha´-xta-ge> I bite. çtáxtake <shta´-xta-ge> you bite. àðáxtaka pe <oæ-tha´-xta-ga i> we bite.

••• Cf. waðáaxtake. 

ðaazó (variant: ðaazáì [unconfirmed]). V [sync./uninfl., _ðaazó] (intr.) whoop, lulu, ululate (RBn12-06; FH/11/17/01/pc). ðaazópi! lulu, you all! (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod).  

••• Cf. oðáaze, oðáazo. 

ðaazúpe. V [sync., _ðaazúpe] (trans.?) drink soup (RBn12-07).

ðaaëóce. V [sync., _ðaaëóce] (trans.) blow, blow on (RBn22-08; PM/109).

•• LFD 354: ëóce <zho´-dse> whistle.

••• KS màsóýe whistle, flute (RR), wabóçoýe flute, a type of whistle (MR, RR).

ðaaëóëi (variant: ðaaëôëi). V [sync., _ðaaëóëi] (trans.) insult by word, speak ill of, slander, malign, belittle.

••• Cf. hkiláaëoëi. 

ðáha. CONJ when, upon a certain event. íiwiðe ðáha owíhkie màëí when I saw you, I didn't talk to you (FH/02/17/96/pc:prod). hàà káaçi ðáha achípe they came late at night (lit., 'when it had been night for a long time, they arrived here').

•• JOD (slip file): ðáha <¢a´-ha> soon after, as soon as.

ðáhta. ADV left; leftward; lefthand (ERE; not recognized by FH). hkilíhkòìãa, ðáhta ki turn to your left (RBn10-21). ðáhta ha toward the left (RB). ðáhta ci ha to the left (RB). down a path to the left (02/15/95/FH/pc:uk, all).

•• LFD 112: ðáhta <tha´-¾a> the left; on the left; lefthanded. nâpe ðahta che <noæ´-be tha-¾a tse> the left hand. LFD 142: ðáhta hta opahe <tha´-¾a ¾a u-ba-he> toward the left side; the left side. ðahtáci <tha-¾a´-dsi> at the left side.

ðaìçé (variants: ðàìçé, ðààçé, ðaaçé). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for moving 2nd sg. subject (action or state may continue from past to present, corresponding to English perfect ['have/had been']). ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] óce ðaìçé? are you [moving, sg.] looking for things? âçpaão ðaìçé you're pushing me. wacúe skúe paðáçce hta ðàìçé? are you [moving, sg.] going to cut the cake? ðihúheka ðààçe áape anâkØò I heard you [moving, sg.] were sick (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). kasîe ówò hta ðaìçé? are you [moving, sg.] going to be busy tomorrow? (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). ðúuhpeece wì açcî ðaìçé? do you [moving, sg.] have a match? • you are characterized by [the immediately preceding word or phrase, which may be a noun phrase]. hîì hpíiëi ðaìçé you have bad teeth. waðílà hpíiëi ðaìçé you've got a bad temper.

ðakxâçe (variant of ðatxâçe).

ðakØéðe (variants: ðakØée, ðakØéi). V [reg., ðakØé_ðe] (trans.) feel sorry for; pity (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ðakØéwai be good to them; have pity on them (FH:prod). ðakØéwaðapi have pity on us; be good to us (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ðakØéwie I pity you; I feel sorry for you. ðakØéawaðe I pity them (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ðakØéwaðáðe you pity them (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ðakØéàwaðape we pity them. ðakØéwiðe ðekôòce óxi ðe nà I am sorry for you now for this death. ðakØéwaðe hkôbra I want you to pity them. ðakØéwaðaðe, xíða ðéche íinòòhpe ðìké you pity us, and we don't fear death. wîðakçe nìkçé ahá, wahkôta akxa ðakØéðiðe hta akxai if you are in earnest, God will pity you. waðákØeðíðe nìkçé aape, ðe età, ðakØéwaðapi they said you were kind, so pity us. ðakØéwaðapi have pity on us, be good to us [who are not your own] (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok). • be good to, be merciful to. ðakØéàðape we were good to him; they were good to me; he was good to me. • take care of. pée ðakØéðie ðìké hta akxa? wahkôta akxa éenà who will take care of you when everything is gone? only God (FH). • bless (BE2.23).

•• LFD 141: ðakØéðe <tha-Ð'e´the> pity; to be tender, gentle, and sympathetic to one who suffers with grief or is in great trouble; tenderness; kind-heartedness. ðakØé waðe <tha-Ð'e´ wa-the> to have pity for others. ðakØé awaðe <tha-Ð'e´ a-wa-the> I pity them. ðakØé waðaðe <tha-Ð'e´ wa-tha-the> you pity them. (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok).  

••• Cf. ðakØékiðe, waðákØeðe. 

ðakØéhkiðe (variant: ðakØéhkie). V [reg., ðakØé _hkiðe ] [hkik- RECIP/REFL + ðakØéðe] (intr.) be good to each other; be kind to each other; pity each other (reciprocal sense). ðakØéhkiðe be good to each other. ðakØéhkie pái you all be good to each other [pai commands continuing future behavior]. ðakØéhkiepi be good to each other; be kind to one another [now] (03/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.104). • pity oneself, feel sorry for oneself (reflexive sense).

•• LFD 140 (unconfirmed, not accepted by modern speakers): ðakØéhkiðe <tha-Ð'e´-Ðithe> self-pity; inward hurt. [FH: has nothing to do with pitying oneself or being hurt.] ðahkeahkiðe <tha-Ðe-a-Ði-the> I was inwardly hurt (feelings). ðahkeðahkiðe <tha-Ðe-thaÐi-the> you pitied yourself. ðahkeàhkiða pe <tha-Ðe-oæ-Ði-tha i> we were hurt inwardly (feelings).

ðakØéi (variant of ðakØéðe).

ðakØékiðe. V [reg., ðakØé_kiðe] [kik- SUU or ki- DAT+ ðakØéðe] (trans.) be good or kind to one's own [SUU] or to s.o. close [DAT]; pity or feel sorry for one's own [SUU] or s.o. close [DAT]. ðakØéwikiðe I feel sorry for you, I pity you, I sympathize with you (FH). ðakØéwikíe achíe I came because I'm sorry for you. ðakØéwikíðe, ðiðáce ðíliëóëi I pity you, your father hurt you [when he died]. àkóðihkíepi áha, ðakØéwaðakíðe hta nìkçé aap when we talk to you, they said you would pity us. ðakØékiðapai be kind to one another, pity one another [understood in reciprocal sense]. ðakØéàðakíe have pity on me [addressed to a close friend or relative] (03/09/95/FH/pc:okc). ðakØéàkíe nàpé you've always been good to me (RBn10-6:JW). ðakØéàkiðe nàpe you're always good to me. ðakØéwaðakíe be good to us; be good to your own.

ðálì (variant: ðáalì). MODAL should, ought to. táatà éekòke àwâçtaakaaëi ðálì you shouldn't tell me things like that.

••• Cf. ðáalì,

ðatxâçe (variants: ðakxâçe, ðatkxâçe, ðàtxâçe). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for standing 2nd sg. or 2nd pl. subject; may also be used for imminent future action or state. waëáëe nîe ðatxâçe you're an Osage [to someone standing]. haakxâta waðákiçtôpapi ðachí hta ðàkxâçe? when are you all going to come see us? (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). súhka háanà ooðáhà hta ðatxâçe? how many chickens are you going to cook? tàhé ðatxâçe? are you [standing] well? ðahkílò ðatkxâçe you [standing] are calling yourself a name (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 142: ðatxàçe <tha-toæ-she> standing (from a ritual).

ðaëáëì (variant of aëáëì).

ðà. ADJ round. [Obsolete, unattested in Mod. Os.]

•• LFD 125: hpahéðò <¼a-he´-thoæ> a round hill.

ðâàce (variant: nâàce). N heart (03/22/95/FH/pc:tape). ðâàce ðuusáaki akxái he [has] had a heart attack. ðâàce ðuusáaki akxái he has a broken heart, a disturbed heart (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.66). ðâàce saakí káaãapi ée nàpé make your hearts strong, he used to say (RBn HWMREI). • hearts (suit in a deck of cards) (RBn12-10/MOJ, 02/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 153: ðâce <thoæ´-dse> heart.

ðâàce ðuusáaki. N heart attack (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ðâàce ðuusáaki akxái he had a heart attack (FH:5/02/96/prod; ok; RBn2-moj/p26). • broken heart ðâàce ðuusáaki akxái he has a broken heart, a disturbed heart (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.66).

ðâàce óðisàha. VP, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) afraid (lit., 'heart fluttering') (RBn23-14). • N scare, fright.

•• LFD 113: nôce oðisàha <noæ´-dse u-thi-šoæ-ha> a shock to the heart; a scare; a fright; heart palpitates quickly. LFD 203: waðôce oðisàha <wa-thoæ´-dse u-thi-šoæ-ha> to excite; excitement; his heart is fluttering with excitement.

ðâàce ósai (variant: ðâàce ózai [RB]). VP, ADJ [conjug. unknown] (be) afraid (lit., 'heart burning, heart set on fire') (RB, unconfirmed).

••• Cf. osái. ðâàce skúðe. N sweetheart. (MREI/t116, 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.130). [Slang, calque of English.]

ðâàce xô. N broken heart (MSB: 2-24-83).

ðâàceíki. V [reg. iða?, ðâàceí_ki] (trans.) love. ðâàceíwiki I love you (RBn HW, unconfirmed). ðâàceíwikipe I love you all (RBn HW, unconfirmed).

ðâàceníe. V [stat., ðâàce_níe ] [ðâàce + níe] suffer from heartache, have a pain in the heart. N heartache.

•• LFD 153: ðâce nie <thoæ´-dse ni-e> heartache. ðâce anie <thoæ´-dse a-ni-e> I have a pain in my heart. ðâce ðinie <thoæ´-dse thi-ni-e> you have a pain in your heart.

ðààcháëi. ADV [ðààché + aëí NEG] improbably, against all odds. ðààcháëi, waëáëeíe çòòçôwe ðée hkôbra I want this Osage language to go on forever [against all odds] (FH:pc). • ADJ impossible, unable. brúwì ðâàchaëì I am unable to buy it (02/27/95/JS/pc:okc; 04/06/95/FH/pc:ma).

•• LFD 281: ðâhta ëi <thoæ´-¾a zhi> impossible. [The unnegated form <thoæ-tse´> (LFD 153) would lead one to expect a negative form <thoæ-tsa zhi> or <thoæ-ta zhi> rather than <thoæ´-¾a zhi>.]

ðààché. MODAL [uninfl. or impersonal form] possible; suitable, appropriate. htáwà kçi brée ðààché hta mìkçé I might go to town (MOJ/11/30/84). çcíhtà ðààcháëie you shouldn't touch it (lit., 'your touching it is not suitable'). ékiëò ðààché nìkçé? is it possible for you to do that? âàðilòðì ðààché ìké we'll never forget you (lit., 'it is not possible that we forget you') (FH:5/02/96/prod). • could, would. oðíhtà wíhta akxa wasúhuëi akxa hàðé çäúuëa ðààché? my car is dirty, could you wash it this evening/tonight? (FH/06/16/01/pc). • probable; look like; be at the point of happening. níiëu ðààché akxa it might rain (lit., 'rain is probable/possible') (RBnB1-41). níiëu ðààché hta akxai it might rain (MOJ/11/30/84). ónalìpi, pahúðe ðààchí akxái hurry up you all, it's about to snow (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod. orig; FH:4/25/96/tape; BE2.70).

•• LFD 153: ðàché <thoæ-tse´> suitable; appropriate; convenient. LFD 308: ékò ðàché <e-goæ thoæ-¾se> possible.

ðâàlì (variant of ðáalì).

ðààçé, ðàìçé (variants of ðaìçé).

ðe. CAU [reg., _ðe] make; have or make s.o. do s.t.; cause s.t. to happen to s.o. or s.t. taazíhiðe make it brown, as in cooking.

ðe (variant: e). DECL indeed; sentence-final declarative marker ("oral period"; probably once limited to female speech but now optionally used by males as well). [May be the same as LF's he 'female(?) declarative marker', not found in Mod. Os.] áëà brée ðe I went to bed [I did indeed] (01/07/95/FH/pc). wéhice pçi I went far away (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). wéhice pçíeðe I went far away (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod).  

••• QU ì female speech, oral period (RR).

ðe. POSIT positional article for a sg. moving entity. tówa ðe táatà ohkíhce? what tribe is he [that unfamiliar person moving]? that, the aforesaid. Jacka háakò eekíe ðe tà iiðáçtà I agree with what Jack says (FH/09/25/01/pc; 03/23/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• Cf. pa POSIT.

ðe áape (variant of ði aape).

ðée (see aðée).

ðée (variants: ðí, ðíi [especially when followed by accented vowel]). PRON that; this; those; these; they. líe ðáha óëo áhkiëi ðíi aape when she came back she was proud of herself [they said] (RBn19-03). níhka ákiãe ðí aape that man is all around [bothering] her [they said] (FH/09/22/01/pc). ókØò éëi ðíi eepe he's confused [they said] (FH/09/24/01/pc/prod). ðée akxa íihò hâàpa ókØà hta apai they [that group] are going to have something on Mother's Day. hkóða ðíi áape they were friends [they said of them] (RBn18-01). [hkóða ðée áape] ðée che akå húe come and get these [a group of stacked round objects: e.g., groceries]. ðée lípi che çki wéewinai I'm thankful, too, for these who have come here (FH/10/13/96). haxî ðe, ðée apa kíða aðî hkôbra I want each of them to have this blanket for his/her own (i.e., they can all call it theirs, each one has a part in this blanket) (01/20/95/PM/pc:prod. orig; BE2.38). ðée apa these people, this group of people (BE2.137; RBn1-moj/p52b; 03/20/95/FH/pc:not sg). ðée akxa the whole bunch of them (RB; 03/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 143: ðéapa <the´-a-ba> these; with reference to people or animals. ðékçe <the´kshe> this that lies here; this gun, this pipe (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok; sg only). LFD 145: ðéche <the´-tse> this; as referring to the object close at hand. hci ðeche <¾si the-tse> this house standing. hcíëepe ðeche <¾si´-zhe-be the-tse> this door hanging.  

ðée áape (variant of ði aape).

ðée ekô. ADV this way, that way, thus, like this, like that. ðée ekô akxa ékiçe nànà you said it would be like this.

••• Cf. haakô, kaakô. 

ðée hta ché. VP (expresses certainty of a future event: 'that is how it will be'). âà, ékiò ðée hta ché okay, we'll do it (lit., 'yes, done like that, that it will be') (RBn17-p03).

ðée ìkçé. PRON that one sitting. ðée ìkçé ohkíhce hôòxce ðìkçé? that one sitting over there, what kind of tribe is he? (03/23/95/FH/pc).

ðée káaãe. VP (trans.) send; dispatch; make s.t. go there. áhu ðée káaãe hta mìkçé I'm going to send this wing around. waléze ðée kaaãe to send a letter (RBn2-moj/p13; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). mâze kØâsaaki ðée káaãa! send a wire! (RBn3-58). wáleze ðée káaãa! send a letter! (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). • mail (MREI). wáleze ðée káaãa mail a letter (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). • let go. çi môçò ðée hpáaãe I'm going to let that arrow go again (lit., 'again I make the feather go'). • lead (in a card game such as pitch); play a card (in a card game). ðée hpáaãe I send this (uttered when leading a card in a pitch game) (RB). ðée hpáaãe I play this (RBn12-10/mj).

•• LFD 143: ðékaãe <the´-ga-xe> to send. ðéhpaãe <the´-¼a-xe> I sent it. ðéçkaãe <the´-shka-xe> you sent it.  

ðéeðe. V [reg., ðée_ðe] [(a)ðée 'go there' + ðe CAU] (trans.) make go, cause to go; send; mail.

•• LFD 143–44: ðéðe <the´-the> to send. ðeáðe <the-a´-the> I send. ðeðáðe <the-tha´the> you send. ðeàða pe <the-oæ-tha i> we send. John waleze wì ðeðeahkiðe Henry ðìkçe ci <John wa-gthe-še-wiæ the-the a-Ði-the Henry thiæ-ke dsi> [expected verb form: ðéeðeakçíðe 'I had him cause it to go'] I had John send a letter to Henry.

ðéeðekçíðe. V [reg., ðéeðe_kçíðe] [ðéeðe + kçíðe] (trans.) have s.o. send or mail s.t.

ðeeká (variants: ðéka, ðéeka, ðeká, ðéekaa). ADV, N there, here, these. okØâ hta apai ðeeká they're going to have something there; they're going to hold an event there (FH/06/25/01/pc).

• V [uninfl] (intr.) be here. ðéekaa mìkçé I'm here (FH:ee,aa).

ðeeká ci. VP, ADVP (be) over here (FH).

ðéeka wì. PRONP one of these. ðéeka wî çkôçta? do you want one of these? (e.g., when offering a cigarette from a pack) (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

ðeekáha. ADV this way. ðekáha kú come this way, in this direction, along this path. ðekáha kçe this way, on this lying path [with positional kçe] (RBn1-23).

•• LFD 143: ðekáha <the-ga´-ha> here; in this region; in this neighborhood; local.

••• KS yegáha those from here; Dhegiha (RR).

••• Cf. ðeekíha. 

ðeekáiha. ADV around this way, round about this way (FH: prod). ëâà lâàðe kaasé, ðeekáiha ðiitâ that big tree that was cut, around this way pull it (04/18/95/FH/pc).

••• KS yegáha Dhegiha (RR).

ðéeke. PRON [ðée 'that, this' + ke] these scattered. táatà ðéeke hôòëike these bad things around.

ðéeke ci. ADV, PRON sometimes, now and then; s.t. scattered (RBn10-5:JW). ðéeke cí ðé anything over there (03/13/95/FH/pc:ma; LS:ma; PM:ma; RBn10-5:JW).

ðeekíha (variant: ðekíha). N those from around here; Dhegiha. ðeekíha those from here (said to be source of the name of the Dhegiha subfamily of Siouan languages, which includes Osage, Omaha-Ponca, Kansa-Kaw, and Quapaw).

•• LFD 143: ðekáha <the-ga´-ha> here; in this region; in this neighborhood; local.

•• KS yegáha those here, the people of this land (JOD), Dhegiha (RR); OM dhégiha those from around here (RR); QU deká those from around here (RR).

••• Cf. ðeekáha, ðeekáiha. 

ðeekçíðe. V [reg., ðee_kçíðe] [(a)ðée 'go there' + kçíðe] (trans.) send, mail or make s.t. go to another person. mâzeohkihki ðeekçíe telephone him/her (RBn3-58). mâzeohkíhkie ðeekçíe call him/her on the phone (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). mâzeohkíhkie ðekçí aape they said they talked on the phone (03/16/95/FH/pc). wáleze ðeekçíe mail this letter to her (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• Cf. ðée káaãe, hukçíðe. 

ðéepa. N chin; jaw (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok; 01/09/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 143: ðépa <the´-ba> the jaw; the underjaw. ðéeze. N tongue (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc). ðéeze íhtaxe the tip of the tongue (t118/03/23/95/FH/pc). ðéeze xáka thorny tongue (03/23/95/FH/pc:prod, BE2.142).

•• LFD 143: ðése <the´-še> tongue (03/23/95/FH/pc: ðéeze; not **ðéese). ðése ihtaxe <the´-še i-¾a-xe> tip of the tongue. ðésexaka <The´-še-xa-ga> Rough-tongue (personal name; refers to the rough tongue of the buffalo).

ðéeze opásike. VP [stat., ðéeze o_pasike] stutter, be tongue-tied; tongue splayed or split, tonguetied (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 143: ðéze opasike <the´-še u-ba-ši-ge> to stutter; to stammer; tongue-tied. ðese àwàpasike <the-še oæ-woæ-ba-ši-ge> I stutter. ðese oðipasike <the-še u-thi-ba-ši-ge> you stutter. çîhto ëìka htà ðese opasike <shiæ´-¾o zhiæ-ga ¾oæ the-še u-ba-ši-ge> the boy is tongue-tied [probably should be çîtoëì txà ðéeze opasike 'the boy standing there is tonguetied'].

••• Cf. paasíke.

ðeká, ðéka (variants of ðeeká).

ðekáhtà. ADV therefore.

•• JOD (wasápeëìka ltr, p1 ln2): ðekáhtà waléze çoðée hpáaãe wihcíëoe <¢e§kátaæ wa§k¢é§se cu¢é páxi au, witsí§cªuæ é> therefore I'm sending this letter to you, niece [sister's daughter]. JOD (slip file): ðekáhtà <¢e-¦ká-taæ> from this place.

ðekíha (variant of ðeekíha).

ðekôòce (variant: ðekôòci). ADV [possibly ðée 'that, this' + kaakô + ci PPN] now; at this moment. ðekôòci from now on (FH). ðekôòci áha waxpáðe níhkaçika, háanà ììksé çki ówaçta apatàha at the present time we are a pitiful people, and there are even very few of us left. kóoci waëáëe apa ðée ékiòpe àëi ðekôòci ðìkápi wihtáeëi akxa íkØuci akxai long ago Osages used to do that but now they are gone and sister is trying her best (gloss by CQ; PM/7/7/94).

waðílà ekôìkí apai, ðekôòci áhkihtòpa ðì there are crazies around, now watch out for yourself.

••• KS gagóoýi now, just now (RR).

ðékçe. ADJ [ðée 'that, this' + kçe] this (lying); that (lying). môëò ðáalì ðékçe môëò ðékçe ðìké hta aaëi íe wíhta çòòçôwe aðée hta akxai heaven and earth shall pass away, but my word will endure (FH: from Matthew 24:35).  

ðéskali. N boil; sore. ðéskali çôcheða! let that boil alone! (RBn11-01/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976; FH/11/19/01/pc:uk).

•• QU déskakde boil, sore (RR).

ðetkxâci (variant of ðetxâci).

ðetkxâha (variant of ðetxâha).

ðetkxâtà (variant of ðetxâtà).

ðétxà. (variant: ðétxa). ADV this time. hôòpa ðétxa híe ðáha çi owíhkie at this time of the day I'm going to talk to you again (lit., 'when this time of the day arrives, again I speak to you'). meeting

ðetxâce (variant: ðetxaci). ADV from now on.

••• Cf. ðetxâtà.

ðetxâci (variant: ðetkxâci). ADV at this time. hâàci ðetkxâci wacúe bráache mìkçé ska last night at this time I must have been eating this bread (FH/09/06/95/pc).

ðetxâha (variant: ðetkxâha). ADV from now on; from this time on, henceforth (03/22/95/FH/pc). ðetxâha háakò éepçe che ékò hkôbra from now on, I want it to be like I've said

(03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). ðetkâàha, ðe haxî ìkçé mî hta mìkçé from now on, I'm going to wear that blanket (FH/09/06/95).

•• LFD 144: ðetxâha ðeðe <the-toæ´-ha the-the> henceforth. ðetxâha ðeðe ece pçe che ekò hkòbra ha <the-toæ´-ha the-the e-de pshe tse e-goæ Ðoæ-btha ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: ðetxâha ðée ðe épçe che éekò hkôbra; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] from now on do as I say (lit., 'from now on I want those things to be the way that I say').

ðetxâtà (variants: ðetxâta, ðetkxâtà). ADV from this time. (FH/07/09/01/pc). ðetkxâtà awáachi hta mìkçé I'm going to dance from now on (FH/07/09/01/pc). ðetkxâtà waðílà ðáalì íbrilà hta mìkçé from now on I'm going to think good thoughts (FH/07/09/01/pc).  

••• Cf. haatxâta. 

ði (variants: ðì, ni, nì). IMPERATIVE MARKER sentence-final marker for command to sg.

addressee. çée nìkçé óhkie ni you're just sitting there, speak to me (RBn10-6:JW; RR/pc). áçihta brée àëì ðíe hcíhta wéðaahpa ði I'm going outside but you stay inside and wait [for people] (FH:prod). waxpáðì nà àhkílai ði carry yourself humble [to one person] (RB).

ðí (variant of ðíe).

ði-. PRNM 2nd person inalienable possessive pronominal ('your', used with some kin terms, e.g., ðihcíko 'your grandfather').

••• Cf. wi- 'my'. ði-. PRNM 2nd person patient pronominal ('you'),  used as subject of stative verbs and as object of active verbs.

ði- (variant of ðu-).

ðí (variant of ðée).

ðí aape (variants: ði áape, ðée áape, ðe áape). REPORTATIVE [possibly ðe POSIT + áape] they said (that) of him/her (moving?). súhka htâà mîka wì hcí káaãe ðí aape the turkey went out to make a nest (RBn19-03). wéeli ðumâða ðí aape she held her head high (RBn19-05).

ðíbra (variant: ðúbra). V [sync., _ðíbra] (trans.) spread, spread out, as a cloth.

•• LFD 334: haxî ðà bríbra <ha-xiæ´, thoæ bthi-btha> [expected Mod. Os. form: haxî bríbra; ðà (or ðò) is an archaic form, not used in Mod. Os.] I spread my blanket.

••• Cf. áðubra. 

ðíbrà. V [sync., _ðíbrà] (trans.) smell. bríbrà I smell it (e.g., cedar).

ðibrîãa. V [sync., _ðibrîãa] (intr.) fart loudly, make a loud fart; break wind noisily (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.44).

•• KS yübíãà to fart (JOD, RR).

ðibrúbruãe (variant: brúbruãe). V [sync., _ðicíze] (intr.) shake; quiver; tremble (MREI

11/1/83/7). ëâà akxa ðibrúbruãe akxa the tree is shaking.

••• Cf. waskúe ðibrúbruãe. 

ðibrúuska. V [sync., _ðibrúuska] (trans.) wad up; flatten. niikáapxokeooëu çtáaçtà tà, ðibruuska when you are through with the pop can, wad it up (02/24/95/FH/pc).

ðicíze. V [sync., _ðicíze] (trans.) dust or clean (e.g., the house). màçóçoce che, ðicíza it's dusty, dust it (FH:4/22/96/tape;prod). • move, remove, take away. áalìì ðihcíze move that chair. áalìì àðíhcize we [two] moved the chair. hôbre hpíiëi ðéke àðicize hkôbra, waðílà hpíiëi ðéke çki, waðílà wasúhu I want you to take away these bad dreams, these bad thoughts, too, cleanse my mind (RBn10-14; cqc). áwanòbre akxa màçóçoce akxai, ðicíza the table is dusty, dust it (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod). waðílà wákalà âðiicíza take this dirty mind away (RBn103:MOJ/79).

•• LFD 318: ðicíze <thi-dsi´-še> remove from office [strictly speaking means 'remove' only; no mention of 'office'].

••• QU íttize [reg.-iða] clean out the house (RR), kdittíze pull one's own (RR), dizé get, take, receive (RR).  

ðiðáce. N your father. ðiðáce howáìke ðe? where is your father? (FH). • your paternal uncle, your father's brother (BE2.45).  

ðiðáceëì (variant: ðiðáciëì). N your paternal uncle, your father's brother (used when speaking to a man or a woman about his/her relative).  

ðíe (variant: ði). PRON you (emphatic). ðíe màðí! you go! (emphatic and contrastive, as in 'I don't want to go, you go'). • your turn. ðíe hta nìkçé your turn (04/04/95/FH/pc:ok). ðíe ðinîe, ðíe níe your turn (lit., 'it's you, you are it') (BE2.162). waðíhta ðíe it's your turn (e.g., to hit drum) (lit., 'handle it, you') (RBn3-22). waðíðihta ði nîe it's your turn to take over (RBn2316).  

ðíãe (variant of ðúãe).

ðihâka. N your sister-in-law (used only when speaking to a man, referring to his brother's wife or his wife's sister).  

ðihcíceðe (variant: ðihcíciðe). V [conjug. unknown] [perhaps ðu-/ði- INSTR + hcíce + ðe CAU?] prance (lit., 'make s.t. produce a rhythmic sound'?) (RB, unconfirmed). ðihcíceðe aðáape, ëúoka nôò ékò he pranced along, with a grownup's stance (lit., '. . . as if his body were an adult's') (RBn15-03).

ðihcíko. N your grandfather (paternal or maternal); your grandparents; your father-in-law (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman about the father of his/her spouse).  

ðihcími. N your father's sister (younger or older), your paternal aunt (FH/09/22/01/pc).

ðihcíni. (variant: ðihcínì). N your daughter-in-law, your son's wife.  

ðihcióëàke. N (variant: ðihcóëàke). N your brother's daughter (used only when speaking to a woman; more specific than English 'niece').  

ðihcíëo. N (variants: ðihcíëò, ðihcíëoe). N your sister's daughter (used only when speaking to a man; more specific than English 'niece'); your father's sister's daughter (used when speaking to a man or a woman; more specific than English 'cousin').  

ðihcîto. N your older brother (used only when speaking to a woman) (FH/09/24/01/ok).  

ðihcóçka. N your wife's brother's son, your sister's son (used when speaking to a man); your brother's son (used when speaking to a woman); your grandchild (used when speaking to a man or a woman); more specific than English 'nephew'). [Use as 'grandchild' is unexpected; cf. ðihcóçpa.]  ðihcóçpa. N your grandchild (RB, FH/09/24/01/ok).

ðihcóëàke (variant of ðihcióëàke).

ðíhota (variant: ðíhotà, ðihótà). V [sync. _ðihota] (trans.) play a joke on, fool, trick. çäíhotàpe you all played a joke on him (RBn HW). ðíðihotape they played a joke on you (RBn HW). bríhota I played a joke (on him/her) (RBn HW). wábrihotà íðilà ðí apé I have fooled them, she thought (RBn19-03). wíbrihotai I fooled you (RBn19-03). súhkahtâà mîìka éëi pa wáðihota ìkçe ípahò ìkçi áape turkey hen knew she had done everything she could to fool the others [them] (RBn19-05).

••• Cf. wahóta. 

ðihpóe. N match (for lighting fires) (LF only).

•• LFD 148: ðihpóe <thi-¼o´-e> a match.

ðíhta (variant: ðíihta). PRON yours, your (sg. or pl. 'you') (RB, 04/27/95/FH/pc). • V [inalien.] be yours.

•• LFD 149: ðíhta <thi´-¾a> (sometimes spoken as <thi-thi-¾a>) yours. hkáwa ðihta <Ða´-wa thi-¾a> your horse. hci ðíhta <¾si thi´-¾a> your house. ëìka ëìka ðihta <zhiæ-ga zhiæ-ga thi-¾a> your child.

ðíhtaapi. PRON your (two or more of you). [ðíhta may also be used instead of ðíhtaapi.] hci ðíhtaapi akxa ëúucape your [pl.] house is red. ákahamì ðíhtaapi akxa çcúuce? are your [pl.] coats warm?

ðihtáeëì (variant of ðihtéëì).

ðihtâha. N your father's sister's husband, your paternal uncle by marriage (used when speaking to a man or a woman); your wife's brother, your sister's husband (used only when speaking to a man; more specific than English 'brother-in-law'). (FH/09/24/01/ok).

•• LFD 238: ihtáhà <i-¾a´-hoæ> a man's brother-in-law.  

ðihtâke. N your older sister (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman, referring both to a sister older than the addressee and to the oldest of the addressee's sisters [who may not be older than the addressee]).  

ðihtéëì. N (variant: ðihtáeëì). your younger sister (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman about a sister younger than the addressee) (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; FH/09/22/01/pc).  

ðihtôce. N your son-in-law (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman).

•• LFD 150: ðihtôce <thi-¾oæ´-dse> your son-in-law.  

ðíhuuce (variant of ðuuhúuce).

ðíi (variants of aðée, ðée PRON).

ðii- (variant of ðu-).

ðiiãó (variant: ðiiãóe, ðiiãówe). V [reg., _ðiião] (trans.) drag.

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p24, ln13): ðixówe <¢iqúwe> drag along.

•• LFD 258: ðíãoe <thi´xu-e> to drag on the ground.

••• QU diãówe drag something along (RR).

ðiiãóão (variant: ðiiãóãoe). V [reduplicated form of ðiiãó] (trans.) keep dragging. Brian akxa mààëâãe tóa ðiiãóão nà oðíhtà ci ehtáha Brian keeps dragging those onions to put them in the car (RBn10-2:MOJ/79).

ðiiãówe (variant of ðiiãó).

ðiihâ (variant: ðíihà, ðíiha). V [sync., _ ðiihâ] (trans.) lift, pick up, hold up, or raise s.o. or s.t. (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). bríiha I lift him/it. çcíiha you lift him/it. àðíiha we lift him/it. îì çé ìkçé ðiihâ pick up that rock (RBn HW11; cq:okc). ðiihâ ðuucØáke akxai he can't lift it (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). wíbriihà I lift you up (02/14/95/FH/pc; (BE2.79).

•• LFD 147: ðihâ <thi-hoæ´> to lift. bríhà <bthi´-hoæ> I lift.  

ðiihcé (variants: iihcé, ðíihce). V [sync.?, _ ðiihcé?] (trans.) touch softly, as with a feather fan; barely touch. mòçô iihcé káaãa let the feather touch it (1/20/83/676; 03/23/95/FH/pc). mâçà àðíihce káaãa let the feather touch me (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). ëâàxe àðíihce the stick is touching me (03/23/95/FH/pc).  

ðiihíce. V [sync., _ ðiihíce] (trans.) play with s.t., fiddle with s.t. hciëé ðiihíce ìká don't play with the door (RBn12-07). ðiihítaëi apai he's not playing with them (LS/07/19/95). ðiihítaëi apai they won't play with them [with those things] (2/24/83). ðiihíce hta apaëí they won't play with them (LS:prod). ëìkáëi apa níi ðiihíce apái the children are playing with the water (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok). • fool, tease; be mischievous or deceitful toward; play slyly or meanly with; deceive, mistreat, persecute (an animal or person). wíbriihice àhé I was teasing you. âðiihice akxa áëamie I think he's teasing me (03/05/95/JS/pc:okc). âðiihice çtà he just keeps on teasing me (03/16/95/FH/pc:okc). wáðiihice akxai he's teasing us (03/16/95/FH/pc). âðiihice ìká stop teasing me (03/16/95/FH/pc). âçciihíce ðatxâçe you are toying with me (MSB/01/27/83).

•• JOD: mâãe <maæ-xe>.

•• LFD 147: ðihíce <thi-hi´-dse> to treat unkindly; maltreat. bríhice <bthi´-hi-dse> I persecuted him. àðíhica pe <oæ-thi´-hi-dsa i> we persecuted him. LFD 103: màxe ðihice <moæ-xe, thi-hi-dse> conjuring the sky.

ðiihkó. N your grandmother (paternal or maternal) (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok); your mother-in-law (used only when speaking to a woman). (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok). ðiihkó akxa ðípà akxa, íiðikiðe kôða pátà your grandmother is calling you, as she wishes to find you.  

•• JOD (slip file): ðihkó <¢ih§kú> [your grandmother].  

ðiihkóìãe. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) turn s.o./s.t. around. ðihkóìãa! turn it around!

(04/04/95/FH/pc). oðíhta ðihkôìãe turn the car around (04/04/95/FH/pc/okc; BE2.146).

•• LFD 348:  nôhkowìãe  <noæ´-Ðu-wiæ-xe>  to turn with the foot.  páhkowìãe  <ba´-Ðuwiæ-xe>  to turn by pushing.  

••• KS yükkómìãe (reg.) to turn something around and around, crank (RR).

••• Cf. hkilíihkòìãe ðiihkówa N your friend (01/20/95 /FH/pd:ok; BE2.51). your grandparents (pl. only). ðiihkówa tàhé ðe? how are your grandparents? (9T#14b-p3; 05/01/95/LS/pc).  

ðiihô. N your mother (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman) (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). ìcé waléze wì abrîe, ðiihô ðíhta I have a picture of your mother (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.90). ðiihô akxa watáaëoe oohô akxai your mother is cooking hominy. ðiihô kçe tàhé akxai? how is your [bedridden] mother?  

ðiihô ðitáce. N your parents (lit., 'your mother, your father'). ðiihô, ðitáce, tàhé apa? how are your parents? (lit., 'your mother, your father, are they well?') (T#14b-p2; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).  ðiihôhtà. N your mother's older sister (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman; more specific than English 'maternal aunt').  

ðiihôëì. N your mother's younger sister (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman; more specific than English 'maternal aunt').  

ðíihta (variant of ðíhta).

ðiihtâ (variant: ðiihtâà). V [sync., _ðiihtâ] (trans.) handle, knead, work s.t. with the hand (e.g., when cutting up squash and removing seeds to get it ready to cook or when getting dance clothes ready to be used by hanging them out to air) (FH/09/24/01/prod). hôòpa ðé htáa ðiihtâ hta apai they're going to work the meat today (FH/09/24/01/prod). • grasp; touch with the hand; feel s.o. or s.t. (03/23/95/FH/pc; 04/06/95/LS/pc; very low â or âà). çcíihtà ðààcháaëie you shouldn't touch it (BE2.143; 1/20/83/693). bríihtà I touched it; I felt it (1/20/83/693). ónòbre ðiihtâ ìká don't touch the food (03/23/95/FH/pc). ðiihtá ìká don't touch it (1/20/83/693).  

•• LFD 150: ðihtâ <thi-¾oæ´> to touch with the hand; to feel. bríhtà <bthi´-¾oæ> I touched it. scíhtà <stsi´-¾oæ> you touched it.

••• KS yüttâ touch, feel with the hands (RR).

••• Cf. áðiihtà, htaaðíihtà, oðíhtà. dance

ðiilóce. V [sync.?, _ðiilóce?] (trans.) peel. hkâàcezi ðiilóca peel the orange (RBn10-20).

••• KS yüxlóýe (yüxlódabe) peel something (RR).

ðiimô. V [sync., _ ðiimô] [perhaps ðu-/ði- INSTR + mâà/môò 'arrow'] (trans.) sharpen. mâàhì ðiimô sharpen the knife (RBn10-2). mâàhì bríimò hta mìkçé (RBn10-2).

•• LFD 148: ðimò <thi-moæ> to whet. brimò <bthi-moæ> I whet. àðímò <oæ-thi´-moæ> we whet.

••• KS mâhì iyåma whetstone, knife sharpener (RR).

ðiipíãà (variant: ðiipíãa). V [sync., _ðiipíãa] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + píãà] (intr.) fart, pass air or gas; break wind. (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• KS yübíãà to fart (JOD, RR).

••• Cf. opíãà.

ðiisâða (variant: ðiisôða). V [sync., _ðiisâða] (trans.) turn, turn over; invert, reverse. oðíhtà ðiisâðape he turned the car over (04/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.146). briisâða I turned it over (FH).

•• LFD 145: ðisâða <thi-šoæ´-tha> to reverse.

••• Cf. liisâða. 

ðiiskí. V [sync., _ ðiiskí] (trans.) grab; grasp s.o. by the scruff of the neck (FH:4/18/96:pc). ðiiskí oðîìka, lîìðìka grab a person by the neck and shake them up and set them down hard [shoving them]. • wad up or wad together (e.g., clothing at the back of the neck).

••• Cf. hkilíiski, kaaskí, waðíiski. 

ðiiskíke. V [sync., _ðiiskíke] [apparently ðu-/ði- INSTR + skíke] (trans.) wad up, bring the parts of a whole together with pressure; bring components into contact (e.g., parts of a blanket); make a fist; grind together (e.g., the teeth); gather. çáake ðiiskíke make a fist. çáake çcíiskike you've got your fist doubled up. hí çki ðiiskíke akxai he's even grinding his teeth.

••LFD 269: nòpé ðiskike iðáchì ha <noæ-be´ thi-ški-ge i-tha´-tsiæ ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I struck him with the fist [FH: correct without the ha (01/26/95/FH/pc:ok)].

••• Cf. hkilíiski. 

ðiisôða (variant of ðiisâða).

ðiistâ. V [sync., _ðiistâ] (trans.) turn off. oðíhtà ðiistâpe he turned the car off (RBn10-12:JW, unconfirmed).

ðiiçkâ (variant of ðuuçkâ).

ðiiçkí (variant: ðuuçkí). V [sync., _ðiiçkí] (trans.) wash (e.g., clothes, one's own or another's hair); launder. (FH/06/26/01/pc).

••• Cf. hkilíiçki, líiçki, waðíiçki. 

ðiiçô (variant of ðuuçô).

ðiiçtâ. V [sync., _ðiiçtà] (trans.) finish. oohô ðiiçtâpe, àwânôbre htai the cooking is finished, let us [three or more] eat (lit., 'they finished cooking, . . .') (01/25/95/FH/pc:okc). oohô ðiiçtâ apai, àwânôbre htai the cooking is finished, let us [three or more] eat (lit., 'they are finished cooking, . . .') (01/25/95/FH/pc:okc). oohô ðiiçtâpi che, àwânôbre htai the cooking is finished [lit., 'they have evidently finished cooking'], let us [three or more] eat (01/25/95/FH/pc:okc). oohô àðíiçtàpe we are finished cooking (01/25/95/FH/pc:ok). wanôbre ðóho ðíiçtape dinner will be ready soon (WHM980326). • stop (e.g., the weather stops doing s.t.). niiëú ðiiçtâ akxá it stopped raining (03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc). • already (did s.t.), be just finished (doing s.t.) [approximate translation]. pààçcéka ëaníe tóa áaëu bríiçtà I already put some sugar on top of the strawberries (lit., 'I finished putting sugar on top') (RBnB1-52). • (intr.) be finished, be through. ðiiçtâ káaãe stop. oáëu bríiçtà I'm finished planting (RBn14-01/LH). bríiçtà I'm finished (doing something) (01/25/95/FH/pc:prod). ðóha bríiçtà well, I'm just about through (FH). çcíiçta? are you finished? (01/25/95/FH/pc:ok;[a]; BE2.47). iðée bríiçtà tà, htâwà ìkçi brée hta mìkçé when I finish here, I'm going to town (01/25/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn HW8). àwâðiiçtà we're through (02/03/95/FH/pc: prod orig). • stop; finish, end. hóni bríiçta I almost finished (but did not) (01/25/95/FH/pc:ok). tààké çô apa, ànâðapi iaha ðiiçtâpe they were fighting, but they stopped when they saw me (lit., 'while they were fighting, when they saw me they stopped immediately'). katxâ àðíiçtà htai let's stop a while (RBn14-09;

03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc). káaçi wáli àwáachipe, àðíiçtà htái we've danced a long time, let's stop (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.81). mîìake hcewîìke àðíiçtà htai let's stop at nine o'clock (03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.128). hkihtôpe ðiiçtà! quit looking at yourself! • be ready. çcíiçtà? are you ready? (RB).

•• LFD 149: ðiçtâ <thi-shtoæ´> to stop, to finish, to make further claim to property in controversy; to relinquish the claim or right. bríçtà <bthi´-shtoæ> I finished, I relinquish claim. àðíçtà pe <oæ-thi´-shtoæ i> we finished, we relinquish claim.

••• Cf. ðaaçtâ, kaaçtâ, nôò ðiiçtâ. 

ðiiçtâ káaãe. VP (trans.) stop; make it end; make s.o. end s.t. súhka mîka ëì ðiiçtâ káaãe ðílà nàpé sometimes the little hen tried to stop him (RBn18-01).

ðiiçtówe (variants: ðiçtó, ðiiçtóe, ðiiçtówi). V [sync., _ðiiçtówe] (trans.) take off or remove a garment; undress. briiçtówe I'm taking it off (FH). húìke ðiiçtóa take your leggings off (MREI). • remove or take off by pulling, pull off (e.g., a shoe or boot). ðiitâ ðiiçtópe he pulled and broke it off [removed it] (RBn16-02; FH:ok). hòòpé sí aníe étana hòòpé bríiçto my shoe was hurting me, so I took it off (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). sí àðíxò étana hòòpé bríiçtoe I broke my foot, so I took my shoe off (FH/11/19/01/pc). • pull (e.g., a tooth) to remove it

(04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). híi ðíiçtoe pull your tooth (RB, 04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). hii âðiiçtoe pull

my tooth (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.108).

ðiiçúpe (variant: ðuuçúpe). V [sync., _ðiiçúpe] (trans.) open (e.g., a can); unlock and open (e.g., a door, a box) (RBn12-05). niikáapxoke tóa ðuuçúpa open some pop (RBn12-05). hci brúuçupe I opened the house (MREI 11-01-83). hciëé ðiiçúpa [unlock and] open the door (FH). hciëé âðiiçupe we opened the door (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). hciëé bríiçupe I opened the door (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). hciëe çcíiçupe you opened the door. hciëé âðiiçupape they opened the door (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 148: ðiçípe <thi-shi´-be> to open anything that has a lid or a door. bríçipe <bthi´-shi-be> I opened the box. LFD 149: ðiçúpe <thi-shu´-be> to open or unfasten a door; to open. hcíëe briçupe <¾si´-zhe bthi-shu-be> I opened the door. hcíëe sciçupe <¾si´zhe stsi-shu-be> you opened the door.

••• KS gaçåwe knock open a door or box (RR).

••• Cf. wéðuçupe. 

ðiitáaëi (variant of ðuutáaëi).

ðiitâ. V [sync., _ðiitâ] (trans.) pull; drag; tug. oðíhtà ðiitâ he pulled the car

(04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). ðiitâ! pull it! (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). oðíhtà çki ðiitâ kôða ìkápe he didn't want to pull the wagon either (RBn16-01). oðíhtà ðiitâ pull the car

(04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). ëâà lâàðe kaasé, ðekáiha ðiitâ that big tree that was cut, around this way pull it (04/18/95/FH/pc). ëâà wáli lâàðe ðiitâpi drag that big tree [speaking to a group] (04/18/95/FH/pc). ðiitâ waçkáape he pulled harder (lit.,'pulling, he did his best').  

•• LFD 145: ðitâ <thi-doæ´> to tug, pull (something); to pull with the hands. brítà awaçkà <bthi´-doæ a-wa-shkoæ> I tugged hard. àðítà pe ha <oæ-thi´-doæ pe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] he or they pulled me. LFD 214: wéðì ðità <we´-thiæ-thi-doæ> to pull anything taut (e.g., rope, tent cover) or spread a blanket tight.

••• KS oyåüdà, oyídà pull on, rein in, restrain (RR).

••• Cf. ðiihtâ, oðíità. 

ðiixô (variant: ðuuxô). V [sync., _ðiixô] (trans.) break by hand, break s.t. long (MSB:02/03/83). bríixò I break it. çcíixò you break it. àðíixò we break it. ðíixò/ðiixô he/they break it. hciëé çcíixò you broke the door (04/19/95/FH/pc). aa àðíixòpe they broke my arm. • break off a long item (e.g., a limb, sofa, car antenna) by using the hands; snap in two, break into two parts (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). çäíixòpe you [two or more] broke it (FH/09/22/01/pc). ëâàxeëì tóa ðiixô break off some little sticks (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ëâàxeëì tóa ðiixôpi break off some little sticks [to two or more addressees] (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). álììscee ðiixôpe they have broken the divan (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 151: ðixô <thi-xoæ´> to break; to break a stick in half. bríxò <bthi´-xoæ> I broke the stick in half. àðíxòpe <oæ-thi´-xoæ i> we broke the stick in half. LFD 25: ëâxa kçe brixò <zhoæ´-xa ke bthi-xoæ> I broke the stick in two. ëâxa kçe scixò <zhoæ´-xa ke stsixoæ> you broke the stick in two. [LFD 219 also erroneously lists bríxò <bthi´-xoæ> 'I break (s.t.)' and àðíxòpe <oæ-thi´-xoæ i> 'we break (s.t.)' as if they were forms of xô <xoæ>

'break' (intr.).]  

ðiizíðe. V [sync., _ðiizíðe] (trans.) stretch (FH).

•• LFD 337: ðisíða <thi-ši´-tha> to stretch, as distend.

••• KS áayüzübe to pull the edge over one, as a blanket (RR); OM same as Osage (LFD 337).

••• Cf. hkilíiziðe. 

ðiizó (variant: ðiizóka). V [sync., _ðiizó] (trans.) make bend (e.g., bend a tree branch over with the hands). mîce bríizoke I bent the bow (02-10-83-p4). mîce çciizóke you bent the bow. mîce ðiizókape they bent the bow. mîce àðíizokape they bend my bow. mîce àlíizoke àkátxai we bend our bows.

••• KS zóoge lean, bend as a tree in the wind (RR).

ðiiëóëi (variants: ðuuëóëi, ðiëóëi, ðuëóëi). V [sync., _ðiiëóëi] (trans.) hurt or harm another physically, mistreat. wáli ðiiëóëipi kçé áape he [lying down] has really been hurt, they said (RB; FH). iwáli ðiiëóëipi ìkçé áape he [sitting] is hurt [all beat up] (RB; FH). çäíëoëi you caused suffering, you hurt him (FH). • harm another mentally, emotionally (e.g., by humiliating another or by dying). ðakØéwikíe, ðiðáce ðíðiëoëi I pity you, your father hurt you [when he died] (uttered at a funeral) (RB). bríiëoëi I caused suffering to him (e.g., by saying something harmful) (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.70).

•• LFD 152: ðiëóëi <thi-zho´-zhi> to cause suffering by humiliating. bríëoëi <bthi´-zhozhi> I suffered from humiliation [rather, 'I caused suffering to somebody']. ðiëoáëi <thizhu-a´zhi> to injure; hurt; to do bodily harm. bríëomàëi <bthi'-zhu moæ-zhi> I hurt him.  

••• Cf. ðaaëóëi, hkilíiëoëi. 

 ðikçîce. V [sync., _ðikçîce] (trans.) miss; fail at; be incorrect at, not get right (e.g., an action). íe brikçîce I didn't tell it right (lit., 'telling it, I failed') (RBn23-17). • drop (e.g., an object or a comment into a conversation). brikçîce I dropped it. çcikçîce you dropped it (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.35). • let slip (as a comment); let slip away (as when one takes one's eyes off a person for a minute and he/she is gone).

•• LFD 147: ðikçîce <thi-kshiæ´-dse> failure to get a good grasp or hold. bríkçìce <bthi´-kshiæ-dse> I failed to grasp it.

••• Cf. kakçîce. 

ðikØíðe (variant: ðikØíe).
