V [sync., _ðikØíðe] (trans.) scratch; tickle. nâhka âðikØíe scratch my back (03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; 05/02/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.117; RBn HW11). wéeli ðikØíði apa he scratched his head (RBn19-02). wéeli ðikØíði e kçí aape he [lying down] scratched his head [they said] (RBn19-02).

•• LFD 147: ðikØíða <thi-Ð'i´-tha> to tickle. bríhkiða <bthi´-Ði-tha> I tickled him. àðíhkiða pe <oæ-thi´-Ði-tha i> we tickled them [expected translation: 'him'].

ðílà. ADJ, N, V [sync., _ðílà] (trans.) flirt (perhaps of flirting with a woman only [RB]); court, woo. John akxa wakØó ðílà çtàpe John flirts with women all the time (FH/11/27/01/pc:prod; BE2.49; 01/26/95/FH/pc:ok).

••LFD 146: ðilâ <thi-gthoæ´> to court; to woo. brílà <bthi´-gthoæ> I court. àðílà pe <oæ-thi´-gthoæ i> we court.

ðiléleze. N [reduplicated form] forked lightning (lit., 'making repeated stripes').

•• LFD 146: ðiléleze <thi-gthe´-gthe-še> the lightning that breaks into branches (forked lightning) (04/14/95/PM/pc:ok).

ðilôke (variant: ðilóke). V [sync., _ðilôke] (trans.) pinch (04/17/95/LS/pc:okc;

01/19/95/FH/pc:prod). âðilokape he pinched me (RBn23-07). wíbriloke hta mìkçé I'm going to pinch you (RBn23-07).

ðilôëe (variant: ðiloëe). V [sync., _ðilôëe] (trans.) grind; grind up; chop. htáa che ðilôëa, htóoëu àkáaãe htai grind up this meat, let's make meat pies (FH/09/24/01/prod). nâãe ðilôëe chopped or chipped ice (RBn; MREI/01/11/83; FH:ok).

ðínà (variants: ðína, ðinâ, ðînà). V, PRON [ðí(e) + na 'only'] (intr.) (be) only you. ðinâ it is only you.

••• Cf. àkónà, eenâ, wínà.  ðiníhka. N your husband (FHt#128a).  

••• Cf. níhka ðíhta. ðipúze. V [sync., _ðipúze] (trans.) dry. iiçtábrì ðipúze hta akxai he'll dry your tears (04/04/99/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 144: ðipúze <thi-biu´še> to make dry by wringing the water out of clothing (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok); the drying of a marshy place by draining.  

ðisíkxà. N your sister-in-law (probably used only when speaking to a woman about her sister-inlaw).  

ðisôeëì (variant: ðisôaëì). N your younger brother (used when speaking to a woman) (BE2.12; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok).  

ðisôka. N your younger brother (used when speaking to a man) (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok).  

ðistópe. V [sync., _ðiçtópe] (trans.) bless or give a blessing to with the hand (by touching a person's head or entire body: head, hands, heart, legs, feet) (RBn10-2; FH:ok). wihcíko ðistópe màðî grandfather, go ahead and bless him. wisôka akxa ðíðistope hta akxa brother is going to give you a blessing (FH/09/25/01/pc). wíbristope hta mìkçé I'm going to give you a blessing (FH/09/25/01/pc; RBn).  

ðiçíkxà. N your sister-in-law (used when speaking to a woman about her brother's wife, her husband's sister, or her husband's brother's wife) (RBn14-10; (03/10/95/PM/pc:ok; FH/09/22/01/pc; BE2.122).  

••• Cf. çíkxà ðíhta. 

ðiçíkØe. N your brother-in-law (used when speaking to a woman about her sister's husband, her husband's brother, or her husband's sister's husband) (FH/09/24/01/rod).  

ðiçkítà (variants: ðiçkíta, ðiçkí). PRON [contains çki 'also'] you too.

•• LFD 132: ðiçki <thi-shki> you also.

••• Cf. eeçkítà. 

ðiçôëi (variant: ðiëóëi). V [sync., _ðiçôëi] (trans.) trouble or mistreat s.o. níhkaçie apa wáli hkilíëoëi apai the people are mistreating each other (RBn 3/3/77).

•• JOD (Wasápeëìka ltr, ln5): háahta ðíçòëi hkôbra ðìké <Háta ¢i´cªuæ§ci kªuæ´§p¢a ¢iñ§ke´> I want you not to be troubled at any time.

•• LFD 152: ðiëóëi <thi-zho´-zhi> to cause suffering by humiliating. ðiëuáëi <thi-zhua´zhi> to injure; hurt; to do bodily harm.

••• Cf. hkilíiëoëi. 

ðiçtó (variant of ðiiçtówe).

ðiwákØo. N your wife (04/27/95/FH/pc).  

••• Cf. wakØó. 

ðíwakØóëì. N your mother-in-law (considered by some to refer only to a male's wife's mother; considered by others to refer to either a male's or a female's mother-in-law).  

••• Cf. wakØóëì. 

ðiwáçtake (variant: ðuwáçtake [FH]). V [sync., _ðiwáçtake] (trans.) tame (e.g., a horse) (03/23/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 150: ðiwáçtake <thi-wa´-shta-ge> tame a horse, make a horse gentle; domesticate a horse or other animal. bríwaçtake <bthi´-wa-shta-ge> I tamed the horse. àðíwaçtakape <oæ-thi´-wa-shta-ga i> we tamed the horses.

ðixí (variant: ðuxí). V [sync., _ðixí] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + -xi 'become awake'] (trans.) wake. ðixí! wake him up! wake her up! (FH:prod). wáðixi! wake them up! (FH:prod). âðixi akxai he's waking me up (FH:prod; HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok). àwáðixíe we [two] woke them up (1-20-83p4).

ðixípe (variants: ðihípe, ðihipi). N personal name of Robert Bristow, name in the Deer clan (lit., 'it caused to awaken', alluding to s.t. that awakens or arouses the sleeping deer).  

ðixópe. V [sync.? _ðixópe] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + xópe] (trans.) revere; hold sacred. àðíðixope we honor you (FH/09/21/01/pc). ëáëe àðíðixope àkatxâ hallowed be thy name (lit., 'we stand honoring your name') • honor; respect (MSB 05-12-83).  

ðixtâ. V [sync., _ðixtà] (trans.) draw water or run water (e.g., into a bathtub); pour. hiiðánii tóe àðíxta run me some bathwater (RBn10-20). màhkása toe âðixtà pour me some coffee (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

ðiëáëa (variant: ðiëâëà). V [sync.?, _ðiëáëa?] (trans.) shake (a person, an object, or one's own body part, such as shaking the head; human agent only, not nonhuman agents such as wind) (FH:prod; MREI 11/1/83; 3/10/83/C). wéehli ðiëâëà he shakes his head [as one with palsy] (03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.119). ëâà ðiëáëai shake the tree (RBn, MREI/01/11/83). wéehli bríëaëái I shook my head [refusing] (03-10-93-C).

•• LFD 152: ðiëâëà <thi-zhoæ´-zhoæ> to arouse; to arouse a person from a sound sleep [definition unconfirmed]. bríëàëà <bthi´-zhoæ-zhoæ> I aroused him by shaking him.

••• Cf. liëáëai. ðiëíce. V [sync., _ðiëíce] (intr.) break wind, fart (with a small noise, by letting the air out slowly) (FH).

••• QU ákkiëi fart, break wind (RR); KS áayüëìýe fart (with noise) (JOD, RR).

ðiëîðe (variants: ðiëî, ðiëîe). N your older brother (used only when speaking to a man) (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).  

ðiëîke. N your son; your brother's son (in both senses used when speaking to a man or to a woman, but its use for speaking to a woman may be more recent). (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok) (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125).  

••• Cf. ðihcóçka. 

ðiëóëi (variant of ðiçôëi, ðiiëóëi).

ðiëôà. N your older sister (used only when speaking to a woman ) (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).  

ðiëôke. N your daughter (used when speaking to a man or woman); your sister's daughter (used only when speaking to a woman; more specific than English 'niece'); your brother's daughter (used only when speaking to a man; more specific than English 'niece') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

ðì (variant of ði).

ðî. V [sync., _ðì; 2nd sg. usually nî, occasionally çcî or  ðanî; 1st sg. usually brî, occasionally mî or anî; 1st pl. waðî.] (intr.) be (a certain way). nâàke kØâsaaki brìe I'm a fast runner (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig). íe waská brî hta mìkçé I'll be the interpreter (RB; MSB/02/17/83). môpçe anî  I'm the elder (7/7/94/PM; 01/06/95/FH/pc:uk) wahóçce brîe I'm small (FH:08/05/99). scéce nî you're tall (02/25/83). íe waská ðáalì nîe you are a good interpreter (RB; MSB). ðóðo nî you're greasy (02/25/83). waëáëe nîpe? are you all Osage? waëáëe nîe ðatxâçe you're an Osage [standing]. ðíe nâàke kØâsaaki nîe you're a fast runner (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod. orig.). môpçe ðanî you're the elder (7/7/94/PM; 01/06/95/FH/pc:uk). wisôka akxa nâàke kØâsaakipe brother is a fast runner (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod. orig). scéce waðîpe we're tall. wahóçce àkai we're small (FH:08/05/99). • live as, exist as. hôòpa wîxci nâçki níhkaçi mî hkôbra I want to live [be a human] one dayat a time (RBn10-21). • be characterized by [the immediately preceding word or phrase, which may be a noun phrase]. wawéeðe hôòëi ðî he sees poorly (lit., 'he is characterized by bad sight')

ðìcéki. N your mother's brother, your maternal uncle (used by anyone speaking to a man or a woman) (02/27/95/JS/pc).

•• LFD 70: icéki <i-dse´-gi> uncle; father's or mother's brother (LFD 349: "on mother's side").

•• KS iýégi uncle, man's mother's brother.  

ðììké (variant: ììké). V [stat., _ðììké] [possibly from aðî 'have'+ ðìké NEG] (trans.) lack a thing, be devoid of, be lacking, not have s.t. any longer; have nothing. àðîìke I lack it. ðiðîìke you lack it. waðîìke we lack it. waðîìke we [two or more] don't have any (#90/FH). àðîìke I have none (RBn3-39). mâzeska àðîìke I don't have any money. wéðuwì ðìké atxâhe I have nothing to buy with (RBnB1-58). ðiðîìke you have none. mâzeska àðîìke I have no money (CQ ok; BE2.94). waðîìke apa there isn't any more (7/8/94/PM/#98b).

•• LFD 148: ðîke <thiæ´-ge> to have none, nothing. tátà àðìke <da´-doæ oæ-thiæ-ge> I have nothing. tátà ðiðìke <da´-doæ thi-thiæ-ge> you have nothing. tátà waðìka pe <da´-doæ wa-thiæ-ga i> we have nothing; to have none.

••• WI hììké. 

••• Cf. ðìké.

ðìká (variant: ìká). NEG [ðìké NEG + a IMPERATIVE MARKER] don't! ékiò ðìká don't do that (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). ékie ðìká don't say that (04/13/95/LS/pc:pl; RBn1-26). íixa ðìká don't laugh (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok [ã]). ðúwì ìká don't buy it (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). wéðuwì ìká don't sell it (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). íe ðìká don't talk (04/26/95/LS/pc). ììçtáxì íe ðìká don't talk

English. çkâ ìká don't move (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok; 04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). ãaaké ìká don't cry (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok). kaakòná kaaãái don't do that any more ('knock it off') (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.33).

ðìké (variant: ìké). V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) be none; be gone, absent, extinct, nonexistent, lacking. hcí wî pçíe, pée ðìké I went to the house, no one was there (BE2.157). wawéðe màëíe, ììçtóolà ðìké I can't see without my glasses (RB). Mary apa ðìkápi che, pçíe ðáha Mary was gone when I got there (FH/07/27/95/pc:prod). ðìkápi che, achíe ðáha it was already gone when he came in (MSB). záani ðìkée it's all gone (01/04/95/FH/pc). waëáëeíe ðìké ée ahípe the Osage language is all gone (01/06/95/FH/pc). hcí akxa ðìkí akxa that house doesn't exist any more. óohò akxa tooská ðìké áakxa the cook says there are no potatoes (RBnB1-43). • pass away, vanish. môëò ðáalì ðékçe môëò ðékçe ðìké hta aaëi íe wíhta çòòçôwe aðée hta akxai heaven and earth shall pass away but my word will endure (FH: from Matthew 24:35).• NEG not, not at all. wacØéàðe ðìké we don't kill at all.

•• LFD 148: ðîka pi a <thiæ´-ga bi a> there were none.

••• Cf. ðììké. 

ðìké hta. NEG + POTENTIAL MARKER won't. óxpaðe [ð]ìké hta apái he won't lose it (lit., 'he will not be losing stuff'). aðáaëi hta apai she won't go.

••• Cf. aëi hta. 

ðìkçé, ðìkçí (variants of ìkçé CONT, POSIT).

ðóðo. ADJ greasy. íhaa ðóðo greasy mouth (BE2.61). ðóðo nî you're greasy (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

• N stain (LF only).

•• LFD 154: ðóðo <tho´-tho> oily, greasy; a stain. waché ðà ðóðo aðaha akihpaãe <watse thoæ tho´-tho a-tha-ha a-gi-¼a-xe> I made my dress greasy (02/03/95/FH/pc:uk; LF sentence unconfirmed).

ðóha (variants: ðôha, ðôhà). ADV almost, nearly, about (to) (implies that the event is likely to occur). ðóha niiëú akxai it's about to rain (RBn3-52). ðóha àëîìhe I'm about asleep

(MREI/04/27/94). ðóha àëîìhe aðìkçe we two are about asleep (MREI/04/27/94). ðôha mîìoke sáhta ahí akxái it's almost five o'clock (01/04/95/FH/pc). ðôha nüëåpé it's about to rain; it's almost raining (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77; FH:okc). ðóha aðáape they're about ready to go (RBn22-10). ðóha aalépe I'm about to vomit (FH/06/27/01/pc). ðôha étxàpe it's almost time (01/04/95/FH/pc:okc:étkxà). oohô ðôha étxàpé it's almost time to cook (RBn3-moj/p21). ðòha oohô étxà akxái it's almost time to cook (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). waachí ðôhà éetkxà ahí akxai it's almost time for the dance (FH/t116b).

•• LFD 153: ðóha <tho´-ha> almost. ðóha alipe <tho´-ha a-gthi bi a> it is almost time for them to come home.

ðótaðe. V [reg., ðóta_ðe] (trans.) regard as a friend.

•• LFD 152, 271: ðótaðe <tho´-da-the> (be) friendly; be on friendly terms with another person; peaceful relationship between two tribes; reciprocity.

ðótahkiðe (variant: ðótahkie). V [reg., ðota_hkiðe] [hkik- RECIP + ðótaðe] (intr.) become acquainted with each other; make friends with each other, regard each other as friends, hold each other dear. ðótahkiðe they made friends, got acquainted (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.51: thó-tah-ki-eh, thó-tah-ki-théh). ðótahkie àðé we [two] made friends. ðótahkiape you all made friends. • take or regard each other as relatives, be related. Smokey, Eddie apa ðotahkie apai Smokey and Eddie are related (RBn22-17).

•• LFD 152: ðótahkie <tho´-da-Ði-e> reconcile, reconciliation [meaning unconfirmed, not accepted].

••• Cf. iiðótahkiðe.

ðóxe. N buffalo; Buffalo clan. ðóxe kahíke buffalo chief (BE2.13; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): ðóxe <¢u´-qe> buffalo with reddish-yellow hair and long legs.

•• LFD 154: ðóxe <tho´-xe> archaic name for buffalo bull.

••• QU toxe reddish yellow buffalo (RR); KS yoxe [no stress marked] reddish yellow buffalo (JOD, RR).

ðóxe kahíke. N Buffalo Chief (personal name). [Russell Koshehe Mashunkashey's name.]

ðôãu. N lung, lungs.

••• KS yáaãü lungs (RR); QU dáãi/dáãì lungs (RR).

ðôha, ðôhà (variants of ðóha).

ðòòpá (variant: ðòòpái [JS]). ADJ, N two; the two of them, both of them. waanáçe é[ð]òòpa àkále hta àðé Waanáçe and I are going home [the two of us]. • ADV twice. hòpái ðòòpá awánòbre I

ate twice today (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.146). hkáwa ðòòpá two horses.

•• LFD 153: ðòpá <thoæ-ba´> two. ðòpá ha <thoæ-ba´ ha> in two parts. ðòpá nàðe <thoæ-ba´ noæ-the> two at a time; two to each person; two by two.

ðòòpáha káaãe. VP (trans.) divide in two, halve (lit., make into two) (04/11/95/FH/pc:ok). LF153: ðòpáha kaxe <thoæ-ba´-ha ga-xe> to halve; to divide equally in two parts.

ðòòpái (variant of ðòòpá [JS]).

ðòòpátà. N twin, twins. (04/06/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 153: ðòpáta <thoæ-ba´-da> two-born, twins. LFD 112: nòpáta <noæ-ba´-da> born two.

ðu- (variants: ðuu-, ði-, ðii-). INSTR action by hand; cause, make (not necessarily by hand).

ðúuhpeece lighter (lit., 'make fire'). ðúulà make angry. ðuuçtáko make neat, straighten.

ðuatáaëe (variant of ðuutáaëi).

ðúbra (variant of ðíbra).

ðuðáalì. V [sync., _ðuðáalì] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + ðáalì] (trans.) make good; fix, remedy; bless. ónòbre che çcuðáalì bless this food.  

ðúeëi. V [sync., _ðúeëi] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + éëi] (trans.) change (lit., 'make different'). waðílà ðúeëipe he changed his mind (FH:prod). áëà çäúeëi you changed the bed (FH:prod).

ðúãe (variant: ðíãe). V [sync., _ðúãe] (trans.) mate, take as a sexual partner. htáa kiðíãepi deer mating moon; October.

••• Cf. wáðuãe. ðuháaçìðe. V [sync., _ðuháaçìðe] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + háaçìðe] (trans.) make inside out, turn wrong side out (RBn10-15).

ðuhcépe. V [sync., _ðuhcépe] (trans.) lift. îì htà kootáha wáli lâàðe, ðuhcépe ìká that big rock over there is really big, don't lift it (FH/09/25/01/pc). tôpa îì htà, çäúhcepe ðààché ìké watch out with that big rock, you can't lift it (FH/09/25/01/pc). • handle, deal with, manage. brúhcepe hta atxâhe I can handle it (9RBn, MREI/01/11/83; FH:okc). wakØó wì oðáhkie çäúhcepe ðààché? is there a chance that you can handle it with that woman you talked to? (FH/09/25/01/pc).

ðuhkîki (variant of ðuuhkíhkì).

ðuhpáahà. V [sync., _ðuhpáða] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + hpaahâ] (trans.) raise. cØé çki çô ìkçe çcúhpaahà nìkçé aapai they said you raised the dead.

ðuhpíiëi. V [sync., _ðuhpíiëi] (trans.) harm, do harm to; make s.t. bad; ruin. hpéecenii akxa ëúoka ðíðuhpíiëi hta akxái whiskey is bad for your health (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; reprod; RBnot 5/3/79/p3; BE2.30). omíëe ðuhpíiëipi ìkçe they have ruined the rug. ëìkáëì apa taðúhpiiëipé, omíëi ðuhpíiëipi ìkçé children are destructive, they have ruined the rug (RBn24).

•• LFD 148: ðihpíëi <thi-¼i´-zhi> to ruin; damage; defilement (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok); to spoil; to ruin by tearing, cutting, or burning [the word actually does not imply any specific sort of causation such as cutting, burning, or tearing]. bríhpiëi <bthi´-¼i-zhi> I ruined it by cutting. àðíhpipaëi <oæ-thi´-¼i-ba-zhi> we ruined it by cutting.

ðuhtáëa. V [sync., _ðuhtáëa] (intr.) protrude or stick out in a round shape (e.g., have one's rear end sticking out) (RB; 2-10-83-p1).

••• KS ttáãe (ttáaãe?) protrude (RR). 

ðuhúce, ðúhuuce, ðuhúuce (variants of ðuuhúuce).

ðuléke (variant of ðuuléke).

ðumáða. V [sync., _ðumáða] (trans.) lift, hold high, raise up, turn up (RBn19-05). wéeli ðumâða ðíape she held her head high.

ðupáxa. V [sync., _ðupáxa] (trans.) pull apart; tear apart (e.g., a tree limb from the trunk) (01/19/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 144: ðipáxe <thi-ba´-xe> to break a string in half. bripáxe <bthi-ba´-xe> I broke the string in two. àðípaxa pe <oæ-thi´-ba-xa i> we broke the string in two.

ðupØîpØìze. V [sync., _ðupØîpØìze] [reduplicated form of ðupØîze] (intr.) blink repeatedly (FH).

ðupØîze. V [sync., _ðupØîze] (intr.) close one's eyes, blink.

ðusáaki. V [sync., _ðusáaki] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + saakí] (trans.) shock, stun, instill fear in (01/26/95/FH/pc:prod orig). ðâàce ðusáaki kçíape it [e.g., a fire in which his home or car burned up] instilled fear in him; it stunned him; it shocked him (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; FH).

••• Cf. ðâàce ðuusáaki. ðusâsàwì. V [sync.?, _ðusâsàwì] (trans.) twist, twist around (e.g., a crepe paper streamer); shake; turn over and over.

ðuçkápa. V [sync., _ðuçkápa] (trans.) carry s.o. who has his/her arms around one from the back, carry piggyback; swim supporting a child in the water.

ðuçpú. V [sync., _ðuçpú] shell, as corn. hápa brúçpu I shelled the corn. • ADJ shelled, as of corn.

hápa ðuçpú che ápçe I pounded the shelled corn.

•• LFD 149: ðiçpí <thi-shpi´> to shell corn.

••• QU diçpí shell corn (RR); diçpé pull off something adhering (RR).

••• Cf. páaçpue. 

ðutáahpa V [sync., _ðutaahpa] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + táahpa] (trans.) make round. hpáxì ðutáahpa a bun [woman's hairdo] (lit., 'hair made round') [also recorded as hpáxì ðuutáahpa]. wacúe ðutáahpa biscuits (lit., 'bread made round').

ðuu- (variant of ðu-).

ðuuáze. V [sync., _ðuuáze] (trans.) open (e.g., a door, a window, the lid on a box). hciëé ðuuáza open the door (BE2.98). okáhàpa záani ðuuáza open all the windows (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc; RBnB1-52; BE2.159).

••• QU diáze pull open (RR).

ðuucØáke. V [sync., _ ðuucØáke] (trans.) be unable to do, fail at (FH/07/02/01/pc). ðíihà ðuucØáki akxái he is unable to lift it (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; 04/06/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.147). brúucØake I can't (FH/06/16/01/pc). àðúucØake we can't (FH/06/16/01/pc). ðiihâ ðuucØáke akxai they can't lift it (RBn10-12:JW). wáali óchiëe çkáaãe, àkóhkihkie àðúucØake you're making too much noise, we can't even converse (02/27/95/FH/pc; BE2.94). waxpéì àkái, ókØu àðúucØake çe nààhtâhtàà oðúucØake wî we're too poor to feed that lazy donkey (lit., 'we are poor, that donkey who was lazy, we are unable to feed him') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). íe ðuucØáki apai he is unable to speak. hpéece çkáaãe çäuucØake tà, opíãà if you can't start the fire, blow on it (FH/11/19/01/pc). hpéece çäúucØake tà ópiãà íkØuca if you can't start the fire,

try blowing on it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). • go set, as in a card game (RBn10-21/JW).

brúucØake màëí I didn't go set (RBn10-21/JW).

••• Cf. óðuucØake. ðuuhépe. V [sync., _ðuuhépe] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + hépe] (trans.) lighten, make lighter or smaller.

••• Cf. hkilúuhepe. 

ðuuhkáamà (variant: ðuuhkâàmà). V [sync., _ðuuhkáamà ] (trans.) ring; ring the bell; press the doorbell.

•• JOD (slip file): ðuhkámà <¢ü-ka´-maæ> v. of kamà; to ring, as a bell, by pulling a rope. íikahtamà brúhkamà hta mìkçé <í§katamaæ §p¢ukamaæ ta-miñ´kci au> I will ring the bell. [Sentence-final <au> is not used in Modern Osage.]

ðuuhkíhkì (variant: ðu(u)hkîki). V [sync., _ ðuuhkíhkì] [possibly ðu-/ði- INSTR + hkíhkìnì (borrowed from English kinky?)] (trans.) curl (as a person's hair); make curly. hpaxîì ðuuhkíhkì apai they're curling their hair (FH/4/17/96/tape,4/22/96/tape).

ðuuhpéece. N [ðu-/ði- INSTR + hpéece] lighter, flashlight, match. htáwà ki çäée tà ðúuhpeece tóe aðîli when you go to town, bring back some matches (RBn12-07; BE2.85; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 148: ðihpece <thi-¼e-dse> a match (localism).

ðuuhúuce (variants: ðuhúuce, ðúhuuce, ðíhuuce, ðuhúce). V [sync., _ðuhúuce] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + húuce] (trans.) pull down; lower by pulling (e.g., a window shade); take down, remove (from a high place such as a shelf or from the wall, such as pictures). oðókinààëî ðuuhúuce pull your pants down. brúuhuuce I took it down (FH/06/16/01/pc).

ðuuláwa. V [sync., _ðuuláwa] (trans.) spread, spread out (e.g., a tarpaulin, a blanket, corn to be dried). ðuuláwa spread it out (BE2.126; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 146: ðiláwa <thi-gtha´-wa> to stretch a rope; to stretch. brílawa weðìkçe <bthi´gtha-wa we-thiæ-kshe> I stretched the rope. àðílawa pe weðìkçe <oæ-thi´-gtha-wa pe wethiæ-kshe> [expected Mod. Os. form: wéðì kçe àðúulawape] we stretched the rope [lying there].

ðúulà. V [sync., _ðúulà] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + ólà] (trans.) make angry (FH: prod).

ðuuléke (variant: ðuléke). V [sync., _ðuuléke] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + léke] (trans.) cause to break, cause to shatter; break or shatter with the hands (e.g., a dish, an egg, a lightbulb, a window) (RBn22-03). brúulekei I shatter it. çcúuleke you shatter it. ðuuléke she shatters it. àðúuleke we shatter it. hììcé ðuuléke che someone broke a dish [and it's there to see]

(01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). okáhàpa ðuuléke chí áape they said that that window is broken (01/07/95/FH/pc). hcéheëì ðúuleke they broke the dishes (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). aa çäúuleke you broke your arm (04/19/95/FH/pc). axíða áha, aa brúuleke when I fell down, I broke my arm (04/19/95/FH/pc). ðuuléka break it in two (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). hpáata tóa ðuuléka break some eggs (to cook) (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.11).

ðuumâçi (variant: ðuumáçi). V [sync., _ðuumâçi] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + mâçi] (trans.) pull up; hold up, raise, lift (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). ìché waléze çäúumaçi hta nìkçe you'll hold up the picture. okáhàpa ðuumáçi! raise the window! (BE2.79; (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). okáhàpa akáspe ðuumâçi raise the window shade.

ðuupxáðe. V [sync., _ðuupxáðe] (trans.) find out (e.g., about s.o.'s activities); investigate (e.g., by questioning) (FH:prod).

••• Cf. waðúupxai, wáopxá. 

ðuusé. V [sync., _ ðuusé] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + se (root not found as an independent word)] (trans.) cut (e.g., with scissors). hpáxì brúuse I cut my hair (FH/07/09/01/pc).

ðuustáko. V [sync., _ ðuustáko] (trans.) straighten; straighten out, arrange, tidy, tidy up; smooth out (e.g., one's clothes, icing on a cake, one's hair with a hand, comb, or brush, or the soil after planting seeds); straighten up (e.g., the rows when planting a garden)

(03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). wéhkilì ðuustáko straighten up your clothes (BE2.92; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; RBn2-moj/p20). hci ðuustáko straighten up the house (WHM981119; FH:ok). hci çäúustako you straightened up your house. íe ðuustáko straighten that word out (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). hpáxì ðuustáko comb your hair (FH).

ðuuçáake. V [sync., _ ðuuçáake] (trans.) pull out multiple (long?) pieces from or of s.t. (e.g., yank out all of one's hair); husk (corn), pick or pluck (a chicken), peel (a banana); strip, denude. hpáxì ðuuçáake pulling someone's hair out. súhka ðuuçáaka pick/pluck the chicken!

htóëàke ðuuçáaka peel the bananas!

ðuuçáwa. V [sync., _ðuuçáwa] (trans.) undress, take clothes off (another person or oneself) (FH). [Despite its apparent meaning, the verb is not reflexive or suus in form.] brúuçawa hta mìkçé I'm going to undress him. brúuçawa I'm going to take these clothes off [myself].

•• LFD 148: ðiçáe <thi-sha´-e> to divest, to undress. bríçae <bthi´-sha-e> I undress.

àðiçaape <oæ-thi´-sha-a i> we undress. [If the LF forms are essentially correct, then ðuuçáwa and ðuuçáwì probably developed from ðuuçá-e with epenthetic w.]

ðuuçáwì. V [sync., _ðuuçáwì] (trans.) tie up; restrain by tying (e.g., a belligerent or uncontrollable person) (RB, unconfirmed; FH rejects the translation 'tie up'); take off a person's clothes (e.g., a child's clothing before a bath); undress s.o.; denude (FH). ðuuçáwì take off his clothes (FH/t116b).

ðuuçkáke (variants: ðuuçká, ðúuçka). V [sync., _ ðuuçkáke] (trans.) untie (e.g., a horse).

•• LFD 350: ðuçké <thu-shke´> to untie a knot. LFD 28: brúçke î to <bthu´-shke iæ do> [sentence-final ì to is not used in Mod. Os.] I untie the knot. LFD 149: ðiçke <thi-shke> to untie a knot. bríçke <bthi´-shke> I untied the knot. àðíçka pe <oæ-thi´-shka i> we untied the knot.

ðuuçkâ (variant: ðiiçkâ). V [sync., _ðuuçkâ] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + çkâ] (trans.) start (e.g., a car motor); place in operation. oðíhtà ðuuçkâ? did he start the car? oðíhtà ðuuçkâ ðuucØáki apai he can't get his car started (FH/09/24/01/pc).

ðuuçkí (variant of ðiiçkí).

ðuuçô (variant: ðiiçô). V [sync., _ðuuçô] (trans.) bend one's limb or body part (e.g., leg or arm). ëeká bríiçò I bend my leg (021083). áa âðiiçòpé they bend my arm (021083). çáake ðiisô! 

bend your hand! (021083 p4).  

••• Cf. ðiizó. 

ðuuçtá. V [sync., _ðuuçtá] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + çtáha] (trans.) make bald or bare, jerk s.o.'s hair out; denude.

•• LFD 148: ðistâ <thi-sda´> to pull the grass until the ground becomes bare, to pluck the beard and eyebrows until the skin becomes bare.

••• Cf. ðuuçtáçtai, hpeeçtá.

ðuuçtáha. V [sync., _ðuuçtáha] [ðu- INSTR + çtáha] (trans.) iron. hâàpa záani wabrúuçtaha I ironed all day.

••• Cf. waðúuçtaha. 

ðuuçtáka. V [sync., _ðuuçtáka] [presumably ðu-/ði- + çtáke] (trans.) calm (FH:4/22/96/tape:ok).

ðuuçtáke. V [sync., ðuuçtáke] (trans.) undress, relieve s.o. of clothing. âðuçtake she undressed me. ákahamì ëúuce ðée pée ðuuçtáke hta ðe? who is going to undress that one with the red coat on? (refers to receiving a wedding coat when the drum is being paid for).  

••• Cf. ðuuçtá, hkilúuçtake. 

ðuuçtáçtai. V [sync., _ðuuçtaçtai] [reduplicated form, probably of ðuuçtá] (trans.) jerk hair out with repeated motion; make bald by plucking out hair over and over (RB).

ðuuçúpe (variant of ðiiçúpe).  

ðuutáaëi (variants: ðiitáaëi, ðuatáaëe [HRE]). V [sync., _ ðuutáaëi] [ðu-/ði- INSTR + táaëi] (trans.) turn off, switch off; extinguish. hpéece ðuutáaëi, átahkai ðuutáaëi put out the fire and turn off the light (RBn HW).

•• LFD 36–37: hpéce britaëi ha <¼e´-dse bthi-da-zhi ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I extinguished the fire. hpéce àðitaëi pe <¼e´-dse oæ-thi-da-zhi i> we extinguished the fire.

ðuuwásu (variants: ðuuwási, ðuuwássu). V [sync., _ðuuwásu] (trans.) clean up; cleanse; clean, disinfect (e.g., a buffalo hide) (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). hcí ðuuwásu ðí clean the house [sg. addressee] (BE2.19). ðâàce, waðílà, waçcúuwasupi tà as you cleanse our hearts and minds.

haxî kóoci çäúuwasu tà wíe paçôwe if you'll clean that oldtime blanket, I'll bind it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). brúuwasu tà ðíe paçôwa if I clean it, you bind it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).  

••• Cf. hkilúuwasu, wasúhu. 

ðuuxô (variant of ðiixô).

ðuuxpáðe (variant: ðuuxpáði). V [sync., _ðuuxpáðe] (trans.) lose s.t.

••• Cf. lúuxpaðe, oxpáðe. 

ðuuxpáwì (variant of ðuxpáwì).

ðuuzáëi. V [sync., _ðuuzáëi] [ðuuzé + aëí NEG] (trans.) reject (lit., 'not take') (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 145: ðíza ëi <thi´-ša zhi> to reject. brísa màëi <bthi´-ša moæ-zhi> I reject. àðisa paëi pe <oæ-thi-ša ba-zhi i> we reject.

ðuuzé (variants: ðúuze, ðuuzí). V [sync., _ðuuzé] (trans.) select, choose; take; get; draw (water), gather or pick (e.g., fruit). brúuze hta mìkçe I'm going to take it (03/07/95/FH/pc). hkâàce hîçäe tóe ðuuzá help yourself to the peaches, take some peaches (03/07/95/FH/pc). wîxci ðuuzá choose one (03/07/95/FH/pc; BE2.102). nâãe toa ðuuzá get [take] some ice

(01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). íhkihkawi hpáaãe àëi mâzeska brúuze mìkçé I exchanged it, but I took money (1/20/83/631; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). hkâàcezi záani ðuuzí akxái wáli wawálì akxai she took all the oranges, she's really stingy (04/26/95/FH/pc). níi ðúuza draw water (FH; ok). íe ðíhta wíbruuze hta mìkçé I'll take your word for it (FH). ðuuzá take it away

(FH/09/23/01/pc:prod). ëâàxe ëì ðuuzái cØéða xci take a stick and just almost kill someone (FH:prod).

•• LFD 154: ðuzé <thu-še´> to take; to receive or accept. brúze <bthu´-še> I take. 

àðúza pe <oæ-thu´-ša i> we take.  

••• Cf. kiðúuze, kilúuze, lúuze. 

ðuuëá (variants: ðuëáawa, ðuuëâ). V [sync., _ðuuëá] (trans.) wash (e.g., dishes, parts of the body, food items, a car) (03/16/95/JS/pc; FH:3/21/96). çáake ðuuëá hkôbra I want to wash my hands (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc). hòpái ðòòpái hîìce wábruuëa I washed dishes twice today (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). hîìce çki wábruuëa I washed dishes, too (RBn3-15). oðíhtà wíhta akxa wasúhuëi akxa hàðé çäúuëa ðààché? my car is dirty, could you wash it this evening? (FH/06/26/01/pc). ée ðuuëá wash this (RBnB1-50). hòbrîke ðuuëá wash those green beans (FH/06/16/01/pc). sí àðúuëa wash my feet (RB; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). hkâàce ðuuëâ wash the apples.

••• KS yüëá wash something (RR).

ðuuëóëi (variant of ðiiëóëi).

ðuwáçtake (variant of ðiwáçtake).

ðúwe. N waist; diaphragm; ribcage (BE2.150; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; WF).

•• LFD 150: ðúwe <thiu´-we> the waist; the body, from the armpits down to the hips (03/10/95/FH/pc:ok).

ðúwenie. N [ðúwe + níe] pneumonia (lit., 'diaphragm hurt') (BE2.105; 03/10/95/FH/pc:ok; BF/12/30/01).

ðuwî (variant: ðúwì). V [sync., _ðuwî] (trans.) buy. brúwì atxàhé I am buying it. brúwì hkôbra ðîke I don't want to buy it (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). brúwì ðààché ìké, mâzeska éenà abrì màëí I am unable to buy it, I don't have enough money (01/09/95/FH/pc:okc). owé ðúwì brée I'm going to buy groceries. ëìkáëi hkâàce wábruwì brée I'm going to buy the kids some apples. brúwì I bought it. brúwì hce let me buy. brúwì ðálì I ought to buy. wî àðúwi ðáalì we ought to buy one (108-b/FH/322). brúwì hkôbra ðîke I don't want to buy it (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). hówaiki çäúwuì where did you buy it? (BE2.15). çcúwì? did you buy it? hkâàce záani àðúwì hce let's buy all the apples. waskú tóa àðúwi ðáalì we ought to buy some fruit. sáhku wì àðúwì hcé let's buy a watermelon. ðúwì you buy it. ðúwì ìká don't you buy it. ðúwì ðî ìká! don't you buy it! (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; FH/07/02/01/pc). hpáze wanôbre ówe brúwì ókxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (04/19/95/FH/pc:okc). hpáze wanôbre ówe ðuwî ókxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (04/19/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 151: ðiwî <thi-wiæ´> to purchase; to buy; to get by exchange of money for article. bríwì <bthi´-wiæ> I purchase. hcíche brìwì hta ahtà hi o <¾si´-tse bthiæ-wiæ ¾a a-¾oæ hi o> [expected Mod. Os. form: hcí che brúwì hta àtxáhe; sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I will purchase a house. hcíche scìwì hta ðahtà çi a? <¾si´-tse stsiæ-wiæ ¾a tha-¾oæ shi a?> [expected Mod. Os. form: hcí che çcúwì hta ðatxáçe?] will you purchase the house?

••• Cf. kíðuwì, lúwì, waðúwì. 

ðuxí. V [sync., _ðuxí] (trans.) chase. çôke apa màçäîka ðuxí apai the dogs were chasing the rabbits.

ðuxí (variant of ðixí).

ðuxpáwì (variant: ðuuxpáwì). V [sync., _ðuxpáwì] (trans.) lift off; remove, take down (e.g., from a shelf or the back of a truck); unload (FH/pc).

••• Cf. oxpáðe.

ðuëáawa (variant of ðuuëá).

ðuëóëi (variant of ðiiëóëi).

é (variant of ðe DECL, ée). éàkiò. V [1st pl. of ékiò] (trans.) we do.

ecí. V [uninfl.] (intr.) be present here/there, exist here/there; be at that time (RBn12-10/MJ). howâàìki ðòòpá ðáabrì náçki ecíe akxa tà, wíe ée brî hta mìkçé na ée eçíe wherever two or three only are, I will always be there, you said (citing a verse of the Christian Bible) (FH:prayer). ecíke the things that are there, these things [around] here. táatà hôòëi ecíkie tà ékiò ðìkápai if there's anything bad around, don't do that. níi ecí hta in the water there (RBn10-10:JW). môëò ðáalì kçi ðakçi tà, níhkaçi lâàðe tóa ecí akxai when you get to that good land, there are some great men there [spoken to the deceased]. táatà záani ecí che? is everything there? (RBn12-11). táatà záani ée ecí che? is everything there [ready]? (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). óhkà ecí che? is there room over there? omâìhka haaçíhta ecí che same place as last year (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc). ecí tà if it's there. ecíkie they are around. táatà hôòëì ecíkie there are bad things around; there is evil around. ecí hta nìkçé? will you be there? (1/2/132).

•• ecí màðì <e-dsi´ moæ-thiæ> go there. ecí ëi ðe ðìke <e-dsi´ zhi the thiæ-ge> one who is never absent. ecíhi <e-dsi´-hi> when that happens, when I get there. ecítxà <e-dsi´-toæ> thence, from that place. ecí txà ðeðe <e-dsi´ toæ the-the> thenceforth. eci, ha <e-dsi, ha> thither.  

éci. CONJ and (in numbers only), plus. lébrà huuëî ðòòpá éci wîxci two hundred and one

(04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). lébrà ðòòpá éci wîxci twenty-one (lit., 'twenty and one') (05/02/95/LS/pc). éci wîxci plus one.

ecí che. VP [uninfl.] (intr.) be definitely decided. ëóàhkile ecí che it's final that we're to be married. â, ékiò ðe hta ché okay, we'll do it (RBn17-p03).

••• Cf. ðée hta ché. 

ecí mìkçé. VP there where I am, my home (similar to French chez moi). ecí mìkçé ecí ëówaðale ðalíe ðe you brought them [people] home to me.

ecí pa. PRNP, ADVP them, those who are there/here; there where they are, the place where they are/were, at their place or their home (similar to French chez eux). ecí pa ëóàðale çíe ðe you went with me to them, you brought me to them, to where they were, to their place.

ecíke (variant: ecíkie). V [uninfl.] there are, there exist scattered around or dispersed.

éðe (variant: ée). V [sync., é_ðe] (trans.) think about, consider, believe (RBn12-10mj). môëò ðáalì kçi, ecí ðakçí ébre hta mìkçé to that good land, I'm going to think that's where you went (back to). súhka mîka äáahpaëì, màhî apa ohcíle ðáalìpe, ecíe ska ébre mìkçé the little hen [said], hay is good for a nest, I'm thinking it's there (RBn19-04). iihò akxa htáëì ohtáza môëò záani éwa[ð]e his mother thought that he was the most beautiful little deer in the world.

••• Cf. ékiðe.

éðòòpa (variant of éeðòòpa).

ée (variant: é). PRON 3rd person emphatic or contrastive pronoun (that one, that person, she/her, he/him; those persons, them; this [pragmatically obvious] person or thing; the foregoing; she herself, he himself, they themselves). ée kípà káaãa make her invite him. ée wáapà káaãa make her invite them. wihtéëì akxa ée akxai this is my younger sister (RBn12-03p2). ée

ékimà I did this (RBn22-06). howâìki waçcíhtà ðáìçe? ówehci ée é where are you working? the grocery store, that's it (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). Maggie ée htá ìkçé it's Maggie's turn (lit., 'Maggie, she's going to be it'). ée ékiò hta apai he'll do it himself (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). ée ékiò apai he's doing it himself (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

••• Cf. tówa.

ée. V [sync. h-stem, é_(h)e] (trans.) say. çîtoëì íhkimàì híðe, iiðáðe hta mìkçé ée ðí áape I will find it, said the boy who had come to visit (RBn19-05;CQ:okc). ée eçí áape they said you said (FH 8/8/94/pc). ðíe éwie mìkçé I mean you [pointing at the person] (RBn10-18). eçéçe you keep saying. ékò ékipçe mìkçé? am I saying that right? (RB). háakò ìkçé ékipçe çkôçta? what is it you want me to say? (RB). ékò ékiçe you said it right (RB). háakòta çée éçe? why did you say that? (RB). waëáëeíe çée ékia say that in Osage (RBn11-02/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976). íiðaxopeëi éçe you said that you didn't lie (RB). naço "àhái" áaapi at least you all could say "yes" [speaking to women] (lit., 'leastways say "yes"!') (RB). kóoci waëáëi ée ékia nàpe that's what old time Osages used to say (RB). Dave akxa íe ðìkí ape Dave didn't say anything (RB). ékie ðìká don't say that (RB; CQc). çí ékia say that again (RB). lúëe íe say it slow (RB). waëáëeíe háakò eçé nàpe? how do you say that in Osage? (RB, CQ/okc/02). haakô épçe? how do I say? (HH/14-a/172ff&pc). haakô éeçe? how do you say? (HH/14-a/172ff&pc). ðâàce saakí káaãapi ée nàpé make your hearts strong, he used to say (RBn HW-MREI). ée háakò eçé nàpé? how do you say that? ìhtáci wahkôta, mâëà ðáalì ìkçi ðaníhkaçi nìkçí eepe our father, who art in heaven. • ask or tell s.o. to do s.t. wiëîke oðíhka hce épçe I asked Sonny to help you.

•• LF 40: e <e> to say. epçe <e-pshe> I say. eçe <e-she> you say. eàkiðà pe <e-oægi-thoæ i> we said.

••• Cf. ékie, hce ée.

ée htáha. ADV in the direction of, toward that direction, over there, along that way. Brian akxa mààëâãe tóa ðiiãóão nà oðíhtà ci ée htáha Brian keeps dragging those onions to put them in the car (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). • toward that time, in that time, near that time. hôòpa wî páðe ée htáha one day toward winter, one winter day (RBn16-02).

ée htáhaëi. ADJ, ADV wrong, out of reason, unlikely, unsuitably, unreasonable, unreasonably; off the subject, pointlessly (lit., 'not toward there') (RBn1-56). ée htáhaëi ékie they are talking way off the subject (05/02/95/LS/pc). í[e] htahaëi íape he talked wrong (LS: prod; BE2.143; 03/23/95/FH/pc:uk; RBn1-MOJ/p56; 03/23/95/FH/pc:uk). ée htáha aëi ékia they're talking out of reason, way off the subject.

ée kçe. PRONP [ée 'that one' + kçe POSIT] that one lying down (animate or inanimate).

éeðòòpa (variant: éðòòpa). ADJ, PRON group including just-mentioned individual(s) (can sometimes be translated as 'both', 'all', 'and another', 'and others', or as 'and I' when followed by a verb with 1st pl. inflection). wiëôa éeðòòpa àkáhi sister and I went over there (lit., 'sister and another we went there') (01/31/95/FH/pc:prod orig). háachi wiëîke wisôka éeðòòpa àkaazà àkai wisôka [my younger brother] and I are always bawling out Sonny [wiëîke]. Stephanie, David, éeòòpa àkále hta àkáðe Stephanie, David, and I are going home. Jane, Ann éðòòpa màëâ hta íihkimai ahíe ðí áape Jane and Ann had come to visit the farm (FH). çôke wíhta akxa hkáwa, hceeská éðòòpa owákaça nàpé my dog takes care of horses and cows (RBn12-03). kîìkììeëì hlaaskáëì éeðòòpa ôòðe aðáape he went leaving [both] the flowers and butterflies behind (RBn15-03). hkóða éeðòòpa àkáðe àðìkçé my friend and I are going.  

•• LFD 89: hkóða eðòpa <Ðo´-tha e-thoæ-pa> my friend and I [rather, '(my) friend and

another (not necessarily I)'].

éehna (variant of eená).

éehtanà (variant of éetana [possibly future form]).

eekô (variant of ékò).

eekô ðìké. ADJ unsound; not right; wayward. waðílà eekô ìkí apai his mind isn't right; he's wayward (FH/pc). ókØà eekô ìké wayward deeds, acts that are not right or suitable.

 ••• Cf. waðílà eekô ìké.

éekxà (variant of éetxà).

eená (variants: éena, éhna, éehna, eenâ). V [inalien.] (intr.) be the only (one). wahkôta akxa eená hta akxa nà, hpahâle mêì, ahkílaðìpai soon it will be only God, put him first, carry yourself that way (04/04/99/FH/pc). ðée eenâ aape they said it's the only way (lit., 'that is the only one, they said') (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). winâ it is only I. ðinâ it is only you. eená/eenâ it is only she. àkónà it is only we. • PRONP therefore, that's why (RBn3-02). hààcí opáwìãe pçíe, éena ìçtáha cØóka I went riding last night, that's why I'm sleepy. çímiëì ókülà kôða tà, éena htâwàkçi pçíe the girls want some clothes, that's why I went to town. céepe hpíiëi kçíape waðáahtà çtà éhna he has a bad liver because he's always drinking. çímiëì apá ìcé káaãe éena wáli wascúutape the girls put on their makeup, that's why they're very slow (BE2.137). • that only. éena âtàhe mìkçé that's the only thing that pleases/satisfies me. • ADJ enough. brúwì ðààché ìké, mâzeska éenà abrî màëí that's enough, I am unable to buy it, I don't have enough money (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok; 01/09/95/FH/pc:okc).  

eenâtòìpe (variant: eenâØtôìpi). N Looking Only at Her, Look Only at Her (name for a second daughter in hcíëo clan) (HRE/pc/12/02). [Name of Jo Ann Shunkamolah Alred.]

eenâëi. ADJ [eená + aëí NEG] insufficient, not enough. mâzeska éenàëi akxai there's not enough money (FH/09/23/01/pc). mâzeska sáhta àkØú kôða akxai, àëi éenààëî akxai he wanted to give me five [dollars] but he didn't have enough (lit., '. . . but it was insufficient') (FH/09/23/01/pc). mâzeska àkáaãe àkóða akakxái àëi htóoëu éenààëî káaãi akxai we wanted to make some money, but he didn't make enough meat pies (FH/09/23/01/pc).

eenâØtôìpi (variant of eenâtòìpe).

éepe (variant of áape). REPORTATIVE they/he or she said, it is said, known by hearsay.

éeçe. INTERJ golly (slang) (04/06/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p5).

eeçkí (variant of éçki).

eeçkítà (variants: eeçkíta, eeçkí, éeçki). PRON he/she too, it too, they too (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.67). nôò apa eeçkíta íixa apa the grownups laughed too (lit., 'the grownups, they too laughed') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). wihé oáhkà eeçkítà àwâhkà nàpé when I help second daughter, she helps me (2-1-G).

•• RB: <eh-shkí>.

•• LFD 41, 132: eçki <e-shki>, eçkí <e-shki´> he, she, or it too.

••• Cf. çki. 

éetana (variants: éetànà, éehtanà). CONJ that is why, therefore, thus, so (FHt#128). opáwìãe pçíe éetana âçkike I went riding and that is why I'm tired (LH 07/18/96:tape). hkâàcezi ánòbre áëu nàpé éetana brúwì they usually put oranges on the table, that's the reason I bought some (FHt#128). éwahkikØò akxai, éetana ðakØéðe ìká don't pity him because he did it himself (FHt#128). hobrîke oowáhà hta mìkçé kasî, éehtanà hâðe brúuwasú hta nî oowáëu hta I'm going to cook beans tomorrow, therefore tonight I'll clean them and put them in water.

éetxà (variants: éetxa, éetkxà, éekxà). V [uninfl.] (intr.) it is time. ðôha éetkxàpe it's almost time (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). waachí ðôhà éetkxàpe it's almost time to dance (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). hápa óoëu éetkxà akxái it's time to plant corn (03/22/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.141). • N time, the moment for s.t. ónalì, étkxà akxa ahí akxai hurry up, it is time (lit., 'hurry, the time has arrived') (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/22/95/FH/pc). • ADV when (lit., 'at the time that'). • PRON that (standing animate).

•• LFD 40: etxà <e-doæ> when. (Frequently found in rituals.)

éewò (variant: éewà). V [3rd sg. of éò] (trans.) he does (it), he did (it) (FHt#128:prod).

éeëi (variant: éëi). ADJ odd, unusual, of a different kind, inappropriate, unsuitable (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc); different, other, otherwise, strange. tówa níhka hpá éeëi apái that man has an odd-looking nose (lit., 'that one man is characterized by an odd nose') (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.97). bra éëi smells odd (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.124). kîkìeëì hîì éëi kíhòpe he liked the different colors of the butterflies (RBn15-02). brâ éeëi [he/she/it] smells strange (03/02/95/FH/pc). súhkahtâà mîìka éëipa wáðihota ìkçe ípahò ìkçi aape turkey hen knew she had done everything she could to fool the others (RBn19-05). éëiçki húheka the others [also] who are sick.

•• LFD 42: éëi <e´-zhi> not that kind. éëi kaãe <e´-zhi ga-xe> to make different. éëi hpaãe <e´-zhi ¼a-xe> I made different. éëi çkaãe <e´-zhi shka-xe> you made different. éëi àkaãa pe <e´-zhi oæ-ga-xa i> we made different. éëi hkihkaãe <e´-zhi Ði-Ða-xe> to disguise one's self. éëi ahkihpaãe ha <e´-zhi a-Ði-¼a-xe ha>  [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.]  I disguised myself. éëi ðahkiçkaãe ha <e´-zhi tha-Ði-shka-xe ha>  [sentencefinal ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you disguised yourself. eëi ohkâci <e-zhi o-Ðoæ´-dsi> separate, distinct, belonging to another class.  

éhkiò. V [sync. nasal vowel stem, éhki_ò] [hkik- REFL + éò] do to oneself, do s.t. without listening to advice, "go overboard," doing s.t. to excess while paying no heed to others (FHt#128). éehkiëòe, éetana ðakØéðe océ ìká you did it yourself so don't look for pity (FHt#128).

••• Cf. éwahkikØò.

éhna (variant of eená).

éhtaha. PPN toward (FH:t119a).

ehtâ. INTERJ well. ehtâ, ówò hta mìkçé well, I'll be busy (RBn2-MOJ/p20). éhtà, àkáaëi hta mìkçé well, I'll drive (RBn10-12:JW).

ékene. N Aiken (surname). ékene akxa hkáwa ëúuce níðape Aiken gave the red horse away (words to Aiken song) (BE2.55).

ékiðe. V [sync., éki_ðe; inflection may be absent in 1st pl. form] [possibly ki- DAT or INCEPTIVE + éðe] think about, consider, think so. ékibra màëíe I don't care to, I don't want to (lit., 'I don't think that'). àkóe ékiðaapaëíe we don't think so (RBn15-01). ékiðe àkáðe we [three or more] are thinking about doing it. ékibre ìké I don't care to, I don't want to. ékiçtaëi nìkçé you don't think so.

ékie. V [sync. h-stem, éki_(h)e] [ki- DAT + ée 'say'] (trans.) say. çee ékia àkái that's what we

said (LS:prod). ékie ée ðe they said he's saying that (FH:prod). ekíape they said. ékie ðìká! don't say that! ée ékiapi ó [archaic form; Mod. Os. would have final ape rather than api ó] he said it [man's way of speaking] (RBn22-06). éàkie we say (FH/09/11/01/pc). íe tóa ékipçe hta, ówaçtake hkôbra I'm going to say something, I want you to tell them (RBn10-15). óohò akxa toská ðìké ée ée akxa the cook says there are no potatoes (03/05/95/JS/pc:ok). éekiða! waëáëeíe haakò éçe nàpé? say it! how do you say that in Osage? [éekiða = ékie + a IMPERATIVE MARKER; ð is epenthetic] (RBn12-11; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ma). waëáëeíe çée ékia! say that in Osage! • (intr., trans.) talk for another, talk in the presence of others. wihtáeëi akxa íe tóa ékipçe kôða akxai my little sister wants me to say a few words [for her] (RBn2317). îlòòçka záani íe tóa ékipçe hta atxâhe all you ilôòçka [drumkeeper and committee], I'm going to say a few words (BE2.132). ékipçe I said (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ékiçe you said (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). éki[e] akxá he's saying it (03/15/95/PM/pc). ékie ðìká don't say that (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; 03/16/95/JS/pc:uk). çi ékia say it again (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). kóoci waëáëe ékie nàpé old time Osages used to say (FH:5/01/96/tape: óo; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok). íe tóe ékipçe hkôbra I want to say something [a few words] (03/05/95/JS/pc:ok).  

ékimà. V [1st sg. of ékiò] I do.

ékiò. V [sync. nasal vowel stem, éki_ò] [apparently ki- DAT + éò (but pronominal prefixes unexpectedly follow ki-)] (trans.) do s.t. (in the presence of others or for others), proceed or go ahead with s.t. (in the presence of others or for others). ékimò/ékimà I do it. ékiëò/ékiëà you do it. ékiò/ékià she does it. éàkiò/eâkiò/éàkià/eâkià we do it. ékiòpe he did it (RBn10-2). çi ékiò do it again (RBn10-2). haakôta ékiëò? why did you do that? (RBn; HW). ekiô! go ahead and do it! ékimà na I do that/I do it that way (04/11/95/FH/pc). ðée ékiëò na? did you do this? (04/11/95/FH/pc:okc). ékimà I did this (04/11/95/FH/pc:ok). ékiò ðìká don't do it (04/11/95/FH/pc:okc). ékiòpi go ahead and do it [pl. addressee]. • can, be able to. ékimà I can do it (lit., 'I do').

•• LFD 40: ékiò<e´-gi-oæ> to do so. ékiwaò <e´-gi wa-oæ> he does so to them (unconfirmed; 04/11/95/FH/pc:incorrect)).

ékitxà. MODAL [ki- INCEPTIVE + etxâ] it's time again.

••• Cf. mîìòpa wahkôta iëîke iitáe ékitxà December (lit., 'it's time again for the month when God's son was born'). ékiëò. V [2nd sg. of ékiò] you do.

ékò (variant: eekô). ADV, ADJ like, similar to; like that; likewise, similarly. kîì ékò wáli hkôbrai, htáaëì akxa ékiape "if only I could fly like that," the little deer said (RBn15-02). wiçkítà çée ékò brîe me too, I'm just like that (RBn17-p03). ékòëi ëà akxai he doesn't believe it; he believes it's otherwise (lit., 'not like that he believes') (RBn17-p03). ékò káaãe make it like that (FH:prod). mâëà ðekáha táatâ ékò ðìkí akxai there's nothing like it here on earth (RBn10-2). haxî kóoci çäuuwasu tà wíe paçôwì, hcéka ée ékò hta akxai if you will clean that old [striped] blanket, I'll bind it and it will be like new (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). hôòe ékò somebody like her (RBn17-p03). ëáëe ðíhta akxa ðáalìe, ëúoka ékò açäíe your name is pretty and your body is likewise (RBn17-p01). ékò kôða apa, ékò waðákçiãe hkôbra whatever they want, fix it for them (lit., 'like that they want it, like that you make it for them, that I want') (RBn22-10). eekô kôða tà what he wants to do (04/11/95/FH/pc:prod). • somewhat, kind of, rather, slightly, a bit. ooláaëi ékò kíe he is somewhat lacking. • right, correctly, correct, appropriate, appropriately, that is right, true! correct!, that's the way! (RBn1:40). ekôxci just right, exactly right.  ékò ëaamí I think it's right (PM). ékò ëaaëi you think it's right (PM; RBn1-40). ékò ékiçe you said it right (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). • CONJ thus, therefore. brúwì hkôbra ekò táatà éhpaahà I made him a proposition (lit., 'I wanted to buy it, therefore I raised something'). • V [uninfl.] (intr.) mean, signify.  éäoýi mòçkó nihkáçi íe 'htáaëì' ékò akxai Echogee in the Creek language means 'little deer'. • happen, be so. óðàëi ékò ëí hta akxái anyway it's never going to happen (lit., 'anyway, it will not be so') (04/17/95/LS/pc:okc; RBn1-MOJ/p28). • (be) as . . . as. mâàãe htóho ékòpe he was as blue as the sky (RBn15-01).

••• Cf. ékòëi, waðílà eekô ìké. ékò ðaacé. VP [sync., ékò _ðaacé] say s.t. right or correctly. ékò çtáace you said it right; you named it right (RBn10-6:JW).

ékò kôðaaëi. VP [sync. fortisizing stop stem + sync., ékò _kô_ðaaëi] [ékò + kôða + aëí NEG] be sorry about being a certain way, not want to be a certain way. ékò brîe àëi ékò hkôbra màëi that's the way I am but I don't want to be that way (this phrase is the closest Osage equivalent to "I'm sorry" [FH]).

ékò ska. VP [uninfl.] I guess that's right.

••• KS çéeyòska that size, it was that big (RR).

ekôìke. ADJ, ADV [ékò 'appropriate'+ ðìké NEG] crazy, crazily, inappropriately, unsuitably. John akxa íe ekôìke étana nôòahpe John talks crazy so I'm afraid [of him] (FH). waðílà ekôìkí apai, ðekôòci áhkihtòpa ðì there are crazies around, now watch out for yourself. • ADV off, not where or how it is supposed to be, off target, out of line, incorrectly (108-b/fh/078; 04/17/95/LS/pc). ekôìke íðae nìkçé you're talking off the subject.

••• Cf. ekôxci. 

ékòska ha. ADJ, N make-believe (RBn23-22, unconfirmed).

ekôxci. ADJ, ADV [ékò + xci] correct, correctly.  

•• LFD 40: ekôxci <e-goæ´-xtsi> exact, precise, downright, real, in reality (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

ékòëi (variant: ekôëi). V [uninfl.] [ékò + aëí NEG] (intr.) not be like this or that, be not thus, be otherwise (RBn17-p03). çée ékòëie it's not that way (RBn3-22). ékòëi [a]ëâà akxai he doesn't believe it (lit., 'he believes it's otherwise') (RBn17-p03). • ADJ unseemly, inappropriate, not right, unsuitable, unfitting, ill-advised, wrong (RBn10-21/JW; FW/77). ekôëi mìkçé I'm not right (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). çíi akxa ekôëi akxai he's not right (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). hôòpa wì súhka tóoka ókØà ékòëi káaãe nàpe sometimes the rooster did things he shouldn't do (lit., '. . . things that were unsuitable') (RBn18-01).

ékòëie ska. ADJP improbable (lit., 'not thus I suppose').

•• LFD 40 (unconfirmed): ékò aëi eskà <e´goæ a-zhi e-škoæ> improbable.

émà. V [1st sg. of éò] I do.

émàhta (variant: ámàhta). ADV that way, that direction (lit., 'toward the other').

émàhtaëi. ADV [émàhta + aëí NEG] the other way.

émàhtaëíha. ADV [émàhtaëi + ha PPN] not toward that way. émàhtaëi ha! not toward that way! toward the other way! (implying 'turn this way instead'; expression used while getting everybody sitting in the correct way in a peyote meeting [RB]) (BE2.146; CQokc; 04/04/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• Cf. ímàhtaha.

éò. V [sync. nasal vowel stem, é_ò] (trans.) do (not in the presence of others or for others). éwò iiðáðe I saw them do it (RBn22-06). éwòpe he did this (RB: <éh-woæ pí-ah>, with archaic pía instead of Mod. Os. pe) (04/11/95/FH/pc:okc). émà/émò I do. éëà/éëò you do. éò/éwò he does, they do. ðíe éwaëò you did that [ðie é-wa-ëò]. pée éwò? who did that? [pee é-wa-ò]. wí wamôe I did that.  

••• Cf. éhkiò, ékiò. 

eçéçe. V [2nd sg. of ée 'say', reduplicated] you keep (on) saying. eçéçe you keep saying it. ée eçéçe you keep saying that (FH).

éçki. ADV, ADJ else; also, otherwise.

•• LFD 41: eçkí <e-shki´> he, she, or it too.

••• Cf. ðiçkítà, eeçkítà, howachéeçki, howaðéeçki, péeçki, çki. 

étà. CONJ therefore. étà àkále htai we should go home now (lit., 'therefore we go, let's us') (RBn10-12:JW).

•• LFD 40: etô <e-doæ´> therefore. etxâ. ADV still. ìtîla àðìkçé hta akxai mâëà ìké etxâ we will still be gossiping when the world ends. • V [uninfl.] (intr.) it is time (MSB).

••• Cf. ékitxà. 

éwahkikØò. V [reg., éwa_hkikØô] [wa- VAL + hkik- REFL + éò] do to oneself (RB; FHt128a,b).

éwahkikØô akxai he did it to himself (RBn10-4:MOJ/79; FH/11/17/01/pc; FHt#128). éwaahkikØô I did it to myself (FH/11/17/01/pc). éwaðahkikØô you did it to yourself (FH/11/17/01/pc).

••• Cf. wéhkikØò.

éwahkiôðe. V [uninfl./reg.+sync., éwa_hkiô_ðe] [contains hkik- REFL] (intr.) get oneself into s.t. by oneself. éwahkiôðe we did it to ourselves (02/01/95/FH/pc:prod orig; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok/ma). éwaðahkiòçce you got your own self into something.

••• Cf. ohkíòðe.

éwaëì. ADV alone, by oneself, on one's own (HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok).

éwaëì nâàke (variants: éwaëi nâàke, áwaëìka nâàke) N automobile, car (lit., 'it runs by itself ') (FH/09/21/01/pc; HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok). [An archaic expression.] éwaëì nâàki akxai the car is running by itself (RBn1-40; FH/09/21/01/pc). • ADV by car.

éëi (variant of éeëi).

éëi wì. PRON another one, a different one. hôòpa ókaaãeìki tà htâwà ki abrîbree hta akxai çí éëi wì waðíhta hpíò ke wì íhkihkawi hta mìkçé? on Saturday, what if I take him to town and trade him for another one that knows how to work? (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; CQ: okc).

éëixci. ADJ [éëi + xci] unique (lit., 'different indeed'), odd-looking, funny-looking, appearing different or abnormal (e.g., a person who has fever) (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok); changeable (04/06/95/PM/pc). tówa akxa éëixci akxái, lôði akxa ska he looks funny [different] so he must be drunk (04/26/95/FH/pc). áa éëixci, ëeká çki éëixci, hóo çki éëixci, íhì ììcé ohkáska éëixcì açäîe you have funny arms and funny legs and a funny voice and a funny-looking moustache in the middle of your face (RBn17-p01).

•• LFD 42: éëi xci <e´-zhi xtsi> singular, unlike.

éëò. V [2nd sg. of éò] you do.

ãaaké. V [reg., _ãaaké] (intr.) cry (01/14/95/FH/pc). ãaaké wáhpaaãe I made them cry (RBn2-MOJ/p24; 01/14/95/FH/pc:okc). ãaaké ìká don't cry. ãaaké akxa he/she is crying. ãaaké âçkáaãe you made me cry. ãaaké wihpáaãe I made you cry. ãaaké ðikáaãe he/they made you cry. ãaaké kaaçénà enough crying, stop crying (HH). awáata çô mìkçé, záani ãaaké wáhpáaãe while I was praying, I made them all cry (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.28).

•• JOD (slip file): ãake <xa-¦ke> to cry or weep.

•• LFD 217: ãaké  <xa-ge´> to weep, to cry, lamentation. áãake <a´-xa-ge> I weep.

ðáãake <tha´-xa-ge> you weep. àãáka pe <oæ-xa´-ga i> we cry or weep.

••• OP ãagé cry.

ãáãaka. ADJ rough (e.g., chapped hands or any rough surface).

•• JOD: ãáãaka <xa´-xa-§ka> rough, as a file, chapped hands.

ãì (variant: xî). ADJ light in color (BE2.88). ììçtáxì/ììçtáãì white person (lit., 'light eyes') [ììçtá + xî] (FH/09/25/01/pc).

••• DAK ãi dark brown.

ãépe (variant of xépe)

ãoî (variants: ãowî, xoî). V, ADJ [stat., _ãoì] stink, (be) stinky, it stinks!, phew!, malodorous, have a fetid odor or offensive smell (worse than ëâxta); vocative derogatory exclamation

(e.g., to an offensive drunk person). si àãoî my feet stink (RBn12-08; WF/12/30/01, 03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc).

•• LFD 22: ãwì <xwiæ> fetid, offensive smell.

ãówe. N noise (PM).

ãôòce. ADJ sloppy, slouchy, unkempt, messed up (9/4/94/FH/p.c.). wéhkilì ãôòci his clothes are all messed up (wrinkly, etc.) (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). ãòòce tôpewai you look sloppy, something makes you look sloppy (FH:prod). ãôòce ðiká don't be sloppy (FH:prod). ëìkáëì ãôòce hcí ci achípi wahkôbra ìké I don't want sloppy children to come to my home (BE2.123).

ha. PPN through (direction), along a path, in a direction, by way of. howaìkíha bree? how do I get there? (lit., 'through where do I go?') (t#14b-p4; 04/26/95/FH/pc:uk). háakò kçíha brée? how will I get there? (04/26/95/FH/pc). çeðóha that way. okahâàpa cí ecíha óhpepi áape the house has been broken into (lit., 'through the window the house had been entered, they said') (05/01/95/FH/pc). owé che ðáabrì ha káaãa make three piles of groceries (lit., 'make the groceries into three piles'). • from. ðetkxâha haakô éepçe che ékò hkôbra from now on, I want it to be like I've said (03/22/95/FH/pc). ðetkxâha ~ ðetxâha from here on, from now on.

ha. DECL declarative. [Archaic or incorrect, not heard in Modern Osage.]

•• LF 80: nàpé ðiskike íðachì ha <noæ-be´ thi-ški-ge i´-tha-tsiæ ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you struck him with the fist. [This sentence-final ha may be Omaha (FH).]

há. INTERJ well (often precedes a statement or command). há wanôbrepi well, go ahead and eat (RBn11-02/JW&FW; HH/pc/c.1976).

••• Cf. hâà (possibly the same word).

háa. N hide, skin of an animal, rind, fabric, cloth. céãenii háa drum hide. htáahaa hide, skin, deerskin (WHM981022; CQokc). • surface(?). niiháa htóho ékò blue [as distinct from green] [niiháa = níi 'water' + háa 'surface'?] (RB, unconfirmed; 01/07/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 56: ha <ha> skin of any animal; the bark of a tree; shell of nuts; cuticle.

••• Cf. ópxàhaa, walúçka háa çooká, waçîhaa.

háa çooká. NP thick skin, exoskeleton.

••• Cf. walúçka háa çooká. 

háabrehka. N [háa + bréhka] ribbon (lit., 'thin cloth') (RBn1-44; FH).

háachi (variant: háchi). ADV all the time, every time, continually, repeatedly, always. ónòbre háachi àðìchí apai they keep on bringing food. ëìkáëì háachi àkâzà àkai we boss the kids around every time. háachi wiëîke wisôka éeðòòpa àkáazà àkai we're always bawling out Sonny and my brother. háachi wiëîke wisôka éðòpa àkáazà àkái we're always bawling out Sonny and younger brother.

háaðaskà. INTERR/INDEF ADV how big, how small. háaðaskâ ìkçé? how big/small is it?  

haakô (variant: háakò). INTERR/INDEF ADV how much. haakô waëáëe? how much Osage are you? • whatever. haakô kôða tà whatever he wants to do (04/11/95/FH/pc:prod). haakô háaëò whatever you do (FH/06/25/01/pc, length and stress confirmed). ðíe, haakô éçe çkôçta tà ékia! just say whatever you want to! • how. haakôhce how [in the future]

(02/09/95/FH/pc:okc). háakò kôða apa, ékò ékima hta mìkçé however they want it, that's how I'm going to do it (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). çé, háakò [e]çé nòpe? how do you say this?

[regarding something near hearer] (RBn12-11) ée háakò eçé nàpé? how do you say that? which way. háakò ðée? which way did they go? where did they go? (RBn1-23). INTERR/INDEF V [uninfl.] be how. haakô ìkçé? how are they? [of people sitting] (FH). háakò nîkçe? how are you? (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). háakò ëâkçé? how are you? [to someone lying down] (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). háakò ðatkxàçé? how are you? [to someone standing] (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.69). mâàãe háakò che áçi? what's it [the weather] like outside? (03/22/95/PM/pc:prod). • INTERR/INDEF PRON what. háakò? what do you want? (RBn1-23; 04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). háakò? what is it? (RBn1-23; 04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). háakò che? what is it? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ma). hâakò? what's the matter? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ma). háakòpe? what's the matter? (RB, unconfirmed). háakò ìkçe ékipçe çkôçta? what is it you want me to say? (RBn10-22/JW&FW). • what is wrong with. háakò nìkçé, táatà nìkçé? what's wrong with you, what are you doing? (RBn12-11).

•• LFD 58: hákoe <ha´-go-e> what has happened? háakòta. INTERR/INDEF ADV why. háakòta íiçcewai ðàìçé? why are you dressed up? haakôta John haxî wakØú ðe? why did John give the blankets away?

haakxâ, háakxà (variants of háatxà).

haakxâci (variant of haatxâci).

haakxâta, haakxôta (variants of haatxâta).

haaléëowaake. N [háa + léëe + óðaake] handkerchief, scarf, neckerchief (lit., 'spotted cloth for telling folks things', but not necessarily actually spotted). haaléëowáake àwâxpaðe mìkçe I have lost my handkerchief (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.63).

•• RB: <hah-léh-zho-áh-keh>.

•• LFD 58: haléëe waðake <ha-gthe´-zhe wa-tha-ge> handkerchief. haaléëe waðáake àwâxpaðe mìkçe o <ha-gthe´-zhe wa-tha-ge oæ-woæ-xpa-the miæ-kshe o> I lost my handkerchief.

háamà (variant: haamâ). INTERR/INDEF VP [1st sg. of háaò] what I do, whatever I do, what did I do.

háanà (variants: háana, hâànà). INTERR/INDEF ADJ how many, how much (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). mâzeska háanà açcî nìkçé? how much money do you have? háanà che? how many are there? how much is there? (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc). háanà pa? how many [people or things] are there? mîì oðaake háanà che? what time is it? (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc). mîì oðaake háanà pa? how many clocks are there? (02/09/95/FH/pc:prod orig). omâìhka háanà ðaaçé? how old are you? (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). kiistómaì háanà híipe? how many councilmen were there (at that place)? (lit., 'how many councilmen went there?') (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc: híi; BE2.69). mâzeska háanà açcî ðaìçé? how much money do you have? (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 58: hánà <ha´-noæ> how much, how many?

háaò (variant: hôò). INTERR/INDEF V [sync. nasal vowel stem, háa_ò] (trans.) do how, do however, do in whatever way. háamà hta che? how am I going to do this? (04/11/95/FH/pc). háamà hta che? how shall I do this? (04/11/95/FH/pc). háamà çkôçta tà . . . however you want me to do it . . . (FH/04/11/95/pc). súhka hôò che? how's the chicken doing [cooking]? (RBn2MOJ/p19b). mòçô oðîìke háaëò hta nìkçé? how are you going to vote? háaëò? how are you doing it? (BE2.32; 04/11/95/FH/pc). háaëò ðaìçé? how are you doing it? (04/28/95/LS/pc). háamà çkôçta tà? how do you want me to do it? (04/11/95/FH/pc). • do what. hâàpa ðe háaëò? what did you [sg.] do today? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc). hòpa ðe háaëòpe? what did you [pl.] do today? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc). hâàci háaëò? what did you do last night? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). táatà haaëô? what did you do? háamà hce? what am I going to do? what shall I do? [calls for hearer's opinion] (FH/06/27/01/pc). Johna háaò hce? what will John do? (FH/06/27/01/pc). háa àkô hce? what shall we do? háaò ðe? what did he do? • do what with, do what about. çôke ékçe háaëò? what are you going to do with that dog lying there? (FH). háaëò? what did you do with it? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). hcúka háaëò? what did you do with the spoons? (RBn1-53; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). óðaake waléze háaëò? what did you do with the newspaper? (BE2.154). haxî hôò ðe? what did he do with the blanket? (MSB). háaëò? what did you do about it? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). • do whatever with, do whatever. háamà hkôbra ékimà hta mìkçé whatever I want to do, I'll do it. háamà whatever I do. háaëò whatever you do. háaò ~ hôò whatever she does (MSB).  

•• LFD 59: háëò <ha´-zhoæ> what are you doing? what did you do?

••• Cf. ékiò, éò.

haaská (variant: haaçká). N dress, buckskin dress; shirt (LS); clothes, clothing; fabric, cloth, material. [Speaker comment: both variants are correct (LS, ERE).] háaska ëíhi íðahkie? did you find your brown dress/shirt? (04/07/95/LS/pc:okc). haaská océ pçíe I went [shopping] to look for a dress (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.34). haaská ská káaãa make the buckskin dress white (FH/10/09/01/pc). haaská ðé ëî hkôbra I want you to wear this shirt (RBn1-44). Mary akxa haaská wì kikáaãape Mary made over a shirt. haaská wasúhuëike paahípai, çäúuwasu htai be sorting the [scattered] dirty clothes, let's you wash them (FH/11/17/01/pc, BE2.120; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; 04/07/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 57: haská <ha-ška´> calico, gingham, canvas, or any cotton goods; gingham or calico shirt, a woman's jacket.

••• Cf. háa. 

haaská wanôpØì. NP handkerchief, neckerchief (lit., 'cloth worn on neck') (RBn).

haaskáhci (variants: haaskáihci, haaskíhci). N [haaská + hcí 'house'] tent, long arbor house (lit., 'cloth house') (03/16/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.136).

•• LFD 57: háská hci <ha´ška´ ¾si> a canvas tent.

haaskámì (variant: haaskámi). N [haaská + mî 'blanket'] shawl (BE2.120; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).

•• LFD 57: haskámi <ha-ška´-mi> shawl, skin-white-robe. haskámi wihta ðà sape <haška´-mi wi-¾a thoæ ša-be> [expected Mod. Os. form: haaskámì wíhta sápe; the form ðò is not recognizable in Mod. Os.] my shawl is black.

haaskíhci (variant of haaskáhci).

haaçí (variant: háaçi). ADJ last. [Speaker comment: both variants are correct (FH).] ómaìhka háaçi ecí  it was [in the] the same place last year (RB). hâàpa wahkôtaki haaçí che last week (BE2.75). mîìòpa haaçíhta last month (HH/09/10/93). • PPN in the back of, behind.

•• LFD 58: háçi <ha´-shi> the last one, the end of things, Omega.

haaçíhta (variants: haçíhta, haaçîhta). ADV before, earlier, in the past. • PRON those long ago, those old ones. haaçíhta apa ékiapi ché the ones before me said that (RBn22-01). • ADJ last, past, back in time, ago. omâìhka haaçíhta ecí ce [in the] same place as last year (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc). hòpái haaçíhta hóni àcØé some days back I almost died. hôòpa ðáabrì haaçíhta three days ago (FH:01/05/01/pc). háaçìðe. ADJ, ADV inside out (RBn10-15). haaçîhta (variant of haaçíhta).

haaçká (variant of haaská).

háaçki (variant: hâàçki, hôòçki). N everywhere, wherever, all over, all paths and directions (e.g., children running, s.t. spilled) (03/23/95/FH/pc). háaçki ípahò apai everybody knows him (lit., 'everywhere they know him') (FH:prod). Mary apa iiëîke óxpaða apa ná háaçki okíci apái Mary's son is lost and she's looking everywhere for him (03/23/95/FH/pc). háaçki otápe they looked all over for it.

•• LFD 58: ha çki <ha shki> in every direction, in any place.

haaçtáha. N [háa + çtáha] broadcloth (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn HW).

•• LFD 58: háçta ha <ha´-shda ha> broadcloth.

haatkxâci (variant of haatxâci).

haatkxâta (variant of haatxâta).

háatxà (variants: haatxâ, háakxà, háatkxà, haakxâ). INTERR/INDEF ADV how far, what distance, (for) how long (04/06/95/LS/pc). háatxà brée hta àhé? how far do I have to go? (t#14v-p5). hátxà àkái htà akatxa? how far do we have to go? (t#14b-p5). háatkxà çäée? how far are you going? (FH/06/26/01/pc; 04/06/95/LS/pc). háatkxà çäée? how long are you going? (FH/06/26/01/pc).

•• LFD 58: hatxâ <ha-toæ´> how far, what distance.

haatxâci (variants: haakxâci, haatkxâci, hátxàci). INTERR/INDEF ADV when in the past, at what time in the past (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). háatxàci ðalîe?/haakxâci ðalíe? when did you return? what time did you get back? (1/2/335; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:prod; BE2.154). haakxâci ðalípe? when or what time did you all get back? (04/28/95/LS/pc; BE2.155).

haatxâta (variants: háatxàta, haatkxâta, haakxâta, haakxôta). INTERR/INDEF ADV when in the future, what time in the future (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc; FH:6/25/01/pc). kasîe, haakxâta htâwàìkçi çäée hta ðáiçe? tomorrow, when are you going to town? (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). ðíe haakxâta çäée çkôòçta? when do you want to go? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). haatxâta ðalíe? when will you be back? haakxâta ðalí hta ðaìçe? when are you coming back? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). haakxâta awánòbre hta àkakxâi? when are we going to eat? (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). haakxâta waðákiçtôpapi ðachí hta ðàkxâçe? [expected form: ..  . nàkxâçe] when are you all going to come see us? (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). haakxâta ðahkíhkôze hta paaçé? when are you all going to have a peyote meeting? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). haakxâta hci oðáhpe? when are you going in [entering] the house? (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). haakxâta htáa paasé hta apai? when are they going to cut up the meat?

•• LFD 58: hatxàtà ðale hta che a(?) <ha-¾oæ-doæ tha-gthe ¾a -tse a(?)> [sentence-final a is not used in Modern Osage] when will you go home?

haawálele. N [háa + waléle] flag, American flag, banner, standard (when flaglike), staff with feathers (BE2.48).

•• LFD 189: haská walele <ha-ška´ wa-xthe-xthe> ensign, flag, banner, symbolic standard. [In LF's day, waléle <wa-xthe-xthe> evidently meant specifically the feathered standard of the Osages, and haaská 'cloth' was added to distinguish the American flag. In Mod. Os., waléle and haawálele signify both 'flag' and 'feathered standard'.]

háaweáze (variant: háawüüze [FH]). N thread. háawüüze sápe tóa àkØú give me some black thread (03/22/95/FH/pc, BE2.140).

•• LFD 58: háweaze <ha´-we-a-še> thread, skin, with which to lace. háweaze sápe hépe àkØú a <ha-we-a-še ša-be he-be oæ-ki a> [sentence-final a is not used in Modern Osage] give me some black thread.

háazu. N grape. háazu íiðuspa ðòòpá brúwì I bought two pounds of grapes (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.60). háazu ëúuce âðalì I like red grapes (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 57: házi <ha´-ši> grapes. hási ëuce àðalì ha <ha´-ši zhu-dse oæ-tha-gthiæ ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.]  I like red grapes. háasu ape çtaha <ha´-ši a-be shta-ha> large wild grapes, with smooth leaves (unconfirmed; 02/03/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• WI: haapsîä (KM).

háazunii. N [háazu + níi] grape juice (RB; 02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.60).

•• LFD 57: házini <ha´-ši-ni> juice of grapes, wine.

háaëò. INTERR/INDEF V [2nd sg. of háaò] do why, do what for. htâwà ìkçí háaëò çíe? what did you go to town for? (FHt#128b).

haaëúuce. N [háa + ëúuce] shroud (lit., 'red cloth') (HRE); stroud (a coarse woolen cloth, blanket, or garment formerly used by the British in bartering with the North American Indians in the late 1600s).

•• LFD 59: háëuce <ha´ zhu-dse> red strouding.

háchi (variant of háachi).

háha. ADJ ready. ðée che háha nìkçé? are you ready to go? (RBn10-5:JW).

•• LFD 289: háha <ha´-ha> light weight. [Translation unconfirmed.]

háhahkie. V [reg., háha_hkie] [háha + hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] (intr.) get ready, make oneself ready, make yourself ready. háhaðahkíe you got ready.

hahkíe. V [stat., _hahkíe] (trans./intr.) be unable to understand, be unsure (of s.t.), not quite get the idea. âhahkie I don't quite get it (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; RBn10-5:JW). ðihahkíe you don't understand (02/27/95/JS/pc; BE2.147).

hámàsi. N spade, spades (suit in a deck of cards) (FH).

hápa. N corn, fresh corn (FH/t116b). hápa ákalìekòëî Osage corn (speckled corn) (01/13/95/FH/pc:uk; BE2.25). hápa óoëu éetkxà akxai it's time to plant corn (FH/t116b).

•• LFD 57: hápaëuce <Ha´-ba-zhu-dse> Red-corn (personal name; refers to a life symbol). LFD 58: hápa <ha´-ba> corn on the cob (03/07/95/FH/pc:ok). hápaleze <ha´-bagthe-še> [expected Mod. Os. form: hápaleëe (léëe 'spotted')] spotted corn (03/07/95/FH/pc:ok). hápa wacúe. N cornbread. [Not commonly used.]  

hápa wacØéka (variant: hápa wahcéka [LR]). N fresh (lit., 'gentle') corn. [Speaker's comment: "squaw corn" is the white man's term (LR).]  hápa waléke. N cracked corn (FH/09/22/01/prod).  

hápa wasúta (variant: hápa wasutà). N corn when it first gets ripe, "just right" corn (when it is just ready to be picked for drying); "fresh" corn (FH). [This newly ripe corn was called "fresh corn" by some Osage speakers.]  haçíhta (variant of haaçíhta).

hátxàci (variant of haatxâci).

hawé (variants: havé, havéu). INTERJ hello (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.66). [Female speakers may say either hawé or havé/havéu (where v is a sound between English v and a semivoiced w; this word is the only place such a sound occurs in Osage).]

•• LFD 58: hawé <ha-we´>, female <ha-ve´> to greet.

haxî. N blanket (bed blanket or Pendleton-type wool blanket for wearing). haxî î kçie put a blanket on him (lit., 'have him wear the blanket') (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod). haxîke opétkxà wrap up those blankets [lying around haphazardly, not stacked] (03/22/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 59: haxî <ha-xiæ´> a woolen blanket. haxî ðìkçe brehka <ha-xiæ´ thiæ-kshe btheÐa> [Mod. Os. would normally use ìkçé rather than ðìkçé] the blanket is thin. haxî wì aðì akxa ha ohtaza xci <ha-xiæ´ wiæ a-thiæ a-ka ha u-¾a-ša xtsi> [Mod. Os. would have akxa rather than akxa ha] he has a showy blanket.

haxîleëekáaãe. N [haxî + léëe + káaãe] Navajo (tribe or tribal member) (lit., 'one who makes spotted/speckled/stippled [léëe] blankets').

•• LFD 59: haxîleëekaãe <Ha-xiæ´-gthe-zhe-ga-xe> Navajo.

-hà. V ROOT [uninfl.] rise.

••• Cf. paahâ, watáahà.

hâà (variant: hâ). INTERJ so! (an exclamation used especially in storytelling). hâà wanôbrapi come on now and eat (MOJ). hâà ékò well, so, that's the way it was. • how about, so (interrogative) (PM). hâà ðí, mâçò oðîìke çkôçta? how about you? do you want to vote right now? (PM/7/7/94). hâà ði? so? how about you? (PM071494). hâà ðí apa? how about you all? (PM071494)

••• Cf. há 'well' (possibly the same word).

hâà. N night, nighttime. • ADV during the night, at night. hâini ðáha ahípe they came late at night (FH:108-b; BE2.93). hâà ðe achí hta apai they'll arrive during the night [tonight] (02/27/95/FH/pc:prod). • ADJ nocturnal.

•• LFD 65: hâtà <hoæ´-doæ> during the night.

••• Cf. hâìnì. 

hàà káaçi. ADVP late at night, already night for a long time (RB; 02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). hàà káaçi ðáha achípe they came late at night (lit., 'when it had been night for a long time, they arrived here').

hâà kootáha ce (variant of hâàce kootáha ce).

hâà ohkáska (variants: hâà ohkáske, hâàhkaska). N midnight. hâà ohkáske akxai it's midnight (02/24/95/FH/pc:ske). hâà ohkáske ahípe midnight is here (02/24/95/FH/pc:ske; BE2.87). hâà ohkáske ahí akxa midnight has arrived, it's midnight (02/24/95/FH/pc: ske; BE2.87).

hâà ohtâka. N midnight.

•• LFD 66: hà ohtàka <hoæ u-¾oæ-ga> night at its greatest strength, middle of the night, midnight (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok).

hâà tà wakØó. N woman of the night (lit., 'when night, the woman'; possibly a clan name).

•• LFD 65: hâtàwákØo <Hoæ´-doæ-wa´-Ð'u> female personal name, Woman-of-the-night.

hâà wakØó. N night woman.

•• LFD 66: hâwakØo <Hoæ´-wa-Ð'u> Night-woman, female personal name (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok, ma).

hâàce (variant: hâàci). N, ADV last night (03/23/95/FH/pc; FH:5/01/96/tape:prod). hâàce háaëò? what did you do last night? (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.75). wiëî, waaðô ðáalì çkáaãe hâàci older brother, you sang good last night (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc: hâàci).

•• RB: <hahæ-tsí>.

•• LFD 63: hà <hoæ> night. hò aci <hoæ a-di> [expected Mod. Os. form: hâàce] last night.  

hâàce kootáha ce (variant: hâà kootáha ce). ADVP, NP night before last (02/24/95/FH/pc).

•• RB: <háhæ-gó-tah-háh-tsi>.

••• Cf. hâàpa kootáha ce. hààðé. N tonight. hààðé wiëîke akxa waëáëeíe hpíò kôða akxa tonight son wants to learn the Osage language (BE2.143).

hààé. INTERJ yes (response when listening to a story).

hâàekôëì. N [hâà 'night' + ékò + -ëì 'little'] early morning (lit., 'a little like night')  (BE2.89, unconfirmed; 02/25/95/FH/pc:uk).

hâàhkaska (variant of hâà ohkáska).

hâàhkaëi. INTERJ no (02/27/95/FH/pc; BE2.94).

•• LFD 66: hâhkaëi <hoæ´-Ða-zhi> no, not so.

hâàhpazé (variant of hâànahpazé).

hâàmàðì (variants: hâàmàì, hààmôì). N Hominy (place name); Night Walker (personal name). [Osage name of Frances Holding's maternal grandfather, after whom the town of Hominy (Osage County, Oklahoma) was named.]

hâànahpazé (variant: hâànàhpazé, hâànàhpáze, hâàhpazé). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) dark, darken, become/get dark. wáli hâànàhpáze akxai it's really dark (RBn12-06). • N jail, guardhouse, prison. hâàhpaze olîì akxái he's in jail. • dark night, darkness of night (BE2.29; 01/19/95/FH/pc:okc; t#14a-p2).

 •• LFD 66: hâànàhpaze <hoæ´-noæ-¼a-še> jail, night-darkness (refers to the gloomy aspect of the prison). hânàhpaze olì <hoæ´-noæ-¼a-še u-gthiæ> a jail sentence. hànâhpaze omàðì pe <hoæ-noæ´-¼a-še u-moæ-thiæ bi o> they walked in darkness.

••• Cf. hâànahpazéhci. 

hâànahpazé oolâ. VP [reg., oo_lâ] (trans.) arrest, put s.o. in jail (lit., 'place into darkness').

waachí hí ëiiçô ðée ðe hpahâle hâànahpazé oolâàpi wáhkôbra before the dances start, first I want you all [lit., 'them'] to put him in jail (FH/09/22/01/pc).

•• LFD 66: hânàhpaze olà <hoæ´-noæ-¼a-še u-gthoæ> to arrest one, to place in jail (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok). hânàhpaze àwàlà pe <hoæ´-noæ-¼a-še oæ-woæ gthoæ i> they put me in jail. hâpehpaze oðilà pe <hoæ´-be-¼a-še u-thi-gthoæ i> [expected Mod. Os. form: hâànahpaze ooðílàpe; LF's syllable <-be-> is perhaps a typographical error] they put you in jail (unconfirmed, 04/19/95/FH/pc).

hâànahpazéhci. N [hâànàhpazé + hcí] jailhouse, jail (lit., 'night house', 'darkness house') (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). hâànàhpazéhci olîì akxái he's in jail (RBn10-12:JW; BE2.72, (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 66: hânàhpaze hci <hoæ´-noæ-¼a-še ¾si> guardhouse, prison. hâànàhpazehci che olìì aðaa pe <hoæ´-noæ-¼a-še ¾si tse u-gthiæ a-tha bi a> he went to prison.

hâànà (variant of háanà).

hâànàhpazé, hâànàhpáze (variants of hâànahpazé). hâàni, hâànì (variants of hâìnì).

hâàpa (variants: hôòpa, hààpái, hààpáe, hòòpái). N day; today. hâàpa ðé today. hâàpa háaëô? what did you do today? (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.290). hòòpái haaçíhta hóni acØé some days back I almost died (2/3/83/1/330; 01/20/95/FH/pc:okc). hâàpa ðé akxa ðáalìëi akxai it's not a pretty day today, the weather is not good today (FH/10/13/96).

•• LFD 63: hâpa <hoæ´-ba> day.

hâàpa hpahâle. N Monday (lit., 'first day') (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.88). [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 64: hâpa hpahàle <Hoæ´-ba ¼a-hoæ-gthe> first day: Monday.

hâàpa htaaðáachaëi (variants: htaaðáachaëi hâàpa, htaaðáachaëi; perhaps also htáa[ð]aachaëi [RB, unconfirmed]). N [hâàpa + htáa + ðaaché + aëí] Friday (lit., 'day of no meat-eating') (BE2.50, 01/30/95/FH/pc:ok, all). [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 139: htaðátxaëi hàpa <¾a-tha´-ta-zhi hoæ-ba> meat eat not day: Friday. [LF's <tha´-ta-zhi> is probably a typographical error for ðáchaëi <tha´-tsa-zhi>; LF has <oætha´-tsa i i> for àðácha pe elsewhere.]

hâàpa ihtóì ðeha. ADVP, NP (in the) future, in days to come (01/30/95/FH/pc:ok). hâàpa ihtúì ðeha, ókaçéìke ëóawahkíe hkôbra I want to be with them from now on with nothing to bother (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.52). hâàpe ihtóì ðehá ìkçe in future days (FH).

hâàpa ke záani. ADVP, NP every day.

••• Cf. hâàpa záani. 

hâàpa kootáha ce. NP day before yesterday (FH: prod).

hâàpa oðóhake (variant: hâàpa oðáhike). N last day; final day of the ilôòçka dance, giveaway day (04/06/95/FH:ok:both variants).

•• RB: <hóæ-pah o-tháh-hi-keh>, <o-thó-hah-keh> (04/06/95/FH:ok; BE2.75).

hâàpa ohkíeche. ADVP, NP every day (BE2.42; MJ).

hâàpa ohkísce. N March (lit., 'half a day', days so called because they could be warm or cold between morning and afternoon, unpredictable days) (t#38a-p1-HH1; 04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). [Names of months were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

hâàpa ókaaãéìke. N Saturday (lit., 'day on which nothing is done') (BE2.116; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok). [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 64: hâpa okaãeðìke <Hoæ´-ba u-ga-xe-thiæ-ge> Saturday.

hâàpa wahkòtáki (variant: hôòpa wáhkòtáki) N week, Sunday. [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).] hôòpawáhkòhtaki ðé niiëúepe this week it rained (BE2.153; RBn1-MOJ/p41).

•• RB: <hóm-pah-wáh-koæ-dáh-gi>.

•• LFD 64: hâpa wahkòtaki <hoæ´-ba wa-Ðoæ-da-gi> a week (04/06/95/PM/pc:ok).

hâàpa wahkôtaki (variants: hôòpa wahkôtaki, hâàpa wahkôta) N Sunday (lit., 'sacred day') (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.129). [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 64: hâpa wahkòtaki <Hoæ´-ba Wa-Ðoæ-da-gi> Sunday, sacred day.

hâàpa wéðaabrì. N Wednesday (lit., 'third day') (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.153; 04/06/95/PM/pc:ma). [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 64: hâpa weðabrì <hoæ´-ba we-tha-bthiæ> third day: Wednesday.

hâàpa wéðòòpa. N Tuesday (lit., 'second day') (RB; 04/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.145). [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 64: hâpa weðòpa <Hoæ´-ba we-thoæ-ba> the second day: Thursday.

hâàpa wétoopa. N Thursday (lit., 'fourth day') (03/22/95/FH/pc; BE2.140). [Names of days were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]  

•• LFD 64: hâpa wetopa <Hoæ´-ba we-do-ba> the fourth day: Thursday.

hâàpa záani. ADVP, NP every day.

•• LFD 63: hôpa zani <hoæ´-ba ša-ni> daily; from day to day.

••• Cf. hâàpa ke záani.

hààpáe, hààpái (variants of hâàpa).
