hâàpascee. N [hâàpa + scéce] January (lit., 'days long' or 'days lengthen') (WHM981022, unconfirmed; FH/11/17/01/pc:uk). [Names of months were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

hâàpaska, hâàpaskaha (variants of hôòpaskaha).

hâhceka. N fly, housefly (01/26/95/FH/pc:prod orig; BE2.49).

•• LFD 66: hâhceka <hoæ´-tse-ga> common house fly. hâhceka htoho <hoæ´-¾se-ga ¾oho> blue fly, the blowfly [unconfirmed 'blue fly' and 'blowfly' (01/26/95/FH/pc:uk)].

hâìnì (variants: hâìni, hâànì, hâàni). N dark, darkness. hâìnì ëiiçô àkále we'll go home before dark (RBn10-7:JW). hâìni hí tà when it gets dark (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod). hâàni hí ëiiçò, lípai get back here before dark (FH/11/17/01/pc). hâìni ahí akxa it's dark (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod).

•• LFD 66: hâiðìtà <hoæ´-i-thiæ-doæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: hâìnì tà] pertaining to the night, nocturnal [rather, 'when it is night'] (02/27/95/FH/pc:uk).

 ••• Cf. hâà 'night'.

hâka. N, ADJ sacred, holy. • N bald eagle (HRE/pc/2002); dark-plumed eagle; earth division (of the Osage tribe); innocence emblem in peace ceremony (a child).

•• JOD (slip file): hâka <Hañ´-§ka> the name of the gentes on the right side of the Osage tribal circle.

•• LFD 65: hâka/hôka <Hoæ´-ga> "The name of one of the two great tribal divisions of the Osage Tribe, the division representing the earth with its water and dry land. The word signifies sacred or holy, an object that is venerated. It is also the name of a subdivision representing the dry land of the earth. The dark-plumed eagle is spoken of by this term, because of its symbolic use; a child chosen as an emblem of innocence in a peace ceremony is called Hoæ´-ga. The origin of the word, being obscure, can not be analyzed."

••• Cf. hcíëo, hpáðìhòka. 

hâka léëe. N golden eagle when young, spotted eagle (HRE). [Harry Red Eagle, Jr., whose adult name is hcíëo hâka, contrasts hâka [h„ka] 'bald eagle' with hcíëo 'golden eagle'.] •• JOD (slip file): xúða léëe <qü-¢á §k¢e-še> the spotted eagle, syn. hâka ópe léëe <hañ§ka ü§pe §k¢e§ce> spotted tail eagle.

•• LFD 65: hâka léëe <hoæ'-ga gthe-zhe> the mottled sacred one, the immature golden eagle.

hàpái (variant of hôòpa ðé).

hce. INJUNCTIVE may it be that (often translated as 'let, allow, have, tell (s.o. to); let's [speaker and one other person]') (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; FH/06/26/01/pc). brúwì hce let me buy it, I'll just buy it (LS). màhkása ðé bráahtà hce I'll just drink this coffee; let me just drink this coffee. ëówile brée hce let me accompany you (RBn1-30). çáake owíbrììke hce let me shake your hand (RBn22-08). lìì ëówile hce let me sit with you (RBn10-4:MOJ/79). hkâàce záani brúwì hce let me buy all the apples. ðekáiha kå, áwitòpe hce come over here and let me look at you; come over this way so that I can watch you. John akxa Mogri Mary óhkà hce éeakxai John told Mogri to help Mary (FH). hkâàce záani âðuwì hce let's [us two] buy all the apples (RBn1-45). óØie che kaçôe hce [let's] leave the problem alone (04/26/95/FH/pc). mâàhispe ðuuzaa, ëâà toe àkáase àkái hce get the axe and let's go cut some wood (RBn2-MOJ/p20; 01/06/95/FH/pc: okc). hkáwaceëenì tóa àðáahtà àkái hce let's [us

two] go drink some beer.

••• Cf. htai. 

hce ée. [hce INJUNCTIVE + ée 'say'] (sequence often translated as 'request [that s.o. do s.t.]', 'ask [s.o. to do s.t.]', 'propose [that s.o. do s.t.]', 'instruct/tell [s.o. to do s.t.]', 'have s.o. do s.t.'). [Pronounced with no interruption, as hcée.] íe tóa ékipçe hce ée apa they've asked me to say a few words. iðái hce ée apa they've asked me to speak (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). iðáe hce ée akxa he wants me to talk, he proposes that I talk (RBn10-21). owáhòì ìhtáce épçe hce ée apa they told me to call you father (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

wiëîke oðíhkà hce épçe I asked Sonny to help you. çéeðò nààëî txa hú hce éa tell the person standing there to come here. çéetxa kå hce éa tell him [standing] to be coming back here. màlî hce éa tell him to go home. hiiðá hce éa have him take a bath (FH/06/26/01/pc). mîìake çáhpe tà, lí hce éa have them come back at six o'clock.

hcé xópe (variant of hcéxope).

hcéðe (variant: hcéða [FH]). N automobile wheel, tire. hcéðe mààstósto a muddy tire (03/22/95/FH/pc). hcéðe akxa tóëe akxái the tire is flat (03/22/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.141). hcéðe mààðô hta mìksé I'm going to steal a tire (RBn12-07).

hcéðe álìì. N bicycle.

•• LFD 160: hceðéalì <¾se-the´-a-gthiæ> a cycle, bicycle.

••• Cf. hcelî álìì.

hcée. N buffalo.

•• LFD 157: hce <¾se> bison.

••• Cf. hceemîìka, hceetóe, hceetóoka.

hceehîì. N [hcée + hîì] woman's yarn belt (lit., 'buffalo hair') (BE2.162; 01/07/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 159: hcehî <¾se-hiæ´> buffalo hair, woven for belts and armlets, for straps for tying bundles, and for sacred articles.  

hceemîìka. N buffalo cow (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc; BE2.13).

•• LFD 159: hce míka <¾se mi´-ga> female buffalo, a cow.

hceeníxaxa (variant: hceeníxàxà). N tripe. [One speaker claimed that this form means 'the ruffly leafed layers of a buffalo'; cf. xáxa.] hceeníxàxà ðaaché âzo çtà I like tripe (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.144).

•• LFD 159: hceníxàxà <¾se-ni´-xoæ-xoæ> tripe (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). hceníxàxà ðache azo çna aða <¾se-ni´-xoæ-xoæ tha-tse a-šu shna a-tha> [expected Mod. Os. form: hceeníxaxa ðaaché âzo çtà (çna appears to be Omaha rather than Osage)] I like tripe.

hcéeska (variant: hceeská). N beef (lit., 'white buffalo'); head of cattle, cow (not necessarily female). hcéska wì cØéðe htai let's kill a beef (RBn11-02/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976).

•• LFD 157: hcéska <¾se´-ška> white buffalo, domesticated cattle. hceská apa kizo pi a niskiðe saki <¾se-ška´ a-ba gi-šu bi a ni-ški-the ša-gi> [preferable Mod. Os. word order is: hceeská apa niskúðe saakí kízope] cattle like rock salt. hceskácØeðe <¾se-ška´-¾s'e-the> the slaughter of beeves.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 157).

••• Cf. hceeskátooka.

hceeská mîìka (variant: hceeská mîe). N cow, heifer (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 157: hceská mika <¾se-ška´ mi-ga> domestic cow, white buffalo female.

hceskámika ëìka <¾se-ška´-mi-ga zhiæ-ga> a heifer.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 157).

hceeskátooka (variants: hceeská tóe, hceeská tooká). N [hcéeska + tooká] bull, steer (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod; ok).

•• LFD 157: hceskátoka <¾se-ška´-do-ga> bull, steer.

hceetóe (variant of hceetóoka).

hceetóeëìká. N young or small male buffalo.

•• LFD 158: hce tóe ëìká <¾se-do´ zhiæ-ga> a young buffalo bull, bladder [the translation 'bladder' is dubious] (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc: young buff. bull, not bladder).

hceetóoka (variant: hceetóe). N buffalo bull (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/25/95/PM/pc:okc).

•• LFD 158: hcetóka <¾se-do´-ga> buffalo bull (also a personal name) (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). hcetóka akxa nôhpewaða pe <¾se-do´-ga a-ka noæ´-pe-wa-tha bi a> the buffalo was dreadful (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok).

hceetóoka kiçipi. N [kiçipi apparently contains ki- INCEPTIVE + waçî + api] June, hunting time (lit., 'the buffalo bull is fat anew') (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). [Names of months were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 158: hcetóka kiçipi <¾se-do´-ga gi-shi-bi> Moon when the buffalo bulls regain fat, June (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok).

hceetóoka màànâãape. N June (lit., 'buffalo bull is rutting'). [Names of months were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 158: hcetóka mànàãapi <¾se-do´-ga moæ-noæ-xa bi> when the buffalo bulls rut, the month of June (04/25/95/PM/pc: ãápe 'ready for the female').

••• KS mànâãe to be in rut, to paw the ground (RR).

hceeëî. N small buffalo, unborn buffalo calf, any unborn calf (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). [A valued food, especially for older people without good teeth. At peyote church the older ones get the unborn calf as the best part of the beef at breakfast, along with corn, fruit, and water; these are the four things allowed (PM).]

•• LFD 162: hcé ëîka <¾se zhiæ-ga> little buffalo, unborn calf.

hcéãe (variant of céãe).

hcéãenii (variant of céãenii).

hcéhapa. N spoon (FH).

•• LFD 158: hcéhapa <¾se´-ha-ba> shell spoons.

hcehé. N buffalo horn(s).

•• LFD 159: hcehéhko <¾se-he´-Ðu> a buffalo-horn spoon.

hcéheska (variant: céãeska). N cup (identical with màhkásai ooëú) (BE2.28; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): màðìkØa céãe <maæ-¢iñk'ªa §t§sªe´xªe>, <maæ-‰iñk'ªa §t§sªe´xªe> pottery.

•• LFD 159: hcehé ëìa <¾se-he´ zhiæ-a> a cup. hcéheëì. N dish, dishes (e.g., a set of plates, cups, and bowls) (FH:6/25/01/pc:h not ã); cup.

•• LFD 159: hcehé ëìa <¾se-he´ zhiæ-a> a cup.

hcehpé (variants: hcéhpe, hcehpú). N liver. waðáahtà çtà éhtana hcéhpe hpíiëi kçí aape he has a bad liver from always drinking (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc). hcéhpe kihúheka áape he had liver trouble (02/16/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.80). hcée hcéhpe buffalo liver.

•• RB: <tséh-pú> (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• JOD (slip file): hcehpú <tse-pu´> a liver.

•• LFD 159: hcehpíscece <¾se-¼i´-stse-dse> the long liver, spleen.

••• KS ääeppå liver (RR).

hcéka. ADJ new, fresh, recent. oðíhtà hcéka wì çcúwì? did you buy a new car? wahcéka owákihce I'm looking for new things (FH/09/24/01/prod). hcéka xci brand new, as a new car (02/27/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.93). hcéka ëì really new, very new. • ADV just now, newly, recently, just a while ago (RBn23-17; MREI/#94). hcéka ðachíe? did you just get here? hcéka ðahpáahà tòpéwai you look like you just got up (RBn14-12). hcéka ðiníe che ákòze hta akxa ska? are you just [now] going to be examined? (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn3-MOJ/p17; 04/11/95/LS/pc:ma). hcéka alíipe he just got back (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig; 04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). hcéka ðanôe ðe you are young (lit., 'recently you grew up') (02/27/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 158: hcéka <¾se´-ga> recently, anew, early, new (e.g., a new blanket, a new robe). hcéka ali pe <¾se´-ga a-gthi bi a> he has come recently. hcéka xci ce <¾se´-ga-xtsidse> inchoate, incipient (unconfirmed, 02/13/95/FH/pc:uk). hcékaxci <¾se´-ga-xtsi> fresh, new. hcékamàì <¾se´-ga-moæ-iæ> Goes-in-new-plumage (personal name; refers to the young eagle) (02/27/95/FH/pc:name ok, but unfamiliar, possibly weather clan?). hcéka nò <¾se´-ga noæ> newly grown, just grown to maturity.

••• Cf. wahcéka. 

hcéka nôò. N teenager, young person or young people, children in their teens (lit., 'recently grown-up' or 'recently adult') (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok, FH: children in their teens). hcéka nôò çò àhé, wábruãe hkôbra ìké I'm still young, I don't want to get married (BE2.162; RBn17-p02).

níhka ëúuce hcéka nôò ohkíhpache apa hàðé waachí hta apai Indian Youth Council are having a dance tonight (lit., 'man red newly grown council . . .') (RBn23-14).

•• LFD 158: hcéka nò <¾se´-ga noæ> newly grown, just grown to maturity (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

hcékaëì. ADV just now, just barely. hcékaëì alípe she had just got back here. hcelî. N [presumably contracted from hcéðe + álìì] wheel (FH:5/01/96/tape).

hcelî álìì. N bicycle (lit., 'sit upon a wheel') (FH:4/22/96/tape:okc). hcéðe álìì achípe he came on a bicycle (RBn12-06).

••• Cf. hcéðe álìì. 

hcéokØa (variants: hcúekØa, cØéokØa [MOJ]). N frog (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod; MOJt#150a).

•• LFD 271 (unconfirmed): hcépiukØa <¾se´-biu-Ð'a> a frog.

hcéwa. N yonkapin (RBn11-02/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976).

•• LFD 160: hcéwaðe <¾se´-wa-the> Nelumbo lutea: "The root of this plant is gathered and used for food. . . . The seeds are also eaten (raw). In taste the meat of this seed is not unlike the chestnut. . . . Its common name is water chinquapin."

hcewîìke (variant of lébrà hce wîìke). 

hcéxi. ADJ sacred, precious, difficult.

••• Cf. hkáwa wahcéxi, mììhcéxi. 

hcéxope (variant: hcé xópe). N spider. hci hcé xópe ochíe the house has a lot of spiders (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125).

•• LFD 161: hcéxope <¾se´-xo-be> a spider. hcéxope sape <¾se´-xo-be ša-be> black spider. hcéxope ëeka <¾se´-xo-be zhe-ga> spider legs.

hcéxopehuuscee. N tarantula (lit., 'spider of long legs').

•• LFD 162: hcéxopehuscee <¾se´-xu-be hiu stse e> long leg spider: tarantula.

hcéze (variant: htéze [RB, archaic]). N stomach, abdomen, belly. içíkØà hcéze íhuheka kçí aape my sister-in-law is sick with her stomach, they say (FH/09/23/01/pc:prod). hcéze íhuheka kçí áape he [lying down] is sick of his stomach (FH/09/23/01/pc).

•• RB: <téh-zeh> [older form htéze also accepted, possibly heard as hcéze] (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.128 & RBn1-MOJ/p26b).

•• JOD (slip file): hcéze <tse´-¦se> the abdomen, belly.

•• LFD 157: hcéze <¾se´-še> abdomen, the belly.

hcéze bráze. N hernia (lit., 'torn [in the] stomach or abdomen') (03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc).

•• LFD 157: hcéze bráze <¾se´-še btha-še> hernia, rupture.

hcí. N house  (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.68). [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] hcí ðuuwásu ðí clean the house (RBn10-12:JW). hcí che wébruwì bríiçtà I concluded the selling of the house; I sold the house. • nest. súhka htâà mîka wì hcí káaãe ðí aape the turkey went out to make a nest (RBn19-03). hcí káaãi che éëi ípahòëi apá aape no one would ever know where she made her nest (RBn19-03). miØíðòpeìkçe htaha, mìhiðéìkçe htaha, aðápe çki hôwaì hcí wíhta íiðaëi htape they may go to the east, they may go to the west, but they'll never find where I built my nest (RBn19-03). súhka htâà mîka hcí nalôhkile ðáalì káaãe che oëoáhkiëi ðe áape turkey hen was proud because she could hide her nest so well (RBn19-05). • V [reg., _hci] (intr.) camp, make camp.  

 •• LFD 133: çôke hci <shoæ´-ge ¾si> dog-house, a kennel. LFD 162: hci <¾si> house, dwelling, hovel. hci wihta <¾si wi-¾a> my house. hcí ðihta <¾si´ thi-¾a> your house.

••• Cf. ahcí. hcí hpíiëi. N shack (lit., 'bad house'). hci hpíiëi wì paaxó ki a shack in the hills (RBn102:MOJ/79).

hcí tóopa. N (personal name) [Name of Charlie Pasetopah (?)] (FH).

hcíce (variant: hcíci). N drumbeat, beat of a drum, beating or thumping sound (e.g., footsteps) (RB). céãenii hcíci ðáalì çkáaãe you hit drum well (RBn1-40).

•• LFD 155: hticé <¾i-dse´> the sound of a drum or the thud of many feet.  

••• Cf. ðihcíceðe.

hcíhta. ADV [hcí + hta 'toward'] inside, in (motion into rather than position within, as in 'come in, come inside'; lit., 'into house') (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc). niiëúe tà hcíhta kåa come inside when it rains (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.71; RBn1-41). hcíhta ówe aðîku bring the groceries in the house (FH:prod). ówe hcíhta aðîku bring the groceries in the house. áçihta brée àëì ðíe hcíhta wéðaahpa ði I'm going outside, but you stay inside and wait [for people] (FH:prod). hcíhta pçú hkôbra I want to come inside (FH/prod).

hcíi (variant of hcîì).

hcíko. N my grandfather (shortened form, used informally or as an endearment).

••• Cf. wihcíko.

hcíle. V [reg., hcí_le] (intr.) live, reside; make a home, set up a household, set up housekeeping (FH). paaxó ki nàhtâhtàëì ëíhi wì hcílepe in the hills lived a little brown donkey (RBn15-0). ní áçka hcíle tà ée ðáalì it's good to live near water. wakØó htà apa ðéka hcíle apái that's where eldest daughter lives. • N house, home, household (FH; 04/11/95/LS/pc). hówaiki àhcíle àkáðe tà wherever we're living (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.67). hcíle àkóhta çkaçkáða àkái we are happy in our home (RBn12-03p5). wakØóhtà hcí ðe ée aðî apa, hcílepa ðée káaãe my daughter has this house, she's making a home in it (PM/7/7/94; 02/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

• family (HRE/12/29/01/pc; BE2.43; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ðé hcíle ðáalì çkáaãe [w]aawíta, waxpáðì hta akxai I pray you make it good for this family, when they're pitiful (RBn106:JW). huuhtâka ohkíhkie apai, hcíle apa hípe a whole bunch of them were talking when the family came over (3/2/89/MSB). ðe hcíle akxa tooká ðìké that family has all girls (01/14/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 163: hcíle <¾si´-gthe> to keep house, to reside, to dwell, to set up house. hci ále <¾si a´-gthe> I keep house. hci ðale <¾si tha-gthe> you keep house. hci àla <¾si oæ-gtha> we keep house.  

hcíohka. N [hcí + óhkâ] room. hcíohka wì ðáalì ówakØupe they lent us a nice room (RBn23-14).

hcióçka. (variant hcióçka possibly used only by women) N my/your/his/her father's sister's son (used when speaker is male or female; more precise than English 'my/your/his/her cousin'). [Does not use inalienable forms.]  

hcipóãa. N Native American Church house.

•• LFD 162: hcípoãe <¾si´-bo-xe> a conical tent, a tipi.

••• KS ääíiboãa tipi, tent with poles tied at the top (RR).

hcíwaëu. N [hcí + wa- VAL + áëu (or hci + wa- VAL + ooëú?)] headright (lit., 'they put in the house') (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod, BE2.65).

•• LFD 164: hcíwaëu <¾si´-wa-zhu> household, family.

hciëé (variant: hcíëe). N door. hciëé ðuuáza open the door (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok). hciëé áðììtà close the door (01/20/95/ERE/pc; BE2.34).

•• LFD 164: hcíëe oðakacØì <¾si´-zhe u-tha-ga-¾s'iæ> you peeped in the door. hciëépe. N doorway, threshold (formal, used especially for "God's doorway" at funerals [RB])

(HH/09/10/93; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.34). [Takes 'standing' positional article che.]

•• LFD 168 htíëepeche oðakáhcì <¾i´-zhe-be-te u-tha-ga´-¾s'iæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: hciëépe che oðákacØì] you peeped in the door.  

hcíëepe áhkita. N porter (lit., 'doorway soldier').

•• LFD 164: hcíëepe ahkita <¾si´-zhe-be a-Ði-da> a porter, door-servant.

hcíëo. N golden eagle (HRE/pc/Dec.2002); Hcíëo, an important Osage tribal division.

•• LFD 165: hcíëo waçtake <§Tsi´-zhu Wa-shta-ge> the Gentle Tsí-zhu (refers to its office as Peacemaker).

••• Cf. hâka, xúða.

hcîì (variants: hcíi, hcíe; htîe [archaic], htîì [archaic]). V [reg.?, _hcîì] (intr.) appear, show. ëé wahtîe apái his penis is showing [to them, to others] (anonymous source). wakáahcìe appears to them suddenly (personal name, referring to deer aroused by something that suddenly

appears; George Shannon's Osage name).

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p24 ln6): áhci aðápe <átcia¢ápe> he suddenly charged.

•• LFD 119: nàëîhcie <Noæ-zhiæ´-tsi-e> [expected Mod. Os. form: nààëîhcìe or nààëîhcìì] Rises-suddenly (personal name; refers to the alertness of the buffalo).

hcoçpá. N [shortened form of wihcóçpa] pal, friend, buddy; my grandchild. hcoçpá wíhta my friend, my pal.

•• LFD 165: hcoçpaðò <¾su-shpa-thoæ o> grandchild (unconfirmed; 05/01/95/LS/pc:uk with ðò).

••• Cf. wihäóçpa. hcú hápa. N ladle.

••• Cf. níiðaahtà.

hcúekØa (variant of hcéokØa).

hcúãe. ADJ dried up. wakáaëi wihta hcúãeëì that's my driver, he's a little dried up guy (PM).

•• LFD 165: cØóãe <¾s'o-xe> tart; Astringent (personal name; refers to the taste of the root of the blazing star). çe cØoãe <she ts'o-xe> [<ts'> is presumably a typographical error for <¾s'>] the apple is tart.

••• Cf. hcúxe (possibly related or a variant).

hcúke (variant: hcúka). N spoon (Osage spoons were originally clamshells from creeks, used only for scraping corn, with little ones for children, larger ones for adults; this term is now used for spoons of other materials such as metal, plastic, or wood) (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.126); abalone shell; shovel (03/09/95/FH/pc; unconfirmed as 'shovel'). ðée hcúke that spoon (03/14/95/FH/pc:hc). mâze hcúke metal spoon. htaaníi hcúke íðaachapi eat soup with a spoon [to pl. addressee].

•• LFD 163: hciuke <¾siu´-ge> a spoon, a shell spoon.

••• QU htíke cup, ladle made of horn (refers to clamshell spoon etymologically) (RR).

••• Cf. ëâàhcuke. hcúkØa. ADJ decayed, rotten.

••• Cf. ëààhcúkØa. 

hcúxe. ADJ mangy. çô hcúxe mangy dog (PM/7/7/94; 02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.84).

•• JOD (slip file): cØuxe <ts'u-qe> mangy.

he. DECL sentence-final declarative marker used by female speakers (recorded by LF only; not found in Mod. Os.).

•• LFD 129: hápa ðiçpi che apçe he <ha´-ba thi-shpi tse a-pshe he> I pounded the corn [woman speaking]. hápa ðiçpi che ðapçe he <ha´-ba thi-shpi tse tha-pshe he> you pounded the corn [woman speaking].

hé. N horn (e.g., of cow or buffalo). htaahékaaãe deer-making-horns (personal name) (RBn2204). hé ðúçka crooked horns (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.67).

•• LFD 59: he <he> horn. LFD 159: hcehéxoce <¾se-he´-xo-dse> a young buffalo with gray horns (not yet turned black with age).

hé ðúçka. N name of a dance (lit., 'crooked horns') received by Poncas before they had horses, when dogs carried their loads. [The dance was given by the Poncas to the Kaws; subsequently the Kaws gave their drum to Pawhuska and Hominy Osages; the drum was given by Poncas to Grayhorse Osages (RBn11-01/JW&FW; HHsk/c.1977).]  

hé káaãe. N roached hair, little boy's roached hair with a tail (lit., 'make horn') (RBn1101/JW&FW; HHaskell/c.1976, unconfirmed).

••• KS hegáãe scalp lock (LF The Omaha Tribe) (RR).

héchì. V [reg., _héchì] [onomatopoeic] (intr.) sneeze (RBn19-01). ahéchie I sneezed (021083p4). ðahéchie you sneezed (021083p4). héchìpé he sneezed. àhéchìpe we sneezed.

héðòòpa. N [hé + ðòòpá] braids (lit., 'two horns'); ponytails (two sections of hair, one gathered from left and one from right side of the head, bound close to the scalp, and hanging loosely). héðòòpa ì wearing braids (lit., 'wearing two horns'). héðòòpa káaãe akxái he's wearing braids (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.11). héðòòpa wearing braids (FH; 04/13/95/LS/pc).

hée. N lice, louse (BE2.79, RBn2-MOJ; HH; 02/15/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 59: he <he> louse.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 59).

heehé (variant of hehé).

héeoce (variant: hióce). N [hée + océ] monkey (lit., 'looks for lice').

heháha (variant: heháhai) V [reg.?, _heháha] [reduplicated?] (intr.) breathe hard, pant (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.12).

hehé (variant: heehé). V [reg.?, _hehé] (intr.) short of breath. heehé apai he's shortwinded (RBn HW; FH:okc).

•• LFD 59: hehé <he-he´> rapid breathing, to pant, respiration. áhehe <a´-he-he> I pant. ðahéhe <tha-he´-he> you pant. àhéha pe <oæ-he´-ha i> we pant.

••• Cf. heháha.

héka. N buzzard (RBn23-08, unconfirmed [01/04/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/17/95/LS/pc:uk]); hawk. héka môçò hawk feathers (unconfirmed; 01/24/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 59: heká <he-ga´> turkey buzzard.

••• QU héga buzzard (RR); OM same as Osage (LFD 59).

hépe. ADJ, N a small amount, approximately half a container; piece, part, some, a bit. níi hépe àkØú give me a little water [about half a glass]. hépe ëì àkØú give me some, not very much. hépe àkØú give me a piece (of paper towel or napkin, etc.). súhka hépe abráache I ate some of the chicken (PM).

•• LFD 59: hépe <he´be> the half of (ritual expression). hépenà <he´-be-noæ> partly, not whole, partial [na 'only'] (03/08/95/FH/pc:ok). hépeðàðà <he´-be-thoæ-thoæ> piece by piece (unconfirmed).

••• QU hébe piece, part (RR).

••• Cf. ohépe. 

hépeëì. N a little piece, a small amount, a little bit (used with both count nouns and mass nouns). • ADV a little. waëáëeíe hépeëì hpímà I know how to talk Osage a little bit (2/2/MSB/504).

héxpa. ADJ, N [stat., _héxpa] bushy head, frowzy, unkempt (BE2.14; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok); fuzzy; disheveled (e.g., having mussed or messed-up hair). çôëì héxpa ëî little fuzzy dog (RBn2208).

•• LFD 59: hpáhìhexpa <¼a´-hiæ-he-xpa> disheveled. héxpa <he´-xpa> frowzy, unkempt. wakØo akxa htaxpi ðò héxpa pi a <wa-Ð'u a-ka ¾a-xpi thoæ he´-xpa bi a> [htaxpi ðò is unconfirmed] the woman has a frowzy head. níhka akxa héxpa pe <ni´-Ða a-ka he´-xpa bi a> the man is unkempt. LFD 125: hpáhì àhexpa <¼a´-hiæ thoæ oæ-he-xpa> I am disheveled. hpáhì ðò ðihexpa <¼a´-hiæ thoæ thi-he-xpa> [Mod. Os. omits ðò <thoæ>] you are disheveled. hpáhì wahexpa pe <¼a´-hiæ thoæ wa-he-xpa i> we are disheveled, unkempt. LFD 126: hpáxì hexpa <¼a´-xiæ he-xpa> disheveled, hair disarranged.

hi (variant of hú 'trunk').

hí (see ahí 'arrive there').

híce (variants: ahíce, hícewae). V [reg., _híce] (trans.) hurry. áhice I hurry s.o. along (108b/FH/400). íhice apái they're hurrying s.o. along (108-b/FH/416). • encourage (PM; RBn2312). tówe pa awáhihce I'm trying to encourage these people (PM/7/7/94). waëáëe apa ahice apa Osages encourage one another (PM; LS).

••• Cf. íhice, wáhice.

híceðe. V [reg., híce_ðe] [híce + ðe CAU] (trans.) hurry s.o., cause to hurry. híceàðe akxai they're hurrying me (RB: HHaskell). hícewaðe tell them to hurry (lit., 'make them hurry') (RB:HHaskell).

•• LFD 59: híceðe <hi´-dse-the> hurry, hasten. híceaðe <hi´-dse-a-the> I hurried him. híceðaðe <hi´-dse-tha-the> you hurried him. híceàwàða pe <hi´-dse-oæ-woæ-tha i> we hurried him.

hícewae (variant of híce).

híðaxa (variant: hîðaxai). N breechcloth, loincloth, diaper (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). híðaxa oxpáði akxai he [has] lost his breechcloth (RBn23-13). híðaxa éëi wì kçiãa change his diaper (lit., 'make him up another diaper') (RBn23-13; ok).

•• LFD 62: híðaxa <hi´-tha-xa> loin cloth, diaper, breechcloth (BE2.12) (RB note: also baby's diaper).

híðe. V [reg., hí_ðe] [ahí + ðe CAU] (trans.) send there (lit., 'cause to arrive there'). ihtéëì akxa mázeíe híðape his sister called (lit., 'his sister made a phone call arrive there').

•• LFD 62: hiðé <hi-the´> to have gone, to have departed, cause to reach there, send thither [all meanings except 'send thither' unconfirmed (03/06/95/FH/pc:uk)].

híðòkxeì (variant of hîðohkiëì).

híenà (variants: híenài, hínà). VP [uninfl.] happen. híenài it happens (FH/pc). hínà when it gets to be that time (lit., 'just as it arrives').

•• LFD 93: míòpa ohkiste hi e nà <mi´-oæ-ba u-Ði-šte hi e noæ> semimonthly. (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 61: hí nà <hi´ noæ> come to.

hii (variant of îhì). 

híi (variant: hîì). N tooth, teeth (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). [Originally híi 'tooth' had a non-nasal vowel, while hîì 'hair, fur' had a nasal vowel, but currently both forms are used for both meanings.] hîì ðáalì çô ðàìçé your teeth are still good (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc). hîì hpíiëi àhé I have bad teeth (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc). hîì lúuëa brush your teeth [imperative] (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.143). híi çki ðiiskíke akxai he's even grinding his teeth.

•• LFD 59: hi <hi> tooth, teeth.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 59).

híi (variant of hú 'trunk, leg' and of hîì 'hair'). híi ìke. ADJP [híi 'tooth' + ðìké NEG] toothless, without teeth (BE2.143; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). hiiðá. V [reg.+sync., _hii_ðá] (intr.) bathe (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). hàpái ahíibra I took a bath today (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). ahíibra hkôbra I want to take a bath (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). ahíibra hta àhé I'm going to take a bath. ðahíiða ðáalì you ought to take a bath [unexpected form of the verb] (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.7). ðahíiçta nìkçé you are bathing (FH:prod). hiiðáape he bathed (FH:prod: aa). hiiðá akxa he's taking a bath (FH/06/16/01/pc). hiiðá wikí[ð]e I'm giving you a bath (lit., 'I am causing you, my own, to bathe') (MREI 1-01-93-8).

• swim. àhíiða çki hta àkái we are also going to swim (05/02/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.130).

•• LFD 61: hiðá <hi-tha´> to bathe in a stream. hiðá bre ha <hi-tha´ bthe ha>

[sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I go to bathe. hiðá àkaða pe ha <hi-tha´ oæ-ga-tha pe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] we go to bathe.

híihkà (variant: híihka). N ankle (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). híihkà wasúhuëi dirty ankles (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.3). híihka wákalà akxái your ankles are dirty (RBn10-3:MOJ/79).

•• LFD 60: híhkà <hi´-Ðoæ> ankles. híhkà wihta ëìka <hi´-Ðoæ wi-¾a zhiæ-ga ha> my ankles are small. híhkà iëìka <hi´-Ðoæ i-zhiæ-ga> small of the leg, the ankle.

híinààëi (variant of hínààëì).

híiØì (variant of hîì). N [hîì 'hair, whiskers' (with unexpected denasalization) + î 'wear'] whiskers (FH).

híko. N fable; learning(?) (RB, unconfirmed, FH: not 'learning'). [Fables are the Osage children's stories in which animals are the main characters, told especially during winter. Some modern speakers (LS) say that snakes will come out if these stories are told at other times of the year; others (FH) disagree that there is danger of snakes, but all agree that winter or when it is snowing is the time for telling a híko.] híko wì obráake hta mìkçé I'm going to tell you a story (JS) (BE2.77).

•• LFD 60: híko <hi´-go> a fable, a myth, a story not to be taken literally.

hínà (variant of híenà).

hínààëì (variant: híinààëi). V [sync.+reg.?, _hí_nààëì?] (intr.) become. ókaaãeìke akxa ðée nàkØôpi áha wáli kíhpiiëi hínààëìpe when Useless heard that, he really got sad (RBn102:MOJ/79). John akxa ðée nàkØôpi áha, wálì kíhpiiëi hínààëìpe when John heard that, he got very sad. • begin, start. oðíhtà ðiitâ çô apa, waachí hínààëì nàpé when he would pull the wagon, he'd start in dancing (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). [The 2nd sg. form parallel to this example would presumably be waachí çíðanààëì (?) 'you would start in dancing'.]

•• LFD 61: hínàëì <hi´-noæ-zhiæ> having arrived there and stood (from a ritual).

hióce (variant of héeoce).

híò (variant: húì). V [conjug. unknown] move to another location.

••• Cf. wahúì.

híònìì (variants: håüni [FH], hìúni). N garter (as for Osage dance costume) (BE2.53). (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok: håüni).

hípçe. V [reg., _hípçe] (intr.) stumble and fall. ahípçe I stumbled and fell (RBn10-2). hípçape he stumbled and fell (RBn10-2). hípça ìká! don't stumble and fall! (RBn10-2).

hiú (variant of hú).

hiúçce (variant of húuscee).

hî. INTERJ isn't it so (expression inserted between phrases, marking pauses, in certain speeches of early to mid-1900s, somewhat like French "n'est-ce pas?" or use of "you know?" by some English speakers).

••• KS hîe question-marking particle (JOD, RR).

hî (variant of hîì).

hîðaxai (variant of híðaxa).

hîðohkiëì (variant: híðòkxeì). ADJ naked, nude (RBn22-08, unconfirmed). John akxa Mary áðiiëà hiðohkiëì John has Mary in bed naked (RB, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 338: ðohkáðì <tho-Ða´-thiæ> stripped to the waist.

••• KS yokkáyì naked or stripped to the waist (MR, RR); QU ðokkânì, tokkânì naked to the waist (RR), ëó ðokkánì hí naked, nude (RR).

hîì (variant: hî). N color, colors, bright colors. hîì ke wáli ohtázape their colors [of the flowers] were very beautiful.

••• QU hìhtazí brown, oak colored (RR); KS óphà hì ekô elk colored, dun [may be hîì] (JOD, RR).

hîì (variants: híi, híiØì). N hair, whiskers, fur, fuzz as on a peach (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok); slivers or small strips of anything. [Originally hîì 'hair, fur' had a nasal vowel, while híi 'tooth' had a non-nasal vowel, but currently both forms are used for both meanings.]

••• Cf. hceehîì, hpahîì, hpaxîì, ììçtáhìì, mààhî. 

hîì (variant of híi 'tooth').

hîì (variant of îhì).

hîìce (variant: hììcé). N dish, plate (FH/8/30/94; prod; PMt#97A; 02/27/95/JS/pc); crockery, bowl; bark (of a tree) (BE2.6; 01/20/95/FH/pc:ok). hîìce huuwáli a lot of dishes. hîìce ëì àðíiçtàpe we're through with these dishes (FH:prod). áwanòbre hîìce áëu set the dishes on the table (BE2.31). hîìce húu aðî akxai they have a lot of plates (RBn14-10). hîìce huuhtâka a lot of dishes (FH:4/17/96/tape). hîìce wíbruleke I broke your dish.

•• LFD 60: hìce <hiæ-dse> the linden tree and its bark. "The inner bark of this tree was often used in making twine and for rough weaving. The inner bark of the following trees was also used: hiæ-dse xo-dse, gray linden (saplings). hiæ-dse zhu-dse, red linden. hiæ-dse sha-be, dark linden. hiæ-dse wa-xtha, the papaw." hîce xci hi chece oða nàëì <hiæ´-dse xtsi hi tse-dse u-tha noæ-zhiæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: hîìcehi che ce oðánààëî] you stood under the linden tree. hîìce braða <hiæ´-dse btha-tha> bowls made of basswood, widened. hîce braxe <hiæ´-dse btha-xe> china plate. LFD 61: hîcehpe <hiæ´-dse-¼e> a wooden tray or bowl for bread or meat. LFD 101 (unconfirmed): mò ôhka hìce <moæ-oæ´-Ða hiæ-dse> [expected Mod. Os. form: môìhka hîìce 'earth plate'] crockery. [Modern speaker's comment: Both 'plate' and 'crockery' are hîìce, but môìhka hîìce is unknown (LF) (04/17/95/LS/pc).] LFD 225: ëâhìce <zhoæ´-hiæ-dse> a wooden bowl. LFD 233: hîce <hiæ´-dse> inner bark of a tree.

••• KS hîìýebe dish, plate, tray, bowl (RR).

hîìce apakØâ. N platter (t#14b-p1; 04/17/95/LS/pc:uk).  

hîìce braaka. N platter (HHtL3-B-p1); dish that is flat and wide (HH).

•• LFD 61: hîce brakØa <hiæ´-dse btha-Ð'a> a plate.

hîìce hu. N pawpaw (the plant, not the fruit).

•• LFD 60–61 (unconfirmed): hîce hu <hiæ´-dse hiu> the papaw (Asimina triloba).

hîìce íðuuëa wépukxa. N [hîìce + í- LOC + ðuuëá + wépukxa] dish soap, dish detergent (lit., 'soap for washing dishes with') (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.32).

••• JOD (slip file): wépuka <we´§-pü-ka> soap.

hîìce ípukxa (variant: hîìce ípuxa). N dish towel (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.32).

hîìcecØohu. N fire-drill stick, stick used to rub fire-making wood (ëâàhpeece).

••• JOD (slip file): hî tsetØoho <hiæ´ §t§se-t'uhu> stick . . . used to revolve on the [ëâàhpeece] as a fire-drill.

hììcéëì. N [hîìce + -ëì 'little'] small crafts (lit., 'small bark', 'small plate'). hììcéëì áëu hta apai they're going to put out [set out] their crafts [for sale] (FH:5/02/96/prod).

hîìhkiàpi. N [presumably hîì 'colors' + hkik- REFL + ôò 'wear' + api] Wearing Bright Colors (personal name) (FH: prod). [Name of FH's relative Martha.]

hîìòke (variants: húuìke, hûùìke, hûùke). N [perhaps from hîì 'color'] hosiery, stockings, socks, leggings. håìke xó gray leggings; gray stockings (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; RB). hûùìke ðiiçtóe take off one's stockings (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod orig). húuìke bríiçtoe I took off my stockings (MREI). húuìke àðíiçtoe we took off our stockings (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok).

•• LFD 62: húìke <hiu´-iæ-ge> leggings (man's).

hîìòke xóe (variant: hûùke xóe). N socks (lit., 'gray hosiery'). hûùke xóe ðiiçkí wash the socks.

hîìska. N beads (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 60: hìská wanòpØì <hiæ-ška´ wa-noæ-¼'iæ> bead necklace. hìská ëìka <hiæ-ška´ zhiæ-ga> small beads.

••• KS hìská beads (RR).

hîìska káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, hîìska _káaãe] do beadwork (04/19/95/FH/pc). • N beadwork.

hììská wekáaãe. VP [sync. k>p, hììská we_káaãe] do beadwork (RB). • N beadwork. hîìskawáata. N [hîìska + waatá] rosary (lit., 'beads for prayer/praying').

hììçá. N Caddo (tribe or tribal member) [tribe near Kingfisher or Anadarko, Oklahoma, of which Stanley Edge and John Wilson were members] (01/20/95/FH/pc:prod orig; 03/08/95/PM).

•• LFD 61: hìçá <Hiæ-sha´> Caddo Indian Tribe. hîìçce (variants: hîìçce, hîìçcece, hîìçäece). ADJ fuzzy. çôke akxa hîìçäece akxai the dog is shaggy, the dog is fuzzy (BE2.52; 01/30/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 61: hîscece <hiæ´-stse-dse> shaggy or long haired. çôke akxa hîsceca pe <shoæ´ge a-ka hiæ´-stse-dsa bi a> the dog is shaggy.

hîìçceëî (variant: hîìçäe ëì [Hominy version]). N fuzzy balls (especially the small fuzzy balls on yarn garters or on a woman's belt), "pill" (as on a sweater when loose fibers form tufts or balls) (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc).

hîìçäece (variant of hîìçce).

hîìzìì. N [possibly hîì 'hair' + zízi 'brown' (PM)] mink (BE2.88, RBn1-MOJ/p22, RBn1-24).

•• LFD 60: hìzîmàì <Hiæ-šiæ´-moæiæ> Brown-hair-walker (personal name; refers to the color of the buffalo calf).

hîçe. ADJ, V [uninfl.] fat (said of a person). wáli hîçe àhé I'm really fat (BE2.45; RBn2/p17, unconfirmed; 01/23/95/FH/pc:no).

hìúni (variant of híònìì).

hkaamâ. V [uninfl.] (intr.) ring (FH).

•• JOD (slip file) hkámà <ka´-maæ> vb. root: ring, as a bell. íikaahtamà hcéska nòpØî kçíðe, hkaamâ màðî apá <í§katamaæ tséska nªuæ´p'iæ kcí¢ªe, kamaæ´ maæ´¢iæ apa´> the cow being made to wear a bell on the neck, it rings as she walks.

•• LFD 82: hkamâ <Ða-moæ´> the sound produced by the striking of a bell.

••• Cf. ðuuhkáamà (and perhaps íikaahtamà).

-hkace (variant: -hkaci). V ROOT heat, hot.

 ••• Cf. óhkace, táahkace.  

hkáãe. N crow (BE2.27; FH:4/22/96/tape:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): hkáãe <k'a´-xªe> crow.

•• LFD 83: hkáãe <Ða´-xe> crow. LFD 84: hkáãe htàka <Ða´-xe ¾oæ-ga> big crow, a raven.

••• OP kkáãe crow.

hkáãe htâka. N raven.

hkáwa. N horse, pony. hkáwa ðé kxa that horse standing (02/09/95/FH/pc:prod orig; BE2.68).

•• LFD 82: hkáwa <Ða´-wa> horse, nag, pony (corruption of the Spanish word for horse). hkáwa hkipánà. N horserace (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.68).

hkáwa óØku (variant: hkáwaakØu). N Horse Feeder (personal name). [May be an error for hkáwa ókØu.]

hkáwa wahcéxi. NP wild horse (lit., 'difficult horse'), untamed horse (RBn HW13; RBn22-06).

hkáwa wakØú. N Horse Giver (personal name).

hkáwa xóe (variant: hkáwa xóce). N gray horse.

••• Cf. hkáwaxoce.

hkáwaakØu (variant of hkáwa óØku).

hkáwaalìì. V [reg., hkáwaa_lìì] [hkáwa + álìì] (intr.) ride horseback (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). • ADV horseback, mounted on a horse. hkáwaalìì aðáapi che they have gone horseback riding (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.68).

•• LFD 82: hkáwaalì <Ða´-wa-a-gthiæ> to ride horseback. hkáwa aalì <Ða´-wa a-agthiæ> I ride horseback. hkáwa aðalì <Ða´-wa a-tha-gthiæ> you ride horseback. hkáwa àkalì pe <Ða´-wa oæ-ga-gthiæ i> we ride horseback.

hkáwaalìì aðée. VP [sync., hkáwaalìì a_ðée] (intr.) go on horseback. hkáwalìì aðéei ché he has gone on horseback (RBn3-05; FH/11/19/01/pc:ok). hkáwalìì aðáapi ché they have gone on horseback (RBn3-05).

hkáwaceëenii. N [hkáwa + céëenii] beer (lit., 'horse urine'). hkáwaceëenii tóa àðáahtà àkái hce let's go drink some beer [said to one person] (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• QU téëe urinate (RR); KS ýéëe urinate (RR).

hkáwatòpa. N [hkáwa + tôpe] horse herder, horse watcher (WHM981022, unconfirmed).

hkáwaxoce. N Grayhorse camp (near Fairfax, Oklahoma) (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok: use hkáwaxoce for the town name).

hkáwaëì htâwà. N [hkáwa + -ëì 'little' +htâwà] Bartlesville, Oklahoma (lit., 'little-horse town') (RBn2-MOJ/p32; HRE/01/17/02/pc:ok).

•• LFD 83: hkáwaëìka <Ða´-wa-zhiæ-ga> name given to the town of Bartlesville, Kansas [sic], by the Osage.

hkâ (variant: hkô). N vein, artery, blood vessel. .

•• JOD (Devouring Mountain p2 ln10): nâàce kà pápaaãe akxa ska <nªan§t§se-k‘ªaæ §pá§paxe  akqá ska> he cut off a heart vein or artery.  

•• LFD 351: hkò <Ðoæ> vein.

hkâàce. N apple; fruit. hkâàce áazo I like apples (BE2.3; FH/09/09/01/pc). hkâàce wì hâàpa záani çtáache tà, ðáalì aapé an apple a day is good, they say (equivalent of "an apple a day keeps the doctor away") (FH/09/09/01/pc).  

hkâàce hîìçce (variant: hkâàce hîìçäe). N peach (03/07/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.102).

•• LFD 89: hkâce hì scee <Ðoæ´-dse hiæ stse-e> hairy plums, peaches. hkâce hì scee che zi <Ðoæ´-dse hiæ stse-e tse ši> [expected Mod. Os. form: hkâàce hîìsce zi, without che] yellow peaches.

hkâàce hpá álà. N pear (lit., 'apple with a nose placed upon it') (BE2.102; 03/06/95/FH/pc:okc).

hkâàce oolâ (variant of hkààcóolà).

hkâàce púze. N dried fruit.

hkâàce sápe. N prune.

•• LFD 89: hkâcesape <Ðoæ´ dse-ša-be> black plums dried, prunes.

hkâàce xóce. N plum. hkâàce xoce apa cuuta pe the plum is ripe (LFD 39; FH; 01/11/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 89: hkâce xoce <Ðoæ´-dse xo-dse> the wild plum.

hkâàce zi. N orange (BE2.99; 03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 89: hkâcezi <Ðoæ´-dse-ši> an orange. hkâce si wì hkòbra <Ðoæ´-dse ši wiæ Ðoæbtha> I want an orange. hkâce si wì çkòçta <Ðoæ´-dse ši wiæ shkoæ-shda> you want an orange. hkâcezi hi <Ðoæ´-dse-ši hi> an orange tree (unconfirmed, 03/03/95/FH/pc:uk).

hkâàce zi cØáaðe. N lemon (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.78).

•• LFD 89: hkàcési cØaðe <Ðoæ-dse´-ši ¾s'a-the> sour orange, lemon.

hkâàce zi ëî. N apricot (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok, ok; BE2.3).

hkâàce ëàà. N burial stick, red stick put into coffin at head or foot, made of special wood (FH/11/19/01/pc).  

hkâàce ëúe (variant: hkâàce ëúuce). N tomato (BE2.142; 04/26/95/FH/pc:okc). hkâàcenii. N [hkâàce + níi] fruit juice (t#14a-p5; 04/14/95/FH/pc).

hkààcóolà (variant: hkâàce oolâ). N [hkâàce + oolâ] pie of any sort (fruit, cream, etc.) (lit., 'place fruit into it') (03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok). watxâ hkààcóolà pumpkin pie. •• RB: <káhæ-tseh o-d-?-láhæ>. •• LFD 89: hkâce olà <Ðoæ´-dse u-gthoæ> pie. hkâàze. N Kaw, Kansa (tribe or tribal member) (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok, PM ok; BE2.73). •• LFD 88: hkâze <Ðoæ´-še> Kaw Indian. ••• KS kkâàze Kansa tribe, gens, the Kaws (RR).

hkéðo. N clear sky, as after a storm. •• LFD 85: hkéða <Ðe´-tha> the sky, the unclouded or clear sky. hkéðamàì <Ðe´-thamoæ-iæ> Clear-day-approaching (personal name).

hkée. N turtle, tortoise, terrapin (04/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.145). •• LFD 84: hké <Ðe´> turtle, tortoise, terrapin. hke táhpa ëìka <Ðe da´-¼a zhiæ-ga> little round turtle. ••• WI: kee turtle (KM).  

hkeetáxe. N shadow (BE2.119; 03/09/95/MREI:ma). [Archaic.] •• LFD 84: hkétaxe <Ðe´-da-xe> shadow. hkétaxe wì hpaxe <Ðe´-da-xe wiæ ¼a-xe> I cast a shadow. hkétaxe wì nòhpa pe çìhtoëìka akxa <Ðe´-da-xe wiæ noæ-¼a bi a shiæ-¾o zhiæga a-ka> [expected Mod. Os. form: hkéetaxe wì nôòhpape çîhtoëì akxa] the boy was afraid of the shadow. ••• KS kkédaãe (JOD), kkédaxe (MR) shadow, shade (RR).

hkéetaxewatôe. N [hkeetáxe + watôe] movies (lit., 'watch shadows') (RB, unconfirmed). hki- (form of the reflexive prefix hkik- except before c, k, p, t, Ø [where it is hkih-]; see hkik-).

hkíaci. V [reg., _hkíaci] [hkik- REFL + kaací] (intr.) wipe oneself (in the bathroom, after using the toilet) (RB; LS). ðahkíaci? did you wipe yourself? (in the bathroom only) (05/01/95/LS/pc; BE2.159). ëìkáëi apa hkíaci apai the children are wiping themselves (05/01/95/LS/pc). hkiácipi wipe yourselves (05/01/95/LS/pc).

hkícheðe (variants: hkíicheðe). V [reg., hkíche_ðe] [perhaps hkik- REFL + che POSIT + ðe  CAU] (trans.) put down, set down, or place a standing item on a surface (e.g., a bowl of soup or basket of rolls) (FH:04/24/96/t-s2). hkíicheðaa! set it down! (FH).

•• LFD 80: hkíicheðe <Ði´-i-tse-the> to put down a thing that can stand, as a filled bag, a pole, or a gun. LFD 86: hkíicheaðe <Ði´-i-tse-a-the> I put it down. hkíicheðaðe <Ði´-i-tsetha-the> you put it down. hkíicheàða pe <Ði´-i-tse-oæ-tha i> we put it down.

••• KS kkiiähégiye put down his [standing inanimate] object before its owner (RR).

••• Cf. kícheðe, ohkíicheðe. hkiðé. ADV [contains hkik- RECIP] beside each other (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod). hki[ð]etóopa eight (lit., 'two fours beside each other').

hkíðe CAU [reg., _hkíðe] [hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] (intr.) make oneself (to do or be). óëì hpíiëi ðìké, ókØà ðáalì hkí[ð]a don't get angry, have good ways (lit., '. . . make yourself be of good ways') (01/04/95/FH/pc).

hkietóopa (variant: hkiðétoopa). ADJ, N [hkiðé 'beside each other' + tóopa] eight (lit., '[two] fours beside each other') (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod). hkíðetóopa ooëú nàpé they [used to, always] put in eight (BE2.41; 04/18/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 85: hkíetopa <Ði´-e-do-ba> eight; the archaic word for eight is <¼e-tha-bthiæ>.

[Unconfirmed as 'eight' by Mod. Os. speakers.]

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 85).

hkih- (form of the reflexive prefix hkik- before c, k, p, t; see hkik-).

hkihkáaãe. V [reg.+sync. k>p, _hkih_kaaãe] [hkik- REFL + káaãe] (trans.) make, build, or make up for oneself (e.g., one's bed), do for oneself. [The expected (but perhaps not attested?) 1st sg. form of this verb is áhkihpáaãe or ahkíhpaaãe 'I built it for myself'; the expected 2nd sg. form is ðáhkiçkáaãe or ðahkíçkaaãe 'you built it for yourself'.] áëà hkíhkáaãa make your bed up (02/24/95/FH/pc; RBn2-MOJ/p33). ðíe hkihkáaãa do it for yourself.

••• Cf. waðílà hkihkáaãe.

hkíhkìnì. ADJ curly, kinky, tangled (FH:okc,08/96). [Borrowed from English kinky.] hpaxîì hkíhkìnì curly hair, black (African) hair, tangled hair.

hkihkôða. V [reg.+sync. fortisizing stop stem, _hkih_kôða] [hkik- REFL + kôða] (trans.) want as one's own, want for oneself. ðáhkiçkòçta you want it as your own.

hkihkôze. V [reg., _hkihkôze] [hkik- REFL/RECIP + kôze] (intr.) hold a Native American Church meeting, have or put on a peyote meeting (lit., 'teach oneself, teach each other'). haakxâta ðahkíhkôze hta paaçé? when are you all going to have a peyote meeting?

(04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). haatxâta ðahkíhkòze hta paaçé? when are you all going to have a meeting? (RBn14-06). iinâëì akxa hkihkôze hta akxái my aunt is going to have a meeting (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok). • N Native American Church (the religion also known as peyote religion, brought to the Osages by John Wilson [known as Moonhead]); peyote meeting, Native American Church meeting.

•• LFD 86: hkihkôze <Ði-Ðoæ´-še> the act of religious devotion.

hkihkôze waaðô. N peyote song, song sung in peyote meeting. hkihkúce. V [reg., _hkihkúce] [hkik- RECIP + hkúce] shoot each other, shoot at each other.

hkíhpaahi V [reg.+sync. fortisizing stop stem, _hkíh_paahi ] [hkik- REFL + paahí] (trans.) pick, pick up, choose, select for oneself. tanákØa hkíhpaahi! pick up your papers [yourself]!

(03/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.102). ðahkíçpaahi you chose it for yourself.

•• LFD 87: hkihpáhi <Ði-¼a´-hi> to choose a man or woman from their own number, as in a ball game.

hkihpíò (variant: hkíhpiò). V [reg.+sync.+sync. nasal vowel stem, _hki_hpí_ò] [hkik- REFL + hpíò] (trans.) know or learn for oneself (RB; 04/14/95/PM/pc:ok). ðahkíçpíëò çkôçta it's yours and you want to learn it [speaking of Indian ways] (lit., 'you learn it yourself; you learn it for yourself') (RB: PM:ok). ahkíhpimà I learn for myself. ðahkíhçpiëò you learn for yourself. hkihpíò she learns for herself. àhkíhpiò we learn for ourselves.

hkíhtòpe (variant: hkihtôpe). V [reg.+sync. fortisizing stop stem, _hkíh_tòpe] [hkik- REFL + tôpe] (intr.) look at oneself. hkíhtòpa! look at yourself! hkihtôpe ðiiçtà! quit looking at yourself! àhkíhtòpe we're looking at ourselves. • (trans.) look at one's own. [Reflexive used as suus.] waáhkihtôpapi húða come and look down upon us.  

hkíicheðe (variant of hkícheðe).

hkiistó. N council meeting, tribal council session meeting; conference. hkiistó panáape he adjourned the council meeting.

•• LFD 85: hkistó <Ði-što´> a council, assemblage, meeting, U.S. Congress, the Senate, court, session.

••• KS kkistó ääí council house or church (RR); QU kistó council of a gens, kkistó htâka tribal council (RR).

••• Cf. kiistó. 

hkiistó omàðì (variant: hkiistómàì). N council member, senator, congressional representative, lawmaker, legislator (lit., 'walks to council') (BE2.26; 01/13/95/FH/pc:ok). hkiistómaì háanà hípe? how many councilmen were present? (lit., '. . . arrived there') (RBn3-01).

•• LFD 85: hkistó omàðì <Ði-štu´ u-moæ-thiæ> a member of the United States Congress, a Senator or Representative.

hkiistóhci. N [hkiistó + hcí] courthouse (01/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.26), council house. •• LFD 85, 245: hkistóhci <Ði-štu´¾si> council house, council house at the agency.

hkiistómàì (variant of hkiistó omàðì).

hkik-. PREFIX [hkih- before c, k, p, t; contracts with following ð to form hkil-; hki- elsewhere, but possibly hkik- before Ø] reflexive prefix: oneself, myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves. éwaahkikØô I did it to myself (FH/11/17/01/pc). owáhkihkie I'm talking to myself (RBn10-21; FH/11/17/01/pc). áhkihtôpa ðì watch out for yourself. éwaðahkikØô you did it to yourself (FH/11/17/01/pc). éwahkikØô he did it to himself (RBn10-4:MOJ/79; FH/11/17/01/pc). hkikØâzehkíe make oneself comfortable (RBn2MOJ/p31). • reflexive prefix with benefactive interpretation: for oneself, for myself, for yourself, for himself, for herself, for itself, for ourselves, for yourselves, for themselves. • with reflexive possessive (suus) interpretation (object is possessed by subject): my, your, his, her, our, their. wacúe skúe áhkihtòì hce let me look at my cake. • reciprocal prefix: each other, one another. ðakØéàhkiðe we are kind to each other (FH/pc). ëóhkile with each other (RBn15-01). níhka wakØó hkíoxta akxai the man and woman love each other (FH:t142). óxtahki[ð]api cherish each other, regard each other as great. óxtahkiapi cherish one another, cherish each other (FH/12/95 prod). • reciprocal prefix with indirect interpretation (dative, benefactive, etc.): for each other, to each other, with each other.  haxî hkíkØu pe they gave each other blankets. waahkíhta paahá pray for each other, raise it up (RBn10-15).

hkikØâze. V, ADJ [stat.?, _hkikØâze?] [perhaps contains hkik- REFL] (intr.) (be) comfortable.

hkikØâzehkiðe. V [reg., hkikØâze_hkiðe] [hkikØâze + hkíðe 'make oneself'] (intr.) rest (lit., 'make oneself comfortable') (RBn10-5:MOJ/79). hkikØâzehkíe making oneself comfortable (RBn2-MOJ/p31).

••• KS kØâzegile (JOD) to rest (intr.) (RR).

hkikØú (variant: hkíkØu). V [reg., _hkikØú] [hkik- REFL + kØú] (trans.) give each other. haxî hkikØúpe they gave each other blankets (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok).

hkiláawa. V [reg., _hkiláawa ] [hkik- REFL + ðaawá] (intr.) count oneself. táatà níðaepi tà ðáalì ée nà aape àëi hkiláawa ée ìkápi they say it is good to give but not to count yourself (lit., 'when you [pl.] give something at giveaway, it's always good, they said, but as for counting yourselves, don't do that') (RBn23-17; CQ:okc).  

hkilaaxô. V [reg., _hkilaaxô] [hkik- REFL + ðaaxô] (intr.) bite oneself.

hkiláaëoëi V [reg., _hkiláaëoëi] [hkik- RECIP + ðaaëóëi (lit., 'hurt each other by mouth'), but with simple transitive interpretation] (trans.) curse a person; say bad things about s.o., "down" s.o. by slandering, maligning or belittling (RBn2-MOJ/p12; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). ••• Cf. ðiiëóëi, hkilíiëoëi.

hkilázo. V [reg., _hkilázo] [contains hkik- REFL] (intr.) relax, recover, come to, after being unconscious. ðahkílazo? did you get relaxed? (RBn23-15, unconfirmed). âskike ààzî ðekôòci ahkílazo I was tired but now I'm recovered (FH:t#128). ëúoka ahkílazo mìkçé my body is recovering (FHt#128). hkilázo akxai he's waking up (as after surgery) (FHt#128).

hkilâke. V [reg., _hkilâke] [hkik- RECIP + lâke] (intr.) marry each other. •• LFD 86: hkilâke <Ði-gthoæ´-ge> intermarrying into another tribe [JS: hkilâke is 'marry', not 'intermarry'.]  ••• Cf. mîìlàke. 

hkilíihkòìãe. V [reg., _hkilíihkòìãe] [hkik- REFL + ðiihkóìãe] (intr.) turn oneself around. ámahta na hkilíihkoìãa turn yourself the other way.  ••• Cf. -hkóìãe, -wìãe.

hkilíisà (variants: hkíliisàðe, hkilíisàðe). V [reg., _hkilíisà(ðe)] [hkik- REFL + ðiisâða] (intr.) turn oneself around. níhka akxa hkilíisàpi iáha òòwíbre tà wakØâ hta mìkçé áape the man turned around and said, "I'll sure be glad when I get rid of you" (RBn79/p4). • change one's ways.

hkilíiski. V [reg., _hkilíiski] [hkik- REFL/RECIP + ðiiskí] (trans.) gather up for oneself, gather together for oneself. táatàëì ðahkíliiski hta nìkçé? those little things that you've got, small items, are you going to gather them up? (JS) • (intr.) (with reciprocal interpretation) gather with each other, gather together. ðahkíliiski hta pààçé? are you all going to gather [together with each other]? (FH:5/02/96/pc). àhkíliiski we gather together (FH). hôòpa hpahâle che hkilíiski hta apai the first day of the week, they're going to gather together (FH:4/24/96/tape). àhkiliiski àkatxâ we are gathered together; we are gathering together. • N (with reciprocal interpretation) gathering of people, meeting, people gathering with each other.

hkilíiça. V [reg. _hkilíiça] [contains hkik- REFL] (intr.) undress oneself, get undressed. •• LFD 85: hkilíça <Ði-gthi´-sha> to disrobe, to undress, to remove one's clothes. ahkíliça <a-Ði´-gthi-sha> I undressed. ðahkíliça <tha-Ði´-gthi-sha> you undressed. àhkíliça pe <oæ-Ði´-gthi-sha i> we undressed.

hkilíiçki (variants: hkíliiçki, ahkíliiçki). V [reg., _hkilíiçki] [hkik- REFL + ðiiçkí] (intr.) do laundry for oneself, wash clothes for oneself. ahkíiliçki I did laundry for myself (FH/08/01/01/pc). hkíliiçki akxa she washed [clothes] for herself (FH/08/01/01/pc).

ahkíliiçki she washed for herself (FH/01/08/01/pc).

hkíliiçtà. V [reg., _hkíliiçta] [hkik- REFL + ðiiçtâ] (intr.) ready oneself, get oneself ready. ahkíliiçtà àkái hce I've got myself ready, let's go (RBn14-07; FH:okc). ahkíliiçtà I'm ready (RBn14-07&FH: a not à). hkíliiçta akxai he's ready (RBn14-07).

hkilíiziðe. V [reg.?, _hkilíiziðe?] [hkik- REFL + ðiizíðe] (intr.) stretch oneself (FH).

hkilíiëoëi. V [reg., _hkilíiëoëi] [hkik- RECIP + ðiiëóëi] (intr.) mistreat one another, hurt one another physically or emotionally. níhkaçie apa wáli hkilíiëoëi apai the people are mistreating each other (RBn 3/3/77).

hkilôãemàì. N honey (FH:4/22/96/tape, ok). •• JOD (slip file): hkilôãemàðì <ki-¦k¢ªuæ'-xe maæ'-¢iæ> a bee, bees.

hkílò(lò). V [reg., _hkílò(lò)] [contains hkik- RECIP; reduplicated] (intr.) call each other names. ðahkílò ðaaçé you [moving] are calling yourself a name (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). hkílòlò apái they are calling each other names; they called each other names (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn107:JW). hkílòlòpe they called each other names (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

hkilúhpiiëi. V [reg., _hkilúhpiiëi] [hkik- REFL + ðuhpíiëi] (intr.) make a mistake causing dishonor to oneself, do or cause oneself ill or harm, harm oneself by making a serious mistake. wáli ahkíluhpíiëi àëi óðàëi ahkílabrì hta mìkçé I made a bad mistake but I'll carry myself on anyway (RBn 5/3/79).

hkilúuhepe. V [reg.?/uninfl., _hkilúuhepe] [hkik- REFL + ðuuhépe] (intr.) urinate (lit., 'make oneself lighter'; euphemism used principally by men rather than women). hkilúuhepe hta mìkçé I'm going to urinate.

hkilúuçawa. V [reg., _hkilúuçawa] [hkik- REFL + ðuuçáwa] (intr.) undress oneself.

•• LFD 85: hkilíça <Ði-gthi´-sha> to disrobe, to undress, to remove one's clothes. ahkíliça <a-Ði´-gthi-sha> I undressed. ðahkíliça <tha-Ði´-gthi-sha> you undressed. àhkíliça pe <oæ-Ði´-gthi-sha i> we undressed.

hkilúuçtake (variant: hkíluuçtake). V [reg., _hkilúuçtake] [hkik- REFL + ðuuçtáke] (intr.) undress oneself. hkíluuçtake he's undressing himself.

hkilúuwasu. V [reg., _hkilúuwasu] [hkik- REFL + ðuuwásu] (intr.) clean oneself. hkilúuwasu! clean yourself up! (RBn12-08).

hkíluwì. V [reg., _hkíluwì] [hkik- REFL + ðuwî] (trans.) buy for oneself. ahkíluwì I bought it for myself (04/06/95/FH/pc). oðíhtà wì ahkíluwì I bought a car for myself. wíe ahkíluwì akxâhe I'm buying it for myself. ðahkíluwì you're buying it for yourself. wahkíluwì apai he bought stuff for himself. hkilúwì akxai she's buying it for herself. ðée hkilúwì apai she bought that for herself. hkilúwì apai they bought it for themselves.

hkíòðe. V [reg.+sync., _hkíò_ðe] [hkik- RECIP + ôòðe] (intr.) divorce, throw each other away (usually used for the process of divorce). [Once the divorce is accomplished, ohkóòðe is more likely to be used.] hkíòðe apai they are getting a divorce, they're separated, they are throwing each other away (04/06/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.32). ohkíòðape they divorced each other.

•• LFD 87: hkiôða <Ði-oæ´-tha> to throw each other away; divorce. àhkíòða <oæ-Ði´-oætha> I am divorced. ðahkíòçta <tha-Ði´-oæ-shta> you are divorced.

hkipánà. V [reg., _hkipánà] [perhaps contains hkik- REFL] (intr.) run in a competition (perhaps lit., 'place oneself first') (FH). hkáwa hkipánà the horse races (FH). • N race.

•• JOD (slip file): hkipanà <ki-§pa-naæ> [no definition given; no accent mark visible].

•• LFD 85: hkípanà <Ði´-ba-noæ> to run a race. ahkípanà <a-Ði´-ba-noæ> I run a race.

ðahkípanà <tha-Ði´-ba-noæ> you ran a race. àhkípanà pe <oæ-Ði´-ba-noæ i> we ran a race.

••• Cf. hkáwa hkipánà, níhkahkipánà.

hkíxiða V [reg.+sync., _hkíxi_ða] [probably hkik- REFL + xí_ða] (intr.) despair, mistrust oneself, not trust oneself, doubt oneself, give up. ahkíxibrai I give up, I can't; I don't think I can do that, I'm not sure of myself (e.g., about driving a car) (FH/11/19/01/pc:ok). ahkíxibrai I don't trust myself (RBn22-05). hkixíðaaëi self-confident, undismayed, not doubting (personal name). hkíxiðape he gave up (FH/11/19/01/pc). •• LFD 88: hkixíða <Ði-xi´-tha> to despair, to become hopeless, disheartened. ahkíxibra <a-Ði´-xi-btha> I am in despair. ðahkíxista <tha-Ði´-xi-sda> [expected Mod. Os. form: ðahkíxiçta] you are in despair. àhkíxiða pe <oæ-Ði´-xi-tha i> we are in despair. kkixíðapaëi <Ði-xi´-tha-ba-zhi> Self-confident (personal name, refers to the warlike spirit of the gens). hkixíðaëi <Ði-xi´-tha-zhi> undismayed.

hkíëì (variant: hkíëaì). V [reg. (+sync. nasal vowel stem), _hkíëa(_)ì (the second inflectional position is only optionally used)] [contains hkik- RECIP] (intr.) be angry at each other, feel quarrelsome; (trans.) be angry at s.o., feel mad at s.o. ahkíëàmie I'm mad at him (RBn105:JW). àhkíëi apái she is mad [angry] at me (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). wíe ahkíëi àhé I'm mad at him (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). àhkíëì ðìká don't be mad at me (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). awáhkiëì mìkçé I'm mad at them (MSB mar83). àðáhkiëi you're mad at me (2/3/83/p2; PM/7/7/94; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). àhkíëi apa he's mad at me (RBn10-5:JW). •• LFD 88: hkiëì <Ði-zhiæ> to quarrel. ðahkíëì <tha-Ði´-zhiæ> you quarrel. ••• Cf. aëî, ihkíëì, ohkíëì.

hkóða. N friend (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod orig). hkóða ðí áape they were friends (lit., 'he was a friend, they said') (RBn18-01; CQc). hkóða akxa hkáwa ðòòpá kòzéhkihkò waaðîpe my friend has two horses just alike. •• LFD 90: hkóða <Ðu´-tha> a friend.

hkohkóma. N pickle, cucumber (03/07/95/FH/pc:ma; BE2.102). [Possibly borrowed from English cucumber.]

•• LFD 88: hkohkóma <Ðo-Ðo´-ma> cucumbers. hkohkóma ðizo a(?) <Ðo-Ðo´-ma thi-šu a(?)>[sentence-final a is not used in Mod. Os.] do you like cucumbers? hkohkóma cØaðe <Ðo-Ðo´-ma ts'a-the> pickles. hkohkóma skuðe <Ðo-Ðo´-ma šku-the> sweet pickles.

hkóhkosa (variant: hkohkósa). N pig, hog, shoat, pork (t#14a-p4). [Possibly borrowed from French cochon.] hkóhkosa léze [expected form: ..  . léëe] spotted pig. hkóhkosa htáa pork (03/08/95/FH/pc:okc). •• LFD 88: hkohkósa ëìka <Ðo-Ðo´-ši zhiæ-ga> a young pig, a shoat. hkohkósi hta <ÐoÐo´-ši ¾a> pork; pig meat. hkóhkosa hta ðízo na? <Ðo-Ðo´ši ¾a thi-šu a(?)> do you like pork?

hkohkósa ékò. ADJ hoggish. •• LFD 88: hkohkósa ékò <Ðo-Ðo´-ša e-goæ> like a hog, hoggish (03/08/95/FH/pc:ok).

hkohkósa wéli. N lard, pork fat (03/08/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 88: hkohkosa weli <Ðo-Ðo-ša we-gthi> hog grease, lard.

-hkóìãe. V [root, conjug. unknown] (intr.) turn, turn around. •• LFD 348: nôhkowìãe <noæ´-Ðu-wiæ-xe> to turn with the foot. páhkowìãe <ba´-Ðuwiæ-xe> to turn by pushing. ••• Cf. ðiihkóìãe, hkilíihkòìãe, opáwìãe, -wìãe. 

hkóopçe (variant: hkóopçi). V [reg., _hkóopçe] (intr.) sneak off, flee, run away (FH/02/17/96/pc:prod). ahkóopçeçtà aapé she says I'm always sneaking off (RBnot 5/3/79/p4). çîhtoëì wì iiðáðe hkóopçi apai the boy that I saw was running away (3-2-163). •• LFD 88: hkóipçe <Ðo´-i-pshe> fear, misgiving [definition not acceptable in Mod. Os.]. 

ahkoipçe <a-Ðo-i-pshe> I had misgivings. ••• Cf. kíhkoopçe.  

hkô (variant of hkâ).

hkôha. N edge. •• LFD 127 (unconfirmed): hpéce hkòha <¼e´-dse Ðoæ-ha> edge of the fire. ••• KS içtáxüha kkâha edge of the eyelids (RR).

hkúce. V [reg., _hkúce] (intr.) fire a gun, shoot a bow and arrow (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). ahkúce I shoot (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; FH:4/24/96/tape:ok). ðahkúce you shoot (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; FH:4/24/96/tape:ok). ée hkúcape he shot (FH:4/24/96/tape). • (trans.) shoot s.o., shoot at s.o. àhkútapé they shot me (RB). àhkúcape they shot me (FH:4/24/96/tape). ahkúce àëi akçîìce I shot at it but I missed it (FH:4/24/96/tape,ok; RBnotnd-1).

•• LFD 90: hkúce <Ðu´-dse> to shoot. ðahkúce <tha-Ðu´-dse> you shoot.

••• Cf. hkihkúce.

hlaaská (variant of laaská).

hlaazípe (variant: hlaazípepí). N [laaská + zi + pe POSIT] August, sunflowers in bloom (lit., 'there are yellow flowers') (HRE/01/17/02/pc:ok; RBn12-05). [One of the very few words in which an initial hl is preserved in Mod. Os. Names of months were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]  

hléke (variant of léke).

hlîì (variant of lîìëe). 

hlúëe, hlúëi (variants of lúëi).

hó. N fish.

hó bráaska (variant: hobráaska). N perch (lit., 'flat fish') (03/07/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn3-MOJ/p5).

•• LFD 63: hobráska <ho-btha´-ška> flat fish, perch. hobráaska apa ðaaché ðáalì pe <ho-btha´-ška a-ba tha-tse tha-gthiæ bi a> perch is good to eat.

hóhkihpaache (variant of óhkihpaache).

hóhtàka. N  Winnebago (Hochunk) (tribe or tribal member) (unconfirmed; 03/08/95/PM/pc:uk; 04/06/95/LS/pc:uk).

•• LFD 68 (unconfirmed): hóhtàka <Hu´-¾oæ-ga> Big Fish, the name given to the Winnebago by the Osage. [It is not certain that LF's etymological explanation of this name as 'Big Fish' is correct.]

hóhtàka íe. N Winnebago language. }

•• LFD 68 (unconfirmed): hóhtàka ie <Hu´-¾oæ-ga i-e> Winnebago language (05/01/95/LS/pc:uk).  

hóize (variant: hóízi). N line, fishing line, hook and line (RBn3-MOJ/p4; ERE:ok; 02/16/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/14/95/PM/pc:uk).

•• LFD 63: hóizi <ho´-i-ši> fishhook.

hóize ëâàxe. N fishing pole (RBn3-MOJ/p5).

hóni (variant: hôni). ADV almost, nearly (can be used to express 'fail to'). hóni waëáëeíe akxai he can almost talk Osage (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.2). hóni brîìçtà I'm almost finished (RBn3MOJ/p15; LH tape; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). hóni axíbra I almost fell. çôke akxa hôni âðaxtake the dog almost bit me (RBn22-10). hóni ðacØé you almost died (FH:prod). hóni àwâchìpe they almost whipped me (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc).

hóo. N voice. • V (intr.) bark, moo, quack, etc., make an animal noise. çôke apa hóo apái ðe the dogs are howling (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• WI hóo voice (KM).

••• Cf. óhoo.

hooðáalì. N [hóo + ðáalì] Good Voice (personal name) (WF/02/pc). [Name of William Fletcher's paternal grandfather.]

hóohtà. V [reg.?, _hóohtà?] (intr.) yell, holler, shout (lit., 'loud voice') (RBn1-11); sing or sound out, make a loud sound; make animal sounds (e.g., sing like a bird, moo, bark, howl) (FH).

hóohtàmàì [hóohtà + màðî] Goes Around Hollering (personal name of John Stink) (FH/01/10/99). kasîexcì waëîka apa hóohtà nààpé the birds sing early in the morning (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). lôò hóohtà wálìpe the thunder was really loud (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). waëìka apa hóohtà apái the birds are singing (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). hceeská apa hóohta apái the cows are mooing. çòmìhkási apa hóo apái the coyotes are howling (RB).

•• LFD 67: hóhtà <ho´¾oæ> the cry or call of animals or birds. LFD 68: hohtàmàì <Hu¾oæ-moæ-iæ> Roars-as-he-comes (personal name).

hóolà. N [hó + oolâ] fishing. hóolà brée I'm going fishing (01/25/95/FH/pc:okc). kasîxci hóolà bree hkôbra àzi nuuëúëu akxai I wanted to go fishing this morning, but it was sprinking (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod orig). hóolà aðée they went fishing (01/25/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.48). iinâ akxa ëìkáëì hóolà íëoçi nàpe mother used to tell the children not to go fishing (FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). hóolà àkái hce let's go fishing [speaking to one person]. hóolà àkái htai let's go fishing [speaking to more than one].

•• LFD 67: hóolà <ho´-o-gthoæ> to fish, to go fishing (01/25/95/FH/pc:ok). hóolà àðahpe <ho´-o-gthoæ oæ-tha-¼e> [expected Mod. Os. form: hóolà àðáhpape] you invited me to go fishing. hóolà bre a ðo <ho´-o-gthoæ bthe a tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: hóolà brée; the ending a ðò is not used in Mod. Os.] I am going fishing.

hóosaaki. V [reg., _hóosaaki] [hóo + saakí] (intr.) whoop, call loudly (lit., 'hard voice').

hóosaaki he whoops.

•• LFD 28: pà hósaki <boæ hu´-ša-gi> to call or shout loudly. ahósaki <a-hu´-ša-gi> I call loudly. ðahósaki <tha-hu´-ša-gi> you call loudly. àhósaki pe <oæ-hu´-ša-gi i> we call loudly.

hooxcî (variant of hôòxcì).

hóoxpe (variant of hóxpe).

hóçechie (variants: óoçechia, óoçechie). V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) startle or shock s.o. (RB); (intr.) be excited, startled, shocked. hóçechíepi tà, ììçtá ápisài koe áa ákabra nâàke htaacéëì oðîìke ahú apai he was excited, with his eyes closed and his arms open he came running to catch Whirlwind (RBn17-p). • (intr.) jump, as when startled (RBn23-14, unconfirmed). • N shocking news, startling report. • ADJ shocking, overwhelming, startling.

•• LFD 67: hóçachiðe <ho´sha-tsi-the> to startle. hóçachiðe àðikaaãa pe <ho´-sha-tsithe oæ-thi-ga-xa i> we startled you. [This example seems to be a double causative, having both -ðe and káaãe.]

••• QU óëa dance (RR).

hówa. INTERR/INDEF ADJ, INTERR/INDEF PRON which, which one. hówa ìkçe çkôçta? which one do you want? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok, BE2.156). hówaxcì txá? exactly which one [standing person]? (LS/07/27/95/pc:prod). hówaxcì ché? exactly which one [standing object]? (LS/07/27/95/pc:prod). hówa ðe? where?/which one? (04/28/95/LS/pc).

•• LFD 67: hówaðe <ho´-wa-the> where, which one. hówaðìkçe <ho´-wa-thiæ-ke> which one (sitting).

••• Cf. hówaìkçe, hówaxcì. 

howachéeçki. INTERR/INDEF ADJ, INTERR/INDEF PRON whichever one (inanimate), whatever (thing), anything, everything. howachéeçki íiðaðe? did you see anything?

howaðéeçki. INTERR/INDEF PRON whichever one (animate), whatever one (person or animate being); anybody; everybody. howaðéeçki ohkíe nàpé he talks to just anybody (RBn104:MOJ/79). howaðéeçki áðuãe hkôbra ìké I don't want to marry anybody (RBn17-p02). howaðéeçki ðakØéða[ð]e you're good to everybody (FH prayer). • whoever. howaðéeçki chí tà, hcíhta hu hce éa whoever comes, tell them to come in the house (RBn10-4: MOJ/79).  

••• Cf. háaçki.

howáìki (variants: hówaìki, hówaìkice, howáike, hówai). INTERR/INDEF ADV where, wherein, where at, where to; be where. howáìki çcée? where are you going? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc). howâìki çtáape? where are you [pl.] going? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:prod). hówaìki oálìì çkôçta? where do you want me to sit? (RBn10-4:MOJ/79; BE2.156). howáìki apai? where are they? (04/28/95/LS/pc). howáìki paaçé? where are you all? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). howáìkí ðaìçé? where are you? • wherever, be wherever. howáìki apa wherever they're at (7/8/94/PM/t#98b). howâìki ðòòpá ðáabrì náçki ecíe akxa tà, wíe ée brî hta mìkçé na ée eçie wherever only just two or three are, I will always be there, you said (from a verse of the Christian Bible) (FH:prayer). howáìki apa ðée wherever they're at (04/28/95/LS/pc). howáìki àðé wherever we [two] are (04/28/95/LS/pc). hôwai íiðai hce you'll never find it (lit., 'wherever will you find it?') (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc).

 •• LFD 67: howaìkíhtàche <ho-wa-iæ-gi´-¾oæ-tse> [expected Mod. Os. form: howaìkí hta che] from what source, what direction. LFD 67 (unconfirmed): hówake ðìke <ho´-wa-ge thiæ-ge> nowhere. hówaki htà ðachi a? <ho´-wa-gi ¾oæ tha-tsi a(?)> [expected Mod. Os. form: hówaìkí hta ðachíe?] where did you come from? hówaìke <ho´-wa-iæ-ge> where, in what place. LFD 68 (unconfirmed): hówake <hu´-wa-ge> where.  

howaìkíha. INTERR/INDEF ADV through where, by what pathway, which way. howaîkíha brée? through where should I go? which way should I go?

hówaìkçe (variants: hówàìkçe, hówààkçe). INTERR/INDEF PRON [hówa + ìkçé POSIT] which one (round, sitting). hówàìkçe?/hówààkçe? which one [round or sitting thing or sitting person]? (04/28/95/LS/pc).

hówaxcì (variant: hówaxci). INTERR/INDEF PRON [hówa + xci] exactly which one (LS/07/27/95/pc:prod). hówaxcì txá exactly which one [person]? hówaxcì ché? exactly which one [inanimate]?

hówààkçe, hówàìkçe (variants of hówaìkçe).

howé (variant: hówe [PM]). ADV yes (men's speech only). oðíhta hcéka wì çcúwì? did you buy a new car? howé, wì brúwì yes, I bought one [man speaking].

•• LFD 67: howé <ho-we´> yes. hówe eci ahi pi o <ho´-we e-dsi a-hi bi o> [expected Mod. Os. form: howé ecí ahípe; sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] yes, he arrived there.  

••• KS howé yes (male speech) (RR).

hówe. N mortar, grinder, mill (RBn23-07).

•• LFD 67: hówe <ho´-we> mortar coffee mill, gristmill.

hóxpe (variant: hóoxpe). V [reg., _hóxpe] cough (01/13/95/FH/pc:prod; FH: 6-30-94). ée hóxpape they coughed (BE2.25; 2/10/83/p4). ðahóxpe you cough. ahóxpe I cough (2-10-83p4). • N cough; cold with sniffles and fever (RB, FH). hóxpe hpíiëi bad cold; bad cough (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok). wéeli hóxpe záani àwáëu mìksé I have a head cold (BE2.21; 01/19/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 68: hóxpe lili <hu´-xpe xthi-xthi> to cough mucus, to expectorate. hóxpe li

íðatxo <hu´-xpe xthi i´-tha-to> [íðatxo unconfirmed] you expectorate.

hóxpe hpíiëi. N whooping cough (or tuberculosis?), influenza, flu, bad cough, bad cold (FH).

hóxpe hpíiëi ôò akxái she has whooping cough(?) (BE2.157; FH:08/22/96).

•• LFD 67: hóxpe hpiiëi <hu´-xpe-¼i-zhi> bad cough, grippe, influenza.

hóxpe léle (variant: hóxpe líli). N phlegm (WF/12/30/01:prod).

•• LFD 67: hóxpelíli <ho´-xpe-xthi-xthi> phlegm.

hóxpe ôò. VP [sync. nasal vowel stem, hôxpe _ôò] (intr.) be suffering from a cold, cough, whooping cough (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok). hóxpe môè mìkçé I have a cold (FH/11/19/01/pc:ok). hóxpe hpíiëi [m]ôò mìkçé I have a bad cold (RB; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ma). hóxpe ëôè? do you have a cold? hóxpe òô ìkçí aape I heard he has a cold (RBn19-01). Smokey akxa hóxpe òô akxai Smokey has a cold (RBn19-01). hóxpe òô àkxai she has a cold. Christine akxa hóxpe òô îkçé? does Christine have a cold? (RBn3-55).

•• LFD 68: hóxpeò <hu´-xpe-oæ> croup, a hard cough.

••• KS hóxpe cough (RR).

hóxpe zúpe. N whooping cough (FH); tuberculosis(?) (FH, 04/28/95;LS/pc:ok). hóxpe hpíiëi ôò akxái she has whooping cough (BE2.157; FH:08/22/96).

hôbre. V [reg.?, _hôbre (LF reports hô_bre)] (intr.) dream, have a dream. hâàce ahôbre last night I dreamed (FH/5/2/95). wáli áhòbre I really dreamed [if this verb is actually stative, the expected form would be àhôbre] (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). • N dream, dreaming. hôbre oðíhpazái? did you have a nightmare? (lit., 'dreaming, did it startle you?').

•• LFD 65: hôbre <hoæ´-bthe> to dream. hòábre <hoæ-a´-bthe> I dream. hòðábre <hoætha´-bthe> you dream. hòàbra pe <hoæ´-oæ-btha i> we dream. [Verb forms unconfirmed.]

hòbrî hi. N bean vine.

•• LFD 65 (unconfirmed): hòbrî hi <hoæ-bthiæ´ hi> the wild-bean vine.

hôbrì htóho (variant of hòbrîke htóho).

hòbrîke. N beans; green beans (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). hkohkósi htáa hòbrîke oðóhkihà âzo I like beans cooked with pork meat (FH/09/21/01/pc). hòbrîke che hpaahíke I sorted the beans (FH:ok).

•• LFD 65: hòbrîke <hoæ-bthiæ´-ge> beans.

hòbrîke htóho (variant: hôbrì htóho). N green beans. hòbrîke htóho tóa ooðáhà hkôbra I want you to cook some green beans (BE2.7; RBn1-52).

hôbrìke htóho ëì. N peas; green beans (03/07/95/PM/pc:both; BE2.102).

hôò (variant of háaò).

hôòche. INTERR/INDEF ADV [perhaps contains che POSIT] how; however. mâàãe hôòche? how's the weather? (RBn12-09).

hôòe wì (variant: hôòe). PRON nobody. hôòe wì ahú apa ðakØéðie hta ðe nobody will be coming to take care of you (lit., 'nobody is coming here that will have pity on you' [FH's father used to say this often]). waðílà hkihkáaãipe, koe çómìhkasi hôòe éekò çí íiðe htai [expected form: waðílà hkihkáaãape koe çómìhkasi hôòe éekòëi íiðe hta ðe] she made up her mind, the coyote would never see anybody like her again (lit., 'her mind she made up thus: the coyote will see nobody like her') (RBn17-p03).

hôòpa (variant of hâàpa).

hôòpa ðé (variants: hâàpa ðé, hòpái, hàpái, hòpá, hôòpa, hâàpa). N, ADV today (lit., 'this day') (03/22/95/FH/pc:okc). hôòpa háaëò?, hâàpa háaëò? what did you [sg.] do today? (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.29). hôòpa htáwà ìkçi pçíe I went to town today (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.142). hâàpa ðé akxa ðáalìëi akxai it's not a pretty day today (the weather is not good today; lit., 'today is not good') (FH/10/13/96). hòpái today [not formal]. hôòpa ðé this day [somewhat formal] (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). hòòpá waðíhtà pçíe I went to work today (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 64: hôpa ðéka <hoæ´-ba the-ga> this day, today (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok).

hôòpa hú (variant of hôòpahu).

hôòpa huuwáli. ADVP, NP (for) a long time (lit., 'many days'). hôòpa huuwáli ëówaðale hkôbra I want you to be with us a long time (RBn12-10/mj).

hôòpa scée. N February (lit., 'long days') (RBn12-05). [Names of months were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

hôòpa wì (variant: hâàpa wì). NP, ADVP day, one day, sometimes, some days (RBn10-3:MOJ/79); sometime, some day. hôòpa wì súhka tóoka ókØà ékòëi káaãe nàpe sometimes the rooster did things he shouldn't do (RBn18-01). hôòpa wî àtôì hí ði come over and see me sometime (RBn10-3:MOJ/79).

hôòpa wîxci ðòòpá hta çki. NP, ADVP a day or two, for a day or so (RBn18-02).

hôòpahu (variant: hôòpa hú). V [uninfl.] be daylight, (day) break. hôòpahu akxai, íikiðapi it's daylight, wake up (RBn23-17). hâàpa hú, hpáahà it's daylight, get up (e.g., out of the chair or out of bed) (FH:prod) • ADV, N (at) daybreak, dawn, daylight. hâàpahu ëiçô before daylight (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). hôòpahu ðáalì daylight came good (said at morning light after a peyote meeting, talking to creator) (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). • daylight approaches, it's coming daylight (personal name). [Name of Herman Petsemoie, Frances Holding's maternal uncle.]  

hòòpái (variant of hâàpa).

hôòpaskaha (variants: hôòpaska, hâàpaskaha, hâàpaska). V [uninfl.] [hôòpa + skáha] be daylight (when the sky is all light or white). hâàpaskaha akxai, hpáahà get up, it's daylight (FH:prod) hôòpaskaha akxai it's daylight (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.29). • N, ADV (at) daylight (PM). wiëîke hâàpaska híi che? káanà ahí akxa Sonny, has daylight come? just a little bit [like this, showing with hand] (FH/09/24/01/prod).

•• LFD 63: hôpa ska <hoæ´-ba ška> daylight (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). LFD 64: hôpa íhtaxe <hoæ´-ba i´-¾a-xe> the tip or beginning of day (04/25/95/PM/pc:uk; unconfirmed, íhtaxe unknown).  

hòòpé. N moccasins; shoes. hòòpé tóohka wet moccasins (a female personal name, probably referring to dew on moccasins). hôòpekaaãe shoemaker (BE2.120; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; HRE).

•• LFD 64: hòpé <hoæ-be´> moccasins.

hòòpé okáwìãe. N socks (lit., 'go-around shoes', 'go-around moccasins') (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p2).

•• LFD 64: hòpé okawìãe <hoæ-be´u-ga-wiæ-xe> socks, moccasins, in which a winding is made. hàpe okawìãe htoho <hoæ-be u-ga-wiæ-xe ¾o-ho> blue socks.

••• OM hìbé gáwìxe <hiæ bé gá wiæxe> stockings (originally referred to either hair from buffalo's head or red grass, which was wrapped around the feet before putting on moccasins) (Larson 2005: 263).

hòòpé scéce (variant of hòòpésce).

hôòpekaaãe. N [hòòpé + káaãe] shoemaker, cobbler (BE2.120; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; HRE).

hòòpésce (variant: hòòpé scéce). N boot (lit., 'tall shoe') (BE2.10; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 64: hòpe stehce/steche <hoæ-be ste-¾se> tall moccasins: boots. [LF normally writes 'long, tall' as <stse-dse>; see, e.g., LFD 134.] hôòçki (variant of háaçki).

hôòxcì. (variants: hooxcî, hôòxce, hôòxci). INTERR/INDEF PRON what kind. oðíhtà hòòxcî ðáaëì nìkçé? what kind of car are you driving? (RBn10-18). nàníòpaëì hooxcî çtáaçoe nà? what kind of cigarettes do you regularly smoke? (RBn23-15). kóota ìkçé ohkíhce hôòxce ðìkçé? that one sitting over there, what kind of tribe is he? (03/23/95/FH/pc).

hôòëi (variants: hôòëì, hôëì). ADJ bad, evil, wicked. táatà ðéke hôòëike these bad things [scattered around]. táatà ðeke hôòëìke ékiò ìká don't do these bad things (RBn10-18). spoiled, ruined; inefficient, inferior, of poor quality, poor. ðe hpáata akxa, hôòëì akxai those eggs are bad (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod, HP). îìçta hôòzi apai she has bad eyes (RBn349:CQc: ì). wawéeðe hôòëi nî you see poorly (lit., 'you are of bad sight') (RB).

hòpá, hòpái (variants of hôòpa ðé).

hòpái haçíhta. N, ADVP this day some time back, this day back in time. hòpái haaçíhta hóni àcØé some days back I almost died; some days ago I almost died.

hpá. N nose, snout (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). ðe hpá that nose (FH:4/25/96/tape).

hpá piãô blow your nose. hpá ocØîze stuffed-up or stopped-up nose (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). hpahlíxtoe a runny nose (FH). hpá lîstowe your nose is running (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok). hpá lîxtowe [his/her] nose is running (RB). hpa lîstowe nìkçé your nose is running (RBn12-08). hpá káaëi blow your nose (03/01/95/FH/pc:ma; BE2.95; unconfirmed; 04/17/95/LS/pc:uk). • head, protuberance, bulge, mound (FH:4/25/96/tape:HP). ADJ bitter (FH/09/25/01/prod). màhkáhpa pepper (lit., 'bitter medicine') (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 125: hpa <¼a> snout, the projecting nose of an animal, the head; bitter. hpa kísceke <¼a gi´-stse-ge> The Nose Splitting [taboo word; refers to a ceremony in which the tip of the nose of a captive is scratched with the tip of the sacred knife].

hpá tóohka. N Comanche (tribe or tribal member), Kiowa (tribe or tribal memeber) (lit., 'wet noses' [RB, PM], 'dew on the head' [PM]) (RBnote: rare usage) (BE2.21; PM:ok; 01/14/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 125, 243: hpátòhka <¼a´-doæ-Ða> the Osage name for the Comanche Tribe, Comanche Indian.

hpaahâ. V [reg. or sync. fortisizing stop stem, _hpaahâ] (intr.) arise or get up from a bed or chair, get up, wake up. ahpáahà I get up. ðahpáahà you get up. àhpáahà she gets up.

kaasîxcìëì ahpáahà I got up very early (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). hcéka ëì ðahpáahà tòpéwai you look like you just got up (FH/11/19/01/pc:ok). hâàhkaëi kóoci ahpáahà no, I got up a long time ago (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.53). mîòke çáhpe tà ahpáahà nà I get up at six o'clock (RBn22-09). kaasîxcì ëìkáëi apa hpaahâ nàpé the children [usually] get up early (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). kaasîxcì ëìkáëi apa hpaahâpe the children got up early (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). hâàpaskaha akxai, hpaahâ get up, it's daylight (FH:prod). hâàpa hú, hpaahâ it's daylight, get up [e.g., out of the chair or out of bed] (FH:prod). hpaahâpi get up [pl.]! (FH01/31/95; FH/11/19/01/pc:HP). çpáahà [expected form: ðahpáahà] you got up (LS). àkóe àhpáahà àkái we're getting up; we're waking up (LS).

•• LFD 125: hpahà <¼a-hoæ> to rise. akíhpahà <a-gi´-¼a-hoæ> [Mod. Os. omits kí-] I rise. ðakíçpahà <tha-gi´-shpa-hoæ> [Mod. Os. omits kí-] you rise. àkíhpahà pe <oæ-gi´-¼ahoæ i> [Mod. Os. omits kí-] we rise.

••• Cf. paahâ.

hpaahíëi (variant of hpaahîëi).

hpaahî (variant: páahi [JOD]). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) sharp. mâàhi hpaahí sharp knife (BE2.119; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ma).

•• LFD 125: hpahí <¼a-hi´> sharp. màhì hpahi <moæ-hiæ ¼a-hi> the knife is sharp.

hpaahîëi (variant: hpaahíëi). ADJ, V [reg., hpaa_hîëi] [hpaahî + aëí NEG] (intr.) (be) dull (perhaps originally 'be unable to cut s.t. into small pieces'). mâàhì akxa hpaahíëi the knife is dull (BE2.37; 01/20/95/PM/pc:ok).

••• Cf. pahîìëi. 

hpáata. N egg. hpáata léëe káaãe akxai he's coloring eggs (e.g., for Easter; lit., 'he's making eggs spotted, speckled') (12/30/94/FH/pc/prod, HP; BE2.41). ðe hpáata akxa hôòëì akxai those eggs are bad (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod, HP).

•• JOD (slip file): hpáta <pa´-§ta> an egg (of any sort).

•• LFD 125: páhta <ba´-¾a> an egg. [LF's transcription of hpáata 'egg' varies considerably; compare <ba´-¾a> here with <¼a´-¾a> in the entry hpáatazi and <¼a-da> and <¼a´-¾a> in the entry hpáaëì.]  

••• KS ittá egg (RR).

hpáata xúha. N eggshell (the shell of an egg of any kind).

hpáataska. N [hpáata + ská 'white'] egg white (lit., 'white of egg').

hpáatazi. N [hpáata + zí] egg yolk (lit., 'yellow of egg').

•• LFD 126 (unconfirmed): hpáhta zi ðìkçe <¼a-¾a ši thiæ-kshe> [expected Mod. Os. form: hpáata zi ðìkçé (ðìkçé POSIT)] the yolk of an egg. [LF's transcription of hpáata 'egg' varies considerably; see the entry hpáata.]

hpáaëì (variants: hpáataëìka [archaic], hpáataëì). N [hpáata + -ëì 'little'] baby, infant, babyhood, infancy (BE2.6; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). hpáaëì paamáçi akxái he's holding up the baby (e.g., for people to see it).

•• LFD 125: hpata ëìka <¼a-da zhiæ-ga> infancy, babyhood. LFD 126: hpáhta ëìka <¼a´¾a zhiæ-ga> baby; an infant, infancy. [LF's transcription of hpáata 'egg' varies considerably, as in these two examples; see the entry hpáata.]

••• KS ittá egg (RR).

hpáaëì okØôhe. VP [reg.?, hpáaëì o_kØôhe] place a baby on a baby board, put a baby inside.

hpáce (variant: hpáci). V [reg., _hpáce] (trans.) operate on, perform surgery on, butcher, dissect. hpátapi ìkçí aape he was operated on; they operated on him [they said] (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc).

wahkôtaki akxa ðihpáce kôða hta akxái the doctor might want to operate on you (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.98). • N surgery (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok, FH:4/22/96/tape).

•• RB: <páh-tah>.

•• LFD 125, 239: hpáce <¼a´-dse> to butcher, to dissect (also hpáhce <¼a´-¾se> butcher [LFD 126, 239]). ahpáce <a-¼a´-dse> I butcher. ðáhpace <tha´-¼a-dse> you butcher. àhpáca pe <oæ-¼a´-dsa i> we butcher. LFD 125: hpátapi <¼a´-da-bi> operation, surgical operation.

•••  KS ppáaýe butcher an animal (RR). 

••• Cf. wahpáce.

hpaðímaha (variants: hpáìmaha, hpáimàhà). N Pawnee Indians (RB; PM; 03/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.101).
