•• LFD 126: hpáðìmàhà <¼a´-thiæ-moæ-hoæ> the Osage name for the Pawnee Indians. hpaì màhà <¼a-iæ moæ-hoæ> the Osage name for a band of the Pawnees known as <Shkithi>.

hpáðì (variant: hpáì). N Kiowa (tribe or tribal member) (RBn23-17). hôòpa ðé wéena akxai ðe níhkaçi tóa áðixòpape, hpáðì wéhkili íwehkili ì kçíãape she's grateful today because they honored her, they dressed her [lit., 'made her clothe herself'] in Kiowa clothes (RBn23-17; CQc). • Pawnee (tribe or tribal member). hpáðì apa achípe the Pawnees have arrived (BE2.144; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.18). • western tribe or tribal member (refers to any tribe from the western United States) (03/08/95/PM/pc; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 126: hpáðì <¼a´-thiæ> a general term for tribes not related to the Osage. LFD 126: hpaì <¼a-iæ> the Osage name for the Pawnee Tribe.

hpáðìhòka. N stranger.

•• LFD 126 (unconfirmed): hpáðìhòka <¼a´-thiæ-hoæ-ga> sacred stranger (personal name).

hpaãáce (variant of hpaxáce).

hpahâle. ADJ, ADV first, first in line, at the outset, from the beginning. wahkôta akxa eená hta akxa na, hpahâle mâì, ahkílaðì pai soon it will be only God, put him first, carry yourself that way (04/04/99/FH/pc). hpahâle wihtéëì iðáe çkôçta che wéewinai first, younger sister, I am grateful for your wanting me to speak. hpahâle che from the beginning (BE2.48; 01/25/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 125: hpahâle <¼a-hoæ´-gthe> in advance of the storm, in the first order of time, original, primary. hpahâle che <¼a-hoæ´-gthe tse> at the outset, from the beginning. [Example contains che POSIT.]

hpahâle ákaaleke. N First Striker (personal name) (WHM980326; CQc).

hpahâle ðée. VP [sync., hpahâle _ðée] precede (lit., 'go first').

•• LFD 125: hpahâle ðe <¼a-hoæ´-gthe the> to precede. hpahâle bre ha <¼a-hoæ´-gthe bthe ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: hpahâle brée; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I precede.

hpahâle màðî. VP [sync., hpahâle mà_ðî] place s.t. or s.o. first. wahkôta hpahâle màðì ée ekò ahkílaði çòòçôwe place God first and keep yourself in that way forever (FH/pc).  

hpahâle màðî àðíðaace (variant: hpahâle màî àðîðaace). N God, God's name as "we'll-call-youfirst-in-our-lives" (lit., 'placed first we call you'). [FH, quoting her father's term for 'God'.]  

hpáhiihto. N [hpá + hîì +htóho] mallard duck (lit., 'green head feathers').

•• LFD 125 (unconfirmed): hpáhihto <¼a´-hi-¾u> the mallard duck. "The skin of the neck and breast of this bird are put upon the sacred pipes of the Osage, Omaha, and Pawnee Tribes."

hpahíke. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) sort, classify, categorize. hòbrîke che hpahíke I sorted the beans (FH:ok).

hpáhì. N porcupine.

•• LFD 125: hpáhì <¼a´-hiæ> porcupine [LF form unconfirmed]. "This animal was useful . . . for its quills, which were used for decorating moccasins, leggings, and other articles of clothing. The quills were colored with native dyes and flattened before using." hpahîì (variant of hpaxîì).

hpahîìska. N [hpá + hîì + ská] Pawhuska (the seat of Osage County, Oklahoma; lit., 'white head hair'); white hair (of the head).

•• LFD 125: hpahúska <¼a-hiu´-ška> White-hair (personal name; refers to the sacred white buffalo). LFD 126: hpáxìska <¼a´-xiæ-ška> a white mane (of horse).

••• Cf. hpaxîì. hpahlíxtoe. N mucus, runny nose (FH).

••• Cf. hpalî.

hpahlì (variant of hpalî).

hpáhtàà. N hickory nut (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.66).

•• LFD 129: hpâhtàa hi <¼oæ´-¾oæ-a hi> large hickory tree, Hicoria. hpâhtàka <¼oæ´-¾oæga> nut of the hickory, hickory nut.

hpahúuse (variants: hpahúase, hpahúese). N scissors (RB; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.117). hpahîðuusé haircutters, scissors.

•• LFD 125: hpahuðise <¼a-hiu thi-še> hair + cutter: scissors. hpahúðise htàka <¼ahiu´-thi-še ¾oæ-ga> large scissors, shears.

hpahúusehtàà. N [hpahúuse + htâà] shears (lit., 'large scissors').

hpahúze. N comb (BE 2:21: unconfirmed; 01/09/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/20/95/LS/pc:uk).

••• KS hélüze [may be hée-] fine tooth comb (RR).

hpáimàhà (variant of hpaðímaha).

hpáì (variant of hpáðì).

hpáìmaha (variant of hpaðímaha).

hpalî. (variants: hpahlì, hpalí). N mucus from the nose, runny nose, snot (FH/09/11/01/pc; FH/t128). hpalîstowe runny nose (FH/t128, (BE2.124; 03/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 126: hpaxðî <¼a-xthiæ´> mucus from the nose.

••• Cf. hpá. 

hpánààke. V [reg., _hpánààke] (trans.) push s.o. onward. ðée ðe hpánààke this one here, push him [making him walk, run] (FH/09/21/01/pc).

••• Cf. hpahâle.

hpápaxò (variant: hpâpaxò). N [hpá + paaxô 'break'] Sioux (tribe or tribal member), cutthroats (lit., 'nose cutter', 'head cutter') (RBnHW13) (unconfirmed, 03/08/95/PM/pc:uk; 04/19/95/FH/pc:uk as a tribe name). çée hpápaxò ihtá this belongs to hpápaxò (FH/09/22/01/pc) • Nose Cutter (personal name for a second son) (04/19/95/FH/pc). [Alfred Oberly, Frances Holding's brother, and Louis Red Eagle both were named hpâpaxò.]  

•• LFD 124: hpápawaxò <Pa´-ba-wa-xoæ> Head-cutter (personal name). pxápawaxò <Pa´-ba-wa-xoæ> [LF's form is presumably a typographical error for the expected hpápawaxò <Pa´-ba-wa-xoæ>] Head-cutters, the Osage name for the Sioux Tribe of Indians (unconfirmed; FH:4/24/96/tape:uk as tribe name).

hpasiólìì (variant of hpasú olîì).

hpásitoopa. N Four Cliffs (personal name referring to buffalo descending in four lines from the hills); Pahsetopa (family name among the Osages).

•• LFD 124: hpasitopa <¼a-ši-do-ba> Four-hills (personal name; refers to the descent of a herd of buffalo from a hill in four lines).

hpasólìì (variant of hpasú olîì).

hpasú. N tip or point of an object.

•• LFD 124: hpasí <¼a-ši´> the top of a tree, the top of a pole, a peak. LFD 19: pasíke <ba-ši´-ge> spiked.

hpasú olîì (variants: hpasólìì, hpasiólìì, hpasúlì). N living on the end, dwelling on the cliffs (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.61); Fairfax or Grayhorse group of Osages (lit., 'living on the end', referring to the west end of the allotment) (FH; PM; RB; RBn2-MOJ/p16; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): hpasü' <pa-sü´> the tip or point of an object.

•• LFD 124: hpasiólì <¼a-šiu´-gthiæ> Dwellers-upon-the-hill-top. "When the river (Mississippi) overflowed its banks, a group of Osage Indians fled from their village and sought the high hills and there established a camp. They were known by the name of <¼ašiu' -gthiæ> and settled in Grayhorse."

hpasúkoça. N [hpasú + koça] paisley, paisley patterned cloth, said to be the first cloth that Osages saw (lit., 'curved points') (MSB 3/3/83).

hpaxáce (variant: hpaãáce). N roach haircut, roached hair (RBn11/JW&FW&HHaskell/c.1976). •• JOD (slip file): hpaxace <pa-qá-¦t¦se> roach(?).

•• LFD 126: hpaxáce <¼a-xa´-dse> a peculiar style of hair cut among the Osage Indians and also in other tribes.

hpáxì (variant of hpaxîì).

hpáxì ðutáahpa (variant of hpáxì ðuutáahpa).

hpáxì ðuusé. N haircut.

hpáxì ðuutáahpa (variant: hpáxì ðutáahpa). N woman's bun hairdo (lit., 'hair made round') (FH:conf).

hpaxîì (variants: hpáxìì, hpahîì, hpáxì). N [probably hpá + hîì] hair of the head or neck of a human or an animal, mane (JS/pc; FH 4/17/96). hpáxìì brúuse íbrilà I'm thinking about cutting my hair (FH/06/16/01/pc). wahkôta iëîke iihô hpaxîì ìkçe xôòce íkòce káaãi apai they're making the cedar like Mary's hair (FH).

•• LFD 125: hpahú, hpahí <¼a-hiu´> the hair of a man's head. hpáhì ðihta akçi çoká <¼a´-hiæ thi-¾a a-ki sho-ga´> your hair is thick. LFD 126: hpaxî <¼a-xiæ´> hair of the head.

••• Cf. hpahîìska. 

hpáxììsà (variant: hpáxììsa). N braid (RBn, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 237: wéðìsà <we´-thiæ-šoæ> braided lariat.

••• KS wabésà sábe rope made of buffalo mane (RR).

hpáze. ADJ, ADV, N evening, in the evening time, not quite dark yet, night

(02/24/95/FH/pc:prod). hâànà hpáze night, at night (FH:prod). hpáze ðe this evening. hpáze íhtà when it gets evening (FH:4/17/96/tape). ðé hpáze that evening (FH). hpáze waachí watôì àkái hta akái we are going for the night dance [to observe the dance].

•• LFD 124: hpáze <¼a´-še> evening, close of the day.

hpáze waachí. N night dance. hpáze waachí watôe àkái hta àkái we're going for the night dance [to watch] (RBn3-12).  

hpáze wanôbre. N supper, evening meal. hpáze wanôbre nîìpe? did you all eat supper? (BE2.130). hpáze wanôbre ónòbre ðúwì ókxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (03/10/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.123; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok).

•• LFD 124: hpáze wanòbre <¼a´-še wa-noæ-bthe> an evening meal.

hpázece. N, ADV last evening. hpázece súhka záani àðáachape we ate all the chicken up last night (MSB).

hpâpaxò (variant of hpápaxò).

hpée. N forehead, brow, head (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod; 04/26/95/LS/pc; BE2.50).

•• LFD 126: hpé <¼e´> the forehead. LFD 127: hpéotxà <¼e´-o-toæ> the forehead.

hpéece. N fire (e.g., cooking fire, meeting fire, cooking stove gas fire). hpéece ðé íiçtope use this fire to bless yourself (RB). hpéece ðuutáaëi turn the fire off [imperative] (03/14/95/MREI/pc). hpéece ístope they used the fire to bless themselves (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok:sto; 01/25/95/FH/pc:okc, BE2.47).

•• LFD 127: hpéce <¼e´-dse> fire.

••• OM <¼e´-de>fire (LFD 127).  

hpéece íhta. N fireman (a position in Native American Church meetings; lit., 'his fire'). hpéece íhta hpahâle first fireman (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). hpéece íhta wéðòòpa, hpéece íhta wáðòòpa second fireman (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). hpéece íhta wéðabrì, hpéece íhta wáðabrì third fireman (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc). hpéece wéðabrì hpáaãe I worked as third fireman (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc; BE2.47). hpéece íhta wéðabrì che olîì a you sit in third [fireman] place (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77; 04/25/95/PM/pc:okc).  

hpéece íiçka. N heating stove, wood-burning stove (for heat, not cooking; lit., 'fire to warm oneself') (MSBt#9RB; 3).

hpéece màðî (variant: hpéece môì). N Fire-Walker (personal name); family name Petsemoie. [hpéece mòî was Frances Holding's ancestor on her mother's side. The city park in Hominy is named after hpéece môì.]

•• LFD 127: hpécemòì <¼e´-dse-moæ-iæ> Fire-walker (personal name; refers to the finding of the red bear walking in the night, a light like a fire shone from his breast).

hpéece océðe. N fire (cooking fire, meeting fire, fire of gas stove).

hpéece ëâà. N firewood (RB).

hpéecenii. N [hpéece + níi] liquor (lit., 'fire-water') (RB; 03/16/95/MREI/pc/ok). níhka akxa wáli lôði akxai, hpéecenii huuwáli waðáahtàpe that man is really drunk, he's drunk a lot of liquor (RBn12-06).

•• LFD 127: péce ni <pe´-de ni> fire water, intoxicant.

••• Cf. hpéeceniihci. 

hpéecenii ðaahtâ hci. N bar, saloon.

hpéeceniihci. N [hpéecenii + hcí] liquor store (lit., 'fire-water house') (FH); bar, saloon (archaic meaning).

•• LFD 127: hpéceni hci <¼e´-dse-ni-¾si> fire-water house, a saloon, whisky house.

hpéeðòòpa (variant: hpéeòpa). ADJ, N seven (lit., 'two foreheads') (BE2.119; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; FH:4/24/96/tape).

•• LFD 127: hpéðòpa <¼e´-thoæ-ba> seven.

hpéeleke. N [hpée + léke] Shattered Forehead (nickname; refers to scar from an injury to the head). [George Treadway's nickname in the mid-1900s (FH).]  hpéeòpa (variant of hpéeðòòpa).

hpeeçtá. N [hpée + çtáha] bald head, smooth forehead or brow (lit., 'clear, smooth or bald of brow') (04/07/95/PM/pc). [Nickname used by Osages for a man in a store where they traded.]

hpéãe. N gourd; gourd rattle (used in peyote meeting [RB]). hpéãe ðé âwali mìkçé I'm really stingy with this gourd (RBn2-MOJ/p37; 02/03/95/FH/pc:okc). Arthur akxa Mongrain hpéãe wî káaãape Arthur made Mongrain a gourd (RBn10-10:JW).

•• LFD 128: hpéãe <¼e´-xe> gourd rattle. hpéãe ðuzapi waðò <¼e´-xe thu-ša-bi wathoæ> Songs of Taking up the Rattle. hpéãe ipa <¼e´-xe i-ba> rattle handle. hpéãe su <¼e´-xe šu> rattle seeds. hpéãe ðuze waðò <¼e´-xe thu-še wa-thoæ> Songs of Taking up the Rattle.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 128).

hpéëe. N weed (RBn HW13); sage, sage bush, sagebrush (RBn HW13). [Takes 'lying down' positional article kçe.]

•• LFD 128: hpéëe <¼e´-zhe> grass, hay, weeds. hpéëe kçe açi aòbra ha <¼e´-zhe ke ashi a-oæ-btha ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: hpéëe kçe áçi aôòbra 'I tossed the weeds outside'; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I took the weeds out.

hpéëe bràðáalì. N sweet-smelling grass.

•• LFD 128: hpéëe bràðalì <¼e´-zhe bthoæ-tha-gthiæ> sweet-smelling grass.

hpéëe htóho. N green tea (lit., 'green/blue weed') (WHM98102; FH/09/23/01/pc:ok).

••• Cf. hpéëehtoho.

hpéëe mâhka (variant: hpéëe màhkása, hpéëe màhkásae). N tea (lit., 'weed medicine') (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok; 03/16/95/FH/pc:ok, hpéëe níi preferred).

•• LFD 128: hpeëe màhka sae <¼e´-zhe moæ-Ðoæ ša-e> weed coffee. hpéëe màhkà sae çtahtà <¼e´-zhe moæ-Ðoæ ša-e shta-¾oæ> you drink tea.

hpéëe xóhtà (variants: hpéëe xóhta). N sage (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1021/JW; BE2.116) (RB note: refers to sage employed in peyote meeting).

•• LFD 128: hpéëexohta <¼e´-zhe-xu-¾a> wild sage, Artemisia.

••• KS péeëe xóttà wild sage, used in flute dance against mosquitos (RR). hpéëehtoho. N lettuce (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.78).

•• LFD 128: hpéëetxoho <¼e´-zhe-tu-hu> [LF's -txo- <-tu-> is presumably a

typographical error for -hto- <-¾u->] pennyroyal (Hedeoma pulegioides). ðáhpàke apa hpéëehtoho isi pi a <tha´-¼oæ-ge a-ba ¼e´-zhe-¾u-hu i-ši bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form: lápxààke apa hpéëehtóho íisipe] mosquitos do not like pennyroyal.

hpéëeníi. N tea (lit., 'weed-water').

hpéëenii nâãe oolâ. N iced tea (lit., 'weed-water with ice put in').

hpíiëi. ADJ, V [uninfl./stat., _hpíiëi] (intr.) (be) bad, awful, evil, wicked. óðaake wálì hpíiëi the news was very bad (01/06/95/FH/pc:okc). hpíiëie that's bad [as to a child]

(01/06/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.6). wálì hpíiëie óhesaëì alîì ðáha níi hpáasike it's awful that I sat down real quick and splattered water (04/19/95/FH/pc). táatà hpíiëì ecíke tà . . . if there are bad things around . . .

•• LFD 129: hpíëi <¼i´-zhi> bad, evil.

hpíiëi aëî. V [sync. nasal vowel stem, a_ëî] [hpíiëi + aëî] (trans.) hate a person, think ill of s.o., hold s.o. in contempt.

hpióka. N part in the hair. hpióka káaãa part your hair (lit., 'make a part') (BE2.101; 03/06/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn2-MOJ/p35).

•• LFD 127–28: hpeókasà <¼e-u´-ga-šoæ> the parting of the hair, the part of the hair (colored red to symbolize the path of the sun).

hpíò. V [sync.+sync. nasal vowel stem, _hpí_ò] (trans.) know how to do s.t.; learn

(02/14/95/FH/pc); be skilled at or expert in. hpímà/hpímò I have learned; I know how (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/14/95/PM/pc:ok). çpíëò you know how (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.74). çpíëò? did you learn? do you know how? waëáëeíe çpíiëò? do you know how to talk Osage?

(RBn1-58). óohò hpíòpe she is a good cook (lit., 'she knows how to cook') (BE2.23;

02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). waëáëeíe çpíëò? can you speak Osage? hpímà hkôbra I want to learn

(04/14/95/PM/pc:ok). waëáëeíe hpíò wáhkôbra I want them to learn the Osage language (04/14/95/PM/pc). hpíò áhkôbra I want him to learn it (04/14/95/PM/pc). waëáëeíe hpíò ðihkôbra I want you to learn the Osage language (04/14/95/PM/pc). Bob akxa wáli waëáëeíe hpíò akxai Bob sure has learned the Osage language (BE2.77). hàðé wiëîke akxa waëáëeíe hpíò kôða akxa tonight son wants to learn the Osage language (RBn22-02). waachí hpíòpe he's a skilled dancer (RBn3-42). waaðô hpíòpe he's a skilled singer (RBn3-42).

•• LFD 129: hpiô <¼i-oæ´> expert. hpímà <¼i´-moæ> I am expert. çpi ëò <shpi zhoæ> you are expert. àhpiò pe <oæ-¼i-oæ i> we are expert, skillful. LFD 70: ié hpiò <i-e´ ¼i-oæ> skilled in the use of language.

••• Cf. hkihpíò.

hpisúhu. N oak (lit., 'acorn tree') (RBn HW13; FH/09/22/01/pc:uk).

•• LFD 128: hpisí hi <¼i-ši´ hi> red oak tree. LFD 299: hpisi <pi-ši> acorn. 

hposú. N acorn (RBn HW, unconfirmed; FH:uk).

••• KS ppüså acorn (RR).

hpôãe. N artichoke, radish, squash. hpôãe áace zì yellow climbing squash (BE2.126, unconfirmed).

•• JOD (slip file): hpâxe <paæ´-qe> artichoke.

•• LFD 129: hpôãe <¼oæ´-xe> the artichoke (Cynara scolymus), an edible plant.

••• KS ppâàãe small white gourd (RR); OP ppâãe ~ ppâxi Jerusalem artichoke, radish (JK).

hpôãe áace ëì. N yellow climbing squash (small squash that the Osages used to cultivate, now extinct; lit., 'little climbing squash') (RB).

•• JOD (slip file): § póãiðacØî < §po´-xi-¢a-ts'iæ> a small spotted squash ("Some are dark or greenish, others white").

hpôhka. N Ponca (tribe or tribal member). hpôhka àkítaake we fight the Poncas (BE2.46; BE2.105; 03/10/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/08/95/PM/pc:ok; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 129: hpôhka <¼oæ´-Ða> the Ponca Tribe.

hpuzá. N sand.

•• LFD 128: hpizá <¼i-ša´> sand, silt. hpizá katace <¼i-ša´ ga-da-dse> quicksand, loose sand in the bed of a river in which there is danger of sinking. hpizáole kaxa <¼i-ša´-ugthe ga-xa> Sand Creek, Okla. hpizáska <¼i-ša´-ška> white sand.

••• KS ppüzá sand (RR); OM same as Osage (LFD 128).

hta. PPN toward, in the direction of, from, into. níi ecí hta in the water [toward] there (RBn1010:JW). hci hta into the house (contrasts with hcí htaha 'to the house'). ówe che hcí hta áðìku bring the groceries in the house.

•• LFD 135: hta <¾a> in that direction (term used in ceremonial ritual). LFD 67: howaìkíhtàche <ho-wa-iæ-gi´-¾oæ-tse> [expected Mod. Os. form: howaìkí hta che] from what source, what direction? hówaki htà ðachi a(?) <ho´-wa-gi ¾oæ tha-tsi a(?)> [expected Mod. Os. form: hówaìkí hta ðachíe] where did you come from? LFD 91: mi hiekéhta <mi hi-e-ge´-¾a> [expected Mod. Os. form: mîìhiðe kçe hta; LF's -ké- <-ge´-> may be a typographical error] toward the setting of the sun (03/23/95/FH/pc:uk).

hta. POTENTIAL MARKER future tense marker: will, be going to. íe tóa ékipçe hta, ówaçtaake hkôbra I'm going to say something, I want you to tell them (RBn10-15). háamà hta che? how am I going to do this? (04/11/95/FH/pc). ákahamì ëúuce ðée pée ðuuçtáke hta ðe? who is going to undress that one with the red coat on? [refers to receiving a wedding coat when the drum is being paid for]. • irrealis marker: could, so that it could/might be; what if, were it the case that, would be. kîì iðákØuce hta mìkçe I will try to fly [circumlocution for 'if I could fly'] (04/13/95/FH/pc:prod). iiðáðe hta if I could see (FH:4/25/96/tape). haaská nà çäihtà tà ðikítàhe hta if you just touch his garment you could get well (FH/pc). çímiëì wé[ð]uãekí[ð]e akxai, wáðohta hta nà they were marrying their girl off so she would be proper, respectable (RBn22-17).  

•• JOD (Devouring Mountain p2 ln13–14): wakØó ðáalì xci çímìëìka ðáalì xci tóopa kØúpe ska, wahôìëìka walâke hta <Wak'u´ ¢á§k¢iæ-qtsi, címiæciñ´ka ¢á§k¢iæ-qtsi §tú§pa k'ü§pe ska, Wahªuæ´ §§ciñ´ka wa§k¢añ´ke ta> they gave him four very pretty women, four very pretty girls so that he, the orphan, could take them as wives.

hta (variant of íhta). 

hta akxa. POTENTIAL MARKER+CONT irrealis or potential: be it (the case that), if (it is the case that), it will be the case that, in the event that, it may be that; would that. [Note that 3rd person continuative akxa is used even with 1st or 2nd person subjects in clauses of this type.] àëi brée tà, oániëi màëí hta akxai [but] if I go I won't be afraid. iðákØue ço àhé waëáëeíe íhpahò hta akxai I'm going to keep on [trying] until I learn the Osage language (RBn1010:JW). brúwì hta akxa, wikØú hta mìkçe if I buy it, I'll give it to you. waachíe watôì çcée nà hta akxai you're always going to go to dances (MSB-9-3-82). hôòpa ókaaãeìki tà htâwà ki abrîbree hta akxai çí éëi wì waðíhta hpíò ke wì íhkihkawi hta mìkçé on Saturday what if I take him to town and trade him for another one that knows how to work (cf. abrîbree hta

akxai 'what if I take him') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; CQ: okc). wáçäuãe tà Mary íçäuãe hta akxai if you get married, Mary will be your bridesmaid (lit., 'if you marry, you would have Mary as bridesmaid'). çí íiwikie hta akxai we'll see each other again (lit., 'would that I [might] see you again'). íinòòhpa, ðaxíçta hta akxai be careful, you might fall (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.43). ìtîla àðìkçé hta akxai mâëà ìké etxâ we will still be gossiping when the world ends (MSB). kîì ékimà hta akxai, kóe môëò záani iiðáðe hta akxai if I could fly, then I could see the whole world (RBn15-02, FH:prod). ehta wábruãe màëí hta akxai maybe I better not get married (RBn17-p02).  

hta apa tà (or hta pa tà?). may.  

•• LF 135: hta patà <¾a ba-doæ> that they may.

htáa. N deer, doe, fawn, buck (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). htáa léëe ëì fawn (lit., 'small spotted deer') (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.30). • meat. htáa hépe piece of meat (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). htáa zíhi fried meat. htáa che táazihi fry the meat [imperative] (FH:4/25/96/tape; 02/24/95/FH/pc). htáa okáçà take care of the meat [imperative] (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc; 04/11/95/FH/pc:ok).

hkóhkosa htáa pork (lit., 'pig meat') (03/08/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 135: hta <¾a> deer; meat of any kind.

htáa htâka. N buck, male deer (lit., 'large deer').

htáa kiðíãepi. N [ki- INCEPTIVE + ðúãe + api] deer mating moon, October. [Names of months were historically not used in Osage and sound unnatural to Osage speakers (HH).]

••• KS ttáa kkåyüãabe month when the deer mate in late autumn (RR).

htáa lìkó. N gravy.

htáa mîìka. N doe, female deer.

htáa nihkaçi. N Deer clan.

••• Cf. htáanihkáçi. 

htáa púze. N dried meat (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod).

htáa çtôka. N meatball, meat candy (lit., 'softened meat').

htáa taazíhi. N steak (lit., 'browned meat'). htáa taazíhi fried meat (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc).

htáabre. V, N hunting for big game or small game. [Probably from an original Osage form tábre, cognate with KS dáble and QU tápde, but reinterpreted as containing htáa 'deer'.] htáabre brée I'm going hunting (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). htáabre aðée iché he has gone hunting (RB).

kasîxci htáabre pçíe this morning I went hunting.  

•• LFD 135: htábre <¾a´-bthe> to hunt deer, deer hunting.

htáabre aðée. VP [sync., htáabre (a)_ðée] (trans./intr.) go hunting (for). htáabre brée I'm going hunting (RBn3-05).

htaacé. N wind, air (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). htaacé lâàðì (lit., 'big wind') a tempest (03/23/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 136: htacé <¾a-dse´> the winds, the four quarters of the earth; air. htaacé lòòðe <¾a-dse´ gthoæ-the> great windstorm, a tempest.

htaacé hpíiëi. N tornado, tempest, windstorm. htaacé hpíiëi apa hå ðí apai a tornado is coming (BE2.143; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 136: htace hpíiëi <¾a-dse ¼i´-zhi> a bad wind, blustery.

htaacé oðîìke. N radio (lit., 'catching the wind') (04/20/95/LS/pc:prod).

htaacé óhesaëi. N cyclone, tornado, storm with strong winds, gale. htaacé óhesaëi wì húðí apai a cyclone is coming (03/07/95/FH/pc:prod orig). htaacé óhesaëi húði eepé they said strong winds are coming (FH:4/24/96/prod).

htaacé saakí. VP be windy. htaacé saakí akxa it is a strong wind; the wind is strong; it's windy (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ma). htaacé saakípe the wind was strong. • N strong or violent wind, windstorm, gale.

•• LFD 136: htacé saki pi a <¾a-dse´ ša-gi bi a> the wind was strong. htacé sakí <¾adse´-ša-gi> violent wind, windstorm, a gale. LFD 356: htaacé sasaki <¾a-dse´-ša-ša-gi> windy. [The probable Mod. Os. pronunciation of LF's reduplicated form <ša-ša-gi> is saasáaki (from saakí 'strong').] htáaceomâi. N Cheyenne (tribe or tribal member) (RB; FH:ok? 'walking in the wind'?).

htaacéxowe. N electric fan (lit., 'wind roaring'). htaacéxowe káaãa turn the fan on [imperative] (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc; BE2.43; FH:4/18/96/tape,ok).

htaacéëì. N Whirlwind (name in an Osage fable).

htaaðáachaëi, htaaðáachaëi hâàpa (variants of hâàpa htaaðáachaëi).

htaaðíihtà. V [sync., htaa_ðiihtà] [htáa + ðiihtâ] handle, knead, or work meat with the hand (as in cutting meat up) (FH/09/24/01/prod). htaaðíihtà handle the meat, take care of the meat [imperative] (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p50). htaabríihtà hta mìkçé I'm going to take care of the meat (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok).  

htaaháa. N [htáa + háa] buckskin, deerskin.

•• LFD 137: htaha <¾a-ha> deerskin.

htaahékaaãe. N [htáa + hé + káaãe] Deer making horns (personal name) (RBn22-04).

htaaníe céãe. N soup kettle. [A term reportedly connected with the district of Grayhorse (DN-WHM; unconfirmed).]

htáanieooëú. N bowl (FH:4/22/96/tape:okc).

htáanihkáçi. N [htáa + nihkáçi] Deer clan (BE2.30; 01/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 137: htáinihkaçika <¾a´i-ni-Ða-shi-ga> Deer People.

htaaníi. N [htáa + níi] soup, broth, consommé. htaaníi káaãe to make soup (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125). htaaníi oohô! make soup! (RBn1-50; FH). súhka htà htaaníi káaãa make soup with the turkey [imperative] (FH/11/17/01/pc). htaaníi ëúe vegetable soup (lit., 'red soup') (FH:4/24/96/ok: ht). súhkahtà htaaníi oohô ðáalì káaãapi ché they cooked the turkey soup well (01/12/95/FH/pc:okc). htaaníi hcúke íðaachapi eat soup with a spoon [to pl. addressees].  

•• LFD 138: htaní <¾a-ni´> soup, broth.

••• KS htaanî soup (RR).

htáaoolà (variant of htóolà).

htaapé. N ball (used in a game) (BE2.6; 01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). htaapé kØò aðáape they went to play ball (RBn2-MOJ/p20; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 135: htapé <¾a-be´> ball. "The Osage usually make their balls of the root of a plant called <¾a-be´ hi> 'ball tree', sometimes of the root of the grapevine." htapésu <¾abe´-šu> ball stick [unconfirmed]. htapésu ipastace <¾a-be´-šu i-ba-sta-dse> [expected Mod. Os. form: htaapésu (?) ípaastace] a curved stick covered with a net (used by the Chippewas in a certain kind of ball game, also used by the Osage, Iowa, Kansas, and Winnebago Tribes).

htaapéskaëìkØô. V [reg., htaapéskaëì_kØô] [htaapé + ská + -ëì 'little' + kØô] play golf (lit., 'play with little white ball'). • N golf.

htáapçe (variant: htaapçé). N [htáa + pçé] pounded meat, pounded dry meat (FH/09/25/01/pc; (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok); meat candy. [Barbecued meat is dried in cotton sacks or in a container or hung on a line then pounded with a mallet in a wooden pounder or ground up in a grinder; honey is added, and the mixture is rolled into small balls. Contrast tôòpçe 'frankfurter, sausage'.]

•• LFD 138: htápçe <¾a´-pshe> pemmican. "Both the Osage and the Omaha prepare this from jerked lean meat of any kind, roasted and pounded, then mixed with marrow grease." htaasílee htáwà. N Tulsa, Oklahoma (lit., 'deer-crossing town').

htaasîìce. N [htáa + sîìce] headdress (lit., 'deer tail').

htaasîìce wahú. N spreader for Osage headdress, roach bone (lit., 'deer-tail bone') (RB; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok).  

htaaská. N [htáa + ská] sheep (lit., 'white deer') (MOJt#150).

htáaweli. N meat grease, known as Indian butter. [The grease coming from beef when cracklings were made was poured or spread over pounded meat and corn to make "platter corn" (FH).]

htachí. N muskrat.

•• LFD 136 (unconfirmed): htachí <¾a-ci´> muskrat.

htáha. ADV, PPN toward; on the way or path to a certain point; in the direction of (MREI, LS). hcí htaha, hcíhtaha toward the house. ecíhtaha toward there. éhtaha toward that way, in that direction (RBn1-56; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). ehtáha àkái htái let's get over that way (04/04/95/FH/pc). màchéhtaha toward the center, inward (03/23/95/FH/pc). hcíhtaha aðáape he went direct[ly] to the house. wasúhuëi kçíhtaha into temptation (lit., 'toward that lying uncleanliness') (HH's Lord's Prayer). Preston apa htâwa kçi éhtaha maðî apai Preston was walking toward town (03/23/95/FH/pc; 05/02/95/LS/pc:ok). mîìhiiðé éhtaha toward the setting sun (03/23/95/FH/pc; 05/02/95/LS/pc:ok). mîì éhtaha toward the sun (03/23/95/FH/pc). ámàhtáha toward the other side. çéehtaha over that way [toward you], go that way (01/31/95/FH/pc:prod). émàhtaëi not that other way.

•• LFD 137: hta ha <¾a ha> toward. ni kçe hta ha <ni kshe ¾a ha> toward the water or river (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. hta 'toward'.

htáha, htáhà (variants of htâhà).

htáhtaze (variants: htáhtáaze, htáhtáeze). V [uninfl., or reg.? _htáhtaze?] [onomatopoeic] (intr.) tick (e.g., clock or insect making noise); clatter (e.g., typewriter keys) (04/06/95/FH:ok).  • N grasshopper, cricket (lit., 'makes a whizzing noise') (FH); ticking, tapping, whizzing, or clicking sound. htáhtaze huuhtâka a lot of grasshoppers (BE2.60; 02/03/95/FH/pc:okc).

htáhtáze óochiëape grasshoppers are noisy (RBn3-55; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• RB: <táh-táh-áh-zeh>, <tah-táh-eh-zeh> (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok both).

•• LFD 34: tatáze <da-da´-še> grasshopper. tatáze ho htàka <da-da´-še ho ¾oæ-ga> great green grasshopper. tatáze sape <da-da´-še ša-be> cricket, black grasshopper. LFD 97: htahtaze <¾a-¾a-še> clicking, ticking. [Note that LF has both <¾a-¾a-še> and <da-da´-še> forms. The latter are erroneous.]

••• Cf. ììçtáxì htáhtaze, mâze htáhtaze, ëâà káahtahta.

htáhu. N neck (02/27/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 137: htáhu <¾a´-hiu> the neck, the nape of the neck.

htai. INJUNCTIVE clause-final element conveying an exhortation or suggestion for a group including the speaker and at least two other persons: let's. [Contrast hce INJUNCTIVE 'let's (speaker and one other person)'.] hkáwaceëenì tóa àðáahtâ àkái htai let's [three or more people] go drink some beer (RBn10-12:JW). haaská wasúhuëike hpaahípai, çäúuwasu htai be sorting the dirty clothes, let's you wash them (i.e., 'how about you wash them?') (FH/11/17/01/pc). ónalì ëìkáëì çáake lúuëe htai hpáxìì çki káapçe htai hurry up and tell the children to wash their hands and comb their hair. hkâàce záani àðúwi htái let's buy all the apples (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok).

htákue. N walnut, black walnut.

•• LFD 137: htákehu <¾a´-ge-hiu> the black walnut (Juglans nigra). "The Osage use the nut of this tree for food. The bark and leaves are used for enticing fish to the hook when one is fishing."

••• KS ttágü black walnut (RR).

htamá. N worm (2/2/1237/MSB/p8; 03/24/95/PM/pc:okc).

•• LFD 138: htamâ <¾a-moæ´> an angleworm, earthworm.

htanâkØa (variant: htanákØa [FH]). N deed, legal document, document (04/11/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p28); paper, paper money, bills (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok); playing cards (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.101); blank paper, stationery.

•• LFD 138: htanâkØa <¾a-noæ´-Ð'a> paper of any kind.

••• KS ttanâkØa paper, playing cards (RR).

htanâkØa ðiihíce. N playing cards, deck of cards (lit., 'paper for playing') (BE2.105; 03/10/95/FH/pc:ok).

htanâkØa ípukxa. N paper napkin, paper towel (FH).

htanâkØa kØô. VP [reg., htanâkØa _kØô] play cards (lit., 'play/gamble [with] paper'). htanâkØakØô hta apai they're going to play cards (FH; RBn12-06). • N deck of cards, card game (RB, unconfirmed; FH: verb only).

•• LFD 138: htanâkØakØò <¾a-noæ´-Ð'a-Ð'o> playing cards.

htanâkØa mâzeska. N paper money, bills of currency. htanâkØa waléze. N newsprint (the material), newspaper (the publication) (03/10/95/FH/pc).

htáçka hí. N buckeye tea (used in the sweat lodge before a peyote meeting to induce vomiting) (BE2.13). [Most expressions for various kinds of teas contain níi 'water' rather than hí. LF's translation (see below) implies that hí here is a variant of hú 'trunk' and that the use of htáçka hí to mean 'buckeye tea' is an extension from an earlier meaning, 'buckeye tree'.]

•• RB:<táh-shkah-hu> (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc ht).

•• LFD 138: htáçka hi <¾a´-shka hi> buckeye (Aesculus). "A kind of tea is made from this tree and taken just before a sweat bath to bring up bile. This is also the name given to the white oak tree." htaçká skue <¾a-shka´ škiu-e> sweet acorn. htaçkáskue hi <¾a-shka´škiu-e hi> sweet acorn tree, the oak family (Quercus alba).

htâà (variants: htôò, htô, htâ). V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) big, full size; become big, grow, increase in size, enlarge. [This form is said to imply a smaller size than does the form htâka.] waðílà htô hta apai their minds are going to grow. • oldest, eldest. ilôòhtà(à) eldest son.

htâàða. V, ADJ [conjug. unknown] (intr.) roll; rolling. oðíhtàà[ða]hcí oðáha a trailer house [ó- LOC + ði- INSTR + htààða + hcí oðáha, lit., 'whereby a house is made to roll and follow'] (04/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

 •• LFD 321: htàða <¾oæ-tha> rolling.  poáhtàða <bu-a´-¾oæ-tha> I shot it and sent it rolling. LFD 177: oðíhtàða hcioðaha <u-thi´-¾oæ-tha ¾si-u-tha-ha> little-wagon-with-ahouse-attached-to-it; action by pulling + to roll or to make run: a buggy.

••• QU odíhtàhtàda to roll something over and over (RR), oyúhtàya wagon, cart (RR).

htâàðì. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) run, hurry along, walk fast, move fast (RBn1-47, unconfirmed). htâàðìðî hurrying, walking fast (RBn10-7:JW).

••• KS ttâàyì to run two-legged (RR).

htààtâ (variants: htôòtà, htòòtá). ADV, N [perhaps htâà + tà 'if, when'] (in the) fall, autumn.

htòòtáce htáabre çíe? did you go hunting last fall? (RBn11-02/JW&FW; HH/14-a/274ff).

••• KS ttâdà midwinter; 'when things abound' (probably 'autumn' rather than 'winter') (RR).

htâhà (variants: htáhà, htâha, htáha). N [shortened form of wihtâha]  my father's sister's husband (i.e., my paternal uncle by marriage; speaker may be either male or female; more precise than English 'uncle'); my wife's brother; my sister's husband (used when speaker is male).  

htâka (variants: htâke, htôka). ADJ big, large (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok); great, grand. [This form is said to imply a larger size than does the form htâà.] wakØó htàà big woman; first daughter (BE2.8). ôpe htâke big hips (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.67).

•• LFD 155: htàká <¾oæ-ga´> big. hta htàka <¾a ¾oæ-ga> large deer.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 155).

htâwà. N town (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). htâwà ki in town [as opposed to in the country] (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). htâwà ki oálìì I live in town (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). htâwà kçi to town (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). htâwa kçi brée I'm going to town (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.143).

•• LFD 156: htàwà <¾oæ-woæ> a town or city. htâwà ki bre <¾oæ´-woæ gi bthe> I am going to town. txâwà ki sce <toæ´-woæ gi stse> [expected Mod. Os. form: htâwà ki çcée; <toæ´-woæ> is presumably a typographical error for <¾oæ´-woæ>, and <stse> is perhaps an error for <shtse>] you are going to town. htâwà ki àkaða pe <¾oæ´-woæ gi oæ-ga-tha i> we are going to town. htâwà ëìka <¾oæ´-woæ Zhiæ-ga> Little Village, an old village of the Osage on the Neosho River (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

htâwàkáaãe (variant: htâwakáaãe). N [htâwà + káaãe] Town Builder (personal name). names  

htâwàla. N clan. táatà htâwàla nîe? what clan are you? (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 156: htâwàlà <¾oæ´-woæ-gthoæ> the common name for the gens. htâwàlà hkiðitxòka [or hkiðitòka] hkilàke <¾oæ´-woæ-gthoæ Ði-thi-toæ-ga Ði-gthoæ-ge> to intermarry, marriage of people from two villages ('marriage' expression unconfirmed; 04/25/95/PM/pc:uk).

htéze (variant of hcéze).

htîe, htîì (variants of hcîì).

htó nâke, htohnâke (variants of htónàke).

htóho (variant: htóhu [rare]). ADJ blue (RBn10-5:MOJ/79). htóho blue (vs. htóhohoe 'some kind of blue or green') (01/07/95/FH/pc). htóho çápe dark blue (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.9; FH/8/30/94).

•• LFD 155: htóho <¾o´-ho> green or blue. LFD 236: htósape <¾o´-ša-be> blue (color).

htóho ekò <¾o´-ho e-goæ> like blue; similar to blue or green (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• KS ttóho blue or bluish black (RR).

htóho sápe. ADJ, N purple (lit., 'blue black') (RBn12-07; ERE, BE2.108).

•• LFD 155: htóhosape <¾o´-ho-ša-be> blue, blue-black. LFD 236: htósape <¾o´-ša-be> blue (color).

htóhohoe. N personal name for a young man in the Deer clan (FH/3/19/00). [Harriett Shadlow's oldest brother's name.]  htóhu (variant of htóho).

htónàke (variants: htó nâke, htohnâke). N otter; otter skin, otter hide (e.g., in Osage dance clothes) (RBn1-24; FH/03/03/95).

•• LFD 155: htohnôke <¾o-hnoæ´-ge> otter.

htoníle. N rainbow.

•• LFD 165 (unconfirmed): htohníle <¾u-hni´-gthe> rainbow.

htóolà (variant: htáaoolà). N [htáa + oolâ] sandwich (BE2.116; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc); meat pie (original meaning) (03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc). [htáaoolà now means 'sandwich' only, and not 'meat pie' (02/24/95/FH/pc).]

•• LFD 187: htáolà <¾a´-u-gthoæ> meat pie. LFD 139: wacúe hta olà <wa-dsiu´-e ¾a ugthoæ> meat pie, bread, meat, put inside.

htóoëu. N [htáa + ooëú] meat pie. [Pawhuska and Hominy term (RB).] htóoëu àkóohò hta àkái we're going to cook some meat pies (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.86).

htóze. N catfish (BE2.17).

•• LFD 165: htóze <¾u´-še> catfish.

htóëàke. N banana, pawpaw (archaic meaning) (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.6).

•• LFD 156: htóëàke <¾o´-zhoæ-ge> the fruit of the papaw tree, much liked by the Osage Indians.

htóëàke eekô. N pawpaw (FH:prod). htô (variant of htâà).

htôka (variant of htâka).

htôò (variant of htâà).

htòòtá, htôòtà (variants of htààtâ).

hú (variants: hi, híi, hiú, húu). N trunk, stalk; leg (e.g., of spider).

•• LFD 59: hi <hi> stalk, trunk of a tree or vine, legs (04/03/95/PM/pc:okt). LFD 162:

hu <hiu> a leg, trunk of a tree, vines, stalks of plants.

••• Cf. huuscée. 

hú (see ahú 'come here').

hú hce (variant húu hce). VP [sync. h-stem, (a)_hú hce] [(a)hú + hce] send here, have come here. wiëîke líi tà hú hce éa have Sonny come to her when he gets here, she asks you to send Sonny to her when he gets here.

húðe (variant: húuðe). V [reg., hú_ðe] [(a)hú + ðe CAU] (trans.) cause to come here, send here

(01/19/95/FH/pc:ok). húða send it here. • hand over, hand to, pass to by hand or other means (e.g., food at the table). húða pass it (to me) (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok, short form). ëààníe huðá pass the sugar (RBn2-MOJ/p5; 03/06/95/FH/pc:ok). àkØú huðá pass it to me (lit., 'pass it here giving it to me'). húða hand it to me; hand it here. haxî che àkØú huðá give me those blankets [and make them come here]. • (intr.) come here. waachí ki çi tà hàðé húða ði when you arrive at the dances tonight I want you to come over to me. waðákiçtôpapi húðe hkôbra I want you to [come and] look down upon us (MSB/t2, side 2). pá húðe snow falling.  

•• JOD (Wasápeëìka letter p26 ln3): wíe waléze wì huðáðe tà, ðéka húða ðì <Wíe wa§k¢é§se wiæ hü¢á¢a-§taæ, ¢e§ká hü´¢a-yiæhaú!> [sentence-final <hau> is not used in Modern Osage, and the final <a> in <hü¢á¢a> is likely a typo for e]  if you send me a letter, send it here.

•• LFD 62: húðe <hiu´-the> to cause to come (ritual expression).  

húheka. V (see kihúheka). • N illness, sickness (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).

•• LFD 62: húheka  <hiu´-he-ga>  sick, ill, sickness. húheka káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, húheka _káaãe] (trans.) sicken, make sick.

•• LFD 62: húheka kaãe <hiu´-he-ga ga-xe> to sicken.

húheka okáçà. VP [reg., húheka o_káçà] nurse or care for the sick. • N nurse (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.96).

húhekahci. N [húheka + hcí] hospital (lit., 'sickness house') (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.68).

húhekahci oëâ akxai he's lying in the hospital (RBn12-06).

•• LFD 62: húheka hci <hiu´-he-ga ¾si> sick house, hospital. húhekahci ce hta àkáðìàkáhi pe <hiu´-he-ga ¾si tse ¾a oæ-ga-thiæ oæ-ga hi bi a> we took him to the hospital.

húhka (variant: håhke). V [reg.?, _húhka?] (trans.) hook s.t. (e.g., clothing or a tree, by using a thrown line) (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn3-MOJ/p4). • N hook of any kind.

••• Cf. wahúhka.

húì (variant of híò).

húkaaãe. V [sync. k>p, hú_kaaãe] [(a)hú + káaãe] (trans.) pass (lit., 'cause to come here') (LS).

htáaliko che húkaaãa, wacúe çki pass the meat gravy and also the bread. (BE2.101,03/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

hukçíðe. V [reg., hu_kçíðe] [(a)hú + kçíðe CAU] (trans.) send here. mâzeohkíhkie hukçí[ð]a ði have him call here on the phone (RB; CQ gloss).

húu. ADJ, PRON [shortened form of huuhtâka, huuwáli] many, lots (of), large amount (of).

ónòbre húu áëu iché there is lots of food prepared, on the table (lit., 'there is a lot of food set out', 'there are many foods set out') (RBn3-14).

••• Cf. huuhtâka. 

húu (see ahú 'come here'). húu (variant of hú 'trunk'). húu hce (variant of hú hce).

húuce (variant: huucéha). ADV down, downward (BE2.34). [Used to direct someone who is looking for something; opposite of ámaçi (RB).]  

•• LFD 168: húce hta <hiu´dse ¾a> down below. LFD 62: okáhuce <u-ga´-hu-dse> steep, a steep hill, a steep bank.

••• Cf. ðuuhúuce. 

húuðe (variant of húðe).

huuhtâka (variant: huuhtâà). ADJ, PRON many, a large number (of), a whole bunch (of), lots (of), a lot (of), a large amount (of). huuhtâka ohkíhkie apai, hcíle apa hípe a whole bunch of them were talking when the family came over (3/2/89/MSB). hîìce huuhtâka a lot of dishes (FH:4/17/96/tape). mâzeska huuhtâka waðákØupe you gave them lots of money.

•• LFD 62: huhtàka <hiu-¾oæ-ga> a great many, a multitude.

••• Cf. húu 'many'.

húuìke (variant of hîìòke).

huukôða (variant: huukôì). PRON many people, a lot of people, everybody, everyone. huukôða waachí apai everybody is dancing (FH). huukôða achípe a lot of people came (FH/06/26/01/pc).

håüni (variant of híònìì).

húuscee (variants: huuscé, hiúçce). ADJ [hú 'trunk, leg' + scé(c)e] tall, long (e.g., a tree, a piece of lumber), having long legs (FH); taller (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.133).

••• Cf. hcéxopehuuscee.

huuwáli (variants: huuwáhli, huuwáalì). ADJ many, a lot of, a large number of. níhkaçika huuwáli a lot of people. mâzeska húuwaalì apai he has a lot of money. nàniôpaëì huuwáli apai húheka àkáaãe nàpé a lot of cigarettes make me sick (MSB 3-2-29).

••• Cf. húu 'many'.

huuëì. ADJ, N a bit (of), a small amount (of), a swallow or two (of a liquid), a little bit (of a liquid or other mass noun, such as ground coffee) (FH); a few, a small number (of a countable noun, such as people). màhkásai huuëì àkØú hu give me a swallow or two of coffee [more than hépeëì; "approximately half a cup"]. wakØó huuëì a few women. 

hûùìke, hûùke (variants of hîìòke).

hûùke xóe (variant of hîìòke xóe).

i. SUFFIX 3rd sg. or 3rd pl. noncontinuative postverbal marker. [A rare or archaic equivalent of api; precedes the evidential che.] htáabre aðée i ché he has gone hunting. hóolà aðée i ché he went fishing, he's gone fishing. okáhàpa kaaléka i ché they broke the window, the window is broken. ónòbre oohô ðáalì káaãa i ché the food was cooked good

(01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.30). ónòbre húu áëu i ché there is a lot of food set out, there are many foods set out (lit., 'food in large amounts they set out, it is apparent') (RBn3-14). hkáwa alîì aðée i che he's gone horseback riding (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). hkáwalìì aðée i ché, hkáwalìì aðáapi ché they have gone on horseback.

í- (variants: íi-, i-, ii-). LOC with, using, as a means of or to, through (an action represented by the verb stem), from, due to. çúpe iihúheka kçi áape he [lying down] has intestinal trouble, they said (12/30/94/FH/pc; BE2.1). ðekôòci ðíe íðakØewaðakie, táatà ówaðakihkà hkôbra now through your kindness to us, I want you to help us with things (RB).

•• LFD 100: màîhka iði çtòka <moæ-iæ´-Ða i-thi shtoæ-ga> harrow (lit., 'with which to make soil soft').  

••• Cf. íðaache, níiðaahtà. 

iáha. ADV immediately when, as soon as. ànâðapi iáha ðíiçtàpe as soon as they saw me, they stopped. achí nâpi iáha mâzeohkíhkie akxa kaamâàpe they were just arriving when the phone rang.

ichóhtàka (variant of ìchóhtàà).

íðaache. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) eat with. htaaníi hcúke íðaachapi! eat soup with a spoon!

iðáce (variants: iðáci). N his/her father. iðáce akxa äáahpape his father is short (2-2-259).

• his/her paternal uncle, his/her father's brother.  

•• LFD 78: iðaci <i-tha´-dsi> his or her father. iðaci akxa huheka pe <i-tha-dsi a-ka hiuhe-ga bi a> his father is ill. iðáci ie okihpa akxa o <i-tha´-dsi i-e u-gi-¼a a-ka o> [expected Mod. Os. 'obey' is okípçe rather than okihpa; sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] he obeyed his father's words.  

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 78).

••• Cf. iðáceëì.

íðace ìké. ADJP, N fatherless, illegitimate (lit., 'father lacking') (RBn10-3:MOJ/79); illegitimate child.  

iðáceëì. N [iðáce + -ëì 'little'] his/her father; his/her father's brother (his/her paternal uncle). [A diminutive form of iðáce, possibly an endearment.]  iðáci (variant of iðáce).

iðáhpe. V [reg., iðá_hpe; sometimes uninfl.] (trans., intr.) wait, wait for. [Osage Grammar erroneously treated this as a reg.-iða verb. Its 2nd person form has sometimes been influenced by the reg.-iða pattern, however, as noted for some examples below.] iðáhpi akxai he's waiting. iðáahpe I am waiting for him. iðáahpe àkxàhé I'm waiting (04/27/95/FH/pc). íðaahpe you are waiting for him [2nd person form remodeled on the analogy of reg.-iða verbs]. íðaahpe çkôçta tà, çeðó nààëî if you want to wait for someone, just stand there [2nd person form remodeled on the analogy of reg.-iða verbs] (04/27/95/FH/pc; RBn2-MOJ/p32; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). iðáhpe àkátxà, iðáahpe àkátxà we've been waiting [uninfl.]. hâàpa záani àná[ð]aðihpape we waited for you all day (FH:5/01/96/tape). wáli niiëúpe àëì àná[ð]aðihpape it really rained but we waited for you (FH:8/15/95; FH:5/01/96/tape).  

•• LFD 79: iðáhpe <i-tha´-¼e> to wait for someone. iðáahpe <i-tha´-a-¼e> I wait for someone. iðáðahpe <i-tha´-tha-¼e> you wait for someone. [Contrast the modern 2nd sg.

form íðaahpe (remodeled on the analogy of reg.-iða verbs) in examples above.]

••• Cf. wéðahpe. 

iðákihpe. V [reg., iðá_kihpe] [kik- SUU + iðáhpe] wait for one's own family or close persons. anâðikihpe we're waiting for you [our own relative] (MSB:2/25/83).

•• LFD 79: àðàakihpa pe <oæ-thoæ-a-gi-¼a i> we wait for someone. [A more accurate translation would be 'wait for someone of one's own'.]

íðakØeðe. V [reg., íðakØe_ðe] (trans.) show pity with, be kind with, use kindness or pity with. ónòbre waatái çki íðakØewaðakíapí [you] pity us with this food and these prayers. ðekôòci ðíe íðakØéwaðákie, táatà ówaðakihkà hkôbra now through your kindness to us, I want you to help us with things (RB).  

íðiiçtà. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) ready. íðiiçtà ðaaçé? are you ready? (RBn14-03, unconfirmed).  

••• Cf. íkiðiiçtà.

íðilà (variant: íðila). V [sync., í_ðilà] (trans.) have on one's mind. íbrilà I have it on my mind. íçcilà, íçäilà you have it on your mind. íðilà she has it on her mind. ànâðilà, ààðílà we have it on our minds. táatà íbrila I have something on my mind (RBn10-5:JW). táatà íçcila? what do you have on your mind? what's on your mind? (RBn10-5:JW, CQc). • want, wish. àwâðahkie íçcilà you wanted to talk to me (FH:5/01/96/tape). owíhkie íbrilà I wanted to talk to you (FH:5/01/96/tape). • think about. íbrilà I'll think about it (when asked for a favor). íbrilà hta mìkçé I'm going to think about it (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p8). íwibrilà (mìkçé) I'm thinking about you (FH:prod). wabrílà mìkçé, íbrilà mìkçé I'm thinking about it. íçäilà? are you thinking about it? have you thought about it? (FH). íbrilà hta mìkçé I'll think about it, I'm going to be thinking about it. waðílà ðáalì na íbrilà hkôbra I want to think good thoughts all the time (a sentence used to ask for guidance when praying) (FH/8/30/94). háakò íçäilà ðáìçe? what are you thinking about? what's on your mind? (03/20/95/FH/pc:prod). àðílà àkákxai we're thinking about it (FH). íðilà! you think about it! (FH: prod). táatà íçcilà? do you have something on your mind?

•• LFD 79: íðilà <i´-thi-gthoæ> to think; to consider; to study; to contemplate. àðâðilà pe 

<oæ-thoæ´-thi-gthoæ i> [expected Mod. Os. form: ànâðilà pe] we consider. hìta íbrilà hte ha <hiæ-da i´-bthi-gthoæ ¾e ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: íbrilà hce; hìta is unknown and sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] let me think. [LF's forms <a´-wa-bthi-gthoæ> 'I consider' and <a´-wa-shti-gthoæ> 'you consider' are actually 1st sg. and 2nd sg. forms of a different verb: see áwaðilà 'meditate on, consider'.]

••• Cf. waðílà. 

íðilà ðìké. ADVP thoughtlessly, in an offhand manner (lit., 'not thinking'). íðilà ðìke íðae you spoke without thinking.  

•• LFD 79: íðilà ðìke íe <i´-thi-gthoæ thiæ-ge i-e> offhand; said without preparation (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok). íðilà ðìke <i´-thi-gthoæ thiæ-ge> reckless; recklessness. íðilà ðìké hpaãé <i´-thi-gthoæ thiæ-ge ¼a-xe> I am reckless [lit., 'I did it without thinking']

(03/20/95/FH/pc:ok). iðílà ðìke çkaãé <i-thi´-gthoæ thiæ-ge shka-xe> you are reckless.

íðiçàha. V [sync., í_ðiçàha] (trans.) detour around, go around, avoid (02/27/95/FH/pc). íçciçàha you go/are going around (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 79: íðiçàha <i´-thi-shoæ-ha> to detour; to go around. íbriçà ha <i´-bthi-shoæ ha> I go around. ístiçà ha <i´-sti-shoæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: íçciçàha] you go around. àðâðiçà pe <oæ-thoæ´-thi-shoæ i> [expected Mod. Os. form: ànâðiçàha pe] we go around.

••• Cf. ihkílaçà. 

íðoce (variant: íðoci). V, ADJ [conjug. unknown] (intr.) (be) open (e.g., a door). hciëé akxa íðoci akxai the door is open (RBn10-20).

••• KS íyåýe open, as a door (RR).

íðohtà. ADJ straight, in a straight line.

•• LFD 80: íðohtà <i´-thu-¾oæ> in a straight line, or to cut across (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. óðohtà, wáðohtà. 

iðôeðìhé. V [uninfl.] (intr.) be in the way, be in the middle (FH 8/8/94/pc). àkáe hce, iðôeðìhé àkái let's go, we're in the way (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). iðôeðìhé you're in the way (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

íðòãe. V [sync., í_ðòãe] (trans.) ask a question of s.o., interrogate or question s.o.; (intr.) ask questions about a certain topic (FH:5/02/96/prod; 01/06/95/FH/pc:prod orig). táatà wì íwibròãe I want to ask you something (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). íðòãa ask him

(01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.5). Carolyn akxa çínà waëáëeíe iðôãe akxa Carolyn keeps asking about Osage words (01/13/95/FH/pc). áçi çcée çkôçta tà iðôãa if you want to go outside, ask the question (i.e., ask if you may go) (FH/8/8/94/pc). ékò çkôçta tà ànâðòãa if that's what you want, ask me (FH/07/09/01/pc). íbròãe hta mìkçé I'm going to ask a question (FH:5/01/96/tape:prod).

•• JOD (slip file): íðòãe <í-¢ªu æ-xe> to ask a question.

•• LFD 80: íðòãe <i´-thoæ-xe> to ask a question; to question. çìhtoëìka ðe íbròãe ha <shiæ-¾o-zhiæ-ga the i´-bthoæ-xe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I questioned the boy. íçtòãe? <i´-shtoæ-xe a(?)> did you question him? LFD 283: ímòãe <i´-moæ-xe> to inquire [Omaha usage, unconfirmed in Osage].

••• OP ímàãe to question.

••• Cf. ilôãe. 

íðòpe. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) appear. óðàëi wécØa apa íðòpe hta apai the snakes will come out [appear] anyway (RBn23-21). mîì akxa íðòpi akxai the sun is coming up (RB; BE2.38, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 80: íðòpe <i´-thoæ-be> to appear; come into sight. mi akxa íðòpa pe <mi a-ka i´thoæ-ba bi a> the sun has appeared. LFD 90: míiðòpe <mi´-i-thoæ-be> the sun appears; sunrise.

••• Cf. mîì íðòpe ìkçé. 

íðuãe. V [sync., í_ðuãe] (trans.) have as a bridesmaid. wáçäuãe tà Mary íçäuãe hta akxai if you get married, Mary will be your bridesmaid (lit., 'if you marry, you would have Mary as bridesmaid').

••• Cf. wáðuãe. 

íðuspa (variant: iðúspa). N pound (measure of weight). tooská íðuspa lébrà hkôbra I want ten pounds of potatoes (BE2.106: 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; with 2nd syll. accent iðúspa).

•• RB: <i-thú-spah>.

•• LFD 79: íðispà <i´-thi-špoæ> scales for weighing.

íðuwì. V [sync., í_ðuwì] (trans.) buy with, acquire in trade for, sell or trade for. mâzeska íbruwì I bought it with money.

••• Cf. wéðuwì.

íe. V [reg.-iða, í_e] (trans.) talk about, discuss, speak of. íðae, íðai you speak of it. iðáe, iðái I speak of it. íe, ée she speaks of it. pée íðai ðaaçé? who are you talking about? (RBn10-18).

• (intr.) talk, say, speak, make a speech or talk. iðáe I speak. ìðáe htai let's talk (lit., 'let's all let me talk') (FH/pc). iðáe mìkçé I am speaking (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). iðái hce let me say something, let me speak (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). iðáe atxàhé I'm speaking [standing] (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). iðái hta mìkçé I'm going to make a talk (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p12). háakò iðáe mìkçé Jack akxa íiçtà akxai Jack agrees with what I say (lit., 'Jack agrees with how I speak')

(FH/11/18/01/pc; RBn1-26). háakò iðáe tà Jack akxa íiçtà akxai Jack agrees with what I said

(FH/11/18/01/pc). ówenà iðáe hkôbra I want to say something in appreciation

(03/05/95/JS/pc:ok). iðáiëi tà if I say nothing (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:uk). iðái hce ée apa they've asked me to speak (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). íðaiëi tà if you say nothing (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:uk). íe hta akxái he's going to speak

(03/14/95/FH/pc). íe akxai she is talking, she is saying it (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok;

03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). wáli íiëi akxai he sure won't talk [íiëi from íe aëí] (RBn10-2). íeëi akxa he/she is not talking, he/she is not saying anything (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:uk). íe óhesaëi to talk hatefully (RBn10-14). íaëi to say nothing (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; 03/16/95/JS/pc:uk). íhtaháaëi íape he talked wrong, inappropriately (LS: prod; BE2.143; RBn1-MOJ/p56). • (trans.) speak a language. waëáëe íe! talk Osage! waëáëe ía! talk Osage!

(03/15/95/PM/pc:okc, both ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). waëáëeíe ìðákØuce htai [expected Mod. Os. form of verb: ànàkØuce] let's try to speak Osage (03/14/95/FH/pc). • N word, words; language; teachings, one's word; speech; prayer. íe ðíhta àkóðaha àkôða àkái çki even though we want to follow your word (part of a prayer) (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.75). wahkôta iëîke íe Jesus' teachings. íe ðáalì káaãape he made a good speech. íe ðuustáko straighten that word out (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). waëáëeíe Osage language. íe kaaçénà ékipçe this prayer ends now, I have spoken (JS: prayer).

•• LFD 70: íe <i´-e> to speak. íe ðáalì káaãa pe <i´-e tha-gthiæ ga-xa bi a> he delivered a fine oration. íe <i´-e> a language. íe ðáalì çkáaãe o <i´e tha-gthiæ shka-xe o> [sentencefinal o is not used in Mod. Os.] your oration was good.

••• Cf. ékie, wíkie. íe áhkie. VP (trans.) talk for or against s.o.

••• Cf. áhkie. 

íe ðaaéëi. VP [sync., íe _ðaaéëi] (trans.) misconstrue (lit., 'mouth different words') (LF).

•• LFD 70 (unconfirmed): íe ðaeëi <i´-e tha-e-zhi> repeating falsely: to misconstrue.

íe ðáalì ëì. N greeting card, gift card (lit., 'good little words') (MREI).

íe ðáawaska. VP (intr.) speak clearly. íe çtáawaska nòpe you speak clearly (RBn HW).

íe ðuuzé. VP tape, make a recording with an audio device (lit., 'take the words'). mâzeíe akxa íe âðuuzi akxái the tape recorder is taping my talk (RBn12-06).

íe hpíiëi. N curse, bad words (BE2.28; RBn2-MOJ/p16; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

íe kipçé (variant of íe okípçe).

íe okaaãéìke. N curses (considered as scattered useless words), things people say maliciously that are untrue, malicious false gossip (FH:prod).

íe okípçe (variant: íe kipçé). VP [reg., íe o_kípçe] [kik- SUU + íe opçé] keep one's own word

(RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). ðíe, íe oðákipçe ðààçé you're a person who keeps his word (RBn1014). íe ðakípçe you keep your word (RBn10-22/JW). • N promise-keeper. íeokípçe a person who keeps his/her word.

íe opçé. VP [reg. íe o_pçé] (trans.) obey, follow, or keep true to s.o.'s word. íe oðápçe you're going to do what their word said (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). Mary íe owápçe hta mìkçe I'm going to obey Mary (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). íe oðípçe hta akxai he's going to make your word true (RBn10-3:MOJ/79; BE2.97). íe opçáape aap they said they obeyed the word (MGreen tape).

••• KS ophé follow (RR).

íe scece (variant: íe scee). VP talk too long. • N talker, person who talks too long (BE2.133; 03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok).

íe wáðohta. VP speak truthfully, talk straight (FH/pc).

íe waská. N clear words, interpreter. íe waská brî hta mìkçé I'll be the interpreter (RB:MSB/02/17/83). íe waská ðáalì nîe you are a good interpreter (RB:MSB). íe waska íkihpáaãe hkôbra I want to interpret for you (BE2.157; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok).

íe waská íkikaaãe. VP [sync., k>p, íe waská íki_kaaãe] [íe + wa- VAL + ská 'white, clear' + ki- DAT + íkaaãe] interpret for another. íe waska íkihpáaãe hkôbra I want to interpret for you (RB).

íe wasúhu. N clean talk, clear speaking. íe wasúhu! speak clearly! (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

íekie. N crier, town crier. [Archaic.]

íeska (variant: íewaská). V [íe + ská] (intr.) speak clearly. • N clear words, clear language.

íeçtà. N [íe + çtà] talker (one who talks too much, is mouthy, or interrupts [RB]; lit., 'talk constantly') (RB; 03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 70: íeçtà <i´-e-shtoæ> a talkative person.

íewaská (variant of íeska).

íeëi. V [reg.-iða, í_eëi] [íe + aëí NEG] (intr.) say nothing; refuse to talk. íeëi akxá she is saying nothing, she is not talking (RBn1-26). iðáeëi tà if I say nothing (RBn1-26). íðaeëi tà if you say nothing (RBn1-26). wáli íiëi akxai he sure won't talk (RBn10-2).

íhaa. N mouth (02/27/95/FH/pc:okc). [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] íhaa che àníe my mouth is sore (BE2.90; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 72: íha <i´-ha> mouth. íha che àníe ha <i´-ha te oæ-ni´-e ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] my mouth is sore.

íhaa ípukxa (variant: íhaa ápukxa). N napkin (lit., 'with which to wipe the mouth') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 72: íha ipihka <i´-ha i-bi-Ða> a napkin.

íhaa ëáhta. N broken or split lip, harelip.

•• LFD 72: <i´-ha zha-¾a> broken lip; harelip. çîhto ëìka akxa íhaëahta pe ha <shiæ´-¾o zhiæ-ga a-ka i´-ha-zha-¾a pe ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: çîtoëì akxa íhaa ëáhtape; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] the boy has a broken lip.

ihâka. N his brother's wife or his wife's sister (more precise than English 'his sister-in-law') (FH/09/22/01/pc).  

ihcíko. N his/her grandfather; his/her father-in-law (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.45).  

••• LFD 80: ihcíko <i-¾si´-go> grandfather.

••• Cf. wihcíko. 

ihcíkoapí. N [ihcíko+ api] president (e.g., of the United States; lit., 'grandfather of all') (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.107).

ihcími. N his/her father's sister (his/her paternal aunt; more precise than English 'his aunt' or 'her aunt'). Johna ihcími John's aunt (FH/09/22/01/pc).

•• LFD 80: ihcími <i-¾si´-mi> aunt, his or her father's sister (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok).  

••• Cf. wihcími. 

ihcíni (variant: ihcínì). N his/her daughter-in-law.

•• LFD 81: <i-¾si´-ni>.  

••• Cf. wihcíni. 

ihcióçpa (variant of ihcóçpa).

 ihcióëàke (variant of ihcóëàke).

ihcíëo (variants: ihcíëò, ihcíëoe). N his sister's daughter (more precise than English 'his niece'); his father's sister's daughter (more precise than English 'his cousin').  

•• RB: <i-tsí-zho>his niece

•• LFD 81: ihcíëò <i-¾si´-zhoæ> niece, daughter of a sister or a father's sister [should be 'niece, daughter of a man's sister or a man's father's sister'].

••• QU ihtíëò man's sister's daughter, niece (RR); KS iääíëo aunt; man's sister's daughter, niece (RR); OM ihtíëà sister's daughter (RR).  

ihcîto. N her older brother (i.e., any of her brothers who is older than she is).

•• LFD 80: ichîto <i-tsiæ´-do> her elder brother, ritual term.  

ihcóçka. N his wife's brother's son, his sister's son, her brother's son (more precise than English 'his/her nephew'); his/her father's sister's son (his/her paternal aunt's son; more precise than English 'his/her cousin') [meaning 'his/her father's sister's son [male cousin]' is attested in LF only, unconfirmed; modern term for 'his/her father's sister's son' is hcióçka 'father's sister's son']; his/her grandchild [use of term to mean 'grandchild' is unexpected].    

•• LFD 81: ihcóçka <i-¾su´-shka> nephew, son of a sister or a father's sister.

••• KS iääóçkayà woman's sister's son (RR).  

ihcóçpa (variant: ihcióçpa). N his/her grandchild. ihcióçpa háanà waaçäì? how many grandchildren do you have? (FH/09/24/01/prod).

•• LFD 81: ihcóçpa <i-¾su´-shpa> to issue; to bring forth (05/01/95/LS/pc:ma); his or her grandchild.  

ihcóçpa áhkiha. NP his/her great-grandchild (05/01/95/LS/pc:prod).  

ihcóëàke (variant: ihcióëàke). N her brother's daughter (more precise than English 'her niece').

•• LFD 81: ihcóëàke <i-¾su´-zhoæ-ge> a niece, her brother's daughter.  

íhcuke. N big mouth (lit., 'spoon with') (RBn23-17, unconfirmed).

íhice. V [stat., í_hice] [1st and 3rd persons appear in examples without stative pronominal]

(trans.) be anxious for, be eager that s.t. take place (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). iðâhice, ìðâhice, àðâhice, ànâhice I am anxious to do it, I am anxious for it. ðée hta ànâhice mìkçé I'm anxious to go (MREI 2-1-82). alée che ànâhice I was anxious to go home (01/06/95/FH/pc:okc). waachí ke brée che iðâhice mìkçé I was anxious to go to the dances (FH:prod). ðalée che ìðâhice I'm anxious for you to go [back/home] (FH:prod). brée hta mìkçé ìðâhice hta mìkçé I'm anxious to go (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). ðalí che iðâhice I'm anxious for you to come home (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; LS; RB; FH:4/25/96/tape). hôòpa çtáke iðâhice I'm anxious for warm weather (FH:4/25/96/tape). ðalí che íðihice? are you anxious to come home? (FH:prod). alí che íðihice? are you anxious for me to come home? (FH:prod). wanôbre íhice apai they're anxious to eat (FH:4/25/96/tape:prod). waachí ke ðée che íhice apái they were really anxious to go to the dances (FH:prod; no wa). aðée hce íhice apai they were anxious to go (FH:prod). ànâhice àðìkçé ~ íhice àðìkçé we [two] are anxious to do it (MREI 22-1-82). ànâhice apai they're anxious for me (MREI 22-11-82). íwihice I'm anxious for you (MREI-22-11-82). íðihice apai they're anxious for you (MREI 22-11-82). • (intr.) be impatient. àðâhice I am impatient (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod). íðihice you are impatient (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod). • (trans.) hurry s.o. along. íhice apái they're hurrying someone along (108-b/FH/416). • (intr.) be ready. wí, àðáhice, ànâhice, àðâhice as for me, I'm ready to go (RBn10-5:JW).

•• LFD 281: íhice <i´-hi-dse> impatience; earnest, eager, impatient. LFD 73: àðâhice <oæ-thoæ´-hi-dse> I am impatient. iðíhice <i-thi´-hi-dse> [expected Mod. Os. form:

íðihice] you are impatient (LF accent unconfirmed).

••• Cf. híceðe. 

íhkihkawì. N [presumably hkik- RECIP + íkawì (otherwise unattested)] exchange, trade, swap, change (money, coins) (1/20/83/631; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). íhkihkawì àkØú pe they gave me back change (after a purchase) (1/20/83/631). íhkihkáwì hpaaãé àëi mâzeska brúuze I exchanged it, but I took money.  

íhkihkawì káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, íhkikawì _káaãe] (trans.) exchange one item for another, trade, swap. hkáwa íhkihkawì àkáaãape we traded horses (1/20/83/631). íhkihkawi hpáaãe àëi mâzeska brúuze mìkçé I exchanged it, but I took money (1/20/83/631; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

• (intr.) change, make change, make a change.

•• LFD 73: íhkihkawìðe <i´-Ði-Ða-wiæ-the> to exchange; to trade; to barter [LF forms all unconfirmed]. íhkiwawì aðe <i´-Ði-wa-wiæ a-the> I exchange. íhkihkawì ðaðe <i´-Ði-Ðawiæ tha-the> you exchange. íhkihkawì àða pe <i´-Ði-Ða-wiæ oæ-tha i> we exchange.

íhkihkie. V [reg.-iða, í_hkihkie] [evidently reduplicated form of hkik- RECIP + íe] (trans.) talk or speak to each other using (a certain language or the hands). waëáëeíe ànâhkihkíe hce let's talk Osage to each other [two persons] (9-6-82). waëáëeíe ànâhkihkíe htai let's talk Osage to each other [three or more persons].

íhkihpahò. V [reg.-iða, í_hkihpahò] [hkik- REFL + ípahò] (trans.) recognize oneself as. íxopeçtà íhkihpahòpe he knows he always lies (lit., 'he knows himself a liar') (RBn23-17c).

íhkilai (variant: íhkilaì). V [reg.-iða?, í_hkilai?] [presumably í- LOC + hkik- REFL + aðî] (trans.) ration, apportion, divide, give out in portions. [Giving out food is a custom among the Osages, especially at the annual ceremonial dances.] wéhkili íhkilai hta apai. they're going to divide clothes (RBn22-17). ónôbre íhkilai tà, káache wihta óçäeche when they divide up the groceries, put mine here (03/06/95/FH/pc:prod all; BE2.101). ówe óçäeche ànáhkilai htai, ówe oçäeche àðáhkilai htai let's all of us divide these leftover groceries (03/06/95/FH/pc). ówe óçäeche íhkilaiapi divide the leftover groceries into piles [pl. addressee]. ónòbre íhkilaipi give out food [pl. addressee] (03/06/95/FH/pc:okc).  

•• RB: <í-ki-laiæ>.

ihkílaçà (variant: ihkílaça). V [reg.-iða?, i_hkílaçà?] pass or go back and forth (RBn23-07; HRE/01/17/02/pc:okc).

••• Cf. íðiçàha. 

íhkiluuëa. V [reg.-iða?, í_hkiluuëa?] [í- LOC + hkik- REFL + ðuuëá] (trans.) wash oneself with. wépukxa íhkiluuëaa wash yourself with soap (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc).

íhkiçike. V [reg.-iða, í_hkiçike] [presumably hkik- RECIP + íçike (unattested elsewhere)] (intr.) miss each other. ànâhkiçike àðìkçe we [two] miss each other (MSB 3-3-83).  

íhkiçoce. N fog, misting rain, drizzle, mist (01/26/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• RB: <í-keh-shó-tseh>.

•• LFD 74: ihkiçoce <i-Ði-sho-dse> haze; mist; fog. páce apa oxpáða pe ha, íkiçoce kçe <ba-dse a-ba u-xpa´-tha pe ha, i´-Ði-sho-dse ke> the boat was lost in the fog.

••• Cf. çóce. 

ihkíëì (variant: ihkíëi). V [reg., i_hkiëi] [í- LOC + hkíëì (possibly from aëî 'think'); evidently contains hkik- RECIP/REFL, but is used as simple transitive] (trans.) be angry with.

ihkówa (variant: iihkówa). N friend. hawé ihkówa hello, my friend (RB). ihkówa wíhta my friend. ðihkówa your friend (01/30/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.51).

•• RB: <gó-lah, gó-wah, kó-wah, kó-weh>.

•• LFD 74: ihkóða <i-Ðu´-tha> crony.  ihkóða <i-Ðo´-tha> fellow, a friend. ihkóða owakihkie <i-Ðo´-tha u-wa-gi-Ði-e> I spoke to a friend.  ihkóðà hkihkaxe <i-Ðo´thoæ Ði-Ðaxe> making friends. LFD 90: ihkóða wihta <i-Ðu´-tha wi-¾a> he is a friend of mine. LFD 147: ðihkóða <thi-Ðu´-tha> your friend.

íhkowa (variant of íhkòe?). V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) catch on s.t., get caught on s.t. haaská íhkowa akxai my shirt caught on something (and is caught) (3-3-83-p1).

íhkòe. N hook, fishhook, hook and line (RBn3-MOJ/p5, unconfirmed; 02/09/95/FH/pc:uk). hóize íhkowa hook and line (RB; 01/25/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 74 (unconfirmed): íhkòðe <i´-Ðoæ-the> the pot hanger. LFD 68: hoíhkòðe <hui´-Ðoæ-the> fishline. ho; ihkòðe <hu; i-Ðoæ-the> fish; line. LFD 74 (unconfirmed): íhkòðe <i´-Ðoæ-the> the pot hanger.

íhkuáci (variant: íhkuéci). N fan made of tail feathers. xúða íkueci eagle tail fan (RBn13-01). •• RB: <í-ku-éh-tseh> <í-kyu-áh-tsi> (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok; 01/23/95/PM/pc:uk; BE2.43).

•• JOD (slip file): íhkiðacú <i´-ki-¢a-¦t¦sü´> a fan.

•• LFD 73: íhkiacì <i´-Ði-a-dsiæ> a fan. màçà íhkiacì wì abrì ha <moæ-shoæ i´-Ði-a-dsiæ wiæ a-bthiæ ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I have a feather fan (LF, unconfirmed; 01/23/95/PM/pc:uk).  

íhpià (variants: íhpie, íhpia). N belt worn by men with dance clothes or outside a blanket to hold it up (BE2.8); any belt (FH).

•• JOD (slip file): úhpuða <ü´-pü-¢a> a belt or girdle.

•• LFD 78: íhpiða <i´-¼i-tha> belt; sash; girdle.

íhpiiëi. V [stat., _(í)hpiiëi] [1st person form: âhpiiëi, àhpíiëi, or ànâhpiiëi] (intr.) be sick with, be very troubled by (e.g., an illness, an ailing body part), have health problems due to, be in bad shape because of, be distraught about. çáake wáli àhpíiëi síi çki my hands really hurt and my

feet too. brée brúucØáke âhpiiëi àhé I'm sick about not being able to go (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). wáli níhka kôða, íhpiiëi akxai, àëâà htai she really wants a man, she's bad off, let's have her stay all night (lit., 'she's sick from wanting a man so much, let's all go to bed'). • be sick or unwell, be near death, be gravely ill. âhpiiëi àhé I haven't been feeling well (05/01/95/LS/pc:okc). ànâhpiiëi mìkçé I'm really sick (2/3/83/1/311).

íhta (variants: ihtá, hta). V, PRON [inalien.] (intr.) (be) his/hers, theirs; belong to (him/her, them). kçôka çôke íhta apa zípe second son's dog is yellow (lit., 'second son his dog is yellow') (2-1-F). íhtaaëi it's not theirs (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.137). pée íhta? who does this belong to? ihtá na [this] belongs to each one, one for each one (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). • V fit, be suitable or appropriate. ihtáaëi it's not his/her way of life, it doesn't fit him/her/them (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p56).

•• LFD 78: ihtá <i-¾a´> his or hers.

ihtá na. VP [inalien.] (intr.) belong to each person; there is/was one or part of s.t. for each person. ihtá na [this] belongs to each one, one for each one. (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. nà 'always'. íhtaapi. PRON [inalien.] their. Mary Johna hci íhtaapi Mary and John's house.

ihtáeëì (variant of ihtéëì).  

ihtáãe. N tip. ðéeze ihtáãe tip of the tongue (03/23/95/FH/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): ihtáãe <i-ta´-xe> an end or tip of an obj[ect].

•• LFD 143: ðéze ihtaãe <the´-še i-¾a-xe> tip of the tongue.

íhtaháaëi. ADJ, ADV wrong, unsuitable/unsuitably, inappropriately. íhtaháaëi íape he talked wrong (LS: prod; BE2.143; RBn1-MOJ/p56).

íhtà. PPN from. ecí íhtà from here (04/13/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 80: ihtà <i-¾oæ> whence.

••• Cf. ihtôì hta ìkçé. íhtàà. V [stat.?, _íhtàà?] [í- LOC + htâka 'big'] (trans.) feel good about. íhtàà akxai he feels big over it (RBn23-15; WF).

ihtâha (variants: ihtâhà, ihtáhài). N his/her father's sister's husband (his/her paternal uncle by marriage; more precise than English 'his/her uncle'); his brother-in-law (his wife's brother or his sister's husband) (FH/09/23/01/pc:ok).

••• Cf. ðihtâha. 

ihtâke. N his/her older sister (i.e., the oldest among a group of sisters; not necessarily older than the person referred to by "his" or "her").

•• LFD 80: ihtâke <i-¾oæ´-ge> his elder sister.  

ihtéëì (variant: ihtáeëì). N his/her younger sister. óhkie çô ìkçé ihtéëì akxa mâzeíe híðape he was talking to someone on the telephone when his little sister called.

•• LFD 80: ihtâe ëìka <i-¾oæ´-’e zhiæ-ga> his or her younger sister.  

ihtôce. N his/her son-in-law.

•• LFD 80: ihtôce <i-¾oæ´dse> son-in-law.  

ihtôì. ADV the future, the days to come, onward in time.  

•• LFD 80 (unconfirmed): ihtôðì hkiðe <i-¾oæ´-thiæ Ði-the> to go first; to go ahead. ihtòðì hkiðe bre <i-¾oæ-thiæ Ði-the bthe> I go ahead. ihtôðì hkiðe màðì o <i-¾oæ´-thiæ Ði-the moæthiæ o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] you go ahead.

ihtôì ðéha (ìkçé) (variant: ihtûì ðéha). ADVP [optionally includes 'sitting, round' positional article ìkçé] in the days to come, from now on, meantime (FH/09/21/01/pc). waëáëeíe màðí ihtûì ðeha ðée àkòðape we want the Osage language to endure (04/06/95/FH/pc; BE2.71). hôòpa ihtôì ðéha ìkçé from this day on into the future. waëáëeíe màðí ihtûì ðeha ðée àkòðape we want the Osage language to endure (04/06/95/FH/pc; RBn23-17).

•• RB: <i-twí-theh-hah> going a long time; into the future (FH).

ihtôì ðihé (variant: ihtúì ðihé) [possibly ihtôì+ aðìhé] ADVP in the future. ihtúì ðihé àkáðapi tà as we go along in the future (FH/pc/98; RBn23-17).

ihtôì hta ìkçé. ADVP from now on.

•• JOD (slip file): ihtûìhta <i-tuæ´-iæ´ta>in the future.

••• Cf. ihtôì ðéha. 

ihtúì ðihé (variant of ihtôì ðihé).

ihtûì ðéha (variant of ihtôì ðéha [ìkçé]).

íhuheka (variant: ihúheka). V [uninfl.] (trans.?) be sick or have health trouble with (an ailing part of the body or some other condition). içíkØà hcéze íhuheka kçí aape my sister-in-law is sick with her stomach, they say (FH/09/23/01/pc:prod). hcéze íhuheka kçí áape he [lying down] is sick of [i.e., 'to, in'] his stomach (FH/09/23/01/pc). çúpe ihúheka kçí áape he [lying down] has intestinal trouble, they said (12/30/94/FH/pc: lying down; FH/09/23/01/pc; BE2.1). çúpe ihúheka àhé I've had intestinal trouble.

••• Cf. húheka. 

ii-, íi- (variants of í- LOC).

íibrà (variant: íibra). V [stat., íi_brà] [doubly stative (semantic subject and object both use patient pronominals); 2nd person either stative or active] (trans.) have enough of, get enough of, have one's fill of, be sated with (either a positive or negative thing); be satiated with; be tired of, be negatively affected by too much of s.t. (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok). ànâbra I've had enough of it. íðibra you've had enough of it. ànâbra we've have enough of it. waxpéì ììðâbrà, waxpáðì ììnâbra I've had enough of being pitiful (12/30/94/FH/pc). íiðabrà, íiðibrà you've had enough. wawéebràpe we're tired of them; we've had enough of them (FH:10/12/95; RBn1-MOJ/p56). íiwinàbra I've had enough of you [from íi-wi-à-brà]. wéebrà ìkçé we [two] had enough (MSB). íbra xcì have more than one's fill (especially more than one's share of pain and suffering) (03/08/95/FH/pc:ok). waxpáðì ìðâbra I'm pitiful with suffering [ìðâbrà from i-à-brà] (RBn1-56; (FH/09/23/01/pc: prod). waxpáðì ànâbra xcì I'm pitiful with suffering (RBn1-56; FH/09/23/01/pc: ok).  

••• Cf. íibràëi. 

íibràxcì. V [stat., íi_bràxcì] (trans.) have more than enough of, have more than one's fill or share of (e.g., sorrow to the point of being pitiful, excessive woe). íibraxci to have had more than one's share [e.g., of pain] or more than one can bear (RBn1-MOJ/p56; BE2.61; 12/30/94/FH/pc/ok). waxpáðì íibraxci pitiful with suffering (RBn1-MOJ/p56).  

íibràëi. V, ADJ [stat., íi_bràëì] (intr.) (be) greedy, not (be) satisfied, can't get enough. ììnâbrà màëí I'm greedy, I can't get enough (RB). íibraëi she's greedy, unsatisfied (RBn1-MOJ/p56; 12/30/94/FH/pc/ok). • N greed (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.61).

iichî. V [reg.-iða, ii_chî] (trans.) hit with, strike with (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok; 2/10/83/p5-2/24-5/83; MSB; FH/09/22/01/pc). iiðáchi I hit with it. íiðachì you hit with it. iichî he hit with it. ànàchìpe we hit with it. çáake iiðáchìe I hit him with my hand (05/02/95/LS/pc). ëâàxe wì iiðáchì I hit him with a stick (03/14/95/FH/pc:no). kxáëì ëâà wì íiðachì you hit kxaëì with a stick (LS). îì íiðachì íiwie ðe I saw you hit him with a rock (LS/07/27/95/pc:okc). çáake íiðachì? did you hit him with the hand? (03/14/95/FH/pc). wéeðachìpe you hit us [with it] (LS). wékaaëi ànâchìpe he hit me with a stick [a whip] (05/02/95/LS/pc; 11/14/82/MREI; 05/02/95/LS/pc:ok). weáchìe I hit him with them.

•• LFD 80: íchì <i´-tsiæ>club (hatchet). nòpé ðiskike iðáchì ha <noæ-be´ thi-ški-ge itha´-tsiæ ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I struck him with the fist (01/26/95/FH/pc:ok; correct without the ha).  

íiðe. V [reg.-iða, íi_ðe] (trans.) see. iiðáðe I saw (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). iiðá[ð]a màëí I did not see (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). íiwiðe hta mìkçé I'll be seeing you (RB). kahúuëa íiwiðe màëi I haven't seen you for a long time (RB). weeáðe I saw them/I saw [indeterminate] him. iiðáðe I saw him/her/it (2/24-5/83; MSB). iiðáði áha if I see him (MSB). íiðaðe you saw him (MSB). wée[ð]aðe you saw them. çáakeoolâkØò pée íiðaðe? who did you see at the hand game? (RB). íiðaðe nìkçé? do you see? (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). íiðape he saw (04/06/95/LS/pc:prod). íiðaëi akxá he can't see (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). çe níhka íiði apái? does he see those men? (RBn1210; CQc). níhka akxa íiði apái? did the man see him? (RBn12-10; BE2.118; CQc). wéeðape he saw them; he saw us; they saw them; they saw us (MSB). mìhkása ðéeðe, hpahâle iiðápi che this black man, the first one they had ever seen (RB). íiðaëi they didn't see (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). íiðaëi akxá they couldn't see (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok/prod). íiðape they saw (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). ànâðapi áha when they saw me (MSB). ànâðe ðáha if we see them (MSB). omáìhka hcéka ðóha ànâðe àkátxa we're about to [lit., 'we almost'] see a new year (RB). çí íiwiki[ð]e hta akxai we'll see each other again. • find. mâàhì hpaahí íiðaðe? did you find the sharp knife? (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.74). iiðáðe I found him/her/it (2/24-5/83; MSB). • (intr., trans.) understand. iiðáðe ðée ðanâkØò nàkxâçe those of you that understand are listening.

LFD 79: íðe <i´-the> to see; to find; to discern; to discover. iðáðe <i-tha´-the> I discern; I discovered. íðaðe <i´-tha-the> you discern; you discovered. àðâða pe <oæ-thoæ´tha i> we discern; we discover.

iiðée. V [stat., ii_ðée] (trans.) go by using, travel on (e.g., certain funds). waëáëe mâzeska iiðáapi áape they went on Osage money (lit., 'with Osage money they went, it is said') (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). waëáëe mâzeska iibrée I went on Osage money (FH).

íiðì. V [sync., íi_ðì] (intr.) win, go out (in a card game) (1-27-83). hóni íibrì I almost won. íiçcì you won. ðóha íiðì akxai he's about to win.

iiðótahkiðe. V [reg.?, iiðóta_hkiðe?] [í- LOC + hkik- REFL + ðótaðe] (trans.) make a friend of. • N person who is made into a friend. iiðótahkie káaãi akxai he's making a friend of him (lit., 'he is making him be a person made a friend of oneself') (RBn10-13).

••• Cf. ðótahkiðe. 

iihcé (variant of ðiihcé).

iihkíðe. V [reg.-iða, ii_hkíðe] [hkik- + REFL + íiðe] (intr.) come to one's senses, come to, regain consciousness. iihkíðe akxai he came to his senses (RBn10-2). • wake up, awaken (lit., 'see oneself'). íihkiða! màhkása akxa íihkiðe ðikáaãe hta akxai wake up! the coffee will make you wake up (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.150; 1/20/83/p4; RBn10-2). • (trans.) find for oneself, find one's own.

•• LFD 74: íhkiðe <i´-Ði-the> to be awake. iðáhkiðe <i-tha´-Ði-the> I am awake. íðahkiðe <i´-tha-Ði-the> you are awake. íhkiðe <i´-Ði-the> to find that which is lost. [For the inceptive meaning 'find what was lost, find anew', the expected LF form would be <i´ki-the> (Mod. Os. has plain k: see íikiðe with plain k).]  

íihkiðemàðì (variants: íihkimàì, íihkimâà). ADV [evidently contains hkik- RECIP, but is also used as transitive] visiting, on a visit (lit., 'going to see each other') (HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok). çîtoëì íhkimàì híðe, iiðáðe hta mìkçé ée ðí áape I will find it, said the boy who had come to visit (RBn19-05; CQ:okc). Smokey ìkçí íihkimai brée I'm going visiting to Smokey's (RBn19-05).

íihkihkiðe. V [reg.-iða?, íi_hkihkiðe?] [evidently contains two instances of hkik- RECIP, but is also used as transitive] (intr.) meet each other; (trans.) meet s.o. wasái akxa çómìhkasi íihkihkiðapé the bear met the coyote (RBn16-02, unconfirmed).

••• Cf. íikiðe. 

íihkimâà, íihkimàì (variants of íihkiðemàðì).

iihkó. N my/his/her grandmother (father's mother or mother's mother) (02/03/95/FH/pc); my husband's mother (my mother-in-law; used only by a woman addressing or referring to this relative) (DN-WHM; FH/09/25/01/okc). iihkó lôò grandmother thunder (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.59). iihkó apa okíhce achípe ska his grandmother, seeking her own, came (JOD, CQc).

•• RB: <í-ko> (RB note: paternal or maternal grandmother).

•• JOD (slip file): íko <ih´-§ku> his or her grandmother, including a mother's mother's sister [transcription contains an unusual mistake for JOD; expected form is iihkó (<iku´> in JOD's transcription); it is likely that his <h> here reflects length of the i, and it is possible that <x> under <k> is an error]; [Additional meanings given by JOD are:] mother's mother's brother's daughter, and any other ihuñ§ka of SELF's mother's father; a father's mother's sister, father's mother's brother's daughter, and any other ihúñ§ka (in her gens) of the father's father of SELF. íkoé <íh§kué> voc. masc.; íkoéi <íh§kué-i> voc. fem.; ikó <ih§kú> [my grandmother]. JOD (How Naq¢e-ca§pe Was Eaten by His Grandmother ln3): ikó <I§ku´> [expected form is ihkó <iku´>]. JOD (slip file): igó <i-§ku´> a grandmother, his or her grandmother.

•• LFD 74: ihkô <i-Ðo´> a man's mother-in-law, his wife's mother [in Mod. Os. 'a woman's mother-in law, her husband's mother'; not applied to a man's mother-in-law]. ihkó <i-Ðo´> grandmother.

••• KS ikkô his/her grandmother (RR).  

••• Cf. ðiihkó, ihkówa. 

iihkó àkóhta. NP our grandmother (02/03/95/FH/pc:prod orig).  

iihkó lôò. N grandmother lightning (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok, but more 'thunder'; BE2.79); grandmother thunder (FH). [For some speakers, lòò is only 'thunder' and does not include 'lightning'.]

•• RB: <í-ko lóæ> thunder.

íihkoáhkiha. N grandchild, grandchildren, descendants, those who follow (MREI; 02/03/95/FH/pc:uk; BE2.59, unconfirmed).

•• RB: <í-ko-ah-kí-hah>.

••• WI hakogíýa grandchild (KM); KS owákkihâhe succession of, one after another, descendants (RR).  

••• Cf. wihcóçpa.

iihkówa (variant of ihkówa).

iihóe, iihóo (variants of íihò).

iihô. N his/her mother, the mother, a mother (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). wahkôta iëîke iihô mother of God's son (Mary, mother of Jesus) (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). • his/her mother's older sister (his/her maternal aunt; more precise than English 'his/her aunt') (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). [Shortened version of iihôhtà.] • wife, in the expression [name of son] iihô. [E.g., if Sam's son is John, Sam may use the expression John iihô 'John's mother' in speaking to or about Sam's wife.]

•• LFD 77: inôhò <i-noæ'-hoæ> my mother.  

íihò (variants: iihôò, iihóo, iihóe). V [reg.-iða, íi_hò] (trans.) ask permission from s.o. for s.t., ask or request s.o. to do s.t. ànâhoa, áçi çcée çkôçta tà ask me if you want to go outside (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). Mary ðée hce iiðáhòò I asked Mary to go (MOJ; FH:hce).
