íihòhâàpa. N [iihô + hâàpa] Mother's Day. ðée akxa íihòhâàpa ókØà hta apai they're going to have something [an event] on Mother's Day.

iihôhtà. N his/her mother's older sister (more precise than English 'his/her maternal aunt') (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok).  

••• Cf. iihô.

iihôò (variant of íihò).

iihôëì. N his/her mother's younger sister (more precise than English 'his/her maternal aunt').  

íikaahtamà (variant: ákaahtami). N [í- LOC + kaahtáama] bell, large bell (e.g., the big bell rung before a dance), dinner bell, church bell (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod; 04/07/95/PM/pc:okt). iikaahtámà ðuuhkáamà ring the bell (01/07/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.8). íikaahtámà ðuuhkâàmà ring the bell (RBn10-12:JW; RBn14-033; FH). wíkiehciëì ci ákaahtamì ðuuhkáamà hta akxai hàðé they're going to ring the little church bell this evening (FH/06/26/01/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): íkatamà <i´-§ka-ta-maæ> [noun derived from] §katamaæ; a bell.

íkaahtamà hcéska nôpØì kçíðe, hkaamâ mâðì apá <i§katamaæ tséska nªuæ´p'iæ kcí¢ªe, kamaæ´ maæ´¢iæ apa´> the cow being made to wear a bell on the neck, it rings as she walks (under <ka´-maæ>).

•• LFD 71: íkahtamà <i´-ga-¾a-moæ> ringing sound as of metal: a bell.

••• KS mâàzettàmà bell (RR); QU dikáda ring a bell [by] pulling a rope (RR).  

íikiðe. V [reg.-iða, íi_kiðe] [ki- INCEPTIVE + íiðe] (trans.) find, discover or discern s.t. íiðakie? 

did you find it? (01/24/95/FH/pc:prod orig). íiki[ð]ape it is found; they found it (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok).  • [kik- SUU + íiðe] (trans.) find one's own relative or possession. iiðáki[ð]e I found it (01/24/95/FH/pc:prod orig). ohkúlà wii[ð]áki[ð]e màëíe I can't find my clothes (BE2.46; CQc). háatxàci ákahami ðé íiðakie? when did you find this [your own] coat? (RBn1-36). óolàke íiðakie? did you find your hat? (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok). ðiihkó akxa ðípà akxa, íiðikiðe kôða pátà your grandmother is calling you, as she wishes to find you. hkáwa ànâki[ð]ape we found our horses (RB).

íikiçcìka (variant: íikiçäìka). V [reg. ki-del., íi_(ki)çcìka] [kik- SUU + íiçcìka] (trans.) kiss or caress one's own. wéakiçcìka I caressed them, my children (2/1/813). íiwiçäìka I'm going to kiss you (RBn12-07). ëìkáëi wáaçäìka àðìkçé we [two] kissed our children (02/14/95/FH/pc; BE2.73).

íikitaðe V [ki- INCEP + iitáðe] be born again (i.e., have a recurring birth date). wahkôta iëîke íikitaðe Christmas (lit., 'God's son is born again').

iilána (variant of ílanà).

iináhi (variant of iinâhi).

iináëì (variant of iinâëì).

iinâ. N my mother (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod; 02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). ììnâ ðe htóoëu che àkØú wakáaãa mother, make them give those meat pies to me. iinâ akxa ëìkáëì hóolà íëoçi nàpe mother used to tell the children not to go fishing (FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). • my mother's sister (my maternal aunt, either younger or older than my mother; more precise than English 'my aunt') (BE2.5; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 77 (unconfirmed): inôhò <i-noæ´-hoæ> my mother (02/25/95/FH/pc:no, incorrect).  

••• Cf. iinâhtà, iinâëì. 

iinâhi (variant: iináhi), V [reg.-iða, ii_nâhi] (intr.) agree. íinahi akxai he agrees (RBn10-3; (FH/09/25/01/pc). záani ànâhipe we all agree (RBn10-3; FH:ok). • (trans.) agree with, be willing to (FH:01/05/01/pc). iiðánahiëi íhpahò I know you don't agree with me (RBn10-3).

• accept; approve of. iináhiëi akxai he doesn't accept it (RBn17-p03; RBn23-05). htanâkØakØô hta apai, kaðô hcí tóopa akxa iinâhiëi akxai they're going to play cards, but Charley [Indian name hcí tóopa] doesn't approve of it.

•• LFD 76: ínàhì <í-noæ-hiæ> to be willing. bre hta che iiðánàhì ha <bthe ¾a-te i-tha´noæ-hiæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: brée che iiðánàhi; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I am willing to go.

iinâhiëi (variant: iinâhìëi). V [iinâhi + aëí NEG] (trans.) disagree with, be unwilling to, object to. iiðánahìmaëí mìkçé àëì âðanakØòëíe I objected to it, but you didn't listen to me.

•• LFD 77: inàhì aëi <i-noæ-hiæ a-zhi>to loathe; to dislike.

iinâhtà. N [iinâ + htâà] my mother's older sister (more precise than English 'my aunt') (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok).  

•• Cf. iinâ.

iinâëì (variants: iináëì, iinâ). N [iinâ + -ëì 'little'] my mother's younger sister (more precise than English 'my aunt') (BE2.5; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). iinâëì akxa ðikôze hta akxái my aunt is going to teach you (03/16/95/FH/pc:prod; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.133).  

•• Cf. iinâ.  

iiníhka. N her husband.  

•• LFD 76: iníhka <i-ni´-Ða> her man, her husband (04/27/95/FH/pc).

íinòòhpaëi (variant: iinôòhpaëi). V, ADJ [reg., íinòò_hpaëi] [íinòòhpe + aëí NEG] (trans.) (be) reckless with, unafraid of, not careful of, wayward (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok).

íinòòhpe. V [reg., íinòò_hpe] (trans.) be careful with, be wary of, watch out for, have a care with regard to, be afraid of, be scared of. [3rd person pl. patient prefix wa- is not possible with 1st pl. agent in this verb; note that **ànânòòwahpe, **âwanòòhpe, and **wéeànòòhpe are ungrammatical.] wecØá iinôòðahpe? are you watching out for snakes? wécØa iinôòhpapái be careful of snakes; be afraid of snakes [pl. addressee] (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). íinòòhpapai, íe áhkihtôpapaði be careful with him/her, watch your talk [pl. addressee] (01/04/95/FH:pc; FH/11/19/01/pc:okc: ahkihtòpapaði). ànânòòhpe àkáðe we're afraid of them. wéenòòhpa ði! be careful of them [sg. addressee]! wéenòòhpaaëi apai they're not wary of them. íiwinòòhpe I'm afraid of you. • (intr.) be careful or wary, watch out, have a care, not be reckless. chípi tà íinòòhpapai íðaapi tà when they come be careful when you [pl.] speak (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). iinôòhpa ði be careful [sg. addressee] (01/04/95/FH:pc; 12/30/94/FH/pc:ok; BE2.1). íinòòhpapi be careful [pl. addressee] (LS; BE2.17). iinôòhpapái be careful [now and into the future; pl. addressee] (01/09/95/FH/pc). íinòòhpaaëí apai he's reckless.

••• Cf. nôòhpe. 

íipuukxa (variant of ípukxa).

íisa. N cane, walking stick, crutch (BE2.17; RBn1-MOJ/p42; 04/25/95/PM/pc:okc).

•• LFD 239: ísale <i´-ša-gthe> a cane. LFD 69: ísae <i´-ša-e> ridgepole (unconfirmed; 04/25/95/PM/pc:uk).

••• KS íisale cane, crutch (RR).

iiscéwai. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) mischievous (FH/06/28/01/pc). tówa apa iiscéwai apai that one, he's doing something wrong, he is into things (FH/06/28/01/pc). iiscéwai níe you're being mischievous, you're being awful (FH/06/28/01/pc).

•• LFD 70: ísie waðe <i´-ši-e wa-the> a knave; a tricky, deceitful person.

íise (variant of íisi).

iiséwaðe (variants: iiséwai, iisíwai, iisíwae, íisiwaðe). V, ADJ [reg.?, iiséwa_ðe?] (intr.) [íisi + wa- VAL + ðe CAU] (be) mean, hateful, disliked, detestible, contemptible, despicable, base, vile, infamous, spiteful (lit., 'cause folks to hate him/her') (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). çôke iiséwai wì açäîe you have a mean dog (BE2.33). iiséwai, ëeká akxa ânàkØòëi akxái the thing [that's] hateful is that my legs won't listen to me (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; HRE:ok). iiséwai! he's hateful! (RB). iiséwai! that's mean! (an admonishment to children) (BE2.64; RBn2MOJ/p12ff).

•• LFD 70: ísiwaðe <i´-ši-wa-the> contemptible; despicable; base; vile; infamous.

íisi (variant: íise). V [reg.-iða, íi_si] (trans.) hate, dislike, detest, abhor, despise. iiðási I don't like it (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). íiwisi I don't like you. íiðasi you don't like it. àànâðasi nìkçé you dislike me (RB: MREI 1-14-82). íisi akxai he doesn't like him. íisipe he didn't like it; he didn't like him. àànâsi apai he dislikes me. íisi akxai he doesn't like it (02/16/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 70: ísi <i´-ši> to dislike; to hate; to abhor; repugnance. iðási <i-tha´-ši> I hate. íðasi <i´-tha-ši> you hate. àðâsi pe <oæ-thoæ´-ši i> we hate. ísiwalì <i´-ši-wa-gthiæ> to detest; great contempt. iðásiwalì <i-tha´-ši-wa-gthiæ> I detest. íðasiwalì <i´-tha-ši-wagthiæ> you detest. àðâsiwalì pe <oæ-thoæ´-ši-wa-gthiæ i> we detest. LFD 190: wálìisi <wa´-gthiæi-ši> to detest; to despise; to hate. walì iðási <wa-gthiæ i-tha´-ši> I detest. walì íðasi <wa-gthiæ i´-tha-ši> you detest. walì àðâsi pe <wa-gthiæ oæ-thoæ´-ši i> [expected Mod. Os. form: walì ànâsipe] we detest.

íisiwaðe, iisíwae, iisíwai (variants of iiséwaðe).

íista (variant: íiçta). V [reg.-iða?, íi_sta?] (trans.) bless with. mîì íista bless [him/her/it] with the sun [imperative] (02/27/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.147).  

••• Cf. íiçtope.

íistahkiðe (variants: íistahkie, íiçtahkie, íiçtahki). V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) use (e.g., cedar smoke or words of a prayer) to bless oneself. [At meals after peyote meetings, birthday dinners, etc., the one praying would say çáake paahápi 'raise your hands' before praying to capture the good of the prayer and after praying would say íistahkiepi 'bless yourselves with it', whereupon the supplicants pass that hand or those hands over their body lightly, including mind and heart. The same procedure was used in the cedar smoking ceremony (04/07/95/PM).] íistahkiepi, íiçtahkiepi bless yourselves with it (01/25/95/FH/pc:okc:ç [s ~ ç variation]). íistahkiapai use it on yourselves (to bless yourselves). kaakônaa, çáake paahâpi, iíçtahkíapai that's all, raise your hand, use it on yourselves (ending for a prayer). Johna akxa ëìkáëì waatá apa íistahkiepi John is praying for the children and the children are asking God for a blessing (lit., '. . . and they are blessing themselves with it'). hpéece íiçtahkipa use the fire to bless yourselves (PM:04/07/95 pc).  

iistó (variant: îçtòwà [LS]). N elbow (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod; 04/07/95/LS/pc:okc).

•• LFD 70: istóhi <i-štu´-hi> elbow.

••• KS áastohü elbow (RR); QU istóhi elbow (RR).

iiçcéwai (variants: iiçcéwa, iiçcé, iiçäéwai). V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) ashamed, feel ashamed (04/20/95/LS/pc). iiçäé mìkçé I'm ashamed (04/20/95/LS/pc). iiçäéwa àðîhe I'm ashamed. iiçäéwai ðaìçe you're shameful (9/17/94/FH/pc). iiçcéwai ðé you should be ashamed (lit., 'that makes one feel ashamed') (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77; CQc). çíi apa iiçcéwai apa he's ashamed of himself (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

•• LFD 78: íçce waðe <i´shtse wa-the> shameful.

••• QU íçte be ashamed (RR).

íiçcewai (variants: íiçäewa, íiçcewa, íçcewa; [Hominy dialect] íiçäewai, iiçäéwai). V, ADJ [reg.iða, íi_çcewai (often uninfl.)] (intr.) dress up in one's best attire, get dolled up or dressed up; (be) dolled up or dressed up (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). [Usually uninflected when used with adjectival meaning ('be dressed up').] iiðáçäewa mìkçé I'm all dressed up (RBn12-12).

iiðáçcewa mìkçé, íiçcewa mìkçé I'm all dressed up (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.34). wáli íiçäewai ðaìçé you are really all dressed up (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc; 9/4/94/FH/p.c.; FH/06/28/01/pc). háakòta íiçcewai ðàìçé? why are you dressed up? íiçäewa akxa she's making herself pretty, she's dolled up (04/25/95/PM/pc). íiçcewa apai they're all dressed up (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

íiçcìka. V [reg.-iða, íi_çcìka] (trans.) kiss, caress (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. íikiçcìka. 

íiçäewa, íiçäewai (variants of íiçcewai).

iiçäéwai (variant of iiçcéwai '(be) ashamed'). iiçtá (variant of ììçtá). íiçta (variant of íista). iiçtáa cØóka (variant of ììçtáhaa cØóka).

iiçtábri (variant of ììçtábri).

iiçtáðe ahkíliitoëe. VP [reg.?, iiçtáðe a_hkíliitoëe?] [presumably hkik- RECIP + ðu-/ði- INSTR + tóëe] (intr.) wink at each other, blink at each other (LS). iiçtáðe ahkíliitóëe they are winking at each other (RBn2-MOJ/p11; 05/01/95/LS/pc:ma).

iiçtáðe ðiitóëe (variant: iiçtáði ðiitóëe). VP [sync., iiçtáðe _ðiitóëe] (intr.) wink or blink the eyes (lit., 'mash the eyelid[s]') (05/01/95/LS/pc). iiçtáðe ðiitóëe akxái he/she is winking (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.159). • (trans.) wink at, blink the eyes at. iiçtáðe àðíitoëe akxai he's winking at me.

•• LFD 77: ìçtá ðitoëe <iæ-shta´ thi-do-zhe> to wink; to nictitate. ìçtá ebritoëe <iæ-shta´ e-bthi-do-zhe> I winked at her.

iiçtáhaa cØóka (variant of ììçtáhaa cØóka).

iiçtáhii (variant of ììçtáhìì).

íiçtahki, íiçtahkie (variants of íistahkiðe).

iiçtáxì (variant of ììçtáxì).

íiçtà. V [reg.-iða, íi_çtà] (trans.) agree with s.t. Jacka háakò eekíe ðe tà iiðáçtà I agree with what

Jack says (FH/09/25/01/pc). Jacka háakò ékie che iiðáçtà I agree with what Jack said (FH/09/25/01/pc). háakò iðáe tà Jack akxa íiçtà akxai Jack agrees with what I said (FH/11/18/01/pc). • (intr.) agree. záani íiçtàpe they all agreed (FH/09/25/01/pc).

íiçtope (variant: íçtope). V [reg.-iða?, íi_çtope?] (trans.) bless with, use to bless (PM). hpéece ðé íiçtope use this fire to bless yourselves/yourself (said to person[s] standing in the altar [cement floor by the fire] in a Native American Church meeting) (04/07/95/PM/pc:okc; JS:uk).

•• RB: <péh-tseh théh í-shto-peh>.  

••• Cf. ðistópe, íista. 

íiçupe. N men's dance belt worn outside the blanket to hold it up (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod; RBn1403/LH).

iitáðape ékitxà (variants: iitáipi ékikxà, iitáipi ékxà, iitáekietxà). VP [iitáðe + api + ðe DECL + ékitxà] (intr.) have a birthday (lit., 'again be the time that one is born'). iitáipi ékikxà; íiðitáðape ékitxà it's your birthday (either expression may be used for 'happy birthday') (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod). iitáðape ékitxà akxái it's his birthday (BE2.8). iitáipi ékikxà akxai he's got a birthday (lit., 'he is characterized by a birthday') (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod).

iitáðe (variants: íitaðe, iitáe, iitái). V [reg.-iða, ii_táðe] (trans.) give birth to. eeçkí iiðátai na [iiðáta(ð)e na] I gave birth to him, too (RBn HW7). weeátaðe I gave birth to them. iitáðape she gave birth to him/her; he/she was born. çímiëìka iitáaðe I gave birth to a girl (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok). ànâta[ð]ape she gave birth to me; I was born. íiðita[ð]a pe she gave birth to you; you were born. hpáaëì wì íita[ð]ape she had a baby. íitaðaðe you gave birth to a child (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok). hâàpa íiðitaðape wéewinai happy birthday (lit., 'I'm grateful for you being born today') (FH). wéeana akxàhé íiðitáipe ska I'm glad you were born; happy birthday! (lit., 'I'm standing here grateful as it seems that this is the day you were born') (9/13/94/FH/470). íiðitaepe, wéeànà àkai, wisôeëì we wish you a happy birthday, younger brother [of a woman] (this phrase was used to decorate a cake) (FH). • (intr.) give birth.

íitaaðe I gave birth (FH).

•• LFD 70: ítaðe <i´-da-the> to bear a child; to give birth to an offspring. ítaaðe he <i´da-a-the he> I gave birth to a child. ítaðaðe he <i´-da-tha-the he> you gave birth to a child. LFD 131: çímiëìka itaaðe he <shi´-mi-zhiæ-ga i-da-a-the he> I gave birth to a girl.

••• KS íidaye bear a child, have a baby (RR).

••• Cf. wasápe iitáipi, wéetaðe. 

iitáekietxà, iitáipi ékikxà, iitáipi ékxà (variants of iitáðape ékitxà).

iitái (variant of iitáðe).

iiwákØo (variant of iwákØo).

íixa. V [reg.-iða, íi_xa] (intr.) laugh. íixa leléze laugh big; [be] laughing a lot (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). íixa léleze [be] laughing over and over (03/22/95/FH/pc). íixa íkaski he's running out of breath from laughing (FH). íixa akxa she's laughing (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). nôò apa eeçkítà íixa apa the grownups laughed too (lit., 'the grownups, they too, laughed') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). íixa ðìká! don't laugh! (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). • (trans.) laugh at. wisôeëì iiðáxa nái I always laugh at my little brother (RB; MREI/01/11/83). íiðixa akxa he's laughing at you (BE2.76; 01/11/95/FH/pc:x). ànâxa akxai she's laughing at me (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). íiwixa mìkçé I'm laughing at you. ànâðaxa nìkçé? are you laughing at me? (MREI).

•• LFD 81: íxa <i´-xa> to laugh; to titter. iðáxa <i-tha´-xa> I laugh. íðaxa <i´-tha-xa> you laugh. íxa íkaski <i´-xa i-ga-ški> a hearty laugh; a laugh that makes the sides ache.

íixaéewaðe (variant: íixaéewai). V [reg., íixaéewa_ðe] [íixa + ée 'say' (?) + wa- VAL + ðe CAU]

(intr.) be funny or laughable, cause folks to laugh at s.o. else's expense. (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok; 02/13/95/FH/pc:okc). • N laughing stock. íixaéewaðae waçkaaãé you made us laughable, you made a joke out of us (lit., 'you caused folks to laugh and you did it to us') (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 81: íixaewaðe <i´-xa-e-wa-the> humorous; ludicrous. íxaewaða pi a níhkaçika <i´-xa-e-wa-tha bi a ni´-Ða-shi-ga> [expected Mod. Os. form: níhka íixaéewaðape] he is very humorous.

íixaëì. V [reg., íi_xaëì] [íixa + -ëì 'little'] (intr.) snicker (lit., 'laugh a little'). íixaëì akxai they're snickering (BE2.124; 03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok). • N smile, grin. • ADV with a grin, grinningly.

íixaëì tôpe to look at with a grin. íixaëì àtôìpe akxai he's grinning at me (RBn12-06).

•• LFD 81: íxa ëìka <i´-xa zhiæ-ga> a grin; a smile.

iizíke. V [uninfl.] (intr.) be or become embarrassed by making mistakes in front of a crowd (RBn12-12). iizíke àçkáaãe you shamed my face, you embarrassed me (lit., 'you caused me to be embarrassed'). iizíke apai they're embarrassed (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). • (intr.?) be embarrassing. iizíki akxai it's embarrassing (RBn12-12).

íizizike (variant of ízizike).

iiëîke (variant of iëîke).

íiëoçi (variant of íëoçi).

íkaaãe. V [sync. k>p, í_kaaãe] (trans.) make out of. ëâàxe íkaaãe akxai íiðaðe? did you see the thing he made out of wood? did you see the thing he made with wood? (lit., 'he was making it with wood, did you see it?'). kaalíëe wéçkaaãe nae you used to make them with flint.

íkaahòòpa (see íkòpa).

íkaase. V [reg. kaa-ret. or kaa-del., í_(kaa)se] (trans.) cut with, sever or chop by striking with. mâhispe íkaase cut it with the axe (RBn10-16).

íkahci (variant: íkiahci). N (05/02/95/LS/pc:okc; BE2.142). toilet paper (RB, unconfirmed;

03/23/95/FH/pc:uk). íkahci wî aðîli bring some toilet paper back (RBn12-06, unconfirmed).

•• JOD (slip file): kahcé or kaché <§ka-tsªe´> skim off grease from the surface of water in a kettle.

•• LFD 71: íkahce <i´-ga-¾se> an implement for skimming grease from food that is cooking.

••• KS gaccé to skim a liquid, skim grease (RR).

íkaske (variant: íkaski). V, ADJ [conjug. unknown] (intr.) (be) out of breath. íkaski àhé I'm out of breath. íkaski bríe I'm out of breath (FH). íkaske nîe he's out of breath, choking, as when having a heart attack (FH). • V (trans.) run out of breath from, become breathless from, choke from (some activity). nâàke íkaske he's out of breath from running (FH). íixa íkaski she is running out of breath from laughing (02/14/95/FH/pc). çómìhkasi mààçóçoce íkaski the coyote was choking in [from] the dust (RBn17-p05, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 81: íxa íkaski <i´-xa i-ga-ški> a hearty laugh; a laugh that makes the sides ache.

íkaskike. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) smother with smoke or dust (RBn23-14, unconfirmed).

íkiahci (variant of íkahci).

íkiðiiçtà. V, ADJ [uninfl.] [ki- INCEPTIVE + íðiiçtà] (intr.) (be) ready. íkiðiiçtà àtxàhé I'm ready (RBn14-03, unconfirmed).

íkie. V [reg.-iða, í_kie] [presumably ki- DAT + íe] (trans.) talk for or against s.o., speak positively or negatively of s.o., take sides with respect to s.o. [An expected 3rd person form (not actually attested) would be íkie akxa 'he's talking against s.o.'] íðikía apái they're talking against you (LS:okc; FH:okc).

íkiha. ADV always, repeatedly. Preston apa oðíhta íkiiha íihpiëi apai Preston's car is always going bad on him (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod orig).

•• JOD (Wasápeëìka letter p26 ln4): ókaçe ðìké ðaìçé ðáha wikínakØò àðâkiha hkôbra <ú§kacé ¢iñ§ke´ ¢á¢iæcé u¢áha wi§kínak'ªuæ aæ¢añ´§kiha kªuæ§p¢au´> I always want to hear that you are fine. [The form àðâkiha in this example (àðâkiha hkôbra 'I always want') suggests that íkiha inflects (stat., í_kiha). No such inflected examples were found in Mod. Os.]  •• LFD 71: íkiha <i´-gi-ha> always; ever; often; frequent; incessant. LFD 56: lôðì ikiha <gthoæ´-thiæ i-gi-ha> habitual drunkard; a sot.

íkihtòpe (variant: íkihtòe). V [reg.-iða or sync. fortisizing stop stem, í_kihtòpe or í_kih(_)tòpe?]

[presumably í- LOC + kihtôpe] (trans.) visit a relative or one's own (family). wíikihtòe achíe I have come to see you [expected Mod. Os. form: íwikihtóe achíe] (t#14-b-p3; 05/02/95/LS/pc:ok).

íkikaaãe. V [sync. k>p, íki_kaaãe] [ki- DAT + íkaaãe] (trans.) make for s.o., cause to be for s.o. íe waska íkihpáaãe hkôbra I want to interpret for you (RB).

íkinaaëi. V [reg.-iða, ki-ret., í_kinaaëi] [í- LOC + ki- DAT + nààëî] (trans.) depend on, count on, rely on (lit., 'stand with another') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; CQ:okc). íwikinaaëi ìké hta akxa I won't depend on you. iðákinaaëi hta akxa you can depend on it (RBn12-06).

íkiçike. V [reg.-iða, ki-ret., í_kiçike] [presumably ki- DAT + an unattested stem íçike] (trans.) be lonesome for s.o. (3-10-83-D). iðákiçike mìkçé I'm lonesome for him (3-10-83-D). íðakiçike nìkçé you're lonesome for him (3-10-83-D). ànâkiçike àðìkçe we're lonesome for him (3-1083-D). weákiçike mìkçé [from wa-i-ðá-kiçike] I'm lonesome for them (3-10-83-D).

wéðakiçike nìkçe you're lonesome for them (3-10-83-D). íwikiçíke mìkçe I'm lonesome for you (3-10-83-D). ànâkisike apai they're lonesome for me (3-10-83-D).

íkòpa. N [probably í- LOC + ka- INSTR + hâàpa]  glass (lit., 'whereby day strikes').  

•• RB: <í-koæ-pah> glass for drinking (BE2.55, unconfirmed; 01/31/95/FH/pc:uk; 05/01/95/LS/pc:uk). 

••• KS ogáhòba window, window glass, glass generally (RR), óoëü kØôyòba lamp, a glass (JOD, RR), kØôyòba transparent? (JOD [uncertain], RR).

••• Cf. okáhàpa, okáhòpa. 

íkòska (variant: íkòske). ADJ, V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) resemble (visually), (be) equal or similar in appearance to, look like (e.g., s.t. carved to resemble another thing). íkòske káaãi akxai he's making it like that (FH:prod). Mary akxa iihô íkòske Mary looks just like her mother (FH:4/24/96/tape:prod). wacúe skue màçäîka íkòske káaãa make the cake like a rabbit (FH:4/24/96/tape:prod). níhkaçi íkòske scarecrow (FH).

•• LFD 53 (unconfirmed): kòzé hkikò <goæ-še´ Ði-goæ>alike; resembling.

••• Cf. ékò, kòzékò. 

íkòskahkíðe. V [reg., íkòska_hkíðe] [íkòska + hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] (trans.) imitate, act like, make oneself equal to. ììçtáxì íkòskahkíe apai he's making himself equal to that white man.

íkòske (variant of íkòska).

íkuspe. V [reg.-iða?, í_kuspe?] (intr.) sign with a thumbprint, make a thumbprint on a document in lieu of a signature (HRE/12/29/01/pc, unconfirmed). íkuspa make your print there (HRE/12/29/01/pc).

íkØo. N belch, burp. íkØo akxa it's a belch; it's a burp (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

••• Cf. wawékØo.

íkØuce (variants: ikØúci, íkØue). V [reg.-iða, í_kØuce] (trans.) try to, strive to, risk, test, taste, try on, attempt. pçí iðákØuce hta mìkçé I'm going to try to go there (RBn23-21). màçcî íðakØuce àëì ðaxíða you tried to walk but you fell down (PM). nààëî íkØucapé he tried to get up (RB: Coyote fable). waëáëeíe anâkØuce we're trying to talk Osage. íkØüta! try! (Osage First Book). íkØuca try it on (RBn10-16). íkØuca! try it! (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok;108/FH/170). màðî íkØuca try to walk (PM). • study. hôòpaðe waëáëe ëî toa ohkíeche ëóàhkile àkái, waëáëeíe íkØuce àkáli today a bunch of Osage young people, we're gathered together, we've come back to study Osage (RBn10-13; FH/11/19/01/pc:okc). • (intr.) try, make an effort, do one's best, try one's best, make one's best effort (RBn22-20; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). iðákØuce hta mìkçe I'm going to try (04/03/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.145). iðákØue ço àhé waëáëeíe íhpahò hta akxai I'm going to keep on [trying] until I learn the Osage language [note reduction of ce to e] (RBn1010:JW). kóoci waëáëe apa ðée ékiòpé àëi ðekôòci ðìkápi wihtáeëi akxa íkØuci akxai long ago

Osages used to do that, but now they are gone and sister is trying her best (gloss by CQ; PM/7/7/94). záani íkØucapí áape they all did their best (RBn19-04). • N class, practice, practice session, workshop. waëáëeíe íkØuca Osage language class [unexpected form ending in -a] (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-36).

•• LFD 74: ikØuche, ikØuhce? <i-Ð'u-tse> [expected Mod. Os. form: íkØuce] to risk.

iðáhkuche <i-tha´-Ðu-tse> I risk. íkØuche <i´-Ð'u-tse> to test the taste.

••• QU ikkíhte to scramble for something (RR).

••• Cf. íkØuce.

ílanà (variants: ílana, iilána). V [reg.-iða, í_lanà] (intr.) damage or hurt one's reputation or standing by doing s.t. inappropriate, make a mistake or commit an error that brings attention to oneself (e.g., dropping s.t. at a dance, thereby causing a commotion), goof, goof up, use bad judgment (e.g., choosing to confide s.t. private to a gossipy person). iðálanai I made a mistake (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). íðalanai you made a mistake (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). íðalanà you made a mistake. ílanàpe someone made a mistake (and they hurt somebody) (BE2.88; RBn1-51). ànâlanàpé we made a mistake/had an accident (RB notes). • be in disgrace because of having made a mistake. ílanàpi che kíhòòëipe he's unhappy because he is in disgrace (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 255: ílanò <i´-gtha-noæ> disgrace. LFD 79: íðalanà hta khì to <i´-tha-gtha-noæ ¾a kiæ do> [expected Mod. Os. form: íðalanà hta nikçé 'you will damage your standing'] you will hurt yourself.  

ilánàðìké. V, ADJ [reg.-iða, i_lánàðìké] [ílanà + ðìké] (be) innocent, having made no mistakes or blunders to disgrace oneself.

•• LFD 72: ílanà ðìke <i´-gtha-noæ thiæ-ge> guiltless; blameless; innocence.

ilánàhkistó. N [ílanà + hkiistó] court (lit., 'meeting or assemblage for mistakes or offenses').

•• LFD 72: ilanàhkisto <i-gtha-noæ-Ði-štu> court.

ílanàwakíçupe. N [ílanà + wakíçupe] fine, penalty (lit., 'pay folks for a mistake').

•• LFD 72: ílanà wakiçipe <i´-gtha-noæ wa-gi-shi-be> a fine; the payment of money for some offense.

íli. N phlegm, saliva (RBn HW12; RBn10-15). íli ðaakØí! spit out the phlegm! (RBn HW12).

•• LFD 305: hóxpe lili <ho´-xpe-xthi-xthi> phlegm.

íliðáakØi (variant of íluekØí).

ilôahpa iihô (variant of ilôòhpa iihô).

ilôàhpa (variant of ilôòhpa).

ilôeëi (variants: ilôeëì, ilôeëe). N cat, puma (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; FH/pc). ðé ilôeëì akxa Jane ihtápe this is Jane's cat (BE2.17; RBn12-03p2).

•• LFD 75: ìlôka <iæ-gthoæ´-ga> puma; also the name given to the domesticated cat when it was first introduced.

ilôeëi iiséwai. N hellcat (RBn22-08).

••• Cf. iiséwaðe. 

ilôeëì (variant of ilôeëi).

ilôãe. V [reg.-iða, i_lôãe] [kik- SUU + íðòãe] (intr.) ask or inquire concerning one's own people or things (04/19/95/FH/pc:ma; WF/12/30/01:ã). • N devil, Satan, ghost, spirit (01/20/95/FH/pc:prod orig; BE2.30; RBn2-MOJ/p3).

•• JOD (slip file): ilôãe <i-k-¢uæ´-xe> to ask a question about his or her own.

•• LFD 72: ílòãe <i´-gthoæ-xe> to make inquiry concerning a relative or some personal belonging. iðálòãe <i-tha´-gthoæ-xe> I made an inquiry about a relative. íðalòãe <i´-thagthoæ-xe> you made an inquiry about a relative. àðâlòãa pe <oæ-thoæ´-gthoæ-xa i> we made an inquiry about relatives. LFD 272: wanâãe ìlôãe <wa-noæ´-xe iæ-gthoæ´-xe> ghost.

ilôò (variant of ilôòhtà).

ilôòhpa (variants: ilôìhpa, ilôàhpa). N first son in any clan (probably a baby name)

(FH/11/17/01/pc). [Kinship terms with -hpa may be baby names; at any rate their use beyond 1st and 2nd person (e.g., for 'my first son' and 'your first son') seems limited.] ilôìhpa akxa htâwà ki aðáape Sonny went to town (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.56–57). ëìkáëì nakxâçe wéewina akxâhe, ilôìhpa waachí çtôpape I want to thank you children for watching my son dance.

••• KS ilóappa first son (RR); PO çéppahàga eldest child (male or female) (KDS).  

••• Cf. ilôòhtà.

ilôòhpa iðáce. N husband (lit., 'eldest son's father'), my/your/her husband (vocative and referent) (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn2-MOJ/p5b).  

ilôòhpa iihô (variant: ilôahpa iihô). N wife (lit., 'eldest son's mother') (RBn2-MOJ/p5b; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc), my/your/his wife (vocative and referent).  

ilôòhtà (variants: ilôò, ìlôò). N eldest son (RBn2-MOJ/p9; CQ:ok; 03/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 75: ìlô <iæ-gthoæ´> special kinship term for the first son.  

••• Cf. htâà, ilôòhpa. 

ilôòka. N wildcat (RBn1-24; DN-WHM; FH/10/09/01/pc:uk).

•• LFD 75: ìlôka <iæ-gthoæ´-ga> puma; also the name given to the domesticated cat when it was first introduced by the early settlers.

••• Cf. ilôeëi.

ilôòçka (variant: îlòòçka). N ilôòçka dances (the war dances or ceremonial dances of the Osages) (RBn1-25; HRE/12/29/01/pc). [By folk etymology, 'playground of the eldest son' (cf. ilôòhpa 'eldest son', çkáce 'play').]

•• RB: <i-lóæ-shkah> (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc).

•• LFD 76: îloçka <iæ´-gthu-shka> the name of a dance which originated with the Omaha and Ponca (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok).  

ilôòçka záani (variant: ilôòçka zaaní). NP drumkeeper and committee (RB). ilôòçka záani, íe tóa ékipçe hta àkxâhe the drumkeeper and all you committeemen, I am going to say a few words (RB).  

íluekØí (variant: íliðáakØi). N spittoon. íluekØi húða hand me the spittoon (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125).

•• RB: <í-lu-eh-k’í>.

•• LFD 34: ðakØí <tha-k'i´> spit.

••• Cf. ðaakØî, íli. 

ímahtaha (variant of ímàhtaha).

ímà. INTERR/INDEF ADJ, INTERR/INDEF PRON which. ímà John íiðe? which of these did John see? (MSB). • other. [Sometimes used with two nouns to imply a choice between alternatives, much like English 'or'; see ímàðe.]  

•• LFD 74: ímà <i´-moæ> the other one (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. hówa. 

ímàche. PRON, ADJ [ímà + che POSIT] next (one) (RBn10-8:JW, unconfirmed; FH/11/17/01/pc:uk). • other (one).

••• Cf. âmà.

ímàðe. PRON, ADJ one or the other. [Often used to convey the equivalent of English 'or'.] ímàðe hòbrîke watkxâ hpáaãe hta mìkçé I'll fix either beans or squash (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. ímàkçe.

ímàhtaha (variant: ímahtaha). ADV, N the other way (RBn19-02). ímahtaha màðî go the other way (RBn19-02)

••• Cf. émàhtaëíha. 

ímàkçe. ADJ [ímà + kçe POSIT] other.

•• LFD 192: wahóhtàðe ímàkçe <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the i-moæ-kshe> [expected Mod. Os. form:

wahóohtà ímàkçe 'the other (lying or long) gun'] the other of the two guns  (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. amâ. 

ínihkaçie (variant: nihkáçi). V [reg., í_nihkaçie] (intr.) become a person, live as a person (lit., 'by which means one becomes a person'). • N clan (lit., 'folks you were born with') (01/09/95/FH/pc:ma). táata iðáníhkaçi nîe? what clan are you? (01/09/95/FH/pc:ma; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.19).

••• KS: níkkaçìña person, people, men, gens, or clan (RR)

íniiðaahtà. N [í- LOC + níi + ðaahtâ] dipper, ladle (lit., 'with which to drink water').

•• JOD (slip file): ëâ íniiðáhtà <§caæ i´-ni-i-¢a´-taæ> "wood for drinking water," a wooden cup or dipper.

••• Cf. níiðaahtà.

íopØàðà. N steam.

•• LFD 81: iópØoðà <i-u´-p'u-thoæ> vapor issuing from the mouth (e.g., of a deer or any other animal) (04/07/95/PM/pc:okc).

••• Cf. opØâða. 

ípaase. V [sync., fortisizing stop stem, í_paase] [í- LOC + paasé] (trans.) cut (s.t.) with (s.t. else) by pushing down on the item being cut (02/13/95-/FH/pc; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). íhpaase I cut it with it. íçpaase you cut it with it. ànâpaase we cut it with it. mâàhì ípaasa cut it with a knife (RBn22-03; CQc).

•• LFD 68: ípase <i´-ba-še> to cut with a knife. ['With a knife' in glosses of this and the other LFD forms is probably not strictly part of the meaning of the Osage term (FH).] ihpase <i-¼a-še> I cut with a knife. íçpase <i´-shpa-še> you cut with a knife. àðâpasa pe <oætho-æ´-ba-ša i> we cut with a knife.

ípaaçàha. N turnaround place, U-turn, return point, turn in the road (lit., 'by which to make a turn'). ípaaçàha çíe, ókaçeìke ðalíe ðe, awáata mìkçé I pray for you to have a safe trip (lit., 'you go to the turnaround, you return safely, I'm praying').

•• LFD 348: opáçò <u-ba´-shoæ> turn (in a road).  

ípaaxce. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, í_paaxce] [í- 'with' + paaxcé] (trans.) tie down using, tie down with, bind, handcuff, or manacle using, tie into a bundle or bundles using. wéðì íhpaaxce I tied it [down] using rope. wéðì íçpaaxce you tied it [down] using rope. wéðì ànâxpaacape we tied it [down] using rope (FH).

•• LFD 69: ípaxce <i´-ba-xtse> to tie with a cord [expected Mod. Os. gloss 'to tie with', no mention of 'cord']. wéðì ëìka íhpaxce ha <we´-thiæ zhiæ-ga i´-¼a-xtse ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I tied it with a cord. wéðì ëìka içpaxce ha <we´-thiæ zhiæ-ga ishpa-xtse ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you tied it with a cord. wéðì ëìka àðà paxca pe <we´-thiæ zhiæ-ga oæ-thoæ ba-xtsa i> we tied it with a cord.  

ípahò (variant: ípaho). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, í_pahò] (trans.) know (e.g., a fact, the answer to a question). ðíoxta íhpahò mìkçé I know you love him/her. iiðánàhíëi íhpahò I know you don't agree with me (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). íhpahò màëí I don't know. íçpahò you know. íçpahòëi you don't know. ànâpahòpe we know that (RBn10-15). • understand. waëáëe íçpahò? do you understand Osage? [contrasts with waëáëi çpíiëô? 'do you know how to talk Osage?'] (RBn1-MOJ/p58). • know as a person, be acquainted with, recognize, know s.o. as

(being a certain way or a certain type of person). waëáëe huuwáli íhpahò I know a lot of

Osages (RBn10-2). wíihpahò I know you [unexpected variant of iwíhpahò]

(02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). ànâçpahò you know me (RBn10-18). àðâçpahô [variant of ànâçpahò]

you know me  (FH). wéçpahò you know them (MSB 5-12-83). omáìhka tóe çímiëì íçpahò? have you known this girl for some years? (RBn; MREI/01/11/93). níhkaçika íçpahò? do you know that man? (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.74). íçpahòpe [expected Mod. Os. form:

wéçpahòpe] you [pl.] know them; you [pl.] know him (MSB 5-12-83). ànâpahò akxai he knows me (RBnotes). íðipahò he knows you. ðíipahò [unexpected variant of íðipahò] he knows you. wépahòpe they know us (MSB 5-12-83). weâpaho a[ð]ìkçe we [two] know them (MSB 2-24-83). ànâpahò àðîkçe we [two] know him (RBnotes). ànâpahòpe we know him, we know them (MSB 2-12-83). weâpahòpe we know them (MSB 5-12-83). • (trans.) guess. àëì howáìki súhkahtâà mîìka hcí káaãe che ípahòëi akxa áape but they could not guess where turkey hen made her nest (RBn19-05; 02/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 69: ípahò <i´-ba-hoæ> to know. íhpahò <i´-¼a-hoæ> I know. íçpahò <i´-shpahoæ> you know. àðâpahò pe <oæ-thoæ´-ba-hoæ i> we know. íhpahò màëi <i´-¼a-hoæ moæzhi> I do not know. íçpahò aëi <i´-shpa-hoæ a-zhi> you do not know. àðâpahò paëi pe <oæ-thoæ´-ba-hoæ ba-zhi i> we do not know.

ípasà. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) turn over. wacúe che ípasà [ð]ì turn that bread over (FH).

••• Cf. ípaaçàha. 

ípehi, ípehì (variants of îpehi).

ípihì oðíçi. N pillowcase (RBn1-54).

••• QU ípahì pillow (RR).

••• Cf. îpehi. 

ípçe. V [reg.-iða, í_pçe] (intr.) pass by, come by, go by, go past (FH:prod). íðapçe ìhtáci ðakØéwai when you pass by, father, remember [i.e., be kind to] us (FH/09/11/01/pc).

áðahtaha íðapçe [on the other side] you passed right by (FH:4/18/96/tape:prod). màðî çò apa kîìkììeëì toa kîì ípçape while they were walking some butterflies came flying by (RBn15-01). áðahtaha ípçape àëi owáhkiapaëíe they went right past us [on the other side] but didn't speak to us (RB-MSB 4/7/83; FH:4/18/96/tape:okc).  

••• Cf. ápçe. 

ípukxa (variants: ípuutkxa, íipuukxa). V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) wipe with, dry with (by wiping). haaská ípuutkxa wipe it with the shirt (BE2.159; FH:4/24/96/prod).

••• Cf. htanâkØa ípukxa. 

ípuze. V [stat., í_puze] (trans.) be thirsty for. [Expected Mod. Os. verb forms: íðipuze 'you are thirsty', ípuze 'she is thirsty', wépuze 'we are thirsty'.] níi òðápuzé [expected Mod. Os. form: níi àðâpuze or níi ànâpuze] I'm thirsty (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.139). níi ànâpuze I'm thirsty (HH). ðíe, nîe ànåpuze? are you thirsty [for water]? (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

•• LFD 69: ípize <i´-bi-še> thirsty. àðàpize <oæ-thoæ-bi-še> I am thirsty. íðipize <i´thi-bi-še>you are thirsty. weápizape <we-a´-bi-ša i> we are thirsty.

isôeëì (variant: isôaëì). N her younger brother (more precise than English 'her brother').  

isôka. N his younger brother (more precise than English 'his brother'). Mogri akxa isôka hcí íhta ci aðáape Mogri went to his brother's house.

•• LFD 70: isôka <i-šoæ´-ga> a younger brother.  

íçcewa (variant of íiçcewai).

içíkxà. N her husband's sister, her husband's brother's wife, her brother's wife (more precise than English 'her sister-in-law'). Mary içíkxà Mary's sister-in-law (BE2.122; FH/pc).

•• RB: <shi-kxáhæ>.

•• LFD 78: içíkxà <i-shi´-koæ> a woman's sister-in-law; her brother's wife or her husband's sister. LFD 329: sister-in-law (a woman's).  

••• Cf. çíkxà. 

içíkØe. N her sister's husband, her husband's brother, or her husband's sister's husband (more precise than English 'her brother-in-law') (BE2.12; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod orig).

•• LFD 78: içíkØe <i-shi´-k'e> a woman's brother-in-law; her sister's husband or her husband's brother.  

íçpaðò (variants: íçpaðo, îçpaðò). ADJ Spanish, Mexican, French (2/24/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.87). •

N Spaniard, any native Spanish-speaking person (especially a Mexican), French person;

Spanish language, French language. [Borrowed from Spanish español.]

íçtope (variant of íiçtope).

íçtòka. ADV right, on the right, rightward, to the right (RBn23-07, unconfirmed). íçtòka ci ha on the right, rightward, to the right (RBn23-07, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 112: nôpe istoke che <noæ´-be i-sdo-ge tse> the right hand.

ítaasuhu. N [í- LOC + taasúhu] sweat lodge (lit., 'cleanse with heat').

•• LFD 70 (unconfirmed): ítasihi <i´-da-ši-hi> sweat lodge.

íto. INTERJ expressing surprise (said to be a woman's exclamation).

iwákØo (variant: iiwákØo). N his wife (FH: t#128). çée nàhtâhtà wéàðuwì hta àkatxâ, níhka iiwákØo ékiepe we're going to sell that donkey, the man's wife said (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; FH/10/09/01/pc:ii).  

íwakØóëì. N his/her mother-in-law.  

íwehkilì V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) clothe oneself with, dress in. hôòpa ðé wéenà akxai ðe níhkaçi tóa áðixòpape, hpáðì wéhkili íwehkili ì kçíãape she's grateful today because they honored her, they dressed her [lit, 'had her clothe herself'] in Kiowa clothes (RBn23-17; CQc).

íwihe. ADJ mixed in, mixed among. çíi akxa htáa wì íwihe hcéská toa ëó[w]ale akxai look, there's a deer mixed in with all those cows (lit., 'that near you is a deer mixed in with some cows') (RBn17-p04).  

íwili. ADJ? burning. íwili, üwili (fragment collected by CQ).

••• Cf. táalì. 

íxope. V [reg.-iða, í_xope (2nd person is inflected as either reg. or stat.)] (intr.) lie, tell untruths. íðaxopaëí you [sg.] didn't lie. íðixope ðààché ìké you wouldn't lie (FH/05/02/95). íðixope apaëíe, íðaxope apaëíe you [pl.] didn't lie (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod). íxope çtâ he is always lying (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). íxope apa they're lying (FH:90). ànâàxopapé we [more than two] lied. íxope ìká don't lie! (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.79). • N lie, fib, untruth, falsehood. íxope àwâçtaake you told me a lie (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). íxope! liar! (lit., 'a lie!') (FH 2-24-83; MSB). íxopeçtà one who always lies; a liar (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 81: íxope <i´-xo-be> to fib; to tell a falsehood; to perjure oneself. àðâ xopa màëi <oæ-thoæ´ xo-ba moæ-zhi> [expected Mod. Os. form: iðáxopa maëí] I did not perjure myself. iðixope <i-thi-xo-be> you perjured [sic].

íxopeçtâ. N [íxope + çtà] liar (lit., 'one who always lies') (RB; 02/15/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 81: íxope çtà <i´-xo-be shtoæ> a liar ('habitually lying'). níhkaçika ixope çtà ðe iðási ha <ni´-Ða-shi-ga i-xo-be shtoæ the i-tha´-ši ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: níhkaçika íxopeçtà ðée iiðási; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I hate a liar.

ízizike (variant: íizizike). N bad things, evil (FH). • ADJ unclean, sick, dirty, evil

(FH/07/09/01/pc). [Apparently a reduplicated form of iizíke 'embarrassed' (but note short i and difference in meaning).] táatà ízizike ecíke tà, ékiò ðìkápi if there is anything unclean, don't do it (FH: Hòopétóohka). ízizike ìké akxai it's not dirty.

••• KS çíge bad, evil, injury [not cognate] (RR).

ízizike káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, ízizike _káaãe] (trans.) contaminate or pollute (e.g., water or air), dirty or spoil s.t. níi ízizike çkáaãape you all polluted the water.

•• LFD 107: níizizike kaãe <ni´-i-ši-ši-ge ga-xe> to make water unclean; to make water unfit for use by pollution. níizizike àkaãa pe <ni´-i-ši-ši-ge oæ-ga-xa i> we made the water unclean.

iëîðe (variants: iëî, iëîe). N his older brother (more precise than English 'his brother') (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).  

iëîke (variant: iiëîke). N his/her son (any son). Yvonnea iëîke akxa húheka akxa Yvonne's son is sick/has a sickness (FH). wahkôta iëîke íikitaðe Christmas (lit., ' God's son is born again') (FH; RB) • his brother's son, her sister's son (more pecise than English 'his nephew' or 'her nephew) (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). [The corresponding 1st person form wiëîke 'my son' can be used also by a woman speaking to or about her brother's son (perhaps a recent usage or one confined to certain dialects or families).]  

•• LFD 82: iëîke <i-zhiæ´-ge> his or her son. (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).  

iëîke iihô. N Virgin Mary (lit., 'his son's mother' or 'mother of his son') (HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok).  

••• Cf. wahkôta iëîke iihô.

íëoçi (variant: íiëoçi). V [reg.-iða, í_ëoçi] (trans.) prohibit, forbid, order or tell s.o. not to, disallow. iðáëoçi àëi óðàëi akxai I said no, but he's going to have his way (lit., 'I disallowed it, but [he's doing it] anyway') (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). ëìkáëi ëààníeëì ðaaché iðáëoçi I told the children not to eat candy (FH:4/18/96/tape:prod). ëìkáëì hóolà iðáëoçi nà I always used to tell the children not to go fishing (FH:prod). ëààníeëì ðaaché iðáëoçi you told me not to eat candy (lit., 'you forbid eating candy'). iinâ akxa ëìkáëì hóolà íëoçi nàpe mother used to tell the children not to go fishing (FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). ëààníeëì ðaaché íëoçi apai they said not to eat candy (FH:4/18/96/tape:prod). • be against doing or refuse or be reluctant to do s.t., say no when asked to do s.t. (t#14a-ps; 04/19/95/FH/pc:ok). waachí iiðáëoçi I refuse to dance (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod). waachí íiëoçi akxai he doesn't want to dance (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod).

iëôà. N her older sister (more precise than English 'her sister').

•• LFD 82: iëôðe <i-zhoæ´-the> her elder sister.  

iëôke. N his/her daughter; his brother's daughter, her sister's daughter (more precise than English 'his/her niece') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).  

•• LFD 82: iëôke <i-zhoæ´-ge> his or her daughter.

 

 

î. V [sync., nasal vowel stem, _î] (trans.) wear (e.g., earrings, warm clothes, a coat, a shawl) (5/12/83/4). mì I wear; I am wearing (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). mî hkôbra I want to wear it (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). haaskámì brî ààhé [with unexpected variant brî of 1st sg. mî] I'm wearing my shawl (FH). ëî you wear; you are wearing (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ëî wihkôbra I want you to wear it (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc). haaská ðé ëî hkôbra I want you to wear this shirt (RBn1-44). àkî ààðé we [two] are wearing [it] (5/12/83/1). haaská çäúuce àkî we're wearing warm clothing. haaskámì î àkái we're wearing our shawls (FH:5/01/96/tape:prod). haxî çooká î ðìké don't wear that thick blanket (FH/09/24/01/prod). ákahamì î put on [wear] your coat (02/15/95/JS/pc:ok; RBn10-12:JW). haxî ì kçí[ð]e let him wear a blanket, cover him with a blanket (lit., 'make him wear a blanket'). • carry (PM). wáìì akxa, çîmìëì those girls, he's carrying them (04/25/95/PM/pc). • have s.t. positioned so that it surrounds part of the body (such as the head or arm). ípehì ípéhì ì kçí[ð]a put a pillow under his or her head (lit., 'have him wear/use a pillow under his head') (BE2.103; RBn2-MOJ/p20; FH: ípehì). ípehì áa kçe î kçíe put a pillow under his arm.

•• LFD 74: ì <iæ> to wear, as a robe or a blanket. LFD 171 (unconfirmed): oì <u-iæ> to wear earrings. oî htà brì <u-iæ´ ¾oæ bthiæ> [expected Mod. Os. form mì 'I wear', not brì] I wear earrings. oì htà àðì pe <u-iæ ¾oæ oæ-thiæ i> we wear earrings. LFD 192: wáì ãake <Wa´-iæ Xa-ge> Carrying (a pipe) and Wailing. "This is the first act in the initiatory ceremony of a candidate." [wa- VAL + î] (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok: wáì ãaake). 

ìcé. N face. táata âhòò íhpahò, ìcé ðuuhpíiëi âhòò I know what I like, I like to make [bad] faces (RBn22-20). ìcé xúãa wrinkly face (a comical and metaphorical usage).

•• RB: <íæ-tseh, iæ-tséh> (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.43).

•• LFD 75: ìcé <iæ-dse´> face.

ìcé bráaska. N slap. ìcé bráze. N slap.

ìcé ðuuhpíiëi. VP [sync., ìcé _ðuuhpíiëi] (intr., trans.?) make faces (at), grimace (at) (lit., 'make a bad face'). táata âhòò íhpahò, ìcé ðuuhpíiëi âhòò. I know what I like, I like to make faces (RBn22-20).

ìcé hpáze. VP, ADJP [stat., ìcé _hpáze] (be) dizzy (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok; FH: ok). ìcé àhpáze I am dizzy (FH:6/25/01/pc). ìcé ðihpáze nìkçé you are dizzy. ìcé àhpáze àkakxái we're dizzy [expected Mod. Os. 1st pl. form: wahpáze] (FH:6/25/01/pc). ìcé wahpáze we're dizzy (FH). ìcé wahpáze apai they are dizzy (BE2.32; FH: 4/17/96/tape). htôpe tà ìcé àhpáze nà when I look at it, it makes me dizzy (RBn10-7:JW; FH:ok).

ìcé káaãe VP [sync. k>p, ìcé _káaãe] put on makeup (lit., 'make a face'). çímiëì apa ìcé káaãe éena wáli wascútape the girls put on their makeup, which makes them very slow (RBn3-19).

ìcé waléze. N picture of anything, photograph, portrait. [Takes 'sitting' positional article ìkçé.] ìcé waléze ìkçé âhòò I like that picture (speaking of a picture on the wall). ìcé waléze hpaamáçi hta mìkçe I'll hold the picture up (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod). icé waléze íiðaðe? do you see the picture? (RBn1-44).

ìcéki. N his/her mother's brother (his/her maternal uncle; more precise than English 'his/her uncle') (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok).  

ìchóhtàà (variant: ichóhtàka). N muskrat (BE2.91; 04/17/95/LS/pc:prod); rat.

•• RB: <i-tsó-tuæ-kah> big rat.

•• LFD 75 (unconfirmed): ìchô htàka <iæ-choæ´ ¾oæ-ga> a rat. ìchôhtàka oðììke <iæ-choæ´-¾on-ga u-thiæ-ge> the butcher bird; a shrike [lit., 'rat grabber'].

ìchóka. N mouse (04/17/95/LS/pc:prod).

•• LFD 296: ìchôka ëìka <iæ-choæ´ -ga zhiæ-ga> a mouse.

ìcóolà. N [ìcé + oolâ] sleep-matter-in-eyes, sand-in-eyes, sleepy-in-eyes (lit., 'put in the face').

-îãe (variant of -wìãe).

îhì (variants: hii, hîì, îì). N beard (BE2.7; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/23/95/FH/pc:hii). îì htô ôò akxa he is wearing a beard (04/25/95/PM/pc).

•• LFD 76: îhì <iæ´-hiæ> beard.

îhìhkicéëe (variant: îhì áhkiceëe). N goat (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok:hk; BE2.59, RBn2-MOJ/p2; FH/11/19/01/pc:ma). [By folk etymology, 'urinates upon his whiskers'].

•• LFD 73: íhì akiceëe ëìka <i´-hiæ a-gi-dse-zhe zhiæ-ga> a kid; a young goat.

ìhtáci. N my father; my father's brother (my paternal uncle; more precise than English 'my uncle') (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok (BE2.147).

••• QU ìttátte my father (RR).

ìhtáciëì. N [ìhtáci + -ëì 'little'] my father's brother (my paternal uncle; more precise than English 'my uncle').  

îì. N rock. îì htà kootáha wáli lâàðe, ðuhcépe ìká that big rock [yonder] is really heavy, don't lift it (FH/09/25/01/pc). tôpa îì htà, çäúhcepe ðààché ìké watch out with that big rock, you can't lift it (FH/09/25/01/pc). îì kootáha skíke that rock over there is heavy (FH/07/31/01). îì çé ìkçe ðíhà pick up that rock (RBn HW11).

îì (variant of îhì).

îì olîì. VP [reg., îì o_lîì] sweat (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok). îì olîì hta akxai they're going to sweat (RBn2-MOJ/p8; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok). îì olîì çí hkôbra I want you to come sweat.  

îìhtò. N [îì + î + htâka] earring(s). íhìhtò ðíhta çkáaãe? did you make your earrings? (RBn; MREI/01/11/93). îìhtò òò akxai he/she has on earrings (RB).

•• RB: <íæ-toæ>.

•• LFD 76: îìhtò <iæ´-iæ-¾oæ> earrings. LFD 73: íìhtò <i´-iæ-¾oæ> an earring.

••• KS ääíhoba ska óì tto shell earrings, 3 or 4 in. long (RR).

ììké (variant of ðììké).

îìolììhci. N [îì olîì + hcí] sweat house, sweat lodge (05/02/95/LS/pc; 03/14/95/MREI/pc; MOJt#150).  

ììçtá (variant: iiçtá). N eye. ììçtá hôòëi apai she has bad eyes (lit., '[her] eyes are bad') (BE2.42; 12/30/94/FH/pc:prod).

•• JOD (slip file): içtá <i-cta´> an eye, eyes.

•• LFD 77: ìçtá <iæ-shta´> eye; eyes. ìçtá ni àwàkihpi <iæ-shta´ ni oæ-woæ-gi-¼i> [expected Mod. Os. form: ììçtá níi àwâkuhpu] my eyes are full of tears.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 77).

••• Cf. mâze ììçtóolà.

ììçtá wawéeðeëi (variant: iiçtá wawéeðeëi). VP [uninfl.] [ììçtá + wawéeðe + aëí NEG] (intr.) be blind, have eyes that don't see things. iiçtá wawéeðe màëi I can't see [contrasts with iiðáðe màëi 'I can't see it'] (FH/08/22/96; FH:prod). iiçtá wawéeðeëi apai he can't see.

••• Cf. íiðe.

ììçtáa cØóka (variant of ììçtáhaa cØóka).

ììçtábri (variant: iiçtábri). N tear, teardrop.

•• LFD 77: ìçtábri <iæ-shta´-bthi> tears (04/04/95/FH/pc:okc).

ììçtáhaa. N [îìçtá + háa] eyelid.

ììçtáhaa cØóka (variants: ììçtáa cØóka, iiçtáhaa cØóka, iiçtáa cØóka). VP [stat., ììçtáhaa _cØóka] be sleepy (lit., 'eyelids droop'). opáwìãe pçíe, étana ììçtáhaa àcØóka mìkçe I went riding and that is why I'm sleepy (03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.123). kaaskíke ììçtáhaa cØóka çki akxai he was tired and sleepy (MREI: ììçtá cØóka or ììçtáhaa cØóka, same).

•• LFD 77: ìçtá ocØoxe <iæ-shta´ u-¾s'u-xe> drowsy; lethargic; sleepiness. ìçtá àhcoxe <iæ-shta´oæ-¾su-xe> [expected Mod. Os. form: ììçtá àcØóka] my eyes are sleepy.

ììçtáhìì (variant: iiçtáhii). N [ììçtá + hîì] eyebrows.

JOD (slip file): içtáhi the eyebrows.  

••• LAK içtáxe the ridge above the eyebrows (Buechel), içtáxe hî the eyebrows (Buechel).  

ììçtáxì (variant: iiçtáxì). N [evidently ììçtá + ãì] white person, French person, Canadian or English person (BE2.157; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:prod) (lit., 'light eyes, gray, brown, or yellow eyes'). ììçtáxì çímiëì wasúhuëi wahókØa a dirty little white girl (FH/04/14/94, 76b). ììçtáxì ëáëe táatà açcîe? what is your English name? (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): içtáxì hcí <ictaqiæ tsi> a white man's house. içtáxì <i-cta´-qiæ> a Frenchman, a Canadian; a white man; white men in general as distinguished from Indians.

•• LFD 77: ìçtáxì <iæ-shta´-xiæ> yellow eyes, a white man.

ììçtáxì htáhtaze. N [reduplicated form, onomatopoeic] grasshopper.  

•• LFD 77: ìçtáxì tatase <iæ-shta´-xiæ da-da-še> [expected Mod. Os. form: ìçtáxì htahtaze] the white man's grasshopper. "This refers to the red-winged grasshopper believed to have been introduced by the white people. It makes a crackling noise as it flies up and down in the air."

ììçtáxì íe (variant: iiçtáxì íe). N English, white man's language. ììçtáxì íe ðìká don't talk English. ììçtáxi íe ékie ðìká ði, oðíchì hta apai, háakò ékiçe che íçpahòëi don't speak English, they're going to whip you, you don't know what you are saying (FH/09/24/01/prod [FH's mother said this to FH's father, who spoke only a few words of English]).

ììçtáxì sáhku (variant: iiçtáxì sáhku). N cantaloupe (lit., 'white man's melon') (01/09/95/FH/pc:ma).

•• LFD 77: ìçtáxì sahku <iæ-shta´-xiæ ša-Ðiu> white man's melon; a cantaloupe. ìçtáxì sahku ðache àða lì <iæ-shta´-xiæ ša-Ðiu tha-tse oæ-tha gthiæ> I like cantaloupe.

ììçtáxìëî. N [ììçtáxì + -ëì 'little'] person of mixed blood (white and Osage; lit., 'a little white') (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; FH/09/25/01; BE2.88).

ìká (variant of ðìká).

ìké (variant of ðìké).

ìkçé (variants: ìkçí, ðìkçí, ðìkçé). CONT 3rd person sitting continuative aspect marker. lîì çô ìkçé while he was sitting (04/28/95/LS/pc:prod). wáli ðiëóëipi ìkçé áape he [sitting] is hurt or all beat up. ðihkówa lôði ìkçé? is your friend [sitting] drunk? (RBn3-54). wakØó tàhé ìkçé? is your wife well? (BE2.5). haakô ìkçé? how are they? (FH). howáìki ìkçé? where is it? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). óolàke wíhta hówaìki ìkçé? where is my hat? kóota ìkçé ohkíhce hôòxce ðìkçé? that one sitting over there, what kind of tribe is he? (03/23/95/FH/pc). waníe ikçí aape she is having birth pains, they said; she is in the hospital having her baby, they said (FH prod orig). waníe ðìkçí aape they said she's in labor (FH/pc). mihkákØe hâà tà ðìkçé the evening star (lit., 'when evening, the star sitting'). óolàke wíhta hówaìki ìkçé? where is my hat? lîì çô ìkçé while he was sitting (04/28/95/LS/pc:prod). ée ìksí áape they said it was he/she [sitting]. Christine akxa hóxpe òô îkçé? does Christine have a cold? (RBn3-55)

ìkçé (variant: ðìkçé). POSIT sitting sg. animate or inanimate positional article (follows a noun or pronoun [usually not the subject of a sentence] that represents a singular sitting entity or singular round entity). ðée ìkçé this one [man] here. çée ìkçe kú hcea tell him [sitting down] to come here (RBn23-17). kóota ìkçé the one sitting over there. háakò ìkçe ékipçe çkôçta? what is it you want me to say? (RBn10-22/JW&FW). tówa ìkçe tôpa look at him/her/that. ðée ìkçe awáçi hkôbra I want that person [sitting] to help me (e.g., one of the other firemen in a meeting) (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). hpôhka htâwà ìkçé màhkâ ðaaché çcée hta ðaìçé? are you going to the meeting over at Ponca? (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). táatà ohkíhce kóota ìkçé? (RBn:87) what tribe is that guy [sitting] over there? (03/23/95/FH/pc). çôke ðìkçe áanààëì I stepped on the dog (RB; 01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok). çôke ðìkçe aðánààëì you stepped on the dog (RB; 01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok; 02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). • lying down or horizontal inanimate plural positional article (follows an inanimate noun or pronoun [usually not the subject of a sentence] that would normally take the positional article kçé 'lying down, long' to show plurality of that noun or pronoun). cØé çki çô ìkçe çcúhpaahà nìkçé aapai they said you [even] raised the dead [pl. of the presumably 'lying down' dead person(s) expressed with 'sitting' positional] (RBn23-17).  

ìkçí. PPN to s.t. sitting or round. hôòpa htáwà ìkçi pçíe I went to town today (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.142). Smokey ìkçí íihkimai brée [íihkimai from íihkiðe màðî bree] I'm going visiting to Smokey's (RBn19-05). niitáahpa ìkçí àkáipe we are going to that pond (RBn3-09). • in that (sitting or round) place. ìhtáci wahkôta, mâëà ðáalì ìkçí ðaníhkaçi nìkçí eepe our father, who art in heaven [they said].  ìkçí (variant of ìkçé CONT).

ìkçíðe (variant: ìkçíe). V [reg.?, ì_kçíðe?] [presumably î + kçíðe] (trans.) have s.o. wear, cause s.o. to put on an article of clothing. haxî ìkçí[ð]e put a blanket on him (lit., 'have him wear a blanket') (RBn10-12:JW).

ìkçítxà (variant: ìkçítxa). PPN off (s.t. round or sitting). paaxó [ì]kçitxa okáxpape he threw him off the hill (RBn19-02). paaxó ìkçítxa àkókaxpai we threw him off the hill (RBn19-02).

ìlé. N excrement, feces, dung, ordure, excretory function, bowels.

•• JOD (slip file): île <iñ-§k¢ªe> dung, ordure, faeces.

•• LFD 75: ìlé <iæ-gthe´> dung; excrement.

ìléha. N buttocks, ass, bottom, anus, rectum, asshole. ìléha wáli htàà akxai, híðaxa ðíhta akxa cúðaëipe his bottom is really large, your diaper is insufficient (BE2.14; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• RB: <ìgléha> (RBn12-08).

•• JOD (slip file): ìléha <iñ-Ð¢é-ha> the anus.

ìlôò (variant of ilôòhtà).

îlòòçka (variant of ilôòçka).

îpehi (variant: ípehi, ípehì, îpehì). N pillow (RBn1-MOJ/p54; 03/08/95/FH/pc:ok). ípehì sí kçe ôò kçíe put a pillow under his foot (03/08/95/FH/pc). ípehì áa kçe î kçíe put a pillow under his arm. ípehì çtôke a soft pillow (FH). • ADV under the head (RBn1-MOJ/p54;

03/08/95/FH/pc:ok). ípehì ípéhì ì kçí[ð]a put a pillow under his/her head (lit., 'have him/her use a pillow under his/her head') (BE2.103; RBn2-MOJ/p20; FH: ípehì).

•• RB: <í-pi-hiæ, íæ-peh-hi>.

•• LFD 74: îpehì <iæ´-be-hiæ> a pillow. îpehì çtòka xta aðe ha <iæ´-be-hiæ shtoæ-ga xta athe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I like a soft pillow (unconfirmed;

03/08/95/FH/pc:uk verb xta). îpehì sakí <iæ´-be- hiæ ša-gi> a hard pillow (03/08/95/FH/pc:ok: saakí). îpehì htàka <iæ´-be-hiæ ¾oæ-ga> a large pillow (03/08/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. ípihì oðíçi. îçpaðò (variant of íçpaðò).

îçtòwà (variant of iistó).

ìëîakika. N bobcat (ML, unconfirmed; FH:4/22/96/tape:uk).

ká (variant of káa).

kaa- (variant: ka-). INSTR by striking, by sudden application of force or sudden movement.

káa (variant: ká). PRON, ADJ these, this, this one (animate or inanimate [may apply to abstract entities], emphatic or expressing certainty or immediacy). húheka çki ôðe apai, káa pa çki ìhtáci, na íçpahò háakò ðáalì che there are also the sick, these ones too, father, only you know how to heal them (FH/08/01/01/pc). wéewinai káa che ìhtáci I am grateful for this, father (FH/08/01/01/pc). íhtáeëì çki húheka kçíepe, káa ðe ìhtaci, ðakØéðai ði younger sister, too, has been made sick, that one, father, bless her (FH/08/01/01/pc). káa che here it is; this is it (e.g., referring to a cup of coffee or a pile of blankets). káa ìkçé here it is (e.g., a blanket or a pie or a plate of food). (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). káa ìkçé, mîìhtoeli hkilúwì here [e.g., handing over money], buy yourself some gum. káa ðìkçé this person [sitting] (PM071494). káa íe txà pée txà? who is that who is talking? (RB note: káa íe txà sounds harsh, as by an older person). káa níhka íe txà pée txà? who is that who is talking (RB note: sounds more polite, as usage characteristic of a younger person) • ADV here, in this place

(02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ðéekaa àwânòbre htai let's eat here (FH:prod). ðéekaa kåe come here; come over here. ðéekaa aðîkü. bring it here (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.66; 02/09/95/FH/pc:ok).  

káa che PRONP [káa PRON + che POSIT] this (standing; a default combination of demonstrative and positional article used for both concrete and abstract items). káa che táatà waaðô? what kind of song is that? (RB). howaðéeçki ðakØéðai, ìhtáci káa che wéewinai you're good to everyone, father, for which we're grateful (FH: prayer). káa che ðaachá eat this (RBn12-11). káa che aðîmàðì take away this thing here. • those inanimate sitting/round things in the surrounding area (referring to a group of sitting items that would be considered 'standing' when gathered together). káa che ôbre hta mìkçé I'm going to throw away that stuff sitting there (e.g., a stack of trash). htóoëu tóe káa che here's some meat pies for you. káa che! here! (when handing a person multiple things that normally sit, such as meat pies or blankets). 

haxî che húða give me those blankets (FH).

•• LFD 48: káche <ga´tse> this; this pile of things before us.  

kaa ché ðe. PRONP [káa PRON + che POSIT + ðée PRON] group of inanimate items sitting there. ['Standing' positional article che pluralizes 'sitting' entities.] kaa ché ðe there's something sitting there; there it sits (FH).

káa ìkçe. PRONP [káa PRON + ìkçé POSIT] this one (sitting) (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok). káa ìkçe oochíëe this one [a person] talks too much; this is too loud (e.g., speaking of the television) (RBn11-02; 03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.133). • these (lying down or horizontal things gathered into a bundle or a sack that sits). káa ìkçé these things tied into a bundle.

kaabráze. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)bráze] [kaa- INSTR + bráze] (trans.) hit or punch (e.g., hit s.o. on the side of the head) (03/07/95/FH/pc:prod orig); tear. oðókanààëì anâkaabrazé I tore my pants (04/03/95/PM/pc:prod).

•• LFD 43: kabráze <ga-btha´-še> to burst, or cause to rip open by falling, a sack of anything. kabrázeaðe ha, oëuhake <ga-btha´-še a-the ha, u-zhi ha ke> [expected Mod. Os. form: ooëuhaa kaabráze hpáaãe] I burst the sack.

kaací. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)cí] (trans.) wipe (any surface); remove some substance from a surface by wiping, raking, or shoveling; wipe clean (after using the toilet) (RB;

05/01/95/LS/pc). kaací! wipe yourself! áaci I wipe. ðáaci you wipe. kaací he wipes. àkáaci we wipe.

•• JOD (slip file): kacü <§ka§t§sü> to wipe clean (under <§ki´-§t§sü> 'to wipe clean for another, to perform this act for a child, who can not do it himself').

•• LFD 44: kací <ga-dsi´> to hoe snow away from around the house. áci <a´-dsi> I hoed away the snow. ðáci <tha´-dsi> you hoed the snow. àkáci pe <oæ-ga´-dsi i> we hoed the snow.

kaacîëe. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)cîëe] (trans.) scrape or push aside. niixoce kaacîëa push all the ashes aside (as in a peyote meeting) [imperative].  

•• JOD (slip file): kacíze <§ka-§t§si´-§se>.  

kaacúxe (variant: cúxe). V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)cúxe] (trans.) sweep (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). hcíoka kaacúxe sweep the room (BE2.130).

•• LFD 45: kacúxe <ga-dsu´-xe> to sweep with a broom; swept. ácuxe <a´-dsu-xe> I sweep. ðácuxe <tha´-dsu-xe> you sweep. àkácuxa pe <oæ-ga´-dsu-xa i> we sweep. hci che acuxe <¾si tse a-dsu-xe> I swept the house.

kaacØó. V [reg. kaa-del.?, _(kaa)cØó?] (intr.?) shave the head.

•• LFD 48: kacØú <ga tsØu´> to shave the head; to make shavings from a stick.

kaaðée. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) pass or give away (e.g., the drum at ilôòçka dances).

céãenii kaaðée hta apai they're going to pass the drum (RBn2-MOJ/p5; 01/31/95/FH/pc:ok).

kaaðéeçpa. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) give away by pressing or pushing away (e.g., the ilôòçka drum). céãenii kaaðéeçpa hta apai they're going to give the drum away; they're pressing or pushing the drum over there (to another person) (BE2.36; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). kaaðó. ADV over there. kaaðó hkíiche[ð]a put it down over there (RBn10-15, unconfirmed).

káaãe. V [sync. k>p, _káaãe] (trans.) make, fix, prepare, bake. hpáaãe I make. çkáaãe you make. káaãe she makes. àkáaãe we make. ónòbre káaãe to fix food, fixing food. màhkása hpáaãe I made coffee (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). háazunii tóe káaãa make some grape juice (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). wacúeskue wì káaãa go bake a cake (RBn10-12:JW). óohò ðáalì káaãapi ché it was well prepared [cooked well] (RBn3-02). xòòcéhu káaãe hôòpa Christmas (lit., 'cedar tree preparation day'). Arthur akxa Mongrain hpéãe wî káaãape Arthur made Mongrain a gourd (RBn10-10:JW; LFD 128). • build. hci káaãe apai they're building a house. htâwakáaãe Townbuilder (personal name). • make or force s.o. (to do s.t.). Mary iihô akxa ðihípe htóoëu toa oohô che Johna kØú káaãape Mary's mother made her give John the meat pies that ðixípe [Robert Bristow] made (RBn; MREI/01/11/83). óðohta káaãa make him behave (RBn22-19). • cause s.t. to be a certain way. hkihkôze ðáalì çkáaãe hàcé you made the peyote meeting [be] good last night (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). wiëî, waaðô ðáalì çkáaãe hàcé older brother, you made good songs last night (lit., 'you made the songs be good') (RBn1-40). hci stáko çkáaãe you straightened up your house (lit., 'you made the house neat'). • turn on. káaãa turn it on (FH:bnbw-MOJ). htaacéxowe káaãa turn the fan on (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc; BE2.43). • do, perform, engage in. hôòpa wì súhka tóoka ókØà ékòëi káaãe nàpe sometimes the rooster did things he shouldn't do [unseemly things] (RBn18-01). • (intr.) make it (in a card game). hpáaãe maëíe I didn't make it (RBn10-21/JW).

••• Cf. kikáaãe, kçíãe.

kaaãú. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) brush. hpáxì kaaãú brush your hair [imperative] (FH).

kaahtáama. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) ring, make a ringing noise, ring like a bell (RBn102:MOJ/79).

•• JOD (slip file): kahtamà <§ka-ta-maæ> 'ring' (under <í-§ka-ta-maæ>). íkaahtamà hcéska nòpØî kçíðe, hkaamâ màðî apá <i§katamaæ tséska nªuæ´p'iæ kcí¢ªe, kamaæ´ maæ´¢iæ apa´> the cow being made to wear a bell on the neck, it rings as she walks (under <ka´-maæ> 'ring').

••• QU dikáda ring a bell [by] pulling the rope (RR); KS mâàzettàmà bell (RR).

••• Cf. íikaahtamà. 

kaahúuëa (variants: kahúëa, kahúëà, kahúuëa). ADV, N (for a) long time, for quite a while. kaahúuëa aðáape he's been gone a long time (02/22/95/FH/pc:prod orig; BE2.81). kaahúuëa íiwiðe màëi I haven't seen you for a long time. kaahúuëà mâëà ðéka omâìpe he lived on this earth a long time (RBn10-13:JW). • a long time ago, long ago (FH/8/30/94). kaahúuëà mâëà ðéka omâì apai he lived on this earth a long time ago (RBn10-13:FH).  

kaakô (variant: káakò). ADV that way, thus with certainty, in this manner. kaakô kôða tà that's the way he's going to do it; since he wants it this way; that's the way he wants it [contrast haakô kóða tà 'whatever he wants to do', eekô kôða tà 'what he wants to do'] (04/11/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 45: kákò <ga´-goæ> in this manner.

••• KS gaagô thus, in that manner (RR).

••• Cf. ékò, haakô.

káakò tà. ADVP therefore, so, and then, whereupon (RBn22-01), when thus, when at last, when at that time.

•• JOD (slip file): káhkòta <¦ka´-kªuæ-¦ta>.

•• LFD 45: kákòtà <ga´-goæ-doæ> when this was done, or being done; therefore; then:

from a ritual.

••• KS gaagó(o)ýedà then, during that time, at last (RR).

kaakônà (variant: kaakônàà [HH]). N [kaakô + na 'only'] plenty, sufficient, enough (lit., 'only like this') (108-b/FH/001). kaakònâà that's plenty (e.g., of coffee) (FH). kaakònâà that's enough (of an activity, such as making s.t.). • end of an activity, final part of s.t. kaakônà ée ðe that's all (RBn10-5:JW). kaakònâe? is that all? is that everybody? (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). kaakònâe ðe that's all (the end of a story). kaakònâà there's no more (e.g., food) (HH/t#38bp3). htaaníi kaakônà the soup is gone, that's all there is (HH:prod). htaaníi kaakônà soup's all gone (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). kaakônà ée ðe that's all (RBn10-5:JW).

•• LFD 45 (unconfirmed): kakô nà çkità <ga-goæ´ noæ shki-doæ> sufficient. kakôeðo <ga-goæ´-e-tho> that is all (unconfirmed; 04/26/95/LS/pc:uk).

••• KS gaago hnâ enough, that is all (RR).

kaakônà káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, kaakônà _káaãe] (intr., trans.) make no more (of), do no more, stop there, cease an unnamed activity. htaaníi kaakônà káaãa don't make any more soup (04/26/95/LS/pc; t#38b-p4; HH). kaakônà káaãa don't do that any more; put a stop to that (e.g., said to children if they are fighting) (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; t#38b-pHH). kaakònâ kaaãá don't do that anymore, make that the end, do it to there only (BE2.2).

kaalâðe (variant of kaalôðe).

kaaléke. V [reg. kaa-del, _(kaa)léke (1st sg. aaléke, 2nd sg. ðaaléke, 3rd sg. kaaléke, 1st pl. àkáaleke); also conjugated as sync. k>p, _kaaléke (1st sg. hpáaleke, 2nd sg. çpáaleke, 3rd sg. kaaléke)] (trans.) shatter or break (e.g., glass), shatter by striking or by sudden movement, fracture (e.g., one's skull). [Historically probably kaaxléke; modern speakers use l or occasionally slightly preaspirated [hl] in all forms based on -léke. Compare the LFD examples below.] okáhàpa kaaléke ché someone broke a window, that's the way it is (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). pée kaaléke? who broke it? çîtoëì apa okáhàpa kalékape the boys broke the window (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). áa ðíhta kaaléke they broke your arm (FH/pc). hììcé àkáalekapé we broke the dishes (MSB 02-24/25-83). hììcéëì wibriileke I broke your dish (MREI 11-01-83-8). • (intr.) shatter, fracture, crack, break, be broken. kaaléke it breaks [as an eggshell does]. kaalékepe it's broken (RBn22-03; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 49: kaléke <ga-xthe´ge> to crack something brittle like glass, china, or stone. î xe che aléke ha <iæ´ xe tse a-xthe´-ge ha> [expected modern Os. form: ìì che aaléke; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I cracked the stones. î xe àkáleka pe <iæ´ xe oæga´-xthe-ga i>we cracked the stones.

••• Cf. ðuuléke, kíleke, paaléke. 

kaalíiëe (variant of kaalîìëe).

kaalî. V [uninfl.] (trans.) lightning strikes. ëâà kaalî the lightning struck a tree (RBn1-12, unconfirmed; 02/15/95/FH/pc:uk). • N lightning strike.

•• LFD 225: ëâkali <Zhoæ´-ga-xthi> Tree-killer; personal name (refers to the lightning that strikes and kills the tree).

kaalîìëe (variant: kaalíiëe). N [kaa- INSTR + lîìëe] sparks that are struck (as by hitting the "iron" against the flint to create sparks to make the sponge-like material from a tree catch fire) (BE2.49; 01/26/95/FH/pc:prod). • N flint used to make flint fire (for peyote meetings or sweat lodge) (RB).  

kaalôðe (variant: kaalâðe). V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) travel, migrate, go on a hunting expedition (FH:5/01/96/tape:uk).

•• JOD (slip file): kalâðe <¦ka-q¢aæ´ ¢e> to migrate, to go on a hunting expedition with many or all of the tribe, to go with a large party, each man taking his household.

•• LFD 49: kalôðe <ga-xthoæ´-the> to migrate; to go on a hunting expedition.

kaalôðì. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)lôðì] [kaa- INSTR + lôðì] (trans.) knock s.o. out.

•• LFD 45: kalôðì <ga-gthoæ´-thiæ> to knock a person senseless. álòðì <a´-gthoæ-thiæ> I knocked him senseless. ðálòðì <tha´-gthoæ-thiæ> you knocked him senseless. àkálòðì pe <oæ-ga´-gthoæ-thiæ i> we knocked him senseless.

kaamâçàçie (variants: kaamáçi, kaamáçiçi). V, ADJ [conjug. unknown] (intr.) bounce up, (be) bouncy (as in a rough ride in a car or wagon) (BE2.10; 01/07/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 46: kamâ <ga-moæ´> feathery (down).

káanà. ADV, PPN this much, just right, just the right amount, only this much. káanà ahí akxai just a little bit [showing with hand] and it'll be here (referring to sunup) (FH/09/24/01/prod).  

••• Cf. éena, háanà.

kaaníeëi. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)níeëi] [kaa- INSTR + ónie 'breathe' +aëí NEG] (trans.) knock

s.o. out, hit s.o. in a way that shakes him/her up badly (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc; RBnot 5/3/79/p2,corr'd). [Implies a less strong impact than káasaaki.] ðáanieëi you knocked him out (02/14/95/FH/pc). áanieëi I knocked him out (02/14/95/FH/pc). âkaanieëi we knocked him out (02/14/95/FH/pc).

kaapáacØì V [reg.? kaa-del.?, _(kaa)páacØì] (intr.) bend over (as when placing one's hands on the floor from a standing position or bending over a table for a medical examination) (PM, unconfirmed). [PM's intransitive gloss is unexpected; a more expected meaning would be

'cause s.o. to bend over by pushing suddenly'.]

•• LFD 42: kapácØì <ga-ba´-ts´iæ> to strike a blow and cause one to bow his head.

káapçe (variant: kaapçé). V [reg. kaa-del.?, _(káa)pçe?] (trans.) brush or comb (one's hair), curry

(an animal's coat) (04/20/95/LS/pc:okc). hpáxì kaapçé brush or dress one's hair (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod: aa). hkáwa káapçe brush the horse. hpáxì káapça! brush your hair!

(01/09/95/FH/pc:ok) hpáxì kaapçé comb your hair (FH:04/17/96). káapça! brush it/comb it!

(FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

••• Cf. kípçe, wékaapçe. 

kaapxóhke. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)pxóhke] (trans.) burst, explode, pop (e.g., a balloon); hit s.o. on the back, knocking the wind out; stun, crash (03/10/95/FH/pc:okc). áapxohke I burst it (03/10/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 46: kapxóhkiàhe <ga-po´-Ði-oæ-he> to crash with a blow. ápxohkiàhe <a´-po-Ðioæ-he> I crashed it with a blow. LFD 129: hpohkié <¼o-Ði-e´>[possibly erroneous for pxohkie or pxohke] a sound like the report of a gun or a popgun.

••• Cf. niikáapxohke. 

káasaaki. V [reg. kaa-del., _(káa)saaki] (trans.) knock out, hit hard, hit with a stunning blow, stun (FH/pc). ásaaki I give a stunning blow. ðásaaki you give a stunning blow. àkáasai we give a stunning blow. káasaakipe he knocked him out (BE2.74; 02/14/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 43: kasáki <ga-ša´-gi> to give a stunning blow; to knock down; to thrash or kill; to stun.

kaascú. V [reg. kaa-del.?, _(kaa)scú?] (trans.) slice, slit, punch through.

••• Cf. wacúe kaascú.

kaasé (variant: káase). V [reg. kaa-ret., _kaasé; or reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)sé] [kaa- INSTR + -se] (trans.) chop or cut with a striking blow (e.g., from a blade, such as an axe or knife); cut with a lawnmower, chop up (e.g., long, thin sticks of wood for a fire); chop down (not by sawing). [It is not clear that all translations are equally appropriate for both the kaa-ret. and kaa-del. conjugations of this verb. 'Cut with a lawnmower' and 'chop up' seem to be attested only for the kaa-ret. variant, 'chop down' only for the kaa-del. variant.] Examples of kaa-ret. forms: ákaase I chop. ðákaase you chop. káase she chops. àkáase we chop. mààhí kaasé hta apai they're going to cut grass (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod). ëâà kaasé brée hta mìkçé I'm going to go cut wood (01/14/95/FH/pc:okc). wéewinai, mààhí wíhta ðákaase thank you for cutting my grass (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.28). ëâà ðákaase hta ðaìçé? are you going to cut down the trees [with an axe]? (FH/06/16/01/pc). mààhîìspe ðuuzái ëâa tóe àkáase àkái hce get the axe and let's [us two] go cut some wood (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod). àkáase hta àkatxâi we're going to chop/cut (FH/06/16/01/pc). ëààkáase cut wood, engage in woodcutting (RBn10-16; 03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). htáa ðákaase hta ðaìçé? are you going to chop the meat? (FH/06/16/01/pc). Examples of kaa-del. forms: áase, aasé I chop. ðáase, ðaasé you chop. kaasé he chops. àkáase we chop (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). ëâà áase I chop wood (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). ëâà ðáase you chop wood (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). ëâà káase chopping wood (MSB:t9). 

•• RB: <káh-séh>.

•• LFD 248: kasé <ga-še´> to cut with a striking blow. ëà áse <zhoæ a´-še> I chop wood. ëà ðáse <zhoæ tha´-še> you chop wood. LFD 225: ëàkáse <zhoæ-ga´-še> to chop wood. ëà àkása pe <zhoæ oæ-ga´-ša i> we chop wood. LFD 43: kase <ga-še> to cut by a striking blow ['by sudden action' (as in haircutting, mowing grass) rather than 'by a striking blow' (01/14/95/FH/pc: not with a striking blow)]. ìcé ðà ðase le ha <iæ-dse´ thoæ tha-še gthe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you cut his face [ðò is not used in Mod. Os.; le he is unknown; and kaasé is not used for cutting someone's face (01/14/95/FH/pc:uk: not someone's face)].

kaasî (variants: kaasîe, kaasîta, kaasîtà). ADV, N tomorrow. kasî táatà hta paaçé? what are you [pl.] doing tomorrow? (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.142).

•• RB: <kah-síæ-eh> (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 44l: kasâì tà <ga-šoæ´-iæ doæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: kasî, kasîtà] tomorrow; some time; the morrow; dawn of another day (unconfirmed; 03/23/95/FH/pc:no).

kaasî kootáha (variant: kaasî kootáha ce). ADVP, N day after tomorrow (BE2.30; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod:ok with or without ce). kaasî wanôbre (variant of kaasîexci wanôbre).

kaasîce. V [reg. kaa-ret., _ kaasîce] (trans.) close, slam, close suddenly or by striking (HRE/12/29/01/pc: ì not ìì). ákasìce I slam. ðákasìce you slam. àkasìce we slam.

••• Cf. ákaasìce.

kaasîe (variant of kaasî).

kaasîexci (variants: kaasîexcì, kaasîxci). ADV, N  (in the) early morning, morning, this morning. (RBn3-MOJ/p12, LH tape). kasîexcì waëîka apa hóohtà nàpé the birds sing early in the morning (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). kasîexcì mîì àtôpe htái let's go see the morning sun coming up (as in a meeting) (BE2.129; 01/14/95/FH/pc). kasîxci htáabre pçíe this morning I went hunting (FH).

•• LFD 44: kasôìxci <ga-šoæ´-iæ-xtsi> early morning.

••• Cf. kasîexcìëì.

kaasîexci ónòbre. N cereal, breakfast food (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). [A new coinage.]

kaasîexci wanôbre (variant: kaasî wanôbre). N breakfast (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok). kasî wanôbre aðîëipe he didn't have breakfast [to offer us] (BE2.12).

•• LFD 44: kasàì xci wanòbre <ga-šoæ-iæ xtsi wa-noæ-bthe> early morning meal; breakfast.

kaasîexcì (variant of kaasîexci).

kaasîexcìëì. N, ADV [kaasîexci + -ëì 'little'] (in the) very early morning, very early in the morning (RBn3-MOJ/p12, LH tape; BE2.38; 12/30/94/FH/pc:prod). kasîexciëì very early in the morning (BE2.38; 12/30/94/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 44: kasôì xci ëìka <ga-šoæ´-iæ xtsi zhiæ-ga> early in the morning; when the morning is young or little. kasâì xci waëìka apa hothà çna pi a <ga-šoæ´-iæ xtsi wa-zhiæ-ga aba hu-toæ shna bi a> [shna is probably Omaha (expected Mod. Os. form is çtà); Mod. Os. form of pi a is pe] the birds sing early in the morning.

kaasîta, kaasîtà (variants of kaasî).

kaasîxci (variant of kaasîexci).

kaaskí. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)skí] (trans.) compress, gather up or wad together with a sudden movement, pinch off (as in making balls out of cornmeal for cornmeal dumplings), grab (FH:4/18/96:pc).

•• LFD 47: kaðíski <ga-thi´-ški> gathering together corn or wheat.

••• Cf. ðiiskí, hkilíiski, pahúkaaski. 

kaaskíke (variant: kaaçkíke). V, ADJ [stat. kaa-del, _(kaa)skíke, some variation between ði- and ða- for 2nd person] [kaa- INSTR + skíke] (be) tired, worn out, exhausted. âskike I'm tired. ðískike you're tired. káaskike he's tired. wáaskike we're tired. wálì âskike mìkçé I'm really tired (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). âçkike I'm tired, I'm worn out (FH/tape 108-b; 04/26/95/FH/pc; RBn1-40). âskike àçkáaãape you [pl.] make me tired. aðískike nìkçé? are you tired? [a- is unexpected in 2nd person; may be a false start] (FH). kaaskíke tôpewai nìkçe you look tired. kaaskíke ðâìçe? are you tired? Johna akxa kaaskíke akxái John is tired (03/22/95/FH/pc:prod). kaaçkíke akxái he's tired (04/26/95/FH/pc). kaaskíke akxa he's tired (BE2.141; CQc). waaskíke apái, kaaskíke apái they're tired (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok both). wáaskike àðìkçe we [two] are tired (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). âàskike àðìkçé we [sitting] are tired  [unexpected 1st dual form; the expected 1st dual or 1st pl. verb form is stative wáskike or wáaskike].

•• LFD 43: kaaskíke <ga-ški´-ge> tedious; wearisome; lassitude; fatigue; to be weary; exhausted (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). àáskike <oæ-a´-ški-ge> I am weary (from running).

ðiáskike <thi-a´-ški-ge> you are weary (from running). waskika pe <wa-ški-ga i> we are weary (from running).

kaaçénà. V, ADJ [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)çénà] (intr.) (be) ended, finished, that's all, s.t. (e.g., soup, coffee) is finished (i.e., ready) (HH). aaçéna na that's enough, I'm through (HRE/12/29/01/pc). ãaaké kaaçéna don't cry (ERE prod: CQc). mâhkasa kaaçénàà don't make any more coffee (T38b-p4; HH, T38b-p3; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). mâhkasa kaaçénà káaãa don't make any more coffee (HH:prod). wacúe kaaçénà káaãa don't make any more bread (HH/t38b-p3). • N closing of a prayer, amen. kaaçéna amen, the end (of a prayer) (FH). íe kaaçénà ékipçe this prayer ends now, I have spoken (JS prayer).

•• LFD 46: kaçé <ga-she´> to force one to abandon his property [unconfirmed]. áçe <a´she> I forced him to abandon his property.  

••• Cf. kaakônà. 

káaçi. V [uninfl.] (intr.) be long. hòpa akxa káaçi akxái the days are longer now (RBn2MOJ/p40; 02/22/95/FH/pc:uk). hàà káaçi ðáha achípe they came late at night (lit., 'the night was long when they arrived here'). • ADV for a long time. káaçi lîìpe he sat a long time. wéhice hí áape hcí káaãe káaçi ðí áape she went a long way and took a long time to build her nest [they said] (RBn19-03). káaçi wáli àwáachipe, àðíiçtà htái we've danced a long time, let's stop (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.81). • N a long time (which has passed). káaçi ðachíe here you are already! (lit., 'so long a time has passed!') (FH/pc; BE2.75).

•• LFD 230: hkáçi <Ða´-shi> [expected Mod. Os. form: <ka´-shi>, with plain k] long ago.

••• KS gaçí long time ago; for a long time (RR), gaçídà long time ago [may have long aa] (RR).

••• Cf. kaahúuëa, kaaçôka. 

káaçkíke (variant of kaaskíke).

kaaçô (variants: kaaçôe, kaaçôwe). N enough (of some activity), final point, end (e.g., of one's earthly existence) (HH; 04/26/95/LS/pc). kaaçô káaãe make that the end, stop! put an end to something, stop some activity (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc).

•• LFD 47: kaçô <ga-shoæ´> it is enough; sufficient.  

kaaçô káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, kaaçô _káaãe] (intr.) cease, stop (lit., 'make it the final point'). kaaçô waðíhtà çkáaãe you stopped work; you made the work stop (04/26/95/LS/pc). • reach a point of sufficiency, produce enough of s.t. (04/26/95/LS/pc).

•• LFD 47: kaçô hpaãe <ga-shoæ´ ¼a-xe> I stopped work. kaçô âkaãa pe <ga-shoæ´ oæ´ga-xa i> we stopped work [definition makes no specific mention of 'work'].

kaaçôe. ADV always. kaaçó ðáalì good for all time (RBn10-15).  

kaaçôe (variant of kaaçô and kaaçôeðe).

kaaçôe che. VP [uninfl.] leave it alone, let it alone, just let it sit, let it be (standing sg. item or construct) (04/26/95/FH/pc:okc). óØie che kaaçôe che [let's] leave the problem alone (04/26/95/FH/pc).

kaaçôeðe (variants: kaaçôiðe, kaaçôe). INTERJ good-bye, farewell (more literally, 'that's all', 'it's over with'; to a dead person) (BE2.59; FH/11/19/01/tape); exclamation acknowledging the end of earthly living, the final event in life (HH; BE2.59). [Some speakers only use this expression in bidding farewell to a dead person; others use it in other circumstances, e.g., saying good-bye at the airport (RB).] kaaçòe, wihtâke, kaaçòeðe good-bye, sister, good-bye (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok) há, kaaçôìðé well now, this is it.

•• RB: <háh-káh-shóæ-i-théh> (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc).  

••• Cf. kaaçénà, kaaçôka. 

kaaçôìke. INTERJ good-bye, the end, the final event, nothing more (HH). kaaçôìke that's all, the end, this is it, final event; good-bye; that's the end of earthly living, it's over (HH).  

••• Cf. kaaçô.

kaaçôka. INTERJ (it's) sufficient, basta, (it's) enough.

kaaçôwe (variant of kaaçô).

kaaçtá. V [reg. kaa-del _(kaaçtá)] (trans.) hammer, hit or beat (e.g., a drum), flatten by striking.

•• LFD 44: kastá <ga-šta´> to beat or hammer metal.
