kaaçtâ. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) end, stop an activity, put an end to s.t., cease (LS). wacúe káaãe kaaçtâ don't make any more bread (04/07/95/LS/pc:okc). wacúe káaãa kaaçtá stop, don't make any more bread (HH:prod). • INTERJ stop, that's the end, there is no more (HH).

••• KS büçtâ stop, cease rubbing, pressing (RR).

••• Cf. ðaaçtâ, ðiiçtâ. 

káataace. V [reg.? kaa-del.?, _(káa)taace?] (intr.) stick, get stuck (RB). oðíhtà akxa káataace akxai the car is stuck (RBn23-14).

••• KS dáýe stuck in the mud, mired (RR), gadáýe stuck in the mud, to get mired (RR). kaatxá, kaatxâ (variants of katxâ).

káawìãe. V (intr.) soar, as an eagle. xúða apa káawìãe nàpe the eagle soars (LFD 218; CQc).

káaxa. V [reg. kaa-del., _(káa)xa (inflection is irregular in that ka seems to be retained in 3rd pl. káaxa)] (trans.) beat s.o. in a race (RBnotes). âxape he beat me (in a race). ðiáxape he beat you (in a race). wiáxae I beat you (in a race). ðáaxae you beat him (in a race). aawáxae I beat them (in a race). ààwâxa àðe we [two] beat them (in a race) (2-10-83-p5). áaxa I beat him. ðáaxa you beat him. áxa ~ xa he beat him. káaxa they beat him.

•• LFD 48: kaxá <ga-xa´> to excel; outrun; outstrip; to outdistance. áxa <a´-xa> I excel. ðáxa <tha´-xa> you outstripped him. àkáxape <oæ-ga´-xa i> we outran him. 

••• KS wáxa [from wa + gaxa] 'beat, surpass them' (JOD, RR).

••• Cf. wakáaxa. 

kaaxíãe (variant of kaaxúãe).

kaaxô. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)xô] [kaa- INSTR + xô] (trans.) break off, break by striking (a long object, such as a stick). oðópçe kaaxôpe he broke the cradle board (04/19/95/FH/pc; 04/19/95/FH/pc). htáhu kaaxô áape they said he broke his neck (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; CQ:okc). áaxò I break it (e.g., the leg from a small horse statue). ðáaxò you break it. 

àkáaxòpe we break it. • (intr.) be broken (when used with continuative auxiliary akxa or apa).

håüni wíhta akxa kaaxô akxai my garter is broken (RBn12-05).

•• JOD (slip file): kaxô <¦ka-qªuæ´> to break, as a nail, ear of corn, stick, etc., without breaking it entirely in two; to break or be broken by falling.

kaaxúãe (variants: kaaxúãa, kaaxíãe). V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) split, split open, crack or splinter by sudden impact (RBn; HRE at WHM981022).

•• JOD (slip file): kaxúãe <§ka-qªu-xe> to break, as any small or thin object, requiring little force.

•• LFD 48 (unconfirmed): kaxíãe <ga-xi´-xe> to break or crack hard substance like corn, nuts, etc., by striking.

kaazâ (variants: káazà). V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)zâ] (trans.) scold, reprimand, chastise, censure, bawl out (RBn12-06; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok). áazà I scold. ðáazà you scold. kaazâ she scolds. àkáaëà we scold. záani awáazà I scolded them all (RB). wiizâ hta mìkçé I'm going to bawl you out (RBn HW). kaazâpi okíce apai she is looking for a scolding (03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok; 01/06/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn2-MOJ/p6). âàzàpe they scolded me (RB). ðíizà hta apai they're going to bawl you out, they're going to scold you (RBn HW; CQc). wáli wáazàpe they bawled us out, they really scolded us (RBn HW). kóoci wáazàpe a long time ago they bawled us out. kaazâëi nôàðape I was raised without being scolded (i.e., was given favored treatment) (RB). ëìkáëì àkáazà çtà we boss the kids around all the time (FH:prod). kaazâ ði scold him, bawl him out (03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.117). oðáhkie tà káazà, taaçéða! when you tell him, bawl him out, get after him! (FH:98/pc). âàzà ìká don't scold me (FH).

•• LFD 43: kazâ <ga-šoæ´> censure; abuse; reprimand; to scold. ázà <a´-šoæ> I scold or censure. ðázà <tha´-šoæ> you scold or censure. àkázà pe <oæga´-šoæ i> we scold or abuse.

kaazâzà. V [reg. kaa-del., _(kaa)zâzà] [reduplicated form of kaazâ] scold over and over, keep on scolding.

kaaëí (variant: kaaëî). V [reg. kaa-ret., _kaaëí] (trans.) drive (a vehicle), herd (animals) (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). oðíhtà akáaëi hta mìkçé I'll drive the car. ðíe kaaëí! you drive! ðákaaëi [contrastive accent on ða-; expected form would be ðakáaëi] you're driving. oðíhtà àkáaëi drive the car for me. hkáwa wakáaëi driving horses. • make or force s.o. to do s.t., command s.o. to do s.t. çáake lúuëe wákaaëi [wakáaëi 'make them' would be expected rather than wákaaëi; accent shift due to imperative?] make them wash their hands (RBn3-13). • blow with force (as in blowing one's nose). hpá kaaëî blow your nose (RBn12-09).

•• LFD 49: kaëî <ga-zhiæ´> to drive a team of horses or an automobile. hkawa ðàkxa awakaëì alì hta mìkçe ha <Ða-wa thoæ-ka a-wa-ga-zhiæ a-gthiæ ¾a miæ-ke ha> [Mod. Osage: hkáwa pa áwakaaëi alí hta mìkçé 'I'll return home driving the horses'; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I can drive the horses home. hkawa ðàkxa waðakaëì ðalì htathe ha <Ðawa thoæ-ka wa-tha-ga-zhiæ tha-gthiæ ¾a-te ha> [Mod. Osage: hkáwa pa waðákaaëi ðalí hta ðaìçé 'you will return home driving the horses'; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you can drive the horses home.

••• Cf. ákaaëi, kíëi, wakáaëi.

kaðô. CONJ then, and then, and next, and then immediately, and right away. kaðò háakò? and then what happened? (RBn19-04). oâhkie çô akxa kaðò waðílà ðúeëi hìì naaëípe he was talking to me, then all of a sudden he changed his mind. awâhkie çô akxa kaðò ãaaké ahípe he was talking to me, then suddenly he started to cry. • and. táatà ëáëi açäîe kaðò hówaìkiha ðachíe? what is your name and where did you come from? (RBn17-p1;

HRE/01/17/02/pc/okc; w/ha). ìlôaëe kaðó çôke niiëú akxai it's raining cats and dogs (RBn). • ADV here next to. ëúuce, ska kaðô htóho red, white, and blue.

••• KS ga and (introduces a sentence) (RR), gayó, gayô and (RR).

••• Cf. kóe. 

kahânaëe. ADV for several days. kahânaëe owíce àhé I've been looking for you [for] several days (03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.119).

•• RB: <kah-háh-nah-zhahæ>.

kahíke (variant: kahíka). N chief. kahíke owátxà assistant chief (01/14/95/FH/pc). kahíke okxâ assistant [lit., 'next'] chief (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.18). áhkita kahíke chief of the soldiers (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). çòmîhka kahíke mâze wanôpØì wì kØúpi áape they gave the Pope [lit., 'Catholic chief'] a medal, they say (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 11: kahíke <ga-hi´-ge> the great one; the chief. áhkita kahike <a´-Ði-da ga-hige> captain. Also used as a personal name by the Osage and Omaha tribes. LFD 45: kahíkenàëì <Ga-hi´-ge-noæ-zhiæ> Standing-chief (personal name; so named on account of position of the chief, permanent, chosen to represent a division). kahíkexci <Ga-hi´-gextsi> Real-chief (personal name). kahikeëìka <Ga-hi-ge-zhiæ-ga> Young-chief (personal name). kahíketxà <Ga-hi´-ge-toæ> Standing-chief (personal name).

kahíke okxâ (variant of kahíke otxâ).

kahíke ókØà. N assistant chief (FH).

kahíke otxâ (variants: kahíke okxâ, kahíke otkxâ). N assistant chief (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; HRE/01/17/02/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p19).

•• LFD 45: kakíke owátxà <ga-gi´-ge u-wa´-toæ> the second chief.

••• Cf. ótxàtxà. 

kahkâ. V [reg. ka-ret.?, _kahkâ] (trans.) fan or fan off s.o. âkahkàpi you [pl.] fan me off (PM).

•• LFD 46: kahkâ <ga-Ðoæ´> to shake a rug or blanket.

••• QU ákakxà powder, sprinkle on (RR); KS gakhâ to shake something, to shake off something (RR). [RR claims that the QU and KS forms are not cognate with the Mod. Os. form.]

••• Cf. kíhkà. 

kahúuëa, kahúëa, kahúëà (variants of kaahúuëa).

kakçîce (variant: kakçîze) V [reg. ka-del., _(ka)kçîce] (trans.) miss (a target), miss out on (e.g., a dinner) by arriving late. akçîce I miss it. ðakçîce you miss it. kakçîce she misses it. àkçîce we

[two] miss it [expected Mod. Os. 1st dual form is àkákçìce] (FH:05/03/95). ákçìce I missed it

(MSB-3-10-83-D). ðákçìce you missed it (MSB-3-10-83-D). kakçîtape he missed it (MSB-310-83-D). àkákçìce we [two] missed it (MSB-3-10-83-D).

••• Cf. ðikçîce. kalôeëe. N horned toad. [Old-time Osages used to make 'woman catchers' from the skin stuffed with medicine (RB).]

•• RB: <káh-lóæ-eh-zhiæ> (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.67).

kasôci. V [reg. kaa-del., _(ka)sôci] (trans.) test s.o., try s.o. out (3-3-83-p1). ásòci àhé I'm testing her out. ðásòci ðaaçé you're testing her out. kasôci akxai he's testing him out.

••• Cf. áhkiasàci, ásàci, opásàce.

kaçíni. N shinny (a team ballgame played on a field with a buckskin ball, sticks, and goals at the opposite ends of the field).

••• Cf. ohkíce.

kaçké. V [reg. ka-del., _(ka)çké] (trans.) tie up or together (e.g., shoelaces). [Expected but unattested inflectional forms: 1st sg. áaçke 'I tied his shoe', 2nd sg. ðáaçke 'you tied his shoe', 3rd sg. kaçké 'he tied her shoe', 1st pl. àkáçke 'we tied his shoe'.] hpáaëì akxai hòòpé kaçkí akxai the baby ties his shoes (FH:5/01/96/tape:prod). hòòpé âàçke tie my shoe! (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). hòòpé àðáçke çkôçta? do you want to tie my shoe? (FH/t116b). káçke tie it (FH: prod).

••• Cf. ákaçke, oðáçke, okáçke. 

kaçpé. N bit, portion (of any item); twelve and a half cents.

kaçpéòpa (variant: kaçpé ðòòpá). N [kaçpé + ðòòpá] quarter (25-cent coin; lit., 'two bits') (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc; t14a-p1b/14, t44). kaçpéòpa hta akxai it will be a quarter (lit., 'it will be two bits' [noun is used as verb]; a phrase said by seller to ask for his money) (BE2.110).

kaçpéòpa oolâ put your 25 cents in.

•• LFD 47: kaçpé ðòpa <ga-shpe´ thoæ-ba> two bits; 25 cents.

kaçúpe. V [reg. ka-del., _(ka)çúpe] (trans.) pay (a debt), pay for (a purchase). [Used to describe the ceremony of paying for the drum at the Osage War Dances.] áçupe I paid for it. ðáçupe you paid for it. kaçúpape she paid for it. àkáçupape we [pl.] paid for it. áçupe I'll pay for it (FH:prod, 2/97). weúuze htà áçupe hta míkçe I'm going to pay this big debt (03/06/95/FH/pc:prod). àkaçupepi na he paid me for it (MSB). àðáçupe na you paid me for it. kaçúpapi! pay for it [pl. addressee]!

•• LFD 46 (unconfirmed): kaçípe <ga-shi´-be> to pay a debt [not **kaçípe, but kaçúpe (FH)].  

••• Cf. kíçupe. 

katxâ (variants: katxá, kaatxá, kaatxâ). ADV, N while, meanwhile, awhile, for a while, after a while, a little while. katxá! stop! wait! [i.e., 'pause or suspend an activity']. katxá àpánaa htai let's stop for a while (RBn3-27) katxá, íe akxa wait, he is speaking; wait, they are speaking (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; also3p; BE2.150).

•• JOD (slip file): kaÐxâ <Ða-kqaæ´> that far; awhile (subdialect).

••• KS gakhâ awhile, for a time (RR).

káxa (variants: káxe, kaxé). N creek, branch (e.g., of a stream or brook) (RBn1-MOJ/p13; 04/07/95/LS/pc:ok). [This term was used for 'creek' by some older Osage speakers in Oklahoma in the 1990s. The variant forms with final e are unexpected.] káxa akxa okåhpu akxa the creek is full (RBn10-6:JW). kaxé akxa okåhpü akxai the creek is full (flooded) (RB; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; FH/09/21/01/pc:ok). • branch of a tree, limb.

•• JOD: kaxá <§ka-qa´> a limb, bough, or branch of a tree; a branch of a stream, a stream of water, a creek or river.

••• KS gaxáhì`gaį creek, small, branch, fork (RR).

••• Cf. ëâà káxa.

káxa ëì (variants: kaxáëi, kaxáëì, káxe ëì). NP branch, small creek or stream (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; FH:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p13; RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). [This term was used for 'creek' by some older Osage speakers in Oklahoma in the 1990s.]

•• LFD 48: kaxá ëìka <ga-xa´ zhiæ-ga> small limbs of a tree; a little branch or runlet. kaxá <ga-xa´> a branch; a creek. kaxa ëìka kçe ëoáhe <ga-xa zhiæ-ga ke zhu-a´-he> [expected Mod. Os. form: káxa ëì kçe ëóapçe] I waded across the creek. kaxáhtàka <Ga-xa´¾oæ-ga> Big Branch; Big Pawnee, Oklahoma.

kaxé, káxe (variants of káxa).

kaëâsi. N unmarried person, maiden (JOD). [It is not clear whether this word was used only of women, or of either men or women.]

••• KS gaëâsi virgin, unmarried person (RR).

ke. POSIT positional article for dispersed, scattered, or randomly located entities (modifies noun or noun phrase). haaská wasúhuëike paahípai, çäúuwasu htai be sorting the [scattered] dirty clothes, let's you wash them (i.e., 'how about you [pl.] wash them?') (FH/11/17/01/pc). táatà ðéke hôòëike these bad things [scattered around]. oçcéke remainders or leftovers that are scattered around. haxîke opétkxà wrap up those blankets [lying around haphazardly, not stacked neatly] (03/22/95/FH/pc). waaëîkake wáðaawa count the [scattered] birds. hôòëìke these bad things around. haxî hkôbra ke ðíe ðikØu apai the blankets [lying around] that I want are the ones she gave you (3-2-209). • SUFFIX around, in dispersed locations or with dispersing action. táatà hpíiëì ecíke tà if there are bad things around. ecíke be around, exist around. nâãe ðaaxôke çò akxai híi ðiixôkape while he was chewing ice, he broke his tooth.

hòbrîke che hpaahíke I sorted the beans (FH).

•• LFD 175: oscéke <u-stse´-ge> [expected Mod. Os. form: oçcé 'remainder' + ke 'scattered'] the rest that are scattered about.

ki. PPN in, into, at, on. htaacé ki waachí eeçkítà kíhòòpe he also liked the way they danced in the wind (RBn15-02). waachí ki to the dance. htâwà ki oálìì I live in town (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). • to s.t. pl. or multiple. paaãó ámaçi ki up into the mountains. paaãó ki aðáape they went to the mountains (RBn10-12:JW). waachí ki pçíe ðe I went to the dances (04/26/95/FH/pc).

htáwà ki çäée tà ðúhpeece tóe aðîli when you go to town [viewed as a collection of buildings], bring back some matches (RBn12-07).

ki-. PREFIX (dative prefix, indicating that an action is done in the presence of s.o. [e.g., ékie 'speak in the presence of s.o.'], for the benefit of s.o. ["benefactive"], in place of s.o., or to s.o. else's possession; can also indicate action transferring s.t. to s.o.). [Dative ki- is omitted after pronominal prefixes (ki-del.) in most but not all verbs. Verbs where dative ki- is retained include ékie 'talk for another, talk in the presence of others' (ki- precedes the pronominal subject) and kípçe 'brush s.o.'s hair'.] kíðuwì apai they're buying it for him, they are buying it from him, they are buying what is his. wiëîke kípà she's calling wiëîke [Sonny] [to appear before others] (FH). çôke kíðuwì buy the dog for him. àkísupa pay for it for me. ékipçe I spoke [before others]. akípçe I brushed her hair.

ki-. PREFIX (inceptive prefix) anew, again, in reaction, in return, back. [Inceptive ki- is retained after pronominal prefixes (ki-ret.) in most but not all verbs.] okíce search for an item again [ki- + océ]. kiðíiçki rewash. wahkôta iëîke iikitáðe Christmas, birthday of the son of God (lit., 'God's son is born again' [implying that the day recurs]). kiçúpe to pay back, repay. kiðúwì to buy back (an item that one had before or sold).

ki- (variant of kik-).

kícheðe (variant: kíche). V [reg.?, kíche_ðe?] (trans.) keep, set aside, put away, save as a memento or treasure. kícheðaa patâhà they set it [the date, the occasion] aside (HREsr#68). •• JOD (slip file): kíicheðe <¦ki´-i-tse´-¢ªe> to put a standing object back in its place (?).

kiðá (variant: kíða). ADJ each. hóxpe níhkaçie kiðá áðìpe each person, everyone has this sickness (01/20/95/PM/pc). haxì ðé, ðée apa kiðá aðî hkôbra I want each of them to have this blanket for his/her own; they can all call it theirs, as each one has a part in this blanket (01/20/95/PM/pc:prod orig; BE2.38; RBn1-MOJ/p52b).

•• RB: <kí-tháh>.

kíðahapa (variant: kíðaha). V [reg. ki-del., _(kí)ðahapa] (intr.) be apart, separated, divorced, divided, distant, or estranged from each other (e.g., an estranged married couple, egg yolks separated from whites). kíðahapáe they're separated [by physical distance]

(02/22/95/FH/pc:prod orig; 04/14/95/PM/pc:ok). kiðáhapa nà they are separated from one another [as in a divorce], they're divided (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). • (trans.) divide or separate the parts of s.t.; separate from, divorce, or become estranged from. hpáata ðe kíðahapa àhé I'm dividing the egg yolk from the white (lit., 'I'm separating the egg') (04/14/95/PM/pc:ok). áðahapa hta mìkçé I'm going to quit him/jump from him (04/14/95/PM/pc:prod). áðahapa I divorce him. ðáðahapa you divorce him. kíðahpa he divorces her. àkíðahapa we divorce.

•• RB: <ki-tháh-hah pah-nah>.

kiðálì (variant: kíðalì). V [stat. ki-del., _ðálì] (intr.) be glad, feel good (also used as an equivalent of 'thank you'). âàðalì I'm glad. ðíiðalì you're glad. kíðalì she's glad. wáaðalì(?) we're glad. àðálì I feel good, I'm glad, I like it, thank you (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.59). • (trans.) like, love, enjoy, be happy about, be pleased with. ooðáha tà âðalì when you cook, I like it (RBn; MREI/01/11/93). háazu ëúuce âðalì I like red grapes (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc). ëààníe kíðalì he likes candy (02/16/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.79). htáa ðaaché kíðalìpe she likes to eat meat (FH). waðáahtà kíðalìpe he likes to drink (02/16/95/FH/pc:ok). ëìkáëì pa kíðalì nàpé the children enjoy it. ëààníi ðaaché ààðálì I enjoy eating candy (3-10-83-A; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.64).

•• LFD 52: kíðalì <gi´-tha-gthiæ> he is pleased. LFD 57: házu ëúuce àðalì ha <ha´-ši zhu-dse oæ-tha-gthiæ ha>[sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I like red grapes. LFD 104: màëâxe âðalì <moæ-zhoæ´-xe oæ-tha-gthiæ> I like onions. màëâxe ðiðalì <moæ-zhoæ´-xe thi-tha-gthiæ a> do you like onions? LFD 135: htáabre kiðalì <ta´-bthe gi-tha-gthiæ> one who loves to hunt, a sportsman.

kíðe (variant: kíe). CAU [reg. ki-ret., _kíðe] [ki- DAT or kik- SUU + ðe CAU] (trans.) make or have s.o. engage voluntarily in some act; let or allow s.o. to do s.t. ëìkáëì haxî ì kíðape he had his children wear their blankets. ììhô akxa çîtoëì hiiðá kí[ð]ape the mother had the child take a bath.

kíðiixò. V [stat. ki-del., _(kí)ðixò] [ki- DAT + ðiixô] (trans.) break off or break s.o.'s (e.g., body part). áa ðíiðiixòpe they broke your arm. áa kíðiixòpe they broke his arm. âàðiixò they broke my. ðíiðiixò they broke your. kíðiixò they broke his. wáaðiixòpe they broke our. wáaðiixò they broke their.

kiðúuze. V [sync. ki-del., (ki)_ðúuze] [ki- DAT + ðuuzé] take away from s.o. kiðúuza màðî go take it away from him (03/16/95/JS/pc). wáawaëì âçcuuze hta níkçé? are you going to take pennies/change away from me? (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; LS ok; BE2.131). wahkôta táatà hpíiëi âðuuze God takes away bad things from me (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok). wahkôta akxa táatà hpíiëi wáðuuze God takes away bad things [from us, from them] (FH/09/23/01/pc). wahéhe mìkçé àëi sisí nìkçé, wahkôta táatà hpíiëi àðúuzai I am weak but thou art strong, Jesus keep me from all wrong (MJ partial version of the Christian hymn "I Am Weak But Thou Art Strong"). ðíðuuze they took something away from you (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). wáawaëì ðíðuuze hta apai they are going to take pennies away from you (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

kíðuwì. V [reg. ki-del.+sync., _(kí)_ðuwì] [ki- DAT + ðuwî] (trans.) buy for s.o., buy in s.o.'s place for the benefit of a third person. ábruwì I bought it for him. ðáçcuwì you bought it for him. kíðuwì she bought it for him. hkâàce tóa kíðuwì she's buying him some apples. kíðuwì they bought it for him. âðuwì we bought it for him. hkâàce tóa âðuwì buy me some apples [for him or her].

kíðuwì. V [sync. ki-ret., kí_ðuwì] (trans.) buy from s.o. (s.t. that belongs to that person). kíbrúwì I'm buying it from him.

kíe (variant of kíðe).

kiãúhke(?). N comfort (HHt9b-p2, unconfirmed).

kih- (variant of kik-).

kíhike. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíhike] (trans.) be chief over.

•• JOD: wikíhikape eðaú [Mod. Os. omits eðaú] I have been chief over you.  

kihkápo. N Kickapoo Indians.

•• RB: <ki-káh-po> (04/11/95/LS/pc:uk; BE2.73, unconfirmed; 02/14/95/FH/pc:uk, but kihkápo pron. corrected).

kíhkà (variants: kihkâ, kíhkò). V [reg. ki-ret., _kíhkà] (trans.) fan off, as at a peyote meeting

(RB; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). há, kihkâpi you [pl.] fan them off (PM/7/7/94; RBn11-02). ðikíhkà

hta apai they're going to fan you off. ðikíhkò ðée pa, ðe these people want to fan you off (01/23/95/PM/pc:prod). àkíhkà fan me off (BE2.43). kíhkà káaãa fan him, fan him off (PM

7/7/94; 7/8/94). há, kíhkâpi [you pl.] fan them off [possibly colloquial use of 'them' for 'him/her']. wákíhkà fan them off (PM/pc). • N fan, fanning (RB).

••• Cf. kahkâ.

kíhkoopçe. V [reg.? (not known whether ki-del. or ki-ret.), _kíhkoopçe?] [ki- SUU (or DAT or both?) + hkóopçe] run off (on s.o.), abandon, leave (s.o.). wakØó apa kíhkoopçe apai his wife ran off on him. kíhkò (variant of kíhkà).

kíhleke (variant of kíleke).

kíhòò. V [stat. ki-del., _(kí)hòò] (trans.) like, love. [Synonymous with kiðálì.] waëáëe ónòbre âhòò I like Osage food (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc). ooðáhà tà âhòò when you cook I like it (RBn; MREI/01/11/93). waaðáçtò tà âhòò when you sing I like it (RBn (MREI/01/11/93). waskåe táatà ðíhòò? what kind of candy do you like? (RBn10-18; CQc). táata ðíhòò íçpahò? do you know what you like? (RBn22-20). táata âhòò íhpahò, ìcé ðuuhpíiëi âhòò I know what I like, I like to make faces (RBn22-20). htáa ðaaché kíhòòpe she likes to eat meat (FH). waðáahtà kíhòòpe he likes to drink, he loves to drink (RBn2-MOJ/p22; 02/16/95/FH/pc:ok). htaacé ki waachí eeçkítà kíhòòpe he also liked the way they danced in the wind (RBn15-02). ëìkáëì watxâ kíhòò those kids like squash.

•• LFD 51: kíhò aëi <gi´-hoæ a-zhi> he does not like it.

••• Cf. hôòëi. 

kihôòëi. V [stat. ki-del. _(ki)hôòëi] [kíhòò + aëí NEG] (trans.) dislike s.t. (FH); (intr.) grieve, be unhappy. kihôòëi hpáaãe I made him grieve (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). kihôòëi àkáaãape we made him grieve (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). kihôòëi çkáaãe you made him grieve (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). ílanàpi che kíhòòëipe he's unhappy because he is in disgrace (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). • N grief, anything one doesn't like (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 51: kihôaëi <gi-hoæ´-a-zhi> grief; sorrow. kíhòaëi kaãe <gi´-hoæ a-zhi ga-xe> made to grieve. kíhò aëi <gi´-hoæ a-zhi> he does not like it. kíhò aëi <gi´-hoæ a-zhi> to displease; to give dissatisfaction; to repine; to resent. âhò màëi <oæ´-hoæ moæ-zhi> I am displeased. ðíhò aëi <thi´-hoæ a-zhi> you are displeased. wáhò paëi pe <wa´-hoæ ba-zhi i> we are displeased.

kíhpaahi. V [reg.? ki-ret.?, _kíhpaahi?] [kik- SUU + paahí] (trans.) select from one's own people or items.

•• JOD (Devouring Mountain, p1 ln2): çímiëìka ðáalì kíhpaahi páta ëóle ahípe ska <Cími§ciñ§ka ¢á§k¢iæ kípahi-§pá§taæ §cú§k¢e ahí§pe ska> they would select good [or pretty] girls and take them there.

kíhpà. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíhpà] [kik- SUU + pâ] (trans.) call, invite one's relative(s). akíhpà I invite him. ðakíhpà you invite him. àkíhpà we invite him. wakíhpà hkôbra I want to invite my relatives (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). wihtáeëì akíhpà hkôbra I want to invite my sister (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). waachípità akíhpà hta mìkçé if they dance, I'm going to call him [my relative]. ðakíhpà paaçé? are you [pl.] inviting your relatives? (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

wihkípà achíe I have come to invite you [my relative] (HH/14-a/172ff&pc). wakíhpà akxai he's inviting his relatives (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). wihcíko apa wa(a)kíhpàpe Grandpa called us [his own grandchildren], Grandpa asked us to come (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). Carolyna ihcíko akxa kíhpà akxai Carolyn's grandpa is asking Carolyn to come (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). kíhpiiëi. V, ADJ [stat. ki-del., _(kí)hpiiëi] (be) sad. âhpiiëi I am sad. ðíhpiiëi you're sad. wáhpiiëi we're sad. John akxa ðée nàkØôpi áha, wálì kíhpiiëi hínààëìpe when John heard that, he got very sad.

kihtôpe. V [reg. ki-ret., _kihtôpe] [kik- SUU + tôpe] (trans.) watch one's own things, look at one's own things. wacúe skúe áhkihtòì hce let me look at my cake.

kihúheka. V [stat., ki-del., _(ki)húheka (1st dual and 1st pl. subject can be either à- or wa-; ki- is sometimes omitted in 3rd person subject forms as well)] (intr.) be sick, suffer from an illness. hâàpa tóa àhúheka I was sick for a few days (lit., 'for some days I was sick') (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). ðihúheka ðààçé áape anâkØò I heard you [moving, sg.] were sick

(03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). ðihúheka ëàkçí aape I heard you [lying down, sg.] were sick (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). húheka akxái she is sick (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok, he’s sick). wahúheka àkái we were sick; we are sick. àhúheka àkái we were sick; we are sick. àhúheka àðìkçé we two are sick (FH). wahúheka àðìkçé we two are sick. nàniôpaëì huuwáli apai húheka àkáaãe nàpé a lot of cigarettes make me sick (MSB 3-2-29). ðihúheka you're sick (02/13/95/FH/pc). àhúheka I am sick (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). hcéhpe kihúheka áape he had liver trouble [they said] (02/16/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.80). iihô kihúheka akxái his mother has a sickness (BE2.121; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).

•• LFD 62: húheka <hiu´-he-ga> sick, ill, sickness. àhúheka <oæ-hiu´-he-ga> I am sick (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ðahúheka <tha-hiu´-he-ga> you are sick. wahúheka pe <wa-hiu´-hega i> we are sick (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. húheka. 

kiistó. V [reg.? ki-ret.?, _kiistó?] (intr.) assemble (as for a council), gather for council, meet and talk things over. kiistó apa ska I guess they are counciling (said upon seeing many cars around a building) (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok). kiistó apa áape I heard they are counciling (01/13/95/FH/pc; BE2.26). kiistó omàì apai, kiistó màðì apai they're in the tribal council (MSBt#9a).

•• JOD (slip file): kistó <¦ki-stu´> to assemble in council.

••• KS gistó to gather or assemble (RR), kkistó council (RR).

••• Cf. hkiistó. 

kiixô. V [stat. ki-del. _(kii)xô] (intr.?) break one's own (e.g., a body part). aa ààxôpe my arm broke. aa ðiixôpe your arm broke. aa kiixôpe his arm broke. ëéka ààxôpe my leg broke (FH).

••• Cf. ðiixô, kíðiixò. 

kik- (variants: kih-, ki-). PREFIX one's own (suus prefix: object belongs to or is related to the subject). [kik- becomes kih- before c, k, p, t; while kik-ð simplifies to kð and becomes l (e.g., kik- + ðuuëá 'wash' becomes lúuëa 'wash one's own'); otherwise, kik- becomes simple ki-.] ëóðakile ðaìçé you are with him [family]. ëìkówahkihà óxtawakíe akxai grandchildren he's making his grandchildren special.

kikáaãe. VP [reg. ki-ret.+sync. k>p, _ki_káaãe] [ki- DAT + káaãe] (trans.) make or produce for s.o.  ëáëe kikáaãe. to sign (as a document), subscribe, undersign, affix one's signature (05/02/95/LS/pc:prod, non-preasp; HRE/12/29/01/ok).

kikáaãe. V [reg. ki-ret.+sync. k>p, _ki_káaãe] [ki- INCEPTIVE + káaãe] (trans.) make over, do over, repair or fix s.t. (belonging to oneself or to another person; e.g., repair a torn place in a dress), redo, reform (FH/98/pc; PM/10/13/96/pc). ákihpáaãe I make it over. ðákiçkáaãe you make it over. âkikáaãe we make it over. ëìkáëì wíhta wáðohta níhkaçika waðákiçkaaãe hkôbra I want you to make my children proper people (RBn19-06). ðakíçkaaãe? did you fix it? (01/26/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.48). Mary akxa haaská wì kikáaãape Mary made over a shirt. hpéece kikáaãa fix that fire (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.84).

kíkòða. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem+sync., kí_kò_ða] [ki- DAT + kôða] (trans.) want s.t. that is another's. oðíhtà ðíhta kíkòða akxai he's wishing for your car, he wants a car like yours.

kíkxà. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíkxà] (trans.) mourn (RBn22-12).

•• LFD 296: kíkxò <gie´-koæ> to mourn. akíkxà I mourn him. ðakíkxà you mourn him. àkíkxàpe we mourn him.

kíkxo (variant: kikxó). V [reg.? ki-ret.? _kíkxo?] (trans.) put on or prepare a feast for another or others, invite others to feast (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc; PM:2001:ok). wikíkxopi achíe I have come to invite you all to eat (04/14/95/FH/pc:okc; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; t14b-p3/170/HH; HRE/12). • N feast. waëáëe kikxó an Osage feast or dinner (FH).

•• LFD 284 (unconfirmed): kihkó <gi-Ðo´> [<Ð> may be a typographical error for <k>, Mod. Os. kx] invitation (formal). LFD 86 (unconfirmed): hkíhko <Ði´-Ðu> [expected Mod. Os. form: kíkxo (<ki´-kxu> in LF's transcription)] a feast. hkíhko sce <Ði´-Ðu stse> [expected Mod. Os. form: kíkxo çcée] you go to a feast [unconfirmed; 04/25/95/PM/pc:no].

••• OM gíkhu invite another to a feast, ðíkhui you are invited (JOD, RR).

kikØô. V [reg.? ki-ret.?, _kikØô?] (trans.) paint the face of a deceased person, apply face paint (RBn12-07, unconfirmed). kikØô hta pa? are they going to paint him [in the religious Indian way for burial]? (FH#128), áahukØoe kikØô kçíe hta apái Henry [áahukØoe] is going to [have someone] paint him [for burial] (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.101, RBn2-MOJ/p21). • N makeup, cosmetics, face paint.

•• RB: <kí-k'ó> face paint; also makeup, cosmetics (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 73: íhkikØò <i´-Ði-Ð'oæ> to put upon the face as a symbol: from a ritual.

kíkØu. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíkØu] [ki- INCEPTIVE + kØú] (trans.) give back (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). àkíkØu give it back to me (BE2.55).  

kíkØu. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíkØu] [kik- SUU + kØú] (trans.) give to one's own, give away to one's own people. haaskámi wì akíkØu hkôbra I want to give you [my relative] a shawl (RBn106:JW). hpáaëì iihô akxa kíkØupe the mother gave it to her baby. haxî waðákikØu you gave them [your own people] blankets. haxî àðakíkØu you gave me [your relative] a blanket.

ónòbre hîì, waðákikØu pi you gave us groceries (lit., 'groceries you gave us').

••• Cf. wakíkØu. 

kíleke (variant: kíhleke). V [reg.+reg.?, _kí_leke] [kik- SUU + kaaléke] (trans., intr.) break s.t. of one's own by shattering, shatter one's own. [Expected but unattested Mod. Os. forms are as follows: akíaléke 'I shatter my own', ðakíðaléke 'you shatter your own', kíhleke she shatters her own', àkíhléke 'we shatter our own'.] mâze içtola akíàleke I broke my glasses (lit., 'I broke my own glasses unto myself').

••• Cf. ðuuléke, paaléke.

kilôëe. V [reg. ki-del.?, _(ki)lôëe?] [apparently contains ki- DAT] (trans.) curse, bewitch or "witch" s.o., cast a spell on a person (04/25/95/PM/pc:prod; FH/ok). [The form kilôãe would have been expected instead, judging from Mod. Os. íðòãe and ilôãe, LFD's hkilôãe, and related forms in KS.]

•• LFD 86: hkilôãe <Ði-gthoæ´-xe> to practice magic upon each other. [A reciprocal form; no dative form of this stem is found in LFD.]

••• KS lóãe to bewitch, to practice sorcery, to shoot projectiles (RR).

kilúuze. V [reg. ki-ret., _kilúuze] [ki- DAT + lúuze] (trans.) take s.t. of s.o.'s own away, take s.o.'s own from him/her. kíluuza! take it away from him! kíluuze màðì! go take it [something that is his] away from him! (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; RBn14-06).

kínàkØò (variant: kínakØò). V [reg. ki-ret., _kínàkØò] [kik- SUU + nàkØô] (trans.) hear s.t. about s.o. or s.t. belonging to or connected with oneself.

•• JOD (letter from Wasa§pe-§ciñ§ka to Prudy Eagle-feather, Carlisle, Pa., p1 ln4): ókaçe ðìké ðaìçé oðáha wikínakØò àðâkiha hkôbra <ú§kacé ¢iñ§ké ¢á¢iæcé u¢áha wi§kínak'ªuæ a ¢añ´§kiha kªuæ§p¢au´> I always want to hear that you are fine.

kiní (variant: kiníe). V [stat. ki-ret. (2nd person), reg. ki-ret. (1st sg.), _kiní] [ki- INCEPTIVE + ní 'be well, live'] (intr.) heal, recuperate, recover from illness (lit., 'be alive anew'). kiní akxai it's healing (e.g., a sore) (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod; RBn1-MOJ/p40). kóota akxa kiní akxai that one over there is recovered (FH/09/25/01/prod). ðikínie? are you recovered?

(FH/09/25/01/prod). akínie I'm recovered (FH/09/25/01/prod). • [ki- DAT + ní 'be well, live'] (trans.) live for another or others. akínie I live for him. ðikínie you live for him. àkínie we live for him.

•• LFD 51: kiní <gi-ni´> to recover from sickness. à kíni bre ha <oæ gi´-ni bthe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I am getting well.

••• Cf. kitâhe. 

kiní káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, kiní _káaãe] [contains variant of kiníe] (trans.) heal (lit., 'make to recover').

•• LFD 51: kiníkaãe <gi-ni´-ga-xe> to heal; restore to health.

kiníe (variant of kiní).

kíopxa. V [stat. ki-del., _(kí)opxa] (intr., trans.) understand, be able to understand. âopxa I understand it. ðíopxa you understand it. kíopxa he understands it. wáopxa (?) we understand it. íiðai ðíopxái nàkxâçe those of you who can understand (said when addressing a crowd, some of whom do not understand Osage) (04/06/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.147).

••• Cf. wáopxa. 

kíopxaëi (variant: kiópxaëi). V [stat. ki-del., _(kí)opxaëi] [kíopxa + aëí NEG] N (trans., intr.) be ignorant (of s.t.), be vague about, not understand, be unable to understand (RBn1-23; 04/06/95/PM/pc:ok). âopxaëi I didn't understand. ðíoxpaëi you didn't understand (04/26/95/FH/pc). kíoxpaëi she didn't understand. âopxaëi àðikçe we [two] didn't understand (04/26/95/FH/pc). waléze tóa bráace àëi âopxaëi I read some letters but I was vague [didn't understand] (02/27/95/JS/pc:okc; 04/26/95/FH/pc:ok). âopxaëi I don't understand (HH/14a/172&pc). kíopxaëi they don't understand it (RBn19-05  

••• Cf. pxáðaëi. 

kíoxta. V [stat. ki-del., _(kí)oxta (transitive with stative object and stative subject pronominal prefixes; object pronominal prefixes precede subject pronominal prefixes)] [ki- DAT + óxta] (trans.) cherish, love, like, treasure or honor s.o. [In 3rd person form, this verb is indistinguishable from suus kíoxta.] wíoxta I love you (RB). âðioxta you love me (FH/10/12/95/prod). ëìkáëì wáðioxta ðààçé you are honoring the children (FH/10/12/95). ëìkáëì wað[i]óxta ðààçé you love the children. wað[i]óxta you love them. âoxta I love him. ðíoxta you love him. níhka wakØó kíoxta the man loves the woman (FH:4/25/96/tape:prod). çîtoëì akxa çôëì kíoxta akxai the boy likes/treasures the little dog (FH:4/25/96/tape). ée âoxtape he/she/it loves me. ðíoxtape he loves you. àkóe âoxtape we love him. àkóe waóxtape they like us.

kíoxta. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíoxta] [kik- SUU + óxta] (trans.) love one's own (relative[s] or s.o. else close) (7/8/94/PM/#98b). [In 3rd person form, this verb is indistinguishable from dative kíoxta.] wíkióxta I love you (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). awákióxta I love them all (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok: not àwà). ëîka owáhkihà awákióxta I love my grandchildren (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.82).

kíòòða. V [reg.+sync., _kíòò_ða] [kik- SUU + ôòða] (trans.) leave behind one's own.

•• LFD 8: ákahahpa akiòòbra achi mìkçe o <a´-ga-ha-pa a-gi oæ-btha a-tsi miæ-kshe o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I left my vest home.

kípà. V [reg. ki-del., (kí)_pà; sometimes reg. ki-del. +sync. fortisizing stop stem, _(kí)_pà (ki- may appear in forms without full inflection)] [ki- DAT + pâ] (trans.) call or visit to ask or summon s.o. to attend or appear before others (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). âàpà he calls me. ðíipà he calls you. kípà he calls her. wáapà he calls us. wáapà he calls them. áapà I call him. 

ðáaçpà you call him. kípà she calls him. âàpà we call him. wíhpà achíe I came to invite you (RBn10-20). Carolyna kípà apai they're asking Carolyn to come (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). wáapàpee they called us (to appear) (PM, pc; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). çée txà kípà call him [standing]. kípà ðíe! call him over here! Johna ðáaçpà you invited John (MSB051283; PM). âpà ìkçé we're inviting him (5-12-83-2). wáhpài I'm inviting them (5-12-83-2). ðíipà akxai he's calling you (2-10-8). âàpà apai they're calling me, inviting me. • invite s.o. (not a relative). ðíipàpi? did they invite you? (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc; BE2.71). wanôbre âàpàpi I am invited to eat (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc). kípà apai they invited him [kípà is reportedly for sg. object 'him/her' only, not pl. object 'them' (PM)]. miðôhta tà wanôbre wáapàpi they invited us to [the] noon meal (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc). záani wáapàpi we are all invited (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc). âpà ìkçé we're inviting him (MSB). wíihpa mìkçé I'm inviting you (MSB051283). wáhpai [expected form: áhpai] I'm inviting him (5-12-83-p2).

•• LFD 50: kípà <gi´-boæ> to summon; to call to appear. ðípà pe ha <thi´-boæ i ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you were called to appear. âpà pe ha <oæ´-boæ i ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I was summoned.  

••• Cf. kíhpà. 

kípçe. V [reg. ki-ret. _kípçe] [ki- DAT + káapçe] (trans.) brush or curry the mane or coat of an animal (RBn2-MOJ/p6; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). hkáwa kípçe akxa they're brushing the horse's mane. • brush or comb s.o.'s hair. àkípçe they're brushing my hair, they're combing my hair (04/13/95/LS/pc; FH:4/22/96/tape: not hk). àkípça brush my hair (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.13). akípçe I brushed her hair, I combed her hair (FH).

kíse. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíse] [ki- DAT + kaasé] (trans.) cut s.t. for s.o.

•• JOD (slip file, under §kí-sªe 'to cut wood, etc., for another'): àkísa <Añ§kísa> cut (them) for me. [The expected Mod. Os. meaning of this form would be 'cut it for me'.]

•• LFD 50: kíse <gi´-še> to cut wood for someone. akíse <a-gi´-še> I cut wood for him. ðakíse <tha-gi´-še> you cut wood for him. àkísa pe <oæ-gi´-ša i> we cut wood for him.

kisúðaëi (variants: kisúaëi, kusúaëi). V [reg. ki-ret., _kisúðaëi] [kisúðe + aëí NEG] (trans., intr.) forget. awákisue màëí I forgot them (3/3/83/MSB; FH). akísue màëî I forgot (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc). ðakísuaëi did you forget? (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc). küsúaëì he forgot. àkísuaëi apá they forgot about me (RBnot-nd-1/p10; 01/30/95/FH/pc:okc). kisúaëi ðîké! don't forget!

•• LFD 50: kisúðaëi <gi-ši´-tha-zhi> to forget. akísiðamàëi <a-gi´-ši-tha-moæ-zhi> I forgot. ðakísiða ëi <tha-gi´-ši-tha zhi> you forgot. àkísiði paëi pe <oæ-gi´-ši-thi ba-zhi i> we forgot.

kisúðe (variants: kisúe, kusúe). V [reg. ki-ret., _kisúðe] (trans.) remember. wikísue I remember you (RBn14-06). àkísue àkái ìhtáci ðakØéða ðì we're remembering her, father, bless her (FH:prayer). küsúðe a remember it (RBn10-5:JW). ðée ékiòpai [ðe] àðákisuðe çkôçtapi tà do this in remembrance of me (lit., 'do this when you want to remember me') (FH/09/11/01/pc).

wahkôta oðáhkiepi tà àkísuepai when you talk to your God, remember me (FH/09/24/01/pc/prod). akísu[ð]e maëí I don't remember. ðakísu[ð]eëi you don't remember. àkísu[ð]e àðìkçé we [two] don't remember. kisú[ð]apé he remembered.  

kíçkace. V [reg. ki-del., _(kí)çkace] [ki- DAT + çkáce] (trans.) play with s.o. (i.e., with any animate being). çôëì áçkace âhòò I like to play with the puppy [someone else's].

kíçkace. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíçkace] [kik- SUU + çkáce] play with s.o. related to oneself, or with animate being of one's own. çôëì akíçkace âhòò I like to play with the puppy [mine].

kíçupe. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíçupe] [ki- DAT + kaçúpe] (trans.) pay s.o., pay for s.o. awánôbre tà àkíçupa ði if I eat, you pay for it (FH). àkíçupapé he paid me [back] for it (MREI). àðíkiçupé we paid you [back] for it (MREI). àðákiçupe you paid me [back] for it (MREI). âkiçupa pay me, pay it for me, pay for it (03/06/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.101). àðikiçupe na we paid you for it. àçúpa ðíe pay me for it. ehtà, âkíçupai well, pay me [for what I did] (RB). • [ki- INCEPTIVE + kaçúpe] (trans.) pay back, repay, reimburse. ákiçupe I repaid him. ðákiçupe you repaid him. ðakíçupe? did you pay them back? (FH/12/1/9øpc).

•• JOD (slip file, under <§ki-cü-´§pe>): íðakíðe tà, wikíçupe hta mìkçé <I´¢a§kí¢ªe-§taæ´, wi§kícü§pe ta-miñkci au> if you find it, I will pay you.

•• LFD 189: akíçipe <a-gi´-shi-be> I repaid him. ðakíçipe <tha-gi´-shi-be> you repaid him. àkíçipa pe <oæ-gi'-shi-ba i> we repaid him. [The form wakíçipe <wa-gi´-shi-be>

(LFD 189) is a valence-reduced form; see wakíçupe.]

kítaake. V [reg.? ki-ret., _kítaake] [ki- DAT + taaké] (trans.) fight, fight against. hpôhka àkítaake we fight the Poncas (BE2.46).

kitâhe. V [reg. ki-ret., _kitâhe] [ki- INCEPTIVE + tàhé] (intr.) improve (with regard to an illness), get better (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p39). ðakítàhe hkôbra I want you to get better (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig). mâhka ëóika mâì akxai, kitâhe hta akxa hôòpa hu he's haywire with peyote but he'll be all right at daylight (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.102; RBn HW). kitâhe hkôbra I want him/her to get better (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; 02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

haaská nà àðíðihtapi tà àkítàhe nàpe just a touch of your garment makes us well (lit., 'if we touch only your garment, we get well') (FH/09/11/01/pc). àkítàhe àkôða we want to get better (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig; BE2.71; ok).

•• LFD 50: kitâhe <gi-doæ´-he> he is better.

••• Cf. kiní.

kítàhe. V [stat. ki-ret., _kítàhe] [ki- INCEPTIVE + tàhé] (intr.) heal fully, get well. [Contrast kitâhe (reg.).] àkítàhe I got well. ðikítàhe you got well. kítàhe he got well. wakítàhe we got well. ðikítàhè hkôbra I want you to get/be well (a wish for one's friend or family)

(03/09/95/MREI/pc; prod). haaská nà çäihtà tà ðikítàhe hta if you just touch his garment you could get well (FH/pc). kítàhe it makes him well (FH/09/25/01/prod). wakítàhe it makes us well (FH/09/25/01/prod).  

kitôpe (variant: kitô). V [reg. ki-ret. + sync. fortisizing stop stem, _ki(_)tôpe; object

pronominals appear only in the first slot] [ki- DAT + tôpe] (trans.) see s.o.; look with regard to s.o., look down on (benevolently), watch over. ðáalì àðákiçtò ðachí che it's good you came to see me (RBn10-15). ðáalì waëô waðákitò ðachí che it is good what you've done, to come and see us (RBn1-2). waðákiçtôpapi håðe hkòbra I want you to [come and] look down upon us (MSB t2-s2). wakítòpapi håða look down upon us (MSB/t2-s2; 02/22/95/FH/pc:ok).  

kítòpe (variant: kítò). V [reg.+sync., _kí_tòpe] [ki- DAT + tôpe] look at s.t. that belongs to s.o. kítòpa ði look at what he's got (as when one looks in someone's sack to see if something is all there or see if it's what it is supposed to be) (FH:prod).

kíwaata. V [reg. ki-del. _(kí)waata] [ki- DAT + waatá] (trans.) pray for (RBn10-15, unconfirmed). [Expected forms are as follows: áawaata 'I pray for him', àðáawaata 'you pray for me', àkíwaata 'we pray for him', awáawaata 'I pray for them', âàwaata 'pray for me', ðíiwaata 'he prayed for you', kíwaata 'pray for him', wáawaata 'pray for us', wáawaata 'pray for them'.]

kíwalì (variants: kíwahlì, kíwali). V, ADJ [stat. ki-del., _(kí)walì] [ki- DAT + wálì 'selfish'] [Mod. Os. kíwalì  'stingy' was earlier ki- + wáxlì and is not related to wáli 'lots, much, very' (although the final vowel of both words now varies between nasal ì and nonnasal i).] (trans.) 

(be) stingy or selfish with, reluctant to share s.t. of one's own because of valuing it so highly (03/14/95/MREI/pc:prod). âàwalì I'm stingy with it. ðíiwalì you're stingy with it. kíwalì he's stingy with it. wáawalì we're stingy with it. hpéãe ðe âàwalì mìkçé I'm really stingy with this gourd (03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc: [sitting]; RBn2-MOJ/p37; 02/03/95/FH/pc:okc, not ki). oðíhtà kíwali akxái he's stingy with his car (03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.128; RBn2-MOJ/p36).

• value, prize, or treasure s.t. hci ðíiwali? do you value your home? (03/14/95/MREI/pc) hcí âàwalì I value my home (03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc). kíwali he values it. hci àkóhta wáawali we value our home (MREI).  

•• LFD 52: kíwali <gi´-wa xthi> to value highly some particular property. kíwali <gi´wa-xthi> to prize very highly that which is one's own. hcíche wawali pe <¾si´-tse wa-waxthi i> we value our home. hcíche àwali ha <¾si´-tse oæ-wa-xthi ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I value my home. hcíche ðiwali <¾si´-tse thi-wa-xthi> you value your home. mi óðaake ðà àwacheli ha <mi u´-tha-ge thoæ oæ-wa-tse-xthi ha> [verb appears garbled (should be âàwali rather than àwacheli); sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I prize my watch. nàpe oðíla ðà àwacheli ha <noæ-be u-thi´-xtha thoæ oæ-wa-tse-xthi ha> [verb appears garbled (should be ðíiwali rather than àwacheli); sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you prize your ring (unconfirmed; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:uk). LFD 53: kiwáliëi <Gi-wa´-xthi-zhi> Not-stingy, personal name.

••• KS gíwaxlì stingy (RR).

kíxope. V [conjug. unknown] [perhaps ki- DAT + xópe] (trans.) respect (RBn1-41).

kixô. V [stat. ki-del., _(ki)xô] [ki- DAT + xô] s.t. belonging to one breaks. [Possessor of the broken thing is expressed by patient pronominal prefixes.] àxôpe something of mine broke (MRB 2-24-83). ðixôpe something of yours broke. kixôpe something of his broke.

 

kízo. V, ADJ [stat. ki-del., _(kí)zo] (trans.) enjoy, like, (be) happy or glad about s.t. (12/30/94/FH/pc). âàzo I enjoy it. ðíizo you enjoy it. kízo she enjoys it. wáazo, waazô we enjoy it. kízo, wáazo, waazô they enjoy it [all three forms are correct and synonymous]. oðáha tà âàzo when you cook I enjoy it (RBn; MREI/01/11/93?). ðíizoëi xci nìkçé, háakò? 

you look very unhappy, what is it? (04/26/95/LS/pc:ma). kízo akxai he's enjoying it

(1/20/83/p5; 2/1/902). waachí kízo apa they are enjoying the dance (RBn1-25). waachí kízo apa they like to dance (12/30/94/dl:ok; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). kízope they enjoyed it. wáazope we enjoyed it (1/20/83/p5). wáazo we like (it). kízo káaãe gladden (or 'he/she gladdens him/her') (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). waðíihice wáazope he likes to tease (03/05/95/JS/pc). waðíihice kízope he likes to tease (03/16/95/FH/pc:okc; MREI/t116a). waazó ëìkáëì tóa kíðalì wakáaãape it was fun to make the children happy. hceeská apa niskúðe saakí kízope cattle like rock salt. • (intr.) have fun; feel enjoyment, be happy, have a good time. kízo ðaaçé you were having fun (RBn14-11). kízo apái he's having fun (RBn14-11). waazó àkái [expected form: wáazo] we were having fun (BE2.52; RBn14-11). kízo apai we had fun, we are having fun (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). waazóe àkçíe hta àkái we are going to make them have a good time (e.g., someone returning after being gone will be feted) (FH/07/09/01/pc). waazó apa they are having a good time (t108-b/FH/438). âàzo mìkçé I'm really having a good time

(04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). hâce kízo ðàìçé you were having a good time last night

(BE2.41;04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). kizó paaçé? [expected accent pattern: kízo] are you [pl.] having a good time? (FH). kízo apai he is having a good time, they are having a good time (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok, both). wáazi apa [expected form: wáazo apa; synonyomous with kízo apai] they are having a good time (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok with -zi or -zo). ékiò ðìká, wáazi àkatxâi! [expected form: . . . wáazo àkatxâ] don't do that, we're having a good time! (e.g., admonishment to a woman who is jealous of another and therefore would want to make trouble at an event). kízo apai we're happy (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). kízo ðìke he's unhappy (04/26/95/LS/pc). kízoëi she's sad (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). âzo maëí mìkçé I'm sad (MSB).

•• LFD 50: kízo <gi´-šu> to be happy. âzo <oæ´-šu> I am happy. ðízo <thi´-šu> you are happy. wázo pe <wa´-šu i> we are happy. kízo káaãe <gi´-šu-ga-xe> gladden; to make glad. ðâàce wihta kizo çkáaãe ha <thoæ´-dse wi-¾a gi-šu-shka-xe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] it gladdened my heart. kízo ðìke <gi´-šu thiæ-ge> without mirth; unhappy. ðizo ëi xci nikçe hakò? <thi-šu zhi xtsi ni-ke ha-goæ> you look very unhappy, what is it? LFD 138: htáapçe àzo <¾a´-pshe oæ-šu> I like pemmican. htáapçe ðizo <¾a´-pshe thi-šu> you like pemmican.

kízoëi. V, ADJ [stat. ki-del. _(kí)zoëi] [kízo + aëí NEG] (intr.) (be) lonesome, unhappy, sad, disconsolate. âàzo màëie I'm lonesome (RBn HW10). âàzo màëi mìkçé I'm sad, I'm lonesome.

•• JOD (slip file): kíçòëi <¦ki´-cªuæ-¦ci> to dislike; to disagree with; to disapprove of. kízo ëi <gi´-šu-zhi> crestfallen; despondent; disconsolate; dispirited; downcast.

•• LFD 50: kízo aëi <gi´-šu a-zhi> disconsolate; he is not happy over it. àzo màëi <oæšu moæ-zhi> I am downcast; I am disconsolate. ðizo aëi <thi-šu a-zhi> you are downcast; you are disconsolate. wazo paëi pe <wa-šu ba-zhi i> we are downcast; we are disconsolate.

kíëa. V [conjug. unknown] doubt(?).

•• LFD 53: kíëa <gi´-zha> to doubt another's word.

••• KS gíëa (JOD) doubt someone's word (RR), wagíëa (JOD), wagíëa ~ waagíëa doubt one's own (child, etc.) (RR).

••• Cf. waëá. 

kíëi. V [reg. ki-ret., _kíëi] [ki- DAT + kaaëí] (trans.) drive for s.o. oðíhtà âkiëi drive the car for me (RBn2-MOJ/p5, FH:okc, not **âka[a]ëì). oðíhtà kíëi drive for him (BE2.35; FH:prod.).

kîì. V [reg.?, _kîì] (intr.) fly (as birds do), ride in an airplane. waëîka akxa kîì akxa birds fly (01/26/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.49). kîì ékimà hta akxai, kóe môëò záani iiðáðe hta akxai if I could fly, then I could see the whole world (RBn15-02). kîì akxai he's flying (FH:prod). kìì ékiò fly (lit., 'do flying'). kîì aðée fly (lit., 'go by flying' or 'go by airplane'). • N airplane. kîì ðée hta apai they're going to fly (lit., 'they are going to go in an airplane') (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod; BE2.2). kîì olîì ride in a plane (lit., 'sit in an airplane') (FH).

•• JOD (slip file): kiâ <§ki-aæ´> v. to fly. 

•• LFD 51: kiô <gi-oæ´> to fly (unconfirmed; 01/26/95/FH/pc:uk).

kîìðe. V [reg. kîì_ðe] [kîì + ðe CAU] (trans.) throw (lit., 'cause to fly') (01/10/95/FH/pc:prod).

kîìkììeëì. N [reduplicated form] butterfly. màðî çò apa kîìkììeëì toa kîì ípçape while they were walking some butterflies came flying by (RBn15-01).

kóe. CONJ and then, and. níhkaçie kíhòòpe kóe màëâki olîì kíhòòpe he liked the people and he liked living on the farm (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). koe ónòò ëiçò çí tà çî tà koe hpíiëi ëiçò çí tà koe péeçki ðikôða htai wáçäuãe ðáalì [and] before you get old and before you get fat and ugly and nobody wants you, you should get married. • but, rather. táatà[e]ëiçki káaãe íisipe kóe wanôbre, hóo saakí, waachí kíhòpe he didn't like to do anything but eat, holler, and dance (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; RBn16-01).

kóoce (variant of kóoci).

kóoche (variant: kóochi). ADJ + POSIT (?) [perhaps kóoci + che POSIT] old and stacked or piled. haxî kóoche those old blankets that are stacked up there (FH/t116b).

kóoci (variant: kóoce). ADJ old-fashioned, old-time, antique, old, from far back in time, ancient (LS/04/26/95:prod). haxî kóoci çäúuwasu tà wíe paaçôwe if you'll clean that old-time blanket, I'll bind it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). haxî kóoci old blankets (03/22/95/FH/pc). • ADV long ago, once upon a time. kóoci waëáëe apa ðée ékiòpe àëi ðekôòci ðìkápi wihtáeëi akxa íkØuci akxai long ago Osages used to do that, but now they are gone and sister is trying her best (gloss by CQ; PM/7/7/94). kóoci, hci hpíiëi wì, paaxó ki, nàhtâhtà ëíhi wì hcílipe once upon a time, in a little shack in the hills, lived a little brown donkey (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). kóoci ékiape they said that a long time ago (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). kóoci wáazàpe a long time ago they bawled us out. kóoce waëáëi apa ée ékiapé a long time ago Osages used to say that. • for a long time. kóoci açkâà ààhé I've been going on for a long time (MOJ). • N those who lived long ago. kóoci apa those who lived long ago (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). kóoci apa ékie nàpe the ones that lived a long time ago used to say (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.81). kóoci apa ée ékiapé old-time people used to say.

•• LFD 56: kóci <gu´-dsi> in times past; a long time ago (primitive), farther into the house.

kootá. ADV farther over there, beyond, on the other side of s.t. (04/19/95/FH/pc:okc). ëâà akxa ápahta kootá ecí the tree is on the other side of the fence (04/19/95/FH/pc).

kóota. ADJ that yonder, that (person or thing) over there (beyond speaker and hearer). kóota níhka akxa óðuucØakape that man is lazy (RBn3-39). kóota wakØó akxa óðuucØakape that woman is lazy (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). kóota okála! face the other way! (RBn19-02). • PRON the farther one, in space or time. kóota ìkçé ohkíhce hôòxce ðìkçé? that one sitting over there, what kind of tribe is he? (03/23/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 53: kótaðiçò <go´-da thi-shoæ> on the other side (unconfirmed;

04/06/95/LS/pc:uk). kóta txà <go´-da toæ> that person standing yonder (unconfirmed; 04/26/95/LS/pc:uk).

kóota che. PRONP those farther over there (pl., inanimate only, beyond speaker and hearer). [Contains che, the positional article for pl. sitting nonsubjects (those that would take ìkçé when sg.).]

kóota ðe. PRONP that one over there (beyond speaker and hearer). kóota ðe níhka tôpa look at that man farther over there.

kóota ðée. ADVP (in the) future, future months (refers to traveling or going along in age, traveling down the road moving into the future) (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok; HH#38a-p1).

kóota ìkçé. PRONP that one sitting over there or yonder (beyond speaker and hearer). kóota ìkçé ohkíhce hôòxce ðìkçé? that one sitting over there, what kind of tribe is he? (03/23/95/FH/pc).

kóota kçe (variant: kootá kçe). PRONP that one lying over there (beyond speaker and hearer). kootá kçe pée ée kçe? that [one] lying over there, who is it?

kootáha. ADV [kóota + ha PPN] (to/from) farther away (in space); farther back, farther ahead (in time or space) (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; FH/07/09/01/pc). [Contrasts with kootáìke 'over there'.] kootáha nààëî stand farther over (FH). kootáha! move over! (e.g., said to a person taking up too much room in bed) (FH). kootáha alîì hkôbra move over because I want to sit down (FH). kootáha, kóotaha farther back in time (04/06/95/FH/pc:ok). • PPN beyond. níiëuuce kootáha beyond the Arkansas River (04/11/95/LS/pc:prod). • ADJ, PRON the next-to-last, the one before last. mîìòpa kootáha next-to-last month; the month before last.

• the one after next, the one past the next.  

•• RB: <gó-tah-hah>.

•• LFD 53: kotáha màðî o <go-da´-ha moæ-thiæ o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod.

Os.] go farther away (04/05/95/MREI/pc:ok). kotáha <go-da´-ha> go away; depart.

••• Cf. hâàpa kootáha ce, kaasî kootáha, sitôì kootáha ce.

kootáìke (variant: kootáìki). ADV over there, yonder, farther than another thing, way over there, way back in time or distance (04/06/95/FH/pc:ok). [Contrasts with kootáha 'farther away'.] kootâìke lîìpi you all sit over there (BE2.44; 04/06/95/FH/pc). kootâìke alîì hkôbra I want to sit over there. kootáìke nààëî go stand over there (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.126).

•• RB: <gó-taiæ-ki>. koça. N [accent perceived as equal in both syllables; possibly kooçá?] curve.

••• Cf. hpasúkoça. 

kôða. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem+sync., _kô_ða; infrequently with triple conjugation, reg.+sync. fortisizing stop stem+sync., _ _kô_ða] (trans.) want, desire. [2nd person form customarily lengthens the ô in interrogatives, though this is not normally indicated in writing: çkôòçta 'do you want?'.] hkôbra I want (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). hkôbra ìké I don't want to (do something). çée wihkôbra I want that for you (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ðée ka wì çkôçta? do you want one of these? háakò çkôçta tà ékiò do whatever you want to do

(03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ðée çkôçta? do you want this? (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). çkôçta? do you want

[it]? (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). kôða ìkí akxai he/she doesn't want to (do something)

(03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.150). mâzeska hâàna kôða akxa? how much money does he want? (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc). kôða he/she wants [it], they want [it] (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). àkôða we want [it] (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). kôða wáli to really want something; to crave it. waëáëeíe hpíò áhkôbra I want him to learn Osage [áhkôbra: triple conjugation] (RBn10-7:JW). hpíò áhkôbra I want him to learn, I want him to learn it [áhkôbra: triple conjugation] (04/14/95/PM/pc:ok; RB).

•• LFD 53: kôða walì <goæ´ tha wa-gthiæ> to crave; a longing (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). khokhóma hkòbra walì <ku-ku´-ma Ðoæ-btha wa-gthiæ> [expected Mod. Os. form:

hkohkóma rather than khokhóma] I have a longing for cucumbers. ëàànii çkòçta walì <zhoæni shkoæ-shda wa-gthiæ> you crave sugar.

kôðawaðe (variant: kôðaéewaðe). V [reg., kôðawa_ðe] [kôða + wa- VAL + ðe CAU] (trans.) make folks want to, make one want to. óohò kôðawai it makes one want to cook. hòpái mâàãe akxa ðáalì akxái, opáwìãe kôðaéewae today the weather is good, it makes one want to go riding (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

kôkòe. V [conjug. unknown] [reduplicated form] (intr.) go around. kôkòe nàpé he would go around and around (FH/11/19/01/pc:uk). çí kôkòe apai, ëìkáëì apa páskuha nààkí apai he went round and round, children ran beside him (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). • N merry-go-round, carousel.

kòpé. N hackberry, hackberries.

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p21 ln6): kòpé <§kuæ§pé>.

kòzé. V [sync. k>p, _kòzé] (trans.) pretend, feign, make believe. [Unconfirmed by modern speakers.]

•• JOD (slip file): kòzé <koæ-§se´> pretend [but:] <§kªuæ´-§se é-§kªuæ>. kôze ékò alike, resembling something else referred to.

•• LFD 53: kòzé <goæ-še´> to feign; to make believe. hpòze <¼oæ-še> I pretend. àkòza pe <oæ-goæ-ša i> we pretend.

kôze. V [sync. k> p, _kôze] (trans.) teach s.t. to s.o.; show s.o. how to do s.t. iinâëì akxa kôze hta akxái my aunt is going to teach him (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok; not kikôze). iinâëì akxa ðikôze hta akxái my aunt is going to teach you (JS/pc:ok; BE2.133). wikôze hta mìkçé I'm going to show you (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).

••• Cf. hkihkôze, kçíòze, wakôze.

kòzéhkihkò. ADJ [hkik- REFL + kòzékò] similar to or like each other, resembling each other.

hkóða akxa hkáwa ðòòpá kòzéhkihkò waaðîpe my friend has two horses just alike.

•• LFD 53: kòzé hkikò <goæ-še´ Ði-goæ> alike; resembling.

kòzékò. ADJ, V [conjug. unknown, uninfl.?] (trans.?) (be) the same as or like another, like, similar to or identical to. hpôhkaíe waëáëeíe hôni kòzékò Ponca and Osage language are almost the same (FH:4/24/96/tape ; BE2.116) wacúe skue màçäîka kòzékò káaãa make the cake like a rabbit (FH:4/24/96/tape:prod). Mary akxa iihô kòzékò akxai Mary is just like her mother [acts like, looks like, or both]. hkâàcezi akxa watkxâ kòzékò akxai the orange is just like the pumpkin (FH:4/24/96/tape:prod). kòzékò káaãi akxai he's making it like that (FH:prod). éhta, ðáalì kòzékò àkái well, it's good we're just alike (RBn17-p02). htóoëu akxa nahkoî kòzékò akxai both those meat pies are just alike (FH:prod). kòzékò káaãi akxai he's making it like that (FH:prod). hpôhka íe waëáëe íe kòzéko Poncas and Osages talk the same

(03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; MREI)

•• JOD (slip file): kôze ékò <§kªuæ´-§se é-§kªuæ> alike, resembling something else referred to.

•• LFD 53: kòzékò <goæ-še´-goæ> alike in appearance; similar; uniform. LFD 38: tôpe kòzékò <doæ´-be goæ-še´-goæ> alike; look alike; similar. tôpe kòzekò pe, wakØo nòpa akxa <doæ´-be goæ-še-goæ bi a, wa-u noæ-ba a-ka> [expected Mod. Os. form: ðòòpá rather than nòpa] the women look alike [rather, 'the two women (here) look alike'].

kôëìka. V [sync. k>p, _kôëìka] (trans., intr.) be unskilled (at), not know how (to). wahôò hpáëika I don't know how to address folks. çkôëìka you don't know how; do you know how? [either a statement or a question] (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; 02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). kôëìka akxai he doesn't know how.

•• LFD 53: kôëìka <goæ´-zhiæ-ga> failure to do a thing for lack of skill; unskilled. hpôëìka <¼oæ´-zhiæ-ga> I am unskilled. çkôëìka <shkoæ´-zhiæ-ga> you are unskilled. àkôëìka pe <oæ-goæ´-zhiæ-ga i> we are unskilled.

kçâka (variant of kçôka).

kçe (variant: kçi). POSIT positional article for an entity that is lying down or long, used after a noun or pronoun that is not an active subject. mâàhisi wakØó kçe abrî I have the queen of spades. iihô kçe tàhé ìkçé? is his or her mother [who is bedridden or lying down] all right? ðiihô kçe tàhé akxai? how is your [bedridden] mother? môëò ðáalì ðé kçe môëò ðé kçe ðìké hta aaëi íe wíhta çòòçôwe aðée hta akxai heaven and earth shall pass away but my word will endure (lit., 'that good land lying there and this land lying here will be nothing but my word always will go on') (FH: from the Bible, Matthew 24:35) kóota kçe pée ée kçe? that [one] lying over there, who is it? çée kçe kØî alípe they hauled him back, they hauled back that one near you lying down (RBn23-17). hkáwa kçe húheka kçe? is that horse lying there sick? çôke ékçe háaëò? what are you going to do with that dog lying there? ëâà kçe the one sleeping over there (03/24/95/PM/pc). ípehì sí kçe ôò kçíe put a pillow under his foot

(03/08/95/FH/pc). ípehì áa kçe î kçíe put a pillow under his arm. tówa kçe çcéða! doctor that one lying there, doctor him! • POSIT positional article that indicates plurality of an inanimate entity that takes che 'standing' positional in the singular. [No examples available in Mod. Os.

data.]

•• LFD 224: ëâ kçe <zhoæ´ kshe> term used in speaking of a log lying on the ground. LFD 192: wahóhtàðe ímàkçe <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the i-moæ-kshe> the other of the two guns [the other lying down or long gun] (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 37 (unconfirmed): tóosku káxa kçe áçka ci alîì <Do´-škiu ga-xa ke a-shka dsi a-gthiæ> I live near Spring River [Sweet Potato Creek]. LFD 92: ëàà hkilé kçe ci amìce bree ha <zhoæ Ði-gthe´ ke dsi a-miæ-dse bthe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I crawled under the log.  

kçe (variant: kçi). CONT lying down or long (used clause-finally; often followed by áape, denoting reported information). çúpe kíhúheka kçí áape he [lying down] has stomach trouble, they said (RBn3-49). wáli húheka kçí áapa àëì nâaãeska kçí áape she [lying down] is awfully sick, but her mind is all right [they said] (FH/6/16/95). waðáahtà çtà éhtana céepe hpíiëi kçí aape he [lying down] has a bad liver from always drinking [they said] (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc). céepe hpíiëi kçí aape waðáahtà çtà éhna he [lying down] has a bad liver [they said] because he's always drinking (RBn3-55). wáli ðiiëóëipi kçí áape he [lying down] has really been hurt, they said (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.70). ëâà kçí áape that person's lying down, they said (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod orig). ée kçí áape [it is] she lying there, they said (RBn11-02). pée ée kçe? who is that over there lying down? çúpe iihúheka kçí áape he [lying down] has intestinal trouble, they said (12/30/94/FH/pc; FH/09/23/01/pc). içíkØà hcéze íihuheka kçí áape my sister-in-law [lying down] is sick with her stomach, they say (FH/09/23/01/pc:prod). àwâxpaðe, íkiçoce kçe I was lost in the [overlying] fog (01/26/95/FH/pc:okc).

kçe áape (variant of kçí áape).

kçi. PPN to, at, on, in that (something lying down or spread out lengthwise). wahkôtaki kçi pçíe ðe I went to the doctor [kçi is optional in this sentence; reference to the office of the doctor is implied] (04/26/95/FH/pc:okc). níiëuuce kçi màðî go to the river [imperative] (RBn16-02). lîìka áwanòbre kçí be seated at the table [imperative] (RBn1-3, 17). ânàkoe kçi lîîka sit on the porch [imperative] (HH/t38-sA-p2). htâwà kçi in town (contrasts with 'in the country' [RB]) (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

kçi (variant of kçe).

kçí (see akçí).

kçí áape (variant: kçe áape, kçíaape). REPORTATIVE [kçe CONT + áape] it is said of him/her lying down. çúpe kihúheka kçí áape they said he [lying down] has intestinal trouble (RB).

kçíðe (variant: kçíe). CAU [reg. _kçíðe] [ki- DAT + kíðe] (trans.) let or allow s.o. to do s.t. ée óhkà kçíe let her help (FH). íe ðée ochíchachae káaãe kçiðé ìká don't let him go on and on [talking] (MSB:t9). • have s.o. do s.t. for his/her own benefit. haxî ì kçíe have him wear a blanket. hiiðá àðákçie you had me bathe (MREI). wáleze ðée kçíe mail this letter to her ['to her' implied by kçíe] (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). waazóe àkçíe hta àkái we're going to show them a good time.

•• LFD 116: nôpØì kçiðe <noæ´-¼'iæ kshi-the> to cause one to wear something around the neck. wakØo ðe wánòpØì htà akçiðe ha <wa-Ð'u the wa´-noæ-¼'iæ ¾oæ a-kshi-the ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I caused the woman to wear a necklace.

kçíãe. V [reg. _kçíãe] [presumably ki- DAT + káaãe] (trans.) make or prepare for s.o. (e.g., prepare a bed, clothing, or food). htáaoolà toa àkçíãa make me some sandwiches (RBn10-2). síekò wikçíãe I made a meat pie for you (MREI 11-1-83-8). Mary akxa haaská wì kçíãape 

Mary made a shirt for him. • fix (prepare or repair) for s.o. àkçíãa fix it for me

(02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig). wíe na àkçíãape they did it just for me. áëà àkçíãa fix my bed for me (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig). ónôbre akçíãe I'm fixing the food for her. ònôbre àwákçíãe àðikçe we're fixing it for them (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig). ònôbre awákçiãe hta mìkçé I'm going to fix food for them. wisôka súhka wì óohò kçíãape they cooked a chicken for Sonny (lit., 'they made a cooked chicken for Sonny'). ékò kôða apa, ékò waðákçiãe hkôbra whatever they want, [I want you to] fix it for them (RBn22-10). táatà howachéeçki waðákçiãe hkôbra whatever [it is], I want you to fix it for them. haaská íikçiãa fix his shirt/their shirts (FH/09/21/01/pc). haaská âkçiãa fix my shirt (FH/09/24/01/prod). haaská wikçíãe hce let me fix your shirt. • have or make s.t. or s.o. be a certain way, have or make s.o. do s.t. íe káache ðáalì waðakçíãe make these words good for us (JS prayer). óðohta wakçíãa make him behave (RBn22-19). wiëîke mâzeska tóa céãenii áëu áwakçie hta mìkçé I'm going to have my son put some money on the drum (RBn10-3:MOJ/79; CQc).  

•• LFD 90: kçíãe <kshi´-xe> to make or do something for another. çîhto ëìka ðe mà wì akäiãe aða <shiæ´-¾o zhiæ-ga the moæ wiæ a-kchi xe a-tha> [expected Mod. Os. form: çîtoëì ðe mâà wì akçîãe àhé] I am making an arrow for the boy. akçiãe <a-kshi-xe> I made something for him. ðakçiãe <tha-kshi-xe> you made something for him. àkçiãa pe <oækshi-xa i> we make something for him. LFD 131: çîhto ëìka ðe mà wì ðakäiãe aðo <shiæ´-¾o zhiæ-ga the moæ wiæ tha-kchi xe a-tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: çîtoëì ðe mâà wì ðakçîãe ðàìçé] you are making an arrow for the boy.

kçíòze (variants: kçúìze, kçíôze). V [reg.+(sync. vowel initial stem), _kçí(_)òze (optionally doubly inflected in 1st sg. as akçímòze or akçíòze 'I teach him'; but singly inflected in other forms, e.g., 2nd person ðakçíòze 'you teach him')] [ki- DAT + kôze] (trans.) teach s.t. to s.o. waëáëeíe akçíòze I teach [the] Osage language (03/23/95/FH/pc). awákçuìze I teach them (my kids) (2/2/p7). táatà íçpahò çkôçta tà, wikçímòze hta mìkçé what you want to know, I will teach you (RBn10-16). kxáëì mâà ðíhtà akçímàze I taught kxáëì how to draw the bow (03/23/95/FH/pc). ëîkáëì wíhta waëáëeíe awákçuìze maëí na I never taught my kids the Osage language. ðakçíòze you teach [him]. waëáëeíe çée àkçíòza teach me that in Osage, teach me that Osage (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). wacúe káaãe àkçúìze teach me how to make bread (RBn23-14). • show s.o. how to do s.t. hpímò wikçíôze I know how so I'm going to show you how (FH/8/30/94: or wikçímòze as second preference). awákçiôze I showed them how (FH/8/30/94; 03/05/95/JS/pc: àwâkçiòze). wikçímôze hta mìkçé I'll show you how (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). àkçíôzape he showed me how (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). ìhtáci akxa kçíôzape my father showed him how (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). pee ðikçíôze? who showed you how? (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). àðíkçiôze we'll show you how (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). àkçíôza show me how (03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc). wakçíòza show them how! (FH/8/30/94: ôza has strong secondary stress).

•• LFD 90, 283: käiòze <kchi´-oæ-še> [expected Mod. Os. form: kçíòze] to instruct, to teach another (05/02/95/LS/pc:okc). LFD 84: hkáëìka màðità ahkäimàze aðo <Ða´-zhiæ-ga moæ-thi-doæ a-Ðchi-moæ-še a-tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: kxáëì mâà ðiitâ ðakçíòze (05/02/95/LS/pc:okc)] I taught kxáëì to draw the bow. hkáëìka màðità ðakäiòze aðo <Ða´zhiæ-ga moæ-thi-doæ tha-kchi-oæ-še a-tho> [expected Mod. Os form: kxáëì môò ðiitâ ðakçíòze]  you taught kxáëì to draw the bow. LFD 84 (unconfirmed): äíòze <chi´-oæ-še> [expected Mod. Os. form: kçíòze] to teach, to instruct. akäíòze <a-kchi´-oæ-še> I teach.

ðakäíòze <tha-kchi´-oæ-še> [expected modern Os. form: ðakçíòze] you teach.

••• Cf. wakçíòze. 

kçôka (variant: kçâka). N second son (in any clan) (FH/11/17/01/pc). kçôka çôke íhta apa zípe second son's dog is yellow (2-1-F).  

kçúìze (variant of kçíòze).

kú (see akú).

kusúe (variant of kisúðe).

kxáhpà (variant: kxahpái). N baby son; baby brother (said to be used by a woman to refer to her youngest brother or to her youngest son if she has at least two older sons).

••• KS kháge ppahâle son, third born (JOD) (RR), khága son, fourth born (JOD), third born (RR).  

kxáke. N third son or subsequent son (FH/pc). [Synonymous with kxáëì.]  

kxáëì (variant: kxáëìka). N third son or subsequent son (in any clan) (FH/11/17/01/pc;

04/26/95/FH/pc:ok). [Synonymous with kxáke.]

•• LFD 84: hkáëìka <Ða´-zhiæ-ga> the third son, a special kinship term. hkáëìka akxa wae nihkaçika pi a <Ða´-zhiæ-ga a-ka wa-e ni-Ða-shi-ga bi a> [probable expected Mod. Os. form: kxáëì akxa ówe níhkaçikape] my third son is a farmer [unconfirmed sentence].  

kxà (variant of txà CONT and POSIT).

kxâha (variant of txâha).

kØâsaaki. ADJ, V [reg. _kØâsaaki] (intr.) (be) fast in movement, fleet (as a runner). wisôka akxa kØâsaakipe brother is fast, speedy (BE2.45), wisôka akxa nâàke kØâsaakipe brother is a fast runner (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig), nâàke kØâsaaki brìe I'm a fast runner (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig), ðíe nâàke kØâsaaki nîe you're a fast runner (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig). • ADV quickly, fast, rapidly, swiftly.

•• LFD 88: kØâsaaki <Ð'oæ´-ša-gi> fleet; swift; very fast. ahkâsaki <a-Ðoæ´-ša-gi>

[expected Mod. Os. form: akØâsaaki] I am swift of foot. ðahkâsaki <tha-Ðoæ´-ša-gi>

[expected Mod. Os. form: ðakØâsaaki] you are swift of foot (01/23/95/FH/pc:no). àhkàsaki pe <oæ-Ðoæ-ša-gi i> [expected Mod. Os. form: àkØâsaakipe] we are swift of foot.

••• Cf. mâzekØàsaaki. 

kØé. V [reg. _kØé] (trans.) dig, dig up. tóoska akØé hta aðìhé I'm going to dig potatoes (BE2.31; FH:ok). tóoska àkØé hta àkái we're going to dig potatoes (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 84: kØe <Ð'e>to dig. to hke bre ì to <do Ðe bthe iæ do> [expected Mod. Os. form: tooská kØé brée] I go to dig potatoes. ahke <a-Ðe> [expected Mod. Os. form: akØé] I dig. ðahké <tha-Ðe´> [expected Mod. Os. form: ðakØé] you dig. àhka pe <oæ-Ða i> [expected Mod. Os. form: àkØápe] we dig.

••• KS kØé dig (RR); QU kØe dig (RR).

kØíe (variant of kØúe).

kØî. V [reg. _kØî] (trans.) carry, carry on the back. nâhka wíhta áalìì hta wikíkØì hta mìkçe áapa I'll carry you on my back, he said (t#24a-p4; 04/11/95/FH/pc:ok). kØî ðée they are carrying them on their back (FH:prod). kØîðaape they are carrying them [i.e., kØî aðée api ðe]. kØîpe they carried them. mâzeska kØî apai they're carrying money (FH:prod).

•• JOD (slip file): kØî <k'iæ> to carry a load on the back.

•• LFD 86–87 (unconfirmed): kØì <Ð'iæ> to carry. ahkî <a-Ðiæ´> [expected Mod. Os. form: akØî] I carry. àhkî pe <oæ-Ðiæ´ i> [expected Mod. Os. form: àkØî] we carry.

kØîahi. V [sync. h-stem, kØîa_hi] [kØî + ahí] (trans.) take, transport, carry (lit., 'carrying arrive there'). Billie akxa àkØîahi hta akxai Billie is going to bring [take] me [there] [the object pronominal à- 'me' precedes kØì].

kØó. N hole.

••• Cf. okØó. 

kØô. V [reg., _kØô] (trans.) play; (intr.) gamble.

kØôhe. V [reg., _kØôhe] (trans.) lay into.

••• Cf. ohkíkØòhe. 

kØôsu (variant: kØôse [FH]). N dice, Osage dice (RB, 01/20/95/FH/pc:prod orig). kØôsu kØô aðáape ska I guess they went to play dice (BE2.31; RBn2-MOJ/p18; 01/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

kØôsukØô. V [reg., kØôsu_kØô] [kØôsu + kØô] (intr.) play dice. • N Osage dice game (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.31).

kØú. V [reg., _kØú] (trans.) give. wikØú I give it to you (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). Bob akxa Joe haxî wì kØúpe Bob gave Joe a blanket. mîìòpa çáhpe nà kØú apai, wahkôtaki the doctors gave him only six months (RBn10-2). haxî wì ðikØúpe he gave you a blanket. haxî wì àkØúpe he gave me a blanket (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). àkØúpe it was given to me (lit., 'they gave it to me') (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn1-23). ónòbre wakØúpi apai we were fed (lit., 'they gave us some food'). àkØúëi they did not give [it] to me (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). àkØú! give [it to] me!

(01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). ëáëe kØú give him/her an Indian name [imperative]

(02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). hôòpa hpahâleche ëáëe kØú hkilíiski hta apai the first day of the week, they're going to gather together for a naming (i.e., to give [him/her] an Osage name). • pass s.t. to s.o. (e.g., at the table). níi toa àkØú pass the water (lit., 'give me some water') (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 85 (unconfirmed): kØi <Ð'i> to give; to present to another. akØí <a-Ð'i´> I give.

ðakØí <tha-Ð'i´> you give. àkØí pe <oæ-Ð'i´ i> we give.

••• KS kØå give (RR).

kØú huu (variant: kØú huðe). VP (trans.) pass by hand. àkØú huu hand it to me (RBn1-7). hcúke ðòòpá àkØú huu hand me two spoons (RBn1-52).

kØúe (variant: kØíe). V [reg., _kØúe] (intr.) scratch an itch. nâhka akØíe I scratch on my back (spoken by a person whose back itches) (RBn10-6:JW, unconfirmed; CQ:okc).

••• QU daxØíxØíke itch one (RR).

láace (variant: laacé). V [reg., _láace ] [kik- SUU + ðaacé] name one's own, call one's own by name. táatà laatáape? what did they name him [their relative]?

laaská (variant: hlaaská). N flower (01/26/95/FH/pc). [This is virtually the only word in which an initial hl is commonly preserved in Mod. Os.] kîìkììeëì hlaaskáëì éðòòpa ôòðe aðáape he went leaving [both] the flowers and butterflies behind (RBn15-03; BE2.49). RB: <hláh-skah, xláh-shkah, kláh-skah>.

láaxò. V [reg., _láaxò] [kik- SUU + ðaaxô] break s.t. of one's own by mouth. híi laaxôpe he broke a tooth.

laazípe (see hlaazípe).

lápxààke (variant: lapxâìke). N mosquito (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). [Hominy usage.]

•• RB: <láh-pxáh-iæ-keh>.

•• JOD (slip file): lápàke <k¢a´-pañ-¦ke> the musquito; musquitoes [sic].

laëîì. ADJ skinny (e.g., a person or a tree), slim, slender, thin; lean (describes a person or an animal, not meat); poor, pitiful, gaunt, haggard. wálì laëîì ðaìçé you're really skinny (BE2.122; FH:prod; 03/10/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• RB: <láh-zhíæ>.

•• LFD 220: laëî ka <xtha-zhiæ´ ga> lean; gaunt; haggard; slender; slim; thin; lean.

lâ (variant: lô). ADJ mad, angry. lâ aðée che iiðáahpe hta mìkçé I will wait until he goes away mad [angry] (FH:prod).

•• LFD 220: alò bre <a-xthoæ bthe> [expected Mod. Os. form: ólà brée] I went away in a sulk.

••• Cf. ólà. 

lâà (variant of lôò).

lâàðe (variant: lâàði). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) big, large, broad, wide (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok); great, stupendous; important; fat, overweight. wáli íhaa lâàðape she has a big mouth (RBnote). lâàðe htâ very large (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.75). lâàðe wáli enormous, huge. nihkáëi lâàðipe he's a big man (2-2-259). htaacé lâàðì a tempest (03/23/95/FH/pc). táatà wîxce lâàðe a great thing (RBn23-09). lâàðe brîe I'm fat (FH). táatà haamáì che lâàði ekxai what I did was important (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 56: lâðe <gthoæ´-the> magnitude; greatness; broad; wide; stupendous; prodigious.

LFD 136: htacé lâðe <¾a-dse´ gthoæ-the> great windstorm, a tempest.

lâàðe wálì. ADJP huge, enormous, exceedingly large.

•• LFD 56: lâàðe walì <gthoæ´-the wa-gthiæ> enormous; exceedingly large; huge. lape lâðe walì htòpe ha <xtha-be gthoæ´-the wa-gthiæ ¾oæ-be ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: ëâà lâàðe wálì htôpe; lape 'tree' unconfirmed; lape and sentence-final ha not used in Mod. Os.] I saw huge trees.

lâàðehtà. ADJ chubby, very large (RBn1-MOJ/p22; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

lâàði (variant of lâàðe).

lâke. V [reg., _lâke] (trans.) marry a woman, take as a wife. çómìhkasi akxa htaacéëì lâke kôðape the coyote wanted to marry the whirlwind (RBn17-p; 02/27/95/JS/pc).

•• JOD (Devouring Mountain p2 ln13–14): wakØó ðáalì xci çímìëìka ðáalì xci tóopa kØúpe ska, wahôìëìka walâke hta <Wak'u´ ¢á§k¢iæ-qtsi, címiæšiñ§´ka ¢á§k¢iæ-qtsi §túpa k'üpe ska, Wahªuæ´išiñ´§ka wa§k¢añ§ke ta> they gave him four very pretty girls so that he, the orphan, might take them as wives.

•• LFD 55: lâke <gthoæ´-ge> to take a wife; to marry.

••• Cf. hkilâke, mîìlàke. 

lébrà (variant: lébra). ADJ, N ten, tenth.

•• RB: <léh-brah> (03/16/95/FH/pc; BE2.136).

•• LFD 54: lébrà <gthe´-bthoæ> [final a or à is quite short] ten.

lébrà álìì ðáabrì (variant: álìì ðáabrì). ADJ, N thirteen, thirteenth.

lébrà álìì ðòòpá (variants: álìì ðòòpá, álìì ðôòpa). ADJ, N twelve, twelfth (BE2.146; 02/27/95/JS/pc:okc).

•• RB: <áh-li-thóæ-pah> [JS: full form or shortened form equally correct].

•• LFD 10: alì ðòpa <a-gthiæ thoæ-ba> two sixes; twelve; a dozen. súhka ëìka alìì ðòòpa waçkòsta <šiu´-Ða zhiæ-ga a-gthiæ thoæ-ba wa-shkoæ-sda> you want twelve chickens.

lébrà álìì hce wîìke (variant: álìì hce wîìke). ADJ, N nineteen, nineteenth. [Full form would be lébrà álìì lébrà hce wîìke, which is rarely if ever used but clearly understood.]

lébrà álìì hkietóopa (variant: álìì hkietóopa). ADJ, N eighteen, eighteenth.

lébrà álìì hpéòòpa (variant: álìì hpéòòpa). ADJ, N seventeen, seventeenth.

lébrà álìì sáhtà (variant: álìì sáhtà). ADJ, N fifteen, fifteenth.

lébrà álìì çáhpe (variant: álìì çahpe). ADJ, N sixteen, sixteenth.

lébrà álìì tóopa (variant: álìì tóopa). ADJ, N fourteen, fourteenth.

lébrà álìì wîxce (variant: álìì wîxce). ADJ, N eleven, eleventh.

lébrà ðáabrì. ADJ, N thirty, thirtieth.

lébrà ðòòpá (variant: lébràðôòpa). ADJ, N twenty, twentieth.

lébrà ðòòpá álìì wîxci (variants: lébraðôòpa áliwîxci, lébraðôòpa éci wîxci). ADJ, N twenty-one, twenty-first (RB; 05/02/95/LS/pc: ok). [The version with éci possibly sounds old-fashioned

(LF).]

lébrà hce wîìke (variant: hcewîìke). ADJ, N nine, ninth (BE2.94; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

lébrà hkietóopa. ADJ, N eighty, eightieth.

lébrà hpéðòòpa (variant: lébrà hpéòòpa). ADJ, N seventy, seventieth.

lébrà huuëî. ADJ, N hundred, hundredth. lébrà huuëî ðòòpá two hundred (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). lébra huuëî ðòòpá éci wîxci two hundred and one (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.69).

lébrà lébrà hce wîìke. ADJ, N ninety, ninetieth. lébrà sáhtà. ADJ, N fifty, fiftieth.

lébrà çáhpe. ADJ, N sixty, sixtieth.

lébrà tóopa. ADJ, N forty, fortieth.

lébràðôòpa (variant of lébrà ðòòpá).

léepa, léepe (variants of lépe).

léke (variant: hléke) V [reg., _léke] (intr.) shatter. lékape it's broken; it broke.

••• Cf. ðuuléke, kaaléke. 

lépe (variants: léepe, léepa [JS]), lélepe (reduplicated; variant: lélepa). V [reg., _lépe] vomit. alépe I'm vomiting (FH). ðóha alépe I'm about to vomit (FH/06/27/01/pc). lelépe akxai he/she is vomiting (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.149; RBn2-MOJ/p22; 02/27/95/JS/pc:uk; FH/06/27/01/pc).

•• RB: <léh-leh-pah> (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok; 02/27/95/JS/pc: léepa; 04/26/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 54 (unconfirmed): lépe màkhà <gthe´-be moæ-koæ> an emetic (04/26/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• QU kdéwe vomit [reg. conj.] (RR).

letâ (variant of letô).

letâ ôpe ëúuce. N redtailed hawk (04/20/95/LS/pc:prod).

letâmàze. N [letâ + mâze 'metal'] Iron Hawk (BE2.65; FH). [A hcíëo clan name referring to the metal color of the eagle; Frances Holding's father's name.]

•• LFD 54: letâmàze <Gthe-doæ´-moæ-še> Iron-hawk, personal name.

letô (variant: letâ). N hawk (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). ëekáxò letô crippled hawk.

•• LFD 54: letô <gthe-doæ´> hawk, falcon, used also as a personal name in the Osage Tribe. letô htàka <gthe-doæ´ ¾oæ-ga> the large hawk, Cooper's hawk. letô ëìka <gthe-doæ´ zhiæ-ga> the little hawk. letàaãe <Gthe-doæ-a-xe> [expected Mod. Os. form: letôkaaãe] Hawk-maker, personal name. letàhce <Gthe-doæ-¾se> New-hawk, personal name. letôchie <Gthe-doæ´-tsi-e> Hawk-passing-by, personal name, refers to the hawk attacking prey. letômihcexi <Gthe-doæ´-mi-¾se-xi> New-hawk-woman, female personal name. letôsàwì <Gthe-doæ´-šoæ-wiæ> White-hawk-woman, female personal name. letôscece <Gthe-doæ´stse-dse> Long-hawk, personal name, refers to the long scalp locks attached to the sacred hawk. letôska <Gthe-doæ´-ška> White-hawk, personal name. letôwahkà <Gthe-doæ´-waÐoæ> Mystery-hawk, personal name. letôwahkòða <Gthe-doæ´-wa-Ðoæ-tha> Attackinghawk, personal name. letôxoce <gthe-doæ´-xo-dse> brown hawk [expected Mod. Os.

translation 'gray hawk'].

••• Cf. letâ ôpe ëúuce, letôwì.

letôsape. N [letô + sápe] black hawk.

•• LFD 54: letô sape <gthe-doæ´ ša-be> black hawk; "symbolizes the courage of the warriors, . . . also represents night."

letôwì. N hawk woman. [Frances Oberly Holding's name.]

•• LFD 54: letôwì <Gthe-doæ´-wiæ> Hawk-woman, female personal name, refers to the sacred hawk. letôwìëìka <Gthe-doæ´-wiæ-zhiæ-ga> Little-hawk-woman, female personal name, refers to the smallest of hawks.

léze. V, ADJ [stat.?] (intr.) (be) striped, lined (having lines). súhka léze guinea hen (striped fowl). sîka hpaléze striped-nosed squirrel, a square dance call in Osage in imitation of "swing your partners" (RBn19-06).

•• LFD 54: lezé <gthe-še´> striped. waché leze wì abrì <wa-tse´ gthe-še wiæ a-bthiæ>

[expected Mod. Os. form: haaská léze wì abrî] I have a striped dress. akahami lezé wì ani <a-ga-ha-mi gthe-še´ wiæ a-ni> [expected Mod. Os. form: ákahamì léze wì açcî; LF's <ani> 'you have' is probably an Omaha form, not used in Osage] you have a striped coat.

••• Cf. páaleze, waléze. 

léëe (variant: léëi).
