ADJ spotted, speckled, stippled (05/02/95/LS/pc). hpáata léëe káaãe akxai he's coloring eggs (as for Easter) (12/30/94/FH/pc/prod). hápa léëe spotted corn, like Osage corn (although this name not used for Osage corn) (FH). hpáata léëe decorated Easter eggs (FH). xúða léëe the spotted eagle.

•• JOD (Wolf and Fawn, p1 ln3): ha wisôka háaëòtà ðiléëe aape ska çômihkase akxa <Há, wisªuñ´§ka, ha´šuæ-§taæ´ ¢ik¢é§cªe, á§pe ska Cªuæmikáse akqa> ho, younger brother, what did you do to get spotted, asked the wolf.

•• LFD 55: leëé <gthe-zhe´> spotted. leëáëa <gthe-zha´-zha> spotted in different parts of the body. LFD 54 (unconfirmed): míãa ëìka ðìkçe leëé <mi´-xa zhiæ-ga thiæ-kshe gthezhe´> [expected Mod. Os. form: míãaëì ìkçe léëe] the duck is spotted.

••• Cf. haxîleëekáaãe. 

lí (see alí).

líi (variant of lîì).

liisâða. V [reg., _liisâða] [kik- SUU + ðiisâða] (trans.) turn, turn over, reverse or invert one's own (04/06/95/FH/pc:ok). haxî alíisàða I turned over my blanket (FH).

•• LFD 145: haxì ðà alisàða ha <ha-xiæ thoæ a-gthi-šoæ-tha ha> [ðà and ha are unconfirmed; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I reversed my blanket. haxì ðà ðalisàða ha <ha-xiæ thoæ tha-gthi-šoæ-tha ha> [ðà and ha are unconfirmed; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you reversed your blanket; to turn.

líiçki (variant: lúuçki). V [reg., _líiçki] [kik- SUU + ðiiçkí] (intr.) do one's own laundry, wash one's own clothing or hair. líiçki akxa she did her laundry (FH/08/01/01/pc). alíiçki I did my laundry (FH/08/01/01/pc). hpaxîì alíiçki hta mìkçé I'm going to wash my hair (RBn23-15). ðíe haaská líiçki! wash your clothes yourself! (CQnotes). haaská líiçki akxai he washes his clothes himself. wéhkilai àlíiçkipe we washed our clothes. alúuçki I did my laundry (FH/01/08/01/pc). lúuçki akxa she did her laundry (FH/01/08/01/pc). hpaxîì alíiçki hta mìkçé I'm going to wash my hair (RBn23-15).

líixò. V [reg., _líixò] [kik- SUU + ðiixô] (trans.) break one's own (body part or possession). alíixò I broke my own (RBn22-03).

líizoke (variant: líizoka). V [reg., _líizoke] [kik- SUU + ðiizó (it is not known what the final ke is here)] (intr.) bend oneself; (trans.) bend one's own (body part or possession). mîce àlíizoke àkátxai we bend our bows.

liëáëai. V [reg., _liëáëai] [reduplicated form] [kik- SUU + ðiëáëa] (trans.) shake one's own (body part or possession). ëâà liëáëai shake your tree (MREI/01/11/83). áa liëáëai shake your arm (MREI/01/11/83). liëáëai shake him (your own) (MJ).

lîì (variant: líi). V [reg., _lîì] (intr.) sit. líipi you all sit down. çeðó lîì sit down over there (RBn10-3:MOJ/79).

•• LFD 55: lì <gthiæ> to sit. alì <a-gthiæ> I sit. ðalì <tha-gthiæ> you sit. àlì pe <oægthiæ i> we sit.

••• Cf. álìì. 

lîì (variant of lîìëe).

lîìðìke (variant of lîìke).

lîìka. V [lîìke + a IMPERATIVE MARKER] (intr.) sit!

lîìke (variants: lîìðìke). V [reg., _lîìke] (intr.) sit down, sit suddenly (PM). howaìki ðalîìke nìkçé? where are you going to sit? where are you sitting down? (1/13/83/434;

03/10/95/PM/pc). lîì ëówile hce let me sit with you (RBn10-4:MOJ/79). lîìka be seated, sit down (03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc). lîì ëóàle sit with me (03/10/95/PM/pc:okc). açkáëì lîìka sit right here by me, sit close to me (03/10/95/PM/pc). lììðikápi you all sit down. lîìkapi be seated; sit down [pl. addressee] (03/10/95/PM/pc; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.117).

•• LFD 55: lîìka <gthiæ´-iæ-ga o-u> [sentence-final <o-u> is not used in Mod. Os.] sit down.

lîìëe (variants: hlîì, lîì). N sparks that fly from a fire.

•• LFD 220 (unconfirmed): lìëá <xthiæ-zha´> sparks of a fire; sparks that fly upward from the sticks or fire drills used for starting a fire. [FH: wrong pronunciation, should be lîìëe.]

••• Cf. kaalîìëe. 

lìkó. N gravy (03/07/95/FH/pc:ok). súhka lìkó wiksíãe hta mìkçé I'm going to make you some chicken gravy (FH/09/21/01/pc). htáa lìkó meat gravy (FH/09/21/01/pc; BE2.60).

lìlîìe. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) sleep sitting up (RB, unconfirmed).

lîxa. N bobcat (RBn HW10; unconfirmed; FH:uk).

lóce. V [reg., _lóce; accent seems to be variable in 1st sg. and 2nd sg.] (intr.) snore. ðáloce? ðalóce? do you snore? (04/26/95/FH/pc). áloce I snore (04/26/95/FH/pc). àëîìhe ta wáalì ðalóce nâì, áçihta ðinâkØò apai when we go to sleep, you snore loud and they even hear you outside (04/26/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 227: ëâloce <zhoæ´-xtho-dse> to snore. ëàáloce <zhoæ-a´-xtho-dse> I snore. ëâðaloce <zhoæ´-tha-xtho-dse> you snore.

lô (variant of lâ).

lôðì (variants: lôðe, lôði). V, ADJ [reg.+sync., _lô_ðì or _alô_ðì; vowels of 1st sg. a- and 2nd person ða- are normally lengthened before the l of this verb (aalôbrì, ðaalôçcì)] (be) drunk, inebriated, intoxicated. ðihkówe akxa lôðì akxa ëaamí I think your friend [sitting] is drunk

(01/20/95/PM/pc:ok, ma; FH:5/02/96/tape). lôði àpa ëaamí I think he [moving] is drunk (01/20/95/PM/pc:prod; FH:5/02/96/tape). ðihkówa lôðì txa? is your friend [standing] drunk? (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). aalôbrì hta mìkçé I'm going to get drunk, I'm going to get angry or frustrated (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc; FH:4/22/96/tape:okc). ðaalôçcì hta ðaìçé? are you going to get drunk? (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod). lôði hta mìkçé I'm going to get drunk (01/20/95/ERE/pc). kaakô çô ðaìçe, ðaalôçäi nana keep on until you get drunk (spoken sarcastically) (RB:MOJ).

lôðiçtà çtà éhtana hcéhpe hpíiëi kçí aape he has a bad liver from always being drunk (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 56: lôðì <gthoæ´-thiæ> to be drunk. alôbrì <a-gthoæ´-bthiæ> I am drunk. walôðì pe <wa-gthoæ´-thiæ i> we are drunk. lôðì ikiha <gthoæ´-thiæ i-gi-ha> habitual drunkard; a sot. lôðì kaãe <gthoæ´-thiæ ga-xe> to make drunk; to intoxicate. lôðìçtà <gthoæ´-thiæ-shtoæ> intemperance; drunkenness.

••• Cf. cØélòðì, kaalôðì. 

lôò (variant: lâà). V [reg., _lôò] (trans.) call s.o. a bad name, revile s.o., "blast" s.o. in an argument. ðilôòpe they called you names (RBn; MREI/01/11/83; CQc). ðilôò he called you names. àlôòpe they called me names. ðilôò apai they called you names. àlôòlòòpe they called me names (3-3-83 [not hl]). • (intr.) say bad words, curse; sulk, be angry, mutter in complaint. lôò ðée che iðáahpe hta mìkçé I'll wait until he goes away mad [angry]. óðààceçi ìká, olâà akxa don't pay any attention to him, he's mad (RBn11-01/JW&FW&HHaskell).

•• JOD (slip file): lôðì <¦k¢uæ´-¢iæ> foolish, silly, beside himself with anger, etc.

•• LFD 55: lò <gthoæ> to call one bad names; to revile. ðálò <tha´-gthoæ> you reviled him.

•• KS là (JOD), lâle, lô curse, revile (RR), yalôya (JOD), yalâye deceive, call names, snap at (RR).

••• Cf. lôòlòò, walôò. 

lôò (variant of lòòhô).

lòò ðúleze. N thunder with lightning (BE2.140; RB, unconfirmed; 02/15/95/FH/pc:uk)

lòò húu. N large amount of thunder, lots of thunder (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod).

lôò iníhkaçika. N Thunder clan, person of the Thunder clan.

•• LFD 56: lôinihkaçika <Gthoæ´i-ni-Ða-shi-ga> People of the Thunder, the name of a gens in the Osage tribe (unconfirmed; 03/22/95/FH/pc:ma).

lôò níhkaçika. N thunder people (FH/t116b).

lôò waléze. N lightning. (lit., 'stripes from thunder'?)

•• LFD 56: lô waleze <gthoæ´ wa-gthe-še> lightning (zigzag).

lòòhóohtà. N, V [uninfl.] [lòòhô + hóohtà] (intr.) thunder (RB; HH/pc).

•• RB: <ló-ho-tah>.

•• JOD (slip file): lò hohtà <¦k¢ªuæ huÆtaæ> "the thunderbird roars," thunder, it thunders.

•• LFD 56: lòhóhtà <gthoæ-ho´-¾oæ> thunder. lòòhóohtà walì pe <gthoæ-ho´-¾oæ wa-gthiæ bi a> the thunder was loud.

••• KS gló ~ ló thunder (N) (RR), lo hóhta to thunder (RR).

lòòhô (variant: lôò). N thunder (RBn1-1). iihkó lòò grandmother thunder (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.59).

•• RB: <loæ>.

•• LFD 55 (unconfirmed): lò <Gthoæ> Thunder deity. LFD 56: lôì <Gthoæ´-iæ> the Thunder deity (unconfirmed; 03/22/95/FH/pc:uk).  

lòòhúu (variants: lòòhúa, lòòhúe). N Osage wedding hat (top hat with colorful plumes that may be worn by the bride in an Osage wedding) (MREI/6/7/94/num94; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; FH/8/30/94).

•• RB: <lóæ-hyú>.

•• LFD 56: lòhi <gthoæ-hi> a hat with ornaments worn by a bride at a wedding. lôòlòò. V [reg., _lôòlòò] [reduplicated form of lôò] (trans.) call names, revile, or curse over and over. nà lôòlòò apa áape they said that they were saying bad words, they said they were calling names. âlòòlòò apa áape they called me names, they said.

•• LFD 55: lòlò <gthoæ´-gthoæ> repeated mutterings, as when one is angry. lúðaalì. V [reg., _lúðaalì] [kik- SUU + ðuðáalì] (trans.) fix one's own, fix up s.t. of one's own. luçúpe. N [presumably ki- SUU + ðiiçúpe/ðuuçúpe] vein in the body (FH: prod). lúuçki (variant of líiçki).

lúuwasu. V [reg., _lúuwasu] [kik- SUU + ðuuwásu] (trans.) wash your own (body part or possession). nààãåce låuwasü! wash your ears! (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok).

••• Cf. hkilúuwasu. lúuxpaðe. V [reg., _lúuxpaðe] [kik- SUU + ðuuxpáðe] (trans.) lose one's own. wéleze àlúuxpaðe we lost our pencils.

lúuze. V [reg., _lúuze] [kik- SUU + ðuuzé] get, take, or take away one's own. wáleze ðalúuze? did you get your letter? (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.78).

lúuëa. V [reg., _lúuëa] [kik- SUU + ðuuëá] (trans.) wash one's own (body parts or possessions) (1-20-83-p1). çáake alúuëa hkôbra I want to wash my hands (RBn1-50). oðíhtâ hàðé ðalúuëa? are you washing your car tonight? (FH/06/16/01/pc). Preston akxa oðíhtà hàðé lúuëa akxa Preston is washing his car tonight. çáake àlúuëa we wash our hands. ììcé luuëá, çáake çki wash your face, also your hands (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.151). síi luuëá wash your feet (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). nâhta luuëá wash your ears (RBn11-02/JW&FW;

RB:HHsk,c.1976). híi luuëá brush your teeth (03/16/95/JS/pc). hîì luuëá wash your mustache (JS). hpáxì luuëá wash your hair (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc). ìcé alúuëamazí I didn't wash my face.

•• LFD 56: lúëa <gthu´-zha> to wash (one's face).

lúwì. V [reg., _lúwì] [kik- SUU + ðuwî] (trans.) buy s.t. of one's own (buy back) (1/2/147-190). áluwì I bought it back and it belonged to me (lit., 'I bought my own'). • buy for one's own (people, family).

lúëi (variants: hlúëi, hlúëe, lúëe). ADV slow, slowly, slower (JS; 03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok). lúëe ía, lúëe íe say it slow (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok: hlúëe ía). lúëi íe say it slowly (03/10/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.123). lúëì káaãa do it slower, go slowly. lúëi ekò! slow down, ease up! (RBn3-MOJ?/p3; 03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok).

lúëi káaãe (variant: hlúëi káaãe). VP [sync. k>p, lúëi _káaãe] (trans.) make slower, slow down (RBn10-5:MOJ/79).

lúëihkiðe (variant: lúëihkie). V [reg., lúëi_hki(ð)e] [lúëi + hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] (intr.) slow down, take it slow (lit., 'make oneself slow').

máihka (variant of mâìhka).

maçcúce. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) slide (e.g., on ice).

máçi (variant of mâçi).

maçká. N crawfish.

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p20 ln6): máçkà <máckaæ>. JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p24 ln7): máçka <mácka>.

maëí (variant: màëí). NEG not (negator for 1st sg. only: 'I am/was not', 'I do/did not', etc.; follows the verb). puçtáha màëí I don't iron (FH/12/11/94). ììcé alúuëa màëí I didn't wash my face.

mâà (variants: môò, mâ, mô). N arrow. çí mâà çó ðée hpáaãe I'm going to let the arrow go again (BE2.4, expression used at peyote meetings; 01/06/95/FH/pc:okc). céãenii mâà nààëí the drum and arrow stop/stand (RBn10-22/JW&FW). môò xô broken arrow (RBn10-6:JW). mâà xô a broken arrow (MSB 2-24-83). • staff used at peyote meetings (RB).

•• LFD 95: mò <moæ> an arrow. "The Osage made their arrows out of a wood they call <moæ´šahi>, arrow wood (Cornus asperi folia). When this wood is not obtainable they use the ash. Two arrows, ceremonially made, are used in some of the Osage tribal rites, one painted black and the other red, to represent night and day, they being symbols of everlasting life."  màà-. N ROOT related to the ground or the earth.

mààðô (variant: môò). V [sync., màà_ðô] (trans.) steal. mààbrôe I stole it. wámààbròðe I stole them. mààðôpe she was stolen (lit., 'they stole her'). táatà wì âmààðòe àðé we [two] stole something (05/12/83/3). ðimôò çtà akxa he's [always] stealing from you (5-12-83-3). táatà wì àmâàðòpe we stole something (2-10-83-p4). • rape. ðímààðôpe you're being raped (lit., 'they raped you'). mààðôpe she was raped (lit., 'they raped her').

••• PO mànâðiwaðe little people [fairies] (lit., 'they take folks off, steal them') (KDS); KS gímòyò steal something from someone (RR).

••• Cf. mààlô, wakØó mààðôçtà, wamâàðò.

mâàãe (variant: môòãe). N sky (BE2.122); weather (03/10/95/PM/pc:not sky). [Takes 'sitting' positional article îkçé or 'standing inanimate' positional article che.] mâàãe háakò che áçi? what's it [the weather] like outside? (03/22/95/PM/pc:prod). háakò ìkçé áçihta? what is it [the weather] like outside? (RBn3-51). hâàpa mâàãe ðáalì akxa today the weather is good (03/22/95/PM/pc:ok;

BE2.153). mâaãe ðáalì tà hóolà àkái hta àkái if the weather is good, we're going fishing

(03/22/95/PM/pc:ok). mâàãe ðáalì good weather (03/22/95/PM/pc:ok). mâàãe akxa ðáalìëi akxa the weather is not good (FH:1998/pc). mâàãe hpíiëi bad weather (03/22/95/PM/pc:ok). mâàãe hôòche? how's the weather? (RBn12-09). mâàãe hôìche? how is the weather? (03/22/95/PM/pc:ok). • the upper world.

•• JOD (slip file): máãe <ma´-xe> sky, upper world, weather.

•• LFD 103: mâãe <moæ´-xe> the sky. mâãe ðálì <moæ´-xe tha-gthiæ> a good sky; a clear day. màãe ðihice <moæ-xe thi-hi-dse> conjuring the sky.

mààhí (variant of mààhî 'grass, hay').

mâàhi (variant of mâàhì 'knife').

mâàhisi wakØó (variant of mâàhìsu wakØó). mâàhispe (variant of mâàhìspe).

mààhî (variants: mààhîì, mààhí). N [possibly màà- 'earth' + hîì 'hair'] grass, hay (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.60). súhka mîìka äáahpaëì, mààhî apa ohcíle ðáalìpe, ecíe ska ébre mìkçé the little hen [said], hay is good for a nest, I'm thinking it's there (RBn19-04).

•• LFD 98: màhî <moæ-hiæ´> grass.

••• KS mààhî, mahî (JOD) grass, weeds (RR).

mààhî htóho (variant: mààhí htóho). ADJP, N green (lit., 'blue/green grass') (MSB:t9).

mààhî htóho éekò. ADJP green (lit., 'like blue/green grass').

mààhî kaasé (variant: mààhí kaasé). VP [reg. kaa-del., mààhî _(kaa)sé] cut the grass. mààhí áase hta mìkçé I'm going to cut the grass (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod). mààhî kaasé màðî go cut the grass (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

mààhî paasé (variant: mààhí paasé). VP [sync. fortisizing stop stem, mààhî _paasé] cut the grass. mààhí çpáase hta ðaìçé? are you going to cut the grass? (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod). mààhí çpáasape? did you all cut the grass? (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod). àà mààhí àpáasape yes, we cut grass [female speaking] (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod). àà mààhí hpáasa yes, I cut the grass [female speaking] (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod).

••• Cf. paa-, -se.

mâàhì (variant: mâàhi) N knife.

•• LFD 286: mâhì <moæ´-hiæ>.

mâàhì htâà (variant: máàhì htâka). N superintendent (as of the Osage Agency), officer or other white person of rank, the government (lit., 'big knife') (PM/7/7/94; 02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.130); white person (archaic or rare) (RBn HW13).

•• RB: <móæ-hiæ-tahæ, máhæ-hi-táhæ>.

•• LFD 99: mâhìhtàka kahike <Moæ´-hiæ-¾oæ-ga ga-hi-ge> Indian agent. màhì, htàka, kahike <moæ-hiæ, ¾oæ-ga, ga-hi-ge> knife, big, chief, big-chief-knife. màhì htàka <moæ-hiæ ¾oæ-ga> knife, big, lit., 'big-knife'. The Osage name for an Englishman.

mààhîhpa. N ragweed (lit., 'bitter grass') (RB).

•• LFD 99: màhîhpa <moæ-hiæ´-¼a> bitterweed, ragweed or hogweed (Artemisiae folia).

mààhîì (variant of mààhî).

mâàhìsi wakØó (variant of mâàhìsu wakØó).

mâàhìska. N axe (RBn10-12:JW, unconfirmed) [Presumed error in RB records for mâàhìspe (?).]

mâàhìspe (variants: mâàhiispe, mâàhispe). N axe (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). mâàhispe nâãe kaaxô he broke the ice with his axe (BE2.5 RBn2-MOJ/p20; FH/09/22/01/pc). mâàhispe ðuuzá, ëâà toe àkáase àkái hce get the axe and let's go cut some wood (RBn2-MOJ/p20; 01/06/95/FH/pc;okc). • Strike Axe [name of the band that the Oberlys (FH's father's family) belonged to] (FH). • spade (e.g., for gardening); spades (suit in a deck of cards) (RBn12-10/MOJ; FH/09/22/01/pc). [The image of an axe appears only on the king of diamonds and the jack of hearts, however.]

•• JOD (slip file): màhìspe <maæ-hiæ-spe> axe.

•• LFD 98: mâhìspe <moæ´-hiæ-špe> ax. mâhìspewechì <Moæ´-hiæ-špe-we-tsiæ> Battle-ax (personal name) [mâàhispe + wa- VAL + iichî, lit., 'axe with which to strike persons or things'].

••• Cf. hámàsi, mâàhìsu, mâàhìsu wakØó. 

mâàhìspeëì. N hatchet (FH).

•• LFD 99: mâhìspe ëìka <moæ´-hiæ-špe zhiæ-ga> a tomahawk, a battle-ax or a hatchet.

mâàhìsu (variants: mâàhusa, mâàhusi, môòhisu, môòhisi). N spade (e.g., gardening tool); spades (suit in a deck of cards) (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn10-21/JW; FH/11/17/01/pc).

mâàhìsu wakØó (variants: mâàhìsi wakØó, mâàhisi wakØó). N queen of spades in a deck of cards (lit., 'spade woman') (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). [Takes 'lying' positional article kçe.] mâàhisi wakØó kçe abrî I have the queen of spades (RB, FH).

•• LFD 98: mâhisi wakØo kçe abrì <moæ´-hi-ši wa-Ð´u kshe a-bthiæ> I have the queen of spades.

mâàhpiiëi N [mâà + hpíiëi] slave (RB, unconfirmed); worthless thing, s.t. of no value (lit., 'bad arrow') (RB); bad weather (03/10/95/PM/pc); bad shaft of an arrow (PM).

•• RB:<móæ-pi-zhiæ>.

mâàhusa, mâàhusi (variants of mâàhìsu).

mâàke (variant: môòke). N chest (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; RBn1-MOJ/p27).

•• LFD 97: mâke <moæ´-ge> breast or chest of a human being.

••• KS mâàge chest of a man (RR); WI mààk chest (of the body) (KM).

mâàke ní. N tuberculosis, consumption (lit., 'chest hurts').

•• LFD 97: mâke nie <moæ´-ge ni-e> consumption, breast-ache, chest-ache.

mâàke púze. N tuberculosis, consumption (BE2.145; RBn2-MOJ/p14; 04/04/95/FH/pc:okc).

mààlô. V [reg.?, _maalô?] [kik- SUU + mààðô] (trans.) steal s.t. of one's own, steal back.

màànâãe. V [conjug. unknown] [presumably contains màà- and nàà-] paw the ground when in rut (said of a male animal ready to breed with a female animal) (04/25/95/PM/pc). hceetóoka màànâãape buffalo bull is rutting (PM).

•• LFD 158: hcetóka mànàãapi <¾se-do´-ga moæ-noæ-xa bi> when the buffalo bulls rut, the month of June [unconfirmed as name of month].

••• KS mànâãe to be in rut, to paw the ground (RR).

mààpíaza (variant: mâàpeza [RB]) N wasp (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.151). [JS prefers mààpíaza to wapázike, which she considers archaic.]

 •• RB: <máhæ-peh-zah>.

mâàsase (variant: môòsase). N [mâà + sase] sauerkraut (lit., 'arrow cuttings') (RB, unconfirmed; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:uk; 04/19/95/FH/pc:uk).

mâàse, mâàsi (variants of môòse).

mâàsihcexi (variant: mâàsihcexì). N [môòse + hcéxi] Sacred Arrow Shaft (female personal name).

[Dora Lookout's name.]

•• LFD 97: môçihcexi <Moæ´-ši-¾se-xi> Sacred-arrow-shaft (female personal name).

••• Cf. hcéxi, môòse. 

mààstósto. ADJ, N muddy, mud (02/27/95/FH/pc:okc; FH:4/22/96/tape:prod; BE2.91). oëàke kçe mààstósto the road is muddy (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). hcéðe mààstósto a muddy tire (03/22/95/FH/pc).

•• RB: <mahæ-stó-sto> ~ <máhæ-sto-sto>.

•• LFD 97: màstósto <moæ-što´-što> soft mud, a muddy road. oëàke kçe màstósto <u-zhoæ-ge ke moæ-što´-što> the road is muddy.

mààçcé. V, N [uninfl.] (be) warm weather (JS prod), hot weather, sunny weather (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc;

RBn2-MOJ/p19; 03/22/95/PM/pc:ok). mààçcé akxa the weather is hot (03/22/95/PM/pc:ok). mààçtáëi akxái it's not hot (weather) (BE2.68).

•• LFD 102: mâsce <moæ´-stse> hot weather, a hot day.

mààçcé kçíhtaha (variant: mààçäé kçi ehtáha). N, ADJP, ADVP south (lit., 'in/to the direction of warm weather'). mààçäé kçi ehtáha koe mììáðee ehtáha tookétà táahkace ci achíe I come from the south and the west in the heat of summer (RBn17-p01; 03/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.125).

mààçcîka (variant of màçcîka).

mààçóce (FH). V, ADJ [uninfl.] [màà- + çóce] (intr.) (be) dusty (as of a table top). áwanòbre akxa mààçóce akxai, ðiicíza the table is dusty, dust it (FH:4/22/96/tape138b).

•• LFD 101: màçóce <moæ-sho´-dse> dust blown or carried by the wind.  

mààçóçoce (FH) (variants: mâàçoço [PM], mâàçoçóce [FH]). V, ADJ [uninfl.] [reduplicated form of mààçóce] (be) dusty. mâàçoçóce it [the air] is dusty/smoky (01/20/95/PM/pc:prod; BE2.37).

áwanòbre akxa mààçóçoce akxai, ðiicíza the table is dusty, dust it (FH:4/22/96/tape138b).

•• LFD 102: màçóçoce <moæ-sho´-sho-dse> dust, dusty, soft mud along the edges of a stream [reduplicated form; unconfirmed as any sort of 'mud']. màçóçoce ðaða pi a <moæ-sho´-sho-dse thatha bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form: mààçóçoce çkáaãe; ðaða unconfirmed by Mod. Os. speakers] you are raising the dust.

mààçtáha (variant: màçtáha). ADJ [màà- + çtáha] slippery (as of a surface).

•• LFD 102: màçtáha <moæ-shta´-ha> slippery ground, wet ground.

mààtóohka. ADJ [màà- + toohká] moist.

•• LFD 97 (unconfirmed): màtóhka <moæ-do´Ða> moist.

mâàëàxe (variant: mààëâxe). N garlic, onion (03/02/95/FH/pc; BE2.98).

•• JOD (slip file): mâëàxe <ma´-¦caæ-qe> an onion, onions.

•• LFD 104: màëâxe <moæ-zhoæ´-xe> onions, garlic. mààëâxe ðiðalì a <moæ-zhoæ´-xe thi-thagthiæ a> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâàëàxe ðihôò?] do you like onions? "Garlic was plentiful on the prairies, but until the Indians saw white men using it for food they did not use it because its odor was offensive."

••• KS móëòxe, máëà- (JOD) onion (RR).

mààëâxe htóho. N green onion (05/01/95/LS/pc:okc; RBn1-MOJ/p14; FH/09/21/01/pc).

màché. ADV in the center of s.t. (centrally located), within, underneath (03/23/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 103: mâche/mâhce <moæ´-tse> in the deepest of secret places.

••• QU mâthe inside, in, within, under (RR); KS mâähe [vowel may be long: âà] (JOD) underneath, within (RR).

màché éhtaha (variant of màchéhtaha).

mâche oðúxa (variant: mâche oðúãa?). N underwear, undergarment (for men or women) (02/27/95/JS/pc; BE2.147). [Likely a direct loan-translation from English 'under' + 'wear', although oðúxa is otherwise unattested in Mod. Os.]

•• LFD 180: oðúxa <u-thu´xtha> to pull on, as leggings.

màchéhta. ADV, N other side, on/to the other side, underneath, inner one or innermost one.

•• JOD (Devouring Mountain p2 ln9): màhcéhta <Maætse´ta> inside.

•• LFD 103: màhcéhta <moæ-¾se´-¾a> inside, interior of anything. màchéhta xci <moæ-tse´-¾a xtsi> inmost, innermost.

màchéhtaha (variant: màché éhtaha). ADJ, ADV inward, toward the center (03/23/95/FH/pc:prod; FH:t119a).

•• LFD 103: màchéhtaha/màhcéhtaha <moæ-tse´-¾a-ha> inward, toward the center.

màðî (variants: méì, mâì, mée, mêì). V (reg.+sync., (_)mà_ðî] (intr.) walk, go by walking, go by foot. màðî alí apai she's walking home (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). áwanòbre ápetxa màðí walk around the table (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). màðî íkØuca try to walk (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.150). màðaçcî hta ðaaçé? are you going to walk? are you going to go afoot? màðì alí apai she's walking home (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). màðí ðachíe? did you come afoot? (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). • go away. màðîpi go away [pl. addressee]; go! go on! [pl. addressee]. • go, go on, walk, get moving. óðaake waléze akå màðí go get the newspaper (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). puuspé màðî go hide (RBn22-06). ðíe màðî! you [sg.] go! [contrastive: e.g., 'I don't want to go, so you go']. • go ahead. màðîpi go ahead and do it [pl. addressee]. • approach, move in closer. hkéðo mâì clear weather traveling, approaching (FH). • stay. çée màðî stay where you are (PM/109-a). • act or live a certain way, go around a certain way (JS, PM). oáðohta àmâbrì àçkáaãe íkØuca try to make me behave (MOJ 1/19/83).

•• RB: <mahæ-thí, moæ-thíæ> (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 85: màðîðe <moæ-thiæ´-the> [expected Mod. Os. form: màðí ðée] to go afoot, walking. hkéðamàì <Ðe´-tha-moæ-iæ> Clear-day-approaching, refers to the clearing of the sky after a storm. LFD 102: màðì <moæ-thiæ> to exist, to walk [unconfirmed as 'to exist']. màðîbre <moæ-thiæ´-bthe> [expected Mod. Os. form: màðî brée] I go afoot. môni <moæ´-ni> [expected Mod. Os. form: màçcî] you exist. màðîðe <moæ-thiæ´-the> onward.

••• Cf. hpahâle màðî, hpéece màðî, oðóçimà, ómàðì, çée màðî. 

màðî aðée. VP go for a walk, go walking. màðî àkáðe let's go for a walk.

màðî ðíe. VP (intr.) go on, get moving (a command to one person). [Used only as imperative.]

màðî káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, màðî _káaãe] (trans.) herd, drive (lit., 'force to walk'). hkáwa ðéeka màðî káaãa çäewai hta mìkçé a [sentence-final a is not used in Mod. Os.] bring the horses here and I'll doctor them (lit., 'make the horses walk here, I will doctor them') (RBn HW).

màðîhka (variant of mâìhka).

màãíðe (variant: mòxíðe). V [reg., màãí_ðe] (trans.) deceive, trick, lie, swindle, defraud, fool (MSB: t9). màãíawai mìkçé I lied [to folks]; I lied to them [màãíawai < màãí-a-wa-ðe]. màãíðai nìkçé you lied to him [màãíðai < màãí-ða-ðe]. màãíàðae you lied to me [< màãí-à-ða-ðe]. màãíwaðaape you [sg./pl.] lied to us [< màãí-wa-ða-ðe-api-ðe]. màãíàðape he lied to me (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). mòxîàða api a [expected form in Mod. Osage: màãíàðape] he lied to me (RBn10-5:JW). màãíðiðe apai he's lying to you. màãíwaðape he lied to us. màãíwaapi akxai [màãí-wa-ðe-api akxa-ðe] they're lying to us now. màãíwaape they fooled us (3-1-326ff).

•• LFD 103: mòãéðe <moæ-xe´-the> to deceive, swindle, hoodwink, delude or defraud. mòãéaðe 

<moæ-xe´-a-the> I deceived him. mòãéðaðe <moæ-xe´-tha-the> you deceived him. mòãe óða pe ha <moæ-xe o´-tha i ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: màãíàða pe; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod.

Os.] he swindled me.

••• KS màãíye fool someone, deceive, tease (RR).

màãíhkiðe. V [reg., màãí_hkiðe] [hkik- REFL + màãíðe] (intr.) deceive oneself, be mistaken.

màhká (variant: màhkâ). N peyote, aspirin, or any other kind of medicine (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

màhkánii peyote tea (lit., 'medicine water') (02/24/95/FH/pc; BE2.86; RBn1-MOJ/p40). mâhkaëóika mâì akxai, kitâhe hta akxa hôòpahu he's haywire with peyote, but he'll be all right at daylight (lit., 'peyote is moving throughout his body, but he will recover at/by dawn') (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.102; RBn HW). mâhkaçtôka pounded peyote (lit., 'soft medicine').

•• LFD 100: màhkâ <moæ-Ðoæ´> drugs, any kind of medicine except poisons. LFD 193: wahkío màhkà <wa-Ði´o moæ-Ðoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form wakØó màhká (lit., 'woman medicine')] love potion.  

••• WI mààká medicine (KM).

••• Cf. màhkáhpa, màhkása. 

màhká aðî (variant: màhkâ aðî). N pharmacist, druggist, one who has medicine (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LF 100: màhkâ aðì <moæ-Ðoæ´a-thiæ> a druggist, one who sells drugs.

màhká hpíiëi (variant: mâhkàhpíiëi). N poison, bad medicine. hcéxopehuuscee apa waðáaxtake che màhkà hpíiëipe the bite of a tarantula is poison (lit., 'tarantulas biting folks is poison').

•• LFD 162: hcéxope huuscee apa waðaxtake che màhkâ hpiiëipe <¾se´-xu-be hiu stse-e a-ba watha-xta-ge te moæ-Ðoæ ¼i-a-zhi bi a> the bite of a tarantula is poison.

màhká oðáahtà eenâ. N liquid medicine, medicine that comes in liquid form only (FH).

•• LFD 101 (unconfirmed): màhkâ oðahtà enà <moæ-Ðoæ´ u-tha-¾oæ e-noæ> strong; forcible; potent; said of a drug (02/24/95/FH/pc:uk). "Used also to represent a dose." [Unconfirmed as 'strong, forcible, potent' or as 'dose'; FH: expected form and gloss: oðahtà 'drink' + enà 'only', lit., 'only comes in liquid form'.]

màhká oðíkØe (variant: màhkâ oðíkØe). VP [sync., màhká o_ðíkØe] (trans., intr.) administer a shot or inoculation. màhká owíbrikØe I gave you a shot (FH:4/25/96/t141, prod).

•• LFD 101: màhkâ oðikØe <moæ-Ðoæ´ u-thi-Ð'e> to inoculate.

màhká saakí. N Liatris punctata, gayfeather, blazing star, dotted gay feather, Kansas gayfeather, dotted button-snake-root, starwort (lit., 'hard/strong medicine'; roots were stored to be used for their sweetness) (Kindscher 1987:142).

màhkáðaaché (variants: màhkâðaaché, màhkáaaché, màhkáaache) N [màhká + ðaaché] Native American Church meeting, peyote meeting (lit., 'eat medicine') (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). hpôhka htâwà ìkçe màhkâðaaché çcée hta ðaìçé? are you going to the meeting over at Ponca? (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.87).

màhkáhpa (variant: màhkâhpa). N [màhká + hpá] pepper (lit., 'bitter medicine') (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 100: màhkàhpa <moæ-Ðoæ-¼a> bitter medicine, pepper.

màhkáhpa sápe. N black pepper (lit., 'black medicine') (03/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 100: màhkâhpa sape <moæ-Ðoæ´-¼a ša-be> black pepper.

màhkáhpa ëúuce (variant: màhkâhpa ëúuce). N red pepper (03/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 100: màhkâhpa ëuce <moæ-Ðoæ´-¼a zhu-dse> red pepper.

màhkáhpaóoëu (variant: màhkâhpaóoëu). N [màhkáhpa + ooëú] pepper shaker (RBn1-7).

màhkása (variants: màhkásai, mòhkásai). N [màhká + sápe] coffee (lit., 'black medicine') (BE2.21; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 100: màhkâ sape <moæ-Ðoæ´ ša-be> coffee. màhkâ sape hkòbra <moæ-Ðoæ´ ša-be Ðoæbtha> I want some coffee. màhkâ sape che skiðe walì <moæ-Ðoæ´ ša-be tse ški-the wa-gthiæ> the coffee is too sweet. màhkâsape oðahtà <moæ-Ðoæ´-ša-be u-tha-¾oæ> coffee cup (lit., 'wherein coffee is drunk').

màhkásaiooëú. N cup (lit., 'wherein coffee is put', coffee cup: refers to any cup) (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• RB: <móæ-kah-sah-o-zhú>.

màhkáxope. N [màhká + xópe] sacred medicine (RB).

mâhkaëóika. V, ADJ [uninfl.] [màhká + ëúoka] (intr.) (be) haywire or crazed with medicine, have one's body affected by peyote. mâhkaëóika mâì akxai, kitâhe hta akxa hôòpahu he's haywire with peyote, but he'll be all right at daylight (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.102; RBn HW).  

màhkâ (variant of màhká).

màhkâhpa (variant of màhkáhpa). màhkâhpaóoëu (variant of màhkáhpaóoëu).

mâhki. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) take hold of one another, similar to wrestling (PM:prod; LS:uk, unconfirmed).

mâhkisòce (variant: mâhkiesi?). V [conjug. unknown] [presumably hkik- REFL/RECIP + mâsòce (unattested)] (intr.) wrestle one another (BE2.161; 04/06/95/LS/pc:okc). mâhkiesi apai they are wrestling (BE2.161; 03/24/95/PM/pc:prod).

•• LFD 100: mâhkisòce <moæ´-Ði-šoæ-dse> to wrestle (03/24/95/PM/pc:uk, unconfirmed). mâhkisòce àkiðali pia nihkaçika aka <moæ´-Ði-šoæ-dse oæ-gi-tha-gthi bi a, ni-Ða-shi-ga a-ka> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâhkiesi kiðálì pe, níhkaçika akxa] the man likes to wrestle.

••• Cf. ásàci. 

mâì (variant of màðî).

mâìhka (variants: môìhka, máihka, mòðîhka, màðîhka). N soil, ground, earth, clay, mud, dirt (BE2.125; 03/13/95/FH/pc:okc: non-nasal i); Earth (name for a second son) (FH:prod). [mâìhka was the personal name of FH's cousin, whose English name was Joe Kemohah.]

•• RB: <mó-iæ-kah, moæ-thíæ-kah>.

•• LFD 100: mòîhka <moæ-iæ´-Ða> ground, earth, soil, clay, mud. mòîhka aðiðaha e ðo <moæ-iæ´Ða a-thi-tha-ha e tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâìhka akxa áðista akxa] the mud sticks to you. mòîhka àðaha e ðo <moæ-iæ´-Ða oæ-tha-ha e tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâihka akxa âàsta akxa] the mud sticks to me. môìhka kaxe <Moæ´ iæ-Ða ga-xe> Maker-of-the-Earth, the name of a gens, also found among the Omahas. mòîhka ska <moæ-iæ´-Ða ška> white clay, gypsum. "Lime made from this kind of stone was used by both the Osage and Omaha for whitening the sinew used in making arrows; a variety of selenite, calcium sulphate." mòîhkaëìka <Moæ-iæ´-Ða-zhiæ-ga> Little-clay (personal name) refers to the four different colors of clay, given by the crawfish.

••• Cf. omâìhka. 

mâìhka íðiçtòka. N hoe (lit., 'with which to make the earth soft').

•• LFD 100: mòìhka iði çtòka <moæ-iæ-Ða i-thi shtoæ-ga> a harrow.  

mâìhkaçi. N cellar, basement (HH tape 8Ap4).

mâka (variant: môka). N skunk (03/10/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.122). [During the early twentieth century, some Osages enjoyed eating skunk and would have white hunters kill and clean skunks to deliver to them at their houses. Mr. George Sells often did so for hòòpé tóohka (AMS:pc).]  

•• RB: <móæ-kah>.

•• LFD 97: mâka <moæ´-ga> skunk.  

••• KS môòga, mâga (JOD) skunk (RR).

mâle. ADV down. hpée mâle forehead down.

•• LFD 127 (unconfirmed): hpemâle <¼e-moæ´-gthe> head bowed down.

màlî V [reg.?, _màlî?] [ki- VERTITIVE + màðî] (intr.) go home. màlîe! go on home! (RBn HW10) màlî hce éa tell him to go home.

màsîha. ADV to or on the other side, opposite (RBn, unconfirmed). mòsîha káaãa go on the other side, referring to a mud hole.

•• RB: <moæ-shí-ha>.

•• LFD 97 (unconfirmed): mòsô ðîhtaapaasta <moæ-šoæ´ thiæ-¾a-a-ba-sda> shave-on-one-side-ofthe-head: penitentiary, <moæ-šoæ´ thiæ-¾a> on one side (of the head), <a-ba-sda> shave. màsòíhta <moæ-šoæ-i´-¾a> at the other side.

mâçà (variants: màçâ, mâçò, môçò [RB]). N feathers of certain kinds of birds (such as eagle, hawk, and macaw) (01/24/95/FH/pc). [Not used for more ordinary feathers such as chicken feathers (súhka hîì) (HRE).] xúða mâçà eagle feathers (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok). xuðámàçò eagle-feather. úpeëâhta môçò scissortail feathers (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk). waëîkaíe môçò parrot feathers (01/24/95/FH/pc:ma; BE2.45). súhkatàà môçò turkey feathers. • fan made of feathers or loose feathers (as used in peyote meeting) (RB). xúða môçò eagle feather fan (RB). waëîkaíe môçò parrot feather fan (RB).

•• RB: <móæ-shoæ>.

•• LFD 101: mòçò <moæ-shoæ> feather, plume, plumage.  

mâçà oðîìke (variants: môçò oðîìke, mòçô oðîìke). VP [sync., mâçà _oðîìke] (intr.) vote (lit., 'grasp the feather'); (trans.) vote for (PM/7/7/94). kahíke mâçò obrîìke hta mìkçé I'm going to vote for the chief (04/26/95/FH/pc; BE2.149). mòçô oðîìke háaëò hta nîkçe? how are you going to vote? (RBn2MOJ/p19; PM). hàà ði, mâçò oðîìke çkôçta? how about you, do you want to vote right now?

(PM/7/7/94). pée mòçô oçcîìke? who did you vote for? • (trans.) endorse, as a check (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok; 02/27/95/JS/pc:ma; RBn2-MOJ/p19).

•• LFD 102: mâçà oðìke <moæ´-shoæ-u-thiæ-ge> voting; indorsing a check. mâçà obrìke <moæ´shoæ u-bthiæ-ge> I indorsed it. mâçà oscìke <moæ´-shoæ u-stsiæ-ge> you indorsed it. mâçà àkiðìka pe <moæ´-shoæ oæ-gi-thiæ-ga i> we indorsed it.  

••• Cf. súhkahtàà mâçò oðîìke. màçcîka (variants: mààçcîka, mâçcìka). N rabbit (BE2.111; JS:ok), hare.

•• RB: <móæ-shtsiæ-kah>.

•• LFD 102: mòçcîke <moæ-shtiæ´-ge> the cottontail rabbit.

mâçi (variant: máçi). V [reg., _mâçi] (intr.) be upward or upright. mâçì ce çkôçta? do you want to be pulled up [to a sitting position in the bed]? (BE2.107; RBn10-7:JW, unconfirmed),

•• LFD 101: môçi <moæ´-shi> up above, the arch of heaven, zenith.

••• Cf. ámàçi, ðuumâçi.

màçíhta. ADV, V [reg.?, _màçíhta?] (intr.) (be) above. màçíhtamàì walking-above (personal name) (RBn22-04). • (trans.) place above. ámaçihta mìkçé I'm going to put it up above (HRE/01/17/02/pc).

••• Cf. ámàçi. 

mâçò (variant of mâçà).

màçtáha (variant of mààçtáha).

mâxpu (variant: môxpu). N, ADJ cloud, cloudy. màxpúmèì apa oðíchìpe aapai lightning and thunder are getting you (line from a children's song) [mâxpu-màðî (lit., 'clouds moving') alludes to lightning and thunder] (FH). môxpu akxá it's cloudy (BE2.20; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 103: màxpí <moæ-xpi´> cloud, cloudy. màxpímàì <Moæ-xpi´-moæ-iæ> Traveling-cloud (personal name).

mâze. N metal of any kind, lead or iron (metal); wire, cable. mâze hcúke metal spoon. hkáwa apa mâze ohkíòðe apái the horses are tangled up in the wire (RBnot-nd-1/p18; FH:ok).

mâze ápahta (variant: mâze ápahtà). N wire or metal fence (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:uk).

•• LFD 96: mâze apahta <moæ´-še a-ba-¾a> wire fence.

mâze hcúke. N metal spoon.

mâze htáhtaze. N typewriter (04/06/95/FH:ok); ticking, tapping, or clicking noise against metal (as made by a typewriter) (FH/10/09/01/pc:ok).

•• LFD 97: mâze htahtaze <moæ´-še ¾a-¾a-še> ticking iron: typewriter. mâze htahtaze hceka wì abrì <moæ´-še ¾a-¾a-še tse-ga wiæ a-bthiæ> I have a new typewriter.

mâze íe ówatòe. N television (lit., 'speaking metal item wherein one watches things').

mâze ììçtóolà N [mâze + ììçtá + oolâ] glasses, eyeglasses, spectacles, lorgnette, any device worn over the eye or eyes (lit., 'metal to place on the eyes') (BE2.55; 05/01/95/LS/pc:ok, 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 96: mâze ìstolà wihta ðà màçoçoce ìða ha <moæ´-še iæ-stu-gthoæ wi-¾a thoæ moæ-sho-shodse iæ-tha ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâze ììçtóolà wíhta màçóçoce; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os. and ðà is not used in this context] my spectacles are dirty. mâze ììçtóolà sápe. N sunglasses (lit., 'black metal to place on the eyes').

mâze níi táahkace káaãe. N hot water heater (lit., 'metal for making water hot') (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig). [New coinage by FH.]

mâze nòpØî (variant of mâze wanôpØì).

mâze oðóbrììke. N [mâze + í- LOC + obrîìke (1st sg. of oðîìke); i + o regularly becomes oðo] trap (lit., 'I catch it with metal') (FH/09/09/01/pc).

•• LFD 222: ëápe wì obrîìke, mâze oðóbrììke <zha´-be wiæ u-bthiæ-ge, moæ-še u-thu bthiæ-ge> I caught a beaver in a steel trap.

mâze ohkíe. VP [reg., mâze o_hkíe] (trans., intr.) call by phone.

mâze oohô (variant: mâzeóohò). N oven.

mâze wanôpØì (variant: mâze nòpØî). N necklace of iron or other metal; iron necklace (personal name) (BE2:87; 02/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

mâze wépaache. N [mâze + wa- VAL + í- LOC + paaché] sewing machine (lit., 'metal with which to sew stuff').

mâzehtahiëì (variant: mâzehtaiëì). N bells, little bells (as on a cradleboard) (RB; 01/07/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• Cf. htáhtaze, mâzeçtahiëì.  

mâzeie. N [mâze + íe] radio (RBn12-06); recording device, tape recorder, tape player, phone, phone call (lit., '[something] metal [that] talks').

mâzeie híðe. VP [reg., mâzeie hí_ðe] (intr.) make a call by phone (lit., 'cause a phone call to arrive there'). óhkie çò ìkçé ihtézì akxa mâzeie híðape he was sitting and talking to someone when his younger sister called.

mâzeie ohkíe. VP [reg., mâzeie o_hkíe] (intr.) converse by phone, talk on the phone. • N conversation by phone, phone call.

mâzeie ohkíe híðe. VP [reg., mâzeie ohkíe hí_ðe] (intr.) make an outgoing phone call, call s.o. to converse on the phone (lit., 'cause a phone call to arrive there').

mâzekØàsaaki. N [mâze + kØâsaaki] telegraph, telegraph wire, message sent by wire (lit., 'fast metal'). mâze kØâsaki ðée hpaaãé I sent it by wire (03/16/95/FH/pc; BE2.134). mâze kØâsaaki ðée káaãa send

a wire (RBn3-58).

•• LFD 96: mâze kØàsaki <moæ´-še Ð'oæ-ša-gi> telegraph.

mâzekØàsaaki ðée káaãe. VP (trans.) send by wire, send there by telegraph (RBn10-12:JW).

mâzeohkíhkie. N [mâze + ohkíhkie ] telephone (lit., 'talk to each other over a wire')

(03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). mâzeohkíhkie òwâhkie call me on the phone (03/16/95/FH/pc). mâzeohkíhkie ðée kçí[ð]e call him/her on the phone (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). mâzeohkíhkie ðeekçí[ðe]áape they said they talked on the phone (03/16/95/FH/pc). mâzeohkíhkie akxa hkáamaa akxái the telephone is ringing (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.134).

•• LFD 97: mâze ohkihkie <mo´n´-še u-Ði-Ði-e> telephone.

mâzeohkíhkie hükçíe. VP [mâzeohkíhkie + hukçíðe] (trans.) have s.o. call by phone. mâzeohkíhkie hükçí[ð]e! have her call me on the phone! call me on the phone! (RB; 03/16/95/FH/pc:ma).

mâzeóohò (variant of mâze oohô).

mâzeôohò oohô. VP [reg., mâzeóohò oo_hô] (trans.) bake in an oven (BE2.6; FH/09/21/01/pc/okc). súhka mâzeoohò ce oowáhà I baked a chicken (FH/09/21/01/pc).  

mâzeska (variant: màzéske). N money, coin, silver (lit., 'white metal') (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok;

03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.121; MOJ). oðóota mâzeska interest money (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). mâëà oota mâzeska lease money (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). mâzeska huuhtâà waðákØupe you gave them a lot of money (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). mâzeska huuhtâà waðákØupe you gave us a lot of money (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). mâzeska háanà açcî ðaaçé? how much money do you have?

(02/25/95/FH/pc:ok: [ðaìçe]). mâzeska tóa àkØú give me some money (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). mâzeska tóe owâkØu loan me some money (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 96: mâzeska <moæ´-še-ška> white metal (money). mâzeska àðìke <moæ´-še-ška oæ-thiæge> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâzeska àðîke] I have no money. mâzeska ðiðìke <moæ´-še-ška thithiæ-ge> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâzeska ðiðîke] you have no money. mâzeska waðìka pe <moæ´še-ška wa-thiæ-ga i> we have no money (02/25/95/FH/pc:all okc).

mâzeska oðótà (variants: mâzeska oðóta, mâzeska óotà, mâzeska óota). N interest money (lit., 'usage of money').

mâzeska ootá waléze. N note, document of borrowed money, loan.

•• LFD 96: mâzeska ootá waleze <moæ´-še-ška u-da wa-gthe-še> paper or writing for borrowing money, a note.

mâzeska wanôpØì. N medal, medallion (lit., 'coin worn around the neck').

•• LFD 96: mâzeska wanòpØì <moæ´-še-ška wa-noæ-p'iæ> silver medal, peace medal (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

mâzeska zí. N gold (metal), coins (lit., 'yellow money') (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.59).

•• LFD 96: mâzeska zi <moæ´-še-ška ši> gold.  

mâzeska zí ékò. ADJP gold (in color), golden, goldlike (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok; RBn10-5:MOJ/79).

mâzeskahci. N [mâzeska + hcí] bank (lit., 'money house') (BE2.6; 01/06/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 96: mâzeska hci <moæ´-še-ška ¾si> bank. mâzeskaooëú (variant: mâzeskoëu [LS]). N [mâzeska + ooëú] purse, wallet, pocketbook, money bag, handbag, billfold (BE2.108; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 96: mâzeska oëu <moæ´-še-ška u-zhu> purse, pocketbook, wallet. mâzeska oëo àwà xpaðe ha <moæ´-še-ška u-zhu oæ-woæ xpa-the ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: mâzeskaooëú âwàxpaðe; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I lost my wallet.

màzéske (variant of mâzeska).

mâzeskoëu (variant of mâzeskaooëú).

mâzeçtahiëì. N bells (such as the ones dancers tie around their legs) (04/19/95/FH/pc:prod).  

mâzewéoohò (variant: mâzewíoohò). N [mâze + wéoohô] cookstove, metal stove (lit., 'metal to cook things with') (BE2.25; 01/12/95/FH/pc:ok; MSBt9; 04/06/95/LS/pc:okc; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ma). [In RB's time, a cookstove that used wood, though its usage may have been extended since then to include any stove used for cooking.]

màëáhku. N medicine bundle (RBnote-nd-1/p20, unconfirmed; 02/24/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 101: mâçahkò <moæ´-sha-Ðoæ> burden strap. "The burden strap was the holiest of the sacred symbols, surpassing even the hawk, the symbol of the warrior's courage. When a husband wishes to honor his wife he has one made for her ceremonially. This was one of the first ceremonies to die out when new religious ideas were introduced by missionaries."

mâëà (variants: môëò, màëâ). N allotment  (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok), farm (RB; FH). [Takes 'lying' positional article kçe.] níhkaçie kíhòòpe kóe màëâki olîì kíhòòpe he liked the people and he liked living on the farm (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). Jane, Ann éðòòpa màëâ hta íihkimai ahíe ðí áape Jane and Ann had come to visit the farm (FH). mâëà olîì aláape they went back to live on the farm (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.26). • earth (12/30/94/FH/pc/pron), world. môëò ðáalì môëò ðéka çki ðìkápi tà, íe wíhta akxa çòòçôwe hta akxai heaven and earth shall pass away, but my word shall endure (BE2.38; FH:4/22/96/tape:prod). môëò ðáalì ðékçe môëò ðékçe ðìké hta aëi íe wíhta çòòçôðe aðée hta akxai heaven and earth shall pass away, but my word shall endure (FH:02/07/96/pc: from the Bible, Matthew 24:35). môëò ðáalì ðékçe heaven. • land, country, countryside. mâëà htàà big country (LS). môëò ðíhta ée ðáalì your country is good (RBn12-11). níi ëópçe pçíe ðáha, táatà wì màëâ olîì iiðáðe when I would go to wade in the river, I saw something that was in the woods (lit., 'when I went to wade in the water, I saw a thing that lived in the countryside') (t24b-p17/num24CQ119;

04/27/95/FH/pc:okc, added iiðáðe). • personal name in the Eagle clan (only the variant môëò is used in this sense) (HRE:pc).

•• LFD 103: màëâ/mòëô <moæ-zhoæ´> earth, country, farm, world, land. 

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 103).

mâëà ðáalì (variants: mâëà ðáalì ðékçe, môëò ðáalì ðé). N heaven. [Takes 'lying' positional article kçe.] ìhtáci wahkôta, mâëà ðáalì ìkçi ðaníhkaçi nìkçí eepe our father, who art in heaven. môëò ðáalì ðékçe môëò ðékçe ðìké hta aëi íe wíhta çòòçôwe aðée hta akxai heaven and earth shall pass away, but my word will endure (FH: from the Bible, Matthew 24:35).  

mâëà ðé ómàðì (variant: môëò ðé ómàðì). VP [reg.+sync., mâëà ðé ó_mà_ðì] (intr.) live this life (lit.,

'walk on this earth'). wéewina môëò ðé çkaçkáða oámàbrì I want to thank you for this good life (lit., 'I am grateful, I walk on this earth peacefully') (RBn10-10:JW).  

mâëà óota (variants: mâëà óotà, mâëà óðootà, mâëà óðoota). N leasing of land (lit., 'land use') (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• RB: <móæ-zhoæ-o-táh>.

•• LFD 318: màëâ ota wakaçupe <moæ-zhoæ´ u-da wa-ga-shi-pe> rent (money paid).

màëâ çkâ. N earthquake (lit., 'earth move') (04/07/95/LS/pc:okc).

mâëà záani. NP world, whole world, universe (lit., 'all the land') (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). màëâhtà. N [mâëà + htâà] countryside.

màëâwaleze. N [mâëà + wáleze] map, chart of land, plat (lit., 'earth letter') (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). màëí (variant of maëí).

mée, méì, mêì (variants of màðî).

mí (variant of mîì).

miáðuãeëîka. N his wife's brother's wife (more precise than English 'his sister-in-law') (JOD).

•• JOD (slip file): miáðuãeëìka <mi-a´-¢ü-xªe-ciñ´-§ka> his wife's brother's wife.  

míaãe (variant: míàãe). N daughter-in-law (04/07/95/LS/pc; BE2.29, RBn2-MOJ/p9;

01/19/95/FH/pc:ok). [Vocative and referent, more familiar than wihcíni 'daughter-in-law' (RB); no difference between wihcíni and míaãe (FH).]

•• JOD (slip file): miáðuãe <mi-a´-¢ü-xªe> his wife's brother's wife.

••• PO míwaðiãe daughter-in-law (KDS); KS mîwayåãe sister-in-law, man's wife's brother's wife (RR).  

miáke (variant of mîìoðaake).

míalòçka (variant: milôçka). N little people (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok), elf, sprite, brownie, leprechaun, fairy. [Strictly speaking, the Osage "little people" are not fairies, but rather a scarier sort of being, not so small and dainty, and rather more ominous.]

•• LFD 93: míwaluçka <mi´-wa-gthu-shka> fay, an elf, a fairy. LFD 90: míaloçka <mi´-a-gthushka> elf, sprite.

miása (variant of mììása).

míaxoke (variant of miixóke).

míàãe (variant of míaãe).

miâke (variant of mîìoðaake).

michó. N lion (BE2.80, RBn2-MOJ/p2; 02/16/95/FH/pc:ok). [Perhaps originally 'grizzly bear'?] •• LFD 92: mìhcó <miæ-¾su´> grizzly bear. michúëìka <Mi-tsiu´-zhiæ-ga> Little-grizzly-bear (personal name).

míe (variant of mîìka).

míãa. N duck (PM); goose (PM); game bird or other large bird (01/20/95/PM/pc; BE2.37). [Takes

'sitting' positional article ìkçé.] •• JOD (slip file): míãa <mí-xa>.

•• LFD 94: míãa ëìka <mi´-xa zhiæ-ga> a teal duck. LFD 95: míãa ëìka xoce <mi´-xa zhiæ-ga xo-dse> teal duck. míãa çape ëìka <mi´-xa sha-be zhiæ-ga> a gosling. míãaçape <mi´-xa-sha-be> dark goose. LFD 93: míãahpahtoho <mi´-xa-¼a-¾o-ho> mallard duck [míãa + hpá 'head' + htóho] (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok, all above okc). míãatoka <mi´-xa-do-ga> a drake. LFD 54 (unconfirmed): míãa ëìka ðìkçe leëé <mi´-xa zhiæ-ga thiæ-kshe gthe-zhe´> [expected Mod. Os. form: míãaëì ìkçe léëe] the duck is spotted.

míãa htâka (variant: mîãa htâke). N goose, big goose or big duck (lit., 'big duck') (RBn1-24; FH/09/21/01/pc; BE2.59; 02/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

míãa ska. N swan (lit., 'white duck') (FH/09/21/01/pc).

•• LFD 93: míãaska <mi´-xa ška> the white swan.

mihkákØe. N star; mushroom (04/17/95/LS/pc:uk; 04/18/95/FH/pc:ok, 03/14/95/FH/pc:pl; BE2.127).

•• LFD 91: mihkákØe <mi-Ða´-k'e> mushroom; star.

mihkákØe hà tà ðìkçé. N evening star (lit., 'the star when it's evening, sitting'). [Takes 'sitting' positional article ìkçé.]

mihkákØe hâàpa tà ðìkçe. N morning star. [Takes 'sitting' positional article ìkçé.]

•• LFD 91: mikákØe hôòpatà ðìkçe <mi-Ða´-Ð'e hoæ´-ba-doæ thiæ-kshe> the morning star, used in rituals.

mihkákØe hâàpaska tà. N morning star (lit., 'star when it is daylight') (FH/09/24/01/prod).

mihkákØe oxpáðe. N falling star, meteor (FH/09/24/01).

•• LFD 91: mihkákØe oxpaðe <mi-Ða´-Ð'e u-xpa-the> meteor, falling star.

mihkákØe óëàke. N orbit of star (lit., 'star path').

•• LFD 91: mihkákØe oëàke <mi-Ða´-Ð'e u-zhoæ-ge> the path of a star, orbit.

mihkákØehtàà. N morning star (lit., 'great star').

mihkákØeëìka. N [mihkákØe + ëìká] little star.

•• LFD 91: mihkákØeëìka <Mi-Ða´-Ð'e-zhiæ-ga> Little-star (personal name).

míi (variant of mîì and mîìka).

miiáðee (variant of mììáðee ehtáha). míihtoili (variant of mîìhtòeli).

míika (variant of mîìka).

míina. N eldest daughter (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). [Pawhuska district usage.]

•• LFD 92: mína <mi´-na> the first daughter; "this is a special kinship term. This term is used by a father and mother for their first daughter. The term is also used by other members of the family. It is not a personal name, it is, however, a gentile name, by which she may be addressed by anybody."  

••• KS mínaga daughter (RR).  

míiòpa (variant of mîìòpa).

miitáaçcuuce (variant of mììtáaçcuuce).

miixóke (variant: míaxoke [FH]). ADJ, N homosexual, lesbian, gay person (for some, this term refers only to males) (BE2.67; FH).

•• RB: <mí-ho-keh, mí-ah-xó-keh> (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc).

milôçka (variant of míalòçka).

míwaapaache (variant of mîwaapaache).

míwatà (variant: míwata). V, ADJ [reg.?, míwa_tà?] (intr.?) (be) jealous (the jealous person is male) (RBn10-19). míwata çtà he's jealous all the time (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok) (RB note: jealous, applies to men's jealousy). N man who is jealous of [about] his wife (RB).

•• LFD 93 (unconfirmed) : míwata <mi´-wa-da> to be jealous, As a man of a woman. waó wì miaata ha <wa-u´ wiæ mi-a-a-da ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I am jealous of a woman. waó wì miaðata ha <wa-u´ wiæ mi-a-tha-da ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you are jealous (02/13/95/FH/pc:uk). [waú or waó in the last two examples is probably Omaha; Mod.

Os. instead uses wakØó 'wife, woman'.]

mî. N blanket, robe, garment, any item worn like a blanket or robe.

•• JOD (slip file): mì <miæ> a robe. 

mî. V [alternate form of 1st sg. of ðî; cf. brî] (intr.) I am, I was, I live, I exist as. níhkaçi mì I live, I am a person, I live as a human. • [1st sg. of î 'wear'] I wear.

mîce. N bow (BE2.10; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). [Takes 'lying' positional article kçe.] ëâàmîce a wooden bow, an ordinary bow to shoot arrows.

•• JOD (slip file): mîce <miæ´-¦t¦se> a bow.

•• LFD 92: mîce <miæ´-dse> bow. "The Osage made their bows of the Osage orange saplings. When this wood is not obtainable, they use the hickory or the ash sapling." mîce kçe aluze <miæ´dse ke a-gthu-še> I recovered my bow. mîce kaãe hpimà <miæ´-dse ga-xe ¼i-moæ> I am skilled in bow making.

mîcehkà. N [mîce + hkâ] bowstring (LF, unconfirmed; 04/07/95/PM/pc:uk; 04/19/95/FH/pc:uk); trigger.

•• LFD 92 (unconfirmed): mîcehkà <miæ´-dse-Ðoæ> the trigger of a gun. wahóhtàðe mîcehkà che brítà ha <wa-hu´-¾oæ-the miæ´-dse-Ðoæ tse bthi´-doæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: wahóohtà mîcehkà bríità; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I pulled the trigger. mîcehkà <Miæ´-dseÐoæ> Bow-string (personal name).

mîceçtá hu. N Osage orange tree, bois d'arc (RBn22-01).

•• LFD 301: mìceçtahi <miæ´-dse-shta hi> Osage orange.

mîe (variant of mîìka).

mîãa htâke (variant of míãa htâka).

mîhkaa (variants: mìhká, mìhkáa). N raccoon (MOJt150; BE2.111; 04/20/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): mikØá <mi´k'ªa´>, mìhká <miæhká> the raccoon.

•• LFD 91: mihká <mi-Ða´> raccoon. "The raccoon was used for food by both the Osage and the

Omaha."

••• KS mikká raccoon (RR).

mìhkása. N black person (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod). [Slang; a corruption, blending mììása 'black person' (lit., 'blackened by the sun') with mîhkaa, mìhká(a) 'raccoon'; influenced by the English derogatory expression coon, which applied to a useless person of any race.] kóoci ìhtáci akxa íinà éðòòpa óðaake ðée, oâðaake ðée: mìhkása ðée ðe, hpahâle iiðápi che a long time ago my father and mother, they told things, they told me this: that that black person was the first one they ever saw (RBn23-10; translation by CQ).

•• JOD (slip file): mihká sápe <Mi-ka´ sa´-§pe> a Negro.

mîì (variants: míi, mí). N sun. kasîexcì mîì àtôpe htái let's go see the morning sun coming up (as in a peyote meeting) (BE2.129; 01/14/95/FH/pc). mîì íistahkie bless yourself with the sun (RBn2-26). mîì akxa íðòpi akxai the sun is coming up (RB; BE2.38). • moon (used in phrases such as "east door, west moon" [a way of running peyote meetings] [PM]). mîìohkâce February, the solitary moon.

•• JOD (slip file): mì <miæ> the sun.

•• LFD 90: mi <mi> sun.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 90).

••• Cf. mîìòpa. 

mîì. N, ADJ female.

••• Cf. mîìka, wîì. 

mîì íðòpe. N sunrise, the emergence of the sun (lit., 'sun appears'). [Takes 'sitting' positional article

ìkçé.] (RB; BE2.38).

mîì íðòpe ìkçé (variant: mîì íðòpa ìkçé). ADV, N east (lit., 'sun appears, sitting').

•• RB <mí-í-thoæ-pah-iæ-kshéh>.

mîì okØâìke. N [mîì 'month' + okØâ + ðìké] March (the month when the sun is just teasing: e.g., sun in the morning but blizzard in the afternoon) (lit., 'month of no events') (RBn12-05).

mììáðee ehtáha (variants: mììáðee ehtá, miiáðee). N west (lit., 'toward where the sun goes', i.e., 'where the sun sets' [RB]). mààçäékçi ehtáha koe miáðee ehtáha tokétà taakáce ci achíe I come from the south and the west in the heat of summer (RBn17-p01). • ADVP toward sundown (as a time of day) (04/06/95/PM/pc).

•• RB: <mi-áh-theh-eh-táh>.

mîìake, mîìàke (variants of mîìoðaake).

mììása (variants: mîìasa, mîìasai, miása). N black person (lit., 'sun-blackened') (HH-T8a-p5; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok:all).

•• RB: <miæ-áh-sah>.

••• Cf. mìhkása. 

mììðóhta (variants: mîìðohtà, mîìðohta). ADV, N (at) noon, midday, high noon, sun seen straight overhead (03/01/95/FH/pc:okc). mîìðohta ahí akxa it's straight up noon (lit., 'it's arrived at sun straight up') (PM). ónalìpi, mîìðohta ahíe akxái hurry up you all, it's [noon]time (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig).

•• RB: <mí-thoæ-tah>.

mììðóhta ðiiçtâ (variant: mììðóhtà ðiiçtâ). ADV, N (in the) afternoon (lit., 'noon finished') (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod).

mììðóhta waaðô. N midday songs, noontime songs.

•• LFD 93: miðóhtà waðò <Mi-tho´-¾oæ Wa-thoæ> Mid-day Songs.

mììðóhta wanôbre (variant: mîìðohtáwanôbre). N lunch, noon meal, dinner eaten at midday

(03/01/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). mîìðohta wanôbre táatà àðáache hta akátxa? what are we having for noon meal? (BE2.83).

•• LFD 103: miðóhtà wanòbre <mi-tho´-¾oæ wa-noæ-bthe> dinner. miðóhtà áwanòbre <mi-tho´¾oæ a-wa-noæ-bthe> I had dinner [expected gloss: 'I ate at noon']. miðóhtà waðánòbre <mi-tho´-¾oæ wa-tha-noæ-bthe> you had dinner [expected gloss: 'you ate at noon'].

mììðóhta ëiçô. ADV, N (in the) forenoon, late morning (CQnote80; RBn1-10). mîìðohta, mîìðohtà (variants of mììðóhta).

mîìðohtáwanôbre (variant of mììðóhta wanôbre).

mììhcéxi (variant: mîìhcéxì). N [mîì 'sun' or 'female'? + hcéxi] personal name for a first daughter (perhaps 'precious female', 'difficult female', 'stout daughter', 'sacred sun') (FH).

•• LFD 92: mîhcexi <Miæ´-¾se-xi> Sacred Robe. LFD 54: letômihcexi <Gthe-doæ´-mi-¾se-xi> New-hawk-woman (female personal name).

••• Cf. waëáëemîìhcéxì. 

mîìhiðe (variant: mîìhìðe). N sundown, evening (BE2.129; MREI; 04/05/95/LS/pc:ok). brée aðìhe mîìhiðe kçi hta àhé I go onward toward the west (BE2.154).

•• LFD 28: bre aðì heða mihiðe kçe htahe <bthe a-thiæ he-tha mi-hi-the kshe ¾a-he> [expected

Mod. Os. form: brée aðìhé, mîìhiðe kçehta] I go onward toward the west. LFD 91: mîìhiekçéhta <mi hi-e-ge´-¾a> [LF's <ge> is presumably an error for <ke>, modern kçe] toward the setting of the sun.

mîìhpapo. N [mîì 'sun' + hpapó 'going down' (not otherwise attested in the Mod. Os. data, but presumably related to papó)] late afternoon, but not close to dark (HRE/01/17/02/pc:RBn1-10; WF:ok: 12/30/94/FH/pc/uk). [Synonymous with mîìhiðe (HRE).]

•• LFD 124: hpapó <¼a-bu>down hill, a steep incline.

mîìhtòeli (variant: míihtoili). N [mîì + tôpe + alí] sunflower; gum, chewing gum. [Secondary accent recorded on -htò-.] mîìhtoeli oolâ akxa he's chewing gum (lit., 'he has put gum in [his mouth]') (RBn14-03; HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok). mîìhtòili bráaçkike I'm chewing this gum (01/24/95/FH/pc:prod). mîìhtoili wì àkØú give me a piece of gum. káa ìkçé, mîìhtoeli hkilúwì here, buy yourself some gum (BE2.62).

•• RB: <mí-to-eh-li>.  

•• LFD 92: míhtoole <mi´-¾o-o-xthe> sunflower, looks always to the sun. "The compass weed, from this weed there is a gum that exudes from the stalk."

mîìhuðe. N daybreak, dawn, morning, moment when the sun is coming up. mîìhuðe che? is the sun coming up? (04/13/95/FH/pc:prod; FH:4/25/96/tape).

mîìka (variant: míika). ADJ female. àëì howáìki súhkahtâà mîìka hcí káaãe che ípahòëi akxa áape but they could not guess where turkey hen made her nest [they said] (RBn19-05).

•• LFD 90: miká <mi-ga´> female. hce míka <¾se mi´-ga> female buffalo. hkáwa mika <Ða´wa mi-ga> female horse (mare). [All LF forms should have nasal ì or îì.] ••• KS mìgá ~ mîga female, female animal, female of any species (RR).

••• Cf. çòmîìka. 

mììká ðìké. ADJP, VP [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) without females (said of a family with all daughters and no sons).

mîìlàke. V [reg., mîì_làke] [mîì + lâke] (intr.) marry a woman, take a wife, marry

(MREI/6/7/94/num94; 02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). mîìðalàke? are you getting married? haakxâta mîìðalàke hta ðaìçé? when are you going to get married? (RBn10-18). John mììlâkiape John got married (RBn14-08). John mîìlàki áape John got married [they said] (RBn). mîìlàke aðáape they went to get married (02/24/95/FH/pc; BE2.85). mîìlàke àkáðe we went to get married (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

• ADJ married (referring to a man). John akxa mîìlàki akxai John's married (02/24/95/FH/pc). mîìðalàke ðaìçé you're married (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). • N wedding, marriage (used by friend or family of groom) (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; MREI/6/7/94/num94). mîìlàke brée ðe I'm going to a wedding (spoken by family or friend of the groom) (02/27/95/JS/pc; 02/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): mìlàke <miæ-§k¢añ-¦ke>.

•• LFD 93: míða làke ì to <mi´-tha gthoæ-ge iæ do> [ì to is not used in Mod. Os.] you are married.

mîìoðaake (variants: mîìake, mîìàke, miâke, miáke, mîìòke). N [mîì 'sun' + oðáake] clock, o'clock, time, time of day (lit., 'sun tells it') (FH). mîìoðaake háanà che? what time is it? (BE2.20; 01/07/95/FH/pc). mîìoðáake háatkxà hí che? what time has it gotten to be? (FH:prod). mîìake háanà ìkçé? what time is it? (RBn3-35). mîìòke lébrà tà alí hta mìkçé I'll be back at ten o'clock.

•• LFD 93: míoðake <mi´-u-tha-ge> a clock. míoðake wihta ðà wahosca <mi´-u-tha-ge wi-¾a thoæ wa-hu-stsa> my clock is small.

mîìoðaake háanà (variant: mîìòke háanà). NP what time? (lit., 'how much on the clock?'). mîìoke háanà che? what time is it? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). mîìoðaake háanà ci ðalíe? at what time did you get back? (RBn1-46).

mîìoðaake ohtánà. N hour.

mîìohkâce. N [mîì + óhkace] January (lit., 'moon alone') (RBn12-05; FH/11/17/01/pc:ok); February, the solitary moon (LF).

•• LFD 93: míohkàci <Mi´-u-Ðoæ-dsi> the solitary moon, month of February. "This is the version of Black Dog, while Chief Look-out says it is the month of January."

 mîìòke (variant of mîìoðaake).

mîìòkØaìke. N [mîì + ókØà + ðìké] February (lit., 'month of inaction') (RBn10-19, unconfirmed).

[Reported by RB as 'half days good, half not good'.]

•• LFD 93: mi ókØò ðìke <Mi´ u-Ð'oæ thiæ-ge> Moon of the Idle days, March.

mîìòpa (variant: míiòpa). N moon, month, month's time (PM:pc,02/25/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.89). [Names of months and days were not used in Osage and are not natural for Osage speakers (HH).]

•• LFD 92: míòpa <mi´-oæ-ba> the moon. míòpa kikØape kile <mi´-oæ-ba gi-k'a-be gi-gthe> the waning of the moon (unconfirmed; 02/25/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• Cf. mîì 'sun, moon'.

mîìòpa aðikeëe. N crescent moon (02/25/95/FH/pc:ma). [aðikeëe is not otherwise attested in the Mod.

Os. data.]

•• LFD 92 (unconfirmed): míòpa aðikeëe <mi´-oæ-ba a-thi-ge-zhe> a half moon, a crescent.

mîìòpa álìì ðòòpá. N December (lit., 'month twelve') (HH/14-a/305ff; HH/pc).

mîìòpa álìì wîxci. N November (lit., 'month eleven') (HH/14-a/249ff; HH/pc). mîìòpa hkíetoopa. N August (lit., 'month eight') (HH/14-a/274ff ).

mîìòpa hpàhâle. N January (lit., 'first month to arrive') (04/28/95/LS/pc; HH/14-a/249ff).

mîìòpa hpeðôòpa (variant: mîìòpa hpéòòpa). N July (lit., 'month seven') (HH/pc).

mîìòpa kootáha. N month before last (lit., 'the month beyond', 'that month farther away') (HH/t38a-p1).

mîìòpa lébrà. N October (lit., 'month ten') (HH/14-a/305ff; HH/pc).

mîìòpa lébrà hce wîìke. N September (lit., 'month nine') (HH/14-a/305ff; HH/pc).

mîìòpa çápe. N April (lit., 'shaded moon' or 'dark moon') (RBn12-05, unconfirmed).

mîìòpa táahpa. N full moon (lit., 'round moon') (02/25/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 92: míòpa ðò tahpa <mi´-oæ-ba thoæ da-¼a> the moon is round.

mîìòpa wahkôta iëîke iitáe ékitxà. N December (lit., 'the month when God's son was born, it's that time again') (HH/14-a/347; HH/pc).  

mîìòpa weðáabrì. N March (lit., 'third month') (HH/14-a/249ff ).

mîìòpa weðôòpa (variant: mîìòpa wéðòòpa). N February (lit., 'second month') (HH/14-a/249ff ).

mîìòpa wesáhtà. N May (lit., 'fifth month') (HH/14-a/449ff).

mîìòpa weçáhpe. N June (lit., 'sixth month') (HH/pc).

mîìòpa wetóopa. N April (lit., 'fourth month') (HH/14-a/449ff). mîìçechie. N Follows-the-Sun, an Eagle clan name (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.171). [Smokey Lookout's name.]

•• RB: <mí-sheh-tseh>.

••• KS mîähiyé-khe (JOD) south, the course the sun passes (RR).

mììtáaçcuuce (variant: miitáaçcuuce). N [mîì + táa- + çcúuce] sunbeam (lit., 'warm by heat from the sun') (FH/09/23/01/pc).

•• LFD 90: mi táscuce <mi da´-stsu-dse> sunbeam.

mììwáaðòëì. N [mîì + waaðô + -ëì 'little'] sun songs (based on LF).

•• LFD 93 (unconfirmed): mi wáò ëìka <mi wa´-oæ zhiæ-ga> little songs of the sun. "These songs are the ¾si´zhu [hcíëo] version and are appeals for aid from that heavenly body for success in defeating the enemies of the tribe. In these songs the Sun is referred to as Grandfather, reference is made to its rising--first, its outspreading rays, second, its appearance above the horizon visible to the supplicant, third, the appearance of plumelike shafts, and, fourth, when it has fully arisen."

mìkçé. CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 1st sg. sitting or lying down subject. [mìkçé is sometimes used for 1st sg. subjects that are not lying down; hence it can be regarded as the default 1st sg. continuative marker.] ðéekaa mìkçé I'm here (FH). brée hta mìkçé I'm going; I will go. oáhà mìkçé I was cooking; I am cooking.

çée mìkçé I'm just sitting here [near you]. haaléëowaáke àwâxpaðe mìkçe I have lost my handkerchief (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.63; 04/11/95/LS/pc:okc) [contrast this example with haaléëowaáke àwâxpaðe 'I lost my handkerchief' (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok)]. ëéka xô mìkçé my leg is broken (FH). wébruwì mìkçé I'm selling it [contrast this example with wébruwì 'I sold it'].

mîwaapaache (variant: míwaapaache). N [mî 'blanket' + wáapaache 'ribbon work, sewing'] woman's broadcloth blanket (RB; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; FH/09/10/01/pc:ok).

mô. V [1st sg. form of ô 'do'] I do (rare usage).

mô (variant of môò 'I wear').

mô, môò (variants of mâà).

mòðîhka (variant of mâìhka).

mòhkásai (variant of màhkása).

môìhka (variant of mâìhka).

môka (variant of mâka).

mòkápo. N coat (BE2.21, unconfirmed; 01/09/95/FH/pc: môkápxo?; 04/13/95/LS/pc:uk; PM/uk; BE2.21).

[Pawhuska usage; borrowed from French (RB).]

•• LFD 97: màkápo <moæ-ga´-bu> "same as a-ga-ha-mi [i.e., ákahamì 'coat, cape']."

mônòì (variant: mônoi). N prairie chicken (BE2.107; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). ëòhpazi mònoì océ pçíe I went to look for quail and prairie chicken (RBn3-MOJ/p1).

•• LFD 101: mônòì <moæ´-noæ-iæ> prairie chicken. 

môò (variants: mô, môì, môè). V [1st sg. form of ôò] (trans.) I wear.

môò (variant of mààðô).

môòãe (variant of mâàãe).

môòha. N cliff, bank, escarpment, mountain (RB; 04/06/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 98: môha <moæ´-ha> a cliff.

môòhahtáhu. N [presumably môòha + htaacé + ahú] west wind. môò htahú weather, coming toward us (04/06/95/PM/pc:okc; BE2.154).

•• LFD 98: môha hto iðe <moæ´-ha ¾u i-the> wind from the west (unconfirmed; 04/06/95/PM/pc:uk).

môòhisi, môòhisu (variants of mâàhìsu).

môòke (variant of mâàke).

môòke zí htâà. N meadowlark (lit., 'large yellow chest') (RBn18-01, unconfirmed).

môòsa (variant of môòse).

môòsa hu. N dogwood (RBn HW13), arrow shaft tree (RBn22-01).

••• QU mâsa hí dogwood bush or tree, Cornus (RR).

môòsase (variant of mâàsase).

môòse (variants: mâàse, mâàsi, môòsa). N arrow shaft (RB10:15, unconfirmed). môòse hcéxi sacred arrow shaft (RBn10-15, unconfirmed). mâàsihcexi Sacred Arrow Shaft (female personal name).

•• JOD (slip file): mâsa <maæ´-sa> an arrow-shaft.

•• LFD 232: môsa <moæ´-ša> arrow shaft.  

môòsi céãe. N willow (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77, unconfirmed).

môpçe. N older generation. môpçe ðanî you're the elder (7/7/94/PM). môpçe anî I'm the elder (7/7/94/PM; 01/06/95/FH/pc:uk). • forebears, ancestors (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 101: môpçe <moæ´-pshe> birth, the beginning of a family, the start of a generation.

môçò (variant of mâçà).  

mòxíðe (variant of màãíðe).

môxpu (variant of mâxpu).

môëò (variant of mâëà 'land, country').

muskóke. N Creek Indians (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 246: mòçkóke <Moæ-shko´-ge> Creek Indians.  

na (variant: nà). ADV only, just, solely, not anything else than, not anything but. wahkôta akxa eená hta akxa na, hpahâle mêì, ahkílaðìpai soon it will be only God, put him first, carry yourself that way (04/04/99/FH/pc). mâàhì wahúhka âkaëupaëí, mâzehcuka na àkáëupe we didn't put a knife or fork on, we just put spoons on (RBn3-49). wálì toocéehape waachí nà apái he eats too much and he doesn't do anything but dance (lit., 'indeed he is an over-eater, he only dances') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). éenàìtôìpi looking-only-at-her (personal name). wína, wínà I only. ðína, ðínà you only. éena, éenà he/she/it only, that only. àkóna, àkónà we only. màhkâ oðáahtà éenà a liquid medicine to drink only, a dose of medicine.

••• KS hnâ only (RR).

na (variant of nà 'always').

na-, naa- (variants of nàà-).

naa (variant of nàðé).

naaãúce níe (variant of nààãúce níe). naaãúhaçe (variant of nààãúhaçe).

naahléke, naaléke (variants of nààléke). naastâ (variant of nààstá).

naaxí (variant of nààxí).

naaxô (variant of nààxô).

nahkòî (variants: nàhkówì, nàhkùî). PRON both (BE2.10; 01/07/95/FH/pc:prod; 03/02/95/FH/pc:prod hk); pair, couple, the two of them.

•• LFD 115: nâhkowì <noæ´-Ðu-wiæ> the two, both.

nakxáçe, nakxâçe (variants of nàkxáçe). nalôòha (variant of nàlôòha).

nana (variant of nànà).

náçki (variant of nâçki).

naçò (variant: naço). ADV at least, leastways. naço "àhái" áaapi! at least you all [women] could say "yes"! (lit., 'leastways say "yes"!').  

náwaze (variant of nâwàzi).

nà (variant of na 'only').

nà (variants: na, nò). ITERATIVE MARKER always, repeatedly, habitually, customarily, usually, recurringly, continually, continue to, used to. [Placed after verbs.] ékie nàpe they always said. mîxa htâà, hâ wíe ní kçi áçka brée nai well, I always go near water, said the goose (RBn19-04). àwáðahtà nà we drink (MREI 11/01/83). wamâàðò nàpe he steals all the time. wî[e] áoxta tà táata éëiçki ékimà nà when I like somebody, I'll do anything for them (RBn17-p03; HRE/01/17/02/pc:okc). waachíe watôì çcée nà hta akxai you're always going to go to dances (MSB-9-3-82). wî[e] áoxta tà táata éëiçki ékimà nà when I like somebody, I'll do anything for them (RBn17-p03; HRE/01/17/02/pc:okc). kalíëe wéçkaaãe nà[ð]e you used to make them with flint. ëìkáëì hóolà iðáëoçi nà I always used to tell the children not to go fishing (FH:prod). hkáwa ðáalìpi nà he continues to be a good horse (RBn1203p5). • ADJ(?) distributed to each. ihtá na it belongs to each of them.

••• Cf. çínà, çtà. 

nà. INTERJ now, but, well. nà haakxâta líie? but when is she coming back? well, when is she coming back? (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok: well). nà haakxâci líie? [now,] when did she get back?

(02/01/95/FH/pc:prod orig). • I wonder. [Used at the beginning of the sentence, nà adds a speculative tone to an otherwise simple question and is often glossed as 'wonder'.] nà háakxàhta lí? I wonder when she's coming back? (lit., 'now, when in the future does she return?') (RBn2-MOJ/p10, FH:ok).

•• LFD 112: nà <noæ> look you; lo!

nàà (variant of nàðé).

nàà- (variants: na-, nà-, naa-). INSTR on or with one's foot or feet, by foot. nààëì he is standing. naaxô break with the foot (LS:prod: nààãô).

•• LFD 117: nàãáke(?) <noæ-xa´-ge> to make one cry out by kicking him. ðanâãake(?) <thanoæ´-xa-ge> you made him cry out by kicking him.

nâàce (variant of ðâàce). nâàãe. N spirit.  

nâàãeska. V, ADJ [uninfl.] [nâàãe 'spirit' + ská 'clear'] (intr.) (be) sober, not drunk, clear-minded, in one's right mind (lit., 'spirit clear'). nâàãeskaëì mìkçé I'm sober, in my right mind

(03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/13/95/FH/pc:ok; FH:prod). nâàãeska ìkçé? is he sober? (FH). nâàãeska nìkçé? are you sober? (FH). wáli húheka kçi apa àëì nâaãeska kçí ape she's awfully sick, but her mind is all right (FH/6/16/95). nâàãeskaëì very sober, not drunk at all (RB). nâàãeská ðâàçé? are you sober?

•• LFD 117: nâãeska <noæ´-xe-ška> sober. nâãeàska <noæ´-xe-oæ-ška> I am sober. nâãe ði ska <noæ´-xe thi ška> you are sober. nâãe ska pi a <noæ´-xe ška bi a> he is sober, staid, dignified, spirit, white, clearness of mind, return to consciousness, sane, sober. [Stative conjugation is used for this verb in LF's examples.]

nâàãeskahkiðe (variant: nâàãeskahki[ð]e). V [nâàãeska + hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] [conjug. unknown] (intr.) sober up. nâàãeskahkíe! sober up!

nààãúce. N ear, inner ear. nààãåce låuwasü! wash your ears! (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok).

• act of hearing, understanding, paying attention, heeding advice (RB; 01/20/95/PM/pc:prod).

•• LFD 119: nàãuce <noæ-xu´-dse> the internal ear, that which holds the hearing orifice.

nààãúce ðìké (variants: nààãúuce ðìké, nààãúce ìké). N no ears (refers to a person who won't listen and is doing things wrong) (FH/09/22/01/pc:okc) [Not a clan name.] nààãúce ìké doesn't listen to advice (RBn2-MOJ/p5;12/30/94/FH/pc:ok; 01/20/95/PM/pc:prod).

•• LFD 119: nàãúceðìke <Noæ-xu´-dse-thiæ-ge> No-ears (personal name). [May refer to not hearing or heeding warnings of danger, thus 'brave' (KDS). Unknown as a name to Mod. Os. speakers.]

nààãúce níe (variant: naaãúce níe). VP [reg., nààãúce _níe] have an earache (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). • N earache.

•• LFD 119: nàãúce nie <noæ-xu´-dse ni-e> earache.

nààãúce oðipxokçi. N ear pop (WF/12/30/01).

•• LFD 119: nòãúceoðipxokçi <noæ-xu´-dse-u-thi-po-ki> ear pop, oak gall. "Children gather the oak gall and pop them in each other's ears; hence the name."

nààãúce xéka. V, ADJ [stat., nààãúce _xéka] (intr.) (be) deaf. nàãúce xékapi na he's deaf (RBn23-15). [Expected Mod. Os. forms: nààãúce àxeka 'I'm deaf', nààãúce ðixeka 'you're deaf'.]

•• LFD 249: nàãúce xeka <noæ-xu´-dse xe-ga> deaf.

nààãúhaçe (variant: naaãúhaçe). N ear wax (WF). naaãúhaçe akxa he has ear wax (WF/12/30/01).

nààãúuce ðìké (variant of nààãúce ðìké).

nààhtâ (variant: nâàhta [FH]). N ear (of a person or animal), outer part of ear, earlobe (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod: short final a; 01/20/95/PM/pc:ok both). nâàhtà lúuëa wash your ears (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok; BE2.38). nâàhtà àðúuëa wash my ears.

•• RB: <naæ-táh>.

•• LFD 117: nàhtá <noæ-¾a´> the lobe of the ear.

nààhtâhtàà (variant: nààhtâhtàka). N [nààhtâ + htâka] mule, jack mule, donkey, burro, ass (lit., 'big ears') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok, prod; 01/20/95/PM/pc:prod). waxpéì àkái, ókØu àðúucØake çe nààhtàhtàà oðúucØake wî we're too poor to feed that lazy donkey (lit., 'we are poor, that donkey who was lazy, we couldn't feed him') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79).

•• LFD 117: nàhtá htàka <noæ-¾a´ ¾oæ-ga> a mule.

nâàke. V [reg., _nâàke] (intr.) run (RBn12-07). çí hkôhkòe apai, ëìkáëì apa páskuha nààkí apai he went round and round, as children ran beside him (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). wisôka akxa nâàke kØâsakipe brother is a fast runner (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig).

•• LFD 114: nâke <noæ´-ge> to gallop. anâke <a-noæ´-ge> I galloped. ðanâke <tha-noæ´-ge> you galloped. ònâka pe <oæ-noæ´-ga i> we galloped, to run, the running of a four-legged animal.

••• KS nâge to run four-legged (RR).

nààkØô (variant of nàkØô).

nààléke (variants: naaléke, naahléke). V [ reg.?, _nààléke?] [nàà- INSTR + léke] (trans.) shatter by foot or with the foot.

nààstá (variant: naastâ). V [ reg., _nààstá?] [nàà- INSTR + stá] (trans.) kick (RB-MOJ); (intr.) stomp the ground, trampling or flattening it (lit., 'make bare by foot'). hpahâle nààstâ apa nà kówe ìlôòçka waachípe first he kicked, then he war-danced (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; CQ:okc: àà). hkáwa apa nààstá apai the horses are kicking (RBn23-14, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 113: nàstáke <noæ-šta´-ge> trample down, crush the grass: ánàstake <a´-noæ-šta-ge> I trampled it down. ðánàstake <tha´-noæ-šta-ge> you trampled it down. ànàstakape <oæ-noæ-šta-ga i> we trampled it down.

••• Cf. kaaçtá, ostá . 

nààxí (variant: naaxí). V [reg., _nààxí] [nàà- INSTR + -xi] (trans.) wake or awaken by (nudging someone with the) foot.

•• LFD 117: nàxí <noæ-xi´> to awaken a sleeping person. anâxi <a-noæ´-xi> I awoke him by heavy walking. ðanâxi <tha-noæ´-xi> you awoke him by heavy walking, by walking heavily or by dancing around him ['by heavy walking/dancing' unconfirmed].

••• Cf. ðixí. 

nààxô (variant: naaxô). V [reg., _nààxô] [nàà- INSTR + xô] (trans.) break by foot, break with the foot (FH:4/16/96/ok; 04/07/95/LS/pc: nààãô). níitahpa nâãe nààxô he broke the pond ice (FH/09/22/01/pc/prod).

 •• LFD 117–18: nàxô <noæ-xoæ´> to hurt oneself [expected Mod. Os. gloss 'to break with the foot'). anâxò <a-noæ´-xoæ> I hurt myself by breaking the board in the floor [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'I broke it with my foot']. ðanâxò <tha-noæ´-xoæ> you hurt yourself by breaking the board in the floor [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'you broke it with your foot']. ànâxò pe <oæ-noæ´-xoæ i> we hurt ourselves by breaking the board in the floor [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'we broke it with our feet'].

nààëî (variant: nààëí). V [reg., _nààëî] (intr.) stand, be standing. hìì nààëî he stood there (FH:prod). çée nààëî! wait! (lit., 'there where you are, stand!'). hìì nâàëì ðìká, màðí don't just stand there, get going (FH:prod). kahíkenâàëì standing chief (personal name) (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). kootáìke nààëî go stand over there (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.126). kootáha nààëî stand farther over (FH). hkáwa akxa nààëî akxai that horse is standing there. anâàëi çô àkxâhe I'm still standing here (04/26/95/FH/pc). çéðò nààëî txa hú hce éa tell the person standing there to come here. • stand up, get up; terminate ongoing activity preparatory to departing. ëìkáëì apa nòhpéhi apai ànâàëì hta àkatxái the children are hungry so we're going to [get up to] leave (FH). nààëîe stand up (RBn10-5:JW). anâàëì àkxâhe I'm getting ready to leave (lit., 'I'm going to stand up') (04/26/95/FH/pc). àkále hta àkai éhtà ànâëì hta àkái we're going to leave (said after sitting and talking a while, to indicate that we're going leave now, spoken while still sitting, indicating that we are going to get up from our sitting position) (FH). háakò óØie àkôða tà àðíiçtà nai ehtà ànâàëìe what we had to talk about we finished so I'm going to get up (i.e., 'I'm going to go now') (04/26/95/FH/pc). anâàëi àkatkxai I'm leaving (FH). nààëî íkØucapé he tried to get up (RB: Coyote fable). • (come to a) stop. céãenii mâà nààëî the drum and arrow stop (RBn1022/JW&FW). wálì ohtáza tà nààëî che ðíità tôpape she was so pretty he stopped in his tracks to look at her (RBn17-p1;CQc; RBn1-MOJ/p40). àwâlòò nààëî apai we [two] never call people names (lit., 'our calling people names stopped', i.e., 'we have stopped calling people names') (FH:prod). • (trans.) stop, cause to stop (e.g., a motor or s.o. engaged in an activity), halt, detain s.o. who is passing by (03/14/95/MREI/pc; MREI: nààëî). wacØéðe ànâàëì we don't kill (lit., 'we stopped killing folks') (FH:prod).  

•• LFD 119: nàëì <noæ-zhiæ> to rise or stand. anâëì <a-noæ´-zhiæ> I rise. ðánàëì <tha´-noæzhiæ> you rise. ànâëì pe <oæ-noæ´-zhiæ i> we rise. nàëì oo! <noæ-zhiæ o-u> get up, arise! nàëîwaðe <Noæ-zhiæ´-wa-the> Causes-them-to-stand (personal name). nâëìëì <noæ´-zhiæ-zhiæ> repeatedly to stand, from a ritual. LFD 131: çénàëì o <she´-noæ-zhiæ o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] stand there a while.  

••• Cf. oðókinâàëì, okínààëì. 

nààëîle. V [reg.?, _nààëîle?] (trans.) stop (RBn1-40). nààëîla! you stop him or her! (RBn1-40; FH/09/23/01/pc).

nâce káaãe. V [sync. k>p, nâce _káaãe] (intr.) trench. nâce hpáaãe I'm trenching (around the teepee) (RBn12-09).

•• LFD 13: nâce <noæ´-dse> the back of the house, the walls or sides.

••• KS nâýe ke ogádà to peg the walls of a tent or tipi (JOD) (RR).

nâceaha (variant: nâceahe). N trench, small ditch around teepee for drainage (BE2-32; 04/25/95/PM/t124/pc:ok; 12/30/94/FH/pc:prod; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok).

nàðé (variants: nàà, naa). ADV a certain number or amount at a time, a certain number or amount per person (e.g., 'a bit at a time', 'two at a time', 'two each'). äóopa nàðe káaãe do or make a little at a time (FH/05/08/01:ok). ihtá na belongs to each one, one for each one (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

nâãe. N ice. nâãe ðilôëe chopped ice (RBn, MREI/01/11/83,FH:ok). nâãe toa ðuuzá! get some ice! (lit., 'take some ice!') (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). nâãe akxa táaskàpe the ice has melted (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc). nâãe átaa iced over, iced (e.g., referring to an iced road or river) (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc). nâãe ðaaxôke çò akxai híi ðiixôkape while he was chewing ice, he broke his tooth.

•• RB: <náh-xeh, núhæ-xeh> (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): náãe <náxªe> ice.

•• LFD 117: nâãe <noæ´-xe> ice. nâãe akxa táskà pi a <noæ´-xe a-ka da´-škoæ bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form: nàãe akxa táaskàpe] the ice has melted. nâãe ata <noæ´-xe a-da> iciness, icy.

nâãe kípçe. N ice cream (lit., 'ground up ice') (RB, unconfirmed).

•• RB: <núhæ-xeh kí-psheh> (02/13/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/17/95/LS/pc:uk).

••• Cf. pçé. 

nâãe paazénii. N ice cream (lit., 'ice milk') (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.71).

nâãehci. N [nâãe + hcí] refrigerator, icebox, cooler, ice chest (lit., 'ice house'). nâãehci obrúxpaðe hta mìkçé I'm going to take it out of the refrigerator (FH/09/23/01/pc).

nâãenii. N ice water (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.71).

nâãeooëú. N [nâãe + ooëú] refrigerator, icebox, cooler, ice chest. nâãe ooëú tôpa màðí go look in the icebox.

nâãeëì. N [nâãe + -ëì 'little'] sleet (lit., 'small ice') (03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok; FH:4/24/96/ok; MREI). nâãeëì húði akxái it's sleeting (RBn12-10). • V [uninfl.] (intr.) sleet. nâãeëì akxa it's sleeting (FH:okc).

nâhka. N back (of a human or animal's body) (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). nâhka aníe my back hurts

(01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). nâhka lúuëa wash your back [imperative]. nâhka àðúuëa! wash my back! (BE2.6). nâhka wíhta áalìì hta wikíkØì hta mìkçe áapa I'll carry you on my back, he said (t24ap4/num24CQ25; 04/11/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 114: nâhka <noæ´-Ða> the back, the part of the body from the shoulders to the hips.

nâhkai (variant: nâhkale). N saddle (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.116; 03/23/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• RB: <nóæ-kai>.

•• LFD 114: nàhkale <noæ-Ða-gthe> a saddle (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 115: nâhkale kaãe <noæ´-Ða-gthe ga-xe> a saddler. nâhkale, kaãe <noæ´-Ða-gthe, ga-xe> a saddle, to make, or the art of making: one skilled in making saddles (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok: nâhkale káaãe). nâhkalehpa <noæ´-Ðagthe-¼a> [expected Mod. Os. form: nâhkale hpá] saddle head, the pommel.

nàhkówì, nàhkùî (variants of nahkòî).

nâhtà. ADV what if, what would you think if. nâhtà pá húðe tà mààçäé? what if it snows in summer? (lit., 'what if when it snows it is warm weather?') (04/14/95/FH/pc).

nàka (variant: nàkà). ADV maybe (DN:FH, unconfirmed). kasîì nàkà pçí hta mìkçé maybe I'll go tomorrow. nàka nâàke hta akxa maybe he'll run.

nàkxáçe (variants: nàkxâçe, nakxâçe, nakxáçe). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 2nd pl. (i.e., pl. addressee) sitting subject.
