[Often heard in the greeting to the participants and the audience at the ilôòçka (war dance) gathering, as most are seated.] xóhka nàkxâçe you singers (singers are addressed as a group in this manner by a person making a speech at the war dances) (03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.121). hátxàta waðákiçtòpaapi ðachí hta nàkxáaçe? when are you all going to come see us? íiðai ðí opxái nàkxâçe those of you who can understand (said when addressing a crowd, some of whom do not understand Osage) (RB: 04/06/95/FH/pc:okc). ëìkáëì nakxâçe, wéewina akxâhe, ilôìhpa waachí çtôpape I want to thank you children for watching my son (lit., 'you children sitting here, I stand here grateful, you watched my eldest son dance').

•• LFD 115: nâhkaçe <noæ´-Ða-she> [should be nâkxaçe <noæ´-ka-she>] you who are sitting there.  

nàkØô (variants: nòkØô, nààkØô). V [reg., _nàkØô] (trans.) hear, hear about, understand (RBn105:MOJ/79). ánàkØò, anâkØò I heard it. ðánàkØò, ðanâkØò you heard it. ànâkØòpé we heard it. áanàkØò 

I heard it myself (01/04/95/FH/pc). áanàkØò I hear it [with contrastive emphasis on "I"] (05/01/95/LS/pc). ðanâkØò? have you heard about it? did you hear about it? (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok). waachí pa ðánàkØò? do you hear the dances? did you hear about the dances? (05/01/95/LS/pc). Tony ðanâkØò? did you hear about Tony? (01/04/95/FH/pc; 05/01/95/LS/pc:ok). íe àðánàkØò çkôçta ìké paaçé àëi iðáe àtxàhé you all don't want to hear me talk, but I'm talking (RBn10-16).

•• LFD 115: nàkØô <noæ-Ð'oæ´> to hear. anâkØò <a-noæ´-Ð'oæ> I hear. ðanâkØò <tha-noæ´-Ð'oæ> you hear. ànàhkò pe <oæ-noæ´-Ðoæ i> [presumably a typographical error for ànâkØò pe <oæ-noæ´-Ð'oæ i>] we hear.  

••• Cf. ánàkØò, ónàkØò. 

nàlôòha (variant: nalôòha). ADJ, V [reg., _nàlôòha] (intr.) (be) sneaky, hide, be sly, secretly scheme against s.o., go behind s.o.'s back, be cunning (as Coyote is in stories); (trans.) hide, conceal. táatà wíbruwì, ánàlòòha I bought something for you and I've hidden it (FH). ðánàlòòha did you hide it? (FH). ðé çômhìkasi akxa nàlôòhape this coyote was sneaky (RBn16-02). oçpéëì nàlôòha apái ðée apa ahú apai óceçtàpe they're hiding their things because the people coming are snoops. ânàlòòhape we hid it (FH). mâzeska ðíhta nàlôòha hide your money (RBn10-2; BE2.124; 03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). • ADV on the sly, covertly.

•• LFD 119: nàlôha <noæ-xthoæ´-ha> underhand, privacy, retirement, secrecy. nàlôha owahkie <noæ-xthoæ´-ha u-wa-Ði-e> I am underhanded [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'I spoke to him on the sly']. nàlôha oðahkie <noæ-xthoæ´-ha u-tha-Ði-e> you are underhanded [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'you spoke to him on the sly']. nàlôha owahkie hkòbra ha <noæ-xthoæ´-ha u-wa-Ði-e Ðoæ-btha ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I want a private consultation with him. nàlòha wanàkØò <noæ-xthoæ´-ha wa-noæ-Ð'oæ> an eavesdropper.

nàlôòha átòpe. VP [sync. fortisizing stop stem, nàlôòha á_tòpe] (trans., intr.) conduct espionage, spy, have under surveillance (lit., 'on the sly, watch over').

•• LFD 119: nàlôha atòpe <noæ-xthoæ´-ha a-doæ-be> espionage.

nàlôòha wanâkØò. VP [reg., nàlôòha wa_nâkØò] [nàlôòha + wa- VAL + nàkØô] eavesdrop (lit., 'listen to things on the sly').

nàlôòhkile. N [presumably contains nàlôòha and hkik- REFL] hidden item, hiding place, cache. súhkahtâà mîka hcí nàlôòhkile ðáalì káaãe che oëoáhkiëi ðe áape turkey hen was proud because she could hide her nest so well (RBn19-05).

nànà (variant: nana). ITERATIVE MARKER [reduplicated form of nà 'repeatedly'] on and on, continually, keep on with the action of the verb. [Placed after verbs. May be pronounced with very relaxed vowels, as (nœnœ).] kaakô çô ðaaçé, ðáalòçäì naná keep on until you get drunk (RBn2-MOJ/p28).

nàniókiooëu (variant of nànìôkuëu).

nànióoëuhaa (variant of nànúhuooëúhaa).

nàníòpaëi (variant of nànîòpaëì).

nànìôkuëu (variant: nàniókiooëu) N [nànúhu + ó- LOC + kik- SUU + ooëú) tobacco pouch, tobacco bag

(a long bag for carrying or storing tobacco, usually beaded) (04/07/95/PM/pc:okc; 03/22/95/FH/pc; 03/22/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.142). • giveaway, the event of giving items away (archaic) (RB).

nànìóküëu it's giveaway time (FH:prod).

•• RB: <nah-nyóæ-kyu-zhu>.

nànîòpa. N pipe, smoke.

•• LFD 16: nâniòpa <noæ´-ni-oæ- ba> a pipe. nànîòpa káaãe. VP make a smoke, roll a cigarette (04/25/95/PM/pc:prod). nànîopa káaãe hkôbra I want to make a smoke, as in a peyote meeting (PM:pc).  

nànìôpa olîì. N tobacco boss (who sits to the left of the roadman in a peyote meeting).

(04/07/95/PM/pc:ok; RB).

•• RB: <nah-ni-óm-pah-o-líæ>.

nànîòpaëì (variant: nàníòpaëi). N [nànîòpa + -ëì 'little'] cigarette (lit., 'little pipe' or 'little tobacco') (4/17/96/FH). nàníòpaëì káaãe hkôbra mìkçé I want to make a cigarette (as at a peyote meeting, for prayer). nàníòpaëi hpáaãe hkôbra mìkçé I want to make a cigarette (as at a peyote meeting, for

prayer) (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.19).

•• LFD 116 (unconfirmed): nàníòpaëìka <noæ-ni´-oæ-ba-zhiæ-ga> a little sacred pipe, a symbol of the Wa-zha´-zhe gens.

nànúhu. N tobacco.

•• RB: <nah-niú-hu, nah-nú-hu> (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.142).

•• LFD 115: nàníhi <noæ-ni´-hi> tobacco, white man's tobacco, trade tobacco, archaic Osage name for plants used for smoking (03/22/95/FH/pc: not archaic for 'tobacco').

nànúhu íkiahì. N plant to mix with tobacco (a small, sweet-smelling plant with yellow flowers that is mixed with tobacco; apparently lit., 'mix into tobacco') (RBn10-18, unconfirmed).

••• KS ígahi ~ íigahi mix together, as tobacco and sumac (RR).

nànúhuooëúhaa (variant: nànióoëuhaa). N [nànúhu + ooëú + háa] tobacco bag (lit., 'skin for putting tobacco inside') (03/22/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 116: nànúëiha <noæ-nu´-zhi-ha> a tobacco pouch.

nàpe (variant: nòpe). ITERATIVE MARKER [nà 'habitually' + api + ðe 'declarative'] always did, used to do; usually, normally. [Used after verbs with 1st pl., 2nd pl., and 3rd person (sg. or pl.) subjects, especially in generic statements.] kóoci ékie nàpé that's what they used to say [contrasts with kóoci ékiape 'they said that a long time ago'] (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). iinâ akxa ëìkáëì hóolà íëoçi nàpe mother used to tell the children not to go fishing (FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). kasîexcì waëîka apa hóohtà nàpé the birds sing early in the morning (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). pée tà nuuëú nàpé when it becomes spring, it usually rains (RBn3-52). hkiistómàì háanà ooëú nàpe? how many councilmen do they usually put in? níi akxa opØâðe nàpé water steams (MSB 2-2-670).

nàsâsàwa. V [ reg.?, _nàsâsàwa?] (trans.) clap (e.g., the hands). íixa apa çáake nasâsàwa çkí apai they laughed and clapped their hands (RBn10-2:MOJ/79, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 31: sòsô <šoæ-šoæ´> to tremble. ðasôsò <tha-šoæ-šoæ´> you tremble.

nâçki (variant: náçki). ADV [na 'only' + çki] only, just, even only, merely, solely. hôòpa wîxci nâçki níhkaçi aní hkôbra I want to live [just] one day at a time (RBn10-21). hôòpa nâçki ðáalì only one good day (RBn10-21, gloss by CQ). howâìki ðòòpá ðáabrì náçki ecíe akxa tà, wíe ée brî hta mìkçé na ée eçie wherever only just two or three are, I will always be there, you said (from the Bible, Matthew 18:20; FH:prayer).  

nâwàzi (variant: náwaze). V [reg., _nâwàzi] (trans.) be jealous about s.o. in regard to the opposite sex

(the jealous person is usually female) (04/14/95/FH/pc:okc). ánawazé I'm jealous (about him) (BE2.72; HH/pc; 04/14/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p22). ânàwazé apa they're jealous of me [PM: a man speaking of a woman's or women's jealousy] (PM/96b; 02/13/95/FH/pc:okc). ânawazé akxai she's jealous of me (RBn12-10). ánawazí I'm jealous of [about] him (said by a woman whose boyfriend is talking to another woman). • N woman who is jealous (e.g., about her spouse or boyfriend) (LH; 02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• RB: <náh-wah-zi> (04/14/95/FH/pc:okc).  

•• LFD 117: nâwàzi <noæ´-woæ-ši> jealousy by a woman. anâwàzi he <a-noæ´-woæ-ši he> I am jealous. ðanâwàzi he <tha-noæ´-woæ-ši he> you are jealous.

ni (variant of ði IMPERATIVE MARKER).

ni (variant of ðíe 'you').

ní (variant: níe). V [reg., _ní] (intr.) be well or all right, be in good health (FH/09/25/01/prod). aní, aníe, anî I'm well. ðaní, ðaníe you're well. àníe we're well. ní he's well (01/06/95/FH/pc). aníe I'm well (FH/09/25/01/prod). ðaníe? are you well? (FH/09/25/01/prod). ní akxai he's well (FH/09/25/01/prod). • live, be alive, be living. wawépahò aní çô àhé I'm a witness and I'm still living (RBnot 5/8/79/p2). hôòpa wîxci nâçki níhkaçi aní hkôbra I want to live one day at a time (RBn10-21). aníe mìkçé I'm alive (FH 01/06/95/pc:prod). níe mìkçe I'm living, I'm alive (MREI/num94; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ma). ní aëi akxai he's not living, he's not alive (RBn12-10/MJ). íkaske níe he's out of breath, I'm choking (as when having a heart attack) (FH). ní akxai he's alive. ní çô ðe? is he living still? (RBn12-10/MJ). ní çô apai he's still living (RBn12-10/MJ). àníe àkatxa we're all living (MREI/6/7/94/num94; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). hâàpa ihtôì ókaçeìke nâace nààëî káakò ðaníhkaçika [ð]aní àkôða in future days, standing with untroubled hearts is how we want you to live.

•• LFD 105: ni <ni> to exist, to live. aníe ðo <a-ni´e tho> [expected Mod. Os. form; aní or aníe; ðo is not used in Mod. Os.] I live. ðaní e ðo <tha-ni´ e tho> [expected Mod. Os. form ðaní or ðaníe] you live. àní pi a ðo <oæ-ni´ bi a tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: àní pe] we live.

••• Cf. ðî, ónie.

ní (variant of nî 'you are').

níaòhta záani (variant of níòhta záani?).

níaëì. ADJ, N quiet (RBn10-5:MOJ/79). ••• KS niâëi silent, quiet, still (stative) (RR).

níðe. V [reg.?, ní_ðe?] [ní 'live' + ðe CAU] (trans.) allow to live. •• LFD 110: níðe <ni´-the> to permit to live. "When captives are brought in, it is the ¾si-zhu Washta-ge gens that makes the decision as to which one may live." ••• Cf. toníðe, waníðe. 

níðe. V [reg., ní_ðe] (trans.) give away, divest oneself of. táatà ðáalì toa níða! give some good things away! haxî ðé niáðe atxàhé I'm giving this blanket away (RBnotes). ékene akxa hkáwa ëúuce níðape Aiken gave the red horse away (words to "Aiken song") (BE2.55; 01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). haxî ðéche ée ðe níðape these are the blankets that they gave away. wihtáeëì akxa ékipçe kôða akxa, hôòpa ðé wéeðina akxai, mâzeskaëì níðe kôða akxa Sister wants me to say something, she's grateful today and wants to give away a little money (RBn23-17). • be out of, be lacking. níi níðe akxai he's out of water (FH:prod). ónòbre níðe akxai he's out of food (FH:prod). mâzeska àníðe we [two] are out of money (FH:prod). •• LFD 110: níðe <ni´-the> to exterminate, to destroy utterly, annihilate. níðe <ni´-the> to spend money, to give away one's own possessions, till all are gone. níakiðe <ni´-a-gi-the> [expected Mod. Os. form: niáðe] I spend. níðakiðe <ni´-tha-gi-the> [expected Mod. Os. form: niðáðe] you spend. níàkiða pe <ni´-oæ-gi-tha i> [expected Mod. Os. form: àníðape] we spend.  ••• Cf. waníðe. 

níe. V [reg./stat., _níe (reg. for 1st sg. subject, reg. or stat. for 1st pl. or 2nd person subject)] hurt, experience pain. aníe it hurts me, I feel pain. ðiníe, ðaníe it hurts you, you feel pain. àníe [expected 1st pl. form: àníe or waníe] it hurts us, we feel pain. ëeká aníe my leg hurts (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). çáake aníe my hand hurts (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; MREI/6/7/94/num94). aníe it hurts me. çåpe aníe my stomach hurts (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.70). wéehli aníe my head aches (RBn3-39). nààãúce aníe I have an earache. tóoce àníe I have a sore throat [the pronominal prefix form à- in this example is probably not the stative prefix, but rather is due to leftward spread of nasality to a-] (FH/t116b). tóoce ðiníe? do you have a sore throat? (FH/t116b). táatà ðiníe? what hurts you? (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). çáake ðaníe your hand hurts (MREI/6/7/94/num94).  táatà ðiníe? what was hurting you? (RBn3-16). wéehli ðiníe, wéehli ðaníe your head aches. hcéka ðiníe che ákòze hta akxa ska I guess he will examine you now (lit., 'just now, he will examine your hurting, it seems') (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.42). hówaìki ðiníe? where do you hurt? (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). waníe ðìkçí aape they said she's in labor (FH/pc). íkaske níe he's out of breath, choking (as when having a heart attack) (FH). •• LFD 107: níe <ni´-e> an ache. wéðili ànie ha <we´-thi-xthi oæ-ni-e ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: wéeli aníe; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] my head aches. wéðili ðinie ha <we´thi-xthi thi-ni-e ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: wéeli ðiníe; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] your head aches. àníe <oæ-ni´-e> I have pain. ðinie <thi-ni-e> you have pain. LFD 72: íha che àníe ha <i´-ha te oæ-ni´-e ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: íhaa che aníe; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] my mouth is sore. LFD 228: ëóika nie <zhu´-ga ni-e> ache; pain in any part of the body. ëóika anie <zhu´-i-ga a-ni-e> I have a pain. ëóika ðinie <zhu´-i-ga thi-ni-e> you have a pain. ••• Cf. waníe. 

níe (variant of ní 'be well').

níe (variant of nî 'you are').

níhce (variant: níhci). V [stat. ní_hce] (intr.) be cold, feel cold (animate subject). [Replacement of final e by a before the completed action marker (a)pi and the negative marker (a)ëí is especially variable with this verb.] níàhce I'm cold (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok). níðihce you're cold (BE2.21). níhce çki akxai he was cold, too (RBn16-02). níàhtamaëíe I'm not cold (1-20-83-p2). níhcipe he's cold (1-20-83-p2).  

níhka. N man, person. níhka wì achípe a man came (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). níhkaçie wî cØéðape they killed a man (RBn10-20). níhkaçi pa wátòpa look after those men. • husband. [Either alienable possessive pronouns or inalienable possessive prefixes are used for 2nd and 3rd person possessor; only alienable pronouns are used for 1st person possessor (**winíhka for 'my husband' does not exist).] níhka my husband. níhka wíhta my husband (04/27/95/FH/pc; 02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.84). níhka ðíhta your husband [níhka ðíhta is preferred over ðiníhka (FH)] (04/27/95/FH/pc). níhka íhta her husband. •• LFD 107: níhka <ni´-Ða> man. LFD 109: níhkaðòpa <Ni´-Ða-thoæ-ba> Two-men (personal name) [níhka 'man' + ðòòpá 'two'].  ••• Cf. iiníhka, níhkaçie.

níhka sápe. N black person, African American (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.9). •• LFD 107: nihká sape <ni-Ða´ ša-be> negro. ••• Cf. sáeëì.

níhka watâìke. N Gentle Man (personal name) [Antoine Pryor's name] (FH). •• LFD 186: watáìka <wa-da´-iæ-ga> a lover of jests, a joker, one who is fond of fun or a frolic.

níhka waëîhtàà. ADJ, N determined, strong-willed (person) (RBn1-29). •• LFD 21: waëî htàka <wa-zhiæ´- ¾oæ-ga> great courage, very brave. ••• KS waëî lâàye brave(?) (RR).

níhka ëúuce. N Indian, Indians (lit., 'red man', 'red people') (BE2.71). •• LFD 109: níhka ëuce <Ni´-Ða zhu-dse> Red man, Indian.

níhkahkipánà. N [níhka + hkipánà] Running Man (personal name) [Name of the father of Weuãaake, who was the father of John Oberly; Níhkahkipánà was Frances Holding's paternal great-grandfather (FH:pc).]

nihkáçi (variant of ínihkaçie).

nihkáçi, níhkaçi (variants of níhkaçie).  

níhkaçi íkòske. N scarecrow (lit., 'similar to a person').

níhkaçie (variant: níhkaçi). N human, person, individual, man (FH/09/22/01/pc:prod). waëáëe níhkaçi an Osage person. níhkaçíe wì achípe a person came (01/06/95/FH/pc). hôòpa wîxci nâçki níhkaçi mî hkôbra I want to live [be a human] one day at a time (RBn10-21). • persons, people. níhkaçie ànâsi ecíke there are people around that don't like me. níhkaçíe achípe some people came (01/06/95/FH/pc:okl 03/07/95/PM/pc: same as níhka apa ahí). níhkaçika äóopaëì just a few people (BE2.102). ••• Cf. níhka. níhkaçika. N the people, a people (03/07/95/PM/pc:ok). níhkaçika apa waxpáðìpe the people are poverty stricken (FH/pc). •• LFD 108: nihkaçika ekò <ni-Ða-shi-ga e-goæ> human, mankind. níhkaçika <ni´-Ða-shi-ga> a people, a ritual term. níhkaçika hu pi a <ni´-Ða-shi-ga hiu bi a> many people.

níhkaçika. V [reg., _níhkaçika] (intr.) live, exist. ðaníhkaçika you're living. aníhkaçika I'm living. hâàpa ihtôì ókaçeìke nâace nààëî káakò ðaníhkaçika (ð)aní àkôða in future days, standing with untroubled hearts is how we want you to live (RB). môëò ðáalì ìksé ðaníhkaçika nìkçé, éebré hta mìkçé you'll be living in heaven, I'll be thinking. hôòpa húu aníhkaçie hkôbra I want to live a long time (RBn1210/MJ). •• LFD 13: aníhkaçika <a-ni´Ða-shi-ga> I am a person having that power (an expression from a ritual) ['having that power' unconfirmed] .  

níhkaçika ochí. N country (lit., 'people plentiful'). •• LFD 108 (unconfirmed): níhkaçika ohci <ni´-Ða-shi-ga u-¾si> a village or country full of people, a populous country.

níhkaçikaëì. N little people (small beings in Osage mythology) (PM).

níi (variant: nîì). N water, any fluid, liquid (03/16/95/JS/pc:prod; BE2.151). níi che huukáaãa pass the water (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok). nâãe níi ice water (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). níi ápçe wákØue pass the water around. níi níni cold water (HH;t15a-p1). •• LFD 105: ni <ni> water, river, rivulet, creek. ••• OM same as Osage (LFD 105).

níi ápuãe. N beer (lit., 'boiling or foaming water or liquid') (archaic) (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.10).

níi cØáaðe. N vinegar (lit., 'sour water') (FH). •• LFD 110: nícØaðe <ni´-ts'a-the> sour water, vinegar.

níi htâka (variant: níi htâà). N Mississippi River (lit., 'big water'), ocean, sea. níi htâà áðuuhta brée hta mìkçé I'm going to go across the ocean (FH/04/08/01/pc).

níi wécØa. N water moccasin (RBn HW13). •• LFD 215 (unconfirmed): wécØa niki <we´-¾s'a ni-gi> water snake, water moccasin.

niiámàðì. N [níi + ámàðì] water-strider bug. niiámàsa, niiámàse (variants of níimàse).

níiðaahtà (variant: níiiðaahtà). N [níi + í- LOC + ðaahtâ] dipper, ladle (lit., 'with which to drink water') (T14b-p1; 04/07/95/LS/pc:ok). ••• Cf. íniiðaahtà.

niiháa. N [níi + háa] algae (lit., 'water's skin/surface'); surface of water (perhaps 'superficial appearance of a body of water'). niiháa htóho ékò blue (as distinct from green) (RB, unconfirmed; 01/07/95/FH/pc:uk). [The proper meaning of this term is perhaps 'water's surface' rather than 'algae'; that is implied by the fact that niiháa htóhoekò means 'blue' rather than 'green'.] •• LFD 107: níha <ni´-ha> algae, a green, red, and brown plant found in both sea and fresh water, commonly called kelp or seaweed.

niiháa htóhoékò. ADJP [niiháa + htóho + ékò] blue (as distinct from green) (lit., 'green/blue like the surface of water') (RB, unconfirmed; 01/07/95/FH/pc:uk).  

niikáapxohke. N [níi + kaapxóhke] soda pop, soft drink (lit., 'liquid explodes') (BE2.106).

niikáapxokeooëú. N [niikáapxohke + ooëú] can, bottle, or other container for soda pop. niikáapxokeooëu çtáaçtà tà, ðibrúuska when you are through with the pop can, wad it up (02/24/95/FH/pc). ••• Cf. mâzeskaooëú. 

níimàse (variants: niiámàse, niiámàsa). ADV abroad, overseas. kahíke mâàhihtà éðòòpa níimàse aðáaapi áape the chief and superintendent went abroad (lit., 'chief, superintendent, both abroad went, they said') (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). Sara akxa niiámàsa ahípe Sara went abroad (03/02/95/FH/pc). • N ocean.

niiámàsa aðáapi áape they went across the water (the ocean) (03/02/95/FH/pc; BE2.97). •• RB: <ní-moæ-síæ-tah>.

níini N [níi + níni] spring, well (sources of water) (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok). •• LFD 107: niní <ni-hni´> water cold, a spring or well.

niióhkiacØì. N [níi + hkik- REFL + okácØì] mirror (lit., 'peer at oneself in the water') (PM) (BE2.88; 03/01/95/FH/pc). •• RB: <níu-kiah-ts'íæ>. •• LFD 110: nióhkilacØì <ni-u´Ði-gtha-¾s'iæ> a mirror.  LFD 168: okáhàpa nuhkila sì <u-ga´ hoæba niu-Ði-gtha šiæ> a looking-glass.  

níiooëú. N [níi + ooëú] pitcher (lit., 'pour water into it') (t14b-p1; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

niióço. N Neosho (town in Oklahoma) (FH). [Possibly from níi + ooëú 'pour water into it', i.e., 'main river'.]

níipxaðe. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) drown. •• LFD 109: nihpáhaiðe <ni-¼a´-ha-i-the> [expected Mod. Os. form: niipxáðe or níipxaðe] drown (to), drowned. nihpáhaibre <ni-pa´-ha i-bthe> I drowned. nihpáha àka i aðápe <ni-pa´-ha oæ-ga i atha i> we drowned. [LF forms all unconfirmed; all should have -pxa.]

níiskue (variants: niiskúðe, níiskuðe, níisku) N [níi + skúðe] salt (lit., 'sweet water'). níiskueooëú salt shaker (lit., 'put salt in it') (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.116; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). •• RB: <ní-skyu-theh>. •• LFD 105: niskíðe saki <ni-ški´-the ša-gi> hard salt, rock (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). niskíðe <niški´-the> salt (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). "The Osage knew salt and the use of it long before the coming of the white man. They knew the salt springs and the places where rock salt could be obtained."

níiskueooëú. N [níiskue + ooëú] salt shaker.

níiçoce. N [níi + çóce] drizzle, mist, gray rain, haze (FH: prod).

níita (variant: níità). N flooding water, running water that is flooding (as over a spillway). níitâ akxái water is running over (e.g., a spillway) (FH). • elephant (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod). •• LFD 106: níta <ni´-da> elephant. "The bones of great animals were frequently found in banks by . . . the Osage, which they indiscriminately called by this name. When they saw the elephant in a circus they applied this name to it."

niitáahpa (variant: níi táahpa). N pond (lit., 'round water'). [Takes 'sitting' positional article ìkçé.] níi táahpa ìkçí ëìka nôòðe ðáalì, ecíe ska ààëì àkátxa the pond is a good place to raise children, we think it's there (RBn19-04; CQ:okc; BE2.105; 03/10/95/FH/pc:ok). •• RB: <ní-tah´-pah>. •• LFD 106: nítahpa <ni´-da-pa> round water, a pond.

níità (variant of níita).

níixoce. N ashes (BE2.4; 01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). •• LFD 111: nixóce <ni-xo´-dse> ashes.  ••• Cf. xóce. 

níixoce weooëu. N [níixoce + wa- VAL + í- LOC + ooëú] flask for gunpowder. •• LFD 111: nixóce weoëi <ni-xo´-dse we-u-zhi> flask, powder flask.

niixócooëu. N [níixoce + óoëu] ashtray (FH).

níiëu (variants: núuëu, niiëú, nuuëú). V [uninfl.] (trans., intr.) rain (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok). níiëu akxa it is raining (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). ìlôaëe kaðó çôke niiëú akxai it's raining cats and dogs (RBn). níiëuëi akxa it's not raining (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). níiëu ðiiçtâ akxa it's stopped raining (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). kasîe níiëu hta akxa tomorrow it will rain (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). níiëu ðààché akxa it looks like rain. pée tà nuuëú çtà in the spring, it rains a lot (03/14/95/FH/okc; BE2.126; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). • N rain.

níiëu oxáke. N toad (FH:5/01/96/tape:ok).

niiëú xóce. N drizzle, mist (lit., 'gray rain') (FH:prod). •• LFD 111: niëú xoce <ni-zhiu´ xo-dse> gray rain, drizzle (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

níiëu xóhtà. N drizzle, mist, fine raindrops (lit., 'small rain') (FH).

níiëue (variant of níiëuuce).

níiëue hkâàce (variants: núuëue hkâàce, níiëuuce hkâàce) (03/10/95/FH/pc:ok). N plum (lit., 'river apple') (BE2.105).

•• LFD 111: níëuce hkàce <ni´-zhu-dse Ðoæ-dse> the sand plum.

niiëúpa. N [níiëu + pá] sleet (lit., 'rainy snow').

•• LFD 111 (unconfirmed): niëú pa itape <ni-zhiu´ ba i-da-be> sleet, rain and snow mixed.

níiëuuce (variant: níiëue). N [níi + ëúuce] river (lit., 'red water').

níiëuuce hkâàce (variant of níiëue hkâàce).

níiëuëî. N [níiëu + -ëì 'little'] a rain shower (lit., 'small rain').

•• LFD 111: niëú ëìka <ni-zhiu´ zhiæ-ga> a small rain, a shower.

niiëúëu (variant: nuuëúëue). N [reduplicated form of níiëu] light rain, sprinkle (FH/06/27/01/pc).

nílòze. ADJ scrambled. hpáata nilôze bráache hta mìkçé I'm going to eat scrambled eggs (FH:4/24/96/tape:prod).

níni. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) cold (used for inanimates only), cool to the touch, cool, as weather (RB). nínie it's cold (BE2.21; 01/19/95/FH/pc:uk, unconfirmed). htóoëu níni wì a cold meat pie (FH). htóoëu akxa níni akxai the meat pie is cold (FH/07/21/95:prod; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). níi níni cold water (HH;t15a-p1). níni mâàãe ðéche, níni ahí akxa this weather is cold, it's cold now (lit., 'it's cold, this weather, cold has arrived here') (PM071494). mâàãe níni ahí akxa it's cold here (lit., 'cold weather has arrived here') (PM). • N cool weather.

••• Cf. níwahce. 

níòhta. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) be frustrated (?), become frustrated (?). [This form was recorded on an early tape (speaker: Henry Pratt, whose Indian name was Nôòhpewaðe or Nonpewalla) but is unfamiliar to three Mod. Os. speakers. Probably it is influenced by Omaha.]

•• LFD 111 (unconfirmed): ni óhta ðì <ni u´-¾a thiæ> shall become exhausted (from a ritual).

••• QU oníòkdázi breathe (RR).

níòhta záani (variant: níaòhta záani?). N world, universe, all the universe, all the world (RBn1-MOJ/p13, unconfirmed) [Rejected by some (03/24/95/PM/pc:no), but accepted by others as a borrowing from

Omaha, according to HH (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok).]

•• RB: <ni-aoæ-tah záh-ni> (BE2.1610).

•• LFD 109: niô <ni-oæ´> breath. niô akxa <ni-oæ´ a-ka> he breathes.

níòhta ëîka. N island (WHM981022, unconfirmed).

níòpapa (variants: níòpapai, nìôpapai). N lightning (RB; 02/15/95 /FH; HH/pc).

níwahce [wa- VAL + níhce]. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) cold (an impersonal weather expression, not used for people). wáli níwahci akxái it's very cold weather (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 111: níwahce <ni´-wa-tse> it is cold. níwahce ikiha <ni´-wa-tse i-gi-ha> cold, rigors of the winter weather, severity of the weather.

níwahcekçi htáha (variant: níwahcikçi ehtáha). ADV, N [níwahce + kçi + htáha/éhtaha] north (lit., 'in the direction of the cold', 'toward the cold') (BE2.94; 03/01/95/FH/pc:okc).

nì (variant of ði IMPERATIVE MARKER).

nî (variants: nîe, níe, ní). V [2nd person form of ðî] (intr.) you are/were, you are/were a certain way or a certain thing, you live(d) or exist(ed) as, you are/were characterized by a quality. waëáëe nîpe you [who are] Osages. wahkôtaki nî áapie [expected Mod. Os. ending: áape] they said you were a doctor (BE2.33). ðóðo nî you're greasy. çcéce nî you're tall. äáahpa nîe you're short (FH). wascúuce nîe you're late! (you have arrived late!) (FH:08/22/96). ðíe nâàke kØâsaaki níe you're a fast runner

(FH/pc:prod orig). waðíðihta ði nîe it's your work (lit., 'you are characterized by your work') (RBn23-16). wawéeðe hôòëì nì you have bad eyesight. wascúuce nîe you're late! (you've arrived late; you're always late) (FH:08/22/96). hâàpa záani wapúçtaha nîe? were you ironing iron all day? (FH:prod). iiscéwai níe you're being mischievous, you're being awful (FH/06/28/01/pc). wahkôtaki nî áapie they said you were a doctor (BE2.33).

nî ké hta huðe. N north wind (RB, unconfirmed, RB2-94; 03/01/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/17/95/LS/pc:uk).

[Probably nii ìkçé ée hta húðe 'water (sitting or round), from there it comes'.]

•• RB:<níæ-kéh-táh-hu-theh>

•• LFD 109: nikçéci <ni´-ke-dsi> [expected Mod. Os. form: níi ìkçe ci] at the river or the water.

nîcekØa. N hearts (suit in a deck of cards) (RBn10-21/JW, unconfirmed).

nîe (variant of nî 'you are').

nîì (variant of ðaanîì).

nîì (variant of níi). 

nìkçé (variant: nìkçí). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 2nd sg. sitting subject. [nìkçé is sometimes used for 2nd sg. subjects that are not sitting; hence it can be regarded as the default 2nd sg. continuative marker.] waëáëe nìkçé you're Osage [to one sitting]. háakò nîkçe? how are you? (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). çée nìkçé óhkie ðì you're just sitting there, speak to me (RBn10-6:JW). hpa lîstowe nìkçé your nose is running (RBn12-08). ðúuhpeece wì açcî nìkçé? do you [sitting] have a match? kasîe ówò hta nìkçé? are you [sitting] going to be busy tomorrow? (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). táatà ðáalì waðakçíe hta ðíe nìkçi áape they said you're the one that's going to make everything good for us (RBn22-02). íe ohkípçe nìkçí áape they said you keep your word. • you are characterized by [the preceding expression, which may be a noun phrase]. ëéka xô nìkçé your legs are broken (lit., 'you are characterized by broken legs') (FH). haakô nìkçé? what's wrong with you? (HH).  

nìôpapai (variant of níòpapa). nò (variant of nà 'always').

nò ahí (variant of nôò ahí).

nôe (variant of nôò).

nòhòò. ADJ wayward (said of females only, not applicable to a male). wakØó nòhò woman of bad reputation, wayward woman (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

nôhòëì (variant: nôòëì). N [nôhò (Mod. Os. nôò) + -ëì 'little'] secret society (religious society of men who conducted ceremonies) (RB; 04/07/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:uk; BE2.117; 04/07/95/PM/pc:ok); young men (PM only) (04/07/95/PM/pc).

•• LFD 114: nôhòëìka <noæ´-hoæ-zhiæ-ga> old men (04/07/95/PM/pc:ok: nôhòëì or nôòëì). "The title of a man who has been initiated into the mysteries of the tribal rites."

nòhpéhi. V, ADJ, ADV [uninfl. or stat., nòhpé_hi; commonly appears uninflected and followed by a continuative, e.g., nòhpéhi àhé 'I'm hungry'] (intr.) (be) hungry (12/30/94/FH/pc). nòhpéhi àhé I'm hungry [moving]. nòhpéhi akxai he's hungry (FH; BE2.69). wasái akxa nòhpéhipe the bear was hungry (RBn16-02). hâàhkaëi nòhpéàhi no, I'm hungry (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok; t14b-p30).

•• LFD 116: nòhpéhi <noæ-¼e´-hi> to be hungry. nôhpeàhi <noæ´-¼e-oæ-hi> I am hungry.

nôhpeawahi pe <noæ´-¼e-a-wa-hi i> [expected Mod. Os. form: nòhpéwahipe] we are hungry.

nòhpéhicØe. V [reg.?, nòhpéhi_cØe?] [nòhpéhi + cØé] (intr.) be famished, starving, dying from hunger.

•• LFD 116: nòhpéhicØe <noæ-¼e´-hi-¾s'e> to be famished, to suffer for want of food, to starve. nòhpéhi ahce <noæ-¼e´-hi a-¾se> [expected Mod. Os. form: nòhpéhi acØé] I am famished. nòhpéhi àhca pe <noæ-¼e´-hi oæ-¾sa i> [expected Mod. Os. form: nòhpéhiàcØá pe] we are famished.

nòkØô (variant of nàkØô).

nôò (variant: nôe). V [reg., _nôò] (intr.) be old, grow up to adulthood, mature (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). anôò mìkçé, ánòò mìkçé I'm old. ðanôò nìkçé, ðánòò nìkçé you're old (MSB). nôò akxa/ónòò akxai she's old. ânòò àkatxái we [pl.] are old (FH). ónòò àðìksé we [two] are old. hcéka ðanôe ðe you are young (lit., 'recently you grew up/matured/became an adult') (FH). nôò kôða akxai he is old (lit., 'he wants to be old') (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.98). • N adulthood, grownups, adults

(03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). nôò ëáëe adult name. nôò apa eeçkítà íixa apa the grownups laughed, too (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). • old folks, elders in times past, old ones. nôò apa tàhí apai the old folks are well (FH/07/11/01/pc). • advanced age, old age.  

•• LFD 112: nò <noæ> to grow, to age, to mature. anô aða <a-noæ´ a-tha> [Mod. Os. omits aða] I have grown to maturity. ðanô aða <tha-noæ´ a-tha> [Mod. Os. omits aða] you have grown to maturity. ònò pi a ða pe <oæ-noæ bi a tha i> [expected Mod. Os. form: ànôòpe] we have grown to maturity. nò <noæ> an adult (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok: nôò). LFD 117: nò wálì <nonæ wa´-gthiæ> superannuate, very old age. LFD 114: nôhò <noæ´-hoæ> older person (03/02/95/FH/pc: not with h, should be nôò).

••• Cf. hcéka nôò, ónò. 

nôò ahí (variants: nò ahí, nòòhí). VP [sync. H-stem, nôò _(a)hí] grow up (lit., 'arrive at adulthood').

níhkaçika ð[e]ìkçe nôò ahípe the person [sitting] has grown to be an adult (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). nôò àhí tà when I get old (lit., 'when I arrive at old age') (RBn HW12).

•• LFD 112: çémi ëìka htà nò ahò <she´-mi zhiæ-ga ¾oæ noæ a-hoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: çîmìëì txà nôò ahípe] the girl has grown up. níhkaçika ðìkçe nò hiahò <ni´-Ða-shi-ga thiæ-ke noæ hia-hoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: níhkaçi ìkçé nôò ahípe] the person has grown to be an adult.

nôò ðiiçtâ. VP. grow up, reach maturity (lit., 'finish growing up') (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). George akxa nôe ðiiçtâ George has reached maturity (03/02/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 117: nò ðíçtà <noæ thi´-shtoæ> mature, maturity.

nôòðe. V [reg., nôò_ðe] [nôò + ðe CAU] (trans.) raise, rear, bring up. nôòðape they raised him. nôòwiðe I raised you (RBn; MREI/01/11/93?). níi táahpa ìkçí ëìka nôòðe ðáalì, ecíe ska ààëì àkátxa the pond is a good place to raise children, we think it's there (RBn19-04; CQ:okc). kaazâëi nôòàðape I was raised without being scolded (given favored treatment).

••• Cf. nôòwaapi. 

nòòhí (variant of nôò ahí).

nôòhiëi. ADJ [nôò + ahí + aëí NEG] immature.

•• LFD 114: nòhíëi <noæ-hi´-zhi> immature, not fully grown (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc).

nôòhpaëi. V [reg., nôò_hpaëi] [nôòhpe + aëí NEG] unafraid, fearless.

•• LFD 116: nôhpaëi <noæ´-¼a-zhi> not afraid, not afraid to face danger. nòáhpamàëi <noæ-a´-

¼a-moæ-zhi> I am not afraid. nòðáhpaëi <noæ-tha´-¼a-zhi> you are not afraid. nâàhpapaëi pe <noæ´-oæ-¼a-ba-zhi i> we are not afraid.

nôòhpe (variant: nôòhpi). V [reg., nôò_hpe] [w is sporadically heard in 1st sg. (nôòwahpe)] (intr.) be afraid or scared. nôòahpe I am afraid, I'm dreading to do that (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod). nôò[w]ahpe I'm afraid (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). nôòðahpe? are you afraid? (FH). nôòahpe ìké mìkçé I'm not afraid. nôòahpa màëí hkôbra I don't want to be afraid (FH:prod). nôòhpa! be careful! have a care! (an admonishment to someone who exaggerates when speaking, to tell the person to hold himself or herself back) (FH). nôòhpaëi [be] unafraid (12/30/94/FH/pc) (FH). nôòhpe ìkápi don't be afraid [pl. addressee] (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod). nòòhpé ìká! be unafraid! (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod;

FH/11/18/01/pc:prod; LR:6/25/01/pc). • (trans.) be afraid of, be scared of, fear (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok;

LR). nôòwihpe I'm afraid of you (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). nôòawahpe àhé I'm afraid of them (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). John akxa íe ekôìke étana nôòahpe John talks crazy so I'm afraid [of him]. nôòawahpe ðìké, ðiçkítà nôòwihpe ìké I'm not afraid of them or you either (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). howaðéeçki nôòwahpe ðìké I'm not afraid of anybody at all (RBnot-nd-1/p17; 12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). níhka ðe nôòðahpe? are you afraid of that man? (12/30/94/FH/pc/ok). çôke kçé nôòðahpe? are you afraid of that dog [lying down]? (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod orig; LR:6/25/01/pc). nôòðahpe? are you afraid of that? (e.g., indicating a dog nearby). htáace hpíiëi nôòhpi akxai he's afraid of storms (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod). nôòàwahpe we're afraid of them. íe hpíiëi nôòàhpape we're afraid of his bad words (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod).

•• LFD 116: nôhpe <noæ´-¼e> to be timid, to fear, to dread, to have a horror, to be afraid. nôahpe <noæ´-a-¼e> I am timid. nôðahpe <noæ´-tha-¼e> you are timid. nòâhpa pe <noæ-oæ´-¼a i> we are timid. nôhpe ðìke <noæ´-¼e thiæ-ge> fearless. nâhpe àðìke <noæ´-¼e oæ-thiæ-ge> I am fearless. nâhpe ðiðìke <noæ´-¼e thi-thiæ-ge> you are fearless. nôhpe ewaðe <noæ´-¼e e-wa-the> hideous, makes one afraid, scary. nôhpewaðe <Noæ´-¼e-wa-the> Fear-inspiring (personal name). nôhpewaðe <noæ´-¼e-wa-the> dangerous, formidable, hideous, horrible, terrible, frightful, dreadful.

••• WI: nààkéwe be afraid of, fear (KM).

••• Cf. íinòòhpe. 

nôòhpewaðe (variants: nôòhpewae, nôòhpewai, nôòhpewe). ADJ, V [reg.?, nôòhpewa_ðe?] [nôòhpe + wa- VAL + ðe CAU] (be) scary, make folks fearful (lit., 'make folks be afraid'). • N fearful thing, s.t.

to be afraid of (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok); Fearful One (personal name) [with variant pronunciation nôòhpewali, Henry Pratt's name].

nôòhpi (variant of nôòhpe).

nòòpé (variant: nôpe). N palm of the hand (BE2.101; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok); fist (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

['Hand' is an archaic meaning, not found in Mod. Os. (contrary to frequent claims).]

 •• LFD 112: nòpé <noæ-be´> the hand [unconfirmed; translation perhaps should be 'fist']. nòpé hi wihta nòpe hi ða pi ðà çki <noæ-be´ hi wi-¾a noæ-be hi tha bi thoæ shki> [expected Mod. Os. form: nòòpé wíhta nòòpé ihtáapi tà 'when my hands are their hands'] and when they make my hands their hands (04/17/95/LS/pc: fist; use as 'hand' archaic). .

nòòpé aski (variant: nòòpé askíke). N fist (BE2.48). [Possibly askíke implies a harder fist than aski (FH).] nòòpé askíke a very hard fist (01/26/95/FH/pc:prod orig).

•• LFD 112: nòpé ðiskike <noæ-be´ thi-ški-ge> hand folded, the fist.

nòòpióolà. N [nòòpé + oolâ] ring (for wearing on the finger) (lit., 'put it on the fist').

nôòwaapi. N [wa- 'us' + nôòðe + api] those who raised us, our forebears, all our parents, the old ones, somebody older than us (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). nôòwaapi apa the people that raised us (BE2.98).

nôòëì (variant of nôhòëì). nòpe (variant of nàpe).

nôpe (variant of nòòpé).

nôpxata (variant: nôpxahta). N clan subdivision (of the deer clan; meaning unknown, may refer to a deer's coloring). [According to Walter Maten, nóæ-pxah-tah is the clan to which the Pitts and

Whitehorn families belong (RB).]

••• OM nâpàta deer (possibly from 'thundering hooves'), name of a group (sub-gens) (RL/pc). cultural object, society

nòpØî (variant: nôpØì). V [reg.?, _nòpØî?] (trans.) wear around the neck (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). wapúuska nôpØì akxái she's wearing beads around her neck (RBn2-MOJ/p30; 02/27/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.92). wapúuçka tóe nôpØì akxai they've got beads around their neck (RBn12-08).

•• LFD 116: nôpØì <noæ´-¼'iæ> to wear around the neck. nôpØì kçiðe <noæ´-¼'iæ kshi-the> to cause one to wear something around the neck, as a necklace. LFD 96: mâzenòpØì <Moæ´-še-noæp'iæ> Iron-necklace (personal name).

••• Cf. wanôpØì. 

nuuëú, núuëu (variants of níiëú).

núuëue hkâàce (variant of níiëue hkâàce).

nuuëúëu. V [uninfl.] (intr.) sprinkle, rain lightly. kasîxci hóolà bree hkôbra àzi nuuëúëu akxai I wanted to go fishing this morning, but it was sprinkling (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod orig).

••• Cf. níiëúëu. 

nuuëúëue (variant of niiëúëu).

 

 

ó- (variant: o-). LOC place at which, culmination of (a certain action or state), wherein (a certain thing takes place). huukôða ðalípe nàà, ðe ówaachi ilôòçka many of you have come back to this place of the ilôòçka dances.  

oáëu (variant: wáëu). N [ó- + áëu] rack, barbecue rack (lit., 'place for setting things upon').

océ. V [reg., o_cé] (trans.) look for or search for s.t. or s.o. (for one's own purposes, not because it or he/she was previously lost) (2/22/95/FH). [Contrast okíce 'find again that which was lost'.] oáce, owáce I look for. oðáce you look for. àkóce we look for. otá look for it! haaská océ pçíe I went to look for a shirt (02/22/95/FH/pc). Bill owáce pçíe I went to look for Bill (02/22/95/FH/pc). owíce àhé I've been looking for you (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.81). táatà oðáce ðaìçé? what are you looking for? (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc, with ðaìçe; 02/22/95/FH/pc:prod). otá look for it (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). • hunt for, go hunting for (small game) (108-b/FH/9-13-94) sîka àkóce àkái hce let's go squirrel hunting [sg. addressee] (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). ëôhpazi mônòì océ pçíe I went to look for quail and prairie chickens (BE2.70; 02/22/95/FH/pc:ok).  

•• LFD 167: océ <u-dse´> to seek, to hunt for something missing. owáce <u-wa´-dse> I seek. oðáce <u-tha´-dse> you seek. àkóca pe <oæ-gu´-dsa i> we seek. LFD 180 (unconfirmed): ohcé <u-¾se´> [expected Mod. Os. form: océ] to hunt, to search for. owahcé <u-wa-¾se´> [expected

Mod. Os. form: owáce] I hunt. oðahcé <u-tha-¾se´> [expected Mod. Os. form: oðáce] you hunt.

àkóhca pe <oæ-gu´-¾sa i> [expected Mod. Os. form: àkóca pe] we hunt.

••• KS oýé look for (RR).

••• Cf. óce, océçtà, okíce, sìkóce. 

óce. V [uninfl. or reg., ó_ce] [wa- VAL + océ] (intr.) search, search for stuff, look for things. óce ðaìçé? 

are you looking for things?

••• Cf. óceçtà. 

océðe. V [reg.?, océ_ðe?] (intr. [perhaps trans.?]) build a fireplace or fire. súhka ooðáhà çkôçtapi tà, hpéece océðapi, oohôpi if you want to cook a chicken, build a fire and cook it (FH/09/21/01/pc). • N fireplace or fire for cooking or warming oneself, place to build a fire, stove.

•• LFD 167: océðe <u-dse´-the> hearth, fireplace, a place hollowed out in the ground in which to place or kindle a fire.

••• KS ýéeye kindle a fire, set fire to (ýe_ye, reg. conjugation) (RR).

••• Cf. áceðe. 

océhci. N [presumably océðe + hcí] fireplace in a home or in a place used for religious purposes, including the ceremonial fireplace used in the peyote times (BE2.47; FH/09/21/01/pc; 02/27/95/FH/pc:okc; FH:4/18/96/tape,ma).  

océçtà. V [reg., o_céçtà] [océ + çtà] snoop or look for constantly (lit., 'searches constantly').

óceçtà. ADJ, V [reg., ó_ceçtà] [óce + çtà] (be) snoopy. oçpéëì nàlôòha apái ðée apa ahú apai óceçtàpe they're hiding their things because the people coming are snoops (or 'are always snooping'). • N snoop, s.o. who looks for things constantly, s.o. who likes to get into another's things.

océëe. N [ó- LOC + céëe] urinal (04/26/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 167: océëe <u-dse´-zhe> urinal.

••• Cf. oëéhci. 

océëehci (variant of oëéhci).

ochí (variants: oochí, ochíe). ADJ, V [stat., o_chí] (be) plentiful, many, abound, exist in large quantity, (be) a lot of, (be) full of (e.g., worms). huuwáli ôwò òâchi I've got a lot to do (lit., 'many chores abound for me') (RBn12-07; FH/11/19/01/pc: okc). wáali ówò oðíchi you're really busy

(04/25/95/PM/pc:prod). ówò oðíchi ðaaçé íhpahò I know you have had a lot to do (RBn104:MOJ/79). môëò ðékçe táatà ðáalì ochíe tà, iiðáðe brée ðáalì if there are such beautiful things [abounding] in the world, I ought to go see them. wécØa ochíe there are lots of snakes (RBn3-09). watástoe ochí there are a lot of pecans (RBn10-2; LS:ok). ëìkáëì oochí a lot of kids (LS). ónòbre oochí a lot of food (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). haxî oochí a lot of blankets (LS). waðílà ochíe smart (lit., 'mind plentiful') (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; MJ/11/19/83). waðílà ochí akxai he has a lot on his mind

(EREsr). walúçka ochí wormy, full of worms. • (be) excessive or the most extreme, worst or best (above all others in a certain aspect). íxopeçtà ochí akxa he's standing on top of all the liars; he's the worst of the liars (lit., 'he is extreme in lying constantly') (RBn12-10/MJ; CQc).

•• LFD 180: ohcí <u-¾si´> [expected Mod. Os. form: ochí] plenty, plentiful. LFD 185: wasápe ochi <Wa-ša´-be u-tsi> where bears are plentiful, Bear Creek.

••• Cf. óochiëe. 

ochíchacha. V, ADV [conjug. unknown] (intr.) (be) excessive. íe ðée ochíchachae káaãe kçiðé ìká don't let him go on and on [talking] (MSB:t9).

ochíe (variant of ochí).

ochî. V [reg., o_chî] (trans.) whip strongly, beat up, spank or "get" s.o, drub, thrash. owíchì hta mìkçé, owíchì mìkçé I'm going to whip you (04/28/95/LS/pc:prod). oáchì hta àhé I'm going to whip him (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok; RBn10-7:JW). tówa ìkçe owáchì hta mìkçé I'm going to whip that one [sitting there, male or female] (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). hóni àwâchìpe, hóni owâchìpe they almost whipped me (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc; BE2.156). màxpúmèì apa oðíchìpe aapai lightning and thunder [lit., 'clouds moving'] are getting you (line from a children's song) (FH). • hit or strike (e.g., a drum or a person). céãenii ochî brée I'm going [to attend] to hit drum (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). céãenii ochî ðáalì çkáaãe you hit drum good (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). céãenii ochî ðáalì ìkçiape he hit drum good for him (BE2.67). ììçtáxi íe ékie ðìká ði, oðíchì hta apai, háakò ékiçe che íçpahòëi don't speak English, they're going to whip you, you don't know what you are saying (said by the speaker's mother to the speaker's father, who didn't speak English well) (FH/09/24/01/prod). ëâàxe abrîe áwachì I hit him with a stick (lit., 'I had a stick, I hit him') (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 180: óchì <u´-tsiæ> to strike. owáchì <u-wa´-tsiæ> I struck him. oðáchì <u-tha´-tsiæ> you struck him. àkóchì pe <oæ-gu´-tsiæ i> we struck him, to maul, to beat, to pound; to give a drubbing, to thrash.  

óchì. V [reg., ó_chì] [wa- VAL + ochî] (intr.) hit or beat things (such as a drum). óchì ðáalì káaãì aha wíkie whenever he hits [drum] well, there's a prayer (RBn10-18; gloss by CQ).

••• Cf. ochî. 

ocØîze. V, ADJ [stat.?, o_cØîze?] (be) stopped up, stuffed up, congested. hpoocØîze akxai he has a stopped up nose [i.e., hpa ocØîze akxai].

ódla (rare variant of ólà).

oðáake. V [sync., o_ðáake] (trans.) tell (e.g., news, stories), relate, narrate, recite, state, proclaim, inform, say so (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). táatà záani owíbraake I've told you everything (03/16/95/FH/pc). owíbraake ná I told you so (lit., 'I used to tell you it') (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). híko wì owíbraake çkôçta you want me to tell a story (03/16/95/FH/pc). pée oðíðaake? who told you that? (FH:prod). táatà oðíðaake? what did he tell you? (03/16/95/FH/pc). owâðaakape he told me [it] (03/16/95/FH/pc). àwâðaakape he told me (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). òwâðaake nàpé they used to tell me

(03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). oðáake ìká don't tell it (03/16/95/FH/pc:okc). àwâàðaki apai they're telling me something (MSB Mar 83). àwâðaaka tell it to me (RBnot-nd-1/p9; 03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). oâçtaake ðálì you ought to tell me. táatà éekòke àwâçtaakaaëi ðálì you shouldn't tell me things like that. íxope àwâçtaake you told me a lie (MSB-03-83). • (intr.) bid. pée oðáake hta ìkçé? whose bid is it? (in a card game; lit., 'whose bid will it be?') (RBn12-11).

•• LFD 175–76: oðáke <u-tha´-ge> to make a statement, to tell a tale or a story. obráke <ubtha´-ge> I made a statement. oçtáke <u-shta´-ge> you made a statement. àkóðaka pe <oæ-gu´-thaga i> we made a statement (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 123: oðáke <o-tha´-ge> to relate. obráke <o-btha´-ge> I relate. óçtake <o´-shta-ge> you relate, to tell, recite, narrate.

••• Cf. óðaake, ohkílaake. 

oðáake kØò. N pitch (a card game: lit., 'telling it game'; this phrase may also refer to other card games) (FH; BE2.103; 03/08/95/FH/pc:ok).

óðaake. V [sync., ó_ðaake] [wa- VAL + oðáake] (intr.) tell things, inform. owíbraake I'll tell you (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). ówabraake I tell them (things, stuff). âwaðaakape they told me (RBn19-02). ówaðaakapi tell us (03/16/95/FH/pc:okc). • N story, tale, legend, narrative, telling of s.t., reporting of news.

óðaake waléze. N newspaper, letter, magazine (lit., 'document with writing that tells things') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.93).

•• RB: <ó-thah-keh wáh-leh-zeh>.

•• LFD 123: óðake waleze <o´ tha-ge wa-gthe-še> newspaper.

oðáaçce. [sync., o_ðáaçce] [ðaa- INSTR + oçcé] (trans.) leave by mouth (e.g., remaining food).

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p24 ln7): wíëìðé, wì oðáaçta ðì hau <wíciæ¢é, wiæ uæ¢ácta-¢iæ haú> Elder Brother, leave one.

óðaaçce. N lunch, food taken home from a feast (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.83) . • V [sync., ó_ðaaçce] [wa- VAL + oðáaçce] (intr.) leave some as a remainder by mouth.

•• RB: <ó-thahæ-shtseh>.

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p24 ln9): ówaðaaçtá ðì haú, íihkitaðe htape <úwa¢actá-¢iæ haú, íki-xtá¢ªe tá§pe> leave some [of them, the crawfish], they will breed among themselves.  

oðáaze. N [ó- LOC + ðaazó] whoop, ululation (applies only to the noise that women make) (RBn22-08). oðáazo. N [ó- + ðaazó] female singers (FH: HH/t10-B-p1).  

oðáha (variant: oláha). V [sync., o_ðáha] (trans.) follow (e.g., a path, a person, God's word, a car, or a horse) (01/26/95/FH/pc; PM). àwâçipe oláha brée he hired me so I'm going [to follow him?]

(03/24/95/PM/pc). ékò anâkØòe ékò obráhai I heard it like that, I'm going to follow it like that

[woman speaking] (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). hkáwa obráha I followed the horse (FH:prod; BE2.49). ékò anâkØò ìtó ékò obráha ìtó I heard it like that, I'm going to follow it like that [man speaking] [ìtó is unfamiliar and not used in Mod. Os. (FH)] (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). óëàke obráhà ìtó I'll follow that road [ìtó is unfamiliar and not used in Mod. Os. (FH)] (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). oëâke obrâha àhé I'm following the road (RBn22-05). kîìkììeëì ówaðáha apa, kóe watôpe che he followed the butterflies so that he could watch them (RBn15-02; FH:ok). íe ðíhta àkóðaha àkòða àkái we want to follow your word (01/26/95/FH/pc:okc). àkóðiðaha ihtóì ðéha ìkçé we will follow you in the days to come (JS prayer). • (intr.) be behind, be attached to the back, be hanging (on the back of or behind s.t. else). álììhceðe oðáha oðíhta owíbraha hang the wheelchair on and I'll follow your car (lit., 'wheelchair attached, I'll follow the car') (RBn; MREI/01/11/93). oðíhtàhci oðáha a trailer house (lit., 'house following car') (04/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 122: oðáha <o-tha´-ha> to follow. óbraha <o´-btha-ha> I follow. ostáha <o-sda´-ha> you follow. àkóðaha <oæ-gu´-tha-ha> we follow.  

oðáhaaðee V [reg.+sync., o_ðáha_(a)ðee (object inflection and reg. subject inflection in first slot, sync. subject inflection in second slot)] [oðáha + aðée] (trans.) go with, go following. ówaðahaçcée? are you going with them? (RBn11-02/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976).

oðáçke (variant: oðâçke). V [sync., o_ðáçke] (trans.) tie (as a shoe). hòòpé obráçke çkôçta? do you want me to tie your shoe? (FH/t116b). hòòpé oðáçke çkôçta? do you want me to tie your shoe? hòòpé òðáçke çkôçta? [hòòpé o-à-ðáçke çkôçta] do you want to tie my shoe? (lit., 'do you want to tie for me the shoe?') (03/22/95/FH/pc).

••• Cf. okáçke. 

óðaëi (variant of óðàëi).

óðààceçi (variant: óðààçe). V [uninfl./reg., óðààce_çi] (trans.) worry about, feel concern over, be concerned about (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok; FH:4/24/96/prod). óðààceçi mìkçé I'm worried (BE2.161, unconfirmed). mâzeska oðâàceçi mìkçé I'm worried about money (RBn HW). Mary akxa óðààceçi Mary is worried about something. oðíhtà óðààceçi akxai he's worried about his car. ëékaëì apa óðààcewaçí apai Little-legs is worried about us (RBn23-17). óðààceàiçi àkai we're anxious [note unexpected i before çi in óðààceàiçi] (LS:prod). • focus on, pay attention to, look into, attend to, think about (FH:5/01/96/tape; 03/24/95/PM/pc:okc). óðààcaëi mìkçé ha I haven't thought about it [expected Mod. Os. form: óðààceçi(a)ëi mîkçe (ha is not usually used in Mod. Os.)] (03/24/95/PM/pc:prod). ëìkáëì óðààceçi pay attention to the children (05/01/95/LS/pc; 01/04/95/FH/pc/ok). ëìkáëì óðààcewaçí pay attention to the children (FH/09/25/01/prod; BE2.2; 03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). óðààceçi ìká, olâà akxa don't pay any attention to him, he's mad (RBn11-01/JW&FW&HHask).

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p23 ln5): ónàhceëi <uæ´nantseci´> hearts . . . not easy.

•• LFD178: óðàceçi <u´-thoæ-dse-shi> anxiety, to be anxious, deeply concerned, solicitous. óðàce àçi <u´-thoæ-dse oæ-shi> I am anxious. óðàce ði çi <u´-thoæ-dse thi shi> you are anxious. óðàce àçi pe <u´-thoæ-dse oæ-shi bi a> he was solicitous for me.

óðààceçi ðìké (variant: óðààceçi ìké). VP [conjug. unknown (presumably stat., óðààceçi _ðìké)] (trans.) disuse, be unconcerned with, disregard, not pay attention to (lit., 'not worried about') (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok: disregard). óðààceçi ìká don't pay any attention to him (RBn1101/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976). • (intr.) be unobserved, as a custom (FH/09/25/01/ok).

•• LFD 178: óðàceçi ðìke <u´-thoæ-dse-shi thiæ-ge> disuse, out of use.

óðààçe (variant of óðààceçi).

oðâçke (variant of oðáçke).

óðàëi (variants: ôðàëi, ólaëi, óoðààëi, óðaëi). ADV in spite of everything, inevitably, contrarily, anyhow, anyway, even so, regardless, notwithstanding everything, however, nevertheless, at any rate (RBn1MOJ/p28b; 02/01/95/FH/pc:okc; 05/01/95/LS/pc:ok). óðaëi ékò kíe it's that way anyway (FH). óðàëi niiëú akxa in spite of everything it's raining (05/01/95/LS/pc). óðàëi waachí apai in spite of it, they're dancing (05/01/95/LS/pc). óðàëi niiëú che waachí apai in spite of the fact it's raining, they're dancing (05/01/95/LS/pc). ókaaãeìki akxa óðàëi waachípe Useless couldn't help but dance (lit., 'Useless danced anyway') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). • V (intr.) [uninfl.] get it, do it or make it despite s.t., have one's way. iðáëoçi àëi óðàëi akxai I said no, but he's going to have his way (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

•• JOD (Wasápeëìka letter, lines 2–3): ôðaëi, wihcíëoe, waðíhòìki <ªuæ´¢a§ci, witsí§cªuæé, wa¢íhªuæ'iñki au.> at any rate, niece, you are an orphan.

•• LFD 178: óðàëi <u´-thoæ-zhi> inevitable. óðàëi ekò <u´-thoæ-zhi e-goæ> infallible, unerring, unfailing.

oðíbrà. V [sync., o_ðíbrà] [ó- LOC + ðíbrà] (trans.) smoke, cause to smell, as in making cedar smoke for a cleansing or a blessing (lit., 'wherein one causes there to emanate an odor').  

••• Cf. xòòcóðibrà. 

oðíhtà (variants: oðíhta, owíhta). N car, wagon (BE2.150; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). [Describes a rolling motion (RB).] oðíhtà olîì hta mìkçé I'm going in a car (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). oðíhtà olîì hta apái they're going in a car (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). oðíhtà çkâ káaãa start the car (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). oðíhta akxa çkâëi akxái the car won't start (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.17). owíhta ëúuce ëì wíht[a] olîì hu come ride in my little red wagon.

•• LFD 177: oðíhtàða <u-thi´-¾oæ-tha> anything propelled by rolling, a wagon, buggy, a carriage.  

••• QU odíhtàhtàda to roll something over and over (RR).

••• Cf. oðíhtàhci. 

oðíhtà. N work, occupation, position (LF).

•• LFD 177: oðihtà <u´-thi-¾oæ> an occupation. óðihtà ðalì xci owanàëi <u´-thi-¾oæ tha-gthiæ xtsi u-wa-noæ-zhi> I have a good position. óhihtà thi wihta theti bre <u´-hi-¾oæ ti wi-¾a te-di bthe> [expected Mod. Os. form: oðíhtàhci wíhta che ci brée] I went to my office. óðihtà thi ðihta theti çni a(?) <u´-thi-¾oæ ti thi-¾a te-di shni a(?)> [çni was never an Osage word, likely Omaha, should be çcée] are you going to your office?

••• Cf. waðíhtà. 

oðíhtà hcí oðáha. N trailer (lit., 'rolling house following') (04/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 177: oðíhtàða hcioðaha <u-thi´-¾oæ-tha ¾si-u-tha-ha> little-wagon-with-a-house-attachedto it: a buggy.

oðíhtà hciëé. N car door. oðíhtà kØâsaaki. N train (lit., 'pulls fast'), locomotive (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.144; RB). oðíhtà olîì. ADVP by car. oðihtà olîì achíe I came by car.

oðíhtàhci. N [oðíhtà + hcí] garage (lit., 'car house') (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.53).

•• RB: <o-thí-tah´-tsi>.

•• LFD 177 (unconfirmed): oðíhtàða onàëì <u-thi´-¾oæ-tha u-noæ-zhiæ> a garage (01/31/95/FH/pc:uk with onàëì).

oðíhtàhci hcíëe. N garage door. oðíhtà hci hcíëe áðiità close the garage door (RBn1-MOJ/p45; FH/08/15/95/pc:okc).

oðíinà (variant: oðíina). V [sync.?, o_ðíinà?] (trans.) fasten, button (e.g., an old-fashioned shoe with buttons or a sweater with buttons), zip, tie up, rope (e.g., a calf). hciëé akxa oðíina akxái the door is locked (fastened) (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.80; RBn2-MOJ/p21). oðíkinààëi oðíina zip up your fly

(fasten your pants) (RBn2-MOJ/p21; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok). çôke oðíinà go tie the dog up

(03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). hcéska oðíina akxai he's roping a cow (RBn23-13). hceeská oðíinà aðáape they went to rope calves (RBn11-02; 3/22/95/FH/pc:ok).

oðíità. V [sync., o_ðíità] (trans.) stop, halt (e.g., the horse pulling a buggy, the motion of a car), curb motion, check a horse's forward movement (03/14/95/MREI/pc; BE2.128; RBn1-MOJ/p40; HH/14a/172ff&pc: ooðíità).

•• RB: <o-thí-dahæ>.

•• LFD 176: oðítà <u-thi´-doæ> check. hkawa ðì obrità <Ða-wa thiæ o-bthi-doæ> I checked the horse.

oðíkinâàëì (variant: oðíkinâàëi) (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok both oðó- and oðí-). N pants, trousers, underwear (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p2; MOJt150; FH/t116b). oðíkinààëi oðíina zip up your fly (fasten your pants) (RBn2-MOJ/p21; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok). oðíkinààëì okíkxà put your underwear/trousers/pants on (03/22/95/PM/pc).

••• Cf. oðókinâàëì. 

oðíkØe. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) drop s.t. into (e.g., eyedrops into eyes) (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ììçtá oðíkØe put some into your eyes.

•• LFD 77: ìçtá oðikØe <iæ-shta´ u-thi-Ð'e> to drop anything into the eye, as an eyewash.

oðínii. N umbrella (04/06/95/FH/pc:ok). oðínii ëìka a parasol (FH/pc).

•• LFD 171 (unconfirmed): oíhniëìka <u-i´-hni-zhiæ-ga> a parasol. oíhni ëìka wì abrì <u-i´-hni zhiæ-ga wiæ a-bthiæ> I have a parasol. [The sequence of vowels oi <u-i>, <o-i> in LF's data often corresponds to oði in Mod. Os.]

óðisàha. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) flutter. ðâàce óðisàha a fright, a scare (lit., 'heart flutters') (RBn2314).

•• LFD 113: nôce oðisàha <noæ´-dse u-thi-šoæ-ha> a shock to the heart, a scare, a fright: heart palpitates quickly. LFD 203: waðôce oðisàha <wa-thoæ´-dse u-thi-šoæ-ha> to excite, excitement. His heart is fluttering with excitement.

oðíçi (variant: oðíçì). V [sync., o_ðíçi] (trans.) wrap (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod). obríçi I wrap it. oçciçi you wrap it. oðíçi she wraps it. àkóðiçi we wrap it. • N cover (for a teepee, sweat house, pillow, etc.).

ípihì oðíçi pillow cover, pillowcase (RBn1-54; BE2.26;01/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 177: oðíçì <u-thi´-shiæ> to wrap anything up. obríçì <u-bthi´-shiæ> I wrap it up. àkóðiçì pe <oæ-gu´-thi-shiæ i> we wrap it up. oðíçìle <u-thi´-shiæ-gthe> to surround an enemy as in an attack.

••• Cf. wacúexò oðiçi. 

oðízà (variants: óðizàha, óðiëàhe) V [sync., o_ðízà] (trans.) be among others in, be a member of (e.g., a club), belong to, be a part of, be among (HRE/01/17/02/pc:ok). hlaaskáëì obrízà mìkçé I'm a member of the hlaaskáëì club (HRE/01/17/02/pc). óðizà nìkçé you're part of it; you belong; you're a member (LS05/08/01; BE2.3; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). oðízà apai they are among them (01/14/95/FH/pc). ecí àkóðizâhape we belong there (MSB 03-83).

•• RB: <ó-thi-záhæ-hah>.

oðîì (variant of oðîìke). 

oðîìðe (variant of oðîìmà).

oðîìke (variant: oðîì). V [sync., o_ðîìke (variant oðìì is sometimes uninfl.)] (trans.) take hold of s.o.'s body part, take or have hold of, grasp, hug, embrace, catch (a person or an animal). owíbrìì I hugged you. oðíðììke catching you, to have a hold of you (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). oðíðìì I caught you, I have hold of you (9/17/94/FH/pc; 9/17/94/PM/pc). tóoce oscîìke you took him by the throat (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). wamààðôçtà oçcîìke you caught the thief. • hold, hold on to, embrace as tradition. mâça owíbrììke I voted (lit., 'I grasped the feather'). mâça oçcììke? did you vote?

(8/8/94,FH, pc). oðîìke apai they held on to it. àkòðììke we're holding on to something. saakí oðîìka hold on tight; hold it tight (FH/pc; BE2.67). oðîìkapi!  hold on to it! [pl.].

••• Cf. mâçà oðîìke, mâze oðóbrììke. 

oðîìmà (variant: oðîìðe). V [sync., o_ðîìmà] (trans.) lock (e.g., a house door, a trunk, a car door). saakí oðîìmà lock it tight; fasten it (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). oðíhtà oðîìmà! lock the car! (FH/t116b). oðíhtà oðîìma akxai the car door is locked (FH). saakí açäîìmà [a- prefix is unexpected; expected Mod. Os. form: oçcîìmà or oçäîìma] you fastened it (FH:ok).

•• LFD 29: sakí oðimà <ša-gi´ u-thi-moæ> to make fast, to secure, to fasten. sakí obrimà <ša-gi´ u-bthi-moæ> I made secure. saki oscimà <ša-gi u-stsi-moæ> you fastened it. sakí àkoðimà pe <šagi´ oæ-gu-thi-moæ i> we fastened it.

oðóðe. V [reg., oðó_ðe] (trans.) be in charge of, supervise, boss (e.g., an event), manage. oðo[w]aðe I am in charge of it. oðóðaðe you are in charge of it. ónòbre oðóaðe hta mìkçe I'm going to be bossing [taking care of] the food. ónòbre che oðó[w]a[ð]i kôða they want me to oversee this dinner (FH:prod). htóoëu wéðuwì kôða apai àëì oðóða[ð]i hce ée apai they want to sell meat pies, but they want you to oversee it (FH:prod). oðówaapi akxai he's bossing us around [oðówaapi from oðo-wa-ðeapi] (FH:prod).

••• Cf. oðówaðe. 

oðóhake. ADJ more, last, final. htáalìko oðóhake hkôbra I want more meat gravy (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc; t14-b-p2).

•• LFD 179: oðóhake <u-thu´-ha-ge> the last time. oðóhake che <u-thu´-ha-ge tse> final, the final act, the last. hcíëo oðohake tsi´-zhu u-thu-ha-ge> the last in the line of the tsizhu gens.

••• Cf. hâàpa oðóhake. 

oðóhake íðilà. VP [sync., oðóhake í_ðilà] (trans.) reconsider, think about again, rethink (LF).

•• LFD 123 (unconfirmed): oðóhake ílilà <o-tho´-ha-ge i-gthi-gthoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: oðóhake íðilà] to reconsider. oðóhake iðálilà <o-tho´-ha-ge i-tha´-gthi-gthoæ> I reconsidered.

oðóhake íðalilà <o-tho´-ha-ge i´-tha-gthi-gthoæ> you reconsidered. oðóhake àðàlilàpe <o-tho´-hage oæ-thoæ-gthi-gthoæ i> we reconsidered.

oðóhkiðe. V [reg.?, oðó_hkiðe] [presumably hkik- RECIP + oðóðe] (trans.) intermingle, mix, blend, place together (as when cooking two or more items together). htáa ðé oðóhkiðaa cook this meat with it (04/06/95/LS/pc:okc; RBn1-MOJ/p49b).

oðóhkihà. V [presumably ó- LOC + hkik- RECIP + oohâ] (trans.) add in cooking. hòbrîke owáha hta mìkçé, waçî çki oðóhkihà when I'm going to cook beans, I [also] add salt meat (01/12/95/FH/pc:hk; BE2.24).

•• LFD 179: oðóhkihà <u-thu´-Ði-hoæ> two kinds of food boiled or cooked together.

oðóhta (variant: oðóhtà). ADJ straight up.  

óðohtà (variant: óðohta). V [reg., ó_ðohtà] (intr.) behave. óðohta àhé I'm behaving (108-b/FH/152). oáðohta àmâbrì àçkáaãe íkØuca try to make me behave (MOJ 1/19/83). óðohta ðaìçé you're behaving (108-b/Fh/152). óðohta káaãa make him behave. óðohta ði! behave yourself! (said when scolding someone for not living right) (RBn 3/3/77). óðohtà mâì! behave! (lit., 'go on and behave', as an admonishment to children who are laughing too much). • ADJ straight, virtuous. waðílà óðohta káaãa think straight (lit., 'make your mind straight'). • N behavior, good behavior, acting with rectitude (may refer to conduct of the moment or to long-term behavior).

•• LFD 124: óðohtà <o´-tho-¾oæ> recititude, moral integrity, good behavior. óðohtà aëi <o´-tho¾oæ a-zhi> depraved. níhkaçika wì óðohtà aëi ha <ni´-Ða-shi-ga wiæ o´-tho-¾oæ a-zhi ha> [sentencefinal ha is not used in Mod. Os.] a depraved man, corrupt, wicked. óðohtà ahkila ðì <o´-tho-¾oæ a-Ðigtha thiæ> demeanor, deportment, behavior [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'to carry oneself with rectitude']. LFD 178: oðóhtà <u-tho´-¾oæ> a virtuous woman [expected gloss for Mod. Os. form: 'virtuous', not necessarily a woman]. LFD 180: oðóhtà aëi <u-thu´-¾oæ a-zhi> not true, not straight, dishonest, not accurate, not upright. LFD 150 (unconfirmed): ðiðóhtà <thi-tho´-¾oæ> to regulate [make straight], to make straight that which is crooked, reparation of a wrong; to regulate, to make a rule by which to guide or to be guided. briðóhtà <bthi-tho´-¾oæ> I regulate. àðíhtohtàpe <oæ-thi´¾ho-¾oæ i> [<-¾ho-> is a typographical error for <-tho->] we regulate.

••• Cf. wáðohtà. 

óðohtàhkiðe. V [reg., óðohtà_hkiðe] [óðohtà + hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] (intr.) behave oneself, make oneself straight by acting with rectitude (lit., 'cause oneself to act straight'). óðohtàhkíe! behave yourself! (lit., 'make yourself straight, properly behaving') (01/07/95/FH/pc; BE2.8). • N good behavior. óðohtahkíe good behavior (FH prod).

oðókahi. V [reg., oðó_kahi] (trans.) stir (e.g., food when cooking). (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ma; 04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). oðóakahi I'm stirring it. oðóðakahi you're stirring it. ónòbre àkóðokahipe we're stirring the food (RBn1-MOJ/p50; FH:ok).

•• LFD 178: oðókahi <u-thu´-ga-hi> to stir up. oðówakahi <u-thu´-wa-ga-hi> I am stirring what is in the pot cooking. [Strictly speaking, 'in the pot cooking' is not part of the meaning of the Os. form.] oðóðakahi <u-thu´-tha-ga-hi> you are stirring what is in the pot cooking, to stir up what is cooking or boiling. [Strictly speaking, 'in the pot' and 'cooking or boiling' are not part of the meaning of the Os. form.]

oðókanáaëi, oðókanâàëi, oðókanâàëì (variants of oðókinâàëì).

oðókinâàëì (variants: oðókanâàëi, oðókanâàëì,oðókanáaëi, oðókinâàëi). N trousers, pants, underwear.

oðókanâàëì okíkxà put on your pants (BE2.144; 04/03/95/PM/pc: ðókináëi also ok).

•• RB: <ó-tho-kah-náh-zhi, o-thó-ki-náh-zhi>.

•• LFD 123: oðókinàëì <o-tho´-gi-noæ-zhiæ> trousers. LFD 179: oðókinàëì <u-thu´-gi-noæ-zhiæ> pants, pantaloons, trousers. oðókinàëì aakihpasta <u-thu´-gi-noæ-zhiæ a-a-gi-¼a-šta> [aakihpasta is not acceptable in Mod. Os.] I patch my pants. [Translation should be 'I put my pants on' (PM).] oðókinàëì akinà braza <u-thu´-gi-noæ-zhiæ a-gi-noæ btha-ša> I tore my pants. [Verb form for 'I tore it' should be anâkaabrazé (PM).]  

••• Cf. oðíkinâàëì. 

oðókinâàëì ákaha. N overalls.

•• LFD 179: oðókinàëì akaha wihta <u-thu´-gi-noæ-zhiæ a-ga-ha wi-¾a> my overalls (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

oðóohpa. V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) obey (e.g., the law). wahkílaace oðóohpa akxái it's the rule, he's obeying the law (BE2.76; 02/14/95/FH/pc:ok). wahkílaace oðóohpa nàpe he obeys the law (02/15/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 29: okíhpa <u-gi´ ¼a> obey (to).

oðópçe. N baby board of any type (MREI/pc/1994; FH); cradle of any type, cradleboard (BE2.27; FH 1994/pc).

•• LFD 179: oðópçe <u-thu´-pshe> cradle board.

••• Cf. ípçe. 

oðóçi. ADJ in the way, in front of and blocking. oðóçi nìkçé you're in the way [sitting] (BE2.152).

•• LFD 179: oðóçi ha omàðì <u-thu´-shi ha u-moæ-thiæ> to walk in advance of a group of people. oðóçi ha omàbrì <u-thu´-shi ha u-moæ-bthiæ> I walked in advance. oðóçiha àko màðì pe <u-thu´shi-ha oæ-gu moæ-thiæ i> [expected Mod. Os. form: oðóçi àkómàðìpe] we walked in advance.

oðóçimàðì (variants: oðóçima, oðóçimà). V [uninfl. or sync., oðóçimà_ðì] [oðóçi + màðî] (intr.) block s.o.'s way or be in the way while moving. oðóçimàbrî I'm just in the way (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; FH:5/01/96/pc). oðóçimà ðée apa he's in the way (lit., 'he's in the way, that one moving'). ðée apa oðóçimàðì he's in the way (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc; FH:5/01/96/okc). oðóçimàçcì you're in the way [moving].

oðóta, oðótà (apparently variants of ootá).

oðótà mâzeska. N interest money (lit., 'use money', 'use of money') (04/14/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p28; FH:4/25/96/tape: oðótà; 04/13/95/FH/pc).

••• Cf. mâzeska oðótà, mâëà ootá, ootá mâzeska. 

oðówaðe (variants: oðówai, oðówe). V [reg., oðówa_ðe] [wa- VAL + oðóðe] (intr. [also trans.?]) be boss in relation to an event (e.g., a dinner), be in charge of, see to or oversee a certain occasion. ónòbre che oðóawaðe hta mìkçé I'm going to be taking care of the food (FH:prod). oðówaðaðe you are taking care of it. ónòbre che oðówaðai hkôbra I want you to oversee this dinner (FH:prod). ónòbre oðówa[ð]i akxa she's bossing the food; she's in charge of food (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod orig). Carolyn ónòbre che oðów[að]e kôða apai they want Carolyn to oversee this dinner (FH:prod). Mary, Darlene ónôbre che oðóepi wáhkôbra I want Mary and Darlene to oversee this dinner [oðóepi < oðówaðe api] (FH:prod). waaðô hta apai, oðówaðaðe hta nîkçé? they're going to sing, are you going to see about things? • run a business, conduct one's own or s.o. else's affairs, be boss or foreman. xuháaska apa táatà àkóhta oðówa[ðe] apai white people are running our business, bossing us (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.10). • N boss, foreman. oðówai boss, foreman.

óðoxta. N [wa- VAL + óxta] s.t. or s.o. valued, beloved, or treasured (such as a favorite child). óðoxta çkaaãe you're making it special, you're making it a favorite thing.

oðúluha. ADV underneath, beneath, below, under (LF).

•• LFD 349 (unconfirmed): oðúluha <u-thú-xthu-ha> underneath.

••• QU odíxda under, beneath a solid object (RR).

oðúucØake. ADJ, V [sync., o_ðúucØake] [apparently ó- LOC + ðuucØáke] (intr.) (be) lazy. waxpéì àkái, ókØu àðúucØake çe nààhtàhtàà oðúucØake wî we're too poor to feed that lazy donkey (RBn102:MJ/79). obrúucØake I'm lazy (FH:4/25/96/tape). • V (trans.) be or become tired or weary of. níwahce obrúucØake I'm tired of this cold (RBn23-14). oçcúucØake are you getting tired of this? (FH:5/01/96/tape:prod). obrúucØake I'm getting tired of this (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.141). áwabruucØáke mìkçé I've had enough of them; I've gotten tired of them (MSB). àwáçcuucØake nìkçé? are you tired of me? • N laziness. wáli oðúucØake çíe you have really gotten lazy (lit., 'indeed you arrived at laziness') (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.77).

óðuucØake. V [sync., ó_ðuucØake] [wa- VAL + oðúucØake] (intr.) be lazy (RB; 02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). hàpái wálì óbruucØake mìkçé I was very lazy today (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). tówa apa óðuucØakape that person is lazy (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; FH:4/25/96/tape). kóota níhka akxa óðuucØakape that man is lazy (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). kóota wakØó akxa óðuucØakape that woman is lazy (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok).  

oðúuxpaðe (variant: oðúuxpa). V [sync., o_ðúuxpaðe] (trans.) take out or unload s.t. by removing, by extracting, or by lowering from a carrier or storage (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.147; RB). htáa che oðúuxpaðe take the meat out (of the car) (FH:5/02/96/prod). nâãehci obrúuxpaðe hta mìkçé I'm going to take it out of the refrigerator (FH/09/23/01/pc). àkóðuuxpaðe àkatxái we're going to take it out (FH/09/23/01/pc).

ohcíle. N [ó- LOC + hcíle] home, place to live, abode, household that one lives in (lit., 'wherein one has a household') (LS). ohcíle wíhta my home (RB; 02/09/95/FH/pc:okc). ohcíle ðáalì wì íiðe ðí aape she found a good place to live (RBn19-03). • furnishings, furniture (HH/pc). [LS contrasts hcíle 'household' with ohcíle 'house or household as a place that you live in'.]

ohépe (variant: óhepe). N small amount, amount not quite filling a container or vessel, less than the full amount (especially of liquids); portion that fills a container approximately half full. níi tóa àkØú, ohépe give me some water, about half a glass, not quite full (FH:prod). ohépe àkØú give me [it] about half full (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 170: ohépe <u-he´-be> dose of medicine [expected gloss not limited to medicine].

••• Cf. hépe. 

óhesaëi (variant: óhesaëì). ADJ, ADV fast, rough(ly), bad(ly), untamed, forceful(ly), pushy, abrupt(ly), very strong(ly), fierce(ly), hard, with force, quickly, abruptly. htaacé óhesaëì the wind is really strong (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig; FH:4/18/96/t; BE2.45). wisòka akxa wáli íe óhesaëìpe brother is really a strong talker (FH). wálì hpíiëie óhesaëì alîì ðáha níi hpáasike it's awful that I sat down real quick and splattered water (lit., 'it is really bad that when I sat down quickly I splattered water') (04/19/95/FH/pc). çtôpaëie ðalîì óhesaëì áha níi çpáasike you didn't look when you sat down hard, and you sat in water and splattered it, made it shoot out (04/19/95/FH/pc). wisôka akxa wáli óhesaëì wáli íe akxai brother is really talking strong. wálì hpíiëie óhesaëì alîì ðáha níi hpáasike it's awful that I sat down real quick and splattered water (04/19/95/FH/pc). • ADJ worse, more intense, stronger. taaké óhesaëi ahí akxa the war is worse (lit., 'it is becoming worse fighting') (03/24/95/PM/pc; BE2.161). taaké óhesaëi hi chí aapé [they say that] the war is getting worse, it's getting to where they're really fighting (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 170: óhesaëi <u´-he-ša-zhi> to act in a violent manner, fiery. hkáwa ohesaëi <Ða´-wa uhe-ša-zhi> a fiery horse.

ohí. V [reg., o_hí] (trans.) beat, conquer, best s.o. in a game (not used for a race). àkóhipe we beat him. àkówahie we beat them at a game. owíhie I beat you. owáhie I beat him. àwáhipe he beat me. áwahíe I beat them. oðíhipaëi he didn't beat you. • (trans.) win. ówe tóa owáhi I won some groceries. mâzeska àwáhipe he won money from me.

•• LFD 170: ohi <u-hi> [no accent indicated by LF] to defeat, to overcome, to prevail (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). owáhi <u-wa´-hi> I win. oðáhi <u-tha´-hi> you win. âkohi pe <oæ´-gu-hi i> we win.

••• Cf. óhi. 

óhi. V [reg., ó_hi] [wa- VAL + ohí] (intr.) win at a game or contest, defeat others, best everyone in a game, be the winner (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). oáhi/wáhi/owáhi I win (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc). íkiha owáhi I win repeatedly (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc). wálì óðahi ðàìçé aape you sure have been winning, they say (BE2.158). ówaðahi you broke us. hóni óhipe he almost won (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). àkówahie we won. àkóhipe we won. óhiçtà winner. pée óhi? who won? óhiçtà a winner, someone who always wins. • (trans.) win s.t. ówe tóa owáhi I won some groceries (RBn22-09; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok).

ohíiða. N [ó- LOC + hiiðá] bathtub, place to bathe, place to swim (BE2.7; 01/06/95/FH/pc: ok). ohíiðahci. N [ohíiða + hcí] bath house (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok (BE2.7).

óhipaëinai. N [óhi + api SUFFIX + aëí NEG + nà 'always' + ðe DECLARATIVE MARKER] loser, s.o. who customarily does not win (lit., 'does not win habitually').

óhiçtà. N [óhi + çtà] habitual winner, s.o. who wins constantly or repeatedly.

óhkace (variant: óhkaci). V [conjug. unknown] [ó- LOC + -hkace] (intr., trans.) cook, grill, barbeque, cook outside (refers only to cooking meat on a rack, as for barbeque) (RBn1; BE2.86; 01/11/95/FH/pc:ok; 02/24/95/FH/pc:okc; 04/13/95/LS:ok).

 ••• Cf. táahkace. 

ohkáðìke (variants: ohkâìke, ohkáìke). V [uninfl.?] [óhkà 'space' + ðìké NEG] (trans.) crowd s.o. wáli ohkâðìke àhé àëi àwáachi àhé I'm really crowding everybody but I'm dancing (RBn2-MOJ/p17). wi ohkáìke I'm crowding people (RBn2-MOJ/p17; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

ohkáska (variant of ohkâska).

óhkà (variant: óhka). N space, room (in the sense of an unoccupied area). óhka lâàðe a large space (FH/t113). óhka wahókØa a small space (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). óhkà ecíhta? is there room over there? (asking for room for someone to sit) (RBn3-51).

•• LFD 173: ohkà lâàðe <u-Ðoæ gthoæ´-the> a large space, spacious. LFD 172: ohkâ <u-koæ´> a vacancy, a space. Room for one more person in a house or at a gathering.

••• Cf. wíohkaðì. 

óhkà (variant: ohkâ). V [reg., ó_hkà] (trans.) help, help s.o. with a task, assist, aid (2-10-83). ówaðahkàì you help them (2/1/D). o[w]áhkà I helped her. waëáëeíe àwâðahkà hkôbra I want you to help me with the Osage language (RBn1-58). óhkà màðí! go help them! (RBn10-18). àwâhkà! help me! (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.66). àkóhkàëi áha ékiòëí hta apai if we don't help her she won't do it (MREI 1-14-82). owíhkà hce I'll just help you, let me help you (2-1-125). wihé oáhkà eeçkítà àwâhkà nàpé when I help second daughter she helps me (2-1-G). owáhkàpi! help us! (MREI 11-1-83-1).  

••• Cf. okíhkà. 

ohkâci (variant: ohkâce). ADJ, ADV, V [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) alone, isolated, by oneself, individual, distinct, single, sole, apart from anyone else, solitary, ohkâci àhé I am by myself (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 172: ohkâci <u-Ðoæ´-dsi> single, distinct, alone separate, sole. ohkâci ne ha <u-Ðoæ´-dsi ne ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: ohkâci çcée; ne is not an Osage word; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you went alone. LFD 173: ohkâci ðe kaãe <u-Ðoæ´-dsi the ga-xe> to isolate, to make to be apart, to segregate, to make alone. LFD 121: óhkàci <o´-Ðoæ-dsi> individual, one single person. ohkâciðòðò ò <u-Ðoæ´-dsi-thoæ-thoæ> [ðòðò unconfirmed] severally, each one apart from the rest. ohkâcinàëì <U-Ðoæ´-dsi-noæ-zhiæ> Stands-alone (personal name), refers to the solitary buffalo that stands apart from the herd. ohkâciwaçkà <O-Ðoæ´-dsi-wa-shkoæ> Struggles-by-himself (personal name): No one to help him fight.

••• Cf. mîìohkâce. 

ohkâci káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, ohkâci _káaãe] (trans.) isolate (lit., 'cause to be alone').

ohkâcilà. N [ohkâci + oolâ] ace in a deck of cards (LF only, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 172: ohkâcilà <u-Ðoæ´-dsi-gthoæ> one-that-is-placed-in-the-center-of-space. ohkà, ci, là <u-Ðoæ, dsi, gthoæ> space, there (in the center), placed: the ace in a deck of cards (unconfirmed; 04/19/95/FH/pc:not quite right, uk; 04/25/95/PM/pc:uk, first part means 'help').

ohkâìke (variant of ohkáðìke).

ohkâska (variants: óhkàska, ohkáska, ohkôska). N, ADV (in the) center, middle, (at the) halfway point (RBn1-10; 02/24/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.87; 04/19/95/FH/pc: non-nasal: ohkáska).

•• RB: <ó-kahæ-skah>.

•• LFD 172: ohkâska <u-Ðoæ´-ška> the center. Ce ohkàska <Dse u-Ðoæ-ška> center of a lake [ce is not recognized in Mod. Osage as 'lake']. ní ohkàska <ni´ u-Ðoæ-ška> center of waters (the earth). "This was a name given to a subgens of the water division (Wa-zha-zhe gens) of the Osage tribal organization." hta wì cØe aðe, ðue ohkàska ao <¾a wiæ ¾s'e a-the, thiu-e u-Ðoæ-ška a-u> [expected Mod. Os. form: htáa wì cØéaðe, ðúwe ohkáska 'I killed a deer, (through) the center of the diaphragm'; sentence-final ao <a-u> is not used in Mod. Os.] I killed a deer, I shot it through the middle of the body. íwiðe hkòbra, ðohtà pçi, ðeka ohkàska xci awihkihpa <I´-wi-the Ðoæ-btha, tho¾oæ pshi the ga u-Ðoæ-ška xtsi a-wi-Ði-¼a> [expected Mod. Os. form: íiwiðe hkôbra, ðóhtà pçi, ðéeka ohkáskaxci áwihkihpa I want to see you, I went in a straight line to find you, but meet you here (lit., 'I wanted to see you, straight I went there, exactly in the center here I encountered you')]. mi ohkàska <Mi u-Ðoæ-ška> [expected Mod. Os. form: mîì ohkâska] mid-heaven or mid-sun. LFD 121: okxâska <o-koæ´-ška> [incorrect <o-koæ´-ška> for the correct <u-Ðoæ-ška>, Mod. Os. ohkâska] the middle part of the house.

ohkí (variant of ohkíe).

óhkiache (variants: ohkåche, óhkiachi, ohkíechi). N quilt (lit., 'sewn together', 'sewn to each other') (BE2.110; RBn1-MOJ/p54; 04/20/95/LS/pc; 04/19/95/FH/pc:ok; FH/09/21/01/pc; RBn 3/3/77).

•• RB: <ó-kyah-tsi>.

•• LFD 57: haská ohkihpache <ha-ška´u-Ði-¼a-tse> a patch quilt.

ohkíce. N goal, curved stick used to play kaçíni (shinny) (03/23/95/FH/pc). [This stick is for hitting the ball made out of buckskin in the game of shinny, which was declining in popularity in the early twentieth century, circa 1916 when FH was born.]

•• LFD 171: ohkíce <u-Ði´-dse> a goal, the goals in the game of shinny.

ohkícheðe (variant of ohkíicheðe).

ohkíe (variant: ohkí [rare, archaic?]). V [reg., o_hkíe] [originally a reciprocal form 'speak with each other, converse' (ó- LOC + hkik- RECIP + íe), now used regularly as a transitive form] (trans.) call on the telephone. mâzeohkíe oâhkie they called me by phone (RBn10-20). • converse with, interview, talk with or to. owíhki hkôbra ìké I don't want to talk to you (PM/7/7/94; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). owíhkie achíe I came to talk to you (RBn12-01). waëáëe záani owíhkie akxâhe I'm talking to all you Osages. waëáëe záani owíhkie mìkçé I'm talking to all you Osages. owíhki[e] hkôbra I want to talk to you (RBn10-5:JW; 03/05/95/JS/pc:ok owíhki). òwâðahkie çò ðaìçé íiðixope when you [pl.] were talking to me you lied (FH/05/13/94). oðíhkie kôða he wants to talk to you (03/05/95/JS/pc:okc). oðíhkie hta akxái he is going to talk to you. àwâhkia talk to me (FH). àwâðahkíe çcílà e you wanted to talk to me (MSB). owíhkie brílàe I wanted to talk to you (MSB; BE2.133; 03/05/95/JS/pc:okc).

•• LFD 171: ohkíe <u-Ði´-e> to interview, to speak or to talk to one another, to hold an interview. owáhkie <u-wa´-Ði-e> I had an interview. àkóhkia pe <oæ-gu´-Ði-a i> we had an interview.

••• Cf. ohkíhkie, okíhkie. 

ohkíe. N get-together, meeting of a group of people to converse. [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] hôòpaðe waëáëe ëî toa ohkíe che ëóàhkile àkái, waëáëeíe íkØuce àkáli today a bunch of Osage young people, we're gathered together, we've come back to study Osage (RBn10-13; FH/11/19/01/pc:okc). 

ohkíechi (variant of óhkiache).  

ohkíetxàtxà (variant: ohkíekxàkxà), ADV [ó- LOC + hkik- RECIP + etxâ (reduplicated)] every time, consecutively, one after another, time after time (04/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 171: ohkiá txàtxà <u-Ði-a´ toæ-toæ> consecutive, one following the other, a series.

ohkíeëà. V [conjug. unknown] [presumably hkik- REFL + óëà] (intr.) care for oneself. ohkíeëà akxai they're taking care of themselves (FH; 04/25/95; PM/pc:ok).

ohkíhce (variant: ohkíhci). N tribe other than Osage (including western tribes), "off-tribe" (FH/09/22/01/pc; FH/09/25/01/prod). tówa ðe táatà ohkíhce? what tribe is he? kóota ìkçé ohkíhce hôòxce ðìkçé? that one sitting over there, what kind of tribe is he? (03/23/95/FH/pc). • enemy, stranger.

•• RB: <o-kí-tseh, o-kí-tsi>.

óhkihkaçe (variant: óhkihkaçà?). V [reg., ó_hkihkaçe] [hkik- REFL + okáçe] (intr.) take care of oneself. oáhkihkaçà hpímà, htáaëì akxa waðílà hkihkáaãape I know how to take care of myself, the little deer thought (lit., 'taking care of myself I am skilled at, the little deer made up his own mind') (RBn15002).

ohkíhkie. V [reg., o_hkíhkie] [hkik- RECIP + ohkíe] talk with one another, converse with each other (usually more than two people). àkóhkihkie htái let's talk to each other (03/05/95/JS/pc:okc).

•• LFD 172: ohkíhkie <u-Ði´-Ði-e> a dialogue. ohkíhkie <u-Ði´-Ði-e> to speak to one another, to hold a conversation.

ohkíhpa che. NP [presumably ó- LOC + áhkihpa + che] council (lit., 'wherein they meet each other'). [Includes 'standing' positional article che.] níhka ëúuce hcéka nò ohkíhpa che apa hàðé waachí hta apai Indian Youth Council are having a dance tonight (RBn23-14). 

óhkihpaache (variant: hóhkihpaache) N [hkik- RECIP + ópaache] man's blanket (lit., 'sew [to] each other') (01/07/95/FH/pc). [Refers to the seam in the center of the man's red and blue blanket.]

••• QU okkippathe sewed together (RR).

••• Cf. óhkiache. 

ohkíicheðe (variant: ohkícheðe). V [reg., ohkíiche_ðe] [ó- LOC + hkícheðe] (trans.) put down, set down, place. aðîku, kaðó ohkíche[ð]e bring it here and put it down (RBn10-21/JW; FW/77). káa ohkíche[ð]e put it here (RBn10-21/JW; FW/77). çeðó ohkíchi[ð]e put it over there (RBn10-21/JW; FW/77).
