ohkíkØòhe. V [reg.?, o_hkíkØòhe?] [hkik- REFL + okØôhe] (intr.?) interrupt (lit., 'insert oneself into'). óhkikØôhe he's interrupting.

ohkíkØu. V [reg.?, o_hkíkØu] [hkik- RECIP + ókØu] (intr.) give away to each other, have a giveaway. [Giving away is a custom at the annual Osage dances, especially on Sunday, when blankets, shawls, groceries, cash, and other items are given to others in appreciation.] ohkíkØu hta apai hôòpa ðé they're going to give away today (FH/09/21/01/pc).  

óhkila, óhkilà (variants of ohkúlà).

ohkílaake. V [reg., o_hkílaake] [hkik- REFL + óðaake] (intr.) tell about oneself, speak of oneself (RBn 3/3/77; FH/09/11/01/pc okc). ohkílaaka ði! tell about yourself! (RBn10-6:JW).

•• LFD 171: ohkílake <u-Ði´-gtha-ge> to speak of oneself. owahkilake <u-wa-Ði-gtha-ge> I spoke of myself. owáhkilake <u-wa´-Ði-gtha-ge> [sic; expected Mod. Os. form: oðáhkilaake] you spoke of yourself. àkohkílaka pe <oæ-gu-Ði´-gtha-ga i> we spoke of ourselves.

óhkioolâ (variants: óhkulà, óhkilà, ohkílà). V [conjug. unknown, presumably reg.+reg., ó_hkioo_lâ] [ó- LOC + hkik- REFL + oolâ] (trans.) put on oneself or dress in (e.g., a shirt or a dress). haaská ohkílà put the dress on (RBn12-05). haaská wasúhu wî ohkúlà put on a clean shirt (RBn12-08). • (intr.) dress oneself, put on clothes.

•• RB: <hó-kyu-lah> (04/07/95/LS/pc:okt; BE2.33).

••• Cf. ohkúlà. 

ohkíòðe (variant: ohkúìðe). V [reg.+sync., o_hkíò_ðe] [ó- LOC + hkik- REFL + ôòðe] [secondary accent on ôðe] (trans.) throw oneself into, jump into, get tangled in, fall into. hkáwa apa mâze ohkíòðe apái the horses are tangled up in the wire (RBnot-nd-1/p18; FH:ok). • (intr.?) be in trouble for doing s.t. wrong (04/03/95/PM/pc:ok). ohkíòðe nìkçé you're in trouble (BE2.144). ohkåìðe mìkçé I'm in trouble (BE2.144). oðáhkiòçce nìkçé you sure got into trouble. • V, ADJ (intr.) (be) divorced, separated. ohkíòðe mìkçe she divorced me, quit me, let me go (04/03/95/PM/pc). ohkíòðe nìkçé she quit you (04/03/95/PM/pc). • V (intr.) throw each other away , throw each other away, quit or abandon each other (PM). Johna éeðòòpa àhkíòðe hta àðìhé I'm divorcing John (lit., 'John and I are going to throw each other away').

•• LFD 172: ohkíòðe <u-Ði´-oæ-the> to throw themselves into, to become insnared (04/03/95/PM/pc:ok).

••• Cf. éwahkiôðe, hkíòðe. ohkísce. N half (of anything), half dollar (01/04/95/FH/pc; BE2.63; RB).

•• RB: <o-kí-steh>.

•• LFD 172: ohkísce <u-Ði´-stse> half; 50 cents.

ohkíëì. V [reg., o_hkíëì] [presumably ó- LOC + hkíëì] (intr., trans.) be angry, be mad. oáhkiëì, awáhkiëì I'm angry. oðáhkiëì you're angry. àkóhkiëì we're angry. awáhkiëì mìkçé I'm mad at him (MSB 03-83).

••• Cf. ihkíëì. 

ohkôska (variant of ohkâska).

ohkåche (variant of óhkiache).

ohkúìðe (variant of ohkíòðe).

ohkúlà (variants: ohkílà, óhkilà óhkila, ohkúla). N [hkik- REFL + oolâ] clothes (lit., 'that which one puts oneself into') (FH: 01/Aug/01). [óhkilà is same as wéhkilì (EH)] óhkilà táapuze akxai the clothes are drying. ohkúlà weeáhkie màëí I can't find my clothes [for myself]. ohkúlà wasú I washed my clothes (FH/01/03/01/pc). waëá ohkílà Osage clothes.

••• QU ókkíkdaxda shirt (RR).

••• Cf. óhkioolâ. 

óhkulà (variant of óhkioolâ). ohláaëi (variant of oolâàëi).

ohlé (variant of olé).

óhoo. V [conjug. unknown] [probably ó- LOC + hóo] (intr.) bark, woof (as a dog does). hâàce çôke wíhta akxa wáli óhoope my dog sure barked last night (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.6). çòke apa óhoo apái ðe the dogs are barking (01/04/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 171: óhoho <u´-hu-hu> the bark or yelp of a dog. (03/01/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 171).

ohpáza. V [stat., o_hpáza (but 1st dual/pl. has reg. prefix àk-, not stat. wa-)] (intr.) be startled (as by a dream or nightmare). àwâhpaza I was startled. oðíhpaza you were startled. ohpáza she was startled. àkóhpaza we were startled. hôbre ohpáza akxai a dream startled him (he had a nightmare). hôbre àkóhpaza àkátxai we have nightmares. hôbre oðíhpazái? did you have a nightmare? (lit., 'dreaming, did it startle you?'). • N nightmare, bad dream. ohpáza che a nightmare. hôbre ohpázà che àkatxâe we had a nightmare (lit., 'dreaming, we had a nightmare').

ohpé (variants: óhpe, ohpéwì). V [reg., o_hpé] (trans.) enter or go in/into, enter formally (as into a peyote meeting) (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). haakxâta hci oðáhpe? when are you going in the house? (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). mîìhiðe tà oðáhpe you went in at sundown (RBn12-12; CQc). okahâàpa cí ecíha óhpepi áape the house has been broken into (lit., 'it was through the window that the house had been entered, they said') (05/01/95/FH/pc). tówa apa háachi hci ohpéwì kôða apai those ones [dogs] keep wanting to come inside the house. mîìhiðe tà àkóhpe we're going in at sundown (RBn12-12).

•• LFD 175: ohpé <u-¼e´> to enter. owáhpe <u-wa´-¼e> I enter. oðáhpe <u-tha´-¼e> you enter. àkóhpa pe <oæ-gu´-¼a i> we enter.  

óhtaiðìke. ADV safely (RB, unconfirmed). óhtaiðìke alí hkôbra I want to return safely.

•• LFD 175: ohtáðì <u-¾a´-thiæ> to spread fame; refers to the courage of warriors.

ohtáza. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) good looking, handsome, beautiful, very pretty. çe ëâàëì akxa ohtáza akxái the little tree is pretty (1/1/83/30/MSB). ohtáza nààëî Stands There Beautiful (personal name) [Joyce Stabler's name] (BE2.59).

•• LFD 175: ohtáza <u-¾a´-ša> handsome. ohtáza walì <u-¾a´-ša wa-gthiæ> it is very pretty, showy; stateliness; pretty; comely; pleasing to the sight.

ohtázaëi. ADJ [ohtáza + aëí] ugly, homely, not pretty or handsome (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 175: ohtázaëi <u-¾a´-ša-zhi> homely; homeliness; ugly.

ohtânà (variant: ohtâna). N, PPN between, in between, the space between things (FH).

••• KS ottánà space between two things (RR).

••• Cf. oëâke ohtâna. óhuheka. N sickness. óhuheka óhesaëi wì àhkíôðe we've come upon a bad sickness (02/01/95/FH/pc:prod orig; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).

óie (variant: óØie). V [conjug. unknown] [ó- + íe] (intr.) discuss, talk about s.t. positively or negatively; worry about or question s.t. verbally, as in a business meeting (4/17/96/sideB,FH). [The locative prefix ó- has recently been added to íe, so that speakers may still sense a boundary between ó- and íe; hence the occasionally (but rarely) heard variant óØie.] óØie àkái we're discussing it (FH:prod). óØie çtà he causes a lot of talk about everything; he brings up any little thing (FH:prod). óie apai they're worrying/questioning. • N argument, problem. [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] óØie che kaçôe hce [let's] leave the problem alone (04/26/95/FH/pc).

••• Cf. áhkie, íkie, ohkíe, ohkíhkie. 

oísi (variant of wísi).

ókaaãeìke (variant: ókaaãéìke), ADJ, V [ó- LOC + káaãe + ðìké NEG] (be) idle, useless, with nothing to it, meaningless (lit., 'wherein nothing is done') (RBn HW8). okaaãéìke! it's idle [gossip], there's nothing to it! íe ókaaãeìki akxai his talk is useless, there's nothing to it (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok; 02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.148). ókaaãeìke ëáëe aðîpe "Useless" was his name (RBn10-2:MOJ/79).

•• LFD 120: ókaãe ðìke <o´-ga-xe thiæ-ge> value-nothing, valueless. LFD 168: ókaãe ðìke <u´ga-xe thiæ-ge> nonsense, absurd; meaningless; immaterial; a useless person.

••• Cf. hâàpa ókaaãéìke. 

 okábra. V [uninfl.?] (trans.) disperse a group, scatter (e.g., corn for drying), spread around. (03/01/95/FH/pc); (intr.) go away, depart, scatter, disband, leave (e.g., a crowd leaving after a dance or other public gathering). àkábra htai let's scatter [unexpected form, omits o-] (RBn HW). okábra káaãa akxai they are all leaving now (RBn10-7:JW). okábra káaãape they have already gone (lit., 'they have caused them to scatter') (RBn10-7:JW).

•• LFD 120: okáe bra <o-ga´-e btha> to disperse. LFD 167: okáebra <u-ga´-e-btha> to scatter; to disband; to scatter in every direction. okáebra hpaãe <u-ga´-e-btha ¼a-xe> I made them scatter. okáebra çkaãe <u-ga´-e-btha shka-xe> you made them scatter. okáebra àkaãa pe <u-ga´-e-btha oæ- ga-xa i> we made them scatter. LFD 28: bràðálì okábrà <bthoætha´-gthiæ u-ga-bthoæ> redolence (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).  

okácØì. V [reg., o_kácØì] (trans.) peer in or into; peep into (03/01/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 168: okácØì <u-ga´-¾s'iæ> to peep; stealthily look into the crack of a door or window. htíëepeche oðakáhcì <¾i´-zhe-be-te u-tha-ga´-¾siæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: hciëépe che oðákacØì] you peeped in the door.

••• Cf. niióhkiacØì. 

okáhàpa (variants: okáhààpa, okáhòpa). N [ó- LOC + kaa- INSTR + hâàpa] window; pane of glass, window glass (lit., 'place where by sudden action daylight'). okáhòpa áðihtà close the window (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc: short final a/à). okáhàpa záani ðuuáza open [all] the window[s] (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc; RBn1-52; BE2.159). çîhtoëì apa okáhàpa kaalékape the boys broke the window (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). okáhàpa kaaléke che ðe someone broke a window, that's the way it is (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; LS: ok). okáhàpa wahósce a small window (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc).

•• LFD 168: okáhàpa <u-ga´-hoæ-ba> a window glass, pane of glass. çìhto ëìka apa oká hàpa kale ka pi <shiæ-¾u zhiæ-ga a-ba u-ga´ hoæ-ba ga-xthe ga bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form: çîtoëì apa okáhàpe kaalékape] the boy broke the pane of glass. okáhàpa wahósca <u-ga´-hoæ-ba wa-ho-stsa> a small pane of glass for a window.

okáhàpa akáspe. N window shade (RBn HW11). okáhàpa akáspe ðuumâçi raise the window shade.

okáhòpa (variant of okáhàpa).

ókahpo. ADJ, ADV sick from eating too much (BE2.121; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok) [ókahpo, ókohpa, and okúhpu have similar meanings and may have partially influenced each other in form. ókahpo and ókohpa possibly contain wa- VAL (wa- + o- > ó-).]

okákØò. V [conjug. unknown, presumably reg. ka-del., o_(ká)kØò] (intr.) make a hole. okákØòapía [expected Mod. Os. form: okákØòpe] they broke a hole in it (RBn10-19).

okále. V (trans.) face a certain direction. kóota okála! face the other way! (RBn19-02).

•• LFD 265: ehtá okale <e-¾a´ u-ga-xthe> facing. hkímòhò okale <Ði´-moæ-hoæ u-ga-xthe> [expected Mod. Os. form: hkímàhà okále] facing (the wind).

okáçà (variant: okáça). V [reg., o_káçà] (trans.) take care of or handle s.t. specific for s.o., take charge of, undertake, supervise or have the responsibility for s.t. specific in response to a formal request (e.g., taking care of the food for an event) (RBn22-15;04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). owíkaçà hta mìkçé I'll take care of you (MSB,t9a). owákaçà mìkçé I'm taking care of it for somebody. çôke wíhta akxa hkáwa, hceeská éðòòpa owákaça nàpé my dog takes care of horses and cows (RBn12-03). hcéska okáça apai he's taking care of the cattle [for someone else] (FH/09/24/01/pc/prod). htáa okáça take care of the meat (includes cutting it up for different dishes, cooking the ribs outside, activities mostly performed by men, with women slicing the meat for meat gravy) (FH/09/23/01/pc). ëìkókaça taking care of kids (RBn10-6:JW). xuðókaça takes care of the eagle (personal name) [xúða+ okáçàa] (RBn22-04). çôke wíhta akxa hkáwa, hceeská éðòòpa owákaça nàpé my dog takes care of horses and cows (RBn12-03). • (intr.) go on an errand, set out on or undertake a new task under one's charge (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok). oðákaçà çcee? are you going on an errand? (03/01/95/FH/pc). àwâkaçà àká[ð[ape [àwâkaçà not the expected form] we're going on an errand (03/01/95/FH/pc). àkókaçà àká[ð]ape we're going on an errand (03/01/95/FH/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): okáçà <u-§ka´-caæ> to travel.

•• LFD 168 (unconfirmed): okáçà <u-ga´-shoæ> going forth on an errand. okáçà bre ha <u-ga´shoæ bthe ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I am going on an errand (unconfirmed;

03/01/95/FH/pc:no). okáçà çte a? <u-ga´-shoæ shde a?> are you going on an errand? okáçà àkaða pe <u-ga´-shoæ oæ-ga-tha i> we are going on an errand (03/01/95/FH/pc:no).

••• Cf. okáçe.

ókaçà. V [reg., ó_kaçà] [wa- VAL + okáçà] (intr.) take charge of things in general for another. ókaçape nà ðe ánààëì màbrî çki tà even when I get there (go and stand up there), he always takes charge of things (RB; trans by CQ). ëìkáëì áwakaçâ hta mìkçé I'll take care of the kids (lit., 'as for the children, I'll take care of things') (MSBt9a;RB:MSB/02/17/83;CQc).

okáçe (variant: okáçi). V [reg., o_káçe] (trans.) take care of, see to (especially a person). okáçi apai he's taking care of him/her (RB:MSB/02/17/83). owíkaçe hta mìkçé I'll take care of you (RB:MSB/02/17/83).

••• Cf. óhkihkaçe, okáçà. 

ókaçe. V [uninfl.] (intr.) be suffering a period of illness, be troubled, distracted, or impeded by problems or sickness (MREI). ókaçe akxa he's sick (RBn1-40). ókaçe akxái she or he is sick or is not feeling very well (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). oðíhtà ókaçe apai his car is holding him back (lit., 'with regard to his car, things are troubling him'). Preston akxa çáake ókaçí akxa Preston's hands are causing him trouble (lit., 'Preston is suffering with his hands') (05/06/94; MREI:ma). • N spell of illness or trouble of any kind (MREI). [The period of illness is ókaçe, while the illness itself is húheka (02/13/95/FH/pc).]

•• LFD 120: ókaçe <o´-ga-she> obstacles in the path of life, such as disease and accidents which interfere with the enjoyment of life and health (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 168: ókaçe <u´-ga-she> ailment, not well.

ókaçéìke (variant: ókaçéìki). ADJ, ADV [ókaçe 'be ill, troubled' + ðìké NEG] untroubled, nothing wrong, well, in good health, free from worry or illness, safely, okay, all right (BE2.59; 02/01/95/FH/pc:okc),

•• LFD 120: ókaçe ðìké <o´-ga-she thiæ-ge> hearty; no interference in the enjoyment of good health; hale (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok:well). LFD 168: ókaçe ðìke <u´-ga-she thiæ-ge> well; healthy; no interruption to the enjoyment of good health. ókaçe àðìke mìkçe o <u´-ga-she oæ-thiæ-ge miæ-kshe o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I am well. ó kaçe ðiðìke nikçe a(?) <u´ ga-she thi-thiæge ni-kshe a(?)> are you well(?) [No conjugated forms attested in Mod. Os.] okáçi (variant of okáçe).

okáçke. V [reg., ka-ret., o_káçke] [ó- LOC + kaçké] (trans.) tie (e.g., shoelaces), tie up (e.g., a dog or a horse). hòòpé okáçke tying shoes (FH:prod). hòòpé oðákaçke tie my shoe (lit., 'you tie the shoe') (03/22/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 168: okáçke <u-ga´-shke> to tie or tether a horse or any other animal.

••• Cf. oðáçke, wapíokaçke. 

ókawai. ADJ sickly (RBn22-09).

••• Cf. ókaçe. 

okáwìãe. ADV around.

 ••• Cf. ákiãe, hkilíihkòìãe, hòòpé okáwìãe, opáwìãe.

okáxpa. N Quapaw Indians (BE2.110; 03/08/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 168: okáxpa kaxa <U-ga´-xpa ga-xa> Quapaw Creek; Quapaw, Okla.

okáxpa. V [reg., o_káxpa] (trans.) throw off (suddenly severing or moving s.t. or s.o. from s.t.). paaxó citxa oákaxpai I threw him off the hill (RBn19-02). paaxó kçitxa okáxpape he threw him off the hill (RBn19-02). hkáwa ówakaxpa áape he said the horse threw him off (RBn19-01). hkáwa apa okaxpápe he got thrown off the horse (lit., 'the horse threw him') (RBn19-01). paaxó ìkçítxa àkókaxpai we threw him off the hill (RBn19-02).

okáxta (variant: okáxtà). V [reg. kaa-del.?, o_(ká)xta] (trans.) pour or dump out (e.g., garbage) (RBn; HW12).

•• LFD 309: ní káxtà <ni´-ga´xtoæ> pour [water]. ni áxtà <ni´ a-xtoæ> I pour water. wakáxtà <wa-ga´-xtoæ> pour.  

okíce (variant: okíci). V [reg. ki-ret., o_kíce] [kik- SUU + océ (but with unexpected c rather than hc)] (trans.) look for or search for s.t. or s.o. lost or misplaced (often s.t. or s.o. belonging to oneself) (FH). ówakice look for them. ðíe okíca look for it yourself (FH:4/25/96/tape:prod; 02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). Mary apa iiëîke óxpaðe apa ná háaçki okíci apái Mary's son is lost and she's looking everywhere for him (03/23/95/FH/pc). ákahaamì okíca look for your shawl (BE2.117).

•• JOD (slip file): okíce <u-§kí-¦t¦se> to hunt, seek, or search for his own.

••• QU okíhte to look for one's own (RR); OM ogine look for one's own (RR).

okíce. V [conjug. unknown] [ki- DAT + océ] look for or search for s.t. or s.o. for another. [Possibly reg. ki-del. conjugation, but there are no examples available.]

okíhkà. V [reg. ki-ret., o_kíhkà] [kik- SUU + óhkà] (trans., intr.) help one's own (relative). [Uninflected form is homophonous with dative form of this verb.] waëáëeíe àwáðakihkà hkôbra I want you to help me talk Osage (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; FH:4/25/96/tape; RBn10-5:JW). okíhkàpái you all help him [a relative] out [and continue to do so] (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc). táatà owâðakihkà hkôbra I want you to help me with something (RBn22-02).

okíhkà. V [reg., o_kíhkà] [ [ki- DAT + ohkà] (trans.) help another (who is not a relative). [Uninflected form is homophonous with suus form of this verb.] okíhkàpái you all help him [not a relative] out [and continue to do so] (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc).  

okíhkie. V [reg., o_kíhkie] [kik- SUU + ohkíe] (trans., intr.) speak to one's own relative, family, or friends.

•• LFD 169: okíhkie <u-gi´-Ði-e> to speak [definition should include 'to a relative']. owákihkie <u-wa´-gi-Ði-e> I spoke to a relative. oðákihkie <u-tha´-gi-Ði-e> you spoke to a relative. àkókihkia pe <oæ-gu´-gi-Ði-a i> we spoke to relatives; to speak to a friend or some relation.

okíkxà (variant of okítxà).

okínààëì. V [reg. (ki-ret.?), o_kínààëì] [ki- DAT + onâàëì] (trans.) follow (lit., 'stand next to another'). • ADJ successive, following.

•• LFD 169 (unconfirmed): okínàëì <u-gi´-noæ-zhiæ> to succeed (05/02/95/LS/pc:uk). owákinàëì <u-wa´-gi-noæ-zhiæ> I succeed. oðákinàëì <u-tha´-gi-noæ-zhiæ> you succeed. àkókínàëì pe <oægu´-gi´-noæ-zhiæ i> we succeed; to stand in the place of; to follow in order.

okípçe. V [reg. ki-ret., o_kípçe] [kik- SUU + opçé] (trans.) follow one's own, be true to one's own, obey one's own. íe owákipçe I have followed their [my parents'] word. íe àkókipçe hta àkáðe we will keep our word.

••• Cf. íe okípçe. 

okítxà (variant: okíkxà). V [reg. (ki-ret.?), o_kítxà] [kik- SUU + otxâ] (trans.) put on one's own pants or shoes. oðíkinààëi okíkxà put on your pants (RBn10-12:JW).

ókohpa. V [conjug. unknown] (intr., trans.) vomit, regurgitate, or throw up due to overeating or being too full (PM/pc; 04/26/95/FH/pc:ok). [Possibly based on a borrowed word and partially influenced in form by the semantically similar word okúhpu.]

••• Cf. ókahpo.  

okçéhtà. V [reg., o_kçéhtà] (trans.) gain, earn, come into possession of, obtain. • N salary, earnings, gain, winnings.

•• LFD 272: okçéhtà <u-kshe´-¾oæ> gain. LFD 173: okçétà <u-kshe´-¾oæ> wages, pay, salary, compensation, earnings, income. okçéhtà <u-kshe´-¾oæ> to obtain, come into possession of, win, gain, earn.

okúhpu (variants: okühpü, ókuhpi, okúhpe). V, ADJ [stat., o_kúhpu] (trans.) (be) full of, have a fullness of, be filled with (as the stomach is full; said of a person); be full, be flooded (e.g., a creek filled to capacity). ììçtá níi àwâkuhpe my eyes are full of tears (FH/09/21/01/pc). ììçtá níi oðíkuhpe your eyes are full of tears (FH/09/21/01/pc). kaxé akxa okúhpu akxai the creek is full (flooded) (RB; 04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; FH/09/21/01/pc:ok). • N full amount; houseful (LS; RBN1-29). okúhpu kaaãé fill it up (lit., 'make it the full amount') (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). okúhpu àwâëu fill it up for me (lit., 'pour the full amount for me') (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc; BE2.51).

•• RB: <o-kyú-pu>.

•• LFD 170: okíhpi <u-gi´-¼i> full, will contain no more, replete. LFD 77: ìçtá ni àwàkihpi <iæshta´ ni oæ-woæ-gi-¼i> my eyes are full of water.

••• KS ogíppi full, filled (RR); OM same as Osage (LFD 170).

••• Cf. ókahpo, ókohpa. 

ókxaëi (variant of ókxàëi).

okxâ (variant: otkxâ). PRON, ADJ [ó- LOC + txà] next, following, the following one (01/11/95/FH/pc).

••• KS owákhà next of kin (RR), owákkihâhe succession of, one after another, descendants (RR).

okxâ (variant of otxâ).

ókxàkxà (variant of ótxàtxà).

ókxàëi (variants: ókxaëi, ótkxàëi). V, ADJ [otxâ + aëí] [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) slow, slow about catching up, always late, never on time (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok:tk). hpáze wanôbre ónòbre ðúwì ókxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (03/10/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.123). hpáze wanôbre ówe brúwì ótkxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

ókØà (variant: okØâ). V [uninfl.] (intr.) put on a program, hold an event, have a "doings" (FH:prod). ókØà hta apa they're going to have a program. ókØà hta àkai tà háachi niiëú nà àpai when we're going to have something, it always rains. ókØà àkôða tà háachi niiëú nàpe whenever we want to have something, it always rains (FH). • (trans.) act like. ììçtáxì ókØà akxai he's acting like a white man (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). • N act, deed, ways, custom, personality, personal characteristics (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ókØà tàhe he has good ways (FH:prod). ókØà ðáalì good ways, cheerful, easy to get along with (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ókØà hpíiëi bad ways, bad tempered, hard to get along with (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc). cØéka ókØà ée ìká don't try any funny stuff, don't act the fool. Ed apa ókØà ðáalìpe Ed has good ways (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.152). waëáëe okØâ oxpáðape Osage ways are all gone (lit., 'Osage ways got lost') (05/01/95/LS/pc).

•• LFD 121: ókØà <o´-Ð'oæ> habit, a tendency to follow certain inclinations continuously. ókØà ðálì pia <o´Ð'oæ tha´-gthiæ bia> [pia unconfirmed (FH: pe, not pia)] he has good manners. LFD 172: ókØà <u´-Ð'oæ> custom, rite, ceremony. ókØà tàhe <u´-Ð'oæ doæ-he> kindly disposition.  

ókØà axópe. N , VP (trans.) respect (lit., 'honor by acts') (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). [Position of accent recorded as different from áxope 'honor'.]

•• LFD 172: ókØà axope <u´-Ð'oæ a-xo-be> proper respect for things sacred.

ókØà ðaalì. ADJP likable; having good ways, manners, and thoughts; cheerful. ókØà ðáalì hkí[ð]a have good ways (FH:prod). • NP good manners, good thoughts.

•• LFD 172: ókØàðalì <u´-Ð'oæ-tha-gthiæ> meek, lovable, a likable disposition.

ókØà ekôëi. ADJP, ADVP, N wrongful, wrongly, inappropriate, inappropriate action (FH:6/25/01/pc:ok; LR:pc/ok).

•• LFD 173: okØà ekòëi <u-Ð'oæ e-goæ-zhi> wrongful, wrongly. Any act that is contrary or does not conform to custom.

ókØà éëi. VP [conjug. unknown] be wrongheaded, act unsuitably. ókØò éëi ðíepe he's confused (FH/09/24/01/pc/prod). • N wrongful acts or bad deeds (such as bad talk or theft).

ókØà hpíiëi. ADJP having bad manners or ways, ill-mannered (lit., 'bad ways'), unruly (FH; BE2.27); cross, high-tempered, cranky, having a bad disposition, sullen, morose.

•• LFD 173: ókØàhpiëi <u´-Ð'oæ-¼i-zhi> cruel, wicked, unruly, person with a bad disposition, sullen, morose.

ókØà wanàðaëi. N perplexity. [Unconfirmed; possibly an Omaha expression, not Osage.]

•• LFD 121: ókØà wanàða ëi <o´-Ð'oæ wa-noæ-tha zhi> perplexity, bewilderment (01/06/95/FH/pc:uk; FH:6/25/01/pc, no, LR; no).

ókØàçtà. N [ókØà + çtà] busybody (refers to s.o. who is into everything).

okØó (variant: okØóce). N [ó- LOC + kØó] hole. sîìce okØó ce oolâà put your tail in the hole (RBn16-02). céãenii okØóce akxa the drum has a hole in it (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). céãenii okØóce ahí akxa the drum has a hole in it (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok).

okØôhe. V [reg.?, o_kØôhe?] [ó- LOC + kØôhe] (trans.) insert, put into, sheathe, place into, put. [Implies 'lifting up and putting in', as a baby into a crib or onto a baby board or blankets into a box (FH).] hpáaëì okØôha put the baby on the board (RBn2-MOJ/p30; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 173: okØôhe <u-Ð'oæ´-he> to sheathe, to place in a scabbard. LFD 179: oðókØòhe <uthu´-Ð'oæ-he> to put a horizontal object into a receptacle for another person [not 'for another person']. LFD 66: hânàhpaze okØòhe <hoæ´-noæ-¼a-še u-Ð'oæ-he> to imprison, imprisonment, to place in confinement (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

okØú. V [reg., o_kØú] [apparently ó- LOC + kØú] (trans.) lend. mâzeska tóe àwákØu lend me some money (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.78). hcíoka wì ðáalì ówakØupe they lent us a nice room (RBn23-14). waléze toa àwâðakØu na these are the books that you loaned me (MSB/ 2/10/83). áwakØu I loaned it to them; I fed them (MSB 2-25-83). • give, provide, furnish, supply.

•• LFD 171: okØí <u-Ð'i´> to lend. owákØi <u-wa´-Ð'i> I lend. oðákØi <u-tha´-Ð'i> you lend. àkókØi pe <oæ-gu´-Ð'i i> we lend. màhì spe wihta hpisi owakØi <moæ-hiæ špe wi-¾a ¼i-ši u-wa-Ð'i> I loaned my ax to Pi-ši. [Vowel i rather than u in this stem (okØí, etc., seen in LF's examples) is unacceptable to Mod. Os. speakers.]

ókØu. V [reg. ó_kØu] [wa- VAL + okØú] (trans.) give, provide, furnish, give stuff to s.o. ókØupe it was given (lit., 'they gave it to some folks'; with a nonspecific actor on an active verb in Mod. Os., the gloss is often English passive). ówakØupe it was given to us (lit., 'they gave some things to us').

• feed. hkáwa owákØu I fed the horse (01/24/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.46; 01/24/95/FH/pc:prod). çôke ókØu màðî go feed the dog (RB). waxpéì àkái, ókØu àðúucØake çe nààhtàhtàà oðúucØake wî we're too poor to feed that lazy donkey (RBn10-2:MJ/79). áwakØu I fed them (2-25-83). • N giving, giveaway, event of giving or giving away.

oláha (variant of oðáha).

ólaëi (variant of óðàëi).

ólà (variants: óolà, olôò, ódla [rare]). ADJ, V [reg., ó_là] [ó- LOC + lâ] pout, sulk; sulky. owálà mìkçé I'm pouting (MSB 03/83; 04/18/95/FH/pc:OK?). óðalà nìkçé you're pouting (MSB).

olé (variant: ohlé). V [reg., o_lé] (trans.) chase, chase away, run off. cØáiëi, wakØóëì apa olé apai the old man and old woman chased him (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). owále I ran him off, chased him away (BE2.18; CQc 'them' changed to 'him').

•• RB: <o-hléh> (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 182: olé <u-xthe´> to overtake. oðále <u-tha´-xthe> you overtake.

olîì. V [reg., o_lîì] [ó- LOC + lîì] (trans.) sit in, occupy (a seat), be seated on, sit down on, take a seat on. hówaìki oálìì çkôçta? where do you want me to sit? (RBn10-4:MOJ/79). howáìki oðálìì çkôçta? where do you want to sit? (02/16/95/FH/pc:prod orig). háçi olîì sit in the back, sit in a certain place, as at a peyote meeting (03/10/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.119; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok). • ride, ride in. oðíhtà ëúuce ëî ðiitâ owálìì hkôbrai I want to ride in your little red wagon (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). oðíhtà olîì ride in a car (RBn19-01). oðíhtà olîì hta apái they're going in a car (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). pacíolìì àkái hta àkái [pacé olîì àkáðe hta àkáðe] we are going boating (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.9). •live in or at,  dwell in, inhabit, live within metaphorically (e.g., a person's heart). túlsa htâwà owálìì I live in Tulsa (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc). howáìki oðálìì? where do you live? (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc). níi ëópçe pçíe ðáha, táatà wî màëâ olîì iiðáðe when I would go to wade in the river, I saw something that was in the woods (lit., 'when I went to wade in the water, I saw a thing that lived in the countryside') (t24bp17/num4CQ119; 04/27/95/FH/pc:okc, added iiðáðe). ðâàce oâlìì he lives within my heart (04/04/99/FH/pc). howáìki olîì? where does he live? (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 170: ólì <u´-gthiæ> to occupy a seat.

••• Cf. álìì. 

olôò (variant of ólà).

ómahka (variant of ómàhka). omáìhka (variant of omâìhka).

omâðì (variants: omâì, omêì). V [ reg.+sync. o_mâ_ðì] [ó- LOC + màðî] (intr.) live. oámabrì I live. oðámàçcì you live.  kaahúuëà mâëà ðéka omâìpe he lived on this earth a long time (RBn10-13:JW). kaahúuëà mâëà ðéka omâì apai he lived on this earth a long time ago (RBn10-13:FH). wéewina môëò ðé çkaçkáða oámàbrì I want to thank you for this good life [that I live] (RBn10-10:JW). • (trans.) walk in, be in, among, or throughout an area or a group of people. oëâke omâðì apai they're walking in the road (RBn 5/3/79; corrected; FH:5/01/96/tape:prod). • (intr.) be active within (as a substance within a body). çée mìkçé, wanôbre akxa oméì mìkçé I'm just sitting there, that peyote is working in me (RBn10-6:JW; CQc). omâði apa (PM: it's [that whiskey is] in him, he's got a little in him [equivalent to 'he's drunk', describing a state equally as drunk as lòðì]).  

••• Cf. omâìëì, taaké omâðì. 

ómàðì. V [reg.+sync., ó_mà_ðì] [wa- VAL + omâðì] (intr.) walk among folks, live among others.

omâhà. N, ADJ Omaha (tribe or tribal member) (BE2.9; 03/08/95/PM/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): omâhà <U-maæ´-haæ> an Omaha, the Omaha.

•• LFD 300, 173: omâhà <U-moæ´-hoæ> Omaha, Nebr., the Osage name for Omaha (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• KS òmôhò Omaha tribe, those who went upstream (RR).

ómàhka (variant: ómahka). ADJ easy, cheap, inexpensive (RB; 12/30/94/FH/pc). ómahka apa ahå apái cheap things are coming (FH). haxì ómàhka káaãi akxai he made the blankets cheap in value (RBn22-17; BE2.38). ómàhka xcî it's easy (RBn10-18). táatà ómahkà ecíepe éetana ostówe aðíi apai a whole line of people are running because there's something cheap [aðíi from aðée] (FHt128).

•• LFD 174: ómàhka <u´-moæ-Ða> easy, not difficult.

omâì (variant of omâðì).

omâìhka (variant: omáìhka). N year. omâìhka hcéka new year (HH/14-A/308; 03/24/95/PM/pc:prod; BE2.162; FH/09/24/01/pc:hk).

•• LFD 173: omâìhka <u-moæ´-iæ-Ða> a year (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). omâìhka wì <u-moæ´-iæ-Ða wiæ> one year. omâìhka satxà <u-moæ´-iæ-Ða ša-toæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: omâìhka sáhtà; <ša-toæ> is an error for <ša-¾oæ>, Mod. Os. sáhtà] five years.

omâìhka háanà (variant: omáìhka háanà). INTERR/INDEF NP how old? omáìhka háanà nìkçé? how old are you? (RBn2-MOJ/p40; 03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). omâìhka háanà ðaaçé? how old are you? (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

omâìhka hcéka (variant: omáìhka hcéka). N January (HH/14-a/249ff); new year.

omâìhka lébrà híenà. N decade (LF).

•• LFD 173: omâihka lebrà hienà <u-moæ´-i-Ða gthe-bthoæ hie-noæ> a period of ten years.

omâìhka wì hienà. ADVP annually (lit., 'one year arrives').

•• LFD 174 (unconfirmed): omâìhka wì hienà <u-moæ´-iæ-Ða wiæ hi e-noæ> yearly.

omâìëì. V, ADJ [uninfl.] [omâðì + -ëì 'little'] (intr.) (be) very active within (as a substance is active within a person's body, such as when alcohol causes drunkenness) (01/20/95/PM/pc). [Said to be synonymous with lôðì.]

•• RB: <o-máh-iæ-zhiæ>.

omêì (variant of omâðì).

omíëe (variant: omîëe). N blanket, quilt, bedclothes, bedding; rug, carpet (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2MOJ/p3; RBn2-02). [Takes 'sitting' positional article îkçé.] omíëe aðúsu cover her with a blanket (01/07/95/FH/pc:ma; 04/07/95/PM/pc:uk; 04/07/95/LS/pc:uk,ma; BE2.9). omíëe àkçixa fix my bedclothes (RBn12-08). ëìkáëi apa taaðúhpiiëipe, omíëe ðuhpíiëipi ìkçe children are destructive, they have ruined the rug (lit., 'children are destructive, the rug is sitting there ruined') (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.30; 04/07/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.9). • mattress, pallet (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 173: omíëe <U-mi´-zhe> Bedding (personal name), refers to the buffalo hide used for bedding <u-mi´-zhe> mattress, bedding, pallet, carpet.

onáaëi (variant of onâàëì).

ónalì (variants: ónaxlì [rare, archaic], ónàle, ónahlì). V [conjug. unknown] hurry up! (FH). [Historically ónàxðì; Proto-Siouan *xð > hl > l in Osage.] ónalìpi, mîìðohta ahíe akxái hurry up you all, it's time (02/13/95/FH/t141/pc:prod orig). ónalìpi, pá húðe ðààchí akxái hurry up you all, it's about to snow (02/13/95/FH/pc:prod orig; FH:4/25/96/tape; BE2.70).

•• LFD 122: ónàlì ðe wakaãe <o´-noæ-xthiæ the wa-ga-xe> to dispatch, to send them [messengers] in a hurry. ónàlì ðe wahpaãe <o´-noæ-xthiæ the wa-¼a-xe> I dispatched [them] (02/13/95/FH/pc:ma). ónàlì ðe waçkaãe <o´-noæ-xthiæ the wa-shka-xe> you dispatch [them] (02/13/95/FH/pc:ma). ónàlì ðe àwakaãa pe <o´-noæ-xthiæ the oæ-wa-ga-xa i> we dispatch [them] (02/13/95/FH/pc:ma). LFD 174: ónàlì <u´-noæ-xthiæ> to make haste, to hurry. ónàlì kaãe <u´-noæ-xthiæ ga-xe> to expedite, to hasten. ónàlì xci <u´-noæ-xthiæ xtsi> hastily, speedily.

ónaxlì (variant of ónalì).

onâàëì (variant: onáaëi). V [reg. o_nâàëì] [ó- LOC + nààëî] (trans.) wear or put on (footwear or clothing) (RB). hòòpé onáaëi put your shoes on (PM:prod). ðée onáaëi here, put it/them on; get into these (PM). • (intr.) stand in there, get in or stay in there, as in a room or place (03/22/95/PM/pc). ðée onáaëì! stay there! (as in your room) (PM). • (trans.) attend. taapóskahci onâàëì attending school.

ónàkØò. V [reg., ó_nàkØò] [wa- VAL + ó- + nàkØô] (intr.) hear a rumor, have foreknowledge of an event. óðanàkØô? did you hear that? (04/20/95/LS/pc:ok). óðanàkØò? did somebody else tell you about this? (referring to an event that is happening, such as a knock on the door) (04/20/95/LS/pc:prod; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). owáðanàkØô? have you heard [about them]? (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). • N rumor, s.t. heard about (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; 05/01/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 174: onâkØò <u-noæ´-Ð'oæ> a rumor. oðake wì anâkØò <u-tha-ge wiæ a-noæ´-Ð'oæ> I heard a rumor. oðake wì ðanâkØò <u-tha-ge wiæ tha-noæ´-Ð'oæ> you heard a rumor. oðake wì ànâkØò pe <u-tha-ge wiæ oæ-noæ´-Ð'oæ i> we heard a rumor, a report, hearsay.

oní ðìké (variant: onîìke). VP be quiet, not make noise, no sound! (04/18/95/FH/pc). onî ìká, awáata hta akxâhe be quiet, I'm going to pray. onî ìka! don't make noises! (RBn11-02/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976).  

ónie. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) breathe, draw breath (PM:prod). • N sound (RBn22-01, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 174: óni oëâke <u´-ni-u-zhoæ-ge> road for the breath, the windpipe, air passage for breathing (lit., 'breathing path') (PM: ónie 'breathe', 04/14/95/PM/pc:ok).

ónihkaçi. N [apparently ó- LOC + níhkaçie (or níhkaçika 'live'?)] place or condition of being saved (in the Christian religious sense), fulfillment as a person, culmination of living. ónihkaçi çí tà, waçäíhtà tà when you are a saved person, when your work [on earth] is done (lit., 'when you've arrived there at fulfillment, when you've done work') (RBn12-10/MJ).  

oníhkaçie (variant: oníhkaçi). N [apparently ó- LOC + níhkaçie (or níhkaçika 'live'?)] life. oníhkaçie ðáalì waðakçíãe iche you made this good life for us (RBn10-12:JW). ìhtáci wahkôta, oníhkaçi haakò ðáalì wakçíapi our father God, how good you have made our lives (RBn).  

ónihkaçika. V [conjug. unknown] [apparently ó- LOC + níhkaçika 'live'] (intr.) have or lead a life, live life. ónihkaçika ðáalì lead a good life.  

ónihkie. V [reg.?, ónihki_[ð]e?] (intr.) get well or be healed, be free at last from illness (phrase often used in a funeral service) (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p14). oníhkie akxai he's free at last (said of the deceased who suffered from illness) (RBn23-20).  

oníëi (variant of onîëì).

onîìke (variant of oní ðìké).

onîëì (variants: onîëi, oníëi). V [reg., o_nîëì] (intr., trans.) be afraid or feel fearful (owing to an indefinite or nonspecific stimulus, such as darkness, being alone, catching a cold, flying, pain in general) (FH). [Contrast nôòhpe, said to be used for fear of a specific storm that is occurring; e.g., çôke nôòahpe 'I'm afraid of that dog' vs. çôke owánìëi 'I'm afraid of dogs'.] owánìëì I'm afraid (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod). owániëi àëi ëìkáëì apa kíðalì nòpe I'm feeling fearful, but the children enjoy it. íhaa che owánìëi I'm afraid of his mouth [his gossiping about me] (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod). síØ aníe owánìëi I'm afraid of my feet hurting (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod). kîì owánìëi I'm afraid of flying (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod). çôke owánìëi mìkçé I'm afraid of dogs (FH/11/18/01/pc). oðánìëì nìkçé? are you afraid? (12/30/94/FH:pc). àkónìëì we're not afraid (RB).

•• LFD 174: oníëì <u-ni´-zhiæ> the fear of darkness, a coward, craven, timid. [This verb in fact does not imply 'darkness' specifically.] owániëì <u-wa´-ni-zhiæ> I fear darkness. oðániëì <u-tha´ni-zhiæ> you fear darkness. àkóniëì pe <oæ-gu´-ni-zhiæ i> we fear darkness. hta apa oniëì nà pe <¾a a-ba u-ni-zhiæ noæ bi a> the deer is timid. oníëì paëi <u-ni´-zhiæ ba-zhi> not afraid of darkness. owániëì màëi <u-wa´-ni-zhiæ moæ-zhi> I am not afraid of darkness. oðáni ëí aëi <u-tha´-ni zhi´ azhi> you are not afraid of darkness. àkóniëì paëi pe <uæ-gu´-ni-zhiæ ba-zhi i> we are not afraid of darkness.

ónò. N [apparently ó- LOC + nôò] old age. ónò kçi pçíe ðe I'm old, I've arrived at old age (FH/6/16/96). ónò ahí akxai he or she has reached old age (RBn10-6:JW). ónò kçi àkáhi aðîkçe we [two] are old (FH:prod).

ónò ahí. VP get old (lit., 'arrive at old age'). koe ónò ëiçò çí tà çî tà koe hpíiëi ëiçò çí tà koe péeçki ðikôða htai wáçäuãe ðáalì before you get old and before you get fat and ugly and nobody wants you, you should get married (RB).

•• LFD 114: nòhí <noæ-hi´> senility (unconfirmed; 03/02/95/FH/pc:uk). nòhí <noæ-hi´> reaches mature age.

••• Cf. nôò ahí. 

ónòbre. N food, groceries, rations. ónòbre áëupi serve the food (01/30/95/FH/pc:ok). ónòbre húu áëupi ché there is lots of food set out (01/30/95/FH/pc:produced corrected). ónòbre húu oohôpi ché they cooked many foods, a lot of food (BE2.50; 01/30/95/FH/pc:ok). hpáze wanôbre ónòbre ðúwì ókxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (03/10/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.123). • meal, dinner. Carolyn ónòbre che oðówe kôða apai they want Carolyn to oversee this dinner (FH:prod).

•• LFD 174: ónòbre <u´-noæ-bthe> a grocery.

••• Cf. wanôbre. 

ónòbréooëú (variant of wánòbréooëú).

oochí (variant of ochí).

óochiëe (variant: oochíëe). V, ADJ [reg., óo_chiëe, but sometimes stative in 2nd sg.] (intr.) (be) loud or noisy (03/05/95/JS/pc:ok; RBn22-06; FH/11/17/01/pc; 04/14/95/PM/pc). ooáchiëe I am noisy. ooðáchiëe, ooðíchiëe you are noisy. káa ìkçe óochiëe this is too noisy (speaking of a television) (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.133; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.9). htáhtáze óochiëape grasshoppers are noisy (RBn3-55; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). • (be) talkative in excess, talk too much. káa ìkçe óochiëe this one talks too much (03/15/95/PM/pc). ðée akxa óochiëe this one talks too much (03/05/95/JS/pc). • N noise, disturbance, rumpus, turbulence (FH/11/17/01/pc). óochiëe çkáaãe you're noisy (lit., 'you are making noise') (FH). wáli óochiëe çkáaãe, àkóhkihkie àðúucØake you're making too much noise, we can't even converse (02/27/95/FH/pc; BE2.94).

•• LFD 180: óchiëe <u´-tsi-zhe> a row, an uproar, a rumpus; a fracas, riot, disorder, a fray. óchiëe kaãe <u´-tsi-zhe ga-xe> a riot, uproar, tumult [expected gloss: 'cause an uproar, a tumult,' etc.] (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). óchi ëi kaãe çtà <u´-tsi zhi ga-xe shtoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: óochiëe káaãe çtà 'always making noise') riotous, noisy, turbulent. LFD 166: óäiëe <u´-chi-zhe> [expected Mod. Os. form: óchiëe, not óäiëe] disturbance. owáäiëe <u-wa´-chi-zhe> [expected Mod. Os. form: óachiëe] I caused a disturbance. óðiäiëe <u´-thi-chi-zhe> [expected Mod. Os. form: óðichiëe] you caused a disturbance.

óoðààëi (variant of óðàëi).

óohkihà (variants: óohkiha, óohkihòò), V [reg., óo_hkihà] [hkik- REFL + óohò] (intr.) cook for oneself (01/11/95/FH/pc:prod, PM; LS). hpáata wì oowáhkiha I cooked myself an egg (RBn22-17). hpáata wì óohkihà cook yourself an egg (RBn22-17). • take care of a meal when asked to do so, put on a feast (01/11/95/FH/pc:prod; RBn1-41). óohkiha hta apai they're going to have a feast (BE2.24; RBn22-17) • boss, oversee an event (e.g., a naming) (FH/06/28/01/pc). •• LFD 172: ohkíhà <u-Ði´ - hoæ> to cook something for oneself (LS:ok). owáhkihà <u-wa´-Ðihoæ> I cooked for myself (01/11/95/FH/pc:ok). oðáhkihà <u-tha´-Ði-hoæ> you cooked for yourself. àkóhkihà pe <oæ-gu´-Ði-hoæ i> we cooked for ourselves (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

oohláaëi (variant of oolâàëi).

oohô. V [reg., oo_hô] (trans.) cook, prepare (e.g., food). ooáhà, ooáha, oowáhà, oowáha I prepare it. ooðáhà, ooðáha you prepare it. oohô he prepares it. àkóohò we prepare it. oohô bríiçtà I'm finished cooking (01/12/95/FH/pc:ok). htáaliko owáhà I cooked some meat gravy (01/12/95/FH/pc:ok). súhka háanà ooðáhà ðatxàçé? how many chickens are you cooking? (01/12/95/FH/pc:okc). tóopa oowáhà atxâhe I am cooking four (01/12/95/FH/pc:ok). súhkahtà htaaníi oohô ðáalì káaãapi ché they cooked the turkey soup well (lit., 'cooking the turkey soup they did it well') (01/12/95/FH/pc:okc). ónòbre huukôì oohôpi che they cooked many foods, a lot of food (01/12/95/FH/pc:ok, prod). ónòbre oohô ðáalì káaãa iché the food was cooked well (lit., 'cooking the food, they did it well'). oohô hpíòpe she is a good cook (lit., 'she knows how to cook') (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.23). oowáhai I cooked it. ooðáhai you cooked it (MSB 2-24-83). àkóohò [àð] ìkçé we [two] cooked it. àkóohòpe we [pl.] cooked it. htóoëu àkóohò hta àkái we [pl.] are going to cook some meat.

••• Cf. óohò. 

oohô (variant: óohò [MSB]). N cook, person who cooks (FH/07/09/01/pc). oohô akxa tooská ðìké akxa áa akxái the cook says there are no potatoes (01/12/95/FH/pc:prod).

óohò. V [reg., óo_hò] [wa- VAL + oohô] (intr.) cook things, cook stuff. óohò àwâàxta I love to cook (FH). wáli táahkaci akxái, óohò hkôbra ìké it's hot, I don't want to cook (01/12/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.24). • N cooking pot. óohò ootáapi apai they're borrowing the pot (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 170: óhò <u´-hoæ> to cook. owáhà <u-wa´-hoæ> I am cooking. oðáhà <u-tha´-hoæ> you are cooking. âkohò pe <oæ´-gu-hoæ i> we are cooking, the act of cooking, to cook by boiling or stewing.

óohò hcí (variant of oohôhci).

óohò owáwakØu. N [óohò + wa- VAL + wa- VAL + ókØu] waiter, waitress (lit., 'one who feeds cooked things [over and over?] to folks').

óohò saakí. N dried corn (lit., 'hard cooking': dehydrated corn made by boiling ears of corn lightly then drying the kernels in the sun for approximately three days).

oohôhci (variant: óohò hcí). N [oohô (or óohò) + hcí] kitchen, cookhouse. oohôhci ðuuwásu clean the kitchen (02/14/95/FH/pc; BE2.74).

•• RB: <ó-hoæ-tsi>.

•• LFD 170: óhò hci <u´-hoæ ¾si> kitchen.

ooláaëi (variant of oolâàëi).

oolâ. V [reg., oo_lâ] (trans.) put into, place inside of, pour round items into (e.g., fruit into pies), add items to cooking, pour liquid into. mâzeska ooðálà? have you put your money in? mîìhtoeli oolâ akxa he's chewing gum (lit., 'he has put gum in') (RBn14-03; HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok). paazénii wéli pààçcéka oolâ put cream on your strawberries. hpáataëì oðópçe oolâ put the baby in (the baby board). níi tóe

oolâ add water to it (e.g., the soup) (FH; LS). kaçpéòpa oolâ put your 25 cents in. htáaoolà sandwich (lit., 'meat-put-inside'). hkààcóolà lébra oðíhtà ci oolâ akxa there are ten pies sitting in the car (lit., 'they have placed ten pies in the car').

•• JOD (slip file): olâ <u-k-¢aæ´> to put a cv. ob [i.e., curved object], paper, book, piece of cloth, etc., in a receptacle.

••• Cf. hkààcóolà. 

oolâ (variant of oolâke).

óolà (variant of ólà).

oolâàëi (variants: ooláaëi, ohláaëi, oohláaëi). V [reg., oo_lâàëi] [oolâ + aëí NEG] (trans.) do (s.t.) not quite right, do imperfectly, make a poor performance of or fail at. oowáhlà maëí I don't quite do it perfectly; I can't make it, I can't succeed [at it] (03/05/95/JS/pc:ok). céãenii ochî ooláaëi káaãape he didn't hit drum quite right (not up to par) (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok).. • V, ADJ (intr.) fall short, fail, miss the mark; (be) not up to par, inferior, poor, subpar, inadequate. hóo ðáalì açäì aëî àëi oohláaëi açäîe they think you have a good voice, but it isn't right (lit., 'you have a good voice, you think, but you have it not up to par'). mîì táahkace oolâàëi ìkçi aape éhta pààçäéka cúuce oolâàëi apa aapé the sun had not been warm enough to make the strawberries ripe (lit., 'sun warming fell short, they said, therefore strawberries ripening failed, they said'] (RBn18-02). àkóolaaëi eekô àkái we fall short, being as we are (BE2.43).

•• LFD 182: oláëi <u-xtha´-zhi> secondary, of less importance, inferior; fail. owálamàëi <uwa´-xtha-moæ-zhi> I failed to beat in the race. oðála aëi <u-tha´-xtha a-zhi> you failed to beat in the race.

oolâke. V [reg., oo_lâke] [probably contains oolâ] (trans.) wear on the head, put on the head, don as a hat. óolàke oolâka put on your hat (03/22/95/PM/pc:okc; RBn10-12:JW). • ADJ with the head covered.

óolàke. N [wa- VAL + oolâke] hat, head cover, item worn on the head (RBn1-20). óolàke sápe çe ðíhta? is that your black hat? (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.64).

•• RB: <ó-luæ-keh>.

•• LFD 120: ólàke <o´-gthoæ-ge> a hat, a cap. LFD 170: ólàke <u´-gthoæ-ge> hat. "This article of wearing apparel was not known to the Osage until introduced by the traders."

óoçechia, óoçechie (variants of hóçechie).

óoçechiðe (variant of óçechiðe).

ootá (variant: ootâ [perhaps also oðóta, oðótà]). [reg., oo_tá] (trans.) ask for (as a loan), request to borrow; borrow, use s.o.'s, ask for s.t. to use it. ooðáta you ask for a loan. àkóota we ask for a loan. mâzeska oowáta hkòbrái I want to borrow money (01/07/95/FH/pc;ok). oðíhtà ðíhta oowáta hkôbra I want to borrow your car (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod ootá; BE2.10). ée ootápe he borrowed it (01/07/95/FH/pc;ok). óohò ootáapi apai they're borrowing the pot (04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ootá! borrow it! (01/07/95/FH/pc;ok; 1/20/83-p2/020; RBn2-MOJ).

•• LFD 96: mâzeska ota waleze <moæ´-še-ška u-da wa-gthe-še> paper or writing for borrowing money, a note. LFD 178: oðóta (?) <u-thu´-da> interest money. [LF's original analysis is <u-da> 'borrow', <thu> 'by which'.]

••• KS wadá beg, ask for, request (RR); QU wahtá pray (RR).

••• Cf. mâzeska ootá waléze, mâëà óota, oðótà mâzeska, waatá. 

ootá mâzeska (variant: ootâ mâzeska). N rent. màëâ ootá mâzeska lease money (for land) (lit., 'land usage money') (RBn1-28). mâëà ootà mâzeska lease money (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc).

óota (variant: óotà). V [ reg., óo_ta] [wa- VAL + ootá] (intr.) ask for stuff to be loaned, borrow things.

ootâ (variant of ootá).

óowe (variant of ówe).

ooëú. V [reg., oo_ëú] (trans.) pour or serve liquids or small solids such as beans, pour for (s.o.). oowíëu hce let me pour for you. màhkása toe ooâëu pour me some coffee (RBnot 5/3/79/7; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). mâhkasa âàwàëu pour me some coffee (03/10/95/MREI/pc). ààwáëu pour for me (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.106). • put in. wéli tóe oðíhtà ooðáëu? did you put some gas in the car? (RBn12-06). hkiistómàì háanà ooëú nàpé how many councilmen do they usually put in? (RBn3-01; 04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). hkíðatoopa ooëú nàpé they put in eight (RB; 4/18/95/FH/pc:ok). hpéece ooëú put them in the fire (RBn10-16). • plant or sow (e.g., seed in the ground), "put in" plants. oowáëu bríiçtà I finished planting them. hápaóoëu etkxâ akxái it's time to plant corn (lit., 'corn-planting it is time') (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.104). • N receptacle, container, bottle, cup, bowl, jar, shaker, holder (for pourable dry or liquid substances). [ooëú follows the noun naming the filler substance.] ëààníeooëú sugar bowl (FH: 04/18/95).

••• Cf. htáanieooëú, màhkásaiooëú, mâzeskaooëú, níiooëú. 

óoëu. V [reg., óo_ëu] [wa- VAL + ooëú] (intr.) put stuff in, plant stuff. háanà óoëu apái? how many people have put in? (e.g., if attendees at an event are to bring a certain number of cans of tomatoes, one asks 'how many [people] have put in?') (03/09/95/FH/pc; FH/t116b). • N pocket, bottle, container, vessel. óoëu htóho a blue bottle (FH: 04/18/95).

•• LFD 182: óëi htóho <u´-zhi ¾o-ho> a blue bottle. óëi <u´-zhi> to plant. oëí pçi aða<u-zhi´ pshi a-tha> [expected Mod. Os. form: óoëu pçí] I have been to plant [aða unconfirmed in all examples] (03/09/95/FH/pc:uk). óðaëi çe aða <u´-tha-zhi she a-tha> [expected Mod. Os. form: 

óoðaëu çí] you have been to plant (03/09/95/FH/pc:uk). oëí àkahi pi aða <u-zhi´ oæ-ga-hi bi a-tha> [second syllable accent in verb is probably an error; expected Mod. Os. form: óoëu àkáhipe] we have been to plant.

óoëuhaa. N [óoëu + háa] bag, sack, pouch made of hide or leather (lit., 'skin into which to put stuff').

ópaache. N [wa- VAL + ó- LOC + paaché] sewing (lit., 'wherein stuff is sewn'). • ADJ sewn, sewn together (RBn1-MOJ/p4304/19/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• Cf. óhkihpaache. 

opáaãa. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem?, o_páaãa?] (intr.) open (e.g., flowers opening out). hlaaská opáaãa akxai the flowers are opening out. opáaãa káaãa! open it!

••• Cf. paaãáce. 

opáahà (variant: opâàhà). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, o_páahà] (trans.) raise up, hold up (LS/02/95/LS/pc: prod); put on, don (as clothing) (04/18/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/18/95/FH/pc:ok). ákahamì ohpâàhà àhé I'm putting this coat on (FH:prod). wéhkili wì ohpáahà mìkçé I'm putting on my clothes (ERE). ákahamì oçpâàhà ðaìçé? are you putting this coat on? (FH:prod; BE2.109). wéhkili wì opâàhà he's putting on his clothes (ERE). ákahami opâàhà put this coat on. haaská ðé opáahà put this shirt/clothing on (04/18/95/FH/pc:ok). àkópâàhà we put it on.

••• Cf. ðuhpáahà, hpaahâ, paahâ, wéhkilì okíhpaahà, wéhkilì opáahà. 

ópaaçike. ADJ overbearing (describes s.o. who is always butting in, interrupting) (RBn22-01, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 175: opáçie <U-pa´-shi-e> Counsellor (personal name).

••• QU páçike ruin by cutting in or poking a hole in (RR).

opáhce. N herd (LF, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 165 (unconfirmed): opáhce <u-ba´-¾se> a herd. "Now applied to a herd of cattle." ìtáci akxa hceeská opáhce hu waðî pe <iæ-da-dsi a-ka tse-ška u-ba´-¾se hiu wa-thiæ bi a> my father has a large herd of cattle.

opáhce (variant: opáhcilà). V (trans.) hang up (e.g., clothing) (RB; 04/11/95/LS/pc:okc). ákahamì ðíhta opáhce hang your coat up (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.64). opáhcila hang it up (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

óolàke opáhcila hang that hat up (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77, unconfirmed).

•• RB: <o-páh-tsi-nah>.

•• LFD 166: opáhcilà <u-ba´-¾si-gthoæ> to hang something on a peg or the limb of a tree. opá hcialà <u-ba´ ¾si-a-gthoæ> I hung something on a peg. opáhciðalà <u-ba´-¾si-tha-gthoæ> you hang something on a peg. opáhcikilà <u-ba´-¾si-gi-gthoæ> he hung something on a peg. ópahciëu <u´-ba-¾si-zhu> to hang bunches of ears of corn to dry; to hang clothes to dry (unconfirmed; LS/04/11/95/pc:ma, may mean hanging more than one thing).

opákØo (variant: opákØoe). V [presumably sync. fortisizing stop stem, o_pákØo] [ó- LOC + paakØó] (trans.) punch a hole in, cut a hole in by pushing. nâãe opákØoe cut a hole in the ice (RBn16-02).

•• LFD 165: opáhkuce <u-ba´-Ðu-dse> [should be <u-ba´-k'u-dse>, Mod. Os. opákØoce] to punch holes in a pair of moccasins or clothing [expected gloss would not include moccasins or clothing].

••• KS obákØoýe (obákØodabe) make or enlarge a hole (RR).

opásàce. V [conjug. unknown]. (trans.) have it in for; consider (s.o.) an opponent. opásàce they've got it in for him, they're "laying for him" (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod).

••• KS ábasàýe to push against something, to have sex with (RR), áabüsàýe to press down on, wrestle (RR).

••• Cf. áhkiasàci, ásàci, kasôci. 

opáwìãe. V [uninfl.?] (intr.) wander, roam, rove, travel around; go for a ride, drive around for pleasure, go on an excursion. opáwìãe ààðìhé I'm riding around (FH:prod). oðíhtà opáwìãe aðáape they went riding in the car (RBn10-20). mâàãe ðáalì akxa, opáwìãe àkái hce the weather is good, let's go for a drive [two people]. opáwìãe àkái htái let's go for a ride [three or more people]. • N excursion, ride. opáwìãe brée ðe I'm going riding, I'm going for a ride (FH:prod; 01/20/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.35).

•• JOD (Wolf and Fawn p1 ln2): ha wiëìe ohpáwìãe áðìhe <Ha´, wi´¦ci æe´! Upa´wiæ xe a´¢iæhe´> [expected form <U§pa´wiæ xe>] Ho, elder brother, I've been wandering around.

•• LFD 263: opáwìãe <u-ba´-wiæ-xe> an excursion. LFD 166 (unconfirmed): opáwìãe <u-ba´wiæ-xe> to travel, to roam about, to wander, to travel for pleasure to rove, to saunter, to stroll; to swirl in a kettle when cooking. ohpáwìãe <u-¼a´-wiæ-xe> I travel for pleasure. oçpáwìãe <u-shpa´wiæ-xe> you travel for pleasure. àpópawìãa pe <oæ-bu´-ba-wiæ-xa i> [presumably a typographical error for àkópawìãa pe <oæ-ku´-ba-wiæ-xa i>] we travel for pleasure. opáwìãe àðalì <u-ba´-wiæ-xe oæ-tha-gthiæ> I like to stroll.

opázo (variant: ópazo). N [apparently ó- LOC + pázo 'finger'] index finger (RBn10-9:JW; 01/24/95/FH/pc:prod).

 ••• Cf. çáake opázo, wéapazo. 

opâàhà (variant of opáahà).

opéni. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, o_péni] (trans.) detect, find out about or partially uncover an undisclosed idea or plan (such as a surprise party), discover in part but not fully, get wind of, get word of, get a feeling about s.t. without full knowledge of it. ohpéni àìhé I found out, I have a feeling (LS). oçpéni you [sg.] found out, you [sg.] have a feeling (LS). opéni paaçé you [pl.] found out, you [pl.] have a feeling (LS). pée John opéni ðe? who found out about John? who did John find out about? (RBnot-nd-1/ps; LS/7/27/95, all short vowels). pée opénipe? who did they find out about?

opéni kaaãé ìká don't let them get wind of it (RBnot-nd-1/p2; 01/24/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/09/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 166: opéhni <u-be´-hni> to detect (01/24/95/FH/pc: opéni, no preaspiration of p or n). ohpéhni <u-¼e´-hni> I detect. oçpéhni <u-shpe´-hni> you detect. àkópehtà pe <oæ-gu´-be-¾oæ i> [-htà- is unexpected in this form; expected Mod. Os. form: àkópenipe] we detect, to discover.

opétxà (variants: opétkxà, opétxa). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem?, o_pétxà?] (trans.) tie in a bundle or wrap up s.t. specific. haxîke opétkxà wrap up those [scattered] blankets (03/22/95/FH/pc). haxî hcéka che haaská wasúhu opétkxà wrap up those new [stacked] blankets in a clean cloth (03/22/95/FH/pc). háxî toa opétxà tie up some blankets (RBn2/p18; 03/22/95/FH/pc:ok).

ópetxà (variants: ópetkxà, ópetxa). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem?, ó_petxà?] [wa- VAL + opétxà] (intr.) wrap or tie up stuff as a bundle. ópetxà put it inside and wrap it up (as inside a blanket or in a cloth) (BE2.161; 03/24/95/PM/pc:okc; LS). ópetxa tie that up (e.g., tie up some blankets) (BE2.140; RBn125).

•• LFD 166 (unconfirmed): opéhtà <u-be´-¾oæ> [expected LF form would be <u´-be-toæ>, expected Mod. Os. form ópetxà] to wrap. ohpéhtà <u-¼e´-¾oæ> I wrap up the goods. oçpéhtà <ushpe´-¾oæ> you wrap up the goods. àkópehtà pe <oæ-gu´-be-¾oæ i> we wrap up the goods or envelop (unconfirmed; 03/24/95/PM/pc:no). [In all these LF examples, -htà should be -txà.]

opíãà (variants: opíãa, opíxà) V [conjug. unknown (sync. fortisizing stop stem?, o_píãà?)] [ó- LOC + píãà] (trans.) blow into or on (e.g., a fire in a fireplace), blow inside, play a horn or other wind instrument (RBn1-42; FH:ok:[x]). hpéece çkáaãe çäuucØake tà, opíãà if you can't start the fire, blow on it (FH/11/19/01/pc). hpéece çäúucØake tà ópiãà íkØuca if you can't start the fire, try blowing on it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod; HRE/12/29/01/pc opíxà). • N whistle, horn, flute, wind instrument (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.67).

•• LFD 166: opíãà <u-bi´-xoæ> any wind instrument, as a flute or horn.

ópoce (variant: opóce). N trash, things scattered around (as in a messy house), scattering, collection of scattered things (FH: t119a). ópoce áçihta aðîðaa take the trash outside (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc; t119a;BE2.144, RBn2-MOJ/p20). opóce ðaaçé you're falling apart (lit., 'you are a collection of scattered things') (3-10-83C; 03/23/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn10-12:JW).

•• LFD 166: opóce <u-bu´-dse> profusion, abundance.

opçáëi. V [reg., o_pçáëi] [opçé + aëí NEG] (trans.) disobey.

opçé. V [reg. o_pçé] (trans.) obey, follow, heed. háakô çkôçta tà oðípçe hta akxai however you want it to be, they're going to listen to you.

••• Cf. íe opçé, okípçe. 

opxá. ADV down the middle. opxá (see kíopxa).

opxáëi (see kíopxaëi).

opxâ (variant: opxá). V [reg., o_pxâ] (trans.) follow (as a path), go through or down (as a road) (RBn2204, unconfirmed). oëâke owápxa àhé I'm going through that road (RBn22-05 [archaic?]). 

•• LFD 192: wáhkilace owahpa <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse u-wa-¼a> [LF's <¼> (Mod. Os. hp) is probably an error for <p> (Mod. Os. px)] I obey the law (02/14/95/FH/pc:uk). wáhkilace oðahpa <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse u-tha-¼a> [LF's <¼> (Mod. Os. hp) is probably an error for <p> (Mod. Os. px)] you obey the law (unconfirmed). wáhkilace ohpa <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse u-¼a> [LF's <¼> (Mod. Os. hp) is probably an error for <p> (Mod. Os. px)] he obeys the law (unconfirmed).

••• Cf. opxâpxâ. 

ópxà (variant: ópxa). N elk (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; 12/30/94/FH/pc:uk; BE2.41; RBn1-24).

•• LFD 123: ópxà waðò <o´-poæ wa-thoæ> Elk Songs.

ópxà hîì ekô. ADJP, N light brown, dun colored (lit., 'like the color of elk') (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 122: ópxà hì ekò <o´-poæ hiæ e-goæ> dun colored, the color of the elk.

ópxàhaa. N [ópxà + háa] elk skin (4/25/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 122: ópxà ha <o´-poæ ha> elk skin.

opxâpxâ (variant: opxâpxâi). N [reduplicated form of opxâ 'follow'] chief-to-chief (refers to succession of hereditary chiefs within a family); one of anything following the other (04/13/95/FH/pc:okc). 

opØâða (variant: opØâðe).V [uninfl.] (intr.) steam, emit vapors, produce a rising fog (such as fog from water in a pond, lake, or swamp) (BE2.49; 04/07/95/PM/pc:okc; MSB/pc). níi akxa opØâðe nàpé water steams (2-2-670). • N fog rising from standing water when the sun shines on it, steam or vapor arising.

•• LFD 129: opØóðà <u-p'o´-thoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: opØâða] steam rising from a kettle over a fire (01/26/95/FH/pc:uk; 03/14/95/FH/pc:uk). LFD 175 (unconfirmed): pØóðà <¼'o´-thoæ> steam arising from boiling water. pØóðô che ôðò nite akçe <¼'o´-tho´æ tse o´æ-thoæ ni-de a-ke> the steam burnt my arm [this sentence is not confirmed and is unintelligible].

osái (variant: ozái [RB only]). V [reg., o_sái] [presumably ó- LOC + sápe] (intr.) burn, be on fire; (trans.) set fire to, burn. [Probably used specifically of lighting cigarettes at a peyote meeting (FH/11/19/01/pc).] nàníòpa osái burn the cigarettes (RBn10-16). oðásai you burned cigarettes (in a peyote meeting) (RB).

•• LFD 166: osá pi o <u-ša´ bi o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] to set fire. owáse <u-wa´-še> I set fire to it. oðáse <u-tha´-še> you set fire to it. àkósa pe <oæ-gu´-ša i> we set fire to it.

••• KS osé to be burned, to be set afire (RR).  

••• Cf. ðâàce ósai. 

oscé (variant of oçcé).

ósi. V [reg., ó_si] (intr., trans.) alight (from), get off (e.g., a horse), get out of (e.g., a car). ósipi get out [pl. addressee] (FH/11/18/01/pc). oðási you got out (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

••• Cf. wísi. 

óski. N arch of the foot.

ostá. V [reg., o_stá] (intr.) slide, slip.

••• Cf. çtáha. 

ostówe. ADJ [apparently ó- LOC + stówe] running as a group, hurrying toward s.t., being rushed or rushing in a row (FHt128). táatà ómahkà ecíepe éetana ostówe aðíi apai a whole line of people are running because there's something cheap (lit., 'something cheap is there, thus rushing in a line/group they are going there') (FHt128).

•• LFD 167: ostówe nàëì <u-štu´-e noæ-zhiæ> to stand abreast, to stand in a row

oçcé (variants: oscé, oçäé). V [reg., o_çcé] (intr.) remain, be left or left over (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). wanôbre níi tóa oçcé? is there any peyote tea left? (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.78). ðekôòci áha waxpáðe níhkaçika, háanà ìksé çki ówaçta apa tàha at the present time we are a pitiful people, and there are even very few of us left [ówaçta apa is probably a misrecording for ówaçtape 'we are left']  • (trans.) leave (as leftovers), spare. • N remainder, rest, leftover amount. oçcé ke remainders or leftovers that are scattered around.

•• LFD 175: oscéke <u-stse´-ge> the rest that are scattered about (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. oðáaçce. 

oçcé che (variants: oscé che, oçäé che). ADJP leftover, remaining (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). ówe oçäé che ànáhkilai htai let's all of us divide these leftover groceries (03/06/95/FH/pc). N remainder (sg. standing inanimate or pl. sitting inanimate), leftovers. htáatà oscé che whatever is left (PM).

•• LFD 175: oscé che <u-stse´ tse> the rest that has been gathered and stands in a pile; the remainder, part left over (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 35: táatà oscé che <da´-doæ u-stse´-tse> what is left over, remainder, residue (04/14/95/PM/pc:ok).  

oçcé ke. N remainders, leftovers, or rest (scattered around).

oçcúuce. N slowpoke, slow person, pokey one.

oçäé (variant of oçcé).

óçe. V [uninfl.] (intr.) exist plentifully (03/23/95/FH/pc). [Nearly synonymous with ochí, but óçe cannot be used with ëìkáëì 'child' or haxî 'blanket', for example (LS).] táatà óçe something plentiful (FH). ónòbre óçe a lot of food (lit., 'food-wise there is plenty'). táatà óçe a lot of things (LS/04/17/95/pc). • N lots, abundance, plenty, profusion of s.t.

•• LFD 175: óçe <u´-she> plenty, plentiful.

óçechiðe (variants: óçechie, óoçechiðe). V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) be much, be many. ónòbre óoçechíepe there's a lot of food.

óçechiðe wakáaãe. N quail. [Possibly óçechiðe here is a variant of hóçechie 'jump as when startled'; in that case the expression would literally mean 'make them jump up in a startled fashion', referring to the sudden movement or sound that quail make when flushed (LF, unconfirmed).]

•• LFD 313: oçechiðe wakaaãe <u'-shi-¾si-the wa-ga-xe> quail (unconfirmed).

óçkika (variant: óçkike). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) mischievous (said of a person who tends to laugh and make fun of people). Eddie akxa óçkika akxai Eddie is being mischievous (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok); (be) unreliable, ornery, worthless, no good (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p5; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.94). níhka çtáke apa wáli óçkike apai, taaçéðai hta mìkçé that nice [or 'gentle'] man is really being ornery [or 'a drag'], I'm going to shake him up [or 'hit him on the head'] (FH/98/pc; FH/10//13/96/pc). óçkika! you're ornery! (a response to someone who has just said something crazy and funny).

•• LFD 175: óçkika pi a <u´-shki-ga bi a> [expected Mod. Os.: óçkikape] he is perverse. LFD 256: óçkika <o´-shki-ga> dissipated, dissolute. LFD 123: çe níhkaçika apa óçkika pi a <she ni´-Ðashi-ga a-ba o´-shki-ga bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form: çe níhka apa óçkikape 'that man is ornery'] he is very dissipated, dissolute.

oçpéëì. N [ó- LOC + -çpé + -ëì 'little'] fragment, small piece, chip, bit, bits and baubles, one's small things (RB; FH). oçpéëì nàlôòha apái ðée apa ahú apai óceçtàpe they're hiding their things because the people coming are snoops. • change left over after a purchase, coins, small change, pennies (RBn2-MOJ/p19; 03/07/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.102; FH).

•• LFD 175: oçpé <u-shpe´> a fragment (03/07/95/PM/pc:ok).

••• Cf. kaçpé, paaçpú. 

oçtá. N [presumably ó- LOC + çtáha] yard, lawn, cleared area, bare ground. oçtá kaasé mow the lawn (RBn10-16).

otáa. V, ADJ [conjug. unknown] [presumably ó- LOC + táa 'freeze'] (intr.) (be) frozen. htóoëu akxa otáa akxai the meat pie is frozen.

ótaa. V [conjug. unknown] [wa- VAL + otáa] (trans.) freeze in/to another substance, make s.t. freeze. sîìce akxa nâãe ótaape his tail was frozen in the ice (RBn16-02). htóoëu ótaa ðiké don't freeze the meat pie.

otáhpa. N entrails, part of the stomach resembling little books or pages, used for soup (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok; 3/3/83/p2). [Also called "bible," it lies in layers and has a fringe on it; may have grass inside that the animal has eaten earlier.]

•• LFD 167: otáhpa <u-da´-¼a> the third stomach of an ox. LFD 120: otáhpa <o-da´-¼a> the third stomach of an ox, used by the Indians for food and considered a delicious delicacy.

otkxâ (variant of okxâ).

ótkxàëi (variant of ókxàëi).

otxâ (variants: okxâ, otxá). V [reg., o_txâ] (trans.) put on (e.g., pants, shoes). lîìka, hòòpé ðé otxá sit down, put these shoes on (RBn1-MOJ/p38).

•• RB: <o-txáh>.

•• LFD 313: hòòpé otxà <hoæ-be´ u-toæ> to put on shoes. LFD 65: hòòpéotxà <hoæ-be´-u-toæ> to put on moccasins. hòòpé oðatxà <hoæ-be´ u-tha-¾oæ> [LF's t <¾> here and in the next two examples is evidently an error for tx <t>] you put on moccasins. hòòpé owatxà <hoæ-be´ u-wa-¾oæ> I put on moccasins. hòòpéàkotxà pe <hoæ-be´-oæ-gu-¾oæ i> we put on moccasins.

ótxàtxà (variant: ókxàkxà [FH]). ADJ, N [reduplicated form] time after time, generation, generational, generation after generation, referring to a long line of chiefs, ongoing (02/14/95/FH/pc: prod). kahíke ókxàkxà hereditary chief (FH).

•• LFD 178 (unconfirmed): oðoátxà <u-thu-a´-toæ> to follow; to be next; sequence. [Related, not identical, to ótxàtxà.] oðóawatxà <u-thu´-a-wa-toæ> I follow next. oðóaðatxà <u-thu´-a-tha-toæ> you follow next. àðâkotxà pe <oæ-thoæ´-gu-toæ i> we follow next. oðoáwatxà anàëì <u-thu-a´-watoæ a-noæ-zhiæ> I follow next to him.

••• Cf. opxâpxâ. 

ówaachi. N [ó- LOC + waachí] dance place or location. huukôða dalípe na, ðe ówaachi ilôòçka many of you have come back to this place of the ilôòçka dances (HREsr: 1965 ilôòçka-line 2).  

ówaðaace. N [ó- LOC + wa- VAL + ðaacé] law.

•• LFD 181: ówaðace <u´-wa-tha-dse> the law.  

owáhkiha. N [presumably ó- LOC + áhkiha] grandchild(?), grandchildren. ówahkiha háanà açäî? how many grandchildren do you have?  

••• Cf. ëìká owáhkihà. owánòbrehcí. N [ó- LOC + wanôbrehci] cafe, restaurant (BE2.16; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). [Preferred to wanôbrehci (FH).]

ówatoì (variant: ówatòe). N [ó- LOC + wa- VAL + tôpe] show, picture show, movie, film, theater presentation, exhibition (lit., 'wherein to see things') (04/19/95/FH/pc:okc; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). ówatoì àkái hce let's go to the show [sg. addressee] (RBn2-MOJ/p5; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). wíe hâàce ówatòe pçíe I went to the movies last night (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.90).

•• LFD 180: ówatòpe <u´-wa-doæ-be> a theater, a circus. ówatòpe ðe àzo <u´-wa-doæ-be the oæšu> [expected Mod. Os. form: ówatòe ðée âàzo] I like to go to the theater.

ówatòìhci N [ówatoì + hcí] theater, exhibition hall (lit., 'show house') (MOJt150a).

ówe (variant: óowe). N groceries (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok). hpáze wanôbre ówe brúwì ókxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (04/19/95/FH/pc:okc). ówe hcíhta áðìkü bring the groceries inside (BE2.61). ówe tóa owáhi I won some groceries. • garden, cultivated area, field planted for harvest (FH). óowe ðáalì açäî you have a good garden (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok, prod). • greens, vegetables, produce (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok).

ówe hci (variant: owéhci). N grocery store (BE2.61; 01/11/95/FH/pc:ok). óweche brée I'm going to the grocery store (FH).

óweena (variants: óweenà, ówiina) V, ADJ [uninfl.] [ó- LOC + wéenà] (intr.?) (be) glad. ðachí che óweena àçkáaãe I'm glad you are here (HH/14-a/401ff&pc). [Used in formal speech.] • (be) thankful, appreciative, grateful (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok). óweena àkxâhe I'm thankful (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). ðachí che óweena àçkáaãe thank you for coming (lit., 'you have made me grateful, as you have come here, as is evident') (HH/14-a; pc). óweena iðá[ð]e hkôbra I want to say something in appreciation (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). ónòbre ðé waðákikØupi che ówiina àkátxà we are grateful for this food you have given us (part of a prayer).

•• LFD 181: ówehnà <u´-we-hnoæ> thankfulness, gratitude.  

owéhci (variant of ówe hci).

owíhta (variant of oðíhtà).

ówiina (variant of óweena).

owísi (variant of wísi).

ówò (variant: ôwò). V, ADJ [uninfl.] [presumably ó- LOC + wa- VAL + éò] (intr.) (be) busy (BE2.37).

hòpái wálì ówò àhé today I was very busy (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). wáli ówò àhé I'm really busy (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). eetà, ówò hta mìkçé well, I'm going to be busy (01/09/95/FH/pc:okc). kasîe ówò hta ðaìçé? are you going to be busy tomorrow? (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). kasîe ówò hta nìkçé? are you going to be busy tomorrow? (BE2.14). ówò àkxàhé, lîìpi I'm busy, sit down (FH:prod; RBn2-MOJ). • N chore, task, errand, duty, things one has to do (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). huuwáli ôwò òâchi I've got a lot to do (lit., 'a large number of chores are plentiful to me') (RBn12-07; FH/11/19/01/pc: okc). wáli ówò oðíchi you're really busy (04/25/95/PM/pc:prod). ówò oðíchi ðaaçé íhpahò I know you have had a lot to do (RBn104:MOJ/79).

•• LFD 181: owò <u-woæ> to be busy. óò òwàhci <u´-oæ oæ-woæ ¾si> I am busy. óò oðihci <u´oæ u-thi-¾si> you are busy.

ówò káaãe, VP [sync. k>p, ówò _káaãe] (trans.) make trouble for s.o., trouble another, be a burden to s.o. wáli ówò wihpáaãe I'm a lot of trouble to you.

ówò kçíãe. VP [reg. ówò _kçíãe] (trans.) make trouble for s.o., trouble another, be a burden to s.o. ðihkówa akxa wálì ówò àkçíãe akxai your friend is making me a lot of trouble (lit., 'your friend really makes tasks for me') (RBn23-17).

óxe. N grave, ditch, burial place. óxe pakØó apái they're digging the ditch; they're digging the grave (RB; 02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok). hlaaská óxe áëu put flowers on the grave (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.6).

••• OP óxe grave.  

óxe mâëà. N cemetery, graveyard, burial ground.

óxe sápe. N coffin (LF, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 124: óxe sape <o´-xe ša-be> a coffin.

óxiða. N [ó- LOC + xíða] death (RBn10-7:JW). ìhtáci wahkôta akxa óxiða káaãi akxái God created this death (said at a peyote meeting).  

óxìì. V, ADJ [uninfl. (neither **oðíxì nor **oðáxì 'you are jealous' is acceptable)] (trans., intr.) (be) jealous, envious (e.g., of another's position) (RBn10-7:JW). ée óxìì akxai they're envious (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). óxìe nìkçé you're envious (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.42). • pout, sulk about another's good fortune (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). • N envy, jealousy (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc).

•• RB: <ó-xiæ, óæ-xiæ>.

oxpáðe (variants: oxpái, oxpáðì). V [stat., o_xpáðe] (intr.) fall from a height. oxpáðe ìká don't fall in (RBn23-17). ëâà kítxà àwâxpaðe I fell out of a tree. oxpáðape he fell from a height, they fell from a height. • get lost, become lost, be lost. o[w]àxpa[ð]e, owâxpaðe I get lost. oðíxpaðe you get lost. owáxpaðape we get lost. hòpá oâxpai aðìhé I got lost today (RBn). oxpáðape they got lost; it was lost (FHt128). oxpáðe apai, oxpáðape they've gotten lost, they're lost. çôke wíhta akxa oxpáðe akxa my dog is lost (04/27/95/FH/pc). çôke wíhta akxa oxpáðape my dog was lost (04/27/95/FH/pc). waëáëe okØâ oxpáðape Osage ways are all gone (lit., 'Osage ways got lost') (05/01/95/LS/pc). • (trans.) lose (s.t. specific or s.o. specific) (RBn1-23). [Accent tends to fall on the initial o- in the 1st pl. form in the transitive use of this verb, as in ówaxpaðape 'we lost it', causing this to resemble the valencereduced form óxpaðe.] àwâxpaðe I lose it. oðíxpaðe you lose it. owáxpaðe we lose it. mâzeskaooëú àwáxpai I lost my purse (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.82). waðílà àwáxpai I lost my mind (RBn23-20). haxî àwâxpaðì I lost my blanket (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). sôke wíhta àwâxpaðe I lost my dog (04/27/95/FH/pc). haxî oðíxpaðe you lost your blanket (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). wéleze Frances akxa oxpáði akxai Frances [has] lost her pencil (02/27/95/FH/pc). haxì oxpáðape they lost their blanket, she lost her blanket (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok). hòòpé ówaxpa[ðe] àkáðe we lost our shoes (RBnotes, MSB). óolàke oðíxpai ðàìçe you lost your hat (RBnotes, MSB). àwâðaxpai you lost me. ówaðaxpai you lost us.

•• LFD 181: oxpáðe <u-xpa´-the> to grope, to feel around with the hands in the dark; to fall, to become lost. [The gloss 'grope, feel' is unconfirmed.] àwâxpaðe <oæ-woæ´-xpa-the> I felt around in the dark. [A more accurate translation is probably 'I fell'.] LFD 73–74: àwâxpaðe ha íhkiçoce kçe <oæ-woæ´-xpa-the ha, i´-Ði-sho-dse ke> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I was lost in the fog. oðíxpaðe ha íhkiçoce kçe <u-thi´-xpa-the ha, i´-Ði-sho-dse ke> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you were lost in the fog. páce apa oxpáða pe ha íkiçoce kçe <ba-dse a-ba u-xpa´-tha pe ha, i´-Ði-sho-dse ke> [phrase-final or sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] the boat was lost in the fog.  

••• Cf. óxpaðe. 

oxpáðe káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, oxpáðe _káaãe] (trans.) mislead, cause to get lost.

•• LFD 181: oxpáðekaãe <u-xpa´-the-ga-xe> to mislead, to lead one into error. oxpáðe hpaãe <u-xpa´-the pa-xe> I misled him. oxpáðe çkaãe <u-xpa´-the shka-xe> you misled him. oxpáðe àkaãa pe <u-xpa´-the oæ-ga-xa i> we misled him.

óxpaðe (variant: óxpaði). V [stat., ó_xpaðe] [wa- VAL + oxpáðe] (intr.) lose things, lose stuff. [Note the contrast to transitive oxpáðe 'lose it, lose s.t. specific'.] Frances akxa óxpaði akxai Frances lost some stuff (FH; RBn).

oxpáðeðe. V [reg., oxpáðe_ðe] [oxpáðe + ðe CAU] (trans.) cause to be lost. oxpáðewaðai you lost them (lit., 'you caused them to be lost').

oxpáði, oxpáðì, oxpái (variants of oxpáðe 'lose').

óxta. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) precious, dear or beloved, valuable, marvelous, important, special, right, respectable. ëîka oxta honored or favored child (CQ ok; BE2.107). ëúika akxa óxta akxai my body is precious (RBn10-9:JW). óxta káaãe akxai they're making him important.

óxta káaãe VP [sync. k>p, óxta _káaãe] (trans.) hold sacred, consider precious, regard as holy. hâàpa ðe óxta káaãe apai people hold this day sacred (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 181: óxta <u´-xta> marvelous, pleasing, mysterious, lovable, to hold precious, to prize highly, to hold a thing as precious or valuable. [LF's definitions 'to hold precious, to prize highly, to hold a thing as precious or valuable' strictly speaking apply to the phrase óxta káaãe rather than to óxta alone.] óxta hpaãe ekò saki obrìke <u´-xta ¼a-xe e-goæ ša-gi u-bthiæ-ge>I hold it precious. [A more accurate translation would be 'I made it precious, therefore I hold tightly to it'.] óxta àkaãa pe ekò saki àkoðìka pe <u´-xta oæ-ga-xa pe e-goæ ša-gi oæ-gu-thiæ-ga i> we hold it precious. [A more accurate translation would be 'we made it precious, therefore we hold tightly to it'.]  

 ••• Cf. kíoxta, óðoxta. 

óxtaðe. V [reg., óxta_ðe] [óxta + ðe CAU] make precious, special, or important.

•• LFD 182: óxtaðe <u´-xta-the> to be fond of a person. oxtaaðe <u-xta-a-the> I am fond of that person. oxtaðaðe <u-xta-tha-the> you are fond of that person.

óxtahkiðe. V [reg., óxta_hkiðe] [hkik- REFL/RECIP + óxtaðe] (intr.) make oneself important, make oneself right and respectable. óxtaðahkie you made yourself right and respectable. óxtahkie he's making himself important. • cherish each other. óxtahkiapi cherish each other.  

óxtakiðe. V [reg., óxta_kiðe] [ki- SUU + óxtaðe] (trans.) make dear, make special, give special status to a relative or s.o. close. ëìkówahkihà óxtawakíe akxai he's making his grandchildren special.  

ozái (variant of osái).

ozó. N lowland, low wooded level (JOD).

•• JOD (Wolf and Fawn p15 ln1): hcaléëe ozó ki áhkihpape ska <Tca-§k¢e§ce u§sú §ki ákipá§pe ska> he met Fawn on the lowland.

óëà. V [reg., ó_ëà] [ó- LOC + ëâà] (intr., trans.?) lie abed, lie down. oáëà I lie abed. oðáëà you lie abed. oëà he lies abed. àkóëà we lie abed. húhekahci oëâ akxai he's [lying abed] in the hospital (RBn1206). çkáëi ëâà! lie still! (RBn23-15). • (trans.) lie down in (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). áëà àkóëà hta [að]ìkçé we [two] are going to lie down in the bed (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). • N bed, place one lies in (FH). óëà oðáëà ëàkçé you're lying in bed (FH/pc).

óëàke (variant: oëâke). N road, highway, thoroughfare, route, path, pathway, orbit. [Takes 'lying down' positional article kçe.] oëâke kçe bráaða the road is wide. oëâke olìì sit in the road, sit at the altar in a peyote meeting, thus be a roadman.

•• LFD 182: óëàke <u-zhoæ-ge> a trail, a path, a route to be taken, a thoroughfare, a road.

oëâke ohtânà. N street (lit., 'road between') (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

oëâke olîì. V [reg., oëâke o_lîì ] (intr.) be a roadman (lit., 'sit in the road [altar in the peyote religion]'). oëâke oðálìì hta nìkçé? are you going to be roadman? (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod). pée oëâke olîì hta ðe? who's going to be roadman? (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod). • N roadman in the peyote religion, minister of a religious entity, preacher, pastor, priest.  

óëeðe (variants: oëéðe, oëéða). V, ADJ [uninfl. or stat. ó_ëeðe ] (intr.) feel tired, (be) fatigued, weary, tired (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). àwâëeðe I'm tired (BE2.141; 03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). oëéðe mìkçé I'm tired (03/22/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 182: oëéða <u-zhe´-tha> to be tired, to be weary (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). àwaëeða <oæ-wazhe-tha> I am tired. oðíëeða <u-thi´-zhe-tha> you are tired. owáëeða pe <u-wa´-zhe-tha i> we are tired.

oëéhci (variants: óëehci, océëehci). N [ó- LOC + ëé + hcí] bathroom, toilet room, john, w.c., outhouse (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/26/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 182: oëéhci <u-zhe´-¾si> fireplace [unconfirmed as fireplace, perhaps this gloss is for Omaha?]. 

••• OM <u-zhe´-ti> (LFD 182).

oëíëie (variant: oëíëe). V [reg., o_ëíëie] (trans.) bait or coax s.o. to say or do s.t., egg on, encourage, incite. áwaëiëíe I egged him on. éekòaëi ówaðaëiëíe you egged them on anyway (RB:MSB/02/17/83). ékimà hkôbra ìké àëi àwâðaëiëíe I didn't want to do it, but you egged me on (RB:MSB/02/17/83). oëíëi apai they egged him on. • convince. àwâðaëiëie you convinced me (2/3/83/236; FH:ma).

óëì hpíiëi. VP (intr.) become angry, get mad. óëì hpíiëi ðìké, ókØà ðáalì hkí[ð]a don't get angry, have good ways (lit., 'don't become angry, make yourself be of good ways') (01/04/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 182: oëí akxa/oëú akxa/oëó akxa <u-zhu´- a-ka> the person himself, personally, self.

óëo áhkiëì. VP [reg., óëo áhkiëì] [hkik- REFL + óëo áëi] (intr.) be proud of oneself, be conceited (RBn HW). líe ðáha óëo áhkiëi ðí áape when she came back she was proud of herself (RBn19-03). súhkahtâà mîìka hcí nalôòhkile ðáalì káaãe che óëo áhkiëi ðí áape turkey hen was proud [of herself] because she could hide [for herself] her nest so well (RBn19-05).          

•• LFD 182: oëo áhkiëì <u-zhu a´-Ði'zhiæ> conceit, vainglorious, egotism, pride.

óëo ákiëì (variant: óëo ákiëi). VP [reg. ki-ret. + sync. nasal vowel stem, óëo á_kiëa_ì (object pronominal or portmanteau subject-object prefix wi- in the first slot, subject pronominal in second slot; underlying stem is ákiëaì (ákiëai), seen when there is a subject pronominal in the second slot (akíëami 'I am proud of', akíëaëi 'you are proud of', etc.), but becomes ákiëì (ákiëi) when no subject pronominal precedes the ì)] [kik- SUU + óëo áëi] (trans.) be proud of one's own (as of one's relative). ëìkáëì wíhta óëo áwakiëami I'm proud of my children (RBn HW). óëo áwikiëami I'm proud of you (RBn HW; RBn22-0). ëìkáëì óëo áwakiëi akxai he's proud of his children (RBn10-15;gloss by CQ). oëo áwikiëamí àhé I'm proud of you (RBn10-15;RBn HW-MREI).

óëo áëi (variants: oëóaëì, óëo áëai, óëo áëaì). VP, ADJP [reg.+sync. nasal vowel stem, óëo á_ëa_i (object pronominal or portmanteau subject-object prefix wi- in the first slot, subject pronominal in second slot; underlying stem áëaì/áëai becomes áëì/áëi when no subject prefix precedes the ì)] (trans.) (be) proud, proud of. óëo áðiëi apai they're proud of you (RBn HW). táatà owáðakihkà óëò [áëì?] mìkçé I'm proud of what you did to help them (RBn10-21; CQ EN gloss). • admire. hci wì oëóaëì akxai they're admiring a house (FH/09/11/01/pc).

•• LFD 187: ihkóða wihta oëo aáëì mikçe o <i-Ðo´-tha wi-¾a u-zhu a-a´ zhiæ mi-kshe o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] he is my friend, I hold him in esteem.

••• Cf. aëî. 

óëokØa. N bet, wager (04/07/95/PM/pc:okc, PM, FH ok'd óëokØa, not óëokØà).

•• LFD 183 (unconfirmed): óëokØà <u´-zhu-Ð'oæ> a wager (04/07/95/PM/pc:okc: not à). [Mod. Os. speakers have óëokØa, not forms with final nasal vowel (**óëokØà, ** óëokØò).] óëokØà hpaãe <u´-zhu-Ð'oæ ¼a-xe> I made a wager. óëokØà çkaãe <u´-zhu-Ð'oæ shka-xe> you made a wager. óëokØà àkaãa pe <u´-zhu-Ð'oæ oæ-ga-xa i> we made a wager.

óëokØa káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, óëokØa _káaãe ] (intr.) make a bet.

óØie (variant of óie).

ô. V [sync. nasal vowel stem, _ô (1st dual/pl. àô 'we do' > òô or ôò)] (trans.) do, engage in (an activity [rare usage]). àhíiða çki ôò hta àkái we are also going to swim (RBn3-32). ónòbre àkáðì tà áçihta àwánòbre çkí ôò htai we have food, so we will have a picnic (lit., 'since we have food, let's also do a meal outside') (BE2.102; 03/07/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• Cf. ékiò, éò, háaò. 

ôðàëi (variant of óðàëi).

òô (variant: ôò). V [1st pl. form of ô 'do']. we do (rare usage).

ôò (variant: òô). V [sync., nasal vowel stem, (á)_ôò (1st sg. and 2nd person subject forms, regularly môò and ëôò, respectively, may have an additional initial accented á, the status of which is unclear: ámòò, áëòò áëôè)] (trans.) suffer from, have as an illness, be sick from. [Perhaps more literally 'be enveloped by (sickness)', '(sickness) lies upon s.o.'; cf. the meaning 'wear' below.] Mary mâàke púze òô nàðe áape Mary has tuberculosis (FH/09/24/01/pc/prod). húheka çki òô ðée apai sickness lies over them [envelops them] too (FH: prayer). waðílà waxpáì òô ðée apai worry is upon them (FH/09/24/01/pc). húheka òô ðée apai there are those whom sickness lies over (FH/09/24/01/pc).  hóxpe òô akxai he's got a cold (5/12/83/4). Christine akxa hóxpe òô îkçe? does Christine have a cold? (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).
