Smokey akxa hóxpe òô akxai Smokey has a cold (RBn19-01). wácini òô akxai he or she had VD (BE2.31). hóxpe hpíiëi òô akxái she has whooping cough (FH:08/22/96). hóxpe hpíiëi [m]ôò mìkçé I have a bad cold (RB). hóxpe môè mìkçé I have a cold (FH/11/19/01/pc:ok). hóxpe ëôè? do you have a cold? • wear, use. môè I wear it. ëôe you wear it. îhìhtà môò mìkçé I'm wearing earrings (5/12/83/4). haaská çäúuce ámòì I'm wearing warm clothes (FH). haaská çäúuce áëò ðàìçé you're wearing warm clothing. haaská òô àkxai she's wearing a dress (01/19/95/FH/prod). ììhì htà ôò akxai he or she is wearing earrings. îhìhtà àkôò àkatxai we're wearing earrings (5/12/83/4). îhìhtà àkôò àkáðe we're wearing earrings (5/12/83/4). wanôpØè òô put on the necklace, wear the necklace. ákahami ôò kçíe put a shawl on her (03/08/95/FH/pc). ípehì sí kçe ôò kçíe put a pillow under his foot (lit., 'have him have his foot be enveloped by a pillow') (03/08/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 8: ákahami ohpa hà <a´-ga-ha-mi u-pa hoæ> I wear a coat. ákahami oçpa hà <a´-ga-hami u-shpa hoæ> you wear a coat. ákaha mi akihpi ðìke xci mò ha <a´-ga-ha mi a-gi-¼i thiæ-ge xtsi moæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: ákahamì akihpi (?) ðìké/ðìkçé xci môò 'I am wearing a coat really not (ahkipi)'; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] my coat is threadbare. LFD 37: tósku mò ha <do´-škiu moæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: tóoske môò; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I have the hiccups. tósku ëò ha <do´-škiu zhoæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: tóoske ëôò; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you have the hiccups.

••• QU Øò use, have (as a disease) (RR).

ôòða (variant: óoðaðe). V [reg.+sync., _ôò_ða (possibly ôòða and ôòðe have the same base form,

[_]ôò_ða[_]ðe)] (trans.) throw away, throw, leave or quit s.o., discard s.o. or s.t., toss out (FH,pc, 8/8/94). aôòbra ~ ôòbra ~ aôòbre ~ ôòbre I throw it away. ðaôòçta ~ ðaôòçce ~ ôòçta ~ ôòçce you throw it away. John apa Mary ôòðape John quit Mary (03/22/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 122: ôða <oæ´-tha> to throw away, to dispense. aôbra <a-oæ´-btha> I throw away (03/22/95/FH/pc:okc). ðaôçta <tha-oæ´-shta> you throw away (03/22/95/FH/pc: ðaôòçäe). àôða pe <oæ-oæ´-tha i> we throw away. (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. hkíòðe. 

ôòðe. V [(reg.+) sync., (_)ôò_ðe (possibly ôòða and ôòðe have the same base form, [_]ôò_ða[_]ðe)] (trans.) throw away, discard, leave behind, remove, as from office (FH). áòòbra I threw something away (FH/t116b). káache ôòbre hta mìkçé I'm going to throw away that stuff [stack of trash] (FH/t116b). níhka akxa hkilíisàpi iáha òòwíbre tà wakØâ hta mìkçé áape the man turned around and said, "I'll sure be glad when I get rid of you" (RBnot 79/p4). ðaôòçäe? did you throw it away? (FH/t116b). kîìkììeëì hlaaskáëì éðòòpa ôòðe aðáape he went leaving the flowers and butterflies behind (RBn15-03). • quit s.o., divorce or separate from. wôòbre I left them, I quit them [from waôòbre]. John apa Mary ôòðe hta apai John is going to quit Mary (03/22/95/FH/pc). Mary apa ôòðe ðiiçtâ apai Mary has already quit him (FH/t116b). John apa Mary ôòðape John quit Mary (03/22/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 45: kahíke òða pe o <ga-hi´-ge oæ-tha bi o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] the chief was removed from his office.

ôpe. N hip, hips, tail, buttocks (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). ôpe htâke big hips (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.67; BE2.74).

•• LFD 121: ôpe <oæ´-be> the buttocks.

••• Cf. letâ ôpe ëúuce. 

ôpeëahta (variant: úpeëahta). N scissortail (lit., 'tail divided') (BE2.117; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:uk; 04/13/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/20/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• RB: <u -peh zháh-tah>.

•• LFD 121: ôpeëahta <oæ´-be-zha-¾a> forked tail.

••• Cf. ëáhta. 

ôwò (variant of ówò).

pa. POSIT positional article for pl. nonsubject. ecí pa ëóàðale çíe ðe you brought me to them (lit., 'you went with me to those ones there'). súhkahtâà mîìka éëi pa wáðihota ìkçe ípahò ìkçi áape turkey hen knew she had done everything she could to fool the others [them] (RBn19-05). níhkaçi pa wáatòpa take care of those men [standing or sitting], look after those people.

••• Cf. tówa pa. 

pa (variant of pai).

pá. N snow. pá húðe akxa pá çkópe akxá the snow is deep (lit., 'the snow coming down is a deep snow') (03/13/95/PM; BE2.124). nuuëú pá ëóle húði akxai rain and snow are coming down together (FH:4/24/96/pc; BE2.123). pá xoce gray snow, dingy snow.

•• LFD 17: pa <ba> snow.

pá húðe. VP [uninfl.] (intr.) snow. pá húðe akxa it is snowing (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). pá húðe ðiiçtâ akxa it stopped snowing (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). pahúðape it snowed (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). N snow, snowfall, snow coming down, falling snow. pá húðe akxa pá çkópe akxá the snow [coming down] is [a] deep [snow] (03/13/95/PM; BE2.124).

•• RB: <pah-hyú-theh> (lit., 'snow coming down') (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 21: pahúðe <ba-hiu´-the> snowstorm.  

pa- (variant of paa-).

pá- INSTR by use of a sharp edge, by cutting. [Precedes pronominal prefixes; thus, páa- 'I . . . by cutting', páða- 'you . . . by cutting', pá- 'he/she . . . by cutting', àpá- 'we . . . by cutting'.] haatxâta páðaleke hta nîkçé súhka? when are you going to hatch, chicken? (lit., 'when will you shatter it by using a sharp edge, chicken?') (FH).

•• LFD 17: pa <ba> a prefix to denote the act of cutting with a knife, a verb prefix denoting an act is done with a stick, spear, or any other sharp thing.

••• WI màà- by cutting (KM); OM ma- by cutting (RL); LAK wa- by cutting (RL).

••• Cf. páse. 

paa- (variant: pa-). INSTR by pushing away or by hand, by pushing or pressing on s.t. (either compacting or spreading it), by pushing up and away with the hands (FH/04/24/96tape). [Follows pronominal prefixes and takes sync. fortisizing stop stem inflection; thus, hpaa- 'I . . . by pushing', çpaa- 'you . . . by pushing', paa- 'he/she . . . by pushing', àpaa- 'we . . . by pushing'. But unexpectedly (probably as a result of language disuse) some Mod. Os. verbs with paa- sporadically use reg. inflection: apaa- 'I . . . by pushing', ðapaa- 'you . . . by pushing', àpaa- 'we . . . by pushing'.] haatxâta çpáaleke hta nîkçé súhka? when are you going to hatch, chicken? (lit., 'when will you shatter it by pushing outward, chicken?') (FH).

••• OM ba- by pushing (RL); LAK pa- by pushing (RL); WI wa- by pressure or pushing (KM).

••• Cf. paaãówe, paahí, paasé, paaxcé.

paaché. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paaché ] [perhaps paa- INSTR + che POSIT] (trans.) sew. hpáache I sewed it. çpáache you sewed it. àpáache we sewed it.

•• LFD 24: paché <ba-tse´>to sew. hpáche <¼a´-tse> I sew. çpáche <shpa´-tse> you sew.

àpácha pe <oæ-ba´-tsa i> we sew.

••• Cf. wapáache. 

paacØî (variant: paacØí [FH]). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paacØî] [presumably contains paa- INSTR] (intr.) stoop over (as to touch one's toes), bend down. hpaacØîe I stooped over. çpaacØî you stooped over. ée paacØî akxai he is stooping over (MSB). • ADJ, V (intr.) (be) crooked (04/25/95/PM/pc).

•• RB: <pah-ts'íæ> (BE2.128; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:prod).

•• JOD (slip file): ëé ðiçtà tà, pacØî-aú, ápi aú <§Ce´ ¢üctaæ´ - §taæ, §páts'iæ -au´, á§pi au´> [expected Mod. Os. form: ëé ðiiçtâ tà, pacØî-a áape 'when he finished defecating, bend down, he said'] When he (a child) finished stooling, he said, Turn bottom up!

•• LFD 24: pacØî <ba-ts'iæ´> head down and feet up, headlong, head foremost (meanings unconfirmed; MREI).

••• Cf. paakØó. 

paacØó. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paacØó] [presumably contains paa- INSTR] (intr.) stoop over.  

paaãáce. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem?, _paaãáce?] (intr.) open out, spread, spread open, blossom, bloom. hlaaská akxa paaãáci akxai the flowers opened out.

•• JOD (slip file): paxáce <§pa-qa´-¦t¦se> crest of hair, parting of man's hair (JK). [Note discrepancy between JOD's x and Mod. Os. ã.]

••• Cf. opáaãa. 

paaãí. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem?, _paaãí?] [presumably contains paa-INSTR] (trans.) push to awaken or make active, activate by pushing on (RBn23-17). çíi apa oðíhtà paaãí apai they're pushing the car

(to start it) (RBn23-17).

•• JOD (slip file): paxí <§pa-qi´> to arouse once from sleep by pushing with a stick, etc., held firmly against him (?). [Note discrepancy between JOD's x and Mod. Os. ã.]

••• Cf. ðixí. 

paaãó. N hill, mountain (rare; variant of paaxó?) (LS, JOD); corner, angle (JOD).

•• JOD (slip file): paãó <§pa-xu´> modern word, a hill or bluff, a high hill or mountain. "The ancient word was §pahªe." paãó <§pa-xu´> an angle or corner. paãó tópa <§pa-xu´ §tú§pa> fourcornered.

paaãówe (variants: paaãó, paaãóe, páaão [MSB]). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paaãówe) [presumably contains paa- INSTR] (trans.) push along, push s.o. or s.t. steadily (making the person or object move along) (MSB 01/02; FH:4/24/96/tape:ok). wihpáaãowe I'm pushing you (FH). âçpaaão ðaìçé you're pushing me (FH/06/16/01/pc). paaxó paaãówe apai he's pushing the mountain (FH:4/24/96/tape).

paaxó paaãó apai he's pushing the mountain. ðée ðe paaãówe this one here, push him (FH:4/24/96/tape). âpaaão ìká! don't push me! (FH/07/02/01/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): paxówe <§pa-qu´-wªe> to make an obj., as a book on a table, slide or slip along by pushing it. [Note discrepancy between JOD's x and Mod. Os. and KS ã.]

••• KS mà baãówe the game of 'swing the arrow' (RR).

••• Cf. ðiiãó.

paahâ (variant: paahá). V [sync., fortisizing stop stem, _paahâ] [presumably contains paa- INSTR] (trans.) raise, hold up (RBn10-10:JW). hpáaha I raise it. çpáaha you raise it. àpáaha we raise it. çáake paahápi raise your hand (instructions uttered by the person saying the prayer to those present, before beginning to say the prayer at a birthday dinner or after a peyote meeting, etc., followed at the end of the prayer by íistahkie pi 'bless yourselves with it', instructing supplicants to pass the previously raised hand over their minds and their hearts). kaakônaa, çáake paahâpi, íçtahkíapai that's all, raise your hand, use it on yourself (FH). nòòpé paahâ raise your hand (as when voting by a show of hands) (RBn22-03). waahkíhta paahá pray for yourselves, raise it up (RBn10-15). waahkíhta paahá pray for each other, raise it up (RBn10-15).

•• LFD 49: kípaha <gi´-ba-ha> to show anything to another. hkawa wihta ehpaha tòpe ahkiðe ha <Ða-wa wi-¾a e-¼a-ha doæ-be a-Ði-the ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: hekáwa wíhta ée hpáahà tôpe akçíðe; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os. and kípaahà not attested] I showed him my horse (lit., 'my horse for him I raised up, I allowed him to see it'). màëâ ðitxaðà ðeçpaha <moæ-zhoæ´ thi-ta thoæ the-shpa-ha> you showed him your land.  

••• Cf. opáahà, táatà paahâ, watáahà. 

paahí (variant: paahî). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paahí] [perhaps contains paa- INSTR] (trans.) pick or gather (e.g., fruit, flowers), collect together or pick up (many small, scattered things) (RBnot-nd1/p21; FH/7/24/95/pc:okc). hpáahi I gather it. çpáahi you gather it. àpáahi she gathers it. háazu çpáahi? did you pick grapes? hápa àpáahi àkái we are picking corn. watástoe paahî toe àkái hce let's go pick pecans (RBn12-05). • sort (e.g., beans, clothing to be laundered). hòbrîke che hpaahíke [ke 'scattered'] I sorted the beans (FH:ok). hòbrîke hpáasihi mìkçé [hpáasihi rather than hpáahi is unexpected] I'm sorting the beans (FH/11/17/01/pc). hòbrîke paahí akxai he's sorting the beans (FH/11/17/01/pc). hòbrîke che paahí apai they're sorting the beans (FH/11/17/01/pc). haaská wasúhuëi ke paahípai, çäúuwasu htai be sorting the dirty clothes [pl. addressee], let's you [pl.] wash them (FH/11/17/01/pc).

•• LFD 21: pahí <ba-hí> to pick, as selecting one from many; to sort, to sort the good from the bad; picked, selected, the best. LFD 65: hòbrîke che hpahi <hoæ-bthiæ´-ge tse ¼a-hi> I sorted the beans.

••• Cf. wapáahi. 

paahí. N diamonds (suit in a deck of cards) (03/10/95/FH/pc:ok; (RBn10-21/JW).

páahi [JOD] (variant of hpaahî). [This form perhaps is simply a misrecording by JOD.]

paahî (variant of paahí 'pick or gather').

paahléke (variant of paaléke).  

paakíce. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paakíce] [probably paa- INSTR + an otherwise unattested stem kice 'squeak' (LF)] (intr.) play music on an instrument. • N musical instrument, piano [Osage has no special words for other instruments (except drum) (LS)] (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p42; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.91; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; FH/09/22/01/pc; BE2.91). • music. paakíce káaãe make music.

•• JOD (slip file): pakíce <§pa-§ki´-§t§se> to play a fiddle.

•• LFD 20: pakíce <ba-gi´-dse> a fiddle. pakice kçe spákice ha <ba-gi-dse ke spa´-gi-dse ha> [expected Mod. Os form: paakíce çpáakice; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] you play the fiddle.  

páakØa (variant: páaxa). N cottonwood (HRE).

•• RB: <báh-xah, bah´-kØah> (BE2.25; RBn23-08;HRE/12/29/01/pc: both ok).

•• JOD (slip file): pákØa <§pa´-k'a> a cottonwood tree, cottonwood.

paakØó (variant: paakØô). V [sync., fortisizing stop stem, _paakØó] (trans.) dig (e.g., a grave) (RBnot-nd1/p22); (intr.) stoop over (a little) (1/27/83/p1). [The triplet paacØì, paacØó, and paakØó apparently show consonant and vowel symbolism.]

•• LFD 22: pákØo <ba-Ð'u´> to dig a ditch. hpákØo <¼a´-Ð'u> I dig a ditch. çpákØo <shpa´-Ðu> you dig a ditch. àpákØo pe <oæ-ba´-Ð'u i> we dig a ditch.

paaléke (variant: paahléke [historically paaxléke]). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paaléke] [paa- INSTR + léke] (intr.) hatch, shatter by pushing outward. [Refers to birds pushing outward on the shell of an egg until it breaks; contrasts with pá_leke 'hatch, shatter by using a sharp edge' (with instrumental pá- 'by using a sharp edge'), which refers to birds' beaks cutting the eggshell (FH).] hpáaleke I hatch. çpáaleke you hatch. àpáaleke we hatch. haatxâta çpáaleke hta nìkçé, súhka? when are you going to hatch, chicken?

páaleze (variant: páleze). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _páaleze] [paa- INSTR + léze] (trans.) write s.t.

or make one's mark upon s.t., vote, vote for or against s.t. or s.o. (BE2.161; 04/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• KS baléze to make striped, to write lines (RR).

páalòðì (variants: paalôðì, paalôðe). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem? _páalòðì] [paa- INSTR + lôðì]

(trans.) impel s.o. to drunkenness, push s.o. to be drunk or upset, make s.o. nervous, talk s.o. silly (FH). ðée pa páalòði apai these here are all upset, all shook up (lit., 'these ones they've pushed them making them nervous') (FH).

paamâçi (variants: paamáçi, pamáçi). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paamâçi] [paa- INSTR + mâçi] (trans.) lift, hold up (e.g., a picture in front of a group of people in an auditorium), raise (e.g., a flag or a window) (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). hpáaëì paamáçi akxái he's holding up the baby (e.g., for people to see it). ìcé waléze hpaamáçi hta mìkçe I'll hold the picture up (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod). haaská paamáçi raise your shirt up (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 22: pamâçi <ba-moæ´-shi> to raise an object by pushing it upward with the hands or with a pole. hpámàçi <¼a´-moæ-shi> I raised the object with my hands. çpámàçi <shpa´-moæ-shi> you raised it with your hands. àpámàçi pe <oæ-ba´-moæ-shi i> we raised it with our hands.

paasása. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paasása] [reduplicated form of paasé] (trans.) dice by cutting over and over (lit., 'cut repeatedly by pushing down on') (FH). paasása! dice it! (RB) .

paasé. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paasé] [paa- INSTR + -se] (trans.) cut up (e.g., meat or potatoes), cut into pieces (e.g., a cake) (lit., 'cut by pushing down on'). htáa hpáase mìkçé I cut up meat.

haakôta wacúe skúe çpáase ðikôða apai? why did they want you to cut the cake? htáa çpáase nìkçé you cut up meat. htáa páase akxai he cuts up meat. htáa àpáase àkatxâi we cut up meat. • cut off by using a pushing motion. ëâà hpáase I'm cutting off a limb. çpáase hta ðaìçé? are you going to cut it off? (FH/11/17/01/pc). çpáasape? did you all cut it off? (FH/11/17/01/pc). àpáasape we cut it off (FH/11/17/01/pc).

        ••• Cf. páse.         

paasíke (variants: páasike, paasîke). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paasíke] (trans.) splatter, spray, splash, squirt, splinter, cause to fly out in pieces. wálìì hpíiëie óhesaëì alîì ðáha níi hpáasike it's awful that I sat down real quick and splattered water (04/19/95/FH/pc). hpáasike I splattered it (04/19/95/FH/pc). çtôpaëie ðalîì óhesaëì áha níi çpáasike you didn't look when you sat down hard, and you sat in water and splattered it, made it shoot out (04/19/95/FH/pc). • (intr.) splatter, spray, splash, squirt, splinter, fly out in pieces. ëâà akxa paasíke akxái the wood chips are flying out (lit., 'the wood is flying out in pieces') (04/19/95/FH/pc). ëâà kaasípi tà ëâàëì paasíke akxai when he cuts wood, the little splinters fly out (or 'when he cuts wood, he splinters it'?) (04/19/95/FH/pc).

paaspâ. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paaspâ] (trans.) touch with the fingers, nudge, punch. hpáaspà I touch it. çpáaspà you touch it. alîì çò mìkçé àpáaspàpe I was sitting there and he punched me (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc; 1/20/83/693).

•• LFD 19–20: paspâ <ba-špoæ´> to nudge with the hand, the elbow, or with a stick to attract the attention of another. hpáspà <¼a´-špoæ> I nudged with my hand. çpáspà <shpa´-špoæ> you nudged with your hand. àpáspà pe <oæ-ba´-špoæ i> we nudged with our hands.

paastôka. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paastôka] (trans.) soften by pushing on.

 •• JOD (slip file): pastôka <§pa-ctªuñ´-¦ka> to thrust a stick, etc., into a hole at a soft object, as at an animal covered with hair, or to see if the soft ob. is there. JOD (Devouring Mountain p2 lines 10–

11): wahôiëìka bráani na nâàce âpastòka ku káaãape áakxa ska <Wahuæ´i§ciñ´ka ¦p¢a´hniæ -na´ nªan´¦t¦se aæ´ pa-ctªuñ´-¦ka ¦ku kaxa§pi, á akqá ska> [JOD's ku káaãape <ku kaxapi> is likely kikáaãape in Mod. Os.] the orphan that I devoured made my heart turn soft, he said.

paaçcéka (variant of pààçcéka).

paaçé. CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 2nd pl. sitting/moving/lying down subject. ['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's locationin space do not count.] ëìkóhkiha ðíizo paaçé? are you all enjoying your grandchildren? íe àðánààkØò çkôçta ìké paaçé àëi iðáe àtxàhé you all don't want to hear me talk, but I'm talking (RBn10-16). ëìkáëì ókaçeìki paaçé? are your children okay? [note 2nd pl. use with ëìkáëì] [paaçé in this example pluralizes the understood 2nd person possessor of ëìkáëì] (RBn10-7:JW). kasî táatà hta paaçé? what are you [pl.] doing tomorrow? (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.142). howáìki paaçé? where are you all?

(04/28/95/LS/pc:ok:prod). • you are characterized by [the preceding expression, which may be a noun phrase]. hîì hpíiëi paaçé you [pl.] have bad teeth. waðílà hpíiëi paaçé you [pl.] have a bad temper.

••• Cf. ðaìçé. 

paaçpú (variant: paaçpé). N cut corn, fresh corn cut off the cob (01/12/95/FH/pc:ok, not preasp). [To prepare paaçpú, cut the corn off the cob, place it in boiling water, and cook it until it takes on the consistency of gravy.]

páaçpue. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _páaçpue] [presumably contains paa- INSTR] (trans.) peel (RBn10-16). záani hpaaçpue I peeled them all (RBn10-16)

••• Cf. ðuçpú. 

páaxa (variant of páakØa).

paaxcé. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paaxcé] [perhaps contains paa- INSTR] (trans.) tie down (e.g., a drum), place or push two or more things together and tie them; bind, handcuff, manacle. céãenii paaxcé apai they're tying a drum (RBn10-7:JW). • gather and tie in a bundle or bundles (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). hpáaxce I tied it into bundles (FH). çpáaxce you tied it into bundles (FH). àpáaxcape we tied it into bundles (FH). haxî haaskámì çki çpáaxce hta nìkçé? these blankets and shawls, are you going to gather them up and tie them in a bundle? paaxcí apai they are gathering [something] up and tying [it/them] in a bundle (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). paaxtáëi apai, paaxcáëi apai they're not gathering it/them up and tying it/them into a bundle (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). paaxtá! gather it/them up and tie it/them into a bundle! (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). haxî che paaxcé tie those blankets up (FH).

•• LFD 25: paxcé <ba-xtse´>to tie up into bundles as a sheaf. hpáxce <¼a´-xtse> I tied it into bundles. çpáxce <shpa´-xtse> you tied it up. àpáxca pe <oæ-ba´-xtsa i> we tied it up. paxcé <baxtse´> to manacle, handcuff, shackle. hpáxce <¼a´-xtse> I handcuffed [him]. çpáxce <shpa´-xtse> you handcuffed [him]. àpáxca pe <oæ-ba´-xtsa i> we handcuffed [him]. LFD 345: páxce <ba´- xtse> [same forms listed as for paxcé <ba-xtse´>] to tie a bundle.

••• Cf. ípaaxce. 

paaxó N hill, mountain. [Perhaps lit. 'rise, rise up from the earth' (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc). Also a name, probably shortened from paaxóska (Carl Kemohah was often called by this shortened form, used actively in the early 1900s by the other children growing up with him, among whom only Osage was spoken [FH]).] paaxóëì low hill, little hill (FH:4/25/96/tape; BE2.66). paaxó ìkçítxa àkókaxpai we threw him off the hill (RBn19-02). paaxó ki àkáipe we're going to the mountains (to express 'we're going to Colorado') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). paaxó ki aðáape they went to the mountains (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.90, RBn22-15). paaxó çcee a high hill or tall mountain.

•• LFD 26: paxó <ba-xu´> a hill, a ridge. paxó htâka <ba-xu´ ¾oæ-ga> a mountain.

••• OP baãú flat topped hill (mesa, butte), hilltop; KS baxó mountain (RR).

••• Cf. paaãó. paaxóska N White Mountain (personal name). [Carl Kemohah's name (Joe's brother), possibly an earth clan name.]

paaxô. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _paaxô] [paa- INSTR + xô] (trans.) break a long object by pushing, break off by pushing (e.g., a limb) (01/07/95/FH/pc; 04/19/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 25: paxô <ba-xoæ´> to break a stick, tent pole, or an awl by pushing. hpáxò <¼a´-xoæ> I broke the tent pole by pushing [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'I broke it by pushing']. çpáxò <shpa´xoæ> you broke the tent pole by pushing. àpáxò <oæ-ba´-xoæ> we broke the tent pole by pushing. ëâxa kçe hpaxò <zhoæ´-xa ke ¼a-xoæ> I broke the stick [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'I broke the stick that was lying there'].

paazé. N breast, udder. paazé wáli lâàðe akxai she has [lit., 'is characterized by'] really big breasts (BE2.12; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 18: pazé <ba-še´> a woman's breast. [LF's alternate term màzé <moæ-še´> 'woman's breast' (LFD 96) is not Osage; it is probably Omaha.]  

paazénii. N [paazé + níi] milk (lit., 'breast liquid') (BE2.87; 02/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• RB: <báh-zeh-ni>.

•• LFD 18: pazéni <ba-še´-ni> milk. pazéni skiðe <ba-še´-ni ški-the> sweet milk. pazéni niwekØuce(?) wì <ba-še´-ni ni-we-Ð'u-dse wiæ> a quart of milk (unconfirmed; 03/01/95/FH/pc:uk

'quart').

paazénii ðiiscúe. VP [sync., paazénii _ðiiscúe] (trans.) milk (LF).

•• LFD 19: pazéni ðiscue <ba-še´-ni thi-stsu-e> to milk. paséni, briscue <ba-še´-ni, bthi-stsue> I milk. paséni àðiscua pe <ba-še´-ni oæ-thi, stsu-a i> we milk.

••• QU distíhte pull open, milk, pull out (RR).

paazénii saakí. N cheese (03/07/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 18: pazéni saki <ba-še´-ni ša-gi> cheese. pazéni saki àzo <ba-še´-ni ša-gi oæ-šu> I like cheese. pazéni saki ðizo <ba-še´-ni ša-gi thi-šu.> you like cheese.

paazénii skúðe. N sweet milk.

paazénii wéli. N butter (lit., 'milk grease') (BE2.14; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok); cream.

•• LFD 19: pazéniweli <ba-še´-ni-we-gthi> cream. pazéniweli waskiðe itápe àso <ba-še´-ni-wegthi wa-ški-the i-da´-be oæ-šu> [expected Mod. Os. form: waskúðe paazénii wéli áaëu âàzo] I like cream on fruit.

paazénii wéli saakí. N cheese (lit., 'hardened cream') (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod).

pábrakØa. V [reg., pá_brakØa] [pá- INSTR + brákØa] (trans.) flatten by cutting, make flat by using a sharp edge, plane (as wood with a woodplane).

 •• LFD 18: pábrakØa <ba´-btha-k'a> to flatten a piece of wood, or make smooth as with a plane. páðabrahka <ba´-tha-btha-Ða> you flattened the wood by cutting.

pacé (variant: páce). V [reg?., pa_cé?] [presumably contains pá- INSTR] butcher. hceeská wî páce hta apái they're going to kill a beef (FH: 07/24/95, 4/17/96, FH/4/22/96/tape).

••• Cf. hpáce.

páce (variant: pacé). N boat. pacíolìì. N [páce + olîì] boating.

paðe (variant of pai).

paðé (variant: páðe). N winter (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.159). [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] hôòpa wî páðe ehtáha one day toward winter, one winter day (RBn16-02).

•• RB: <páh-théh>.

•• LFD 24: páðe <ba´-the> winter. páðe ce ëà oðaà htahce ani kçe ahì <ba´-the dse zhoæ u-tha-oæ ¾a-¾se a-ni ke a-hiæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: páðe che ëâà açcî hta nìkçé?] have you wood for the winter? páðe che ëà abrì ha<ba´-the tse zhoæ a-bthiæha> [expected Mod. Os. form: páðe che ëâà abrî; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I have my wood for the winter. paðíhta. ADJ last. mîìòòpa paðíhta last month (HH/t38-a-p1; 04/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

páðo (variant: páðò). N locust, insect (RBn3-55; 02/16/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.80).

•• LFD 24: páðo <ba´-tho> harvest fly, locust. páðo apa ëàape ke ðasni a po <ba´-tho a-ba zhoæa-be ge tha-šni a bo> [expected Mod. Os. form: páðo apa ëâàpe ke ðaachá pe; the form ðasni was never an Osage form (it is probably Omaha), and a po is not recognized by Osage speakers] the locust eats the leaves of trees.

pae (variant of pai).

paãíce (variant: paãîce). V [stat., _paãíce] (intr.) sweat, perspire (RBn10-21/JW). wálì âpaãici mìkçé I'm sure sweating (RBn10-21/JW).

•• LFD 24: paãíce <ba-xi´-dse> to perspire. âpaãice <oæ´-ba-xi-dse> I perspire. ðípaãice <thi´ba-xi-dse> you perspire. wápaãica pe <wa´-ba-xi-dsa i> we perspire.

 ••• KS baãîýe (baãîýape) sweat, perspire (stative JOD) (RR).

páhììëi (?) (variant: páìëi [JOD]). V [reg., pá_hììëi] [pá- INSTR + hîì 'slivers, small strips' + aëí NEG] (trans.) fail to cut due to dullness of the knife.

•• JOD (slip file): páìëi, páìpáëi <§pa´-iæ-§ci>, <§pa´-iæ-§pa´-§ci> to fail in cutting with a knife, because of its dullness. páaì máëi <§páaiæ-má§ci> I fail to cut. páðaìëi <§pá¢a-iæ-§ci> you fail to cut.  

••• Cf. hpaahîëi.

pahúkaaski. N [pá húðe + kaaskí] snowball (lit., 'compressed snowfall') (01/10/95/FH/pc:prod).

pai (variants: paiðe, paðe, pae, pa). SUFFIX continuative imperative plural postverbal marker (follows the verb and signals that the speaker desires that the addressee [always pl.] continue the action of the verb into the future; can be approximately translated 'be doing [the action of the verb], continue to do [the action of the verb], go along doing [the action of the verb]' [FH]). [Replaces api.] ðée ékiò pai àðákisuðe çkôçtapi tà do this in remembrance of me (lit., 'be doing this whenever you want to remember me') (FH/09/11/01/pc). wahkôta akxa eená hta akxa na, hpahâle mêì, ahkílaðì pai soon it will be only God, put him first, [be] carry[ing] yourself that way (04/04/99/FH/pc). înòhpa pai, wécØa ochía be careful (lit., 'be going along carefully'), there are lots of snakes. haaská wasúhuëi ke paahí pai, çäúuwasu htai be sorting the dirty clothes, let's you [pl. addressee] wash them (FH/11/17/01/pc). táatà hôòëi ecíkie tà ékiò ðìkápai if there's anything bad around, don't do [be doing] that. hpéece íiçtahkipa [íiçtahkiðepa] use [be using] the fire to bless yourselves (PM:04/07/95/pc). okíhkàpái! you all help [be helping] him out! (RB; 02/09/95/FH/pc:okc). àhkihtôpa pai you all watch [be watching] each other, take [be taking] care of each other.

•• LFD 24 (unconfirmed): pa ðì ho <ba thiæ ho> [expected Mod. Os. form: pái] an emphatic expression used at the end of a sentence. onàlì pa ðì ho <u-noæ-xthiæ ba thiæho> hurry up. xìðaða pa ðì ho <xiæ-tha-tha ba thiæ ho> [sentence-final ho in the above examples is not used in Mod. Os.] be quick.  

páìëi (variant of páhîìëi?).

páleke. V [reg., pá_leke] (intr.) hatch; (trans., intr.) shatter by cutting or using a sharp edge. [Contrast with paaléke.] haatxâta páðaleke hta nîkçé súhka? when are you going to hatch, chicken?

páleze (variant of páaleze).

pamáçi (variant of paamâçi).

panáa. V [conjug. unknown; may be reg., _panáa] (intr., trans.) adjourn, be adjourned, stop, pause, recess, disband, end, break up (as a meeting), "let out" (e.g., school for summer recess), be dismissed (as at the end of a school day). àpánaa hce let's [two people] adjourn (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok). àpánaa htai let's [more than two people] adjourn (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod orig). kaatxá àpánaa htai let's stop a while [more than two people]. taapóska apa panáipe school is out (12/30/94/FH/pc:corr). waëáëi íe íkØuce hàðé hôòpa tóe àpánaa htai let's adjourn our Osage language class this evening for a few days (lit., 'trying to talk Osage, we're going to let out for a while' [FH]) (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok; BE2.1). taapóska panáa school is dismissed [said at the close of the school day], school is out [for the summer] (03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.116).

•• LFD 22: panâða <ba-noæ´-tha> to disband, to adjourn a meeting. panâðe <ba-noæ´-the> recess.

pánihkáçie. N [pá + nihkaçie] snowman. pánihkaçie wì káaãape he made a snowman (RBn23-14).

papó. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) sink, lower, go down (e.g., the sun when setting) (HRE/01/17/02/pc). [Possibly hpapó?]

••• Cf. mîìhpapo. 

pásàci. N north (LF only, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 19: pásàci <ba´-šoæ-dsi> north (unconfirmed; 03/01/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/17/95/LS/pc:uk).

pascé (variant: paçcé). V [reg., pa_scé] [pá- + scéce] (trans.) cut up, slice into strips or slices using a sharp edge (e.g., bananas, sausage, watermelon). wacúe skúe paðáçce hta ðàìçé? are you going to cut up the cake? hcéska wì pascé hta apai they're going to cut up a beef.

páse. V [reg., pá_se] [pá- + -se] (trans.) cut with a sharp edge. wacúe skúe paðáse kôða apai they're wanting you to cut the cake. páase I cut it with a sharp edge. paðáse you cut it with a sharp edge. àpásape we cut it with a sharp edge.

•• LFD 18: páse <ba´-še> to cut hair, cord, or rope with a knife. wéðì kçe páase o <we´-thiæ ke ba´-a-še o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I cut the rope. wéðì kçe páðase o <we´-thiæ ke ba´-tha-še o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] you cut the rope. wéðì kçe àpasa pe <we´-thiæ ke oæ-ba-ša i> we cut the rope. LFD 24 (unconfirmed): páðase <ba´-tha-še> [expected Mod. Os. form páse] to cut as when butchering [gloss should probably be 'you butcher'].

páskuha (variant: paskúha). ADV, PPN alongside, beside, adjacent, parallel (to). çí kôkòe apai, ëìkáëì apa páskuha nààkí apai he went round and round, children ran beside him (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). óëàke paskúha beside the road.

•• LFD 19: paskú <ba-škiu´> near, side by side, contiguous, adjacent.

••• KS baskåha nearby, close, parallel (RR).

paçcé (variant of pascé).

paçô (variant of paçôwe).

paçôçòwe V [presumably reg., pa_çôçòwe] [reduplicated form of paçôwe] (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc) (trans.) bind.

•• LFD 358: paçôçò <ba-shoæ´-shoæ> zigzag.

paçôwe (variants: paçô, paçôwì). V [reg., pa_çôwe] (trans.) bind (as a blanket), using a zigzag pattern on the edges. haxî kóoci çäúuwasu tà wíe paaçôwì, hcéka éekò hta akxai if you will clean that old [striped] blanket, I'll bind it and it will be like new (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). brúuwasu tà ðíe paçôwa if I clean it, you bind it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). haxî ìkçé páðaçò hta ðàìçé? are you going to bind the blanket? (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

pátà. CONJ when, and. [Often appears in speeches as a default connector of phrases, pronounced pœtƒ.]

•• JOD (slip file): pátà <§pa´-¦taæ> when, and; it often connects verbs in the pl., but sometimes it refers to the 3rd sg.

páxoce. N [pá + xóce] Ioway or Iowa Indians (a tribe living in Nebraska, Kansas, and Oklahoma and in earlier days in Iowa) (lit., 'gray snow'). [In the Ioway language, Baxoje 'gray snow'; refers to the soot-tainted snow from cooking and lodge fires covering Chakirutha lodges (wigwams, long houses) when the Oto-Missouri reunited with the Baxoje after decades of separation (Jimm Goodtracks).]

•• RB: <páh-xó-tseh> (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.71).

•• JOD (slip file): páxoce <§pa´-qu-¦t¦se> Ioway.

•• LFD 25: páxoce <Ba´-xo-dse> the name of the Iowa tribe of Indians living in the State of Nebraska.

pázà htá hu. N east wind, "fall winds" (PM) (probably lit. 'comes [(a)hú] from the pines [cf. páze hú]') (RB, unconfirmed).

•• RB: <páh-zah-táh-hu or péh-zeh-táh-hu> (BE2.38, unconfirmed; 12/30/94/FH/pc:uk; 04/26/95/LS/pc:uk).

•• LFD 19: pázàhi <ba´-šoæhi> spruce or pine trees. pázà <ba´-šoæ> from the cedars, the north, a ritual term (04/25/95/PM/pc:ma, unconfirmed).

••• KS bázàtta east wind, power of the east (wind) [may have long vowel: báa] (RR).

páze hú. N pine wood, pine tree (RBn HW13).

•• JOD (slip file): pázà hü <¦pa´-¦saæ> a pinetree.

pazó. N inedible red berry that grows in the woods (FH).

•• LFD 20: pazó <ba-šu´> pokeweed (Veratrum viride).

••• KS bazó pokeberry (RR).

pazó ekô. ADJ, N maroon, dark red color (lit., 'resembling berries').

•• RB: <báh-zó-eh-kóæ> (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc; FH:5/02/96/okc; BE2.84).

••• KS bazó ego purple, the color of pokeberries (RR).

pázo. N finger; score or point(s) in a game (BE2.117; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok: pazó).

••• Cf. opázo, pázo, wéapazo. 

páëahta (variant: paëáhta). V [reg., pá_ëahta] (trans.) brand (lit., 'slit by using a sharp edge'), slit, divide, notch, or make forked.

•• LFD 26: páëahta <ba´-zha-¾a> to mark an animal, as a horse, cow, or pig, by slitting the ears. páaëahta <ba´-a-zha-¾a> I slit the horse's ear to mark it. páðaëahta <ba´-tha-zha-¾a> you slit the horse's ear to mark it. páàëahta pe <ba´-oæ-zha-¾a i> we slit the horse's ear to mark it.

paëáëaki (variants: paaëáëa?, paaëâëà?). N [reg., pá- 'by using a sharp edge' + ëáhta 'forked']

[reduplication of truncated ëáhta] zigzag (FH; 04/20/95/LS/pc:okc), zigzag pattern on each side of a woman's yarn belt (04/20/95/LS/pc:prod; BE2.163).

•• RB: <bah-zháh-zhah>.

•• LFD 271: paëáke <ba-zha´-ge> forked. LFD 358: paçôçò <ba-shoæ´-shoæ> zigzag cutting.  

••• Cf. paçôçòwe, paçôwe, páëahta. 

paëí (frequent combination of postverbal plural or 3rd person noncontinuative marker api plus negative aëí; see api and aëí).

pâ. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _pâ] (intr.) holler, yell, scream, shout. níhkaçie tówa apa pâ àpái áapa those people coming there are just hollering, they're saying (01/04/95/FH/pc:okc;

FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). pâ àpai áapa they're hollering they say (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

•• LFD 28: pâ <boæ> to call, to shout. àpâ pe <oæ-boæ´ i> we call or shout. pà hósaki <boæ hu´ša-gi> to call or shout loudly.

••• KS bà call out, proclaim publicly (RR).

••• Cf. kípà. 

pààçcéka (variants: pòòçäéka, paaçcéka). N strawberry. pààçcéka wacúesku hpáaãe I made a strawberry cake.

•• RB: <bah-shtséh-kah> (BE2.129; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc).

•• LFD 23: pascéka <ba-stse´-ga> strawberry. pascéka apa nòbre ðalì <ba-stse´-ga a-ba noæ-bthe tha-gthiæ> strawberries are good to eat. pascéka àðalì nà aða <ba-stse´-ga oæ-tha-gthiæ noæ a-tha> [expected Mod. Os. form: pààçcéka âðaalì] I like strawberries. pascékahu <ba-stse´-ga-hiu> strawberry vine, the berry is called <ba-stse´-ga>.

pe (very frequent combination of postverbal plural or 3rd person noncontinuative marker api plus declarative ðe; see api).  

pe POSIT positional article for a pl. entity in nonrandom arrangement. wéewina záani pe I'm grateful to you all [sitting or standing in rows, not in random pattern] (RBn22-13). ëâà pe trees (planted in a regular formation such as in rows or in a line; contrast ëâà ke 'trees [as in a forest, occurring naturally with no pattern]').  

pé ðaha. N [derivation unknown] diamonds (suit in a deck of cards) (03/10/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn10-21/JW). •• LFD 84, 253: hkéhpa <Ðe´-¼a> diamond in a deck of cards [perhaps hkée 'turtle' + hpá 'head'].

pée. N springtime, spring. • V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) be spring. pée tà in the spring, in springtime, when it is spring. pée tà nuuëú çtà in the spring, it rains a lot (03/14/95/FH/okc; BE2.126).

•• LFD 26: pe <Be> spring of the year. pe akxa ni pi a <be a-ka hni bi a>[expected Mod. Os. form: pe akxa nípe] it is a cold spring. pe tà oi nà pi a laska cuhu apa <be doæ u-i noæ bi a xtha-ška tsu-hu a-ba> [probable Mod. Os form: pée tà hlaaskácúuhu apa ówe nàpe] violets grow in the spring (lit., 'when it's spring, violets grow').

pée. INTERR/INDEF PRON who, whom, to who(m). Johna haxî pée kØú e? who did John give the blankets to? (MSB 03/93). Johna pée haxî wakØú e? who [pl.] did John give the blanket(s) to?

(03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok) çée txa pée ðe? who is that standing over there? (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). hkáwa ðé txa pée íhta? whose horse is that over there? (lit., 'that horse standing there, to whom does he belong?'). káa íe txa pée txa? who is that who is talking? ká níhka íe txa pée txa? who is that person who is talking? pée oðáake hta ìkçe? whose bid is it? çáake oolôkØò pée íiðaðe? who did you see at the handgame? pée ðàìçé? who are you [sg. moving]? pée nìkçé? who are you [sg. sitting]? pée ðaaçé? who is it? (asking the person who knocked at the door, lit., 'who are you?') (MSB 02583).

• whose turn? pée hta ìksé? whose turn? (lit., 'who will it be?') (04/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.146). • anybody, anyone, nobody, no one. pée kípàpaëíe he didn't invite anybody (FH:ok, reconf; 5/12/83/rbnot D). pée kípàëí akxai he's not inviting anybody (FH:prod). pée aðée ìké hta ðé? isn't anybody going? (MRB02583). pée aðée ìké hta apai nobody is going (MRB02583). pée ðaaëî hta apai nobody is going (MRB02583). hcí wî pçíe, pée ðìké I went to the house, no one was there (lit., 'nobody was at the house that I went to') (BE2.157).

 •• LFD 26: pe <be> whoever, any one of them, a ritual term. pe a(?) <be a(?)> who is it? pé ewaðakçe a <be´ e-wa-tha-ke a> [expected Mod. Os. form: pée waðáakçe? sentence-final a is not used in Mod. Os.] who do you mean?

pée háanà. INTERR/INDEF PRONP who all (lit., 'who how many'). Johna akxa pée háanà wéeðe ðe? who all did John see?

pée íhta. INTERR/INDEF VP whose (lit., 'who owns [it]?' or 'to whom does it belong?'). hkáwa ðé txà pée íhta? whose horse is that [standing] over there? (lit., 'that horse standing there, to whom does it belong?') (RBn1-46).

péeçki. INTERR/INDEF PRON [presumably pée + çki] everybody. péeçki ípahòpe everybody knows him. • nobody. koe ónòò ëiçò çí tà çî tà koe hpíiëi ëiçò çí tà koe péeçki ðikôða htai wáçäuãe ðáalì before you get old and before you get fat and ugly and nobody wants you, you should get married.

• anybody. péeçki kípàpaëíe he didn't invite anybody.

pi (form of the postverbal plural or 3rd person noncontinuative marker api; see entry api.)

pi (variant of api).

pi- INSTR by blowing (as on a fire to get it started, dust from a table top, dandelion fluff into the wind, anything from the palm of the hand).

pi ché (see api SUFFIX, che EVIDENTIAL).

píãà (variants: píãa, piãâ, piãô). V [conjug. unknown (sync. fortisizing stop stem?, _píãà?)] (FH) (trans.) blow (as one's nose), blow on s.t. (e.g., blow into a fire, blow dust off a surface, blow a dandelion away in the wind, blow on a burnt finger to relieve pain) (FH: à). hpá piãâ! hpa piãô! blow your nose!

•• LFD 27: píãò <bi´-xoæ> to make a fire burn by blowing. hpíãò <¼i´-xoæ> I made the fire burn by blowing. çpíãò <shpi´-xoæ> you made the fire burn by blowing. àpíãò pe <oæ-bi´-xoæ i> we made the fire burn by blowing [gloss should be 'blow' and should not mention fire burning].

••• KS biãâ blow on a fire to make it burn (JOD) (RR).

••• Cf. opíãà. 

pixô. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem?, _pixô?] [presumably pi- INSTR + xô] break down (presumably by blowing upon) (LFD 237, unconfirmed). [Based on LF, expected forms are hpíxà 'I break down', çpíxò 'you break down', àpíxòpe 'we break down'.]

pó. N blackhaws (JOD only).

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p21 ln7): po <¦pu>.

pó-. INSTR by means of sudden intrusive action (e.g., 'by shooting', 'by punching').  

••• Cf. pólòðì. póbraska. V [reg.?, pó_braska?] [presumably pó- INSTR + bráaska] (trans.) flatten by shooting (LF, unconfirmed).  

pólòðì. V [reg.?, pó_lòðì?] [pó- INSTR + lôðì] (trans.) startle, shock (as with suddenly emerging news); ADJ, V (intr.) (be) startled, shocked.

pósu. N rice (RB; FH).

•• LFD 27: pósu <bo´-šu> rice.

••• KS sì wild rice (JOD) (RR).

pòòçäéka (variant of pààçcéka).

pçé. V [reg., _pçé] (trans.) pound. apçéðe I pounded it. ðapçéðe you pounded it. àpçáape we pounded it. ée pçápe they pounded it. pçá! pound it! apçá màëíe I didn't pound it (1/20/83). htaa ðápçe hta ðàìçé? are you going to pound meat? htáa waðápçe hta ðàìçé? are you going to pound meat? (6-30-94).

•• LFD 129: pçe <pshe> to pound corn into fine meal. apçé <a-pshe´> I pound. ðaçpé <thashpe´> [çp <shp> is presumably an error for pç <psh>] you pound. àpçá pe <oæ-psha´ i> we pound. hápa ðiçpi che apçe he <ha´-ba thi-shpi tse a-pshe he> [expected Mod. Os. form: hápa ðuçpú che ápçe 'I pounded the shelled corn' ] (w. sp. [presumably "woman speaking"]) I pounded the corn.

••• Cf. kípçe, nâãe kípçe. 

pu-. INSTR by pressing down on with movement back and forth (?); by smoothing. [Verbs with this prefix usually seem to be uninflected.]

••• Cf. púkxa, puçtáha, púze. 

púãa. V [conjug. unknown, uninfl.?] (trans.) dust off, clean off (RB, unconfirmed).

••• Cf. píãà. 

púkaçke (variant: påkaçke). N drop feathers (feathers such as those hanging on a staff in a Native

American Church meeting, above and to the left of the first group of feathers at the top). [In the

ilôòçka dance too, the men's dress has drop feathers; these hang to left side in Hominy, and in

Grayhorse to right side (HRE/12/29/01/pc).]  

púkxa (variant: pútkxa). V [sync./reg., _púkxa] (trans.) rub or wipe to efface, obliterate, erase, clean off or dust off by wiping, dry by wiping (01/09/95/FH/pc; BE2.19). áwanòbre ðapúkxa? did you wipe [clean/dust] the table? (05/01/95/LS). áwanòbre púutkxa wipe off the table (FH:4 /24/96/prod).

•• LFD 27: pikxá <bi-ka´> to efface, to erase; to obliterate, to wipe out. hpíkxa <¼i´-ka> I erase. çpíkxa <shpi´-ka> you erase. àpíkxa <oæ-bi´-ka> we erase. 

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 27).  

••• Cf. hîìce ípukxa, wépukxa. 

puçtáha (variants: puçtá, púçtaha). V [uninfl., or sync. fortisizing stop stem, _puçtáha.] [pu- INSTR + çtáha] (trans.) iron, smooth by pressing (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). púçtaha iron this (BE2.71). hpuçtáha maëi I don't iron (FH).

 •• RB: <pú-shtah-hah>.

 ••• Cf. wapúçtaha. 

pútkxa (variant of púkxa).

púuspe (variant: puuspé). V [uninfl.] (intr.) hide, conceal oneself; (trans.) hide or conceal s.t. púuspape they hid it. puuspé brée I'm going to go hide (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). púuspi akxai he's hiding (RBn1206). puuspé màðî go hide (RBn22-06).

púze. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) dry, wither (01/20/95/PM/pc:prod; BE2.37; 01/20/95/PM/pc:ok withered). hápa akxa áçihta púze akxa corn dries outside (FH:prod).

•• LFD 26: púze <biu´-še> dry, withered. laska the púze ha <xtha-ška te biu´-še ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: hlaaská ðe púze; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] the rose is withered. [In the following examples, all LF pi should be pu; all these examples are more accurately translated as 'I/you/we caused it to dry by heat', without specific mention of 'sun', 'fire', 'clothing'.] píze <bi´-še> dry. LFD 27: tápizekaãe <da´-bi-še-ga-xe> to dry wet clothing. tápize hpaãe <da´-bi-še ¼a-xe> I dried my clothes in the sun. tápize çkaãe <da´-bi-še shka-xe> you dried your clothes in the sun. tápize àkaãa pe <da´-bi-še oæ-ga-xa i> we dried our clothes by the fire. LFD 6 (unconfirmed): ápize <a´-bi-še> to become dry.

púzeðe. V [reg., púze_ðe] [púze + ðe CAU] (trans.) dry, cause to be dry. hápa áçihta púzeða! dry that corn outside!

 ••• Cf. ðuuláwa. 

pxáðaëi (variant: pxáëi). ADJ, V [uninfl.] [presumably contains aëí NEG] (intr.) (be) off in the head, (be) confused, not understand. pxáðaëi mìkçé I don't understand (RBn HW9). pxáðaëi akxai he doesn't understand (RBn HW9). • N demented or confused person.

••• Cf. kíopxaëi. 

sa (variant of sápe).

saakí. ADJ, ADV tight, tightly (03/22/95/FH:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p14). wahkâta íe saakí oðîìka hold tight to God's word (03/22/95/FH/pc). • ADJ firm, solid, hard (in texture), strong, muscular. htaacé saakí strong wind. níhkaçie saakípe he's a strong person (FH/06/27/01/pc). • difficult, hard to do things with. níhkaçie saakípe he's a person hard to do anything with (FH/06/27/01/pc).

•• LFD 29: sakí <ša-gi´> firm, solid, strong, hard.  

saakí çòòçôwe. ADJP permanent (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 29: sakíçòçòe <ša-gi´shoæ-shoæ-e> permanency, permanent.

saakíëìka. ADJ [saakí + ëìká] slim (lit., 'hard small') (LF).

•• LFD 29 (unconfirmed): sakíëìka <ša-gi´-zhiæ-ga> slim, slender, thin.

sáeëì (variant: sáiëì). N [sápe + -ëì 'little'] little black person.

••• Cf. níhka sápe. 

sáhku. N watermelon. sáhku çúpe zí yellow-meated watermelon (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.152).

•• LFD 29: sáhku <ša´-Ðiu> watermelon. sákhu ðache àzo çna aða <ša´-kiu tha-tse oæ-šu shna atha> [expected Mod. Os. form: sáhku ðaaché âzo çtà (çna was never an Osage form; probably Omaha)] I like watermelon.

sáhtà (variant: sáhta). ADJ, N five. htóoëu sáhtà abrî I have five meat pies (BE2.48; 01/26/95/FH/pc:ok, a/à).

sáhtà aëi. N [sáhtà + áëu] five-spot (the 'five' card in a deck of cards; perhaps lit. 'five scattered on' [LF]) (LF only).

•• LFD 29: sáhtà aëi <ša´-¾oæ a-zhi> five-spot in deck of cards.

sakí ho. N Sac and Fox (tribe or tribal member) (03/08/95/PM/pc:prod).

sakíwa (variant: sakíwo). N Sac and Fox (tribe or tribal member) (lit., 'making it tight' [PM:ok:]) (RBnote; 03/08/95/PM/pc:prod).

•• LFD 29: sakéwa <ša-ge´-wa> Sac and Fox. "This term is used when speaking of these tribes by the Osage."  

sakíëì. N [saakí + -ëì 'indeed'] Sac and Fox (tribe or tribal member).  

••• Cf. sakíwa. 

sápe (variant: sa). ADJ, N black (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.9). [Takes 'standing' positional article che.]

•• LFD 28: sápe <ša´-be> black. sápe che hkobra <ša´-be tse Ðoæ-btha> I prefer black. sape che çkòçta <ša-be tse shkoæ-shta> you prefer black.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 28).

••• Cf. çápe. sase. N [reduplicated form of -se] shavings.

••• Cf. mâàsase. 

sáta. ADJ stiff, rigid, stiffened. áa akxá sáta akxái his arm is stiff (03/14/95/FH/pc:okc). ëeká sáta mìkçé my legs are stiff (03/14/95/FH/pc; BE2.128).

•• RB: <sáh-táh>.

•• LFD 29: sáta <ša´-da> stiff, rigid, stiff-jointed.  

sâà. N forest. [LF only, unrecognized by Modern Osage speakers.]  

••• Cf. zâàce, zààcéolìì. 

scéce (variants: scé, scée [JS]). ADJ tall (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/05/95/JS/pc: scée only); long

(03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/05/95/JS/pc: scée only). kahíke scée Tall Chief, a name (03/16/95/FH/pc; BE2.133). kahíka scée Tall Chief (03/05/95/JS/pc:ok). scéce nî you're tall. paaxó çcee a high hill or tall mountain. huuscée very long in length, very tall (BE2.81; RBn2-MOJ/p3; 02/16/95/FH/pc:okc).

scéce káaãe lengthen, make longer, make taller.  

•• RB: <stéh-tseh>.

•• JOD (slip file): scéce <sté´-§t§se> long.

•• LFD 134: scecé <stse-dse´> tall, a tall man; long. LFD 209: walélescece <wa-xthe´-xthe-stsedse> a tall standard made by the Osage, also by the Kaw and the Omaha.  

scúuce (variant: çcúuce). ADJ slow.

••• Cf. wascúuce. 

-se. V ROOT cut. mààhîse cut grass (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod). paasé cut with any instrument by pushing down on, as cutting grass or cutting s.t. into pieces (e.g., cake, meat, potatoes). ípaase cut with. ðuusé cut with scissors or knife (e.g., hair). kaasé [with reg. kaa-del. inflection: 1st sg. áase, 2nd sg. ðáase, 3rd sg. kaasé] chop or cut into long thin sticks, mow lawn, cut down (e.g., a tree with an axe or knife, not by sawing); [with reg. kaa-ret. inflection: 1st sg. ákaase, 2nd sg. ðákaase] cut with a sudden or striking action (e.g., chopping meat, cutting down trees with an axe [not by sawing], cutting grass). páse cut by using a sharp edge (as in cutting a cake; contrast pacé 'butcher [chop by using a sharp edge]' and pascé, paçcé 'cut up, slice into strips').  

síekò. N [síi + ékò) meat pie (lit., 'foot-like', referring to the shape of the traditional meat pie). [Especially used in the Grayhorse district.] síekò wikçíãe I made a meat pie for you (RB; MREI 111-83-8; 02/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. htóoëu.  

síi. N foot, feet. síi ãoî stinking feet (BE2.50).

•• RB: <sí ãwíæ>.

•• LFD 30: si <ši> foot. si hce <ši ¾se> the foot or the feet. LFD 31 (unconfirmed, unintelligible): si hce ahkio ha <ši ¾se a-Ði-u ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I have a wound on my foot (01/30/95/FH/pc:uk). sihce òðòpa <ši-¾se oæ-thoæ-ba> my feet are swollen (01/30/95/FH/pc:uk). sihce opaha te eðiðàpe ha <ši-¾se u-ba-ha de e-thi-thoæ-be ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] your foot protrudes (01/30/95/FH/pc:uk). si hce opaha hta e àðàpe ha <ši ¾se u-ba-ha ¾a e oæ-thoæ-be ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] my foot protrudes (FH: uk).

siihpó. N toe. siihpóhtà big toe (RB; 03/23/95/FH/pc). siihpóëì any toe or toes other than the big toe (03/23/95/FH/pc; BE2.142).

•• LFD 31: sihpá <ši-¼a´> toes (unconfirmed: 03/23/95/FH/pc:no).

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 31).

síioski (variant: síioske). N arch of the foot (RBn10-9:JW; RBn22-19).

•• LFD 31: sióskita <ši-u´-ški-da> the hollow in the sole of the human foot.

siisí (variant of sísi).

síke. N third daughter (LF only, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 30: sike <ši´-ge> the third daughter, special kinship term.

••• Cf. asîka. 

sinôbre (variant: sinôìbrî [RB-MSB]). N kidney (human or animal). sinôbre çtáache nòpe? do you eat kidney? (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.73).

•• LFD 30: sinòbre ekò <ši-noæ´-bthe e-goæ> resembling a kidney in shape.

sisâðe (variant of sísiàðe).

sísi (variant: siisí). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (be) strong. wíe sisi brîe àðìhé I'm strong (FH; RBn10-6:JW). íe çò ðaaçé, sísi mà[ðì] ðaaçé while you're [still] talking, you'll get strong (RBn10-6:JW). wahéhe mìkçé àëì sísi nìkçé I am weak, but thou art strong (line in a Christian hymn) (MOJ). • (be) energetic, well, doing well, healthy (LS). sisípe he's well, energetic (FH/09/22/01/pc; BE2.129; LS: ok).

•• LFD 30: sísi <ši´-ši> stalwart, brave, active. sísi pe <ši´-ši bi a> he is stalwart.

sísiàðe (variant: sisâðe). V [conjug. unknown] [presumed reg., sísià_ðe] (intr.) seesaw, make a back and forth movement (as when riding a teeter-totter), wobble or teeter (e.g., a glass when jarred or bumped). sisâðe akxai it's teetering (FH:prod).

sitôì. ADV, N yesterday. sitôì Smokey iiðáðe I saw Smokey yesterday (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). Bill akxa sitôì achípe Bill arrived here yesterday.

•• LFD 30: sitóci <ši-do´-dsi> yesterday.

••• QU sióhti yesterday (RR); KS sídoýi yesterday (RR).

sitôì kootáha ce. ADVP, N (on the) day before yesterday.

•• RB: <siæ-twí gó-tah-háh-tseh> (04/11/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.30).

••• QU sióhti kkohtí htehtá yesterday, the day before (RR).

sízo (variant: cízo?). N thigh.

•• RB: <tí-zo> (BE2.138, unconfirmed; 03/20/95/FH/pc:uk; FH/09/23/01/pc:uk).

•• LFD 343 (unconfirmed): sizó <ši-šu´> thigh.

••• KS híëo ~ hîiëofemur (JOD), thigh (RR).

sîìce. N tail, animal's tail, part of Osage dance costume; tail dancer at Osage War Dances; last part of a dance song (BE2.131; 02/27/95/JS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 30: sîce che <šiæ´-dse tse> the refrain, the repetition of the last part of a song to which only two or three select men dance. "This word also means the tail; it is the last of the dance that those, aside from the select men, must pay in order to dance in the tail."  

sîka. N squirrel.  

•• LFD 30: sîka <šiæ´-ga> squirrel. "The squirrel figures in the myths of the Osage and the Omaha." sîka sape <šiæ´-ga ša-be> black squirrel. "The black squirrel is not known to the Omaha."  

••• Cf. sìkóce, sîçtaa.

sîka hpaléze. N square dance (lit., 'stripe-nosed squirrel', a square dance call equivalent to "Swing your partners") (RBn19-06). [Modeled on the English expression.]

sìkóce. N [sîka + océ] squirrel hunting. sìkóce àkáðe hce let's go squirrel hunting (BE2.126; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

sîçtaa. N [sîka + çtáha] possum (lit., 'smooth squirrel').

•• RB: <síæ-shtáh> (BE2.106; 03/10/95/FH/pc:okc).

ska. MODAL it must be that, it seems that, I suppose that, I guess that, perhaps, I deduce that.

[Impersonal suppositional particle; sometimes implies that the event took place previously, and can then be loosely translated 'before, previously, earlier, already' (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok). Often pronounced skœ.] tówa akxa éëixci akxái, lôði akxa ska he [that one] looks funny, so he must be drunk (04/26/95/FH/pc). ðachíe ska you must have been here before (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). hkiistó apá ska I guess [as I see all the cars around the building] that they are counciling (RBn24). éekò ska I guess so (RBn23-15). hàce wáli nuuëúpe ska, ëìkáëi apa hôpái niiëópçi apái last night it must have rained a lot, the children today are wading (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok). hâàci ðetkxâci wacúe bráache mìkçé ska last night at this time I must have been eating this bread (FH/09/06/95/pc). tówa akxa éëixci akxái, lôði akxa ska he looks funny [different] so he must be drunk (04/26/95/FH/pc). kØôsu kØô aðáape ska I guess they went to play dice. táatà hpíiëi wì áðanààëî ska táabrà ðàìçé you must have stepped on something bad, because you're smelling bad (FH:prod). ðachíe ska you must have come here before (lit., 'you arrived here, it seems') (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

ská. ADJ, N white. hci htàà ska çki a big white house, the big white house. • bright, clear (as variant of skáha).

•• LFD 31: skáska <ška´-ška> [reduplicated form] white spots, flecked with white spots.  

••• Cf. hcéeská, xuháaska. 

skáha (variants: skáhe [rare], ská). V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) bright, clear (RBn10-5:MOJ/79; FH/11/19/01/pc:ok). mihkákØe skáha, çtáha the stars are bright and shiny (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). níi skáha clear water (01/09/95/FH/pc:ma). níi ská clear water (04/13/95/LS/pc). mâàãe akxa skáha akxa the weather cleared off (01/09/95/FH/pc:okc; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok, skáha or skáhe). • ADV clearly. íe ska speak clearly (FH). íiði skáha [expected form: íiðe skáha] see clearly (HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok; BE2.20).

••• Cf. íe waská, nâàãeska. 

skákaaãe. V [sync. k>p, ská_kaaãe] [ská 'white' + káaãe] (trans.) whiten (lit., 'make white')

(FH/10/09/01/pc). haaská skákaaãa make the buckskin dress white (FH/10/09/01/pc). hpáxì skákaaãe she made her hair white (FH/10/09/01/prod).

•• LFD 31: skákaãe <ška´-ga-xe> whiten.

skâà (variant of çkâ).

skíke (variant: çkíke). ADJ heavy, tired, weighted down, heavily laden (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok: not çk; 

RBn18-06). [One speaker in the early 1980s reported a distinction between skíke 'tired' and çkíke 'heavy'. Possibly such a difference in meaning between the two forms once existed and has been partially lost.] îì kootáha skíke that rock over there is heavy (BE2.66; FH/07/31/01). ðéka håpi waxpáðìpi aha nâàce skíke paaçé aha, ðakØéwikie hta mìkçé, çkaaçkáða come unto me you who are poor and heavy laden and I will give you rest, I will give you peace. çkáace màðîpi, wáskike waçkáaãapi you all go on and play, you make us tired.  

••• Cf. ðiiskíke, kaaskíke. 

skúðe (variants: skúe, skú). ADJ sweet (BE2.130). wacúe skúe cake (lit., 'sweet bread').

•• RB: <skyú-theh> (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok).

•• LFD 31: skíðe <ški´-the> sweet. màhkâ sape che skiðe walì <moæ-Ðoæ´ ša-be tse ški-the wagthiæ> the coffee is too sweet.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 31).

••• Cf. ðâàce skúðe, níiskue, waskúe. 

stá. ADJ smooth, clear, bald.

••• Cf. nààstá, ostá. 

staahîke (variant of wastâìke).

stáðe. V [reg., stá_ðe] [stá + ðe CAU] (trans.) apply a substance (such as ointment, grease, or cream), smear on, anoint, apply as salve or medicine to a wound (lit., 'cause to be smooth'); paint (e.g., a house or a small object of any kind) (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok). stáaðe I paint it. stáðaðe you paint it. 

àstáðe we paint it. hcí stáða paint the house! (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.101). hci staaðe hta mìkçe I'm going to paint the house (03/03/95/FH/pc). • (intr.) paint (engage in painting as a hobby or profession). • N cream, paint, grease, ointment (for applying to a surface to make it smooth). çáake ni çtáðe analgesic cream for the hands (lit., 'cream for hands hurting') (FH).

•• LFD 31: snáðe<šna´-the> [expected form: stáðe; sná- is incorrect in all examples here and elsewhere, and is probably Omaha (sn has never been a permitted sequence of consonants in Osage; it elicits laughter from Osage speakers)] to heal the wound of a child by using an ointment made from buffalo grease; to grease a wagon or oil machinery. snáaðe <šna´-a-the> [expected form: stáaðe] I grease machinery ['machinery' is not strictly implied by the example]. snáðaðe <šna´-thathe> you grease [expected form: stáðaðe] snáàða pe <šna´-oæ-tha i> [expected form: stáàðape or àstáðape] we grease.  

stáko. ADJ neat, uniform, level, smooth, even, straight, nice-looking.  

•• RB: <stáh-kó>.

•• LFD 32: stakó <šta-go´> even, level, uniform, smooth.  

••• Cf. ðuustáko, nààstá. 

stówe. V run, flow or emerge from (as a liquid). hpalístowe, hpalîstowe runny nose

(FH/11/17/01/pc:prod; FHt128). hcí níi stówe water is running from the house (FH/11/17/01/pc:prod).

••• Cf. ostówe. súhka. N chicken (BE2.18; MREI:ok). wisôka súhka wì oohô kçíãape they cooked a chicken for Sonny.

súhka húhka. N needle.

•• RB: <sóo-kah hí-kah> (02/27/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.92)  

•• LFD 31: súhkahuhkà htaãe <šiu´-Ða-hiu-Ðoæ ¾a-xe> pin.  

súhka léze. N guinea hen (lit., 'striped chicken') (RBn19-02).

súhka mîìka (variant: súhka mîìe). N hen.

súhka oðîìke N hawk (lit., 'catches chickens').

•• RB: <sóo-kah-o-thíæ-kah> (RBn1-58, unconfirmed; 01/04/95/FH/pc:uk).

súhka saaki. N banty (bantam chicken).

súhka tóoka (variant: súhka tóe). N rooster. hôòpa wì súhka tóoka ókØà ékòëi káaãe nàpe sometimes the rooster did things he shouldn't do (RBn18-01).

súhkahtàà. N [súhka + htâà] turkey (lit., 'big chicken') (BE2.145; MREI).

súhkahtàà hâàpa. N Thanksgiving Day (lit., 'turkey day').

•• LFD 31: súhka ðache hàpa <šiu´-Ða tha-tse hoæ-ba> [expected Mod. Os. form: súhka ðaaché hâàpa] Thanksgiving day.  

súhkahtàà mâçò oðîìke. VP [sync., súhkahtà mâçò _oðîìke] (intr., trans.) vote, vote for (lit., 'grasp the turkey feather'). súhkahtàà mâçò obrîìke I've already voted (lit., 'I grasped the turkey feather').

••• Cf. mâçà oðîìke. 

súhkahtàà mîìòpa. N November (lit., 'turkey month') (HH/14-a/231ff; HH:pc).

súhkahtàà mîìka. N turkey hen. àëì howáìki súhkahtâà mîìka hcí káaãe che ípahòëi akxa áape but they could not guess where turkey hen made her nest (RBn19-05).

súhkahtàà môçò (variant: súhkahtàà mâçò). N turkey feather, any quill (PM/7/7/94).

••• Cf. súhkahtàà mâçò oðîìke. 

-súhu. V ROOT clean.

••• Cf. taasúhu, wasúhu. 

súu. N seed, pit, kernel. hpéãe súu rattle seeds, gourd seeds.

•• LFD 128: hpéãe su <¼e´-xe šu> rattle seeds.

••• QU si seed, pit, grain or kernel (RR).

••• Cf. wasúutà.  

súutà (variant: súuta). ADJ [súu + tà] ripe, ready to pick or harvest (FH). hápa akxa súutà akxai the corn is ripe, ready to pick (01/31/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 30: síta <ši´-da> ripe corn ['corn' is not strictly implied by this form]. hapa apa sita pi o <ha-ba a-ba ši-da bi o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] the corn is ripe. LFD 186: wasíta <wa-ši´-da> the ripening of the corn, the harvest.

••• KS wasúda hard or firm, as corn (RR), wasúdabe the month when the corn is hard, midsummer, July (RR).  

çaáke. N Cherokee (tribe or tribal member) (BE218, unconfirmed).

••• Cf. çálaki.

çáake. N hand, claw; handprint, footprint, tracks; hands of the body that are touched by the attendees when passing by it at a funeral (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p27). çáake oðîìke to shake hands (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). çáake oðîìka! hold tight! (FH/06/27/01/pc). súhka çáake turkey track. çáake weáchìe I hit him with my hand (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.63). • finger. çáake ëì the little finger (RBn1-MOJ/p26b). çáake àwâpazo ðìká don't point the finger at me (said to the children by FH's mother) (01/24/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.47; 01/24/95/FH/pc:prod). çáake ohkâska owakxâ [presumed Mod. Os. form based on KS form] ring finger (lit., 'next to the middle finger').

•• LFD 130: çáke <sha´-ge> hands, paws, claws, talons (02/13/95/FH/pc:ma). LFD 31: suhkáçake ekò <šiu-Ða´-sha-ge e-goæ> resembling a turkey track, Flat Rock, Okla. LFD 130 (unconfirmed): çáke ozápe <sha´-ge u-ša-be> fingers (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk). çake oscéce che <shage u-stse´-dse tse> the long or middle finger (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk). çáke oëìka <sha´-ge u-zhiæ-ga> the small finger, the little finger (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk). çake nie <sha-ge ni-e> a run-around ('finger ache') (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk). LFD 112 (unconfirmed): nàpe oëîka <noæ-be u-zhiæ´-ga> the little finger (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk).  

••• KS çáge ohkâska owakhà the next to the middle finger (RR).

••• Cf. nòòpé. 

çáake ípukxa (variant: çáake íipukxa). • VP [conjug. unknown] (intr.) wipe one's hands (01/04/95/FH/pc).

çáake íipukxa wipe your hands! (BE2.63; FH: without ði). N hand towel, napkin (01/04/95/FH/pc).

•• RB: <sháh-keh í-pú-xah>.

••• Cf. htanâkØa ípukxa. 

çáake oðîìke. VP [sync., çáake o_ðîìke] (trans.) shake hands with, touch the hands of s.o. çáake oðîìke shake hands with a person, touch the hands of the deceased when passing by the coffin at a funeral

(RBn1-MOJ/p27). çáake owíbrììke hkôbra I want to shake your hand (RBn1102/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.63). • sign, write one's signature or name on

(lit., 'grasp in the hand', as in writing one's name on a document) (HRE/12/29/01/pc, unconfirmed); endorse (as a check) (HRE: unconfirmed; 04/27/95/FH/pc:ma). çáake oscîìke you endorsed it.  

••• Cf. mâçà oðîìke. 

çáake opázo. N index finger (lit., 'hand pointer').

••• Cf. wéapazo. 

çáakeðíiskike. V [sync. çáake_ðíiskike] [çáake + ðiiskíke] (intr.) make a fist. • N fist.

çáakeoolâkØô. N [çáake + oolâ + kØô] hand game.

çáhpe. ADJ, N six. hkâàce oolâ çáhpe paasé hta apai they're going to cut the pie six times (FH:4/24/96/tape:prod).

•• RB: <sháh-xpeh, sháh-peh> (03/10/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.122).

•• LFD 130: çáhpe <sha´-¼e> six. çáhpe à <sha´-¼e oæ> six times. çáhpe aëi <sha´-¼e a-zhi> six spot in a deck of cards.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 130).

çálaki (variant: çáléke). N Cherokee (tribe or tribal member) (BE2.18;03/08/95/PM/pc: çálaki; 01/09/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• RB: <shah-láh-keh, shah-áh-keh>.

••• Cf. çaáke. 

çápe. ADJ dark (in color), shaded, darkened.  

••• Cf. mîìòpa çápe, sápe. 

çáwanìì. N Shawnee (tribe or tribal member) (BE2.120; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc).

•• RB: <sháh-wah-nah>.

•• LFD 226 (unconfirmed): ëàní <Zhoæ-ni´> Shawnee, the name of an Indian tribe.

çcéðe (variant: çäéðe [Hominy]). V [reg., çcé_ðe] (trans.) doctor a person, administer medical care to s.o.

(01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok:çä). çcéaðe I doctor him. çcéðaðe you doctor him. çcéðe she doctors him. 

çcéàðe we doctor him. çäéàðe doctor me (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok; BE2.33) çcéàða! doctor me! tówa kçe çcéða! doctor that one lying there, doctor him! àkóe çcéàðapé we doctored them.

•• RB: <shchéh-theh>.

••• Cf. waçcéðe. 

çcî V (variants: çcîe, çäíe [Hominy]). V [rare variant 2nd person sg. of ðî 'be a certain way, exist as'

(more usual form is nî)] (intr.) you are (a certain way). wascúuce çäîe you're slow (04/26/95/FH/pc).

çcúuce (variant: çäúuce [Hominy]). V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) warm (e.g., clothing, a house; not used of people). haaská çäúuce mì àhé I'm wearing warm clothes (FH/10/12/95/pc). hci àkóhta akxa çcúuce akxai our house is warm. ákahamì ðíhtapi akxa çcúuce? are your [pl.] coats warm?

••• QU çtíhte warm, comfortable (RR).

••• Cf. mììtáaçcuuce. 

çcúuce (variant of scúuce).

çäéðe (variant of çcéðe).

çäíe (variant of çcî).

çäúuce (variant of çcúuce).

çe. ADJ that (near you). çe ëâàëì akxa ohtáza akxai that little tree is pretty. çe hkâàce akxa toëáðe akxai that apple is rotten. wéhice nàkØô çe ðíhta? is that your radio? (RBn1-44). óolàke sápe çe ìkçé ðíhta? is that black hat over there yours? (RBn1-45). óolàke sápe çe ðíhta? is that your black hat?

(01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.64).

•• LFD 130: çe <she> that one, there (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok). çe éwakçe <she e-wa-kshe> that in your hand is what I mean.

çée (variant: çíi [especially when followed by a subject marker akxa or apa]). ADV here near you. çée mìkçé, táatà íhpahò màëí I'm just sitting here [near you], I don't know anything (RBn10-6:JW). çée mìkçé, wanôbre akxa oméì mìkçé I'm just sitting here, that peyote is working in me (RBn10-6:JW). • there near you, there (closer to the hearer than to the speaker). çée nìkçé óhkie you're just sitting there, speak to me (RBn10-6:JW). çée màðî stay where you are (lit., 'go there by you') (PM/109-a). • PRON him/her/it (closer to the hearer than to the speaker); that, that one near you. çée ðe iiðási I dislike him [he is moving]. waëáëeíe çée àkçíòza teach me that in Osage (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). çée bróka sáhta wikØúe I'll give you five dollars for it [for that] (RBn10-10:JW).  

••• Cf. çíi akxa, çíi apa.

çée apa (variant of çíi apa).

çée che. PRONP that one standing (inanimate), those things (sitting or round items). çée che a group of [sitting or round] items sitting there (03/20/95/FH/pc).

çée ðe. PRONP that one moving (animate or inanimate). çée ðe iiðási I dislike him [he is moving].

çée htaha. ADVP toward you, along a path toward where you (the hearer) are or toward s.t. or s.o. closer to you (the hearer) than to the speaker (FH: t119a) çée htaha aðáape they went over that way, toward you over that way (BE2.143; 04/26/95/FH/pc:ok)  

çée ìkçé (variant: çée ðìkçé). PRONP that one sitting (animate or inanimate), that one over there, closer to the hearer than to the speaker. çée ìkçé, çée ðìkçé that over there sitting [animate or inanimate] (e.g., referring to sitting sack of flour) (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok, person or thing). âðikue, çée ðìkçe bring me that thing there.

çée kxà (variant of çée txà). çée màðî. VP stay there! [Used in imperative sense.] çée màðî stay where you are (PM/109-a).

çée nààëî. VP wait, stay there (lit., 'there near you stand').

çée txà (variants: çée tkxà, çée kxà). PRONP that one standing (animate). çée txà that over there [standing, animate: person or animal] (03/20/95/FH/pc). çée tkxà pée ðe? who is that [standing] over there? (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.136).

çeeðó (variant of çeeðô).

çeeðóha, çeeðóhà (variants of çeeðôha).

çeeðô. ADV (variants: çeeðó, çó). ADV there where you are, right there where you are (FHprod). [Sometimes used in formal speechmaking or lengthy monologue as 'and also' or 'and then' (RB).] çeeðó brée I'm coming over there [where you are] (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.137). çeeðó ha bree I'm going there where you are. çeeðó akçí hta apai they're going to come back there (PM/7/8/94; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). çeeðó méì stay where you are (RBn 3/3/77). • PRON that person there. çeeðó nààëî txà hú hce éa tell the person standing there to come here. çeeðó aðáape he went that way.

•• RB: <shéh-thoæ> (03/20/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 131: çéðo <she´-thu> yonder, there where you are.

çeeðôha (variants: çeeðóhà, çeeðóha). ADV that way, along a path toward the hearer, to a place right next to the hearer (RBn1-23). çeeðóha aðáape he went that way [toward where hearer is located].

••• Cf. çée htaha. çéçeka. V [uninfl.?] [reduplicated form] (intr.) stagger. çéçeka àðìhée I'm staggering around (BE2.126; 03/14/95/FH/pc).

çi. ADV again, more. çí ékia say that again (BE2.1;12/30/94/FH/pc:ok: but ékie preferable). çi záani ðalípi hkôbra I want you all to come back again (RBn10-21). çi àkálììpe we're back again (RBn10-

16). Carolyn akxa çínà waëáëeíe iðôãe akxa Carolyn keeps asking about Osage words

(01/13/95/FH/pc). çí tóa àkØú give me some more [e.g., food] (lit., 'again some give me'). çí mâà çó ðée hpáaãe I'm going to let the arrow go again (expression used at peyote meetings) (BE2.4; 01/06/95/FH/pc:okc). ókaaãéìke akxa çí waachípe "Useless" [a donkey] danced again.

•• LFD 131: çi <shi> again; and çínà <shi´-noæ> again and again (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok).  

çí. V [2nd person sg. of ahí 'arrive there'] (intr.) you arrive there. îì olîì çí hkôbra I want you to come sweat (lit., 'I want you to go there and sit among the rocks').

çí ôpe. N hip joint (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• QU çìhtéhi káxakdé pelvis, hips (RR).

çiðôce. N kneecap (unconfirmed; 02/14/95/FH/pc:uk).

•• LFD 132 (unconfirmed): çiðôce mòçkò <shi-thoæ´-dse moæ-shkoæ> the kneecap.

••• KS çiyâje knee (RR).

••• Cf. çîìce.

çíi (variant of çée).

çíi akxa. PRONP [çée + akxa SUBJECT MARKER] that one (thing or person not in motion) near you, those ones (not in motion) near you. çíi akxa waðíhici akxái that person is teasing (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p11).

çíi apa (variant: çée apa). PRONP [çée + apa SUBJECT MARKER] that one (thing or person in motion or deceased) near you; those ones (in motion or deceased) there (near you) (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77; RBn22-03). çíi apa cØápe that man died (RBn22-17). çíi apa oðíhtà paaxí apai they're pushing the car (RBn23-17). çíi akxa waðíhici akxái that person is teasing (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p11).

çíkxà (variant: çikxâ). N my brother's wife, my husband's sister, my husband's brother's wife (used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my sister-in-law') (RBn14-10;

03/10/95/PM/pc:ok; FH/09/22/01/pc:ok). • her brother's wife, her husband's sister, her husband's brother's wife (more precise than English 'her sister-in-law'). [In this usage, synonymous with içíkxà.]

•• RB: çikxâ <shi-kxáhæ>.  

çíkxà ðíhta (variant: çíkxà ði). NP your brother's wife, your husband's sister, your husband's brother's wife (used only when addressee is female; more precise than English 'your sister-in-law').

••• Cf. ðiçíkxà.  

çíle. V [conjug. unknown] [presumably çi + ki- INCEPTIVE/VERTITIVE + ðe CAU] (trans.) set off, remove from (e.g., remove a kettle from a cooking fire) (BE2.119; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).

••• Cf. ále.  

çínà (variant: çína). ADV [çi + nà 'always'] over and over, again and again (used to express 'keep on, continue to do a thing'). Carolyn akxa çínà waëáëeíe iðôãe akxa Carolyn keeps asking about Osage words (01/13/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 131: çínà <shi´-noæ> again and again (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

çíòce (variant of çîìce).

çì (variant of waçî).

çî. V, N (be) fat.

••• Cf. waçî. 

çîhtàkà (variant: çîhtàà). ADJ [çî + htâka] fat, portly. [The longer variant çîhtàkà may possibly imply a somewhat greater degree of fatness than does the shortened variant çîhtàà (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok).] wáli çìhtàà àhé I'm really fat (01/23/95/FH/pc).

•• RB: <shíæ-táhæ> (01/23/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 131: çîhtàka <shiæ´-¾oæ-ga> portly, fat.

çîìce (variant: çíòce). N knee (FH:4/25/96/tape: çîìce preferred; FH:4/20/96/pc).

•• RB: <shí-ahæ-teh>.

•• LFD 132: çiðôce <shi-thoæ´-dse> knee, that part of the leg around the kneepan (02/14/95/FH/pc:uk, unconfirmed).

••• Cf. çiðôce.

çîmìëì. N girl, baby girl; girlfriend. çîmìëì ihtá apa that's his girlfriend (RBn19-01; 01/31/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.54).

•• LFD 131: çímiëìka <shi´-mi-zhiæ-ga> a baby girl, a damsel, a maiden, a lassie.

çîmìëì àkóhta. NP our daughter.  

çîtoëì (variant: çîtoëìka [archaic]). N boy, baby boy, male child (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). Yvonne çîtoëì kíhuheka Yvonne's boy has a sickness (BE2.10; RBn14-02; FH/11/19/01/pc:uk).

•• JOD (slip file): çîhtoëîka <ciæ´-tu-§ciæ´-a> a boy under five feet high, one under fifteen years of age. [JOD's ht (<t> in his transcription) contrasts with Mod. Os. t and Kansa d (from t) in this word.]

•• LFD 131: çîhto ëìka <shiæ´-¾o zhiæ-ga> a baby boy. LFD 132: çîhto ëìka <shiæ´-¾u zhiæ-ga> a boy. çîhto ëìka ëáëe brace o <shiæ´-¾u zhiæ-ga zha´-zhe btha-dse o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I called the boy by name. çîhto ëìka ëáëe çtace o <shiæ´-¾u zhin-ga zha´-zhe shda-dse o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] you called the boy by name. [LF ht contrasts with Mod. Os. t and KS d in this word.]

••• KS çídohìña boy, young man (RR).

çká. V, ADJ (be) quiet. hpáaëì akxa çká akxa the baby is quiet (FH).

••• Cf. çkaçkáða.

çkáce V [reg., _çkáce] (intr.) play (RBn23-17c). ëìkáëì apa çkáce apa the children are playing (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok: short a). htaapéçkace play ball (HRE/12/29/01/pc:prod). ëìka akxa çkáce akxa the child is playing. çkáce màðípi you all go play (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.105). çkáce ëówalapi hta paaçé? are you all going to play with us? (03/09/95/FH/pc). çkáce ëólaëi apai they won't play with them (2-10-83-p4).

•• LFD 132: çkace <shka-dse> to play. açkáce <a-shka´-dse> I play (03/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ðaçkáce <tha-shka´-dse> you play. àçkaca pe <oæ-shka-dsa i> we play, to sport. çkáce kizo 

<shka´-dse gi-šu> full of life (sport, play, happy: sportive) (lit., 'likes to play'). çkáce hi waðì 

<shka´-dse hi wa-thiæ> society, club; sport, play, arrive at, house or place for (03/09/95/FH/pc:uk; unconfirmed sentence).

••• Cf. kíçkace. 

çkaçkáða (variants: çkaçkáðà, çkaçkáðe). ADJ [probably contains a reduplicated form of çká] all right, nothing wrong; happy, content. çkaçkáða mìkçé, çkaçkáða nìkçé I'm all right, you're all right, I'm OK, you're OK (as book title) (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok: -ða). çkaçkáða àkái we're happy (RBn12-03p5). hcíle àkóhta çkaçkáða àkái we are happy in our home (RBn12-03p5). • ADJ, ADV peaceful(ly), calm(ly), at rest, still (as a lake), in harmony, harmonious(ly), not worried, satisfied. çkaçkáðe he's calm (BE2.102; FH:prod). wéewina môëò ðé çkaçkáða oámàbrì I want to thank you for this good life (lit., 'I am grateful, I walk on this earth peacefully') (RBn10-10:JW). çkaçkáða màbrî hkôbra I want to go on in peace, harmony (RBn22-17).  

•• LFD 132: çkaçkáðà <shka-shka´-thoæ> happy, joyous, facetious, humorous. [Final vowel should be nonnasal a rather than nasal à or ò (FH).]

çkâ (variants: çkâà, skâà). V [reg., _çkâ] (intr.) move, change (as the weather) (FH:ok) àçkâ htai let's move, let's start (RBn12-11). háakòta çôke apa çkâkàða? why is this dog moving around so much? • go on, continue. kóoci açkâà ààhé I've been going on for a long time (MOJ). • start. oðíhtà çkâ káaãa start the car (lit., 'make the car start') (RBn2-MOJ/p35; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). oðíhtà çkâ ché? is the car started? (FH:prod). àçkâ htai let's get started (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.127; RBn2-MOJ/p19b).

•• LFD 132: çkà <shkoæ> to be active. açkà <a-shkoæ> I am active. ðaçkâ <tha-shkoæ´> you are active. àçkà pe <oæ-shkoæ i> we are active, to move, to stir. çkà wahtóke <shkoæ wa-¾o´-ge> quick in action.

••• Cf. çkàçkâ, waaçkâ.  çkâ ðìké (variant: çkâ ìké). ADJP, VP [reg., _çkâ ðìké] (be) quiet, still (lit., 'not move'). çkâ ìká! be still! (04/18/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.110).

•• LFD 132: çkâ ðìke <shkoæ´ thiæ-ge> motionless.

çkâaëi (variant: çkâëi). ADJ, ADV[reg., _çkâaëi] [çkâ + aëí NEG] still (lit., 'not move') quiet, quietly (as not in movement), unable to move or start (as a motor vehicle). oðíhtà akxa çkâëi akxa the car won't start. çkâëi lîì sit still (RBn23-15). çkâëi ëâà lie still (RBn23-15).

•• LFD 132: çkàáëi <shkoæ-a´ zhi> not active, inactive. ëàape ke çkàçtiwà aëi <zhoæ-a-be ge shkoæ-shti-woæ a-zhi> the leaves are motionless [unconfirmed sentence; <shti-woæ> is unintelligible]. çkâà (variant of çkâ).  

çkàçkâ. V [reg., _çkàçkâ] [reduplicated form of çkâ] (intr.) keep moving, move again and again. çkàçkâðe keep moving. çkâëi (variant of çkâaëi).

çki. ADV also, too (often used as a way of implying 'and'). [Often not glossed in English: hcí htàà ska çki 'a big white house' (lit., 'big house also white').] hpáata waçî çki toa brúwì hce let me buy some eggs and bacon, too (RBn1-43). ðée lípi che çki wéewinai I'm thankful, too, for these who have come here (FH/10/13/96). àhíiða çki hta àkái we are also going to swim (BE2.130; 05/02/95/LS/pc:okc). màhkása tóa àwâëu, wacúe çki tóa àkØú pour me some coffee and give me some cake (RBn1-45; MREI/ok). hpáata waçî çki bacon and eggs (lit., 'egg, bacon also') (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.3). • even. waðíhtaëi çki apai they don't even work (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). híi çki ðiiskíke akxai he's even grinding his teeth (FH). táatàëî çki oðáake she's a blabbermouth (lit., 'she even tells small things'). • even though, in addition, as well. hòbrìke owáha hta mìkçé, waçî çki oðóhkihà I'm going to cook beans, I add salt meat (lit., 'I'm going to cook beans, I also cook salt meat with it') (01/12/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 132: çki <shki> also.

••• KS çki and/also (RR).

••• Cf. àkóçki, ðiçkítà, eeçkítà, -çkítà, wiçkítà. 

çkíke (variant of skíke).

-çkítà. ADV also, too. [Suffixed to pronouns.] wiçkítà, wiçkí me too, I too (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). ðiçkítà, ðiçkí you too. àkóçki we also. eeçkítà, éeçki he or she or it/they too (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.67). nôò apa eeçkítà íixa apa the grownups laughed too (lit., 'the grownups they too laughed') (RBn102:MOJ/79).

••• Cf. çki.

çkópe. ADJ deep. pa çkópe akxa the snow is deep (RBn1-11; HH/pc). pá húðe akxa pa çkópe akxa the snow is deep (03/13/95/PM).

•• LFD 105: níaxexe çkope <Ni´-a-xe-xe shku-be> Deep Ford. "At this place there was bad crossing. The location was near what is now the cemetery of Pawhuska, Okla. This was the sixth camp of the first trail."

çó (variant of çeeðô). 

çó chéðe. VP [çó + che POSIT + ðe CAU] leave it alone (lit., 'stand it there by you').

••• Cf. çôcheðé. 

ço ðíe. VP leave alone, leave be (command form). ço ðíe! let her alone! leave her be!

çóce. ADV, N smoke, smoky, dingy, gray (FH, 03/13/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.124). [Smoke was the personal name of one of Frances Holding's maternal uncles whose English last name was Petsemoie.]

•• LFD 132: çóce <Sho´-dse> Smoke (personal name). çóce <sho´-dse> smoke. çócenà <sho´dse-noæ> turned to smoke, usually smokes. hpéce hôëi çoce <¼e´-dse hoæ-zhi sho-dse> a smoky fire [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'a fire that is bad (hôòëi) because it is smoky'].

••• Cf. xóce. 

çoðée (variant: çòðée). VP [sync., çó + (a)ðée] go toward you, go to the place where you are or near you (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). ðakínakØò táatà çoðée hpáaãe I'm sending something [this message] along to you so that you may hear about your own people (FH:ok).

•• LFD 134: çoðé <sho-the´> come toward you.

çoðée káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, çoðée _káaãe] send, make go where you are. John apa íiðiðe kôðapí apa nà, çoðée hpaaãé hta mìkçé John wants to see you [pl.], so I'm going to send him to see you (FH:5/01/96/tape119a).

çómihkasi, çómìhkase (variants of çômìhkase).

çooká (variant: çóoka). ADJ thick (RB; 03/20/95/FH/pc:okc). haxî çooká îì ðìké don't wear that thick blanket (FH/09/24/01/prod).

•• RB: <çóká>.

•• LFD 132: çoká <sho-ga´> thick, as applied to goods, skin, or any material. LFD 125: hpáhì ðihta akhi çoká <¼a´-hiæ thi-¾a a-ki sho-ga´> [expected Mod. Os. form: hpáhìì ðíhta kçe çooká] your hair is thick. LFD 190: walúçka haçoka <wa-gthu´-shka ha-sho-ga> [LF's <ha-sho-ga> is presumably Mod. Os. háa çooká] a shard, a bug with a shell or tough skin.

••• QU ákkiçóka crowded, thick, dense, plentiful (RR); KS çóoga thick, dense as a forest (RR).

çô (variants: çôe, çôwe, çòðé). CONJ while, as, when. íe çô akxá while they're talking, while they were talking; while he/she is/was talking (04/28/95/LS/pc:pl; 04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). ohkie çô akxai while he was talking [conversing]. owíhkà çôwe achípe while I was helping you, he got there. kå çô apa while they were coming back (RBn22-07). owíhkà çôwe achípe I was helping you when he came in (lit., 'while I was helping you, he arrived'). awâhkie çô akxa kaðò ãaaké ahípe while he was talking to me, he got to crying; he was talking to me then suddenly he started to cry
