(FH/8/30/94/prod). lìe çô ìkçé while he was sitting (04/28/95/LS/pc:prod). màðî çô apa, xíðape while he was walking, he fell down. alîì çò mìkçé àpáaspàpe I was sitting there and he punched me (03/23/95/FH/pc:okc; 1/20/83/693). nâãe ðaaxôke çò akxai híi ðiixôkape while he was chewing ice, he broke his tooth. • ADV still. çò átxàhe I'm still doing it (04/26/95/FH/pc). wawépaho aní çô àhé I'm a witness and I'm still living. híi ðáalì çô ðaaçé your teeth are still good (RBn3-49). ànâëi çô àkxâhe I'm still standing here (04/26/95/FH/pc). wakØó ðáalì çò ðaìçe wáçäuãe ðáalì you ought to get married while you're still a pretty woman (RBn17-p02). àtíðe çô ànìkçé we [two] are/were still gossiping (MSB). • continually. kaakô çô ðáìçe, ðalôçäi n‚nœ keep on [like this] until you get drunk (lit., 'you are this way continually, you will just be drunk') (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p28).

•• LFD 134: çô ðìkçe ì ta <shoæ´ thiæ-kshe iæ da> even as he sat, while yet he sat. From a ritual. LFD 133: çò átxàhe <shoæ-a´-toæ-he> I am still here, standing (04/26/95/FH/pc:ok FH: means 'I'm doing it' or 'I'm still doing it'). çôahtàhe aðo <shoæ´-a-¾oæ-he a-tho> [expected Mod. Os. form: çô atxàhe; aðo is not used in Modern Osage] I am still standing. çôðahtàçe <shoæ´-tha-¾oæ-she> [expected Mod. Os. form: çô ðatxâçe] you are still standing. [All LF examples should contain <t>, which may reflect the correct tx in Mod. Os., and not <¾>, which equates to ht and is erroneous.]  çô (variant of çôke). çô htà (variant of çôke htàà 'wolf').

çôce. N penis. [Not as socially acceptable for 'penis' as ëé] oðíkinààëi oðíina çôce wahtîì [Mod. Os. form of wahtîì is wahcîì] zip up your fly (fasten your pants), your penis is showing (RBn2-MOJ/p21; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).  

•• LFD 133: çòcé <shoæ-dse´> the scrotum. çòcé ðìke <shoæ-dse´ thiæ-ge> gelding.

çôcheðé (variants: çòchéðe, çôchíe). V [reg., çôche_ðé] [çô 'still' + che POSIT + ðe CAU] (trans.) leave alone without bothering, touching, or otherwise disturbing it/them [inanimate standing sg. item or sitting pl. items] (lit., 'cause to be still standing') (BE2.78; 01/04/95/FH/pc:okc; 05/08/01,01/06/95, 02/15/95/FH/pc:prod). waléze che çôchia leave the letters alone [as they are] (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). çôchéða! leave that alone! (e.g., to children [RB]) (RBn2-MOJ/p12; BE2.2-3). çôchie leave that alone, don't bother that, don't touch that (FH/11/18/01/pc:prod).

•• LFD 134 (unconfirmed): çòhce <shoæ´-¾se> as it is, in fact (02/15/95/FH/pc:uk with this gloss).

çòcóso. N scrotum, testicles (RBn HW13). [Possibly çôce + ó- LOC + súu (lit., 'place for seeds for the penis').]

•• LFD 325: osú <u -ši´> seeds. sáhku akxa osú ochípe <ša-škiu a-ka u-ši´ u-tsi bi a> the watermelon has many seeds.

çòðé (variant of çô).

çòðéðe (variant: çòòðéðe). ADV forever, for always, for good. çòðéðe brée hta mìkçé I'm going and not coming back (MOJ/RBn2/p21). çòðéðe aðáape she's left for good and not coming back (as when a wife leaves a husband) (PM).

çòðée (variant of çoðée).

çôe (variant of çô).

çòhtâà sa. N black dog (lit., 'black wolf').

çôìkçeðe (variants: çôìkçée, çôìkçíe) V [reg., çôìkçe_ ðe] [çô + ìkçé POSIT + ðe CAU] (trans.) leave it (round or sitting item) alone, leave him/her (sitting) alone, let him/her be, let it alone (includes allowing it/him/her to move freely), not have anything to do with s.o. or s.t. (MSBt9b;02/15/95/FH/pc:ok). çôìkçe[ð]e! leave her alone! (RBn HW).

çôke (variant: çô). N dog. kçâka çôke íhta apa zípe second son's dog is yellow. çôke kçé nôòðahpe? are you afraid of that dog [lying down]? (12/30/94/FH/pc:prod orig). çô htàà a big dog. çôëì a small dog.

•• LFD 133: çôke <shoæ´-ge> dog. çôke ðìkçe aðanàëì <shoæ´-ge thiæ-ke a-tha-noæ-zhiæ> you stepped on the dog, wolf (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok).

çôke. N wolf. çôke xóce gray wolf (RBn HW13; RBn22-04). çôke sápe black wolf (RBn HW13; RBn2204).

•• LFD 133: çôke ska <shoæ´-ge ška> white wolf. çôke sape <shoæ´-ge ša-be> black wolf.

çôke htàà (variant: çô htà). N wolf.

çôke sa. N Black Dog (personal name) (RBn1-29).  çôkehci. N doghouse, kennel.

çôkçeðe. V (trans.) leave it/him/her (lying down) alone (MSBt9b). çôkçe[ð]a! leave her alone!

çòmîe (variant of çòmîìka).

çòmîhka (variants: çòmîhke, çômìhka). N Catholic (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok, hke or hka; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok, definitely hka only). [After an early Catholic missionary named Father Shoemaker (RB).]  

••• Cf. çômìhkase. 

çòmîhka kahíke (variant: çômîhke kahíke). N pope (lit., 'Catholic chief'). çòmîhka kahíke mâze wanôpØì wì kØúpi áape they gave the pope a medal, they say (lit., 'chief of the Catholics, a metal necklace they gave him, it is said') (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok).

çòmîhka wakØó. N nun (lit., 'Catholic woman').

çômìhkase (variants: çómìhkase, çómihkasi). N coyote (BE2.27; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok, hk; FH:4/22/96/tape:okc). • Fox or Wolf (personal name). [Possibly Henry Haskell's name.] çòmihkase ëúuce red wolf.

•• JOD (Wolf and Fawn p15 ln1): çômihkase wì aðaape ska <Cªuæ´mikáse wiæ a¢á§pe ska> a wolf went out.

•• LFD 133: çómihkasihtàka <sho´-mi-Ða-ši-¾oæ-ga> big coyote; gray wolf. çómihkasi sape <sho´-mi-Ða-ši ša-be> a black wolf.

••• KS çômihkase hì htóho (htâga) wolf, grey (RR).

çòmîhke (variant of çòmîhka).

çòmîìka (variants: çòmîì, çòmîe). N [çôke + mîìka] female dog, bitch.

çòòðéðe (variant of çòðéðe).

çòòçôwe (variants: çôçòwe, çôçò). ADV always, forever; during that time (refers to s.t. going on and on through time, uninterruptedly) (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). waëáëeíe çòòçôwe màðî ðée hkôbra I want the Osage language to go on and on (BE2.3; 01/04/95/FH/pc:prod orig).

•• LFD 29: sakíçòçòe <ša-gi´shoæ-shoæ-e> permanency; permanent. saki; çàçàe <ša-gi; shoæshoæ-e> solid, strong; always.

çôwe (variant of çô).

çôëì. N [shortened from çôke ëìká 'small dog'] puppy (FH:ok).

-çpé. N ROOT fragment, bit. • V ROOT fragment.

••• Cf. kaçpé, oçpéëì, paaçpú. 

çpéka. (variant of xpéka). 

çpôò. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) softened by soaking in water; soften, become soft, sodden.

•• LFD 134: çpò <shpoæ> sodden; softened by soaking in water.

••• KS çpâye ~ çpâàye to soak something in water (RR); QU çpô wet (RR).

çtá(a) (variant of çtáha).

çtáha (variants: çtáa, çtá) [uninfl.] ADJ, V (be) shiny and smooth (as a lake surface), slick, bald, hairless, cleared. oëâke apa çtáha apai the roads are slick (RBn23-14). mihkákØe skáha, çtáha the stars are bright and shiny (FH).

•• LFD 134: çtáha <shta´-ha> slick; smooth (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok).

••• Cf. ðuuçtá, ðuuçtáha, haaçtáha, hpeeçtá, kaaçtá, mààçtáha, oçtá, puçtáha, wéeliçta. 

çtáke. V, ADJ [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) gentle, mild, or calm (a person or a person's ways); soothing, comforting. níhka çtáke a gentle man (FH). • (be) mild, calm (e.g., weather). mâàãe çtáke mild weather (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.87; RBn2-MOJ/p19). • (be) tepid, lukewarm. níi akxa çtáke akxái the water is tepid (04/26/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 110: ni che çtáke ha <ni te shta´-ge ha> [sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] the water is tepid. LFD 134: çtáke <shta´-ge> tepid, slightly warmed; stagnant.

••• Cf. waçtáke. 

çtà. ADV all the time, incessantly, always, a lot; constantly, continuously; keep on doing s.t. [Contrast nà (usually followed by pe) 'customarily'.] Preston apa oðíhtà xôò çtà Preston is always having car trouble (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). ëìkáëì àkâzà çtà we boss the kids around all the time (FH:prod). pée tà nuuëú çtà in the spring, it rains a lot (03/14/95/FH/okc; BE2.126). ëìkáëì àkáazà çtà we boss the kids around all the time (FH:prod). íxope çtâ akxai he lies so much (3-1-698). niiëú çtà akxái it keeps on raining, it likes to rain, it's always raining (ok CQ; RBn2-MOJ/p22). wakØó waðíhtà çtà wì a working woman (a woman who works all the time or constantly).

•• LFD 134: çtà <shtoæ> in the habit of. ekò çtà pe <e-goæ shtoæ bi a> he is in the habit of doing it; habitually; constantly.

çtôka. ADJ soft. [**çtâka would be incorrect (FH); a (rare) clear difference in ò vs. à.] wacúe çtôka cornbread (made from fresh corn) (RB;2/2/07/MSB/849; 03/13/95/FH/pc:ok: final a short; BE2.124).

•• RB: <shtóæ-káh>.

•• LFD 187: wacúe çtòka <wa-dsiu´-e shtoæ-ga> corn meal.

••• Cf. mâìhka íðiçtòka.  

çúpe. N intestines; appendix; colon; entrails, insides; stomach area, stomach (FH:ok; LS:ok). çúpe ihúheka kçí áape he [lying down ] has intestinal trouble, they said (12/30/94/FH/pc; FH/09/23/01/pc; BE2.1). çåpe aníe my stomach hurts (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.70).

•• LFD 132: çúpe <shiu´-be> intestines.  

tá. V [reg.(?), _tá] (trans.) ask for, request. mâzeska tá akxái, bróka sáhta kØú he is asking for money, give him five dollars (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.89). kaçpéòpa tá akxai he's asking for a quarter (RBn3-55).

••• Cf. ootá, waatá. 

taa- (variants: tae-, ta-). N ROOT behavior (in regard to behavior or conduct). ëìkáëì apa taaðúhpiiëipe, omíëi ðuhpíiëipi ìkçé children are destructive [in their behavior], they have ruined the rug (RBn24).

taeðáalìëi mischievous (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 35: táe ðalì aëi <da´-e tha-gthiæ a-zhi> unaccommodating; an unruly person; a disobedient child; willful; obstinate; forward; iniquitous; intractability.

••• Cf. ootá, waatá. 

táa. V [uninfl.] (intr.) freeze, be frozen. wáli táape he was frozen fast (RBn16-02). wáli táa akxa sîìce his tail was really frozen (FH/11/27/01/pc:prod). sii ðíhta táa hta apa you'll freeze your feet. htóoëu akxa otáa akxai the meat pie is frozen.

•• LFD 117: nâãe ata <noæ´-xe a-da> [possible Mod. Os.: nâãe átaa or nâãe táa] iciness; icy.  

••• Cf. átaa, otáa, táalì. 

táa-. INSTR by extreme of temperature, by heat or cold. taazíhi brown (as when fried food browns) [táa- + zíhi].  

•• LFD 187 (unconfirmed): watóçtaha káaãe <wa-do´-shta-ha ga-xe> to iron clothes [presumably wa- + táa- 'by heat' + çtáha, but unrecognized, unconfirmed].

••• Cf. táahkace, táalì. 

táabrà .V [uninfl.] [táa- INSTR + brâ] (intr.) smell from heating or body heat; emanate an odor while being heated (as in cooking/burning, refers to either a good or bad odor). óohò akxa táabrà akxai the cooking is smelling (FH). óohò akxa táalì akxa ska, táabrà akxai the cooking must be burning, because it's smelling (FH). táatà hpíiëi wì áðanààëî ska táabrà ðàìçé you must have stepped on something bad, because you're smelling bad (FH:prod).

táaðìke káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, táaðìke _káaãe] [táa- INSTR + ðìké + káaãe] (trans.) burn, burn up, burn down, incinerate, reduce to ashes.

•• LFD 36: táðìke káãe <da´-thiæ-ge ga-xe> to make to burn; incinerate; to reduce to ashes. táðìke hpaãe <da´-thiæ-ge ¼a-xe> I reduced it to ashes. táðìke çkaãe <da´-thiæ-ge shka-xe> you reduced it to ashes. táðìke àkaãa pe <da´-thiæ-ge oæ-ga-xa i> we reduced it to ashes.

taaðúhpiiëi. ADJ [taa- 'behavior' + ðuhpíiëi] destructive (lit., 'make behavior bad'), engaging in harmful behavior. ëìkáëi apa taaðúhpiiëipe, omíëe ðuhpíiëipi ìkçe children are destructive, they have ruined the rug (lit., 'the children have bad behavior, the rug is sitting there ruined') (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.30).

•• RB: <táh-thú-pi-zhi>.

táahkace (variant: táahkaci). V, ADJ [uninfl.] [táa- INSTR + -hkace] (intr.) (be) hot to the touch, (be) warm (an object or a substance; or a person only in special circumstances, such as with fever; does not apply to weather). tâàhkataëì mìkçé I'm not hot (e.g., in the sweat house) (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.68). táahkata màëí mìkçé I'm not hot. táahkace it's hot [an object]. htóoëu táahkace wì àkØú give me a hot meat pie. níi táahkace hot water (02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). wáli táahkaci akxái, óohò hkôbra ìké it's hot [in here], I don't want to cook (01/12/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.24). táahkataëí akxá it's not hot to the touch. táahkace káaãa! heat it up! níhka táahkace a warm man (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 36: táhkace <da´-Ða-dse> hot. LFD 7 (unconfirmed as conjugated verb): átahkace <a´da-Ða-dse> to be hot from the heat of a fire or from the sun's rays. âtahkace <oæ´-da-Ða-dse> I am hot from the fire. táðihkace <da´-thi-Ða-dse> you are hot from the fire. táwahkaca pe <da´-wa-Ðadsa i> we are hot from the fire.

táahkace káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, táahkace _káaãe] (trans.) heat (lit., 'make it hot; cause it to heat up').

••• Cf. taaçcúe. 

táahkiðe. V [uninfl.] [táa 'freeze' + hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] (trans.) freeze one's own. síi táahkiðe I froze my feet.

táahpa. ADJ round, circular. niitáahpa pond (lit., 'round water') (BE2.105; 03/10/95/FH/pc:ok). [Forms diminutives äáahpa, äáahpaëì.]  

•• LFD 36: tahpa <da´-¼a> disk; round, globular, orbicular; rotund. LFD 44: katatahpa <ga-dada´-¼a> to cut a log into short pieces  

••• Cf. ðutáahpa, wahóohtà táahpa. 

taahpóska (variant of taapóska). 

taaké. V [reg., _taaké] (intr.) fight; go to war. atáake I fought. ðatáake you fought. çòëì apa taakí apái the puppies are fighting (01/24/95/FH/pc:prod orig). taaké apá aape I heard they're fighting

(01/24/95/FH/pc:okc). ðòha taaké hta apá aape they are about to fight or go to war

(01/24/95/FH/pc:ok). àtáakaaëi hce let's don't fight [sg. addressee] (MSB/4/83/p7). • ADJ fighting. taaké níhkaçika a fighting man, a boxer or wrestler (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok). • N fight, fighting; war. [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] súhka taaké a chicken fight (01/24/95/FH/pc:prod). súhka taaké cock fight. taaké óhesaëi hi chí aapé the war is getting worse, it's getting to where they're really fighting (lit., 'they're getting to having fierce fighting, they said') (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 35: také <da-ge´> to fight; engagement; dissension; battle; pugilism. atáke <a-da´-ge> I fight. ðatáke <tha-da´-ge> you fight. àtáka pe <oæ-da´-ga i> we fight. také che ewò akxa eepia <da-ge´ tse e-woæ a-ka e-e-bia> he is the cause of the fight [lit., 'that fight (taaké che), he is doing it (éwò akxa), they said (éepe)'] (01/24/95/FH/pc:uk). táke nihkaçika hpiò ðe tòpe àzo nà aða <da´ge ni-Ða-shi-ga ¼i-oæ the doæ-be oæ-šu noæ a-tha> [expected Mod. Os. form: taaké níhkaçika hpíò ðe tôpe âzò nà] I like to see a good pugilist [lit., 'a fighting man who is skilled, I always like to watch'].

taaké ie. N verbal fight, fighting or arguing, quarrel (lit., 'fight talk') (RB; 01/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 35: také ie <da-ge´i-e> an angry dispute; quarrel; altercation.  

taaké omâðì (variant: taaké omâì). VP be in the armed forces, be a member of the military service; go to war (BE2.4; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). N armed forces; any branch of the military service.

taaké onâàëì (variant: taaké onáaëi). VP, N (be in the) armed forces or services (04/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• RB: <tah-kí-o-náh-zhi>.

taakéçtà. ADJ quarrelsome (lit., 'fights continually'). wakØó taakéçtàpe she's a quarrelsome woman.

táaliko (variant of táalìko).

táalì. V, ADJ [stat.] (intr.) burn; burned. ðéeze àtáalì I burned my tongue (01/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.13). óohò akxa táalì akxa ska, táabrà akxai the cooking must be burning, because it's smelling (FH). htáa táalì çkaaãée you burned the meat (lit., 'you caused meat burning') (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). htáa akxa táalì akxai the meat's burned (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.13).

táalìko (variant: táaliko). N [probably táa- INSTR + lìkó] meat gravy, popular Osage dish made of boiled meat (BE2.86; FH). [Meat is cut up, washed, rinsed, and stored in a pot overnight. The next day the meat is rinsed off then covered with the rinse water and juices that have exuded and accumulated in the pot. Salt and pepper are added, and the meat is boiled until almost dry, whereupon bacon grease and flour are added and the entire mixture is browned. Water is then added to achieve gravy consistency (FH).]

•• RB: <tah-líæ-ko> (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 56: táli pe <da´-xthi be> to boil meat till tender. talípe hpaãe <da-xthi´-be ¼a-xe> I boiled it till tender. LFD 220: li <xthi> fester, suppurate. [No exact match for táalìko has been found in LFD.]  

taapóska (variants: tapóska, taahpóska). N school (03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok: short final a). [Borrowed from Pawnee taapuska 'school' (Douglas Parks). The Pawnee word may have entered Osage at different times in different forms, with or without preaspiration of the stops (h)t and (h)p and with a long or short vowel aa or a; it is losing or has lost the preaspiration in (h)t and (h)p.] taapóskahci school building (03/08/95/MREI/pc). taapóska màðî go to school [sg. addressee]. taapóska máðîpi go to school [pl. addressee]. taapóska panáa school is dismissed [said at the close of the school day], school is out [for the summer] (03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.116). ëìkáëì apa kasîxciëì páahà nàpé, taahpóska wábrìbree nai the children get up early, I take them to school (02/27/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.131). taapóska çäée hta ðàìçé tà áhkihtôpa ði when you're going off to school, take care of yourself.

•• RB: <tah-pó-skah>.

•• JOD (slip file): htáposka <ta´-pu-ska> a teacher.

•• LFD 138: htáposka <¾a´-pu-ška> a school-teacher. htáhposka wihta oxta akiðe <¾a´-¼u-ška wi-¾a u-xta a-gi-the> I like my school-teacher. htápxoska hci <¾a´-pu-ška tsi> [here LF's <-pu-> is a mistake for <-¼u-> (Mod. Os. -hpo-)] Mission House; School. taapóska mîìòpa. N September (lit., 'school month') HH/14-a/249ff&pc). taapóskahci. N [taapóska + hcí] schoolhouse (03/08/95/MREI/pc).

táapuãe. V [uninfl.] (intr.) boil over (BE2.10; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. ápuãe. 

táapuze. V [uninfl.] [táa- INSTR + púze] (intr., trans.) dry from heat; boil dry (lit., 'by heat dry') (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p50). [Contrast this word with htáa púze 'dried food; dried meat'.] haxì táapuze mìkçé [the blanket is drying; mìkçé here indicates ownership or interest in the process] I'm drying the blanket (FH). óhkilà táapuze akxai the clothes are drying (FH). watáaëoe táapuze mìkçé I'm drying corn for hominy. • ADJ boiled dry.

•• LFD 6: ápize <a´-bi-še> to become dry.

táasaaki. N [táa- INSTR + saakí] burned meat, charred meat (the burned black part of meat such as barbecue; lit., 'hard due to heat').

táaskà. V [uninfl.] [presumably contains táa- INSTR] (intr.?) melt (FH:ok). nâãe akxa táaskàpe the ice has melted (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• KS dáaskà melt (RR); QU táskà melt (RR).

táaske. ADJ mellow (02/27/95/FH/pc, unconfirmed).

taasúhu. V [táa- INSTR + -súhu] (trans.) be clean or cleanse by heat or cold.

•• LFD 34: tásihi <da´-ši-hi> to cleanse with heat; to purify. tásihi akçiðe <da´-ši-hi a-ki-the> [LF's -kçi- <-ki-> is probably an error for -hki- <-Ði->] I cleansed or purified myself with heat (01/30/95/FH/pc:uk). tásihi ðakçiðe <da´-ši-hi tha-ki-the> [LF's -kçi- <-ki-> is probably an error for -hki- <-Ði->] you cleansed or purified yourself with heat (01/30/95/FH/pc:uk). tásihi àkçiða pe <da´-ši-hi oæ-ki-tha i> [LF's -kçi- <-ki-> is probably an error for -hki- <-Ði->] we cleansed or purified ourselves with heat.  

••• Cf. wasúhu. 

taaçcúe (variants: táaçcue, taaçäúe [Hominy]) (BE2.151; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) presumably reduced from táa- INSTR + çcúuce] (be) warm. ohkúla taaçäúe warm clothing (lit., 'clothing that warms') (03/16/95/JS/pc). táaçcue akxai it's warm (speaking of an object such as a food item).

••• Cf. mììtáaçcuuce. 

táaçcue káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, táaçcue _káaãe] (trans.) warm (lit., 'make warm'). táaçcue káaãa! warm it up!  

táaçcuehkíðe. V [reg., táaçcue_hkíðe] [taaçcúe + hkik- REFL + ðe CAU] (intr.) warm oneself, as at a stove or fire (lit., 'cause oneself to be warm') (MSBt9).

taaçäúe (variant of taaçcúe).

taaçéðe. V [reg., taaçé_ðe] (trans.) thump hard or knock s.o. in the head; shove, shove s.o.'s head quickly in anger. [Does not apply to thumping watermelon; is not synonymous with ochî.] taaçéwi[ð]e hta mìkçé I'm going to thump you on the head (FH:5/01/96/tape:prod). taaçéwie hta àkatxâ I'll knock you in the head (RBn22-12; CQc). Bob akxa Mongrain taaçéðape Bob hit Mongrain over the head (RBn22-12). taaçéðe tà, waðílà htôò hta apai when you hit him on the head, that will make his mind get right (FH/1013/96). taaçéðie hta akxai they'll hit you over the head (RBn23-20). oðákie tà káazà, taaçéða when you talk to him, bawl him out, hit him on the head. taaçéðe ìkà don't shove (FH:5/01/96/tape:prod).  

táata záani (variant of táatà záanì).

táatà (variant: táata). INTERR/INDEF PRON what (interrogative). htâwa ìkçí táatà çíe what did you all go to town for? (04/27/95/FH/pc:ok). táatà háakò? what happened? (RBn10-15). táatokØâ apa? [táatà okØâ apa] what are they doing? (RBn10-15). táatà çtáachape? what did you all eat? (04/27/95/LS/pc:ok). táatà çtáahtàpe? what did you all drink? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). mììðóhta wanôbre táatà àðáache hta àkatxâ? what are we having [going to eat] for noon meal? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). táatà çtáaci nòpe? what do you call that? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). táatà çtáache nòpe? what do you eat? (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.154). • thing(s); anything, something; what, whatever (indefinite or relative). táatà çkáaãe what you did (lit., 'the thing you did'). táata ðíhòò íçpahò? do you know what you like? (RBn22-20). táata âhòò íhpahò, ìcé ðuuhpíiëi âhòò I know what I like, I like to make faces (RBn22-20). táatàëì ðahkíliiski hta nìkçé? those little things, small items that you've got, are you going to gather them up? táatà ékipçe sitôì, wanáhkai ékimà what I said yesterday I did it by mistake (lit., 'I said things yesterday, I made a mistake') (RBn10-2). táatà hpíiëi ecíke ta if there are bad things around. níi ëópçe pçíe ðáha, táatà wì màëâ olîì iiðáðe when I would go to wade in the river, I saw something that was in the woods (lit., 'whenever I went to wade in the water, I saw a thing that lived in the countryside') (T24b-p17/#24CQ119; 04/27/95/FH/pc:okc, added iiðáðe). táatà ízizike ecíke tà, ékiò ðìkápi if there is anything unclean, don't do it (FH: Hòpétoohka). táatà ékizò ðaìçé che wéeàna mìkçé whatever you're doing, I'm grateful. • INTERR ADJ what kind, what sort, what type, what class of (interrogative). káache táatà waaðô? what kind of song is that? (RB). táatà ohkíhce kóota ìkçé? what tribe is he [the one sitting over there]? waskåe táatà ðíhòò? what kind of candy do you like? (RBn10-18; CQc). • INTERR V [uninfl.?] do what (interrogative). kasî táatà hta paaçé what are you all going to do tomorrow? [note that no verb appears for 'do'] (04/27/95/FH/pc:okc).

táatà ékò ðìké. INDEF VP nothing like it. mâëà ðekáha táatâ ékò ðìkí akxai there's nothing like it here on earth (RBn10-2).

táatà éëiçki (variant: táatàëiçki) INDEF PRONP anything; any other thing, anything else (lit., 'thing other also'); everything else, all other things. wî áoxta tà táatà éëiçki ékimà nà [expected Mod. Os. form of 'like': âoxta] when I like somebody, I'll do anything for them (RBn17-p03; HRE/01/17/02/pc:okc). táatàëiçki káaãe íisi pe kóe wanôbre, hóo saakí, waachí kíhòòpe he didn't like to do anything but eat, holler, and dance (lit., 'everything else he hated doing, but eating, hollering, dancing he liked') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; RBn16-01).

táatà howachéeçki. INDEF PRONP whatever; everything, anything at all. táatà howachéeçki waðákçiãe hkôbra whatever it is, I want you to fix it for them. táatà howachéeçki waðákçiãe hkôbra anything at all, I want you to fix it for them; everything, I want you to fix it for them.

táatà hôòëì. INDEF PRONP evil, bad things. táatà ðeke hôòëìke ékiò ìká don't do these bad things (RBn1018).

táatà íbrilà che. INTERR/INDEF VP guess what? (lit., 'I'm thinking something'). [Contains 'standing' positional article che.] táatà íbrilà che guess what?

táatà íðilà. INDEF VP [sync., táatà í_ðilà] (intr.) think about or consider s.t., have s.t. on one's mind. [For

'think of us', use kisúðe 'remember' (FH).] táatà íbrilà I've got something on my mind

(03/20/95/FH/pc:ok: short à in verb). táatà íbrilà I'm thinking about something (FH; RBn1021/JW&FW/77). táatà îçäilà ðáìçe? what's on your mind? (03/20/95/FH/pc:prod). táatà ðáalì na íðilà think good thoughts (FH/98/pc). táatà íbrilà che? do you know what I'm thinking about? guess what? do you know what [I have on my mind]? (as when introducing an unexpected comment) (FH).  

táatà ochí. INDEF PRONP many things, lots of things; disorderly abundance; mixture of items that are out of order, trashy mixture; mess (PM/pc:prod; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 35: tatà ochí <da-doæ´ u-¾si> superabundance.  

táatà paahâ (variant: táatà paahá). VP [sync. fortisizing stop stem, táatà _paahâ] (intr.) show things (lit., 'show something'); make a proposition, proposal, or offer. brúwì hkôbra éekò táatà ée hpáahà as I wanted to buy I made him a proposition.

•• LFD 34: tatà paha <da´-doæ ba-ha> an exhibition; an offer; a proposal; a proposition. bri wì hkòbra ekà táatà éhpaha <bthi wiæ Ðoæ-btha e-goæ da-doæ e´-¼a-ha> I made him a proposition.

táatà záanì (variant: táata záani). INDEF PRONP everything, all of it. táatà záani çcíiçtàpé? have you [pl.] got everything all prepared? (04/13/95/LS/pc:pl) taátà záani íçpahò you know everything [in a religious sense, talking to God] (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). táatà záani ée ecí che? is everything there? is everything ready? (04/26/95/LS/pc).  

táatàëiçki (variant of táatà éëiçki).

táatàëî N [táata + -ëì 'little'] small things. táatàëî çki oðáake she tells everything, she's a blabbermouth (lit., 'small things even she tells').

táatàëî çki oðáake. N tell-all, person who tells everything (RBn14-05), blabbermouth.

taazíhi. ADJ, V [uninfl.] [táa- INSTR + zíhi] (intr.) brown, become brown by application of heat; (be) browned, fried. súhka taazíhi akxa? is the chicken browning? (FH/07/09/01/pc). htáa taazíhi fried meat, steak (RBn3-53). tooská taazíhi tóe oohô cook some fried potatoes (RBn12-05;CQ;okc). mîìðohta ci súhka taazíhi àðáachape we ate fried chicken at noon.

taazíhiðe (variant: taazihíðe). V [presumed reg., taazíhi_ðe] [taazíhi + ðe CAU] (trans.) fry, brown, cause to brown (as food) (01/30/95/FH/pc:ok). Mary akxa súhka taazíhi[ðe] akxa Mary's browning the chicken (FH/07/09/01/pc).

•• RB: <táh-zi-hí-théh>.

•• LFD 34: tázihi <da´-ši-hi> to burn a stick until it becomes yellow.

táaëi. V [uninfl.] [táa- + aëí NEG] (intr.) go out, not burn, become extinguished. táaëipe it [the fire] went out (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; 01/26/95/FH/pc:okc). hpéece akxa táazi akxai the fire is going out (RB).

•• LFD 36–37: táëi <da´-zhi> to extinguish a fire [translation should be: '(fire) become extinguished']. LFD 127: hpéce taëi <¼e´-dse da-zhi> fire burned out.

tae- (variant of taa-).

taeðáalìëi (variants: taiðáalìëi, teðáalìëi). V [taa- 'behavior' + ðáalì + aëí NEG] (intr.) be mischievous, rowdy, or unruly, show unpredictable behavior, misbehave, "run wild" (lit., 'behavior not good') (RBn10-21/JW). wáli taeðáalìëi ðàìçé àcØéðie hta àkatxai you're really behaving badly, we're going to kill you (FH/08/15/95; BE2.115). wakØóhpa apa taiðáalìëi apai my girl is running wild (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 35: táðalì <da´-tha-gthiæ> decency; propriety in conduct, speech. táe ðalì <da´-e thagthiæ> dutiful, obedient. táe ðalì aëi <da´-e tha-gthiæ a-zhi> unaccommodating; an unruly person; a disobedient child; willful; obstinate; forward; iniquitous; intractability. táe ðalì niaëi <da´-e tha-gthiæ ni-a-zhi>you are unaccommodating (03/01/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 131: çîhtoëi táeðalìëi <shiæ-¾o zhiæga da´-e tha-gthiæ a-zhi> a willful boy.

tapóska (variant of taapóska). 

tà (variant: tò [LH]). SUBORDINATOR if; provided that. mâzeska abrîe akxàhé tà, wíbruwì hce ska if I had money, I'd buy it for you [I guess, but unsure] (FH:4/25/96/tape:prod). mâàãe ðáalì tà, hóolà àkái hta àkái if the weather is good, we are going fishing (RBn3-MOJ?/p18). niiëú tà, hcíta küe if it rains, come inside (04/28/95/LS/pc). àkóhkihkàpi tà if we help each other (108-b/FH/527). ðíe waðákaaëi tà, owé hci ci brée hkôbra if you drive, I want to go to the grocery store (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok). • when. péehtàà tà niíëú nàpé when it becomes spring, it usually rains (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). ðéekaa bríiçtà tà, htâwà ìkçi brée hta mìkçé when I get through here, I'm going to town (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc;

BE2.155). htâwa kçi çí tà when you get to town (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc, tape; 03/20/95/FH/pc:prod;

BE2.136). chípi tà íinòòhpapai íðaapi tà when they come, be careful when you [pl.] speak

(FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). chí tà íinòòhpapai íðaapi tà when he comes, be careful when you [pl.] speak (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). ëâà kaasípi tà ëâàëì paasíke akxai [(a)pi on 3rd sg. verb kaasé is unexpected in this context] when he cuts wood, the little splinters fly out (04/19/95/FH/pc). wíe bríiçtà tà waatáihci ci pçí hta mìkçé when I get through, I'm going to go by the church. ókØà hta àkai tà háachi niiëú nà apai when we're going to have something, it always rains. ókØà àkôða tà háachi niiëú nàpe whenever we want to have something it always rains (FH). • since; because. káakò kôða tà since he wants it this way (04/11/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• RB: <tahæ, tuhæ>.

•• LFD 38: tà <doæ> because; when; did.

tâàska. INDEF PRON what-do-you-call-it, thingamajig, whachamacallit; who's-it, what's-his-name, what'sher-name; item, thing, something (BE2.154; RBn2-MOJ/p14; 04/28/95/LS/pc:okc ; FH:ok). [May be used in place of a person's or an item's name that one cannot remember or that seems unimportant to state explicitly.]

tàhé (variant: tàhí). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (be) well. tàhé mìkçé I [sitting] am well. tàhé àhé I [moving] am well; I have been well. tàhé nìkçe? are you well? tàhé ðatxâçe? are you [standing] well? tàhé ðaaçé? are you [moving] well? (LS: or sitting). tàhé ëâkçe? are you [lying down] well? tàhé paaçé? are you all well? ðáalì tâhe nìkçé che it's good you are keeping well (05/01/95/LS/pc:okc). wakØó tàhé ìkçé? 

is your wife [who is not present] well? wiëôke akxa tàhé akxa my daughter has been well (05/01/95/LS/pc). ëìkáëì tàhé apai? are your children well? (BE2.153) tàhî àkái we are well. • (be) wonderful. nihkáçi tàhápe he or she is wonderful (1-27-83-p1).

•• LFD 38: tàhé <doæ-he´> decent, clean, of good character.

••• Cf. kitâhe. 

teðáalìëi (variant of taeðáalìëi).

tíðe. N gossip. [The form of this word is archaic: ti- is a rare sequence in Mod. Os.] tíðe ðìké? is there [not] any gossip? (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok; FH:4/22/96/tape: prod; BE2.59). wakØó tíðe çtà she's a gossipy woman (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod). àtíðe ëô ànìkçé we [two] are/were still gossiping (MSB). àtîla àðìkçé hta akxai mâëà ìké etxâ we will still be gossiping when the world ends.

tó (variant: tô). ADV barely, hardly, only to a limited degree or barely representative amount. íixa che tô ekò káaãa don't laugh so much (lit., 'that laughing, like barely make it') (ERE/2/95/pc). tòníðe barely allow to live. ëîìhe che tó ekò káaãa! don't sleep so much! (02/23/95/FH/pc). taiðáalìëi tó ekò káaãa don't be so rowdy, mischievous (02/23/95/FH/pc). lôðì che tó ekò káaãa don't get drunk so much (02/23/95/FH/pc).

tó ìkçé (variant of tówa ìkçe).

tóa (variants: tóe, tó). ADJ, PRON any. htóoëu tóa wéçäuwì? did you sell any meat pies? (RB). wanôbrenii tóa oçcé? is there any peyote tea left? (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.78). • some. mâhkasa tóe àwâëu pour me some coffee (BE2.125; 03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). tóa çtáache ðáalì you ought to eat some (RBn1-55). tóa wéhice ðachípe some of you came a long ways (RBn11-02/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976). çí tóa àkØú give me some more [e.g., food] (lit., 'again some give me'). wapúçka tóe nôpØì akxai they've got beads around their neck (RBn12-08). mâzeska tóa owáhi I won some money. • (marker of head within a relative clause). [Compare wì ADJ/PRON.] hôòpa ðé wéenà akxai ðe níhkaçi tóa áðixòpape, hpáðì wéhkili íwehkili ì kçíãape she's grateful today because they honored her, they dressed her in Kiowa clothes (lit., 'today she's grateful to the people that honored her by having her dress with Kiowa clothes') (RBn23-17; CQc). waléze tóa àwâðakØu na, ðé é í apai the books that you loaned me are these (2-10-84-p4).

•• LFD 40: tópa <du´-ba> some. tópa <du´-ba> some. LFD 37: tópa <do´-ba> some; a part of. tópa abrì a ðo <do´-ba a-bthiæ a tho> I have some.

tóa (variant of tówa).

tóekôëi. ADJ [tó + ékò + aëí] greedy, overbearing, excessive, not limited in excessiveness (lit., 'not as if limited') (RBn18-04; RBn22-0). [Describes someone that takes over, runs over people (RB)

(03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.100).]

toníðe. V [reg., toní_ðe] [tó + níðe 'allow to live'] (trans.) scold harshly, bawl out or "get after" s.o.; spare s.o.'s life, barely leave s.o. alive. Carolyn, Johna toníðae? Carolyn, did you scold John? toníwaðape they bawled us out, they bawled them out (MOJ; FH:ok). Smokey akxa toníwaipe Smokey bawled them out (RB; CQc). toníðe apai he's just barely alive (lit., 'they've just barely allowed him to live') (RBnot-nd-1/p9). iihô akxa toníwa[ð]ape their mother bawled them out.

toníðape they bawled him out (MOJ;FH:ok). toníàðape they got after me (04/19/95/FH/pc). toníàðape they bawled me out, they almost killed me, they barely left me alive (RB; MOJ).

••• Cf. waníðe. 

tóo-. N ROOT tuber.

••• Cf. tóolehtàà, tóole ëúe, tóoleëi, tooscée, tóoska, tóoskue, tóoëuuce. 

tóoce. N throat, gullet. tóoce àníe I have a sore throat (03/22/95/FH/pc:prod). tóoce ðiníe you have a sore throat (03/22/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.140). tóoce oscîìke you took him by the throat (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 37: tóce <do´-dse> throat; gullet.

tóoce ðiláace (?) (variant: tóoce ðihláace?). N beads (RBn, unconfirmed). [Presumably either tóoce 'throat' + ðu-/ði- INSTR 'by hand' + xláce 'touch' (root not attested in Os., but cf. KS xláýe 'beads for touching or rubbing worn around the throat') or alternatively tóoce + ðu-/ði- INSTR + láace 'name one's own' (lit., '[something] around the throat for naming, calling, or saying one's own'); both derivations refer to rosary beads.]

•• RB: <to-síe thi-lá-tse> beads.

••• KS xláýe ~ xláaýe touch; massage, rub (RR).

tóoce níe. VP [stat., tóoce _níe] sore throat.

tóoce oðîìke. VP [sync., tóoce o_ðîìke] (trans.) choke with the hands (lit., 'grasp the throat'), strangle (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p14).

tóoceha (variant: toocéha [FH]). V [uninfl.?] (intr.) eat too much, overeat (FH/11/27/01/pc:prod: 1st syll stress). wálì tóocehape, waachí nà apái he eats too much and he doesn't do anything but dance (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). Dave akxa toocéha akxa Dave sure likes to eat (RBn 5/3/79). • N glutton, one who overeats (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.55; RBn2-MOJ/p12).  

••• KS waëîga dóoýeha pelican (RR).

••• Cf. tóoce. 

toohká. ADJ wet, moist, damp (FH:10/13/96/pc). hòpé toohká Wet Moccasins (a personal name that may refer to dew on moccasins) [Hòpétoohka was the name of an elderly Osage lady near Hominy in the early 1900s who probably did not have an English name; also Ruth Shackelford's name.]

tooká (variant: tóoka). N male. hceetóoka buffalo bull.

•• LFD 38: toká <do-ga´> the male; a ritual expression.

tooká ðìké. VP [stat., tooká _ðìké] (intr.) be without males (said of a family with all girls)

(01/14/95/FH/pc). tooká ðìké no males (01/14/95/FH/pc). ðe hcíle akxa tooká ðìké that family has all girls (01/14/95/FH/pc).

••• Cf. mììká ðìké. 

tooké (variants: tookétà, tookéta). N summer, when it is summer, summertime (MREI;

05/02/95/LS/pc:ok). tookétà hípe it's summer (lit., 'summer arrived there') (BE2.129). tooké tà when it's summer.

•• RB: <tó-kéh, to-kéh-tah>.

•• LFD 38: toké <Do-ge´> summer.

tookéce. N [tooké + ce 'last'] last summer (FH/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): tokéci <§tu-§ke §t§si> last summer.

••• KS dogéýi last summer (RR).

tookéta, tookétà (variants of tooké).

tóole ëúe. N beet (LF, unconfirmed; FH:4/22/96/tape/ma).

•• LFD 38: tóle ëue <do´ -gthe-zhu-e> beet, radish.

••• KS dóole ãåýe radish (RR).

tóolehtàà. N [presumably tóo- + le (otherwise unattested) + htâà] turnip.

•• LFD 38: tóle htòa <do´gthe -¾oæ-a> pomme blanche.

tóoleëi. N carrot (BE2.17; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 38: tóle <Do´-gthe> Psoralea esculenta Pursh, commonly called "pomme blanche" by the whites [densely hairy perennial of central North America having edible tuberous roots; synonymous with breadroot, Indian breadroot, pomme blanche, pomme de prairie; LF has no entry for 'carrot'].

••• KS: dóole zíhi carrot (RR).

tóopa. ADJ, N four. hcéska tóopa abrîe I have four cattle (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.50).

•• LFD 37: tópa <do´-ba> four.

tooscée (variant: tooçcée). N [too- + scéce] sweet potato, yam (lit., 'long potato') (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p14; FH:5/01/96/tape:prod). tooscée ðe howáìke çcúwì? where did you buy these sweet potatoes? (RBn1-33).

•• LFD 39: tóscece <do´-stse-dse> the sweet potato. to; scece <do; stse-dse> potato; long.

tóoska (variant: tooská). N [too- + ská 'white'] white potato, Irish potato (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). tóoska akØé hta aðìhé I'm going to dig potatoes (BE2.31; FH:ok).

•• RB: <to-skáh> white potato (BE2.106).

•• LFD 37: tóska <do´-ška> white potatoes, Irish potatoes. tóska che paaëape <do´-ška tse ba-azha-be> I pared the potatoes. tóska che paðaëa pe <do´-ška tse ba-tha-zha be> you pared the potatoes. tóska owaëu mikçe o <do´-ška u-wa-zhu mi kshe o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I am planting white potatoes.  

tóoske. N hiccup. tóoske akxa it's a hiccup (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

•• LFD 37: tósku <do´-škiu> hiccup. tósku mò ha <do´-škiu moæ ha> I have the hiccups. tósku ëò ha <do´-škiu zhoæ ha> you have the hiccups.

••• Cf. íkaske, tóoce. 

tóoskue. N [too- + skúðe] sweet potato.

tóoskue káxa. N sweet potato branch (Sweet Potato Creek).

•• LFD 37: toskue kaxa <Do-škiu-e ga-xa> Sweet potato branch; sometimes called Ni-u-zhu (Neosho); Spring River. tósku káxa kçe áçka ci alîì <Do´-škiu ga-xa ke a-shka dsi a-gthiæ> I live near Spring River [Sweet Potato Creek] (unconfirmed; FH:5/01/96/tape:uk).

tooçcée (variant of tooscé).  

tóoëuuce. N [too- + ëúuce] sweet potato (lit., 'red potato') (RBn14-08).

totá aðíi (variant of totâha aðée).

totáha (variant of totâha).

totâ (variant: totá). N war; warpath; scouting, scouting alone; looking for enemies. totá ha bree I'm going off to war (FH). totâ ðée be on the warpath, go to war. hkée wî tòtâ ðée ná one turtle went on the warpath (a line from a song). totá brée I'm going scouting (RB). totá çí? have you been scouting?

(lit., 'did you go there scouting?') (RB).

•• LFD 37: totâ <do-doæ´> to go to war [translation should be simply 'war'; 'go' is not explicitly mentioned].

totâ aðée (variant of totâha aðée).

totâha (variants: totâhàka, totâhà, totáha). N committeeman, member of war dance committee; one with rank or authority, ranking member. • ADJ ranking; with rank and authority (RB).  

•• LFD 11b: áhkita totâhàka <a´-Ði-da do-doæ-hoæ-ga> an army officer of rank. LFD 222: totâhàka <Do-doæ´-hoæ-ga> chief commander of the army.

totâha aðée (variants: totâ aðée, totá aðíi). V [sync., totâha (a_)ðée] go to war, go on the warpath. hkeëî totâha ðée the little turtle went to war (line from a children's song). hkée wì totá aðíi aape a turtle went on the warpath (RB).

•• LFD 37: totâbre <do-doæ´bthe> I go to war. totâ àkaða pe <do-doæ´ oæ-ga-tha i> we go to war.

totâha wahtâka (variant: totáha hâhka). N head committeeman (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• RB: <dó-dah-húæ-gah> or <do-dáh-hahæ-wah-túæ-kah> (BE2.65).  

totâhà, totâhàka (variants of totâha).

tówa (variant: tóa). PRON, ADJ that, those (of one or more persons or things that are more remote than

s.o./s.t. else or whose exact description is unknown or of little importance to the speech event) (MSB3/1/690). tówa txà áwakØu mìkçe I'm giving stuff to that bunch of people. tówa apa óðuucØakape that person is lazy (RBn3-39). tówa níhka hpa éëi apai that man has an odd-looking nose (RBn13-01). tówa níhka ìkçé táatà ëáëe aðíe? what is that man's name? tówa kçe çcéða! doctor that one lying there; doctor him!

tówa akxa. PRONP [tówa + akxa SUBJECT MARKER] that one; that person; those ones, those persons (MREI/6/7/94/#94; 3/1/690). [The combination tówa akxa is somewhat unacceptable ("sounds blunt"), while tówa ìkçe is preferred. Presumably this unacceptability arises because the subject marker akxa implies a subject that is present and not moving, while tówa implies that its referent is not proximate.] tówa akxa waachípi áape they said those ones danced.

tówa apa. PRONP [tówa + apa SUBJECT MARKER] group of people or single person of unknown or unimportant identity, moving and marked as the subject of a sentence. tówa apa aðáapaëíe he didn't go, they didn't go (2-10-83-p2).

tówa che. PRONP [tówa + che POSIT] this one (thing) standing here, that one (thing) standing there; those ones, that stuff (a collocation of sitting or round inanimate objects [such as a bunch of grapes] whose exact identity is unimportant or unknown). tówa che those things sitting there (03/20/95/FH/pc).

tówa ìkçe (variant: tó ìkçé). PRONP [tówa + ìkçé POSIT] that one of uncertain or unimportant identity (animate or inanimate); that person sitting; that object or thing sitting there (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok). [ìkçé is the default positional article, which may be used even if an item or person is not known to be sitting (especially if not present or in an unknown position). It is more polite to use ìkçé with tówa than to use akxa.] tó ìkçe iiðási I don't like that person (RBn19-06). • that group of objects of uncertain or unimportant identity (not animate if pl.) (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 40: tóta ðìkçé <du´-da thiæ-kshe> [tóta is unconfirmed; should be tówa; possibly an error] the one sitting on this side.

tówa ke. PRONP [tówa + ke POSIT] those scattered (e.g., people or leaves) (03/20/95/FH/pc). tówa ke those ones scattered around (BE2.139).  

tówa pa. PRONP [tówa + pa POSIT] group of people of unknown or unimportant identity. tówa pa áwawakØu mìkçé I'm giving stuff to that bunch of people.

tówa txà. PRONP [tówa + txà POSIT] that one or those ones standing (animate, of unknown or unimportant identity). tówa txà áwakØu mìkçe I'm giving stuff to that bunch of people.

•• LFD 40: tóta txà <du´-da toæ> [tóta is unconfirmed; should be tówa] the one standing on this

side.

toëáðe. ADJ rotten, decomposed, putrefied. çe hkâàce akxa toëáðe akxai that apple is rotten.

•• LFD 39: toëáðe <do-zha´-the> rotten.

tóëe. ADJ flat, flattened or mashed (said of a soft object); squashed, deflated (e.g., an object that formerly contained s.t.). hcéðe akxa tóëe akxai the tire is flat (softened, air has gone out of it) (FH/11/27/01/pc:ok; BE2.49).

••• Cf. iiçtáðe ðiitóëe.

tô (variant of tó).

tà (variant of tà).

tô, tôe, tôè, tôì (variants of tôpe).

tôòpçe (variant: tôpçe). N [tôò 'stubby' (?) (root not attested elsewhere in Mod. Os.) + pçé] frankfurter; Indian frankfurters, Indian sausages (made from strips of round steak encased in entrails and broiled until brown; these sausages were cut two to three inches long) (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn2MOJ/p28); any sausage or baloney (03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.116; 03/08/95/FH/pc:ok).  

•• LFD 156: htòpçe <¾oæ-pshe> [expected form (in this and the next example) is <doæ´-pshe>, with plain <d>, not <¾>] sausage, made from the tenderest part of fresh meat and the intestines of the buffalo, well seasoned with pepper and salt; before it is inserted in the casing, water is put in and both ends are tied. htôpçe çoce brà <¾oæ´-pshe sho-de bthoæ> smoked sausage. LFD 39: tôhka <doæ´-Ða> short or stubby, as a bear's tail. [This is a possible source of tôò 'stubby'.]  

••• Cf. htáapçe. 

tôpe (variants: tô, tôè, tôe, tôì). V [sync. fortisizing stop stem, _tôpe] (trans.) see, observe, watch (RBn10-15). [Truncated variants tô, tôè, tôe, tôì occur frequently in combination with other words, as in enàtôìpe 'Look Only at Her' (personal name) and watôehci 'store'.] htôpe I watch it. çtôpe you watch it. tôpe he watches it. àtôpe we watch it. watôpe brée ðe I'm going to see it

(02/22/95/FH/pc:prod orig). waachí watôe àkái hce let's go watch them dance [sg. addressee] (RBn10-12:JW). ëìkáëì nakxâçe wéewina akxâhe, ilôìhpa waachí çtôpape I want to thank you children for watching my son dance. kîìkììeëì ówaðaha apa, kóe watôpe che he followed the butterflies so that he could watch them (RBn15-02; FH:ok). • (intr., trans.) look, look at, on, or upon (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). htóì akxàhé I'm looking (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.81). htôpe tà ìcé àhpáze nà when I look at it, it makes me dizzy (RBn10-7:JW). wátòpapi akxái someone is looking at us; something is looking at us; someone is staring at us (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). tówa ìkçe tôpa look at him/her/that. kóota ðe níhka tôpa look at that man farther over there. tôpa mâàãe ðáalì akxa look, the weather is good (RBn1-33).  

•• LFD 38: tôpe <doæ´-be> to see. wahtôpe <wa-¾oæ´-be> I saw them. waçtôpe <wa-shtoæ´-be> you saw them.

••• Cf. átòpe, hkíhtòpe, kítòpe, ówatoì, ówatòìhci, watôe scee. 

tôpe aðée. V [sync., tôpe (a)_ðée] (intr.) go looking. kaðô tôpe aðáape he started off to see what he could see (lit., 'and he immediately went looking') (RBn15-03).

tôpewaðe (variant: tôpewai). V [uninfl. or reg., tôpewa_ðe] [tôpe + wa- VAL + ðe CAU] (intr.) be worth looking at (lit., 'causes people to look at it'). tôpewai akxa it's worth looking at (1/20/83/p5). • make s.o. look or appear a certain way, look like or appear. lôðì tòpéwai he looks like he's drunk (02/22/95/FH/pc:ma). hcéka ðahpáahà tòpéwai you look like you just got up (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.82). ãôòce tôpewai it makes you look sloppy. áalìì wahéhe tòpéwai the chair looks weak (BE2.152; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

tôpçe (variant of tôòpçe).

túlsa htâwà. N Tulsa (a city in northeastern Oklahoma that includes a small part of Osage County). túlsa htâwà owálìì I live in Tulsa (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• Cf. htaasílee htáwà.

txà (variants: txa, kxà). CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 2nd person sg. animate standing subject; also may indicate initiation of an activity by subject regardless of position. ka níhka íe txa pée txa? who is that person who is talking? mâzeska háanà kôða txa? how much money does he want? (RB, unconfirmed).

ðihkówa lôði txa? is your friend [standing] drunk? (RBn3-54). ðihkówa lôði txa ëamíe I think your friend [standing] is drunk (RBn3-54).

txà (variants: txa, kxà). POSIT positional article for a sg. animate standing entity (usually not the subject of a verb describing action). çée ðò nààëî txa hú hce éa tell the person standing there to come here. hkáwa çé txa pée íhta? whose horse is that over there? (lit., 'the horse, that one standing there, who does it belong to?'). çôke txà kôða akxai he wanted that dog. káa íe txa pée txa? who is that who is talking? (RB).

•• LFD 155: htà <¾oæ> [presumably an error for txà <toæ>; compare next example] the; the one standing; he who is standing. níhkaçika txà <ni´-Ða-shi-ga toæ> the man who is standing.

txâha (variant: kxâha). PPN [txà + ha] until, from. hôòpa ðé kxâha to this day (RBn16-02). ðetkxâha/ðetxâha from here on; from now on.

úpeëahta (variant of ôpeëahta).

úëe. N vagina.

•• JOD (slip file): hceeúëe the vagina of a buffalo cow. úëe <ü´-ce> vagina; the vagina of a woman.

•• LFD 81: úëe <iu´-zhe> urethra.

••• KS üëé (JOD) vagina (RR).

úëewààmòì. N lizard (MOJt150; BE2.80). [Folk etymology: 'stealing the female organ'.]  

wa- (variant of wa- . . . api). 

wa- VAL things, stuff; people, folks (indefinite; eliminates the need for a direct or indirect object). [wa- VAL + initial o- of verbs regularly becomes ó-.] waaðáahtà drink stuff [wa- VAL + ðaahtâ 'drink'] (connotes drinking alcoholic beverages). wahcéka new things, new stuff [wa- VAL + hcéka 'new'] (FH/09/24/01/prod, pl.). waléze book [wa- VAL + léze 'striped'] (04/19/95/FH/pc). çíi apa walôò çtà that person coming sure likes to call people names [walôò < wa- VAL + lôò 'revile s.o.'] (01/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.16). nàniôpaëì wakôða apai a whole bunch of them wanted cigarettes (from anybody: from folks) [wakôða < wa- VAL + kôða 'want'] (3-2-140). wapâ holler for folks, invite folks [wa- VAL + pâ 'holler'].

wa- PRNM 3rd person pl. patient pronominal ('they', subject of stative verb [can be omitted]; 'them', object of active verbs). wahkôða he wants it for them. ée wápà káaãa make her invite them. waátòpa! watch over them [sg. or pl. addressees]! (FH/08/01/01/pc; not 'us'). mâzeska huuhtâà waðákØupe you gave them a lot of money (02/25/95/FH/pc:okc). • (agrees with pl. object noun). ëâàhkoke hcéka ðòòpá wáabrì mìkçé I have two new trunks (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). hkóða akxa hkáwa ðòòpá kòzéhkihkò waaðîpe my friend has two horses just alike. ëikóhkiha wahkôbra I want it for my grandchildren (RBn22-19). íe wasúhu wáli waðánakØò hkôbra I want you to hear very clean words [wa- 'them' in waðánakØò refers to 'words']. ëìkáëì wíhta wáðohta níhkaçika waðákiçkaaãe hkôbra I want you to make my children proper people [wa- 'them' in waðákiçkaaãe refers to 'my children'] (RBn19-06). waëîkake wáðaawa count the birds. çôke wíhta akxa hkáwa, hceeská éðòòpa owákaça nàpé my dog takes care of horses and cows (RBn12-03). waëáëeíe hpíò wahkôbra I want them to learn Osage (more literally, 'I want of them that they learn Osage') (RBn10-7:JW). ëìkáëì ãôòce hcí ci achípi wahkôbra ìké I don't want sloppy children to come to my home (FH). Mary, Darlene ónôbre che oðóapi wahkôbra I want Mary and Darlene to oversee this dinner (FH:prod). waachí hí ëiiçô ðée ðe hpahâle hânahpaze oolâàpi wáhkôbra before the dances start, first I want [them] to put him in jail (more literally, '. . . I want of them that they put him in jail') (FH/09/22/01/pc).

•• LFD 189: waleze <wa-gthe´-še> things striped: a book.  

wa- . . . api (variant: wa-). PRNM 1st person pl. patient pronominal ('we', subject of stative verbs; 'us', object of active verbs). oðówaapi akxai he's bossing us around [oðówaapi < wa- . . . api 'us' + oðóðe] (FH:prod). waátòpapi watch over us [wa- . . . api 'us' + átòpe] (FH/08/01/01/pc). haakxâta waðákiçtôpapi ðachí hta ðàkxâçe? when are you all going to come see us? (04/28/95/LS/pc:okc). çkáce ëówalapi hta paaçé? are you all going to play with us? (03/09/95/FH/pc). hôòpa huuwáli ëówaðale hkôbra I want you to be with us a long time [ëówaðale < wa- 'us' + ða- 'you' + ëóle 'accompany'] (RBn12-10/MOJ). ëówaðale çcée ðáalì you ought to go with us.

wáache (variant: waaché). N skirt with ribbon work or other decorations. waaché wíhta äáahpa my skirt is short (03/10/95/PM/pc; FH:4/24/96/pc). wáache ohíëi my skirt does not go around.

•• RB: <wah-tséh>.

•• LFD 205: waché <wa-tse´> skirt; dress. LFD 206: wachéwihta ðà cahpa <wa-tse´-wi-¾a thoæ dsa-¼a> my skirt is short. LFD 187: wáciohiëi <Wa´-dsi-u-hi-zhi> [expected Mod. Os. form:

wáacheoðíçiëi] Skirt-that-does-not-go-around (female personal name).  

••• Cf. mîwaapaache, óhkihpaache, wáakipaache. 

waachí. V [reg., waa_chí] dance. áwaachi ~ awáachi I dance. waðáachi you dance. àwáachipe we [pl.] dance. ëìkáëì nàkxáçe wéewina akxâhe, ilôìhpa waachí çtôpape I want to thank you children for watching my son dance. waachí hpíòpe she is a good [skilled] dancer (lit., 'she knows how to dance'). káaçi wáli àwáachipe, àðíiçtà htai we've danced a long time, let's stop (BE2.29). àwáachi ðíe dance for me (FH/11/17/01/pc:ok: awáa). • N dance. waachí watôì àkái hce let's go see the dance [sg. addressee]. waachí wì waëáëe apa húuëa ðée aðî apa this dance Osages had a long time (lit., 'Osages had a dance, a long time they've had this one') (PM/7/7/94). hpáze waachí watôì àkái hta akái we are going for the night dance [to observe the dance]. waachí àkái hce let's go to the dance [implies that we will dance]. waachí ðôhà éetkxà ahí akxai it's almost time for the dance (FH/t116b).

•• LFD 206: wahcí <wa-¾si´> dance.

••• Cf. áwaachi. 

waaðô. V [(reg.)+sync., waa(_)_ðô] (intr.) sing. waabrô ~ awáabrò I sing. waaçtô ~ waaðáçtòi you sing. àwáaðòpe we sing. waabrô hkôbra I want to sing (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). wiëî, waaðô ðáalì çkáaãe hâàci older brother, you sang good last night (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). waaðáçtò tà âhòò when you sing, I like it (RBn; MREI/01/11/93). waaçtô che íðibra? did you get enough [of you] singing? Mogri akxa wálì waaðô ðáalì káaãe akxai Mogri is really singing pretty (FH:prod). waëîka apa waaðô apái the birds are singing (FH). waaðô hta apai, oðówaðaðe hta nìkçé? they're going to sing, are you going to see about it/things? (FH). àwáaðò htai let's [three or more] sing (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). waaðôpi awáachi àkxàhé you all sing, I'm dancing. • N song. [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] ìlôòçka wapâ waaðô "calling them" songs (HRE; BE2.121; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:uk; FH:4/24/96/tape:uk). hcée waaðô buffalo songs. káache táatà waaðô? what kind of song is that? htáa waaðô deer songs (RB).

•• LFD 119: nàëî waðò <noæ-zhiæ´ wa-thoæ> the rising song (04/07/95/PM/pc:ok, nààëî waaðò). "This song refers to the rising of the <Xo-Ða> after the symbolic moccasins have been placed on his feet." LFD 123: ópxà waðò <o´-poæ wa-thoæ> Elk Songs (04/07/95/PM/pc:ok; ópxà waaðò).

••• Cf. hkihkôze waaðô, mììðóhta waaðô, mììwáaðòëì, wapâ waaðô. 

waaðô hpíò. VP [sync.+sync. nasal vowel stem, waaðô _hpí_ò] (intr.) be a singer, be skilled at singing (lit., 'know how to sing'). waaðô hpíòpe he's a skilled singer (RBn3-42).

waahkíhta. V [reg., waa_hkíhta] [hkik- REFL/RECIP + waatá] (intr.) pray for oneself; pray for each other. waahkíhta paahá pray for yourselves, raise it up (RBn10-15). waahkíhta paahá pray for each other, raise it up (RBn10-15).  

wáakipaache. N skirt with ribbon work or other decorations (03/10/95/PM/pc; FH:4/24/96/pc).  

••• Cf. wáache. 

wáakipetxà. N [probably wa- VAL + ki- INCEPTIVE(?) + ápetxa] wraparound skirt; blanket wrapped around like a skirt (lit., 'to wrap s.t. around') (FH:4/24/96/pc; BE2.122; 03/10/95/PM/pc:ok). [Not 'wrap s.t. on top of itself'; the word was definitely heard with ki- rather than with reflexive hkik-.]

waaláke. V [conjug. unknown] [wa- VAL + áalake] (intr.) menstruate (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/01/95/FH/pc:ok). wakØó wíhta waaláke akxai my wife is menstruating (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). waaláki akxái she's menstruating (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.87).

wáalake(?) (or wálake?). N bad or unfavorable impression made upon another by offensive conduct (LF, unconfirmed). • taboo (LF, unconfirmed, 03/01/95/FH/pc:uk as 'taboo').

•• LFD 189: wálake <wa´-gtha-ge> an unfavorable impression made by a person upon another or upon a number of persons by his offensive conduct; to come or go for a person that is a relative [unconfirmed: FH: incorrect gloss; uk], a thing sacred which must not be used for profane purposes, and to which is attached a penalty, particularly things consecrated for ceremonial purposes (03/01/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• Cf. áalake. 

wáali, wáalì (variants of wálì).

waanôò. N elder. waanôò wì ecí ìkçe tà ðáalì it's good that there is an elder in here (lit., 'if there is an elder here it's good') (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 196: wanò <wa-noæ´> the senior; the elder of two persons. "The name of a gens occupying the office of the 'oldest.' Term used in rituals."

waápazo átòpe. N [wa- VAL + ápazo + átòpe] scorekeeper.

•• RB: <wáh-páh-zo-áh-toæ-peh> (RB: e.g., one who keeps sticks in an Indian hand game) (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.117).

wáapà. V [wa- VAL + kípà] [reg. ki-del. + sync. fortisizing stop stem, wáa_(ki)_pà] (intr.) invite folks to appear before others. wáapàëi akxai he's not inviting anybody (he's not issuing invitations to folks) (FH:prod).

wáapìce. N restraint (such as a bridle?) (RBn10-5:JW, unconfirmed). [Derivation unknown; possibly a truncated version of LF's wápisòce <wa´-bi-šoæ-dse> (see below) and possibly related to ásàci 'put to the test'.]  

•• LFD 184: wápìsòce <wa´-bi-šoæ-dse> to press or hold to the ground, as an animal to prevent its escape. áhpisôce <a´-¼i-šoæ-dse> I prevented the animal from escaping. áçpisôce <a´-shpi-šoædse> you prevented the animal from escaping. wápice <wa´-bi-dse> see huapice <hu-a-bi-dse>. LFD 67: huapice <hu-a-bi-dse> a fish snare, made of willow saplings tied together so as to make one long piece [see LFD 67 for further description of the snare]. LFD 81 (unconfirmed): iwapî akinàëì <i-wa-biæ´ a-gi-noæ-zhiæ> stepping in the blood that issues from the mouth of the animal (mythical).  

wáaspaëi (variant: waaspáëi). N [wáaspe + aëí] gadabout, one who seldom stays home, s.o. who won't stay home. wáaspaëi nîe you're a gadabout (2-25-83).

•• LFD 186 (unconfirmed): wáspaëi <wa´-špa-zhi> an unprincipled person; mischievous; illmannered; boisterous. [LF's translations are not confirmed by Mod. Os. speakers.]

wáaspe (variant: waaspé). V [reg. or uninfl., wáa_spe (2nd person is seldom inflected)] (intr.) stay, stay quiet. awáaspe I stay. waaðáspe you stay. hcí ci waaspé hta mìkçé I'm going to wait in the house (RBn22-06). waaspé hta nìkçé àëi çäée hta nìkçé? are you going to stay or are you going to go?

(BE2.127). John akxa waaspé hta akxái John is going to stay. wáaspi akxái he is staying

(03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). wáaspe hta apai they are going to stay. wáaspi akxái they are staying (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). wáaspa! stay here! (RBn3-MOJ/p8; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). màðî ðìká ði, wáaspa ði don't go anywhere, stay here (03/14/95/FH/pc). ðíi ìká, wáaspa ði don't go anywhere, stay there. ðée ìká ði, wáaspa don't go anywhere, stay here (03/14/95/FH/pc). wáaspe hta nìkçé? are you going to stay? (2-25-83). N stay-at-home, one who seldom goes out. wáaspe nîe you're a stay-homer.

•• RB: <wáh-speh> (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 186: wáspe <wa´-špe> tranquil; quiet; well behaved; good habits. zani wáspe pe <ša-ni wa´-špe i> [expected Mod. Os. form: záani wáaspape] all is tranquil.

wáasta (variant: waásta). ADJ [wa- VAL + ásta] sticky.

waaçkâ. V [reg., waa_çkâ] (intr.) try hard; do one's best; make an effort; struggle (RBn16-02; RBn10-18: FH). [Used especially when congratulating young people; for example, telling them to try hard upon graduating from high school (FH).] àwáaçkà hkôbra I want to do my best (03/14/95/FH/pc). awáaçkà hta mìkçé I'll try my best, I'm going to try hard (04/04/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn10-9:JW). waaðáçka hta nìkçé you will do your best (04/04/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.145). waaðáçkà çkôòçta? do you want to do your best? (03/14/95/FH/pc). ðiitâ waaçkápe he pulled harder (lit., 'pulling, he did his best'). céãenii ochî waaçkâpi aha ðáalì ché aha, ahú ókaçeìke céãenii ðée ìkçe whenever they're doing their best hitting the drum, when it's good, it's an untroubled, peaceful drum (RB; CQ gloss). waaçkâ try your best (FH/09/22/01/pc). waaçkâ ðì! try hard! waaçkâ pai do your best [pl. addressee, continuative imperative] (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod). àwáaçkà hta àkáðe we'll do our best. • N strength, might, force, power (04/04/95/FH/pc:ok).  

•• LFD 199: waçkâ <wa-shkoæ´> to make an effort; to struggle hard. awáçkà <a-wa´-shkoæ> I made an effort. waðáçkà <wa-tha´-shkoæ> you made an effort. àwâçkà pe <oæ-woæ´-shkoæ i> we made an effort. LFD 121: ohkâciwaçkà <O-Ðoæ´-dsi-wa-shkoæ> Struggles-by-himself (personal name); No one to help him fight. LFD 199: waçkâ htàka <wa-shkoæ´ ¾oæ-ga> great strength. waçkâ <wa-shkoæ´> strength; might; force; power.  

waaçkâðìké. V [stat., waaçkâ_ðìké] [waaçkâ + ðìké] (intr.) be frail; lack strength (LF).

•• LFD 199: waçkâðìke <wa-shkoæ´-thiæ-ge> disability; weak, having little or no strength; frail.

waaçkâhtàka. V [stat., waa_çkâhtàka] [waaçkâ + htâka] (intr.) strong, having great strength (LF).

•• LFD 199: waçkâ htàka <wa-shkoæ´ ¾oæ-ga> great strength. waðiçkà htàka <wa-thi-shkoæ ¾oæga> you have great strength.

waatá. V [reg., waa_tá] (intr., trans.) pray; pray for s.o. or s.t. awáata I'm going to pray

(04/18/95/FH/pc:ok). éekò awáata nai I pray that way all the time. (RBn12-10/MOJ). waawítai hta mìkçé I'm going to pray for you (04/18/95/FH/pc:prod). awáatai hta mìkçé I'm going to pray (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.107). àwâàta àkái we [sitting] are praying (04/18/95/FH/pc:ok). àwáata htái let us pray (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). wawáatapi pray for all of us (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc). wawáata pray for them (04/18/95/FH/pc:ok). Johna akxa ëìkáëì waatá apa íistahkiepi John is praying for the children and the children are asking God for a blessing (lit., 'John is praying for the children and they are blessing themselves with it'). • ask a favor, request s.t.; solicit, petition, or beg for s.t. from s.o. waawítai hta mìkçé I'm going to ask you for a favor (04/18/95/FH/pc:prod). awíwaata achíe ðe I came to ask for a favor [from you] (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod orig; BE2.45). • N grace (as said at mealtime), prayer of any kind.

•• LFD 186: watá <wa-da´> speaking; to solicit; to petition.

••• KS da ask, beg, demand (RR) (type [reg., conj).  

••• Cf. kaaçénà, waatáçta. 

waatáihci. N [waatá + í- LOC + hcí] church. wíe bríiçtà tà, waatáihci ci pçí hta mìkçé when I get through, I'm going to go by the church (FH10/7/94).

waatáçta (variant: waatáçtà). N [waatá + çtà] beggar (04/18/95/FH/pc:prod).

wáawaëì (variant of waðáawaëì).

waazó. V [uninfl.] (intr.) be fun. áçihta wanôbre waazóe it's fun to eat outdoors (RB; 01/30/95/FH/pc:okc).  

••• Cf. kízo. 

wabrâlì. N perfume. wabrâlì brâ akxai he/she smells like perfume (RBn10-20).

wachú (variant: wachúe). V [presumably reg., wa_chú] [wa- VAL + chúe (but sometimes used as transitive)] (intr., trans.) copulate, have intercourse, have sex.

wácinie (variants: wáchini, wáchinie). N venereal disease, sexually transmitted disease (STD)

(01/20/95/FH/pc:ok). [Probably from 'Virginia' (which may have been used to mean 'white man'). Perhaps venereal disease was later associated with wachú 'copulate' and thus may have substituted ch for c, giving the variants wáchini and wáchinie (Robert Rankin, personal communication). Additionally, wácinie may contain or be influenced by níe 'hurt'.] wácini òô akxai he had venereal disease (BE2.31).  

•• RB: <wah-tsí-ni>, <wah-tsí-ní-eh>.

•• LFD 187: wácini <wa´-dsi-ni> a disease, a malady.

wacípxaì (variants: wacípxa, wacípxà, wacípxai). N crier, town crier, announcer (01/14/95/FH/pc;prod; BE2.27; HH/pc); crier at ilôòçka dances (RB).

•• LFD 187: wacéhpaì <wa-dse´-¼a-iæ> [px <p> rather than hp <¼> would have been expected, given the Mod. Os. form] meaning lost; used as an official title among the Osage for a crier.

wacúaxà (variant of wacúexà).

wacúe. N [probably wa- VAL + cúuce] bread; any kind of bread whether corn or wheat, in any shape or size; piece of bread of any kind (RB). [Takes 'standing' positional article che.] wacúe che ípasà [ð]ì turn that bread over. wacúe çtôke 'soft bread', refers to fresh corn bread (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok;

BE2.11). wìcéke, wacúe wì çkôçta? uncle, do you want a [piece of] bread? (RBn1-17). • any kind of flour or grain (such as wheat, oats).

•• LFD 187: wacúe <wa-dsiu´-e> flour.

wacúe bréhka. N pancake(s) (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 187: wacúe brekxa <wa-dsiu´-e bthe-ka> [hk <Ð> rather than kx <k> would have been expected, given the Mod. Os. form] thin bread.  

wacúe ðiiskí (variant of wacúe kaaskí).

wacúe ðubráaska. N [wacúe + ðu-/ði- INSTR + bráaska] dumplings made of wheat flour or corn flour (lit., 'bread made flat') (01/07/95/FH/pc). súhka htaaníi wacúe ðubráaska ëóle hpáaãe I'm going to make chicken and dumplings (BE2.9; FH:prod). súhka htaanì çkáaãe tà wacúe ðubráaska oozú if you're going to make chicken soup, put dumplings in it [in chicken soup, these would be cornmeal dumplings made from squawcorn and dropped into the soup and would float to the top when done] (FH:prod).

wacúe ðutáahpa. N biscuit (lit., 'bread made round') (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; FH:4/22/96/tape:prod).

•• LFD 187: wacúe tahpa <wa-dsiu´-e-da-¼a> biscuit, round bread.

••• Cf. wacúe táahpa. 

wacúe ikaaëì. N [wacúe + í- LOC + kaaëí] grain sieve (lit., 'drive grain with it').

•• LFD 187: wacúe ikaëì <wa-dsiu´-e i-ga-zhiæ> sieve used for screening grain.

wacúe kaascú. N frybread (for which the dough is cut, sliced, or slit through) (01/07/95/FH/pc:okc).

wacúe kaaskí (variant: wacúe ðiiskí). N cornmeal dumplings (cornmeal dough compressed into balls and dropped into chicken or turkey soup to cook) (FH:prod).

wacúe kØâsaaki. N noodles (lit., 'fast bread').

wacúe skúðe (variant: wacúesku). N cake (such as a birthday cake) (lit., 'sweet bread') (RB;

01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). wacúesku tóa àk'ú give me some cake (BE2.16). pààçcéka wacúesku hpáaãe I made a strawberry cake.

•• LFD 187: wacúe skuðe <wa-dsiu´-e škiu-the> sweet-corn-cake. [Sweet bread, not corn (RB).]

wacúe sóso. N dumplings; bread cut into little pieces (RBn22-13, unconfirmed). [Possibly mistranscription for wacúe sása, where sása is reduplicated form of root -se 'cut'.]

wacúe çtôka, wacúe çtôke (variants of wacúeçtò).

wacúe táahpa. N dumplings (lit., 'round bread') (04/07/95/LS/pc:okt; t14a-p5).

wacúe wéli. N frybread (FH).

wacúe xúãa. N crackers (lit., 'bread that makes a noise or is crumbly') (BE2.27; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 187: wacúe xuxu ãe <wa-dsu´-e xu-xu xe> crackers. wacoe; xuxuãe <wa-dsu-e; xu-xuxe> bread; that cracks or crumbles.

••• Cf. kaaxúãe. 

wacúe ëéela. N cornbread or grated fresh corn baked in an oven (lit., 'fried bread') (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok;

FH/09/24/01/pc); turnover bread (cornbread fried in a little grease in a skillet) (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok; FH/09/24/01/pc); deep-fried frybread (rarer usage) (01/13/95/FH/pc:ok; FH/09/24/01/pc).

wacúesku (variant of wacúe skúðe).

wacúeçtò (variants: wacúe çtôka, wacúe çtôke). N cornbread (lit., 'soft bread') (FH/09/24/01/ok; RBn1413; 01/13/95/FH/pc). wacúe çtôke soft cornbread (lit., 'soft bread'; wacúe çtôke is fresh cornbread, never refers to wheat bread) (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2).  

•• LFD 187: wacúe çtòka <wa-dsiu´-e shtoæ-ga> corn meal [translation is unexpected and may be erroneous].

wacúexà (variants: wacúexò, wacúaxà, wacúxa). N cornshuck, corn husk. wacúaxà hkôbra I want the cornshuck (BE2.25) [Saying this signals 'I want to make a smoke' so as to make a prayer at a peyote meeting (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok).]

•• JOD (slip file): wacúcexa <wa-¦t¦sü´-¦t¦se-qa> corn husks.

•• LFD 187: wacúexò <wa-dsiu´-e-xoæ> corn husks.

wacúexo (variant: wacúexoe). N flour (BE2.49; 01/26/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• RB: <wah-tsú-eh-xó> (01/26/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.49).

•• LFD 187: wacúe <wa-dsiu´-e> flour.

wacúexò (variant of wacúexà).

wacúexò oðiçi. N dumplings, tamales (lit., 'wrapped in husks').

•• LFD 187 (unconfirmed): wacúexò oðiçì <wa-dsu´-e-xoæ u-thi-shiæ> corn dumplings, rolled up in corn husks and boiled. Green corn is generally used. Very similar to tamales.

wacúhta. N animal (JS). wacúhta záani eeçkítà ípahòpe all the animals knew him, too (JS: Osage Stories:

Coyote and Bear).  

•• LFD 188: wacúhta <wa-dsu´-¾a> living creatures; animals; a term used in rituals.

wacúxa (variant of wacúexà).

wacØé (variant of wacØéka).

wacØéðe. V [reg., wacØé_ðe] [wa- VAL + cØéðe (but sometimes used as transitive)] (intr., trans.) kill others; kill folks. wacØéàðe ðìké we don't kill at all (FH:ok). awácØeðai I killed [unexpected form] (FH: prod). wacØéaðe I killed. wacØéðaðe you killed. wacØéàðape we killed. wacØéaðe I killed him. wacØéðaðe you killed, you killed him (FH). 

•• LFD 206: wacØéðe <wa-¾s'e´-the> the act of killing in battle or in a quarrel at home. wacØeáðe <wa-¾s'e-a´-the> [position of accent is unexpected] I killed him. wacØeðaðe <wa-¾s'e-tha-the> you killed him.

wacØéka (variant: wacØé). ADJ gentle, docile, tame, not wild, not difficult, easy to do (01/31/95/FH/pc). wacØéka akxai he's gentle (FH/09/24/01/okc; BE2.53). çôëì apa wacØéka the little puppy is gentle (FH/09/24/01/prod). hkáwa akxa wacØéka akxai the horse is gentle (FH/09/24/01/pc:prod). waëáëeíe wacØéka çkáaãe you make Osage language easy (01/31/95/FH/pc:prod orig). • tender (LF) ['Tender' only as describing materials, not as a personality trait (RB).]  

•• LFD 206, 205: wacØéka <wa-¾s'e´-ga> tender; as meat, grains of corn; not difficult; easy, docile, gentle; easily managed (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok).

••• Cf. hápa wacØéka. 

waðáahtà. V [sync., wa_ðáahtà] [wa- VAL + ðaahtâ (but sometimes used as transitive)] (intr., trans.) drink alcohol. níhka akxa wáli lôði akxai, hpéecenii huuwáli waðáahtàpe that man is really drunk, he's drunk a lot of liquor (RBn12-06). wiëîke akxa waðáahtà kíðalìpe Sonny really likes to drink.

•• LFD 142: wabráhtà <wa-btha´-¾oæ> I drank. waçtáhtà <wa-shda´-¾oæ> you drank. wáðaaska. ADV, V [sync., wá_ðaaska] [wa- + ðaa- 'by mouth' + ská 'white, clear'] (speak) clearly; (make) plain, distinct, or clear, clarify, elucidate (lit., 'by mouth make it clear to folks'). íe wáðaaskape he makes the words plain. íe wábraaska I explained it, I made it plain (FH/11/19/01/pc:ok).

••• Cf. wáðuuska. 

waðáaçoe. V [sync., wa_ðáaçoe] [wa- VAL + ðaaçóe] (intr.) smoke. wabráaçoe I'm smoking.

waðáawa. V [sync. wa _ðáawa] [wa- VAL + ðaawá] (intr.) count, say numbers. waðáawa ðatxâçe you count. wabráawa àtxâhe I'm counting. waðáawa akxai he's counting. waçtáawa nìkçé you're counting.

• N counting, number(s).

•• LFD 201: waðáwa <wa-tha´-wa> counting. wabráwa <wa-btha´-wa> I am counting. waçtáwa <wa-shda´-wa> you are counting.

waðáawa htâke (variant: waðáawa htâka). ADJP, N million (lit., 'big count') (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.87).

•• RB: <wah-tháh-wah túæ-keh>.

•• LFD 201: waðáwahtàka <wa-tha´-wa-¾oæ-ga> a million, counting big.

waðáawa lébrà. N dime, ten cents (lit., 'ten count') (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.31).

•• LFD 201: waðáwalebrà <wa-tha´-wa-gthe-bthoæ> a dime. waðáwa; lebrà <wa-tha´-wa; gthebthoæ> cents; ten: ten cents.

waðáawa sáhtà. N nickel, five cents (lit., 'five count') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.93).

waðáawa ëúuce (variant: waðáawa ëúu). N penny (lit., 'red count') (03/07/95/PM/pc).

waðáawaëì (variant: wáawaëì). N [waðáawa + -ëì 'little'] penny, cent, change, coins (lit., 'little count')

(03/07/95/PM/pc:ok). wáawaëì ðiðúuze hta apai they are going to take pennies away from you (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). wáawaëì àçcúuze hta níkçé? are you going to take pennies away from me? are you going to take the change away from me? (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2).  

waðáaxtake. V [sync., wa_ðáaxtake] [wa- VAL + ðaaxtáke] (intr.) bite folks, bite people. waðáaxtake! he bites people! (BE2.9).

waðáazo. V, N [sync.?, wa_ðáazo] [wa- VAL + ðaazó] (intr.) lulu, ululate (i.e., produce the high-pitched, shrill sound that the women singers around the drum sometimes make at an event such as a dance to show that they are pleased by gifts they have just received or by the dancing or some other stimulus; a sound similar to yodeling) (FH/08/22/96).

••• Cf. kízo. 

waðákØeðe. V, ADJ [stat., waðákØe_ðe] [wa- VAL + ðakØéðe] (be a) kind or generous person. waðákØeðíðe nìkçé aape, ðe età, ðakØéwaðapi they said you were kind, so pity us.

waðánii. N Tonkawa (tribe or tribal member) (BE2.143; 03/23/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 200: waðáhni <Wa-tha´-hni> Tonkawa Tribe.

wáðastástá. ADJ [wa- VAL + + reduplicated form of ásta (ð is epenthetic)] sticky (lit., 'keeps sticking to stuff') (MSB 2-25-83).

waðe. CAUSATIVE STEM [reg., wa_ðe] [wa- VAL + ðe CAU] make one, make people, make folks.

••• Cf. kôðawaðe, tôpewaðe. 

waðíhohota (variant: waðíhoohta). N [reduplicated form of wáðihota] clown (BE2.21; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 202: waðíhohota <wa-thi´-ho-ho-da> a droll. wisàka ata waðihohota kiðalì pe <wi-šoæga a-da wa-thi-ho-ho-da gi-tha-gthiæ bi a> my brother is fond of joking; one fond of practical jokes.

wáðihota. V [wa- '3rd person pl. patient' + ðíhota] fool them.

waðíhta. V [uninfl./stat., wa_ðíhta] (intr.) be one's turn. waðíðihta ðinîe it's your turn to take over, you're it (said to next one whose turn it is to hit drum in a meeting) (RBn23-16). [Expected 1st sg. form: âwàðihaà 'it's my turn'; expected 1st pl. form: wáwaðihtapi 'it's our turn'; expected 3rd pl. form:

wáwaðihta 'it's their turn'.] waðíhta ðíe it's your turn (said to fire chief at peyote meeting when it is his turn to carry drum) (RB; 03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). waðíhta ðíe it's your turn (to hit drum) (RBn3-22).  

waðíhtà. V [sync., wa_ðíhtà] (intr.) do work, farm. ónihkaçi çí tà, waçäíhtà tà when you are a saved person, when your work [on earth] is done (lit., 'when you arrive at fulfilment as a person, when you do work') (RBn12-10/MOJ). howâìki waçcihtà ðáìçe? where are you working? where are you farming? (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). kasîe waçcíhtà hta paaçé? are you all going to work tomorrow? waðíhtà aðáape he/she went to work (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.160). waðíhta àkái we work (RBn1203p3).  • N work, employment, job; place of employment, workplace, office (03/24/95/PM/pc:okc). hòpá waðíhtà pçíe I went to work today (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). waðíhtà aðáape he or she went to work (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.160).

•• LFD 202: waðíhtà <wa-thi´-¾oæ> to farm, to work in the field; a household servant, a domestic [unconfirmed gloss]; any kind of work or labor. wabríhtà <wa-bthi´-¾oæ> I work. àwâðihtà pe <oæwoæ´-thi-¾oæ i> we work. waðíhtà olì kçiðe <wa-thi´-¾oæ u-gthiæ kshi-the> to install a man into an office.  

••• Cf. waðíhtàçtà. 

waðíhtà olîì. VP [reg., waðíhtà o_lîì] (intr.) occupy an office, serve in a post.

•• LFD 202: waðíhtà olì kçiðe <wa-thi´-¾oæ u-gthiæ kshi-the> to install a man [could probably be a woman as well] into an office.

waðíhtà wakáaëi. N foreman; driver, chauffeur (03/24/95/PM/pc).

•• LFD 201: waðíhtà wakaëi <wa-thi´-¾oæ wa-ga-zhi> a foreman.

waðíhtàçtà. N [waðíhtà +çtà] workaholic, one who works all the time (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 202: waðíhtàçtà <wa-thi´-¾oæ-shtoæ> industrious; hard-working. wabríhtàçtà <wa-bthi´¾oæ-shtoæ> I am industrious. àwâðihtàçtà pe <oæ-woæ´-thi-¾oæ-shtoæ i> we are industrious. wakØo akxa waðihtó inàhi pe <wa-Ð'u a-ka wa-thi-¾o´ i-noæ-hi bi a> the woman is industrious [better translation: 'the woman is willing to work'].

waðíiðiiski. V [uninfl.?] [reduplicated form of waðíiski] (intr.) gather together with folks ðôha waachí hta apa, háatkxàta waðíiðiiski hta nìkçé? it's almost time for the dances, when are you [sg.] going to get together [with them]? (FH:4/24/96/tape).

waðíihice. V [sync., wa_ðíihice] [wa- VAL + ðiihíce] (intr.) tease people. çíi akxa waðíihici akxái that person is teasing (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p11). waðíihice kízope he likes to tease (03/16/95/FH/pc:okc; MREI/t116a). waðíihice çtàpe he is always teasing. wabríihice àhe I was playing with him, teasing him (01-27-83).  

•• LFD 201: waðíhice <wa-thi´-hi-dse> meddler; a mischief-maker. waðíhice akxa <wa-thi´-hidse a-ka> persecutor.

waðíiski (variant: wawáðiiski). V [inflected only for object in available data] [wa- VAL + ðiiskí] (intr.) gather together; (trans.) gather with s.o. hâàpa ðé wawáðiiski nìkçe, wéewinai I'm glad you [sg.] have gathered [with them] here today (FH:4/24/96/tape; BE2.53; 04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). N gathering of people (e.g., at a dance) (FH:4/24/96/tape).

•• LFD 201: waðíski <wa-thi´-ški> to assemble, to gather together men for council.  

••• Cf. waðíiðiiski. 

waðíiçki. V [sync., wa_ðíiçki] [wa- VAL + ðiiçkí] (intr.) do laundry, wash clothes, wash s.t. • N laundry (clothes needing washing). waçäíiçki you wash clothes (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 202: waðíçki <wa-thi´-shki> to wash clothes. wabríçki <wa-bthi´-shki> I wash clothes (02/14/95/FH/pc:ok).  

waðíiçkihci (variant: waíiçkihci). N [waðíiçki + hcí] laundry (the place), laundry house. waðíiçkihci ci çcée tà ëówile brée hkôbra when you go to the laundry, I want to go with you.

•• RB: <wah-í-shki-tsi> (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.76).

•• LFD 202: waðíçki hci <wa-thi´-shki ¾si> a washhouse, laundry.

waðílà. V [sync., wa_ðílà] (intr.) think things; think about, think on, ponder, muse about (especially about things in the past or events that have already occurred). wabrílà mìkçé I'm thinking about it

(03/20/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn10-05:JW). àwáðilà we're thinking. • N mind, brain, thought, soul, thinking (RBn10-5:JW; RBn2-MOJ/p8ff). waðílà wákalà âðiicíza take these dirty thoughts away (RBn103:MOJ/79).

•• RB: <wah-thí-d-?-lah>.

•• LFD 201: waðílà <wa-thi´-gthoæ> to meditate; reverie, day dreaming. intellect, sense; sound judgement. wabrílà <wa-bthi´-gthoæ> I meditate. àwàðilà pe <oæ-woæ-thi-gthoæ i> we meditate. áwabrilà <a´-wa-bthi-gthoæ> I considered it (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok). waðílàðìke <Wa-thi´-gthoæ-thiæge> No-mind (personal name) (unconfirmed as a name: 03/01/95/FH/pc:ok, but unknown as a name).

••• Cf. áwaðilà.  

waðílà áçka. ADJP, VP [conjug. unknown] (intr.) (be) irritable, easily angered, cranky, irascible. waðílà áçkape he gets mad easily (RBn23-14).

•• LFD 113: nôce áçka <noæ´-dse a-shka> heart quickly moved; quick to anger; a quarrelsome disposition.

waðílà ðáalì màðî. VP [(reg.+) sync., waðílà ðáalì (_)mà_ðî] (intr.) be satisfied (lit., 'walk with a good mind').

waðílà eekô ìké (variant: waðílàekòìké). ADJP, VP [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) wayward, unruly, not in one's right mind. • N crazy person, person of unsound mind, demented person. waðílàekòìkí apai, ðekôòci áhkihtòpa ðì there are crazies around, now watch out for yourself.

waðílà hkihkáaãe. VP [reg.+sync. k>p, waðílà _hkih_káaãe] make up one's mind on one's own, decide for oneself. [For example, a young woman deciding to get married without permission of her parents, who should marry her off (FH). (In the 1980s, it was still thought by some elders to be improper for a young woman to make up her own mind about whom to marry and when.)] [Expected (but unattested) inflectional forms: waðílà áhkihpaaãe 'I decide for myself'. waðílà ðáhkiçkaaãe 'you decide for yourself'. waðílà àhkíhkaaãe 'we decide for ourselves'.] waðílà hkihkáaãe akxai they made their own mind up (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok, prod). waðílà hkihkáaãipe, koe çómìhkasi hôòe éekò çí íiðe htai [expected Mod. Os. form: waðílà hkihkáaãape koe çómìhkasi hôòe éekòëi íiðe hta ðe] she made up her mind, the coyote would never see anybody like her again (RBn17-p03). oáhkihkaçà hpímà, htáaëì akxa waðílà hkihkáaãape  I know how to take care of myself, the little deer thought [decided, made up his mind]  (RBn15-002).

waðílà hpíiëi. N bad temper. waðílà hpíiëi àhe I've got a bad temper (lit., 'I am characterized by a bad temper') (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; MREI/t95).

waðílà káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, waðílà _káaãe] (intr.) decide, make up one's mind. waðílà káaãa! make up your mind! (04/07/95/LS/pc:okc; RBn2-MOJ/p21).

waðílà kikáaãe. VP [sync. k>p, waðílà _ki_káaãe] [waðílà + ki- INCEPTIVE + káaãe] (intr.) change one's mind (lit., 'make up one's mind anew'). waðílà çi kikáaãe tà ée kôðaëipe he didn't want her to change her mind again (RBn17-p04).

waðílà ochí (variant: waílà ochí). ADJ wise. súhkahtâà mîka waílà ochí hcí wì káaãe, anâðapaëi che aëì ðíaape that wise turkey hen has made a nest where she thinks we can't find it (RBn19-05).

waðílà waxpáðì. N worry (lit., 'mind suffering'). waðílà waxpáì òô ðée apai worry is upon them (FH/09/24/01/pc).

waðílàekòìké (variant of waðílà eekô ìké).

waðílàhtàà (variant: waðílàhtòò). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (be) smart, intelligent; (be) a smart person; have a good mind (BE2.124); learn, adjust the mind. taaçéðe tà, waðílàhtòò hta apai shake him up, he is going to learn (FH:98/pc). taaçéðe tà, waðílàhtòò hta apai when you hit him on the head, that will make his mind get right (FH/10/13/96). • N good mind, intelligence, large brain (RBn10-5:JW; RBn2MOJ/p8ff). waðî. N drumkeeper. [Shortened version of céãenii aðî.] waðîpe. V [1st person pl. of ðî 'be' + api 'pl.' + ðe DECL] we are.

wáðohtà (variants: wáðohta, waðóhta). ADJ straight; reliable, respectable, proper, honest

(04/19/95/FH/pc). [Refers to a person's way of living rather than to conduct of the moment and hence is often used in admonishments (as in making one's ways straight, reforming, straightening out, going straight in one's behavior); contrasts with óðohtà, which refers to immediate behavior or conduct of the moment and thus may be used, for example, to scold childen for their current actions.] wáðohtà mâì keep yourself straight (BE2.129). wáðohtà ahkílaðì keep yourself straight
