(FH:4/24/96/prod). wáðohta ahkílai I behave myself/carry myself straight (RBn; MREI/01/11/93?). ëìkáëì wíhta wáðohta níhkaçika waðákiçkaaãe hkôbra I want you to make my children proper people

(RBn19-06). níhkaçie wáðohtapi nà he's proper/reliable/good/respectable (RBn22-17). wáðohtà mìkçé I'll behave myself (MOJ-11-19-83). wasái waðóhta ípahòpe they knew the bear was honest/respectable (RBn16-02). • ADV clearly, straight, properly, truthfully. íe wáðohtà speak clearly, straight or truthfully (FH).

waðótaðe. V [presumably reg., waðóta_ðe] [wa- VAL + ðótaðe] make peace (LF only).

•• LFD 202: <wa-tho´-da-the>.

wáðuãaëi (variant: waðúãaëi). N [wáðuãe + aëí] female who has not married; virgin.

•• LFD 352: wáðiãaëi <wa´-thi-xa-zhi> virgin.

wáðuãe. V, ADJ [sync., wá_ðuãe] [wa- VAL + áðuãe] (intr.) (be or get) married (said of a female).

wáçäuãe ðaaçé? are you married? wáçcuãe? did you marry? (FH:4/25/96/tape). koe ónòò ëiçò çí tà çî tà koe hpíiëi ëiçò çí tà koe péeçki ðikôða htai wáçäuãe ðáalì before you get old and before you get fat and ugly and nobody wants you, you should get married (RB). ehta wábruãe màëí hta akxai maybe I better not get married (RBn17-p02). • N wedding (used by bride's friends or family). wáðuãe brée ðe I'm going to a wedding [spoken by family or friend of the bride] (02/27/95/JS/pc; CQc).

•• RB: <wah-thú-xeh, wáh-thu-xeh>.

•• JOD (slip file): waðúãe <wa-¢ü´-xªe> to take a husband, to marry.

•• LFD 204: wáðuãe <wa´-thu-xe> to marry; to take a husband. LFD 122: àëîka xci tà wabriãe <oæ-zhiæ´-ga xtsi doæ wa-bthi-xe> I married when I was a young woman.  

••• Cf. wéðuãe.

waðúupxai. V [presumably sync., wa_ðúupxai] [presumably wa- VAL +ðuupxáðe] (intr. or trans.?) investigate (RBn22-17, unconfirmed).

wáðuuska. V [(reg.)+sync., (_)wá_ðuuska] [presumably wa- VAL + ðu-/ði- INSTR + skáha] (intr.) make things plain (such as words or lines on a paper, borders on land); clarify or elucidate things (FH).

waðúuçtaha. V [(reg.)+sync., (_)wa_ðúuçtaha] [wa- VAL +ðuuçtáha] (intr.) iron s.t., iron. hôòpa ðé awábrúuçtaha hta mìkçé I'm going to iron all day [secondary accent on -brúu-]. hâàpa záani wabrúuçtaha I ironed all day.

waðúwì. V [sync., wa_ðúwì] [wa- VAL + ðuwî] (intr.) buy things.

waðúwì aðée. VP [sync., waðúwì (a)_ðée] (intr.) shop, go shopping (lit., 'buy stuff'). waðúwì brée I'm going shopping.

wahâ. N yarn (BE2.162 & FH:ok; 03/24/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 191: wahâ <wa-hoæ´> the cross threads in weaving, the woof, a single thread or strand of worsted yarn.

wahâ káaãe. N yarn work (as product or activity) (lit., 'yarn making') (03/24/95/PM/pc:okc; FH/09/24/01/pc/ok; BE2.162).

•• RB: <wáh-háhæ-gáh-xeh>.

wáhce tooka. N star, morning star or male star.

•• LFD 205: wáhce toka <wa´-¾se do-ga> the male star, the morning star (unconfirmed). wahcéehtà. N first son, in hcíëo clan (FH/11/17/01/pc). [The name that everyone would use for the male if no boy name was given to him when young; sometimes this adult name is used constantly by all, even if a boy name has been given (FH).]  

wahcéka. N [wa- VAL + hcéka] treasure; valuable or special things, things a person has put away as special, keepsakes (HHtape9, sideb/p2); new things. wahcéka owákihce I'm looking for new things (FH/09/24/01/prod).

wahcéxi. V, ADJ [uninfl.] [wa- VAL + hcéxi] (be) difficult, hard, challenging, not easy to do (FH). waëáëeíe wahcéxi Osage language is difficult (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok). óðohta ahkílai wahcéxi it's difficult to live a straight life, it's hard to keep yourself straight (RBn23-17; BE2.31; 01/20/95/FH/pc:ok).  

•• LFD 206: wahcéxi <wa-¾se´-xi> difficult to destroy, to be tenacious of life (term used in some of the rituals of the tribal rites); stingy, ungenerous, not liberal, penurious. wahcéxi walì pe <wa¾se´-xi wa-gthiæ bi a> he is very stingy.

••• KS waääéxi hard, difficult to endure (RR).

wahcîì (variants: wahcîe; wahtîì or wahtîe [archaic]). V [conjug. unknown] [wa- VAL + hcîì] (intr.) appear, show, be showing or visible, appear suddenly. ëé wahtîe apái his penis is showing. oðíkinààëi oðíina çôce wahtîì fasten your pants, your penis is showing (RBn2-MOJ/p21; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

wahéhe. ADJ weak (e.g., a human, an animal, an object, or a material). áalìì wahéhe tòpéwai the chair looks weak (BE2.152; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). wahéhe mìkçé àëì sísi nìkçé I am weak, but thou art strong (line in a Christian hymn) (MOJ; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 191: wahéhe <wa-he´-he> weak, feeble, soft. wahéhe kaãe <wa-he´-he ga-xe> [expected Mod. Os. form: wahéhe káaãe 'to make someone weak'] to weaken. wahéhe hpaãe <wahe´-he ¼a-xe> I was made weak [rather, 'I made him/her/it weak']. wahéha çkaãe <wa-he´-ha shkaxe>you were made weak [rather, 'you made him/her/it weak'] . wahéhe àkaãa pe <wa-he´-he oæ-gaxa i> we were made weak [rather, 'we made him/her/it weak'].

wahélele (variant of waléle).

wáhice. V [presumed reg., wá_hice] (trans.) hurry s.o. along, make s.o. hurry. [Expected (but unattested) inflectional forms: áwahice 'I hurry folks', waðáhice 'you hurry folks', àwáhice 'we hurry folks'.]  

••• Cf. íhice.

wahitôci (variant of wihtôce).

wáhkie (variant: áwahkie). N [presumably wa- VAL + áhkie] lawyer, attorney (lit., 'taking up for a person').

•• RB: <wah-kai-ah> or <wáh-ki-eh> (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.76) [FH prefers the version wáhkie.]

••• Cf. áwahkie.

wahkílaace (variant: wahkílaa). N [wa- VAL + hkik- RECIP/REFL + ðaacé 'name, say'] law, regulations, rules (lit., 'things spoken about to each other' by a group of people) (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn1MOJ/p43). wahkílaace áðihtà he violates the law (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). wáhkilaace akxai it's the rule (BE2.76). wahkílaace oðóohpa akxái he's obeying the law (02/15/95/FH/pc). wahkílaace oðóohpa nàpe she obeys the law (02/15/95/FH/pc). wahkílaace káaãe apai they're making it into law.

•• LFD 192: wáhkilace <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse> statute, law: things, possessive sign, spoken: words spoken by a group of persons for their own use or benefit, law; any rule of action agreed upon by the male members of a tribe, ordinance (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc, but accent on second syllable: wahkílaace).

wáhkilace owahpa <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse u-wa-¼a> [hp <¼> is presumably an error for px <p>] I obey the law (02/14/95/FH/pc:uk). wáhkilace oðahpa <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse u-tha-¼a> [hp <¼> is presumably an error for px <p>] you obey the law. wáhkilace ohpa <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse u-¼a> [hp <¼> is presumably an error for px <p>] he obeys the law.

wahkílaace áðihta (variant: wahkílaace áðihtà). VP [sync., wahkílaace á_ðihta] violate the law, break a rule. wahkílaace áðihtà he violates the law 0 (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 192: wáhkilace aðihta <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse a-thi-¾a> to violate [the law].  

wahkílaace káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, wahkílaace _káaãe] legislate, make laws (as in Congress). • N lawmakers, legislators, congressman, congresswoman, representative (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 193: wáhkilace kaãe <wa´-Ði-gtha-dse ga-xe> to make laws, legislate, legislation, law makers.

wahkílae wakáçupe. N [presumably wahkílai (or perhaps wahkílaace?) + wa- VAL + kaçúpe] cash payment.

•• LFD 193: wahkílae wakaçipe <wa-Ði´-gtha-e wa-ga-shi-be> a money payment to members of the tribe by the Government (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

wahkílai (variants: wahkílae, wáhkila). N payment (the quarterly payment some Osages receive) (RB). [It is not certain whether this word can be used of other kinds of payment.] Mongrain akxa wahkílai kízo akxá ska Mongrain is enjoying his payment [I suppose] (RBn10-9:JW; CQc; 03/06/95/FH/pc:okc). • rations from the government (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• RB: <wah-kí-laiæ>.

•• LFD 193: wahkílae <wa-Ði´-gtha-e> issue of Government rations.

wahkô (variant of wahkôta).

wahkôi. ADV hurried, in a hurry, rushed. wahkôì brée hta mìkçé I'm in a hurry (RBn14-05, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 217 (unconfirmed): wàkô <woæ-goæ´> soon. wàkâ ða ðì ho <woæ-goæ´ tha thiæ ho> [sentence-final ho is not used in Mod. Os.] go in haste, in haste.

••• KS wakkâya rush to rescue somebody (RR).

wahkôta (variant: wahkô). N God. ìhtáci wahkôta our heavenly father (lit., 'father God') (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.59).  

•• LFD 193: wahkòta <Wa-Ðoæ´-da> God. "[T]he name applied by the Osage to the mysterious, invisible, creative power which brings into existence all living things of whatever kind." LFD 54: letâwahkò <Gthe-doæ´-wa-Ðoæ> Mystery-hawk (personal name).

wahkôta íe oðáake. N preacher (lit., 'tells God's word') (BE2.107, RBn2-MOJ/p11; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).  

wahkôta iëîke. N Jesus Christ (lit., 'God's son') (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok). wahkôta iëîke iihô mother of Christ (02/13/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.72). wahkôta iëîke íe Jesus' teachings.  

wahkôta iëîke hâàpa iðáalì. INTERJ [í- LOC + ðáalì] Merry Christmas! (lit., 'good with God's son's day') (DN-WHM, unconfirmed).

wahkôta iëîke iihô. N mother of Jesus, Mary (lit., 'God's son's mother'). wahkôta iëîke iihô hpaxîì ìkçe xôòce íkòce káaãi apai they're making the cedar like Mary's hair (FH).  

wahkôta iëîke íikitaðe (variant: wahkôta iëîke íikita[e]). N [wahkôta + iëîke + ki- INCEPTIVE + iitáðe] Christmas (lit., 'God's son is born again'; implies the day recurs) (FH; RB).

wahkôta mâëà. N heaven (lit., 'God's land').

wahkôtahci. N [wahkôta + hcí] church, house of God.

wahkôtaki. V, N [stat., wa_hkôtaki] (intr.) (be a) doctor, physician, healer, minister of a religious group, preacher (04/07/95/LS/pc:prod). waðíhkòtakie you are a doctor (RB, LS:ok). wahkôtaki nî áapie [Mod. Os. form: áape instead of áapie] they said you were a doctor (BE2.33) wahkôtaki kçi pçíe ðe I went to the doctor [kçi is optional in this sentence; reference to the office of the doctor is implied] (04/26/95/FH/pc:okc). wahkôtaki pçíe I went to the doctor (03/08/95/MREI/pc; BE2.118).

•• LFD 194: wahkôtaki <wa-Ðoæ´-da-gi> a person who has knowledge of medicine; a physician; a doctor; one who pretends to communicate with the dead; a necromancer; occult; magic; holy; sacred; anything held sacred. wahkôtaki kipâ ðe awa hkiðe ha <wa-Ðoæ´-da-gi gi-boæ the a-wa Ði-the ha> [expected Mod. Os. form for 'I send for' is áwakçíðe rather than awa hkiðe; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I sent for a physician. LFD 142: ðawáhkòtaki <tha-wa´-Ðoæ-da-gi> to represent a sacred object as having supernatural powers [ðaa- INSTR 'by mouth' + wahkôtaki, i.e., 'call/designate it as supernatural'].

wahkúcØa. ADJ lame (RB).

•• LFD 193: wahkílicØake <wa-Ði´-gthi-¾s'a-ge> cripple.

wahléhle, wahléle (variants of waléle).

wahóhota. N [reduplicated form of wahóta] funny, amusing, or comical person, one who is always making people laugh, joker, clown. • ADJ funny, amusing, comical (BE2.21, 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 202: waðíhohota <wa-thi´-ho-ho-da> a droll. wisòka ata waðihohota kiðalì pi a <wi-šoæga a-da wa-thi-ho-ho-da gi-tha-gthiæ bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form: wisôka apa waðihohota kiðaalì pe] my brother is fond of joking.

••• Cf. waðíhohota. 

wahókØa. V, ADJ [stat., wa_hókØa] (intr.) (be) small, little; (be) young (03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok). àwâhokØa I'm small. waðíhokØa you're small. óhka wahókØa a small space (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). àwâhokØa tà when I was little (RBn21-01HL, FH:okc). • N small amount; reduced quantity. wahókØa óoëu [pour]

just a little (lit., 'little bit pour') (03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok, RB).

•• LFD 191: wahókØa <wa-ho´-k'a> a young person ['person' unconfirmed]. waðíhokØa <wathi´-ho-Ð'a> you are young, a juvenile.

wahókØaëì. V, ADJ [stat., wa_hókØaëì] [wahókØa + -ëì 'little'] (intr.) (be) very small or very young (RB: MREI:ok).

wahóohtà (variant: wahóohta). N [wa- VAL + hóohtà (or perhaps wa- VAL + hóohtà + ðe CAU [LF])] gun, handgun, rifle, shotgun, pistol, revolver (perhaps lit. 'cause things to cry out' [LF]). wahóohta açäî htape? are you all going to have guns? (03/10/95/PM/pc:ok). wahóohtà lókialà [lóhkialà?] shotgun with a big trigger (RBn HW10, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 192: wahóhtàðe <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the> a gun.  

wahóohtà ápahazi. N [ápaha (not otherwise attested)+ zí] rifle (lit., 'gun with yellow [on top back(?)]', referring to the brass sight on top of a rifle).

•• LFD 192: wahóhtàðe apahazi <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the a-ba-ha-ši> a rifle with a brass sight. (unconfirmed; 03/02/95/FH/pc:uk; 03/10/95/PM/pc:uk).

wahóohtà hpa (variant of wahóohtà táahpa).

wahóohtà opáaxò. N [ó- LOC + paaxô] breech-loading shotgun (lit., 'gun that breaks by pushing on').

•• LFD 192: wahóhtàðe opaxò <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the u-ba-xoæ> a breech loading gun. (03/02/95/FH/pc:ma; 03/10/95/PM/pc:uk).

wahóohtà táahpa (variant: wahóohtà hpa). N pistol (lit., 'round gun') (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn3-MOJ/p5; 04/11/95/LS/pc:uk; BE2.103). [Refers to the round chamber in pistols as opposed to the rectangular chamber in rifles and shotguns (except breech-loading ones) in early days. Pistols were the first guns to have round chambers.]

•• RB: <wah-hó-tah-páh> (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc).

•• LFD 192: wahóhtàðe tahpa <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the da-¼a> a pistol. wahóhtàðe hpa <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the ¼a> a pistol.

wahóohtàëì (variant: wahóohtàhpaëî) (RB; 04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). N [wahóohtà + -ëì 'little'] revolver (lit.,

'small gun'). [Early revolvers were much smaller than pistols of the time.]

•• LFD 192: wahóhtàðe hpa ëìka <wa-ho´-¾oæ-the ¼a zhiæ-ga> a revolver.

wahóçce (variants: wahóçäe, wahósce, wahóçäa). ADJ, V [uninfl. or stat., wa_hóçce] (be) small, little (RBn10-5:MOJ/79; 7/8/94/PM/num98b; 02/16/95/FH/pc:prod); (be) narrow, slim. wahóçce brîe I'm small. wahóçce àkai we're small (FH:08/05/99). çôke akxa wálì wahóçäe akxa that dog is really little (FH:08/05/99/DNpc; BE2.123). okáhàpa wahósce a small window (04/28/95/LS/pc). çôke wahóçce a little dog (BE2.80). wahóçäaëì tiny, quite little.

•• RB: <wah-hó-shchiah, wah-hó-stseh, wah-hó-shtah> [note all three grades: sc, çcm, çä].

•• LFD 192: wahósta <wa-hu´-sta> small, tiny. LFD 168: okáhàpa wahosca <u-ga´-hoæ-ba waho-stsa> a small pane of glass for a window.

wahóçäa, wahóçäe (variants of wahóçce).

wahóçäaëì. V, ADJ [uninfl. or stat., wa_hóçäaëì] [wahóçäe + -ëì 'little'] (intr.) very little, quite small, tiny (7/8/94/PM/num98b).

•• LFD 192: wahósca ëìka <wa-hu´-stsa zhiæ-ga> very small, minute. wahósca ëìka <wa-ho´stsa zhiæ-ga> small, tiny, minute.

wahóta. ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) funny, amusing, comical (FH). táatà wahóta wì something funny (lit., 'a funny thing') (3-3-83-p2).

•• LFD 192: wahóta <wa-hu´-da> amusing.

••• Cf. ðíhota, wahóhota, ëáëe wahóta. 

wahótaðe. V [reg., wahóta_ðe] (trans.) make fun of s.o. (LS).

wahówahá. N Potawatomi (tribe or tribal member) (ERE, unconfirmed; 03/08/95/PM/pc:uk; 04/18/95/FH/pc:uk).

••• KS wáhi óyaha Potawatomie (JOD) (RR), badó wadôbe Potawatomie (RR). tribe

wahôì (variant: wahôò). V [reg., wa_hôì] (intr.) address folks with respect (MREI; HRE/01/17/02/pc). áwahòì I address folks with respect. waðáhòì you address folks with respect. wahôò hpáëìka I don't know how to address folks (RBn1-41). wahôò na ðáalì áapa nôò apa they said we should show this respect, the elders (RBn1-41). • (trans.) address as friends and relatives. záani wawíhòìpi I address you all as friends and relatives (FH/10/30/9/pc/ok). wihtâke, wiëî, wisôka, wawíhòìpi sisters, elder brothers, younger brothers, I wish to address you with respect [man speaking] (MREI). wiëôa, wihtáeëì, wihcîto, wisòa, wawíhòìpi elder sisters, younger sisters, elder brothers, younger brothers, I wish to address you with respect [woman speaking] (MREI).  

wahôìke. V, N [stat., wa_hôìke] [wahôì +ðìké] (be an) orphan.

•• JOD (Wasápeëìka letter, ln2, 3): waðíhòìke <wa-¢íhªuæ-iñ´¦ki au> you are an orphan. JOD

(Devouring Mountain p1 ln4): wahôìëìka <wa-hªuæ´-išiñÐa> little orphan [wahôìke + ëìká] (BE2.99; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 191: wahôìke <wa-hoæ´-iæ-ge> no mother, an orphan. "The word was used among the

Indians when speaking of a child with neither father nor mother, an orphan."

wahôò (variant of wahôì).

wahpáce (variant: wáhpace) V [reg., wa_hpáce] [wa- VAL + hpáce] (intr.) perform surgery on folks; butcher, cut up meat (BE2.14; 02/08/95/FH/pc:okc; FH:4/22/96/tape). [The original meaning of this word may be 'perform surgery'; the normal Mod. Os. form for 'butcher' is wapáse.] 

•• RB: <wah-páh-tseh>.

•• LFD 239 (unconfirmed): wahpáce <wa-¼a´dse> butcher.  

wahpíò. V [conjug. unknown] [wa- VAL + hpíò] (intr.) learn, learn how to do s.t., be skilled at doing things (04/14/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• RB: <wah-pyúæ>.

wahpóka (variant: wáhpoke). N owl (03/03/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn1-MOJ/p58). [The call of any kind of owl at night is considered bad luck (FH).]  

•• LFD 198: wahpóka <wa-¼o´-ga> the gray owl, an Osage symbol of night, also a life symbol. "It is a bird that succeeds in bringing its young safely to maturity." wahpóka htàka <wa-¼o´-ga ¾oæga> the great gray owl. wahpóka waðò <wa-¼o´-ga wa-thoæ> Songs of the Gray Owl.

••• KS wappôga owl (not the screech owl), hoot owl.

wahríše. N Generous (non-Osage surname). [Hazel Harper's family's name. Wahríše is not an Osage word; it may be an Omaha cognate of Osage walíëi 'generous, not stingy'.] • ADJ generous. àkóhta wahríše wahkôta iëîke [expected Mod. Os. form: àkóhta wahkôta iëîke walíëi] ours through the bounty of Christ (DN-WHM, unconfirmed; FH: no).

wahtâà. N king (in a deck of cards) (RBn12-10/MOJ).

wahtîe, wahtîì (archaic variants of wahcîì).

wahtóke. V, ADJ [stat., wa_htóke] (be) industrious, have the qualities of a good worker, alert, not lazy, quick to do things, quick-acting (FH:ok). wahtóke apa he's a good worker (BE2.71;02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 206: wahtóke <wa-¾u´-ge> to be active, alert. àwâhtoke <oæ-woæ´-¾u-ge> I am active. waðíhtoke <wa-thi´-¾u-ge> you are active. LFD 204: wahtóke <wa-¾o´-ge> alert, quick, active. àwâhtoke <oæ-woæ´-¾o-ge> I am alert. waðíhtoke <wa-thi´-¾o-ge> you are alert. wahtóke <Wa¾o´-ge> Active (personal name).

wahtôka (variant: wahtâka). ADJ, N [possibly wa- VAL + htâka] authoritative; authority, s.o. with authority. áhkita wahtôka a soldier with authority (FH).

••• Cf. totâha wahtâka. 

wahtôpe. N onlookers. xóhka çki, wahtôpe çki, haanâ, hpáze ðe you singers and drummers, you onlookers, too, however many there are this evening (HREsr: 1965 ilôòçka, lines 1–2).  

••• Cf. watôpe. 

wahú. N bone (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). wahú wanôpØì a bone necklace (BE2.10).

•• LFD 191: wahí <wa-hi´> bones. wahú <wa-hiu´> a bone. wahúsàì <Wa-hiu´-šoæ-iæ> White-bones-woman (female personal name), refers to the story of bones left to whiten on the ground [sà is not recognized as 'white' in Mod. Os.].

wahúàkØì (variant of wahúìkØì).

wahúhka. N [wa- VAL 'stuff' + húhka] fork (01/30/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.50).

•• LFD 191: wahúhka ëahta <wa-hiu´-Ða zha-¾a> a fork, an awl, forked (01/30/95/FH/pc:uk with ëáhta).

wahúì (variants: wahûù, wahûe) V [reg., wa_húì] [probably wa- VAL + híò; for variation between iò and uì, see kçíòze] (intr.) move to another location, migrate (02/27/95/FH/pc). áwahùe I'm moving (02/27/95/FH/pc). wahûè hta akxai he's going to move. hcí hcéka àwáhùe hta mìkçé I'm going to move into the new house (FH/06/20/95). hcí hcéka ðiiçtâpi áape wahûe hta akxai they said that the new house is finished, so she's going to move in (FH/06/20/95). waëîka çki wahúì nòpe even birds migrate.

•• LFD 191: wahíò <wa-hi´-oæ> to pack up, as when preparing to break camp to move from place to place, to migrate, to remove, to depart, to break camp (02/27/95/FH/pc: pronunciation unconfirmed). awáhiò <a-wa´-hi-oæ> I broke camp. waðáhiò <wa-tha´-hi-oæ> you broke camp. àwâhiò pe <oæ-woæ´-hi-oæ i> we broke camp.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 191).

wahúìkØì (variant: wahúàkØì). V [conjug. unknown] [wahúì + kØî] (trans.) load for moving.

•• LFD 191: wahíàkØì <wa-hi´-oæ-Ð'iæ> to load, a load.

wahúni. N [wahú + níe] arthritis, rheumatism, lumbago (lit., 'bone hurt') (01/06/95/FH/pc: ok; BE2.4).

•• LFD 191: wahínie <wa-hi´-ni-e> aching bones, lumbago, rheumatism.

wahúëìka. N [wahú + ëìká] button (lit., 'little bone') (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 191: wahúëìka <wa-hiu´ zhiæ-ga> button.

wahûe, wahûù (variants of wahúì). waíiçkihci (variant of waðíiçkihci).

waílà ochí (variant of waðílà ochí).

wáìãaaké (variant: wéuãaake). N [wa- VAL + î + ãaaké] Carrying and Wailing (personal name)

(04/25/95/PM/pc:ok: wáì ãaake ok). [Wéuãáake was the father of John Oberly, who was Frances Holding's father.]  

•• LFD 192: wáì ãake <Wa´-iæ Xa-ge> Carrying and Wailing, Carrying (a pipe) and Wailing. "The wailing is an appeal to the <Noæ-hoæ-zhiæ-ga> to recite the <Wi-gi-e> (ritual) in its entirety."

wakaacØáiëi. ADJ disrespectful, rude, insolent, failing to show respect to people or property, forward (BE2.32; 04/07/95/LS/pc:okc).

•• RB: <wah-káh-ts'áh-zhi>.

•• LFD 188: wakácØaeëi <wa-ga´-¾s'a-e-zhi> impudence, rude, forward, insolence, officious.

wakáaãe. N, V [sync. k>p, wa_káaãe] [wa- VAL + káaãe] (be) boss (03/24/95/PM/pc, unconfirmed).

wakáahcìe (variant: wakáahcìi). N [wa- '3rd person pl. patient' ('to them') + káa- INSTR + hcîì] Appear Suddenly to Them (personal name referring to the moment the deer look up, disturbed by the appearance of s.t.). [George Shannon's name.] wakáahcìe it appears to them suddenly.

••• Cf. wahcîì. 

wákaapçe N [wa- VAL + káapçe] wire brush (FH). wakáaxa. V [reg. ka-del. wa_(ká)axa] [wa- VAL + káaxa] beat folks at a race.

wakáaëi (variant: wakáaëì). V [reg., wa_káaëi] [wa- VAL + kaaëí] (intr.) drive. wakáaëi hpímò I know how to drive. ðíe waðákaaëi tà owé hci ci brée hkôbra if you will drive, I want to go to the grocery store (01/20/95/PM/prod). • N driver, chauffeur. wakáaëi wihta hcúãeëì that's my driver, he's a little dried up guy (PM). • garage (RBn12-07; 01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok).

•• RB: <wáh-gah-zhi>.

wakái (variant: wákai). V [presumably wa- VAL + kaa- INSTR + ce (root not attested independently; cf. pacé)] cut meat (cutting or slicing meat as for barbecue) (lit., 'slice stuff with sudden motion' [?]) (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok; wákai; 01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn1-MOJ/p50).

•• RB: <wah-kái>.

wákalà. ADJ dirty (RBn10-3:MOJ/79; 01/20/95/FH/pc:uk; MSB 2-25-83). [Possibly borrowed from Spanish guácala or guácatela 'yuck! ugh! dirty!'] waðílà wákalà âðiicíza take these dirty thoughts away (RBn10-3:MOJ/79). híihka wákalà akxái your ankles are dirty (RBn10-3:MOJ/79).  

wákaçtò. N [wa- VAL + çtôka] cushion or pillow to sit on (as for a sofa, chair, or other seat) (BE2.28); saddle blanket; blanket folded to cushion a seat (RB; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; 01/14/95/FH/pc:uk). [Takes 'sitting' positional article ìkçé.] wákaçtò ìkçé hkáwa áalà put that saddle blanket on that horse.

wákazo. N, V [reg.?, wá_kazo?] [wa- VAL + ákazo] judge, examine an issue (lit., 'examine things') (BE2.72; 02/13/95/FH/pc:ok).

wakíkØu. V [reg., wa_kíkØu] [wa- VAL + wakØú (valence-reduced form, but may be used transitively)] (trans.) give away to folks who are family. waðákikØue you gave it away to family. àwákikØupe we gave it away to our own.

wakíçupe. V [reg.? wa_kíçupe] [wa- VAL + kíçupe] (trans.) repay for, reimburse (for) (03/06/95/FH/pc). [Expected (but unattested) inflectional forms: áwakiçupe 'I reimburse her for it', waðákiçupe 'you reimburse her for it', àwákiçupape 'we reimburse her for it'.] •• LFD 189: wakíçipe <wa-gi´-shi-be> to remunerate, to repay.

••• Cf. kaçúpe. 

wakôða. V [sync. fortisizing stop stem+sync., wa_kô_ða] [wa- VAL or wa- '3rd person pl. patient' + kôða] want s.t. for s.o. else. ëikóhkiha wahkôbra I want it for my grandchildren (RBn22-19).

wakôze (variant: wákòze [JS]). • V [sync. k>p, wa_kôze] [wa- VAL + kôze 'teach'] (trans.) teach (03/05/95/JS/pc; 03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). waëáëeíe wakôze mìkçé I'm teaching Osage language (RBn1012:JW). • N teacher, minister (FH, RB). waëáëeíe wakôze mìkçé I'm a teacher of Osage language.

wakôzaëì little teacher [expected Mod. Os. form: wakôzeëì].

•• RB: <wah-kóæ-zeh> (BE2.133;03/05/95/JS/pc: wákòze).

•• LFD 189: wakôze <wa-goæ´-še> an instructor, a preceptor, a teacher, a preacher; to teach, to instruct, to preach. wahpôze <wa-¼oæ´-še> I teach. waçkôze <wa-shkoæ´-še> you teach. àwâkòza pe <oæ-woæ´-goæ-ša i> we teach. wakôze wakØo <wa-goæ´-še wa-Ð'o> a woman instructor, a preceptress (CQ: ok).

wakçé. V [reg., wa_kçé] (trans.) mean, intend, have in mind. ðíe wawíkçe I mean you (RBn22-01). çée ée awákçe that [item near you] is what I meant, that is what I was talking about (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 130: çe ewakçe <she e-wa-kshe> [expected Mod. Os. form: çée ée awákçe that in your hand [rather, 'that near you'] is what I mean. LFD 26: pé eawakçe a <be´ e-a-wa-ke a> [expected Mod. Os. form: pée ée awákçe?; sentence-final a is not used in questions in Mod. Os.] who do I mean? pé ewaðakçe a <be´ e-wa-tha-ke a> [expected Mod. Os. form: pée ée waðákçe?; sentence final a is not used in questions in Mod. Os.] who do you mean? pé ewakçe a <be´ e-wa-ke a> [expected Mod. Os. form: pée ée wakçé akxa?; sentence-final a is not used in questions in Mod. Os.] who does he mean?

••• KS wakhé mean something, refer to, intend (RR).

wakçíòze. V [reg.+(sync. nasal vowel stem), wa_kçí(_)òze] [wa- VAL + kçíòze] (trans.) teach things to s.o.

•• LFD 192: wakäíòze <wa-kchi´-oæ-še> [expected Mod. Os. form wakçíòze] instruction, to give instruction to a pupil, to teach.

wakxázu (variant of watxázu).

wakxâ (variant of watxâ).

wakØâ. V, ADJ [uninfl. (but reg., wa_kØâ, in LF examples)] (intr.) (be) glad, happy, joyous; exult. wakØâ mìkçé I'm glad (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). wakØâ apai they're glad (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.55). wakØâ ðaìçé you're glad (9/17/94/FH/p.c.).

•• LFD 193: wakØà <wa-Ð'oæ> to exult. awákØà <a-wa´-Ð'oæ>I exulted. waðákØà <wa-tha´Ð'oæ> you exulted. àwákØà pe <oæ-wa´-Ð'oæ i> we exulted.

wakØó. N woman. wakØó taaké çtâ a woman that likes to fight (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.160). wakØó wíhta my woman, my wife. • wife; my wife. wakØó wíhta! wife! [man calling his wife]; my wife.

wakØó ðíhta your wife. • queen (in a deck of cards) (RBn23-17c).

•• RB: <wah-k'ó, wáh-k'o>.

•• LFD 193: wakØó <wa-Ð'o´> woman, or women. wakØó kahike <Wa-Ð'o´-ga-hi-ge> Womanchief (female personal name) (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok).  

••• Cf. ðiwákØo, iwákØo. 

wakØó ðílà. VP [sync., wakØó _ðílà] flirt with a woman (RB; 01/26/95/FH/pc:okc).

wakØó ðìké. N widower (lit., 'woman none').

•• LFD 195: wakØó ðìke <wa-Ð'o´ thiæ-ge> has no woman, a widower.

wakØó éekò (variant: wakØó ékò). VP [uninflected] (intr.) be womanly (lit., 'like a woman') (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok; 04/06/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 193: wakØó ekò <wa-Ð'o´ e-goæ> womanly.

wakØó mààðôçtà. N [wakØo + mààðô + çtà] wife stealer (lit., 'steals wife/wives constantly').

wakØó nòòhô. N prostitute, woman of bad reputation (RBn11-02/JW&FW; RB/HHsk/c.1976).

•• JOD (slip file): wakØó nôhô <wa-k'u´ núæ-húæ> a woman who has been married, but who is now alone, a widow.

wakØó wéðuãe (variant: wakØó weúãe). N married woman (04/18/95/FH/pc:both okc: wakØó weúãe is preferred; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ma).

•• LFD 195: wakØo waðiãe <wa-Ð'o wa-thi-xe> a married woman.

wakØó wíhta. NP my wife (used to refer to her but not to address her) (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok; RB).  

wakØóhpa. N eldest daughter. [Kinship terms ending in -hpa may be baby names; at any rate they seem to be infrequently used except with 1st or 2nd person possessor (e.g., for 'my eldest daughter' and

'your eldest daughter').]  

wakØóhtà. N (my/your/his/her, etc.) eldest daughter, first daughter (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). [Used by Grayhorse and Hominy Osages.] wakØóhtà hcí ðe ée aðî apa, hcílepa ðée káaãe my daughter has this house, she's making a home in it (PM/7/7/94; 02/03/95/FH/pc:ok). wakØóhtà apa ðéka hcíle apái that's where eldest daughter lives.  

wakØóëì. N my mother-in-law; mother-in-law. [According to some speakers, used only for the mother of the wife of a male (RB; 02/25/95/FH/pc:okc); according to others, it can also be used for the mother of the husband of a female (04/17/95/LS/pc).] wakØóëì wíhta apa htóolà káaãe kôða ìkí apá my mother-in-law doesn't want to make meat pies (T24b-p15/24; CQ105; BE2.90: 'man speaking').

wakØóëì ðíhta your mother-in-law. • crone, elderly woman, little old woman, little woman (used both to refer to her and to address her) (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.98).

•• LFD 195: wakØó ëìka <wa-Ð'o´ zhiæ-ga> mother-in-law, a crone, an aged woman (02/25/95/FH/pc:ok). wakØó ëîka hi <wa-k'o´ zhiæ´-ga hi> a woman who has reached old age.  

••• Cf. ðíwakØóëì, íwakØóëì.

wakØú. V [reg., wa_kØú] [wa- VAL + kØú (but sometimes used as transitive)] (trans.) give away to folks. ðíe waðákØue you gave it away. àwákØu à[ð]ìkçé we [two] gave it away, we gave it to them. • loan, provide for, feed folks. íkiha táatà áwawakØeu àhé I loan them [people] stuff all the time (5-12-83). áwawakØúe I fed them, provided for them (5-12-83). waléze tóa àwâðakØu na, ðée é í apai the books that you loaned me are these (2-10-84-p4).

wálake(?) (see wáalake).

waléle (variants: wahléle, wahléhle, wahélele) (FH: all variants ok; PM: waléle only). N flag, American flag, staff with feathers (BE2.126; 04/07/95/PM/pc:ok; RB; 01/26/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• RB: <wah-hléh-hleh>.

•• LFD 209: waléle <wa-xthe´-xthe> a war standard. waléle wahkàtaki <Wa-xthe´-xthe Wa-Ðoæda-gi> Mysterious War standards. waléle cØìça <wa-xthe´-xthe ts'-iæ sha> the standard made with a crook by the Osage and Omaha. waléle scece <wa-xthe´-xthe-stse-dse> a tall standard made by the Osage, also by the Kaw and the Omaha. LFD 189: wale <wa-gthe> a symbolic plume made of a downy feather of an eagle.

••• Cf. haawálele. 

waléze. N [wa- VAL + léze] paper, stationery, posterboard, or any other paper or document containing text (lit., 'something striped'). [Contrasts with htanâkØa 'stationery, paper for making signs, blank paper'; waléze already has text on it.] óðaake waléze newspaper (03/06/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.101).

mâzeska ootá waléze note, loan document (document of borrowed money). • book

(04/19/95/FH/pc:pl)  

•• LFD 189: waléze <wa-gthe´-še> book, mail, a script, writing.  

••• Cf. óðaake waléze. 

waléze hpíò. VP [sync. fortisizing stop stem, waléze _hpíò] (intr.) be educated, literate, learned (lit., 'know books').

•• LFD 189–90: waléze hpiò <wa-gthe´-še ¼i-oæ> educated, literate, learned. waléze hpimò <wa-gthe´-še ¼i-moæ> I am educated. waléze çpiëò <wa-gthe´-še shpi-zhoæ> you are educated. waléze àhpiò pe <wa-gthe´-še oæ-¼i-oæ i> we are educated. waléze káaãe. N secretary, record-keeper for tribal council (RB).

waléze sápe (variant: wáleze sápe). N Bible (lit., 'black book') (BE2.8; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

wáleze. N letter. wáleze ðée kçi[ð]e mail this letter [for him/her] (lit., 'make the letter go for another person' [the sender or the recipient]) (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). wáleze ðée káaãa send a letter (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). wáleze ðalúuze? did you get your letter? (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.78).

•• RB: <wáh-leh-zeh> letter (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok).

wáleze wì kçíãe. VP  write a letter to s.o. (lit., 'make a letter to another'). wáleze wì àkçíãa write me a letter (RBn10-20; CQ:okc).

walézeáace (variant: walézeáaci). N [presumably waléze + ðaacé] school, learning, class, reading, schooling, education (lit., 'read books') (01/09/95/FH/pc; 03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok). hààðé walézeáace çäée hta ðaaçé? are you going to class tonight? (RBn12-08). ëìkáëì apa záani walézeáace apái my children are all in school (RB). walézeáace pée wakôze ðìkçé? who is teaching the class? (RB).

walézeaaci mâðî go to school (RBn2-MOJ/p5; MREI).

•• LFD 190: waléze ðace <wa-gthe´-še tha-dse> to read. waléze brace <wa-gthe´-še btha-dse> I read. waléze scace <wa-gthe´-še stsa-dse> [expected Mod. Os. form: waléze çtáace 'you read'; <stsa-dse> is presumably an error for <shda-dse>] you read, to read to someone.

walí. ADJ, V [conjug. unknown] (intr.?) (be) selfish, stingy. [Only found in LFD; Mod. Os. has kíwalì.]

•• LFD 209: walí <wa-xthi´> stingy, uncharitable, unwilling to give, selfish, undue value placed upon certain property. walí walì hi a <wa-xthi´ wa-gthiæ hi a>[expected Mod. Os. form: wáli kíwalipe] he is very stingy. LFD 325: walí walì pe <wa-xthi´ wa-gthiæ bi a> [from kíwali, expected 3rd person form: kíwali wálipe] he is very selfish.

••• Cf. wáawali. 

wáli (variant of wálì).  

walíëi. V, ADJ [stat., _(kí)waliëi] [kíwalì + aëí NEG] (be) generous, not stingy.  

•• LFD 209: walíëi <wa-xthi´-zhi> Generous (personal name), refers to the man who always shared his spoils, taking in his war exploits, with the people; generous, liberal, munificent.

••• Cf. wahríçe. 

wálì (variants: wáalì, wáli, wáali). ADV very, indeed, really, extremely, so very, a great deal, a lot, so very much (used also in expressions with 'too much'). wáli hó lâàðe! what a big fish! (lit., 'it's really a big fish!'). hâàce wáli nuuëúpe ska, ëìkáëi apa hôpái niiëópçi apái last night it must have rained a lot, the children today are wading (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok). wálì tóocehape, waachí nà apái he eats too much and he doesn't do anything but dance (lit., 'he is really a glutton, he only dances') (RBn102:MOJ/79).

•• JOD (slip file): wálì <wa´-¦k¢iæ> very, greatly, very much.

•• LFD 190: wálì <wa´-gthiæ> very much; greatly; a great many; beyond description. LFD 100:

màhkâ sape che skiðe walì <moæ-Ðoæ´ ša-be tse ški-the wa-gthiæ> the coffee is too sweet.

••• QU walí, walî very, really, so (RR).

••• Cf. kíwalì. 

walôò. V [conjug. unknown, presumed reg., _walôò] [wa- VAL + lôò] (intr.) call folks names. çíi apa walôò çtà that person coming sure likes to call people names (cuss them out) (01/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.16). tówa ðe hå ðée walôò çta that person coming there likes to call people names.

•• LFD 190: walô <wa-gthoæ´> to revile; to heap reproach or scandal upon another

(01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). walôlò <wa-gthoæ´-gthoæ> to curse. àwàlòlò pe <oæ-woæ-gthoæ-gthoæ i> we curse (unconfirmed gloss).

walúçka. N bug, insect, worm, vermin, joker (in a deck of cards) (RBn12-10/MOJ01/19/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.13). [A purported word wákluçka 'witch' that appears in some teaching materials probably actually represents an older pronunciation of walúçka 'bug, vermin' (perhaps waglúçka?). The consonant cluster kl is otherwise unattested in Osage.]

•• LFD 190: walúçka <wa-gthu´-shka> bug, any kind of bug, a worm, an insect. walúçka haçoka <wa-gthu´-shka ha-sho-ga> a shard, a bug with a shell or tough skin. walúçka sape <wa-gthu´shka ša-be> black bug, a cricket. LFD 191: walúçka ëìka <wa-gthu´-shka zhiæ-ga> little bugs. walúçka ochí <wa-gthu´-shka u-¾si> wormy, full of worms.

walúçka háa çooká. N beetle or other bug with thick outer layer or exoskeleton.

•• LFD 190: walúçka haçoka <wa-gthu´-shka ha-sho-ga> a shard, a bug with a shell or tough skin.

walúçka ììçtá htâka. N praying mantis (lit., 'bug with big eyes').

•• LFD 191: walúçka ìçta htàka <wa-gthu´-shka iæ-shta ¾oæ-ga> praying mantis.

wamâà (variant of wamâàðòçtà).

wamâàðò (variant: wamôò). V [sync., wamâà_ðò] [wa- VAL + mààðô] (intr.) steal, steal s.t., steal things (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). wamâàbròðe I stole. waðímòò akxai he stole from you. àwámààaðò we [two] stole things. àwámààðòpe we [three or more] stole things (BE2.127). • N thievery, theft, stealing, robbery. [Takes 'standing' positional article che.]

•• RB: <wáh-máh>.

•• LFD 196: wamâðò <wa-moæ´-thoæ> to steal, to take that which belongs to another, to pilfer. wamâbrò <wa-moæ´-bthoæ> I steal. wamâçtò <wa-moæ´-shtoæ> you steal. wamâðò asila <wamoæ´-thoæ a-si-gtha> I accuse you of stealing [asila 'accuse' is unattested]. wamâðò che hpiaëi <wamoæ´-thoæ tse ¼i-a-zhi> [expected Mod. Os. form: wamâàðò che hpíiëi] it is bad to steal.

••• Cf. wamâàðòçtà. 

wamâàðòçtà (variants: wamâà, wamôòìçtà). N [wamâàðò + çtà] thief, robber (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). amâàðòçtà ðe obrîìke I caught the thief (BE2.138; ok; BE2.127; 03/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 196: wamâðòçtà <wa-moæ´-thoæ-shtoæ> one who is in the habit of stealing, a thief. wamâðòçtà ðe obrîke <wa-moæ´-thoæ-shtoæ the u-bthiæ-ge> I caught the thief, one who is in the habit of stealing.

wamâðì. V [sync., wamâ_ðì] [wa- VAL + màðî] (intr.) travel, go on a mission or on a journey, be engaged in going places (such as going over to s.o.'s house to ask for s.t.) (03/23/95/FH/pc:ok). wamâðì brée I'm going on a trip, I'm going to go do something (03/23/95/FH/pc; FH:5/01/96/tape; 05/02/95/LS/pc:ok). • N errand, mission.

•• LFD 195: wamôðì <wa-moæ´-thiæ> to travel, to go forward from one place to another on a mission as a delegate, to go on a journey. wamâðì âzo <wa-moæ´-thiæ oæ-šu a-tha> I like to travel.

wamôò (variant of wamâàðò).

wamôòìçtà (variant of wamâàðòçtà).

wanáaãe (variant of wanâàãe).

wanáhkai. N [presumably wa- VAL + nâhka + ðe CAU] mistake (not a particularly serious mistake). wanáhkai çkáaãe you made a mistake (02/25/95/FH/pc). táatà ékipçe sitôì, wanáhkai ékimà what I said yesterday I did it by mistake (RBn10-2; 02/25/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 197 (unconfirmed gloss): wanâhkaðe <wa-noæ´-Ða-the> to injure. nâhka aðe <noæ´-Ða athe> I injured him. nâhka ðaðe <noæ´-Ða tha-the> you injured him, to maim.

wanáçe (variant: wanáçì). V [conjug. unknown] (trans.) take care of. waxópe wanáçe take care of the bundle (RBn 10-16). • N whipman, whip, soldier. wanâçeëì Little Soldier (personal name).

•• RB: <wah-náh-sheh> (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.156).

•• LFD 197: wanâçeëìka <Wa-noæ´-she-zhiæ-ga> Little-soldier (personal name).  

wanâàãe (variants: wanáaãe, wánààãe) N spirit, holy spirit (LS, FH). wanâàãe ðáalì the good spirit, the holy spirit. • ghost, soul (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p8; 03/14/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.126).

wanâàãe ðáalì the holy ghost.

•• RB: <wáh-nah-xeh, wáh-nah-xeh tháh-liæ>.

•• LFD 197: wanâãe <wa-noæ´-xe> the spirit (used in rituals), the soul of man, a ghost. wanâãe waðò <wa-noæ´-xe wa-thoæ> Spirit songs. LFD 272: wanâãe ìlôãe <wa-noæ´-xe iæ-gthoæ´-xe> ghost.

••• Cf. nâàãe. 

wanâàãe mâëà (variant: wanáaãe mâëà). N spirit land. [Takes 'lying down' positional article kçe.] wanáaãe mâëà kçi brée hta mìkçé I'm going to spirit land.  

waníðe. V [reg., waní_ðe] [likely a borrowing from Ponca] (intr.) give things away, hold a giveaway. [Giving away is a custom at the annual Osage war dances on the last day, when blankets, shawls, groceries, cash, and other items are given to others in appreciation.] waníðe hta apái they are going to give away [stuff] (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). waníðe hta akxai he's going to give away [stuff].

waníða[ð]e tà, táatà ðáalì níwaeðéða when you give away, give good things (MSB 2-24-83). • N giveaway (ceremony at ilôòçka dances and other special occasions).

waníe (variant: wanîe). V [conjug. unknown] [presumably wa- VAL + níe] (intr.) be in labor, be birthing (refers to the accompanying pain) (01/06/95/FH/pc). waníekxà boyhood name of A. C. Oberly, brother of Frances Holding: a boy's name in the Eagle clan [the ending ekxà is a variant of éetxà 'it is time' (FH)]. • N labor during childbirth (01/06/95/FH/pc).

wanôbraëi. V [reg., wa_nôbraëi] [wanôbre +aëí] (intr.) fast, not eat, not be eating, have no appetite (01/06/95/FH/pc). wanôbraëi akxa he/she is not eating, he/she has no appetite (RBn1-55).  

wanôbre. V [reg., wa_nôbre] (intr.) dine, eat (01/06/95/FH/pc). áwanòbre I eat. waðánòbre you eat. wanôbrape he eats, they eat. àwanôbrape we eat. ðáalì áwanòbre che bráaçta it is good that I have eaten, I'm finished (RBn1-3). áwanòbre ~ awánôbre I ate (RBn22-03). waðánòbre? did you eat?

waðánòbre hkôbra I want you to eat. waðánòbrape? have you [pl.] eaten? (RBn10-5:MOJ/79). hkáwa akxa wanôbre akxa the horse is eating [while standing still]. wanôbraëi akxa he/she is not eating (has no appetite). wanôbrape they've already eaten. wanôbrape? did they eat? wanôbre hú ði come over and eat [sg. addressee]. záani wanôbre húðapi come over and eat [pl. addressee]. âwanòbre htai let's all eat. wanôbre kú come and eat [sg. addressee]. wanôbre kúpi come and eat [pl. addressee]. • N dinner, supper (meal served at noon or in the evening) (01/04/95/FH:pc). hòpái wanôbre àkái htai let's go to the dinner today. hòpái wanôbre àkáða pe we're going to the dinner today

(01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). hpáze wanôbre ónòbre ðúwì ókxàëi àhé I was slow buying groceries for supper (03/10/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.123). • N peyote. wanôbre pçé pounded peyote (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). wanôbre çtôka pounded peyote (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). wanôbre htóho green peyote (01/06/95/FH/pc).  

•• LFD 196: wanôbre <wa-noæ´-bthe> a meal, breakfast, dinner, or supper; nourishment, food, to eat, to dine. awánòbre briçta <a-wo´-noæ-bthe bthi-shtoæ> [expected Mod. Os. form: awánòbre bríiçtà 'I finished eating'] I have had my dinner. wanôbre äopa abrì mìkçe o <wa-noæ´-bthe dsu-ba abthi miæ-kshe o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I have a scant supply of food (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 112: nôbre <noæ´-bthe> [not recognized by Mod. Os. speakers] to eat. [Mod. Os. has wanôbre for the meaning 'to eat'. Note that what LF gives as inflectional forms of nôbre (immediately following) are in fact forms of wanôbre, as seen from the fact that they contain wa-.] awanôbre <a-wa-noæ´-bthe> I eat, I am eating. waðánòbre <wa-tha´-noæ-bthe> you eat, you are eating. àwânòbra pe <oæ-woæ´-noæ-btha i> we eat, we are eating.

••• Cf. hpáze wanôbre, mììðóhta wanôbre, ónòbre.  

wanôbrehci N cafe, restaurant (lit., 'eating house') (BE2.16; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). [Less preferred than owánòbrehcí.]

•• LFD 196: wanòbre hci <wa-noæ-bthe-¾si> hotel. [Not confirmed as 'hotel'.]

••• Cf. owánòbrehcí. 

wanôbrenii. N [wanôbre + níi] peyote tea. wanôbrenii tóa oçcé? is there any peyote tea left? (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.78).  

wánòbréooëú (variant: ónòbréooëú). N [wanôbre + ooëú (note adjusted accent in compound)] stomach, abdomen (FH:ok); pantry (04/14/95/FH/pc:ok); food bag (FH).

•• LFD 196: wanôbre oëi <wa-noæ´-bthe u-zhi> the abdomen, a place for keeping food or provisions, food bag, pantry.

wanôpØì (variants: wanôpØe, wanòpxì [FH]). N [wa- VAL + nòpØî] necklace, gorget, choker, medallion, medal (part of Osage dance clothing) (lit., 's.t. worn around the neck') (RB). çòmîhka kahíke mâze wanôpØì wì kØúpi áape they gave the pope a medal, they say (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). wanôpØè òô put on the necklace, wear the necklace.  

•• RB: <wáh-nó-p'iæ> (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.19; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 197: wanôpØì <wa-noæ´-¼'iæ> necklace. "These were made of shells, nuts of trees, elk teeth [02/27/95/FH/pc:ok]. Pendants were made of the mussel shells also. This is also the name applied to the symbolic neck ornament: gorget." LFD 116: wakØo ðe wánòpØì htà akçiðe ha <wa-Ð'u the wa´-noæ-¼'iæ ¾oæ a-kshi-the ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: wakØó waánòpØì htâ akçíðe; sentencefinal ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I caused the woman to wear a [large] necklace.  

wáopxa. V [stat., wá_opxa] [wa- VAL + kíopxa] (intr.) find out or understand things. waðíopxa you understand things.

••• Cf. ðuupxáðe, waðúupxai. 

waô. V [sync. nasal vowel stem, wa_ô] [wa- VAL + ô] do stuff, do things. wamô I do things. waëô you do things.

wápa níhka. N Delaware (tribe or tribal member). [Claimed to mean 'water nation' (RB).]

•• RB: <wáh-páh-ni-kiu, wáh-bah-ní-kah> (01/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.30; 03/08/95/PM/pc:ok; ERE).

•• LFD 183: wápanihki <Wa´-ba-ni-Ði> the Osage name for the Delaware Tribe.

wápaace (variant of wáapaache).

wapáache. V [sync. k>p, wa_páache [wa- VAL + paaché] (intr.) sew, sew things together (RBn1MOJ/p50; 03/08/95/FH/pc:okc: wáa; BE2.119; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). [Contrast wáapaache 'ribbon work'.]

•• LFD 183: wapáche <wa-ba´-tse> to sew. wahpache <wa-¼a-tse> I sew. waçpáche <washpa´-tse> you sew. àwâpacha pe <oæ-woæ´-ba-tsa i> we sew. wapáche wakØo <wa-ba´-tse-waÐ'o> a sewing woman, a seamstress, one who sews. wapáche wakØo wì iðaðe hkòbra <wa-ba´-tse wa-Ð'o wiæ i-tha-the Ðoæ-btha> I want to find a seamstress.

••• Cf. mâze wépaache. 

wápaache (FH) (variants: wáapache, wápaace [PM]). N ribbon work, sewing (FH, PM).

•• LFD 183: wápahce (or wápache) [LF ambiguous] <wa´-ba-¾se> ribbons.

wapáahi. V [reg.+sync. fortisizing stop stem _wa_páahi] [wa- VAL + paahí (but sometimes used as transitive)] (trans.) pick, choose, or select people [or things?]. [Expected (but unattested) inflectional forms: waðáçpaahi 'you choose', wapáahi 'he chooses', àwápaahi 'we choose'.] níhka ðòòpá awáhpaahi hta mìkçe I am going to choose two men (03/07/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 87: níhka ðòpa awahpáhi hta mìkçe <ni´-Ða thoæ-ba wa-¼a´-hi ¾a miæ-ke> I choose [rather, 'I will choose'] two men (03/07/95/FH/pc:okc). wahko ðòpa ði wapahi o <wa-Ðu thoæ-ba thi wa-ba-hi o> [expected Mod. Os. form: wakØó ðòòpá wápaahi 'choose two women' (imperative form); sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] you choose two women (03/07/95/FH/pc:okc).

wapáaleze. N [wa- VAL + paa- + léze] pencil, pen (lit., 'makes marks on stuff by pushing down on'). wapáaleze wì àkØú give me a pencil or a pen (RBn 10-20).

wápaase (variant: wápase). V [sync., wá_paase] [wa- +paasé] (trans.) cut, splice (lit., 'cut something by pushing'). • N cutting, cut (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; FH).

wápaãa. N man's or woman's ornamental pin or brooch (FH/06/16/01/pc; 03/08/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.103).  

••• KS wabáãà safety pin (RR).

wapáleze. N [wa- VAL + páaleze] pencil, pen.

wápaleze. N [ó- LOC + á- LOC + páaleze]  writing (such as a letter) (FH/09/24/01/pc/ok: synonym of wáleze). ["A scratching of some lines" (FH).] wápaleze çkáaãe? did you write something? (FH/09/24/01/pc/prod).

wápaleze káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, wápaleze _káaãe] be a writer (lit., 'make writings') (FH/09/24/01/pc/prod).

wapáse N [wa- VAL 'stuff' + páse] butcher, one who cuts things up (lit., 'cuts things using a sharp edge').

wápase (variant of wápaase).

wapázike. N wasp (archaic) (RB; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). [JS prefers mààpíaza to wapázìke, which she says is archaic.]

•• LFD 353: wapázike <wa-ba´-ši-ge> wasp.

wapâ. V [reg.+sync., wa_ _pâ] [wa- VAL + pâ] (intr.) call, holler for folks, invite people. wapâ màðî go invite people (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). waðáçpa nìkçé? are you inviting? wáahpà I invited.

wapâ waaðô. N calling songs (sung at the start of the annual war dances, in a fixed order). 

wapéì (variant of wapî).

wapíokaçke (variants: wapúçke [HRE], wapíokaçki). N [probably wa- VAL + púkaçke] drop feathers. [In the ilôòçka dance, the men's dress has drop feathers, or brow feathers, which hang down from the roach to the left side for Hominy dancers and to the right side for Grayhorse dancers (HRE/12/29/01/pc).] wapíokaçke drop feathers (RBn14-03 unconfirmed; HRE/12/29/01/pc: wapúçke only).  

••• Cf. okáçke. 

wapî (variant: wapéì). V [stat., wa_pî] bleed. hpá wapéì akxái his nose is bleeding (RBn2-MOJ/p35; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). • N blood (BE2.9; 03/02/95/FH/pc:ok; 01/07/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 184: àwâpì <oæ-woæ´-biæ> I am bleeding. waðípì <wa-thi´-biæ> you are bleeding. wapî <wa-biæ´> blood, bleeding (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). wapì itxaëi <Wa-biæ i-ta-zhi> [expected Mod. Os. form: wapî ðiihtâaëi]. Those-who-do-not-touch-blood, the name of a subgens of the <Tsi´zhu Wa-shta-ge>, the Peacemaker gens.

wapóçke ówe. N wheat, wheat field, wheat crop, harvest (LS04/28/95/pc:prod).

•• LFD 196: wamóske owe <wa-mu´-ške u-we> [expected Mod. Os. form wapóçke ówe; wamóske is likely an Omaha term] wheat field. wapúçka. N beads (BE2.7; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ma).

wapúçke (variant of wapíokaçke).

wapúçtaha. V [reg+sync. fortisizing stop stem, _wa_púçtaha] (intr.) iron, smooth or press s.t. (e.g., cloth with an iron). hôòpa ðé awahpúçtaha hta mìkçe I'm going to iron all day. àwâpuçtaha àkái we've been ironing.

wasápe (variants: wasá, wasái). N bear (especially black bear).

•• LFD 185: wasape <wa-ša-be> black bear (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.7; RB note: black bear). wasápe ochi <Wa-ša´-be u-tsi> where bears are plentiful, Bear Creek. wasape ska <Wa-ša-be ška> the white bear, a subgens of the <Wa-ša´-be ¾oæ> gens. wasápe waðò <Wa-ša´-be wa-thoæ> Black Bear Songs.

wasápe íikitali. N [wasápe + ki- INCEPTIVE + iitáðe] January (lit., 'again time when bears are born'). wasápe iitáipi. N [wasápe + iitáðe] December (lit., 'bears give birth').

wasápeëì. N [wasápe + -ëì 'little'] bear cub (any species of bear) (04/13/95/LS/pc); Little Black Bear (personal name) (FH/pc). [Name of Henry Petsemoie, who was Frances Holding's maternal uncle, and also of Jess Townsend.]

•• LFD 185: wasápe hpata <wa-ša´-be-¼a-da> cub, bear cub.

wascúuce. ADJ, ADV slow, pokey, slowly; late, overdue (describing a person [RB]). wascúuce brìe I'm slow (04/25/95/FH/pc). wascúuce çäîe you're slow [çäî is an unusual alternate form for nî, 2nd person sg. of ðî 'be'] (04/26/95/FH/pc). çímiëì apa ìcé káaãe éena wáli wascúutape the girls put on their makeup, which makes them very slow (RBn3-19). wascúuce àkáe we're slow (BE2.123). íe wascúuce speak slowly, drawl (FH). wascúuce nîe you're late! (FH:08/22/96;04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/10/95/MREI/pc:uk).  

•• LFD 331: wastúce <wa-štu´-dse> slow movements. LFD 71: íe wastuce <i´-e wa-štu-dse> to drawl.

••• QU óstihte (stative) slow, late, be, to delay (RR).

waséhtà. N sycamore tree.

waséhtà xóe. N [waséhtà + xóce] Verdigris River (lit., 'gray sycamore') (RBn22-03; CQc).

•• LFD 351: waséhtà xoe <Wa-še´-¾oæ xo-e> Verdigris River, Oklahoma.

waséhtàhü. N sycamore (RBn22-03, unconfirmed; CQc).

wáseska. N suitcase, purse, handbag (BE2.129; 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok). wasísi. ADJ strong, energetic, elastic. • N elastic.

waskúe. N [wa- VAL + skúðe] fruit, dessert, any sweet food or sweet sauce (BE2.51).

•• RB: <wáh-skyu> (01/30/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 186: waskíðe <wa-ški´-the> sauce, fruit, sweet food.

waskúe ðibrúbruãe (variant: waskú ðibrúbruãe). N gelatin, jello (lit., 'sweet, shimmering/shaking') (02/12/95/FH/pc:okc).

waskúe sápe. N blackberry (lit., 'sweet black fruit') (FH:4/22/96/tape:ok).

waskúe çkâçkâ. N [waskúe + reduplicated form of çkâ] jello, gelatin (lit., 'sweet thing moving') (FH/11/19/01/pc:ok; BE2.72).

waskúeëì. N [waskúe + -ëì 'little'] cookie (lit., 'small sweet thing') (FH:4/22/96/tape:ok).

wastâìke (variant: staahîke). N persimmon (RBn HW13;HRE/12/29/01).

wásueëi. ADJ [wa- VAL + kisúðe + aëí] forgetful (lit., 'not remember things'). 

wasúhu. ADJ, ADV [wa- VAL (?) + -súhu 'clean' (root not attested as independent word)] clean(ly), clear(ly) (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). íe wasúhu clean talk. níi wasúhu clear water. (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.19). íe wasúhu speak clearly (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 186: wasíhi <wa-ši´-hi> clean in character, without reproach, free from blame, tidy, neat. âwàsihi <oæ´-woæ-ši-hi> I am neat. óðisihi <u´-thi-ši-hi> you are neat. wasíhi kaãe <waši´-hi ga-xe> to cleanse, to purify. wasíhi ahki hpaãe <wa-ši´-hi a-Ði ¼a-xe> I cleanse.

wasíhihkiðe <wa-ši´-hi-Ði-the> to cleanse oneself.

••• Cf. taasúhu. 

wasúhuëi. ADJ [wasúhu + aëí] dirty, soiled, unclean. ëìkáëì apa omíëe wasúhuëi káaãapi ché the children have dirtied the rug (BE2.31: FH okc). ììçtáxì çímiëì wasúhuëi wahókØa a dirty little white girl (FH/04/14/94, t76b). haaská wasúhuëi ke paahípai, çäúuwasu htai be sorting the dirty clothes, let's you wash them (FH/11/17/01/pc; 01/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 186: wasíhi aëi <wa-ši´-hi a-zhi> impure, unclean, dirty, poverty stricken.

wasúutà. N [wa- VAL + súutà] vegetable, greens, garden produce (lit., 'ripe stuff') (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p28). wasúutà àkØú give me the garden stuff (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok; 05/01/95/LS/pc).

•• RB: <wah-sú-tah>.

waçápe. N [wa- + çápe] coal, charcoal.

waçápe aðî (variant: waçápe waðî). N mourning dance (lit., 'carrying the charcoal', an expression historically used at Osage funerals) (BE2.90, unconfirmed; PM:uk).

•• LFD 198: waçápe aðì <wa-sha´-be a-thiæ> carrying the charcoal. "This was a very important part in the formation of a war party. Each warrior was to carry a piece of charcoal in a buckskin pouch with which to blacken his face before attacking the enemy." [Such older terms as waçápe aðî, waçápe aðì waëówale, and waçápe waëówale are now unknown to most Osages; they were part of the old religion now replaced by the Native American Church and other Christian religions (FH). Early sources such as LF apply these terms to usages followed by war parties and in related ceremonies. In the mid-twentieth century, speakers who knew the terms applied them to usages connected with funerals, as reported by Bristow.]  

waçápe aðî waëówale. N [waçápe + aðî + wa- (?) + wa- 'them' + ëóle] title of two officers chosen to accompany warriors of the two great tribal divisions (lit., 'he who, having charcoal, accompanies them').

•• LFD 198–99: waçápe aðì waëowale <wa-sha´-be a-thiæ wa-zho-wa-gthe> the title of the two officers chosen at the ceremonial organization of a war party to accompany the warriors of the two great tribal divisions throughout the great ceremony. "The warriors were called Wa-sha´-be a-thiæ because they were to carry with them the dark symbolic charcoal by which each warrior who carries a small pouch of it declares his determination to show no mercy to the foe."

waçápe waðî (variant of waçápe aðî).

waçápe waëówale. N charcoal accompanying them (RB). waçápe waëówale 'charcoal accompanyingthem', the name of a dance that messengers, announcers, conducted (BE2.90).

•• LFD 99: "The two men who accompany the two bodies of warriors bear the title [waëówale

<wa-zho´-wa-gthe>], Accompanying the Warriors."

waçcéðe (variant: waçäéðe). V [reg., waçcé_ðe] [wa- VAL + çcéðe] (intr.) doctor folks, treat others. waçcéðe hkôbra I want to doctor people.

waçí. V [reg., wa_çí] (trans.) hire, employ, ask a favor of s.o., prevail upon s.o. to do s.t.; ask s.o. to help out. áwaçi I hire him. awáçi I hire him. waðáçi you hire him. wawíçi hkôbra I want [to hire] you to do something for me (RBn10-16; 02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). àwâçi apái they're hiring me (02/09/95/FH/pc). àwâçipe éci brée he's/they've asked me to work, so I'm going (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). àwâçipe oláha brée he hired me, so I'm going (03/24/95/PM/pc). Eddie a[w]áçi hkôbra mìkçé I want to ask Eddie to help me (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.161). wawíçi I asked you to help out. wiëîe awáçi hkôbra I want to get my older brother to help me (01/06/95/FH/pc:okc). ðée ìkçe awáçi hkôbra I want that person to help me (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.5). wapáache âwaçipe someone asked me to sew (RBn3-41). wisôka akxa àwáçi akxa younger brother is asking me to help (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). ëâà kaasé àwâçipe they asked me or hired me to cut wood (FH:prod, ok). oohô àwâçipe they've asked me to cook [it] (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). mààhî kaasé àwâçipe they've asked me to cut the grass (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). • N hired person, worker, employee, hired hand.

•• LFD 199: waçí <wa-shi´> to employ one to run on an errand or to do some work; a hireling, a person serving for hire with pay or the equivalent. waçi <wa-shi> to employ; to ask for services. awáçi <a-wa´-shi> I employed him. waðáçi <wa-tha´ shi> you employed him. wawíçi athi <wawi´-shi a-ti> [expected Mod. Os. form: wawíçi achí] I come to ask for your services. wawíçi hkòbra <wa-wi´-shi Ðoæ-btha> I wish to secure your services. wawíçi màëì <wa-wi´-shi moæ-zhiæ> I do not ask for your services.

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 199).

••• Cf. wawáçi. 

waçíëì. N [waçí + -ëì 'little'] hired help, hired worker.

waçî (variant: çì). • V [uninfl.?] (intr.) be fat, be overweight. koe ónòò ëiçò çí tà çî tà koe hpíiëi ëiçò çí tà koe péeçki ðikôða htai wáçäuãe ðáalì before you get old and before you get fat and ugly and nobody wants you, you should get married (lit., 'so before you arrive at old-age, before when you are fat and therefore ugly and when nobody would want you, you ought to take a husband'). N bacon, fat meat, salt pork (of the type cooked with beans) (01/06/95/FH/pc: prod). wiëîke, waçî toe çcúwì? son, did you buy some bacon? (BE2.6; RBn1-18). waçî hpáata ëóle bacon and eggs (RBn12-05).

•• RB: <wah-shíæ, shiæ> (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.45).

•• LFD 199: waçî <wa-shiæ´> fat meat, meat with very little lean.

waçîhaa. N [waçî + háa] Baconrind (personal name) (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.6). [Baconrind was a historic Osage leader.]

waçóçe. V, ADJ [stat., wa_çóçe] (be) brave (FH). waçóçe achí nààëî name of a solo dance by one who has been in a war (lit., 'one who is brave arrives here and stands') (RB2:90).

•• LFD 237: waçóçe <wa-sho´-she> brave (to be), courageous, dauntless, brave, gallant. LFD 199: àwàçoçe <oæ-woæ-sho-she> I am courageous. waðiçóçe <wa-thi-sho´-she> you are courageous. wawaçóça pe <wa-wa-sho´-sha i> we are courageous.  

waçóçe achí nààëî. N name of a solo dance by one who has been in a war (lit., approximately: 'a brave one comes and stands before us') (RB2:90).

waçtáke. ADJ [presumably contains çtáke] gentle. hcíëo waçtáke Gentle Eagle, a name. ókØà waçtáke akxa he's got gentle ways (RBn17-p03).

watáabrà. N [wa- VAL + táabrà] smell of s.t. cooking (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). watáabrà ðáalì the cooking smells good (lit., 'the cooking smell is good').

•• LFD 186: watábrà ðalì <wa-da´-bthoæ tha-gthiæ> a savory smell of things cooking.

watáahà. N [wa- VAL + táa+ -hà] light bread, leavened wheat bread (as opposed to corn bread) (lit., 'something that rises with heat') (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok).

watáaëoe. N [wa- VAL + táa+ ëoe (not otherwise attested)] hominy (any kind, cracked or not) (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; t14a-p4; 02/09/95/FH/pc:ok). watáaëoe oohô apai they're cooking hominy (BE2.67; FH/09/22/01/pc). watáaëoe táapuze mìkçé I'm drying corn for hominy.

•• LFD 187: watáëoe <wa-da´-zhu-e> hominy.

watástosta (variants: watástoe [RB], watáçäoäe [PM]). N pecan nut (BE2.102). watástosta ëâà pecan wood. watástoe paahî toe àkái hce let's go pick pecans (RBn12-05).

•• RB: <wah-táh-sto-stah, wah-táh-stoi> (03/07/95/PM/pc:okc) .

••• QU watástohta pecan (nut) (RR).

watástostahú. N [watástosta + hú] pecan tree (03/07/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 200: wahtástosta hu <wa-¾a´-što-šta hiu> the pecan (Hicoria pecan).  

••• QU watástohtá hi pecan tree (RR).

watáçäoäe (variant of watástosta).

watkxázu, watkxâzu (variants of watxázu).

watkxâ, wátkxà (variants of watxâ).

watôe, watôè, watôì (variants of watôpe).

watôe scee (variant: watôì scee). V [uninfl.] [watôpe + scéce] (intr.) stare (at people, not at inanimate things) (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). watôì scee ékiò ðìká! don't stare! (lit., 'staring, don't do that!') (RBn125). watóe scee akxa they are staring at people. watôe scee àðìkçé we [two] are staring [at folks].

watôehci. N [watôpe + hcí] store, shop, place where things are exhibited (lit., 'house in which to look at things'). Johna táatà íiðe ðe watôehci ce? what did John see in the store?

watôì scee (variant of watôe scee).

watôòëu. N [presumably watôe + ooëú] store, trading house.

watôpe (variants: watôì, watôè, watôe). V [conjug. unknown] [wa- VAL + tôpe] (intr.) see or watch people or events, look on at an event (e.g., a dance [RB]) (03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). waachí watôì àkái ðe we are going to see the dance (03/02/95/FH/pc; BE2.97). waachíe watôì çcée nà hta akxai you're always going to go to [to watch] dances (MSB-9-3-82). waachí watôe watch the dances. N spectators, onlookers, audience, public (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125).

•• LFD 187: watôpe <wa-doæ´-be> the act of seeing, applied to a runner in search of buffalo.

••• Cf. wahtôpe. 

watxázu (variants: wakxázu, watkxázu, watkxâzu). N dried corn, preparation of dried corn soup (LS; FH/09/11/01/pc:ok; RBn1-14). [Some families dried corn on the ear, tying it up with twine to hang it a cob at a time. The children would be in charge of keeping the flies off during the day, and the ears would be taken inside at night if it had been drying outside on tables. If hanging on a screened-in porch, it would be left about three days to dry.]  

watxâ (variants: watkxâ, wakxâ, wátxà, wátkxà). N pumpkin. hkâàcezi akxa watkxâ kòzékò akxai the orange is just like the pumpkin (FH:4/24/96/tape:prod). • squash (the vegetable).

•• RB: <wah-txáhæ, wah-kxáh> (BE2.108; PM/7/7/94; FH: wakxâ; 03/14/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 204: watxâ <wa-toæ´> pumpkin, squash, or any of the vegetables of that family. LFD 205: watxâ hkàce olà <wa-toæ´ Ðoæ-dse u-gthoæ> pumpkin pie.

watxâ púze (variant: watkxâ púze). N dried squash.

wawáðiiski (variant of waðíiski).

wáwalì. V [stat. ki-del, wá_walì] [wa- VAL + kíwalì] (intr.) be a stingy person, be stingy (lit., 'stingy with stuff'). wâàwalì, wáawalì [from wa-â-walì] I'm stingy. waðíwalì you're stingy. wakíwalì ~ wáwalì he's stingy. wá[w]awalì we're stingy. wáawali mìkçé I'm really stingy (04/26/95/FH/pc:okc). John akxa wáli wawálipe, John akxa wáli walípe John is really a stingy person (04/26/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.128). hkâàcezi záani ðuuzí akxái wáli wawálì akxai she took all the oranges, she's really stingy (04/26/95/FH/pc).  

wawáçi. V [presumed reg., wa_wáçi] [wa- VAL + waçí] (intr.) hire or employ folks to work. áwawaçí hkôbra I want to ask someone to work (03/24/95/PM/pc:ok).

wawéeðe. V [reg., wawée_ðe] [wa- VAL + wa- VAL + íiðe] (intr.) see things (as in a dream or hallucination), see multiple things or persons one after another. hâàce wawéeaðe last night I saw something in a dream (RBn12-10). wawéeða[ð]e nìkçé? are you seeing things? (FH/6/16/95; FH/1/17/96:prod). • see, have normal eyesight. wawéeðe hôòëi brî I see poorly (RB). wawéeðe màëíe ììçtóolà ðìké I can't see without my glasses (RB). wawéeðe hôòëi nî you see poorly (RB). wawéeðe hôòëipe she sees poorly (RB). wawéeðe hôòëi àðé we [two] see poorly (RB). • N vision, sight, seeing.

wawéeçce. N [wa- VAL + wa- VAL + iiçcéwai] shame (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 207: wawéçce <wa-we´-shtse> ignominy, shame. wawékØo. V, N [reg., wawé_kØo] [wa- VAL + wa- VAL + íkØo] (intr.) belch, burp. wawéakØoe I belched. wawéðakØoe you belched. wawéàkØope we belched.

wawépahò. V [sync. k>p, wawé_pahò] [wa- VAL + wa- VAL + ípahò] (intr.) be a witness, give testimony (BE2.159; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:uk). • N witness. wawépaho aní çô àhé I'm a witness and I'm still living (RB note: as in a courtroom; 04/06/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 206: wawépahò <wa-we´-ba-hoæ> a deponent, a witness; to give testimony. wawéhpahò <wa-we´-¼a-hoæ> I was a witness. wawéçpahò <wa-we´-shpa-hoæ> you were a witness. wawépahò òlake che hòëi hpaãe <wa-we´-ba-hoæ oæ-gtha-ge tse hoæ-zhi ¼a-xe> I gave poor testimony [expected Mod. Os. phrasing: wawépahò hôòëi hpáaãe 'I did badly as a witness'].

wawíhòìpi. V [wi- '1st person sg. subject–2nd person pl. object' + wahôì 'address folks with respect, address as friends and relatives' + api 'plural'] I address you as friends and relatives. [A very common expression in opening Osage speeches.]

wawîkçaëi. N [wawîkçe + aëí] s.o. who doesn't keep his/her word, disloyal person. • ADJ unfaithful, untruthful. níhkaçi wawîkçapaëíe she's an untruthful person (RB:MSB).

wawîkçe. ADJ [wa- VAL + wîkçe] truthful. níhka wawîkçape he's a truthful person (MSB/2-24-83; FH:prod).

waxáka. N [wa- VAL + xáka] stickers, thorns, briars, cockleburs. waxáka olîì dwell in the thorns [an infinitive or imperative form]. • thorny, burry, prickly (FH:5/01/96/tape,ok). waxákahtóho a certain plant or plants called green briar (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): waxáka ëîa <wa-qa´-§ka §ciæ ´-a> small thorns which grow on plants resembling grass.

•• LFD 207: waxáka <wa-xa´-ga> any plant that has prickly spines, like the sand bur, cactus, cocklebur, prick-ash. waxákahtoho <wa-xa´-ga-¾u-hu> a green briar.

waxákaolîì. N [waxáka + olîì] Pawhuska district, Pawhuska Osages (lit., 'dwelling in the thorns' or 'living in the cockleberry land') (FH/06/16/01/pc). waxákaolîì Pawhuska Osages (03/06/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.101).

•• LFD 207: waxákaolì <Wa-xa´-ga-u-gthiæ> Dwellers-in-the-Thorny Thicket. "This was the name by which a group became known who fled from the overflowing banks and were caught in a thicket of thorny trees and bushes. They live in Pawhuska, Okla."

waxópe (variants: wáxope [RB], waxópi [HRE]) N [wa- VAL + xópe] medicine bundle, sacred object, things consecrated or honored (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). waxópe wanáçe take care of the bundle (RBn 1016).

•• RB: <wáh-xo-peh> (BE2.87).  

•• LFD 208: waxópe <wa-xo´-be> a talisman, or something worn about the person to ward off evil; anything consecrated for ceremonial use. "A portable symbol, like the hawk, that represents or symbolizes the courage of a warrior." waxópe <wa-xo´-be> a whistle used as a sacred symbol after victory (unconfirmed, 02/24/95/FH/pc:uk as 'whistle'). waxópe kaãe <wa-xo´-be ga-xe> to make sacred, to consecrate some object to religious use. waxópe çkaãe <wa-xo´-be shka-xe> you consecrated it. waxópe àkaãa pe <wa-xo´-be oæ-ga-xa i> we consecrated it.

waxpáðì (variants: waxpáì, waxpéì). ADJ poor, poverty stricken. níhkaçika apa waxpáðìpe the people are poverty stricken (FH/pc). waxpéì àkái, ókØu àðúucØake çe nààhtàhtàà oðúucØake wî we're too poor to feed that lazy donkey (lit., 'we are poor, we couldn't feed that donkey who was lazy') (RBn102:MOJ/79). • pitiful, humble, long-suffering (as the victim of pain, poverty, or ill fortune). àwáxpaðì I'm pitiful. waxpáðì nà ahkílaipi carry yourself humbly [to two or more people] (RB). waxpáðì ànâbra xcì I'm pitiful with suffering (lit., 'I've had my fill of being pitiful') (RBn1-56;

FH/09/23/01/pc:ok). waxpéì ìðâbrà I've had enough of being pitiful (12/30/94/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 108: níhkaçika apa waxpaðì pi aða <ni´-Ða-shi-ga a-ba wa-xpa-thiæ bi a-tha> [expected Mod. Os. form: níhkaçika apa waxpaðìpe] the people are poverty stricken.

wáxta. N worm, caterpillar.

wazóeðe. V [reg., wazóe_ðe] [wa- '1st pl. patient' + kízo + ðe CAU] (trans.) make s.o. enjoy. wazóewa[ð]ape we [two or more] had a good time (lit., 'they made us enjoy ourselves') (FH/08/01/01/pc).  

wazóekçiðe (variant: wazóokçiðe). V [reg., wazóe_kçiðe] [wa- '3rd pl. patient' + kízo + kçíðe] (trans.) make s.o. enjoy (s.t.), show s.o. a good time, make s.o. have a good time. wazóowakçíe make them have a good time, show them a good time (FH/08/01/01/pc).

waëá (variant: waëáëe). V [reg., wa_ëá] [presumably contains wa- VAL but is used as transitive] (trans.) doubt. áwaëa I doubt it, I don't believe it (04/25/95/PM/pc:okc; 01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok; ERE prod: awáëa). wáðaëa? are you doubting it? (04/13/95/FH/pc). àwáëaëe he doubts me (04/25/95/PM/pct). awáëaëai eekô ëaëî ahí I doubt it and he doesn't believe it (RB). wáëa apai he doubts it (RB; CQc).

•• LFD 209: waëá <wa-zha´> to disbelieve, to discredit, to doubt the statement, to express doubt. awáëa <a-wa´-zha> I discredit it. waðáëa <wa-tha´-zha> you discredit it. àwâëape <oæ-woæ´-zha i> we discredit it. wawíëa <wa-wi´-zha> I expressed doubt as to your statement. LFD 17 (unconfirmed): éëa <e´-zha> I doubt his statement. ðeëa <the-zha> you doubt his statement. kíëa <gi´-zha> they doubt his statement (01/20/95/ERE/pc:uk, unconfirmed). [LF's forms éëa 'I doubt' and ðeëa 'you doubt' are unusual and probably incorrect.]  

••• KS gíëa (JOD) doubt someone's word (RR), wagíëa (JOD), wagíëa ~ waagíëa doubt one's own (child, etc.) (RR).

waëáe wéhkilì (variant of waëáëe wéhkilì).

waëáihci (variant: waëáehci). N [waëáëe + hcí] tepee (lit., 'Osage house') (MREI; 03/16/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn2-MOJ/p2); long house covered with brush or canvas (like the houses Osages used to live in) (04/28/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.158; MREI); tent, arbor (RB; FH).

waëáwa. N dance. [A rare word; may be Ponca (RB).]  

waëáxì. N Josephine Walker's name, Myrtle Oberly Jones's name (RB).

waëáëe (variant: waëáëi). ADJ, N Osage (tribe, tribal member, or language). waëáëe níhkaçi an Osage person. háakò waëáëe? how much Osage are you? (this question is considered impolite). waëái wéhkilì dress in Osage clothes (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.99). waëáëe nìpe you Osages (lit., 'those of you who are Osage'). waëáëe huuwáli íhpahò I know a lot of Osages (RBn10-2).

•• RB: <wah-zháh-zhi> (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 209–10: : waëáëe <Wa-zha´-zhe> name of the Osage Tribe, corrupted by the French to Osage. The name of the subdivision which refers to the water portion of the earth. It is also a personal name belonging to the <Wa-¾se-¾si> [Mod. Os.: wahcéhci] or <Poæ-Ða Wa-shtage> [Mod. Os.: hpôhka waçtáke] gens. "In the mythical story of this gens the people came from the stars to the earth. In their wanderings they came suddenly upon a man who stood in the midst of the waters that rushed noisily over the rocks. The man leading the way turned around and said to his followers: 'Here stands Wa-zha´-zhe, a person who has made the waters of the earth his body.' . . . The meaning of the name is obscure. Even some of the older Osage fail to give satisfactory interpretation of the name."

waëáëe (variant of waëá).

waëáëe wéhkilì (variants: waëáe wéhkilì, waëáëe óhkilì). N Osage clothes (RB, FH, ERE).

waëáëeíe. N [waëáëe + íe] Osage language (03/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

waëáëemîìhcexì. N [waëáëe + mììhcéxi] name for a first daughter (possible interpretations are 'precious Osage female', 'difficult Osage woman', 'stout Osage daughter', 'sacred Osage sun'). [Name of Armeda Lookout (RB), Robin Bristow (RB), and Priscilla Iba.] waëáëi (variant of waëáëe). waëî. N [wa- VAL + aëî] will, mind, idea.

•• LFD 211 (unconfirmed): waëî wihta hpaãe <wa-zhiæ´ wi-¾a ¼a-xe> I did it of my own free will, it was my own idea.

waëî hpíiëi. ADJ enraged, mad (angry).

••• Cf. óëì hpíiëi. 

waëî hpíiëi káaãe. VP [sync. k>p, waëî hpíiëi _káaãe] (trans.) make a person angry, enrage s.o.

•• LFD 211: waëî hpiëi kaãe <wa-zhiæ´ ¼i-zhi ga-xe> to enrage a person. (LF here provides several inflected forms that are not from waëî hpíiëi káaãe, but rather are from a verb ðuuwáëìhpíiëì or ðiiwáëìhpíiëì 'make angry' [not attested in Mod. Os.]: e.g., bríwaëì hpiëi <bthi´-wa-zhiæ ¼i-zhi> I angered him.)  

waëî ihta. ADVP, ADJP determinedly, determined (RB); of his/her own free will.

•• LFD 211: waëî ihta <wa-zhiæ´ i-¾a> of one's own free will and accord.

waëîhtàà. N [waëîka + htâka] hawk (lit., 'large bird') (RBn14-13).

waëîka. N bird. waëîkake wáðaawa count the [scattered] birds (BE2.8; 01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). waëîka hîì bird feathers. waëîka çáake bird claws, talons. waëîka çki wahúì nàpe even birds migrate. waëîka hpaëúuce red-headed woodpecker. waëîka sápe the blackbird.

•• LFD 210: waëîka <wa-zhiæ´-ga> any bird or fowl. [But note míãa 'duck, goose, any large bird or fowl'.]

waëîkaíe. N [waëîka + íe] parrot, macaw (any bird that can be taught to "speak"). waëîka íe môçò parrot feathers (01/24/95/FH/pc:ma; BE2.45).

waëîëue. N [waëîka + ëúuce] cardinal (the bird; lit., 'red bird').

waëóla (variant: waëóole [PM]). N Oto (tribe or tribal member).

•• RB: <wah-zhó-d-?-lah> (BE2.99; RBn23-11; 03/03/95/FH/pc:ok). •• LFD 211: waëóla <Wa-zho´-xtha> a name given to the Oto Tribe.

wáëu (variant of oáëu).

waëúpe. N marrow (FH:4/22/96/tape:prod; 10/13/96).

••• QU wahí ëiwe marrow (RR); KS waëåbe (JOD), -ëü´we marrow, a long bone in the shin (RR).

wàkóiëì, wàkôìëì (variants of wàkôòëì).

wàkôò. ADV quickly. wàkôò alí hta mìkçé I'll be back quickly (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 313: wàkò <woæ-goæ> I'll come right back quickly.

wàkôòëì (variants: wàkôìëì, wàkóiëì). ADV [wàkôò + -ëì 'little'] right away, immediately. wàkóiëì alí hta mìkçé I'll come right back (RBn3-21).

wé-. PREFIX [The prefixes wa- VAL (or in some cases '1st pl. object' or '3rd pl. object') + í- LOC regularly combine to form we-. This formation is regularly seen in the ordinal numerals and in several names of tools.]

••• Cf. wéðaabrì, wéðì, wéðòòpa, wéðuçupe, wesáhtà, weçáhpe, wétoopa.  

wéapazo (variants: weápazo, wepázo). N [wa- VAL + í- LOC + ápazo] index finger, pointing finger (lit., 'with which to point at things').

••• Cf. çáake opázo.

wécØa. N snake, serpent, viper. íinòòhpapai, wécØa ochíe be careful, there are lots of snakes (BE2.124; 03/13/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 215: wécØa <we´-¾s'a> reptile, snake. wécØa hcihciëi <we´-¾s'a ¾si-¾si-zhi> snake brittle,

name given to the glass snake by the Osage. wécØa niciwaò <we´-¾s'a ni-dsi-wa-oæ> water snake. wécØa hpahta ëìka <we´-¾s'a ¼a-¾a zhiæ-ga> [expected Mod. Os. form: wécØa hpáataëì] a young snake [that has] just hatched. wécØa sape <we´-¾s'a ša-be> black snake.

wéðaabrì (variant: weðáabrì). ADJ [wé- PREFIX + ðáabrì] third, number three.

•• RB: <weh-tháh-briæ> (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.139).

•• LFD 214: wéðabrì <we´-tha-bthiæ> the third.

wéðaawa. V [wé_ðaawa] [wa- VAL + í- LOC + ðaawá] (trans.) count or measure s.t. with. ëâà wéðaawa measuring stick (lit., 'measure stuff using wood') (05/02/95/LS/pc:prod).

wéðahpe. V [reg.-iða, wéð_ahpe] [wa- VAL + iðáhpe (but sometimes used as transitive)] (intr., trans.) wait for folks. wawé[ð]ahpi akxai he's waiting for them (FH). wéàðahpe àkakxái we were waiting for people (FH).

wéðiçipe (variant of wéðuçupe).

wéðì. N [presumably wé- PREFIX + oðîìke] rope, cord (lit., 'with which to hold stuff').

wéðòòpa (variant: weðôòpa). ADJ [wé- PREFIX + ðòòpá] second, number two. hpéece íhta weðôòpa second fireman in peyote meeting (05/02/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.117). hôòpa wéðòòpa Tuesday (lit., 'second day') (RB).

•• LFD 215: wéðòpa <we´-thoæ-ba> the second: from a ritual.

wéðuãe (variant: wéuãe). V [sync., wé_ðuãe] (intr.) get married, follow a man as his wife, take a husband, marry (said of a woman) (02/24/95/FH/pc:ok). wéðuãe? wéçcuãe? did you marry? did you get married? [asking a woman] (02/24/95/FH/pc). wéçäuãe hta ðaìçí aape they said you were going to get married. hatkxâci wéçäuãe? when did you get married? • N wedding. Carolyn apa wéðuãe aðeé hta apá apai Carolyn is going to a wedding [they say] (02/27/95/JS/pc).

•• RB: <wéh-u-xeh> (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc).

••• Cf. áðuãe, íðuãe, wáðuãe. 

wéðuãekíðe (variant: wéuãekiðe). V [reg., wéðuãe_kíðe] [wéðuãe + kíðe] (trans.) make one's own relative take a husband, marry off a female relative (e.g., marry off one's daughter). wéðuãekíðe they made her [the young woman who was their own] marry (FH/prod). çímiëì wéuãekí[ð]e akxai, wáðohta hta nà they married their girl off so she would be proper, respectable (RBn22-17).

wéðuçupe (variants: wéðiçipe, wéuçupe). N [wé- PREFIX + ðuuçúpe] key (lit., 'with which to open'). [Takes 'lying down' positional article kçe.] wéðuçupe açäî ðaaçé? have you got the key? (BE2.73).

wéðiçipe kçe àwâxpaðe mìkçe I lost my door key (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• RB: <weh-ú-shu-peh> (02/14/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• LFD 215: wéðiçipe <we´-thi-shi-be> a key. wéðiçipe kçe àwâxpaðe mìkçe o <we´-thi-shi-be ke oæ-woæ-xpa-the miæ-kshe o>[sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I lost my door key.

wéðuwì. V [sync., wé_ðuwì] [wa- VAL + íðuwì, but used as transitive] (trans.) sell s.t. by bartering for other stuff. wébruwì mìkçé I'm selling it. wébruwì I sold it. haxî wébruwì I sold the blanket htóoëu tóa wéçäuwì? did you sell any meat pies? (RB). htóoëu wéðuwì akxái he or she is selling meat pies (BE2.118). htóoëu wéðuwì kôða apai àëì oðóðai hce ée apai they want to sell meat pies but they want you to oversee it [they're saying] (FH:prod).wéðuwì ìká don't sell it (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). ðúwì ìká, wéðuwì! don't buy it, sell it! (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). • buy or acquire stuff with s.t. haxî wébruwì I bought it [some stuff] with a blanket (or 'I traded the blankets for them'). wéðuwì ðìké atxâhe I have nothing to buy [stuff] with (lit., 'I am without anything to exchange stuff for') (RBn1-58).  

•• RB: <wéh-thu-wiæ> (03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok).

•• LFD 215: wéðiwì <we´-thi-wiæ> to sell or to purchase. wébriwì <we´-bthi-wiæ> I sell. wésciwì <we´-stsi-wiæ> you sell. wéðiwì ðiçtà <we´-thi-wiæ thi-shtoæ> sold. nihkaçika akxa hkawa ðòpa àðiwì akxa o <ni-Ða-shi-ga a-ka Ða-wa thoæ-ba oæ-thi-wiæ a-ka o> [expected Mod. Os. form: níhkaçika akxa hkáwa ðòòpá àðúwì akxa 'the man has bought two horses from me'; sentencefinal o is not used in Mod. Os.] I sold two horses to the man. hci che webriwì briçtà ha <¾si tse webthi-wiæ bthi-shtoæ ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: hcí che wébruwì bríiçtà 'I finished selling the (standing) house'; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] I sold the house. LFD 116: nàníhi weðiwì <noæ-ni´-hi we-thi-wiæ> a tobacconist, one who deals in tobacco.

wéehkile. N [wa- + hkik- RECIP + íiðe] visit, means to see each other.

wéehlihpíiëi (variant: wéelihpíiëi). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) extremely drunk (lit., 'bad head'), very badly inebriated, very drunk, "crazy" drunk. wéehli hpíiëi akxa he's crazy drunk (WF/12/30/01:prod).

wéeli. N head (human or animal) (BE2.65, CQc; FH:ok/pc). wéeli hóxpe záani àwáëu mìksé I have a head cold (lit., 'a head cold is all through me') (01/19/95/FH/pc:uk; BE2.21).

•• RB: <wéh-'l-?-diæ>

•• LFD 215: wéðili <we´-thi-xthi> the head of a man or of an animal.

wéelihpíiëi (variant of wéehlihpíiëi).

wéelihtàà (variant: wéelìhtàà). N cabbage (lit., 'big head') (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.16; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok, htàà).

•• LFD 215: wéðili htàka <we´-thi-xthi ¾oæ-ga> big head: cabbage.

wéeliçta. N, ADJ [wéeli + çtáha] bald head, bald headed (BE2.6; FH: preferable to hpeeçtá; 04/07/95/PM/pc:ok).

wéenacehkiðe (variant of wéenàcehkiðe).

wéenà (variant: wéena). V [reg., wée_nà] (intr.) be thankful, grateful, or appreciative, be glad. wéewinai àkxâhe I'm thankful to you (03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). wéeana àkxâhe I'm thankful (03/16/95/FH/pc). wéena íe iiðáe hkôbra I want to say something in appreciation (lit., 'I want to say grateful words') (03/16/95/FH/pc; BE2.136). wéewina I am grateful to you. wéeana mìkçé záani ðachípe I'm glad you all came (BE2.60). wéenàpi they're thankful (02/03/95/FH/pc:prod orig). • (trans.) be thankful or grateful for, be appreciative of, be glad about. ànâðapi che wéeàna mìkçe I'm glad you all saw me (FH/07/27/95/pc:prod; LS/07/28/9Øpc:ok). tàhé paaçé wéeàna mìkçé I'm glad you [pl.] are well (FH:7/27/95:prod). ëìkáëì nakxâçe wéewina akxâhe, ilôìhpa waachí çtôpape I want to thank you children for watching my son dance. hôòpa ðé wéena akxai ðe níhkaçi tóa áðixòpape, hpáðì wéhkili íwehkili ì kçíãape she's grateful today because they honored her, they dressed her in Kiowa clothes (lit., 'today she's grateful to the people that honored her by having her dress with Kiowa clothes') (RBn23-17; CQc). wéewinai, mààhí wíhta ðákaase thank you for cutting my grass (01/14/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.28).  

wéenàce. V [reg., wée_nàce] [presumably wa- VAL + ínàce 'satisfied with food' (ínàce appears in LFD 76, but is not attested not in Mod. Os.)] (intr.) be full, filled; have one's hunger sated. [According to some, this is a way for a male speaker to express appreciation to the host at a dinner (RB); according to others, both men and women use this expression (FH) (01/25/95/FH/pc:okc).] weeânàce I'm full (RBN3-21; FH:okc). weeðánàce are you full? (BE2.51).

•• LFD 214: wénàce <we´-noæ-dse> to feed [rather, 'eat'] until filled to satisfaction. weánàce <we-a´-noæ-dse> I am satisfied (my hunger [is satisfied]). weðánàce <we-tha´-noæ-dse> you are satisfied (your hunger [is satisfied]). wénàte <we´-noæ-de> gratified, satiated. [LFD lists wénàte <we´-noæ-de> as a separate word, but it is probably an error for wénàce <we´-noæ-dse>.] LFD 76 (unconfirmed): ínàce <i´ -noæ-dse> to be full and satisfied with food.

wéenàcehkiðe (variant: wéenacehkiðe). V [reg.+reg., wée_nàce_hkiðe] [wéenàce + hkíðe CAU (reflexive form)] (intr.) cause oneself to be satiated with food, satisfy oneself with food, make oneself full. pààçcéka bráache weeânàcheahkí[ð]e hta mìkçé I will eat strawberries until I'm satiated (RBn18-02; CQc).

wéetaðaëi. ADJ [wéetaðe + aëí] barren, childless.

•• LFD 212: wétaðaëi <we´-da-tha-zhi> without a child, barren, childless.

wéetaðe (variant: wéetai). V [reg., wée_taðe] [wa- VAL +íitaðe] (intr.) give birth, have a baby

(01/31/95/FH/pc:ok). wéeta[ð]ape she had a baby (FH:4/18/96/tape; BE2.55). wéeðatai? did you give birth? • N childbirth, birth (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 212: wétaðe <we´-da-the> childbirth, the act of giving birth to a child. wétaaðe <we´da-a-the> I gave birth to a child. wétaðaðe <we´-da-tha-the> you gave birth to a child. [Note contrast between LF wéta_ðe and Mod. Os. wée_taðe.]

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 212).
