wéetaha. N lap (part of the body) (RBn22-09, unconfirmed).

wéetai (variant of wéetaðe).

wéewinà (variant: wéewina). INTERJ [wi- '1st person sg. subject–2nd person object' + wéenà] thank you

(lit., 'I'm grateful to you') (BE2.136; 03/16/95/FH/pc:ok). [Not used as frequently as 'thank you' in

English.]

wéhice. ADV far, far away, from afar, a long way (BE2.44; FH). wéhice pçi I went far away

(03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). wéhice pçíeðe I went far away (01/23/95/FH/pc:prod). alée, wéhice achíe I'm going, I have a long way to go (lit., 'I'm returning there, from far away I arrived here'). wéhice çí you went far away (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). tóe wéhice ðachípe some of you have come from far off (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok;prod). wéhice hí áape hcí káaãe káaçi ðí áape she went a long way and took a long time to build her nest [they said] (RBn19-03). wéhice àkáchie we [two] came from a long ways away (RBn3-47). àkále, wéhice àkáchie we're going, we [two] came from far away (as if to say: we're going because it's a long ways home) (FH).

•• LFD 213: wéhice <we´-hi-dse> far away, distant (01/23/95/FH/pc:ok). wéhice pçi <we´-hidse pshi> I went far away. wéhice çi <we´-hi-dse shi> you went far away.

wéhice anâkØò (variant: wéhice nàkØô). N radio (lit., 'listen from far away') (BE2.111; RBn1-9, unconfirmed; 04/20/95/LS/pc:no).

wéhkikØò. N [wé- PREFIX + hkik- REFL + éò 'do'] tool, implement, machinery, gadget, piece of equipment (lit., 'things with which to do for oneself') (HH/pc).

••• Cf. éwahkikØò. 

wéhkilì. N [possibly wé- PREFIX +hkik- + î] clothes, dress, costume, pants, coat, vest, any item of clothing or suit of clothes (RB note: for man, woman, or child) (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok). waëái wéhkilì 

Osage clothes (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). wéhkilì ðuustáko straighten up your clothes (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.20). hôòpa ðé wéenà akxai ðe níhkaçi tóa áðixòpape, hpáðì wéhkili íwehkili ì kçíãape she's grateful today because they honored her, they dressed her in Kiowa clothes (lit., 'today she's grateful to the people that honored her by having her dress with Kiowa clothes') (RBn23-17; CQc). waëái wéhkilì î dress in Osage clothes.

•• LFD 213: wéhkiliwì <we´-Ði-gthi-wiæ> clothing. wéhkiliwì okíhpahà <we´-Ði-gthi-wiæ u-gi´¼a-hoæ> to dress. wéhkiliwì okíhpahà <we´-Ði-gthi-wiæ u-gi´-¼a-hoæ> to dress.

wéhkilì okíhpaahà. VP [reg., wéhkilì o_kíhpaahà] [wéhkilì + kik- SUU+ opáahà] (intr.) dress in or put on one's own clothes. wéhkilì okíhpaahâpi put on your clothes (01/20/95/ERE/pc; 04/18/95/FH/pc:okc).

•• RB: <ó-kyu-lah o-kí-pah-háhæ-pi>.

•• LFD 213: wéhkiliwì okíhpahà <we´-Ði-gthi-wiæ u-gi´-¼a-hoæ> to dress [specifically 'in one's own clothes']. wéhkiliwì owákihpahà <we´-Ði-gthi-wiæ u-wa´-gi-¼a-hoæ> I dress [in my own clothes] (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok). wéhkiliwì oðákiçpahà <we´-Ði-gthi-wiæ u-tha´-gi-shpa-hoæ> you dress [in your own clothes] (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok). wéhkiliwì àkokihpahà pe <we´-Ði-gthi-wiæ oæ-gugi-¼a-hoæ i> we dress [in our own clothes].

••• KS obáhà ~ obáahà wear (RR).

wéhkilì opáahà. VP [sync. fortisizing stop stem, wéhkilì o_páahà] dress in or put on clothing (not one's own). wéhkili wì ohpáahà mìkçé I dress (lit., 'I put on an outfit'--as when I check out some clothing and put it on) (01/20/95/ERE/pc).

wéhpiiëi. V, ADJ [conjug. unknown, presumed reg., wé_hpiiëi] [wa- VAL + í- LOC + hpíiëi] (be) destructive, damaging, harmful (RBn17-p02). • cause trouble or disturbance for others. wéhpiiëi apai  they're causing trouble, they're causing a disturbance (lit., 'folks are troubled [by them]' or 'they are troubled [by them]').

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p20 ln5): wéhpììmaëi <we´piiæ-má¦ci>. [No appropriate gloss given, but the form appears to contain the 1st person sg. negative maëí 'I do not, I did not'—as if wéhpiiëi were wéhpii (unattested) + aëí 'not'. In Mod. Os., however, hpíiëi and wéhpiiëi are clearly not hpíi or wéhpii + aëí.]

wéhuu. V [uninfl., presumably also reg., wé_huu] [wa- VAL + í- LOC + húu 'many'] (intr.) make a crowd (RBn22-17). wéhuu mìkçé I'm here making a crowd (RBn22-17).

wéhuukôì. V [conjug. unknown] [wa- VAL + í- LOC + huukôða] (intr.) make a crowd (FH).

wéhuuëì. V [uninfl.] [wa- VAL+ í- LOC + húu 'many' + -ëì 'little'] (intr.) increase in size a bit by more (number or amount) being added; help to make a bit of a crowd. wéhuuëì brée ðe I'm just going to help make a crowd, I'm going to make a little bit more (BE2.27; FH; 01/14/95/FH/pc:okc).

wékaacuxe (FH) (variant: wékaacuãe [LS]). N [wé- PREFIX + kaacúxe] broom (BE2.12; 01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 212: wékacuxe ëìka <we´-ga-dsu-xe zhiæ-ga> small broom.  

••• KS ääígaãe broom (RR), gaãé sweep (RR).

wékaaãe. V [sync. k>p, wé_kaaãe] [wa- VAL + íkaaãe] (trans.) make from, make using. • N tool used to make s.t.

wékaapçe (variant: wekáapçe). N [wé- PREFIX + káapçe] brush or comb (for the hair), hairbrush (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok; 04/20/95/LS/pc:ok; 04/17/96).

wékaaspe (variant: wékaaspa). N hammer (02/09/95/FH/pc:prod orig). wékaaspe háaëô? what did you do with the hammer? (02/09/95/FH/pc:prod orig; BE2.63).

•• LFD 212 (unconfirmed): wékasta <we´-ga-šta> with which to pound: hammer (FH:uk).

wékaaëi (variant: wékaaëì). N [wé- PREFIX + kaaëí] horse whip, quirt, stick to drive people or animals, stick that tail dancers carry at war dances (05/02/95/LS/pc:ok). wékaaëi ànâchìpe he hit me with a stick (05/02/95/LS).

•• LFD 212: wékaëì <we´-ga-zhiæ> whip, quirt.

wéleze. N [wé- PREFIX + léze] pencil, pen (lit., 'with which to make marks') (RBn10-20; 03/07/95/PM/pc:ok). [The corresponding form in LFD has final ðe (see below), but this is not found in the Mod. Os. data.]

•• LFD 213: wélezeðe <we´-gthe-še-the> a pen, or pencil. wélezeðe ðihta ëúce <we´-gthe-šethe thi-¾a zhu-dse> your pencil is red. wélezeðe wihta sape <we´-gthe-še-the wi-¾a ša-be> my pencil is black.

wéli. N oil; lard; grease or similar substance (such as shoe polish) (HH). wéeli weli hot oil treatment for the hair or scalp (lit., 'head oil') (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod). hkohkósa wéli pork lard. wéli hòòpé ápuçtai polish your shoes. • gasoline, kerosene. wéli tóe oðíhtà ooëú ði put some gas in the car (RBn12-06). wéli tóe oðíhtà ooðáëu? did you put some gas in the car? (RBn12-06).

•• LFD 213: wéli <we´-gthi> grease, oil, kerosene (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok). LFD 88: hkohkosa weli <Ðo-Ðo-ša, we-gthi> hog, grease: lard.

••• Cf. átahkà wéli níini, paazénii wéli, wacúe wéli. 

wéli màhkâ. N castor oil (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 213: wéli màhkà <we´-gthi moæ-Ðoæ> castor oil (oil, medicine).

wélisaaki. N [wéli + saakí] tallow (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 213: wélisaki <we´-gthi-ša-gi> tallow.  

wéoohô. N [wé- PREFIX + oohô] cooking utensils (JS).

wépaase. N [wa- VAL + ípaase] any tool for cutting wood (such as a saw; lit., 'with which to cut things by pushing down on them') (RB).

••• Cf. ëâàpaase. 

wepázo (variant of wéapazo).

wépçe. N [wé- PREFIX + pçé] pestle (lit., 'with which to pound things') (RBn23-07).

wépukxa. N [wa- VAL + ípukxa] soap, detergent (lit., 'with which to rub things') (RBn1-MOJ/p49b; 03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). hììcé íðuuëa wépukxa dish soap (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok). wépukxa íhkiluuëaa wash yourself with soap (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.124).

•• LFD 212: wépukxa <we´-biu-ka> soap. wépukxa topa àðiwì a he <we´-biu-ka du-ba oæ-thiwiæ a he> [expected Mod. Os. form: wépukxa tóa âðuwì] buy me some soap.

wesáhtà. ADJ [wé- PREFIX + sáhtà] fifth.

weçáhpe. ADJ [wé- PREFIX + çáhpe] sixth.

wéçì. N oatmeal (RB, unconfirmed, BE2.97). [Possibly wé- PREFIX + waçî (lit., 'with which to eat bacon or fat'?); perhaps a borrowing.] •• RB: <wéh´-shiæ>  

wétoopa (variant: wetóopa). ADJ [wé- PREFIX + tóopa] fourth.

•• RB: <wéh-tó-pah> (01/30/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.50).

•• LFD 212: wétopa <we´-do-ba> the fourth.

wéuãaake (variant of wáìãaaké). N Carrying and Wailing (personal name).

wéuãe (variant of wéðuãe).

wéuãekiðe (variant of wéðuãekíðe). wéuçupe (variant of wéðuçupe).

weúuze. N [wé- PREFIX + ðuuzé] debt, s.t. owed. weúuze htà áçupe hta mîkçe I'm going to pay this big debt (03/06/95/FH/pc:prod). • instrument for picking s.t. up (tongs, fork, etc.). [By analogy with

Omaha wéðize (RL).]

wí (variant of wíe).

wi-. PRNM combined marker of 1st person sg. subject and 2nd person object ('I . . . you'). [Used both with reg. and sync. verbs (whose subject may also be expressed by agent pronominal prefixes) and with doubly stative verbs (whose subject may also be expressed by patient pronominal prefixes). The object 'you' may be pluralized by addition of api in postverbal position.] çée wihkôbra I want that for you (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). wikØú I give [it] to you. wíbruwì atxàhé I am buying it for you. wawíhôìpi I address you all as friends and family. íiwinòhpe I'm afraid of you. wikíkxopi achíe I have come to invite you all to eat (04/14/95/FH/pc:okc; 04/25/95/PM/pc:ok; t14b-p3/170). ëìkáëì nakxâçe wéewina akxâhe, ilôìhpa waachí çtôpape I want to thank you children for watching my son dance. màhká owíbrikØe I gave you a shot (FH:4/25/96/t141, prod).

wi-. PRNM 1st person sg. inalienable possessive pronominal ('my'; used with many kinship terms, e.g., wihcíko 'my grandfather').

wíaðaaspe (variant of wíoðaaspe).

wícihta. N Wichita (tribe or tribal member) (RBn HW13; FH/10/09/01/prod).

••• KS mítsitta, wítsitta Wichita, people or tribe [ts is not a Kansa phoneme; therefore this a borrowing] (RR).

wíe (variant: wí). PRON me, I (emphatic). wí, àðáhice as for me, I'm ready to go (RBn10-5:JW). wíe hta mìkçé? is it I? • it is my turn. wíe hta mìkçé [it will be I] it's my turn (RB note: Mr. Maten said this to the fireman when it was his turn to hit drum in a peyote meeting) (04/04/95/FH/pc:ok; RB).

•• LFD 216: wíe <wi´-e> I, me.  

wíexci. PRON [wíe + xci] I myself (more emphatic form of wíe).

wíeëi. ADJ bashful (RBn10-18, unconfirmed).  

wihâka. N my wife's sister, my brother's wife (used only when speaker is male [RB]; more precise than

English 'my sister-in-law'). [Traditionally men liked to tease their sisters-in-law with jokes.]  

wihcíko. N my grandfather. wihcíko hpéece grandfather fire (RB; FH/09/24/01/ok). wihcíko mîì grandfather sun (BE2.59). • my father-in-law (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 217: wihcikóe <wi-¾si-go´-e> [02/03/95/FH/pc: wrong pronunciation, should be wihcíko] my grandfather. "The term <¾si-go> is applied to a father's father, to his father, to a mother's father, to his brother, to a father-in-law, and to a wife's maternal uncle. It is also used as a term of reverence for God and for natural objects, such as the sun, the morning star, the dipper, Orion's belt, the pole star, and living objects whose mysterious habits inspire in the Osage mind a feeling of reverence for the Creator."

••• Cf. hcíko. 

wihcími. N my father's (older or younger) sister (my paternal aunt; used when speaker is male or female) (FH/09/22/01/pc; 01/06/95/FH/pc:prod).  

wihcíni (variant: wihcínì). N my daughter-in-law (used when speaker is male or female) (01/19/95/FH/pc:ok).  

wihcióëàke (variant: wihcóëàke). N my brother's daughter (used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my niece') (02/27/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.93).  

wihcíëo (variant: wihcíëoe). N my sister's daughter (used only when speaker is male; more precise than English 'my niece'); my father's sister's daughter (used when speaker is male or female; more precise than English 'my cousin'). [wihcíëo as 'cousin, my paternal aunt's daughter' is said by some to be used only by a female speaker.]

•• LFD 81: ihcíëò <i-¾si´-zhoæ> niece, daughter of a sister or a father's sister.  

wihcîto. N my older brother (oldest of speaker's brothers, not necessarily older than the speaker; used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my older brother') (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 217: wichîto <wi-tsiæ´-do> brother, older (than myself), woman speaking.  

wihcóçka. N my sister's son, my wife's brother's son (used only when speaker is male; more precise than English 'my nephew') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.92); my brother's son (used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my nephew'); son of my father's sister (my paternal aunt's son; used when speaker is male or female; more precise than English 'my cousin'); my grandchild (my granddaughter or my grandson; used when speaker is male or female) (04/17/95/LS/pc; 04/18/95/FH/pc:ok). [Historically, 'grandchild' is an unexpected gloss (perhaps used only by extension to one's grandniece or grandnephew: i.e., one's sibling's grandchild?).]  

••• KS iääóçkayà woman's sister's son (RR).  

wihcóçpa (variant: hcoçpá). N my grandchild (05/01/95/LS/pc). wihcóçpa, ðéka ku grandchild, come over here (RBn1-18).

•• LFD 217: wihcóçpaëi xci ðò <wi-tsu´-shpa-zhi xtsi thoæ> [xci is not confirmed as 'dear' and ðò is not used in Mod. Os.] my dear grandchild (woman speaking).  

••• Cf. wihäóçpa. 

wihcóçpa áhkiha. N my great-grandchild(ren).  

wihcóëàke (variant of wihcióëàke).

wihäóçpa. N my grandchild. [Endearing or diminutive in comparison to wihcóçpa.]  

wihé. N second daughter (02/27/95/FH/pc).

•• LFD 215: wihé <wi-he´> special kinship term, the name by which the second daughter is called (04/07/95/LS/pc:ok).  

wíhta. PRON mine, my. óolàke ðé wíhta this hat is mine (PM:ok; BE2.88).

•• LFD 217: wíhta <wi´-¾a> mine, denoting possession, my. màëà wíhta <moæ-zhoæ wi´-¾a> my land. hkawa wihta <Ða-wa wi-¾a> my horse. hci wihta <¾si wi-¾a> my house or tipi (CQ:ok).

wihtáeëì (variant of wihtéëì).

wihtâha. N my father's sister's husband (my paternal uncle by marriage; used when speaker is male or female; more precise than English 'my uncle'); my sister's husband, my wife's brother (used only when speaker is male; more precise than English 'my brother-in-law') (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.12).  

••• Cf. htâhà, ihtâha. 

wihtâke (variant: wiht„ke). N my older sister (used when speaker is male or female); my sister (loosely used mutually among unrelated younger and older female speakers to show respect); my wife (lit., 'my sister'; used to refer to speaker's wife when they have no children and possibly to address her) (RBn12-12; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.158). [This is the default vocative 'sister' term; the person so addressed need not be older than the speaker. As illustration of this, Mrs. Josephine Walker always called Mrs. Frances Holding, who was younger, wihtàke (FH10/13/96). When used to mean 'older sister', the sister in question may be either older than the speaker or the oldest of the group of

sisters.]  

wihtéëì (variant: wihtáeëì) N my younger sister (used when speaker is male or female) (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).  

wihtôce (variant: wahitôci). N my son-in-law (used when speaker is male or female).

•• RB: <wi-tóæ-tsi> (03/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.125).  

wíkie. N prayer; church (meeting) (RBn10-18). óchì ðáalì káaãì aha wíkie whenever he hits drum well, there's a prayer (RBn10-18; gloss by CQ). ëáëe kØú wíkie prayer for name-giving (LF; CQc). • V [reg., wí_kie] (intr.?) pray (LF only).  

•• LFD 216: wíkie <wi´-gi-e> orison, prayer, to pray. wíakie <wi´-a-gi-e> I pray. wíðakie <wí´-tha-gi-e> you pray. wiâkiape <wi-oæ´-gi-a i> we pray.  

••• Cf. wíkiehci. 

wíkie hîìska. N prayer beads, rosary.

••• Cf. hîìskawáata. 

wíkiehci N [wíkie + hcí] church. çîtoëì akxa wíkiehci ci aðée apai that boy [who is now absent but was just present] is on his way to church.

wíkihciëì. N [wíkiehci + -ëì 'little'] little church (lit., 'little house of prayer'; used to refer to the Friends' Church [Quaker Meeting] in Hominy by its members). (DN/FH980930).

wínà (variants: wînà, wína). V, PRON [1st person sg. of eenâ 'be the only one'] (intr.) (be) only I. winâ, it is only I.

••• Cf. àkónà, ðínà. 

winíhka. N my husband.  

••• Cf. níhka. 

wíoðaaspe (variant: wíaðaaspe). N cork (BE2.25; RBn3-07, unconfirmed; 01/12/95/FH/pc:uk; 04/25/95/PM/pc:uk) (specifically a fishing cork [RB]).

•• LFD 216 (unconfirmed): wéoðatà <we´-u-tha-doæ> a stopper of any kind. [A different word from wíoðaaspe.]

••• KS oyáadà to cork, to put a stopper in (RR).

wíohkaðì. V [uninfl.] [probably contains óhkà 'space, room'] (intr.) in the way, not fitting in the available space. wíohkaðì nìkçé you're in the way (FH:5/01/96/okc). wíohkaðì àðìhée I'm in the way (FH:5/01/96/prod).

wióohò. N [wa- VAL + í- LOC +oohô] cooking utensils (lit., 'with which to cook things'). wióohòëì alábrìbrée hta àhé I am going to take my little cooking utensils along (BE2.25; 01/12/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn3-MOJ/18).

wísi (variants: oísi, owísi, wíse). V [reg., o_ísi, o_wísi] (trans.) get off, alight from (e.g., a vehicle), dismount from (e.g., a horse) (BE2.72). hkáwa owéisi hta mìkçe [hkáwa owáisi hta mìkçé(?)] I'm going to get off the horse (01/31/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.53). • (intr.) jump (02/13/95/FH/pc: wíse).

•• LFD 181: owísi <u-wi´-ši> to leap, to jump in play; to alight, to dismount. oðáwisi <u-tha´wi-ši> you dismount. àkówisi pe <oæ-gu´-wi-ši i> we dismount. LFD 216: wísi <wi´-ši> to jump, alight from a horse, leap.

••• KS oyåsì (JOD) jump down, get off, dismount (reg. conjugation) (RR).

••• Cf. ósi. 

wisíkxà. N my sister-in-law (used only when speaker is female).  

wísikØò. N jumping game (RB).

wísisi. N [reduplicated form of wísi] flea (01/26/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.49).

•• LFD 216: wísisi <wi´-ši-ši> flea.

wisôeëì (variant: wisôaëì). N my younger brother (used only when speaker is female) (BE2.12; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; 04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). ['Younger' here probably means 'younger than the speaker'.]  

wisôka. N my younger brother (younger than the speaker; used only when speaker is male)

(04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). [Also used by both men and women for a related or unrelated younger male.] •• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p21 ln7): wísòká <Wi´sañ¦ka´> my younger brother.

[Historically, it appears that when this word was used vocatively, its accent would shift to the first and third syllables.]

•• LFD 216: wisôka <wi-šoæ´-ga> brother (younger than myself). "This is the ordinary use of the kinship term for my younger brother. But the same term is used ceremonially when no blood relationship exists. One member of a tribe may address members of the other gentes of the same division with this term." wisôka owa hkihkie mì kçe o <wi-šoæ´-ga u-wa gi-Ði-e mi kshe o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] I spoke to my younger brother.  

wiçíkØe. N my sister's husband, my husband's brother (used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my brother-in-law') (RB; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod orig).  

wiçkítà (variants: wiçkíta, wiçkí). PRON [wíe + -çkítà, çki] me too, I too (02/24/95/FH/pc:okc). wiçkítà! 

me too! (BE2.85). wiçkí me too, I too (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 217: wíçki <wi´ -shki> I also. wíçkità <wi´ shki-doæ> I too, for my part.

••• KS wiçkédà (JOD) I too (RR).

wiëîðe (variants: wiëî, wiëîe). N my older brother (used only when speaker is male)

(01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). [When used in the extended sense outside the immediate family, this brother must only be older than the speaker and is not necessarily the eldest son of a family.] wiëîe âwahkà hkôbra I want older brother to help me (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod). wiëî, waaðô ðáalì çkáaãe hâàci older brother, you sang good last night (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).  

•• JOD (Raccoons and Crawfish p21 ln9): <Wi´¦ciæ¢e´>. [Historically it appears that when this word was used vocatively, its accent would shift to the first and third syllables.]

•• LFD 217: wiëîðe <wi-zhiæ´-the> my elder brother, my brother older than myself.  

wiëîke. N my son (any of my sons, including a first son; in this meaning, used regardless of whether speaker is male or female); my brother's son (used only when speaker is male; more precise than English 'my nephew') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok); Sonny (as a nickname, used by either male or female speakers for a son or a friend). [Used also, perhaps more recently or only in certain dialects or families, by female speakers, as either 'my brother's son' or even 'my sister's son' (RB, CQc). Historically, it appears that when this word was used vocatively, its accent would shift to the first and third syllables (wíëìké).] wiëîke líi tà, húu hce éa when Sonny gets back here, have him come over here (03/13/95/FH/pc:ok).  

wiëîke iðáce. NP my husband (lit., 'my son's father') (used to speak about or address one's husband if the first child is a boy).  

wiëîke iihô. NP my wife (lit., 'my son's mother') (used to speak about or to one's wife if the first child is a boy) (RBn12-12; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok).  

wiëôà. N my older sister (i.e., older than the speaker; used only when speaker is female) (BE2.122; HH/pc, 03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok).  

wiëôke. N my daughter (used when speaker is male or female); my brother's daughter (used only when speaker is male; more precise than English 'my niece'); my sister's daughter (used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my niece') (BE2.29).

•• RB: <wi-shóæ-keh, wi-zhóæ-keh>.  

wiëôke iihô. NP my wife (lit., 'my daughter's mother') (when the oldest child of the husband and wife is a girl, this is what a man calls his wife [RB]) (03/16/95/MREI/pc:okc).  

wì. ADJ, PRON a, an, one, single, anyone. wakØó wì achípe a woman came (FH/pc:ok). hòpái wacúe skúe wì hpáaãe I made a cake today (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). wî âðuwì ðáalì we ought to buy one (RBn1-44). wî nâhka álììpi tà, ílòòçka waachí nàpe when he carried anyone on his back, he would war-dance (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; HRE/12/29/01/pc). táatà wahóta wì something funny (lit., 'a funny thing') (3-383-p2). • one of a group. níhka wì akxa aðáape one of these men went. • (marker of sg. head within a relative clause). [Compare tóa.] waachí wì waëáëe apa húuëa ðée aðî apa Osages had this dance a long time (lit., 'this is the dance that for a long time Osages had it') (PM/7/7/94). hcí wî pçíe, pée ðìké no one was at the house I went to (lit., 'I went to a house, no one was there') (BE2.157). waxpéì àkái, ókØu àðúucØake çe nààhtàhtàà oðúucØake wî we're too poor to feed that lazy donkey (lit., 'we are poor, that donkey who is/was lazy, we can't/couldn't feed him') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). nihkáçi wì sitôì achípe haxî wì àkØúpe the man that came yesterday gave me a blanket. çîhtoëì wì iiðáðe hkóopçi apai the boy that I saw was running away (3-2-163). hôòe wì ahú apa ðakØéðie hta ðe nobody will be coming to take care of you (FH).

•• LFD 216: wì <wiæ> one, single. níhka wì <ni´-Ða wiæ> one man. wakØo wì <wa-Ð'o wiæ> one woman. LFD 219: xôcewì <Xoæ´-dse-wiæ> Cedar-woman (female personal name), refers to the cedar tree.

wì. N female, woman (used only in personal names for females). [Historically related to mîì, mîìka.] letô wì/letôwì Hawk Woman (personal name). [Frances Holding's name.]

wî (variant of wîxce).

wìcéki (variant: wìcéke). N my mother's brother (my maternal uncle; more precise than English 'my uncle') (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok). [Accent may change to wîceki in vocative use.]  

-wìãe (variant: -îãe). V ROOT turn, spin, whirl, around (as in drive around, turn around, etc.).

•• LFD 218: xúða apa káawìãe nàpe <xi-tha´ a-ba ga-wiæ-xe noæ bi a> the eagle soars [around] (CQc).

••• QU bakkówìãáãa push round and round (RR), kakóìãaãa go around and around (RR), kkówìãáãa turn round and round (RR); OP wìãe turn, spin, whirl.

••• Cf. ákiãe, hkilíihkòìãe, -hkóìãe, hòòpé okáwìãe, okáwìãe, opáwìãe.  

wîhkikçe. V [reg., wî_hkikçe] [hkik- REFL + wîkçe] (intr.) be true to oneself. wîhkikça! be true to yourself!  

wììðé. N that unique thing, that single item or event. • ADV this particular way, solely or uniquely so. wììðé níhkaçie môpçewaa hpíò apa this particular way our people's forefathers knew it (HREsr-1965 ilôòçka-line 2).

wîkçe. V [reg., wî_kçe] (intr.) speak the truth, tell the truth. wîakçe I speak the truth

(04/03/95/PM/pc:ok). wîðakçe you speak the truth (04/03/95/PM/pc:ok). wîðakçe? are you telling the truth? (04/03/95/PM/pc:okt). wîkçe akxá he/she is telling the truth (04/03/95/PM/pc:okt; BE2.145). wîkçe akxai he's telling the truth (RBn12-11). • (trans.) be true to. wîàðakçe hta ðàìçé? will you be true to me? (04/03/95/PM/pc:okt). • ADJ true. wîkçe ëóàðále hta ðáaçe? will you be true with me? (04/03/95/PM/pc:ok). • N truth. wîkçe oðáaka! tell the truth! (04/03/95/PM/pc:ok). wîkçe owíbraake mìkçé I'm telling you the truth. • INTERJ golly! gosh! (female exclamation of surprise) [As an exclamation, wîkçe is not vulgar and is not a statement about truth or question about truth.] wîìkçé! golly! (RBn2-MOJ/p5; 04/06/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 216: wîhke <wiæ´-ke> [expected Mod. Os. form wîkçe] truth, sincere, genuine, sincerity, sure. wiáhke <wiæ-a´-ke> [expected Mod. Os. form: wîakçe] I speak the truth. wì hkaëi <wiæ Ðazhi> [expected Mod. Os. form wîkçaëi] he speaks not the truth.

••• Cf. wawîkçe, wîhkikçe. 

wînà (variant of wínà).

wîxce (variants: wîxci, wî). ADJ, N one, a, an (BE2.98). hôòpa wîxci nâçki níhkaçi aní hkôbra (lit., 'one day at a time only, as a person, I want to live') I want to live one day at a time (RBn10-21).

•• RB: <wíæ-xtsi>.

•• LFD 217: wîxci <wiæ´-xtsi> one of a kind, a single piece. wîxci hkôbra <wiæ´-xtsi Ðoæ-btha> I want one (03/02/95/FH/pc:ok).  

xáða ADV back, backward, in reverse, retrograde (JS). xáða màðî step backward.

•• LFD 218: xáða màðì <xa´-tha moæ-thiæ> the act of stepping backward. xáða màbrì <xa´-tha moæ-bthiæ> I walk backward. xaðámàscì <xa-tha´-moæ-stsiæ> you walk backward, the act of stepping backward. xaðalé <xa-tha-gthe´> retrograde, to appear to move backward. xáðe <xa´the> backward.

••• OP xáða back.

xáhtape. ADJ dry grass, dried grass (unconfirmed).

•• JOD (slip file): xáhtape <qa´-ta-§pe> dried grass.

xáka. ADJ rough, prickly. ðéeze xáka thorny tongue (03/23/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• JOD (slip file): xáka <qa´-ka> rough, as a tongue.

•• LFD 217: xáka <xa´-ga> bristling, rough in appearance.

••• Cf. ãáãaka, waxáka. 

xáxa (variant: xâxà). ADJ [reduplicated form?] ruffled, ruffly, having leaves or leaflike layers (FH).

••• Cf. hceeníxaxa, waxáka. 

xâxà. ADJ [reduplicated form?] shiny (RBn22-04).

•• LFD 219: xàxâmàì <Xoæ-xoæ ´ -moæ-iæ> Shines-as-he-moves (personal name), refers to the reflection of the sun on the outspreading [sic] of the eagle.

xci (variant: xcì). ADJ, ADV real, really, exactly, very, fully, indeed, precisely (MREI). ëâàxeëì ðuuzái cØéða xci take a stick and really kill someone (FH:prod). waëáëe xci brîe I'm a real Osage. kasîexcì mîì àtôpe htái let's go see the morning sun coming up (as in a peyote meeting) (BE2.129; 01/14/95/FH/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): xci <qtsi> adv. very, real, used only in composition. xúða-xci <qu¢a-qtsi> real eagle.

xée. V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) roar, patter. niëu xée wálì the rain patters very much.

•• JOD (slip file): xe <qe> v. to roar, as running water, to patter, as rain.

xéka. V, ADJ dead (from drying up; e.g., a vegetable), dried.

••• Cf. nààãúce xéka. 

xémàke. N dew, frost (BE2.30; 01/20/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 218: xémàke <xe´-moæ-ge> frost, hoarfrost.

xépe (variant: ãépe?). ADJ shallow. [Possibly related to hépe 'small amount'.]  

•• LFD 218: ãépe or xépe <xe´-be> shallow, not deep (unconfirmed).

••• OP ãébe shallow.

-xi. V ROOT (intr.) wake, awaken.

••• Cf. ðixí, nààxí. 

xíatò. N [xúða + tôpe] name for an eldest daughter (hcíëo clan) (lit., 'looking at the eagle') (HRE/pc/2002).

xíða. V [reg.+sync. _xí_ða] (intr.) fall, stumble, fall down, stumble and fall; euphemism for 'die', pass away; topple (as a tree topples). [It is not clear whether xíða is related to xîna 'hurry', even though xîna has variants such as xîða and xíða.] xíðape he died (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). xíða akxa he fell down (RBn10-18). hóni axíbra I almost fell (FH:4/18/96/okc). màðí çô apa, xíðape while he was walking, he fell down/he died (04/26/95/LS/pc: identical fall down/die). axíbra I fell down (04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). axíbra tà if I fell down (04/26/95/LS/pc). íinòòhpa, ðaxíçta hta akxai be careful, you might fall (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.43). maçcî íðakØuce àëi ðaxíða you tried to walk but you fell down.

•• LFD 218: xíða <xi´-tha> to fall; to topple. axíbra <axi´-btha> I fall. àxíða pe <oæ-xi´-tha i> we fall. ëà akxa xiða txa txa iche eci ahi akxa ha <zhoæ a-ka xi-tha ta ta i-tse e-dsi a-hi a-ka ha> [expected Mod. Os. form: ëâà akxa xíða che ecí ahí akxa; sentence-final ha is not used in Mod. Os.] the tree is ready to topple.  

••• Cf. xíxiða. 

xíða. N eagle. [Archaic variant of xúða.]

xíða (variant of xîna).

xíðaxa (variant: xíðaha). N breechcloth, loincloth, diaper (FH),

•• JOD (slip file): xíðaaxáðe <qi´-¢a-a-qa´-¢ªe> a breech-cloth.

xína (variant of xîna).

xíxiða. V [reg.+sync., _xíxi_ða] [reduplicated form of xíða 'fall, stumble'] (intr.) stumble repeatedly, go stumbling along. cØáiëì akxa xíxiða akxái the old man is stumbling (RBnot 5/3/79/3; FH:okc).  

xî (variant of ãì).

xîna (variants: xína, xíða, xîða). ADJ, V [presumed reg., _xîna] (intr.) go fast. • ADV hurriedly. [Adverbial meaning 'hurriedly' is typically associated with the pronunciation xîða, and vice versa.]

•• RB: <xí-nah> or <xí-thah> (04/25/95/PM/pc: xíða káaãe 'hurry it up' plain í, not î).

•• LFD 218: xîðaða <xiæ´-tha-tha> to hurry, make haste, to hie. xîðaða bre <xiæ´-tha-tha bthe> [expected Mod. Os. form: xîða brée] I hurry [rather, 'I go making haste']. xîðaða sce <xiæ´-tha-tha stse> [expected Mod. Os. form: xîða çcée] you hurry [rather, 'you go making haste']. xîðaða àkaða pe <xiæ´-tha-tha oæ-ga-tha i> [expected Mod. Os. form: xîða àkaðape] we hurry [rather, 'we go making haste'].

xîna káaãe (variant: xîða káaãe). VP [sync. k>p, xîna _káaãe] (trans.) make s.t. go faster, hurry s.t. up, step s.t. up (as in 'hit drum faster', 'hit it faster') (04/25/95/PM/pc:ok: xínà; RBn10-5:MOJ/79; HH/t9b-p1; BE2.45).

xóce (variant: xóe). ADJ gray, dull (color or finish), faded, grayish like ashes, smoky (BE2.61; 02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; FH/09/21/01/pc). hkáwa xóce gray horse, the town of Grayhorse (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): xóce <qu´-§t§se> n. and adj. gray.

•• LFD 219: xóce <xo´-dse> gray, a gray line. hkáwa xoce <Ða´-wa xo-dse> gray horse. LFD 159: hceehéxoce <¾se-he´-xo-dse> a young buffalo with gray horns; one whose horns are not yet turned black with age.

••• Cf. páxoce, çóce. 

xoé (variant of xowí).

xóhka. V [reg., _xóhka] (intr.) sing dancing songs. • N singers and drummers (FH:4/22/96/tape); all singers of dancing songs (RB; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc). xóhka nàkxâçe all you singers (RB; 03/09/95/MREI/pc:okc).

•• JOD (slip file): xóhka <qu´-ka> to sing dancing songs.

••• QU xókka sing dancing songs (RR).  

xóhtà. ADJ small, little, fine (e.g., fine raindrops). níiëuxóhtà fine rain, mist (FH/pc).

••• QU niëíxohtá mist, drizzle (N) (RR).

••• Cf. hpéëe xóhtà. 

xoî (variant of ãoî).  

xóoka. N badger.

•• JOD (slip file): xóka <qu´-§ka> a badger.

••• KS xôòga ~ xóoga badger (RR); QU xóka ground hog, 'badger' in several other languages (RR).

xópe. ADJ sacred, consecrated, holy. màhká xópe sacred medicine, peyote, as used in a peyote meeting (RB).

•• LFD 221: xópe <xu´be> holy, supernatural power; sanctity.  

••• Cf. áxope, ðixópe, waxópe. 

xowí (variant: xoé). V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) growl, roar, sigh, rumble, resound. hcéze xowí akxai my stomach is growling (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 219: xoé <xo-e´> to roar, as the wind or the waterfall, to sigh, to sough, as the wind.

xô. ADJ, V [reg., _xô] (intr.) break, (be) broken. oðíhtà akxa xôpe the car broke, the car is broken. nâàce xò broken heart. ëékaxô akxai his leg is broken (FH). ëékaxô mìkçé my leg is broken (FH). môò xô broken arrow (RBn10-6:JW). xôpe it broke (MSB 2-24-83). ðâàce xô a broken heart. mâà xô a broken arrow (MSB 2-24-83). • (be) broke, without money or penniless (a loan translation). axô àtxâhe I'm broke [I'm standing] (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok: aãô). áxò mìkçe I'm broke [I'm sitting] (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok: ã; BE2.12). ðáxò nìkçé? are you broke?

•• LFD 219 xò <xoæ> to break; just a simple break. [LF erroneously lists bríxò <bthi´-xoæ> 'I break (s.t.)' and àðíxòpe <oæ-thi´-xoæ i> 'we break (s.t.)' as if they were forms of this verb; actually they are forms of ðiixô 'break (s.t.) by hand'.]

xôòce. N cedar (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod;PM:ok). wahkôta iëîke iihô hpaxîì ìkçe xôòce íkòce káaãi apai they're making the cedar like Mary's hair (FH).

•• RB: <xo-tséh>.

•• JOD (slip file): xôce hu <qªuæ´- ¦t¦sªe hú> a cedar tree.

•• LFD 219: xôce <xoæ´-dse> the red cedar. "Used as a symbol among the Osage, found in ritual." xôce hi <xoæ´dse hi> the cedar tree. xôce hi <Xoæ´-dse hi> Cedar Hills. xôce omàì <Xoæ´dse u-moæ-iæ> Dwell-among-the-cedars (personal name). "Refers to the thunder and lightning which are supposed to live among the cedars. There is also another meaning to this word, which is Walksamong-the-cedars, a personal name; refers to the habit of the bears." xôcewì <Xoæ´-dse-wiæ> Cedar-woman (female personal name), refers to the cedar tree.

••• KS xôýe the red cedar (RR); QU xòhté cedar wood (RR).

••• Cf. xòòcóðibra. 

xôòce mâì. N Walks among the Cedars (personal name that refers to thunder and lightning). [The Bear

Dwells among the Cedars, name of Henry Pratt, Jr. (02/22/95/FH/pc).] xòòcéhu. N [xôòce + hú 'trunk'] cedar tree.

xòòcéhu káaãe hôòpa. N Christmas (lit. 'cedar tree preparation day') (RBn10-18, unconfirmed).

xòòcénii. N [xôòce + níi] cedar tea (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.18). [Used in a sweathouse before a peyote meeting to induce vomiting for cleansing, a custom said to be learned by watching bears

(RB).]

xòòcóðibra. V [conjug. unknown] [xôòce + oðíbrà] smoke cedar (cause cedar to smoke), smell cedar, smoke a house with cedar or use in a peyote meeting to smoke a person (BE2.18).

xpéka (variant: çpéka [PM]). V, ADJ [stat., _xpéka] (be) dull (MSB/pc), not shiny (MSB/pc; RBn105:MOJ/79; BE2.37; PM:uk); languid or "blah" feeling one gets in winter.

•• LFD 219: xpéka <xpe´-ga> languid. àxpéka <oæ-xpe´-ga> I am languid. ðixpéka <thi-xpe´ga> you are languid, drooping.

xpi. N flatulence, fart. • V [conjug. unknown] (intr.) expel gas from the body.

xtoe. V, ADJ [stat.?, _xtoe?] (intr.) (be) snotty, filled with mucus. ðíxtoe! you're snotty! (RB, unconfirmed).

•• LFD 221: xtò <xtoæ> to spill, to slop over.

••• Cf. hpahlíxtoe. 

xúða. N eagle. xúða akxa ãaakí akxái the eagle is crying (01/14/95/FH/pc).

•• JOD (slip file): xúða léëe <qü-¢á k¢e-§ce> the spotted eagle, same as hâka ôpe léëe 'spotted tail eagle'. xúða hpasà <qü-¢á pašaæ>the eagle with a whitish head, the bald eagle, a sub-gens of the hcíëo waçtáke. xúða wáðalò ëìké <§qü-¢á wa´-§¢a-§k¢ªuæ ¢iñ-§ke´>an eagle that differs from the hâka òpe léëe; its tail is about six inches long with black feathers, the rest of the feathers are white, the toes are yellow, no feathers on lower legs (CQ paraphrase of JOD gloss).  

•• LFD 221: xuðá <xu-tha´> eagle, the adult golden eagle. xuðá ekò ëìka <xu-tha; e-goæ; zhiæga> resembles a young eagle. LFD 218: xiða <xi-tha> [pronunciation unacceptable to Mod. Os. speakers, should be xúða or xuðá] eagle. xiðá apa kawìxe nà pi a <xi-tha´ a-ba ga-wiæ-xe noæ bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form xúða apa káawìãe nà pe] the eagle soars. xiðá ðìkçe ahì che ðixòpi a <xitha´ thiæ-ke a-hiæ te thi-xoæ bi a> [expected Mod. Os. form: xúða ìkçe áahu che ðiixôpe] the eagle's wings are broken.

••• Cf. xíða 'eagle'.

xuðáchewì. N [xúða + che (?) + wì] Eagle Woman (personal name). [Yvonne Lookout's name.]

xúðalâke. N [xúða + oolâke] eagle headdress.

•• JOD (slip file): <qü-¢a´ §k¢añ-Ðªe> a headdress made of entire eagles.

xúðawì. N [xúða + wì] Eagle Woman (personal name). [Anita Lookout's name.]

xuðáëuuce. N [xúða + ëúuce] Red Eagle (name for first boy in hcíëo clan, used until he becomes a teenager) (FH).

•• JOD (slip file): xuðá ëuuce <xü-¢á §cªu´§t§se> a red eagle, the name of the hcíëo waçtáke gens.

xuðókaçà. N [xúða + okáçà] Take Care of the Eagle (personal name) (RBn22-04).

•• JOD (slip file): xuðókaçà <qü-¢u´-§ka-caæ´> name of gens or sub-gens, referent of aahu-okØoce <ahü-ukØoce>, a personal name.

xúe tôì. N [xúða + tôpe] Looking at the Eagle (personal name) (RB). [Jeanna Redeagle's name.]  

xúãa (variant of xúhaa?). ADJ skin.

xúhaa (variants: xuháa, xúha, xúãa?). N skin, hide, bark. xuháa ska white skin, white person.

•• RB: <xu-háh> (03/10/95/PM/pc:okc; BE2.122).

•• JOD (slip file): xúha <qu´-ha> skin of a person or animal.

•• LFD 218 (unconfirmed): xìha <xiæ-ha> skin of a human being or bark of a tree. xîha çape <xiæ´-ha sha-be> dark skin, swarthy. LFD 221: xúha <xu´-ha> the skin of a person or an animal.

••• Cf. háa. 

xuháaska. N [xúhaa + ská 'white'] white person, Caucasian. xuháaska brîe I'm a white person (FH:08/22/96:x, not ã). xuháaska apa táatà àkóhta oðówa[ðe] apai white people are running our business, bossing us (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.10).

•• JOD (slip file): xúha <qu´ha> the skin of a person or animal.

•• LFD 218: (unconfirmed): xìhá ska <xiæ-ha´ ška> white skin, the white race.

xúuða. ADJ wrinkled (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/24/95/PM/pc:ok;04/06/95/LS/pc). haaská xúuða your clothes are wrinkled (FH:prod). • ragged (PM only; PM/03/10/95/pc).

záani (variant: záanii). ADJ whole, all. kîì ékimà hta akxai, kóe môëò záani iiðáðe hta akxai if I could fly, then I could see the whole world (RBn15-02). ëìkáëì záani wéeðai? did you see all the children? (MSB; FH). hkâàce záani âðuwi hcé let's [two people] buy all the apples

(01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). súhka záani abráani I ate all the chicken (PM). niiôtà záani all the universe (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok, according to HH, who used to employ this expression). ìlôòçka záaní all the dance (the event participants; form of address when making a speech at the ilôòçka) (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). mâëà záani all the world (01/04/95/FH/pc:prod). • PRON all, every one, everyone, everybody. záani wanôbre hipi you all come over and eat (01/04/95/FH/pc: ok). záani wanôbre hípai you all be there to eat. záani aðîalaape they took all of it (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.2). hkáwa záani aðî apai all of them own the horse. Johna záani wéeðape? did John see all of us? (3-226). Johna apa záani wéeðapí apai John saw every one of us (3-2-274).

•• LFD 29: zani <ša-ni´> total, all.

zâà. N country, prairie (FH); timbers [not 'timbers' or 'woods' in Mod. Osage, possibly archaic?]. zààcé a valley with trees, a grove of trees (RBn19, unconfirmed).

zâàce. N prairie, country (i.e., rural area), countryside. hcíëì wì zààcíolìì akxai little house on the prairie (RBn22-08).

zààcéolìì (variants: zâàceolîì, zààcólìì) N Hominy district (lit., 'dwelling in the country' or 'dwelling on the prairie'; no reference to 'timber') (02/09/95/FH/pc:okc; FH/6/16/01); dwelling in the timbers (RB; BE2.67; unconfirmed). [Note that sources disagree as to whether this term refers to 'timber'.] hcíëì wì zààcíolìì akxai little house on the prairie (lit., 'the little house that dwells on the prairie') (FH; RBn22-08).

•• RB: <sáhæ-so-liæ, sahæ-tsí-o-liæ, sahæ-tséh-o-líæa>  

•• JOD (slip file): zàcé <§san-§t§sªe´> a highland containing many trees. zàcolì <§san§t§su§k¢iæ> (cited as a source by JOD, see §<caæ-q¢u-k'u-pe>). zàcólì <San§t§suk¢iæ> dialect or subdialect [given as a dialect of Osage] (e.g., under <káwa> 'a horse').

•• LFD 32: zàceólì <šoæ-dseu´-gthiæ> Dwellers-in-the-upland-forest ['upland forest' unconfirmed by modern speakers]. "This was a name given to a group of Osage Indians who fled from their village at the time of an overflow of the river, and halted at the forest, there pitching their camp. This group now dwells in what is known as Hominy, Okla." zàceólì <Coæ-dse-u´-gthiæ> Dwellersin-upland-forests (personal name).

zâzi N sour odor, acrid smell (such as armpit odor or onion smell) (RB, unconfirmed).

zí. ADJ, N yellow (FH). kçôka çôke íhta apa zípe second son's dog is yellow (2-1-Fl; BE2.162; PM03/24/95/pc: zi only; RBn10-5:MOJ/79: zíhi only).

•• RB: <zí-hi>.

•• LFD 30: zi <ši> yellow. zíhi <ši´-hi> pallor, an unhealthy color (03/24/95/PM/pc:ma). zízie <ši´-ši-e> spotted with yellow, a ritual term (unconfirmed; 03/24/95/PM/pc:uk). LFD 89: hkâce hìscee che zi akxa cuuce akxa <Ðoæ´-dse hiæ stse-e tse ši a-ka dsu-dse a-ko> the peach is mellow [expected Mod. Os. gloss: 'these peaches are yellow, they're ripe'] (03/07/95/PM/pc:ok for 'ripe').

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 30).

••• Cf. zíhi.

zí ëuuce ékò. ADJP orange (lit., 'yellow that is redlike') (BE2.99; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok/ma).

zíhi. ADJ, N brown (05/01/95/LS/pc:brown only, also zi, no distinction); yellow (FH, same as zi). [For the meaning 'yellow', some speakers use both zí and zíhi, while other speakers prefer one form or the other.]

••• Cf. ëíhi. 

zízi. ADJ, N [reduplicated form of zí] brown (03/24/95/PM/pc/prod, unconfirmed; 05/01/95/LS/pc:uk).

ëaamí (variant of áëamì).

ëaaníe, ëaaníi (variants of ëààníi).

ëáhke. N jack (in a deck of cards) (LF; 04/14/95/FH/pc:uk). [Borrowed from English.]

•• LFD 285: ëáhke <zha´-Ðe> jack (playing card).

ëáhta. ADJ divided, forked, notched, branded, split, cut, sliced (04/20/95/LS/pc:prod). ôpe ëáhta bird's tail divided, scissortail flycatcher (BE2.117; 04/20/95/LS/pc:ok).

•• LFD 222: ëáhta <zha´-¾a> cloven, parted, as the foot of a deer, buffalo, or cow.

••• Cf. íhaa ëáhta, ôpeëahta, paëáëaki.

ëamí, ëamî, ëámì (variant of áëamì).

ëápe. N beaver (RB).  

•• JOD (slip file): ëápe <¦ca´-¦pe> a beaver.

•• LFD 221: ëápe <zha´-be> the beaver (04/07/95/PM/pc:no). "This animal figures prominently in Osage tribal rites." ëápe toka <zha´-be do-ga> the male beaver.

ëápuçka. N ant (BE2.3; 01/04/95/FH/pc:prod).

•• LFD 222: ëápuska <zha´-biu-ška> an ant. "In the war rites the ant represents the weapons of the warriors." ëápuska sape <zha´-biu-ška ša-be> black ant. ëápuska zi <zha´-biu-ška ši> yellow ant. ëápuska ëúuce <zha´-biu-ška zhu-dse> red ant.

ëáëe (variant: ëáëi). N name; signature (HRE; 02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). [Males have a childhood name and an adult name, while girls keep their name all life long (HRE); all these are denoted by ëaëé.] táata ëáëe açcîe? what is your name? (lit., 'what name do you have?') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). táatà ëáëe aðîe? what is his name? (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). ììçtáxì ëáëe táatà açcîe? what is your English name? (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). tówa níhka ìkçé táatà ëáëe aðíe? what is that man's name? Bob ëáëi abrîe my name is Bob (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.92). Mary ëáëe aðîpe her name is Mary (RBn12-08). çîtoëì wíhta ëáëe ðakØú hkôbra I want you to give my boy a name (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). ëîkáëì ëáëe child's name (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). nôò ëáëe adult name (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77;

02/27/95/FH/pc:ok). ëáëe kØú give an Indian name (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok)  

•• RB: <zháh-zhi>.

•• LFD 222: ëáëe akØòhe <zha´-zhe a-Ð'oæ-he> to sign name, a signature (02/27/95/FH/pc:okc). ëáëe kçihtò wikie <Zha´-zhe Ki-¾oæ Wi-gi-e> [expected Mod. Os. form: ëáëe kØú wíkie] prayer for name taking (02/27/95/FH/pc:uk). ëaëe kØu <zha-zhe Ð'i> to dub.

ëáëe kikáaãe. VP [reg. ki-del.?, ëáëe _(ki)káaãe?] [ëáëe + ki- DAT + káaãe] (intr.) sign (as a document), subscribe, undersign, affix one's signature (lit., 'produce one's name for others') (05/02/95/LS/pc:prod, non-preasp; HRE/12/29/01/ok).

ëáëe wahóta. N nickname; name used to make fun of s.o. (lit., 'funny name') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 222: ëáëe wahota <zha´-zhe wa-ho-da> nickname.

ëáëe wéleze. N signature. ëáëe wéleze káaãe sign it (lit., 'make the name with a pen') (HRE/12/29/01/pc:ok).

ëáëi (variant of ëáëe).

ëáØaëi (variant of aëáëì).

ëâà. N tree, log, wood, lumber (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok); stick, pole; woods, forest (03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok). ëâà kçe âàhòò I like that tree [lying down]. çe ëâàëì akxa ohtáza akxai that little tree is pretty. ëâà ìkçe çí tà hkilísàða when you get to that particular tree that stands there, turn. ëâà íichìpe he was hit with a stick (lit., 'they hit him with a stick') (FH: prod).  

ëâà. V [reg., _ëâà] (intr.) sleep, go to sleep, lie down to sleep, go to bed; sleep over, stay all night (RBn10-5:MOJ/79). ëâà kçi áape that person's lying down, they said (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod orig). ëâà kçe they're lying down (BE2.76). ëâà kçe the one sleeping over there (03/24/95/PM/pc). çkâëi ëâà lie still (RBn23-15). çôke akxa hci ápetxa ëâà nàpé those dogs just lie around the house. wáli níhka kôða, íhpiiëi akxai, àëâà htai she really wants a man, she's bad off, let's have her stay all night (lit., '. . . let's all go to sleep'). ðaëâà hta paaçe? are you all going to sleep? ðaëâà hta nìkçé are you [sg.] going to sleep here? ðaëâà hta paaçé? are you [pl.] going to sleep here? [implying staying over, sleeping all night] are you going to stay all night (lit., 'are you going to go to sleep?') (RBn1021/JW&FW/77). N sleep, night's rest, overnight stay. ðáabri ëâà tà in three sleeps hereafter (FH:ok).

•• JOD (slip file): ëà <§caæ> to sleep, a sleep, a day.

•• LFD 224: ëà <zhoæ> to sleep. aëâ <a-zhoæ´> I sleep. ðaëâ <tha-zhoæ´> you sleep. àëo pe <oæ-zho' i> [LF's <oæ-zho'> is presumably an error for àëâ <oæ-zhoæ´>] we sleep. LFD 225:

ëâihe <zhoæ´-i-he> to sleep.

••• KS/QU ëà sleep (RR); WI nàà sleep, fall asleep, hanà I sleep, ranà you sleep (KM).

••• Cf. áëà, óëà. 

ëâà áace. N vine (lit., 'embraces the tree').

ëâà ákaastowe. N [ëâà + á- + kaa- + stówe] sleigh, sled.

ëâà háa. N outer bark of a tree.

•• LFD 233: ëâha <zhoæ´-ha> outer bark of a tree.

ëâà káahtahta. N woodpecker (lit., 'pecking on wood') (RBn HW13; FH:uk).

•• LFD 357: hpakátataãe <¼a-ga´-da-da-xe> downy woodpecker.

••• KS ppagádadaãe ppa ëåüýe red-headed woodpecker (RR).

••• Cf. htáhtaze. 

ëâà káxa. N tree branch, limb, tree branching out (FH).

ëâà kØa. N cottonwood (RBn HW13, unconfirmed FH:uk).

ëâà kØà. N root or roots (of a tree, bush, etc.).

•• JOD (slip file): ëâ kØà <§caæ´ k'ªaæ>.

ëâà olîì. VP [reg., ëâà o_lîì] (intr.) live in the woods, dwell in the forest.

ëâà pe. N trees growing in a nonrandom pattern. [Contrast ëâà ke 'trees growing in random pattern'.]

••• Cf. ëààpé. ëâà tái ìké. VP (intr.) talk in one's sleep (RBnot3/3/77; 05/02/95/LS/pc:ok; 03/15/95/PM/pc:uk; 03/16/95/JS/pc:uk). ëâà waxáka. N thorny tree. ëâà wéðaawa. N measuring stick, ruler, yardstick (05/02/95/LS/pc:prod). ëâàhcuke. N [ëâà + hcúke] wooden spoon.

ëààhcúkØa. N [ëâà + hcúkØa] punk, tinder, fine kindling (dried decayed wood used for tinder to strike a flint fire [RB]).

•• RB: <zháhæ-tsu-kahæ> (04/18/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.108).

•• LFD 227: ëâhcikØa <zhoæ´-¾si-Ð'a> decayed-wood, punk, touchwood.

ëâàhkoke (variants: ëâàhkoe, ëâàhkoa). N box, coffer, trunk; thousand.

ëâàhlaa, ëâàhlaaská (variants of ëâàlaa).

ëâàhpaãe. N bat (the flying mammal) (RB; HRE/12/29/01/pc:okc).

ëààhpáto. N beaver (BE2.7; RBn1-24).

•• RB: <zhuhæ-páh-to>.

••• Cf. ëápe. 

ëâàhpeece. N [ëâà + hpéece] fire-making wood (piece of wood laid on ground and rubbed to make fire).

•• JOD (slip file): ëâ hpece <§caæ´ §pe -§t§se>.

ëâàkaaxô. N [ëâà + kaaxô] branch or limb that has been broken off a tree; bridge.

•• LFD 225: ëâkaxò <zhoæ´-ga-xoæ> a bridge. "This word originated from the fact that streams were frequently crossed by using fallen trees that had been blown down into the streams by the wind."

ëâàlaa (variants: ëâàhlaaská, ëâàhlaa, ëààláa). N [ëâà + laaská] blossom or flower on a tree.

ëààníe wapeî huukôða óoëu (variant: ëààníe wapî huukôða óoëu). N, VP [uninfl.] (intr.) (suffer from) diabetes, (have a) high blood glucose level (lit., 'put a lot of sugar in your blood'). ëààníe wapî huukôða óoëu ékò ðaìçé tà, ëààníeëì ðaaché íëoçi apai if you have sugar in your blood/diabetes, they said don't eat candy (FH:4/18/96/tape:prod).

ëààníeëì. N [ëààníi + -ëì 'little'] candy (lit., 'little sugar') (BE2:16; 01/09/95/FH/pc:prod).

ëààníi (variants: ëaaníe, ëaaníi). N [ëâà + níi] sugar (lit., 'tree water', originally referring to maple sap or syrup). paaçcéka ëaaníi áëu put some sugar on the strawberries (03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok, also ok: paaçcéka ëaaníi tóa áëu). paaçcéka ëaaníi áëu bríiçta I already put some sugar on the strawberries (03/14/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.129).

•• LFD 226: ëàní <zhoæ-ni´> sugar; candy. ëàni tópa àhkío <zhoæ-ni do´-ba oæ-Ði´-o>[expected Mod. Os. form: ëààníi tóa àkØú] give me some sugar. ëàni akxa waðasta <zhoæ-ni a-ka wa-tha-šta> [expected Mod. Os. form: ëààníi akxa waastá] the candy is sticky.

ëààníi níëòe. N syrup (DN-WHM, unconfirmed; FH:uk). [It is doubtful that this expression is a real Osage form.]

•• LFD 295: ëòní sápe <zhoæ-ni´ ša-be> molasses.

••• Contrast QU waëôke skíde kdókdo syrup, molasses (RR).

ëààníiooëu. N [ëààníi + ooëú] sugar bowl (MSB, 3-3-83-p4, 03/14/95/MREI/pc:ok).

ëâàpaase. N [ëâà + paasé] saw (for cutting wood).

ëààpé. N [possibly ëâà + ápe] leaf.

•• RB: <zhaæ-béh>, <zháhæ-ah-péh> (04/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.77).  

ëâàxe (variant: ëâàxa). N pole, stick (RBn10:21/JW). hóìze ëâàxe a fishing pole (RBn3-05; FH:prod). ëâàxe ànâchìpe he hit me with a stick. • baby board (FH: prod). ëâàxe wì aðìhú hta apai they're going to bring a board [for the baby] (FH:prod).

•• JOD (slip file): ëâxa <¦caæ´-qa> a stick, a pole.

•• LFD 227: ëâxa <zhoæ´-xa> a yardstick, a counting stick used in counting songs in a ceremony (unconfirmed; 05.02.95.LS.pc:uk).

ëâàxe céãenii. N drumstick (BE2.36; 01/20/95/PM/pc:ok).

••• Cf. céãenii ochî. 

ëâàxeëì. N [ëâàxe + -ëì 'little'] stick, branches, small limbs or twigs (of a tree or bush).

••• Cf. ëâàëì.

ëààxúhaa. N [ëâà + xúhaa] inner bark of a tree.

•• JOD (slip file): ëàxúha <§caæ-qü´-ha>.

ëâàëe. V [uninfl.]? (intr.) smell as spoiled food smells, have a stinking odor or a bad odor (e.g., underarm odor) (t109/PM/506; 01/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ëâàëe ðáìçe you smell bad.

ëâàëì. N [ëâà + -ëì 'little'] splinters (FH); small branches, small limbs or twigs (of a tree or bush).

ëâkçe. CONT continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 2nd sg. lying down subject. óëà oðáëà ëàkçé you're lying in bed (FH/pc). tàhé ëâkçe? are you well? (05/01/95/LS/pc:ok).

ëâkxa ëììhé. VP [reg., ëâkxa _ëîìhe] (intr.) sleep sitting up. ëâkxa ëìhé akxa he's sleeping sitting up (FH/06/16/01/pc). ëâkxa aëîìhe hta mìkçé I'm [going to be] sleeping sitting up (FH/06/16/01/pc).

ëâxta. N body odor, any soured odor (such as the smell of clothes, shoes, feet, or a refinery). hòòpé akxai ëâxta akxai the shoes smell bad (03/02/95/FH/pc). • V, ADJ [conjug. unknown] (intr.) smell unpleasantly sour, have a sour odor; stinky, sour-smelling.

•• RB: <zhúæ-xtah>.

ëé. V [reg., _ëé] (intr.) defecate, have a bowel movement; be excreted, ooze, be emitted. aëé hkôbra I want to shit (BE2.120;CQc: a not à, not stative). • (trans.) excrete, emit. • N penis, male organ. ëé wahtîe apái his penis is showing.

•• JOD (slip file): ëe <ce> to stool. ëé ðiçtà tà, pacØî-aú, ápi aú <§Ce´ ¢üctaæ´-§taæ, §páts'iæ-au´, á§pi au´> [expected Mod. Os. form: ëé ðiiçtá tà, pacØî, áape] When he (a child) finished stooling, he said, Turn bottom up!

••• OM same as Osage (LFD 81).

••• Cf. céëe, óochiëe, oëéhci, úëe. 

-ëé ADV [contraction of aëí NEG + ðe DECLARATIVE MARKER (extremely rare)] not, never. htáaëì akxa kîìkììeëì íiðaapiëé the little deer has never seen butterflies.

ëeká. N leg. iiséwai ëeká akxa ânàkØôëi akxái the thing hateful [i.e., 'hateful thing'] is that my legs won't listen to me (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; HRE:ok). ëékaxô akxai his legs are broken (FH). ëékaxô nìkçé your legs are broken [unexpected stress on first syllable may be due to reassignment of accent due to following accented xô] (FH).

•• LFD 222 (unconfirmed): ëeká <zhe-ga´> the upper part of the leg. ëekáole <zhe-ga´-u-gthe> the muscles and nerves around the thigh bone, the femoral circumflex.

••• Cf. ëekáxò. 

ëeká óhkiche. N knee joint.

•• LFD 222 (unconfirmed): ëeka óhkiche <zhe-ga u´-Ði-tse> knee joint.

ëékaxô. N [ëeká + xô] broken leg(s). ëekáxò letô N Crippled Hawk (personal name).

ëekáëìka. N [ëeká + ëìká] queen (in a deck of cards) (lit., 'little legs') (LF only).

•• LFD 222: ëekáëìka <zhe-ga´-zhiæ-ga> little legs. "This name was given by the Osage to the queen in a deck of cards. It is said that the picture of the queen on the old-style cards was in full figure with very small legs."

ëi (variant of aëí).

ëíhi (variant: ëí). ADJ, N brown (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; 05/01/95/LS/pc). haaská ëíhi ðíhta íiðahkie? did you find your brown dress [for yourself]? (BE2.13; RBn1-45; BE2.162).

•• LFD 222: ëíhi <zhi´-hi> reddish, pink. ëíhi htàka <zhi´-hi ¾oæ-ga> yellow-billed cuckoo.

••• Cf. zí, zíhi. 

ëiçô (variant: ëiiçô). PPN before. hâìnì ëiçô àkále we'll go home before dark (RBn10-7:JW). koe ónòò ëiçò çí tà çî tà koe hpíiëi ëiçò çí tà koe péeçki ðikôða htai wáçäuãe ðáalì before you get old and before you get fat and ugly and nobody wants you, you should get married (RB).

-ëì (variant: ëîka [archaic]). ADJ a little, small amount of s.t. wihtáeëì akxa ékipçe kôða akxa, hôòpa ðé wéeðina akxai, mâzeskaëì níðe kôða akxa [younger] sister wants me to say something, she's grateful today and wants to give away a little money (RBn23-17). • small, little. hkààcóolàëì a little pie (FH: not ëìka). kóe htáa htóhoëì wì pe once there was a little blue deer (RBn15-01). áëàëì cot, small bed. níhkaëì a little man, little men. níhkaëîka a little person, little men [níhkaëì is more common (FH)]. nihkaçikaëì little people (7/8/94/PM/num98b). • ADV really, very, indeed. wàkóiëì alí hta mìkçé I'll come right back [wàkôò + -ëì] (RBn3-21). wahókØaëì very young. áskaëìvery close [áçka + -ëì]. hcékaëì just now [hcéka + -ëì]. ëî. V [2nd sg. of î 'wear'] you wear.

ëîìhe (variants: ëîìha [PM], ëìhé, ëììhé, ëîìhi). V [reg., _ëîìhe] (intr.) sleep, slumber (02/15/95/FH/pc:ok).

aëîìhi, aëîìhe I sleep (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod). ðaëîìhe you sleep (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod). àëîìhe we sleep (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod). ëîìhe brúucØake aìhé I can't sleep (RBn22-08). ëîìhe ðáalì hpáaãe I slept well. ðóha aëîìhe I'm about asleep (MREI/04/27/94). ðóha ðaëîìhe nìkçé you're about asleep (MREI/04/27/94). ëîìhe ðáalì çkáaãe? did you sleep well? (03/10/95/MREI/pc:okc). ëîìhe ðáalì çkáaãapi? did you [pl.] sleep well? (03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok). ëîìhe akxái he/she is asleep (PM:ok; BE2.123). ðóha àëîìhe aðìkçe we [two] are about asleep (MREI/04/27/94). àëîìhe àðìkçé we [two] are sleeping (02/15/95/FH/pc). àëîìhe àkakxái we [pl.] are sleeping (02/15/95/FH/pc). ëîìha go to sleep! (03/10/95/MREI/pc:prod). ëììhápi go to sleep [pl. addressee]! (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn23-09; 03/10/95/PM/pc:ok).

•• LFD 225 (unconfirmed): ëâihe <zhoæ´-i-he> to sleep. LFD 224: ëîha o <zhiæ´-ha o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] lie down.

ëìká (variant: ëîka), ADJ, V [uninfl.] (be) little, small (7/8/94/PM/num98b; 02/16/95/FH/pc:ok). [A somewhat archaic variant of ëì. Use of ëìká instead of ëì sounds old-fashioned in most contexts (FH; 02/16/95/FH/pc; BE2.80).] • N child(ren), little one(s), kid(s) (BE2.19; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok). níi táahpa ìkçí ëìka nôòðe ðáalì, ecíe ska ààëî àkátxa the pond is a good place to raise children, we think it's there (from a fable) (RBn19-04).

•• RB: <zhíæ-kah>.

•• LFD 331: ëiæ-ga <ëìka>. LFD 222: ëìká <zhiæ-ga´> small, little children. "When used in the ritual its meaning is young, as reference is made to a sapling." ëìkáe <zhiæ-ga´-e> this term is found in a ritual, meaning little ones. LFD 224: ëìkáoxta <Zhiæ-ga´-o-xta> favored little ones, a title among the Osage. LFD 224 (unconfirmed): ëìkáhtà <zhiæ-ga´-¾oæ> to have children, to generate. ëìká ahtà <zhiæ-ga´ a-¾oæ> I have children. ëìká ðahtà <zhiæ-ga´ tha-¾oæ> you have children. ëìká àwàhtà pe <zhiæ-ga´ oæ-woæ-¾oæ i> we have children. [All these sentences with -htà are unconfirmed and are unrecognized by Mod. Os. speakers.]

••• Cf. ëìkáëì.

ëìká owáhkihà (variants: ëîka owáhkiha).

•• RB: <zhíæ-kah o-wah-kí-hahæ>.

•• LFD 224: ëìká owahkihà <zhiæ-ga´ u-wa-Ði-hoæ> grandchild; a descendant; to issue, to bring forth.

••• Cf. owáhkiha.

ëìkáëì (variant: ëìkáëi). N child(ren), little one(s), kid(s); childhood (RB; BE2.19; 01/19/95/FH/pc:ok). ëìkáëì nakxâçe wéewina akxâhe, ilôìhpa waachí çtôpape I want to thank you children for watching my son dance.

•• LFD 222: ëìká ëìka <zhiæ-ga´ zhiæ-ga> baby [now archaic]. ëìká ëìka wakilà pi o <zhiæ-ga´ zhiæ-ga wa-gi-gthoæ bi o> [sentence-final o is not used in Mod. Os.] he plans for the good of his children. LFD 217: ëìka ëìka wihta <zhiæ-ga zhiæ-ga wi-¾a> [expected Mod. Osage: ëìkáëì wíhta] my child.

ëìkókaçà (variant: ëìkókaça). V [reg., ëìkó_kaçà] [ëìkáëì + okáçà] (intr.) babysit, take care of kids (RBn10-6:JW). • N babysitting, childcare.

ëóhkile. V [reg., ëó_hkile] [hkik- RECIP + ëóle] (intr.) be with each other. ëóàhkile ðálì ëamíe I think we ought to get married [marry each other] (RBn17-p1). ëóhkile apái they are going with each other (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). ëóika (variant of ëúoka).

ëókile. V [reg. ki-ret., ëó_kile] [kik- SUU + ëóle] (trans.) be with one's own people. ëóðakile ðaìçé you are with him [your own].

ëóle. V [reg., ëó_le] (trans.) marry, accompany, go with, come with, date, be in a courtship with (lit., 'be with'). ëówile hkôbrai I want to marry you (RBn17-p01). ëówile hkôbrai ìké I don't want to marry you (RBn17-p01). ëówile I [am] with you. ëówile brée hce I'll just go with you (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). ëóawale brée hta mìkçé I'm going to go with them (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). lîì ëóàle sit with me (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). ëóðale ðachíe? did you come with her? (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). ëóðale ðaìçé? are you with him? are you going with him? (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). ëówaðale çíe? did you go with them? (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). ëówaðale çäee ðáalì you should go with them/us (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). ëówaðale çkôçta? do you want to go with us? (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok). ecí pa ëóàðale çíe ðe you brought me to them (lit., 'you went with me to them'). Eddie akxa ëóàle achíe I came with Eddie (lit., 'Eddie came with me') (02/01/95/FH/pc:okc). ëóle màðî go with her. ëówalape he went with them. ëówale màðî go with them. ëówale with us, with them. ëówalapi with us (FH). çkáce ëólaëi apai they won't play with them (2-10-83-p4). • PPN with (often glossed 'and' in English). súhka htaaníi wacúe ðubráaska ëóle hpáaãe I'm going to make chicken and dumplings (lit., 'I make chicken soup with dumplings') (BE2.9; FH:prod).

•• LFD 224: ëóle <zho´-gthe> to accompany, to go with some one. ëóale <zho´-a-gthe> I am with him, I accompany. ëóðale <zho´-tha-gthe> you accompany. ëóàla pe <zho´-oæ-gtha i> we accompany. LFD 228: ëóle <zhu´-gthe> with him or her. ëóale bre <zhu´-a-gthe bthe> I went with him. ëóðale sce <zhu´-tha-gthe stse> you went with him.

••• Cf. ëóhkile, ëókile. 

ëópçe. V [reg., ëó_pçe] (intr.) wade (JS, FH). níi ëópçe pçíe ðáha, táatà wì màëâ olîì iiðáðe when I would go to wade in the river, I saw something that was in the woods (lit., 'when I went to wade in the water, I saw a thing that lived in the countryside') (t24b-p17/num24CQ119; 04/27/95/FH/pc:okc, added iiðáðe). níi ëópçe hkôbra I want to wade in the water (04/27/95/FH/pc). hâàce wáli nuuëúpe ska, ëìkáëi apa hôpái nii ëópçi apái last night it must have rained a lot, the children today are wading (01/24/95/FH/pc:ok).

•• LFD 228: ëópçe <zhu´-pshe> to wade, as in the water. ëóapçe <zhu´-a-pshe> I wade. ëoðápçe <zhu-tha´-pshe> you wade.  

ëówale. V [reg., ëówa_le] [wa- VAL + ëóle] (intr.) be with folks.

•• LFD 228: ëówale <zhu´-wa-gthe> to be with [rather, 'to be with them']. ëoáwale brée <zhua´-wa-gthe bthe> I am with them [rather, 'I went with them']. ëówaðale scée <zhu´-wa-tha-gthe stse> you are with them [rather, 'you went with them'].

••• Cf. ëóhkile, ëókile.

ëô. V [2nd sg. form of ô 'do'] you do (rare usage).

ëôe, ëôè (variants of ëôò).

ëòhpáleze (variants: ëôhpaze, ëôhpoize). N [probably contains hpá 'head' + léze 'striped'] quail, stripeheaded quail, bobwhite (FH:4/24/96/tape,ma; 04/20/95/LS/pc). ëôhpázi mònoì océ pçíe I went to look for quail and prairie chicken (BE2.110; RBn3-11; RBn3-MOJ/p1).

•• RB: <zhóæ-páh-zeh> quail.

•• LFD 134: çôhpaleze <shóæ-¼a-gthe-še> quail, bobwhite, striped headed. "This word in modern times is spelled shoæ´ -¼a-'the-še." ëôò (variants: ëôe, ëôè). V [2nd sg. form of ôò 'wear'] you wear. ëúe (variant of ëúuce).  

ëúoka (variant: ëóika). N human body (01/07/95/FH/pc:ok). ëúoka ahkílazo mìkçé my body is recovering, my body is healing (01/07/95/FH/pc:prod, no nasal; BE2.9). mâhka ëóika mâì akxai, kitâhe hta akxa hôòpa hu he's haywire with peyote [medicine is moving in his body], but he'll be all right at daylight (01/06/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.102; RBn HW). hpéeceníi akxa ëúoka ðíðuuhpíiëi hta akxai whiskey is bad for your health (lit., 'whiskey will make your body bad') (JS).

•• LFD 224: ëóika <zho´-i-ga> their bodies, ceremonial ritual term. LFD 228: ëóika <zhu´-iga> body, flesh. ëóika làðe <zhu´-i-ga gthoæ-the> large-body, stocky. ëóika nie <zhu´-ga ni-e> ache, pain in any part of the body. ëóika anie <zhu´-i-ga a-ni-e> I have a pain. ëóika ðinie <zhu´-iga thi-ni-e> you have a pain. LFD 228 (unconfirmed): ëo <zhu> flesh, or body.

ëúuce (variants: ëúe, ëúu). ADJ, V [uninfl.] (intr.) (be) red (FHt128). ákahamì ëúuce ðée, pée ðuuçtáke hta ðe? who is going to undress that one with the red coat? (spoken at the ceremony of paying for the drum, where a woman's red wedding coat is being given to the former drumkeeper). ëúuce, ska kaðô htóho red, white, and blue. htaaníi ëúe tóe káaãa make vegetable soup (RBn12-06, unconfirmed).

••• Cf. hkâàce ëúe. 

ëúuce sápe. ADJP, N purple, burgundy (lit., 'black [i.e., dark] red').

••• Cf. htóho sápe.
